HEADLINE: Trade Gap Is Lowest In 5 Years

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit dropped sharply in September to $7.94 billion, its lowest level since late 1984, the Commerce Department reported today.
Both aspects of the gap showed improvement, with exports climbing 1.9 percent and imports tumbling 3.9 percent from the record August level.
But while the September deficit was considerably lower than most analysts expected, the report inspired little enthusiasm in the financial markets, and even the Bush Administration warned that the figures may not be as good as they seem.
 
An Official Urges Caution
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said yesterday that he had considered a sharp increase in the deficit in August ''an aberration'' and that the even bigger move downward in September ''must also be viewed cautiously.'' 
One reason for the lack of enthusiasm was the fact that the rise in exports was entirely the result of a jump in aircraft sales, mostly to Western Europe. Because of a strike that began at the Boeing Company in early October, aircraft exports are expected to fall sharply in coming months.
As for imports, their decline did indeed help lower the trade deficit but it also seemed to be further evidence that the American consumer is cutting back on spending. Consumers, who account for two-thirds of business activity, had been the main engine for economic growth in the first half of the year, but sales of cars and some other items have lagged of late.
 
Some Optimism
Even with all those qualifications and the widely shared skepticism about the reliability of the trade data, many analysts said the latest figures provided reasons for some optimism.
''I think basically the story is pretty good for the domestic economy,'' said Michael P. Niemira, an economist for Mitsubishi Bank in New York. He cited a firm export pace - some 13 percent higher last month than in September 1988 - and his own surveys of airports and seaports showing expectations of further export gains.
Scott M. Hoyt, assistant economist at the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, called the export sector ''encouraging,'' adding that it suggests ''the increases in the dollar aren't taking too much of a toll.'' A stronger dollar makes American exports more expensive and less competitive abroad.
The dollar, which rose above 2 West German marks and above 150 yen during the summer, has since eased, but remains strong. It is about 4 percent higher against the mark since the beginning of the year and about 15 percent higher against the yen.
In general, economists regard the export side of the equation as a better indicator of the nation's economic performance. Export business means jobs, production and incomes, while imports - though they help raise living standards and provide employment in distribution - mean the production benefits accrue elsewhere.
Today's report showed September exports rose $500 million, to $31.1 billion, just shy of the record $31.3 billion set in June. This included a $1.3 billion increase in capital goods, like industrial machinery, and a $400 million decline in vehicles, parts and engines. The United States exported $2 billion of airplanes, according to figures that are not adjusted for seasonal variation, up from $1.1 billion in August.
 
Decline in Imported Oil
Among imports, industrial supplies and materials fell $900 million and capital goods fell $700 million after surging in August. The nation's bill for imported oil eased $300 million, to $4 billion, but still accounted for more than half of the total deficit. A 23-million-barrel decline in the volume of petroleum imports was partly offset by a 24-cent rise in the average price of a barrel.
The trade gap was about $1 billion narrower than analysts had expected, making it the smallest since a $6.79 billion deficit in December 1984.
The August deficit, meanwhile, which initially had been reported at $10.8 billion, was revised today to $10.1 billion, which is tied with the May figure as the worst of the year. All but about $100 million of the August change was because of a lower import level.
For the first nine months of this year, the deficit is a seasonally adjusted $80.42 billion, compared with $87.94 billion in the 1988 period.
 
Deficit With Japan Rises
The American deficit with Japan edged up about $100 million, to $4.1 billion, but there was a big swing into surplus with Western Europe, a heavy September buyer of aircraft. The United States sold $1.2 billion more goods to Western Europe than it bought during the month, while in August it had a $700 million trade deficit.
The deficit narrowed about $100 million each with Taiwan, South Korea and Hong Kong and dropped by about one-third, to $700 million, with Canada, the nation's biggest trading partner.
Without adjusting for seasonal variation, the September deficit was $8 billion, down from $10.9 billion in August and $10.7 billion in July, today's report showed.

HEADLINE: Texas Air In 40-Plane Airbus Order

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
The Texas Air Corporation, placing its largest order ever for its Continental Airlines subsidiary, said yesterday that it had ordered 40 aircraft worth about $4.5 billion from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium.
The order was an indication that Airbus is making inroads in the United States market after a shaky start.
The medium- and long-range A330 and A340 jets, which are still being developed by Airbus, will enable Continental to replace some aging planes and expand its international service, particularly in the Pacific, the fastest-growing market, said Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Texas Air. Earlier this month the United States and Japan signed an agreement that paves the way for more flights to and from Japan. 
 
Order Backlog at Makers
As airlines rush to expand service and modernize their fleets, a backlog of orders stretching into the mid-1990's has developed at the manufacturers. Gaining a slot, or delivery position, becomes crucial. ''Texas Air had to do this to stay competitive,'' said Raymond Neidl, an analyst with Dillon, Read.
Mr. Lorenzo said that as many as 25 percent of the planes might be assigned to Eastern Airlines, Texas Air's other subsidiary.
In August Mr. Lorenzo said that he was considering selling a minority or controlling interest in Continental and that he had talked to several interested parties. At yesterday's news conference he declined to discuss the progress of such talks, saying only that the Texas Air board was receptive to offers.
Nevertheless, industry analysts said that regardless of Continental's status, the aircraft order was needed to insure the airline's viability. Continental already has a fleet of 330 planes.
In the last few years Airbus has increased its success in selling in the United States, which accounts for 45 percent of the worldwide market. Ten United States airlines are now flying or have ordered Airbus jets. The consortium includes aerospace concerns from France, Spain, West Germany and Britain.
Although Mr. Lorenzo said that Texas Air had secured financing for 20 of the jets, he declined to provide details, saying that the arrangement may change. Industry analysts speculated that Airbus, which has been aggressively courting American carriers, offered Texas Air attractive financing. ''Airbus is probably giving them a leasing and financing arrangement that Boeing would be reluctant to do,'' said George Shapiro, an analyst with Salomon Brothers.
Deliveries for the airplanes will not begin until February 1993. Earlier this year, Texas Air announced orders for up to 100 Boeing 737-300's worth about $2.8 billion. Of the 40 aircraft orders announced yesterday, 20 are firm and 20 are options to buy.
The A340 is a four-engine wide-body plane that seats 286 passengers and can fly nonstop from Continental's hub in Houston to Tokyo. The A330, which seats 300 passengers, is a medium-range twin-engine plane that the airline will use in North America and to expand its service to Europe. Both planes use advanced cockpit electronics and ''fly by wire,'' where the flight controls are linked to the cockpit through a computer rather than mechanically.
Texas Air has yet to announce which engines will be fitted on the Airbus planes.

HEADLINE: At Budget Hotels, Growing Pains

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill.

 BODY:
Judging by the jammed parking lot at the Fairfield Inn here, one might think that the budget hotel business is flourishing. But now, with more than 50 such chains in business, the supply of inexpensive rooms is beginning to outstrip even the surging demand for them, and occupancy levels and profits are sliding.
Some of the best-known names in the hotel industry - including Marriott, Ramada and Quality Inns International - have been opening hotels with no-frills rooms for as little as $25 a night. Their target, increasingly, is the business traveler whose cost-cutting employer is no longer willing to foot a bill of $75 or more.
The result has been a fierce competition for market share. Many operators are cutting prices further, stepping up their advertising and even resorting to giveaways. Indeed, industry analysts now joke of ''amenity creep'' - a move from offering spartan rooms to providing simple perquisites like shampoo and free phone calls, and then on to more exotic frills like facsimile transmission and phones that permit computer hookups. 
 
Some May Be Forced Out
Given such competition, industry experts say, a number of chains will be driven out of business or forced to merge.
Budget hotels are not new. Motel 6 dates from the 1960's, when it offered rooms for $6 a night, and the Days Inns chain started in the 1970's. Days Inn is still the largest chain of budget hotels, with 81,600 rooms expected by the end of the year; Motel 6 is second, with 60,000.
But in the last two years one big hotel chain after another, troubled by stagnating revenues in their full-service hotels, have entered what was once a land of ersatz leather furniture, gold shag rugs and bathtubs with broken tile. The Marriott Corporation, for example, developed Fairfield Inns; the Ramada Corporation acquired Rodeway Inns, and Prime Motor Inns Inc., which owns the Howard Johnson hotels, acquired Wellesley Inns, a budget chain operating in the Northeast. Quality Inns International, which already owned the Comfort Inns chain of ''luxury'' budget hotels, the third-largest chain, developed Sleep Inns.
 
Old Chains Expanding
Even industry old-timers are getting into the act. Kemmons Wilson, the founder of Holiday Inns, has started his second chain, Wilson Inns, expected to open 14 properties by next month.
Meanwhile, budget hotels in existence for years are expanding rapidly. Days Inns of America, the Atlanta-based chain, recently developed Daystop, a barebones operation for $25 a night. And Hampton Inns, which since its inception in 1984 has replaced the since-sold Holiday Inns as the principal lodging chain of the Holiday Corporation, plans to open 55 budget hotels this year, up from 40 in 1988.
''Years ago we used to have rooming houses; now we have budget hotels,'' said Steven Brenner, a leading industry consultant based in New York.
Market figures bear this out. Since 1981, the number of hotel rooms over all has increased by 2 percent annually, according to Laventhol & Horwath, an accounting and consulting firm. But the number of budget rooms grew by 20 percent in 1988 and is projected to rise 17 percent this year, to 613,500 rooms, according to Laventhol.
So fast has the growth of inexpensive hotels been that by the end of the year roughly one in five of the three million hotel rooms in America will be in the budget category.
 
Rates Sharply Lower
Budget hotels are for people concerned mostly about a clean bed and bath, a television set and a telephone. Rates average $32 a night, compared with more than $60 a night for conventional full-service hotels.
Yet in many ways, some budget hotels are hard to distinguish from their full-service counterparts. At the Fairfield Inn in Peoria, for example, guests get two queen-sized beds and a large work area, and can tune in scores of television channels received by a satellite dish out back.
But at the lower end are the so-called hard budget hotels, which offer one bed and a shower but not a bathtub, and in some cases bath towels that might more appropriately be called paper towels.
While the pace of development of budget-hotel rooms has recently shown signs of abating, growth is still so overheated that ''small, regional chains will be hard-pressed to compete,'' said Daniel W. Daniele, a Laventhol executive who tracks the budget-hotel business. ''Only the big national companies will have the marketing dollars to maintain a competitive edge.''
 
Consolidation Under Way
The industry shakeout has already produced consolidation. Motel 6 acquired Sixpence Inns, a budget chain operating in the West, as well as parts of Envoy Inns, which is in the Midwest. Kings Inn, an inexpensive chain in the Southwest, became part of the Comfort Inn chain. And Skylight Inns, which also operates in the Middle West, joined the hugeTravelodge chain.
The budget hotels' success has not been at the expense of the most luxurious hotels. Top executives and other wealthy people continue to stay at such hotels. Rather, the chains have been taking business from more middle-of-the-road properties like Holiday Inn, Ramada Inn and Howard Johnson's.
Some hotel chains have steered clear of the budget-inn business, fearing it might adulterate their image.
''You can't be all things to all people under one brand name,'' said William Hulett, president of the Stouffer Hotel Company, which has not entered the budget business. ''Ultimately, that confuses people. When people think of Stouffer hotels, we want them to think it will cost them $100 a night to stay there.''
 
A Lower Break-Even Point
Big hoteliers that do invest in budget chains like the much lower break-even point of those hotels, largely the result of less fixed overhead than their full-service brethren. They need be only 52 percent to 55 percent full, compared with 65 percent to 68 percent for a full-service hotel.
What is more, occupancy rates at some budget hotels now run close to 70 percent. While the budget hotels have scored their greatest successes among self-employed entrepreneurs, independent salespeople and other travelers paying their own way, more and more big corporations have begun to send lower-level employees to budget hotels to control costs. Some of the companies are: General Motors, General Electric, Procter & Gamble, I.B.M. and Caterpillar. Business travelers now make up the budget hotels' largest customer group, providing 42 percent of revenues.
Moreover, the financial risk posed by budget hotels is much lower than that of the more expensive hotels. Because they are often placed in rural areas and outside major cities, where land costs are low, budget hotels can be built for as little as $32,000 a room. ''A full-service room can cost double that to build,'' said Robert F. Fitzgerald, chief executive of Rodeway Inns.
 
Profits Lower
Most budget-hotel properties remain in the black. An economy hotel that charges the industry average of $32 a night for a room might pay about $7.50 a day for linens, laundry and cleaning for that room. Another $7.50 a day may go for overhead and the hotel manager's salary. That leaves $17 before fixed charges like rent or mortgage, property taxes, insurance and interest are paid. After those expenses, profit now averages $1.09 before income taxes, down from $4.17 two years ago, according to Laventhol. HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
The Senate Ethics Committee is expected to open investigations of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York and his dealings with Federal housing programs and of five Senators accused of intervening improperly on behalf of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. [Page A1.]
In an early morning raid, Federal agents and Phoenix police officers descended on two luxury hotels that had been crown jewels in the financial empire of Charles H. Keating Jr., took control of them, sealed Mr. Keating's office and announced that he was being discharged as president of the hotel management company. [B5.] 
A consensus has developed within the Bush Administration that M. Danny Wall, the top regulator of the savings industry, should leave his post, a senior White House official said. [B5.]
The nation's trade deficit dropped sharply in September to $7.94 billion, its lowest level since late 1984. [D1.]
Officials in the White House who favor a Government pullback from financing high-techology research and development may need to re-evaluate their position because of economic needs and the political climate, economists and legislators said. [D2.]
Trustees of the Financial Accounting Foundation indicated a willingness to abandon a decision requiring government-owned colleges, hospitals and utilities to obey the same standard-setting group as the private sector. [D4.]
 
 
 
Companies
For the first time, I.B.M. publicly acknowledged wrongdoing in its handling of Government contracts. [D1.]
Texas Air ordered 40 aircraft worth $4.5 billion from Airbus, an indication that Airbus is making inroads in the U.S. market. [D1.]
A.T.&T. will raise prices on domestic long-distance service an average of 1.3 percent for night and weekend calling. [D2.]
John Peters and Peter Guber will have to turn out a lot of hits to justify Sony's investment in them. Sony agreed to pay more than $200 million for Guber Peters Entertainment and hundreds of millions more to extricate them from a contract with Warner. [D1.]
Paramount Pictures acquired 49 percent of one of Britain's leading television production companies. [D17.]
Evans & Sutherland has decided to drop out of the supercomputer business. [D2.]
Chrysler will end its venture with Maserati, whose two-seat luxury car, the TC, has had disappointing sales in the U.S. [D4.]
Walt Disney will open a movie studio theme park at its Euro Disneyland complex near Paris. [D4.]
Dun & Bradstreet shares fell $2, to $42.50, adding to a decline begun after it said Wednesday that net would fall next year. [D4.]
The management of Cineplex Odeon failed to obtain the financing for its proposed buyout offer. [D9.]
 
 
 
Markets
Stocks ended narrowly mixed, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 3.08 points, to 2,635.66. [D6.]
Prices of Treasury securities gave ground in spotty trading, as dealers took some profits.[D15.]
The dollar rallied on news of an improvement in the United States trade balance, but it late selling reduced the gains. [D16.]
Grain and soybean futures prices rose amid hopes of greater grain sales as Washington-Moscow relations warm. [D16.]

HEADLINE: Reviews/Film;
Jarmusch's 'Mystery Train,' Vignettes Linked by Elvis

 BODY:
''Mystery Train'' was shown as part of the recent New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 29. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio, Broadway at 66th Street.
Elvis Presley - the myth, the music and (in one scene) the man -hovers over Jim Jarmusch's blissful new comedy, ''Mystery Train,'' bridging the film's three separate but vaguely interrelated vignettes. The principal setting is the run-down Arcade Hotel in Memphis. The Arcade doesn't offer its patrons television (not that the usual Arcade patrons would be interested in it anyway), but every room does have its own portrait of Elvis. One can't be sure, but the portraits look to be tinted. 
What makes this night different at the Arcade is that three most particular sets of patrons would prefer television to Elvis. That is, all except Mitzuko, the effervescent Japanese teen-ager who has traveled to Memphis on a pilgrimage with her dour teen-age-suave boyfriend, Jun.
In the film's opening story, Jun and Mitzuko are first seen on the train taking them into Memphis, each in the private world of a Walkman headset, riding past small mountains of worn-out automobiles, most probably Japanese.
The Memphis that Mr. Jarmusch elects to show in '' Mystery Train'' is no Memphis that any hometown booster would want to recognize. It's a place of abandoned movie houses, eerily empty streets and ailanthus trees growing like weeds in otherwise vacant lots.
To Mitzuko, who has come to pay her respects to Elvis at his shrine of Graceland, Memphis is magical. Her eyes are saucers. Jun, who prefers Carl Perkins and Roy Orbison to Elvis, remains unimpressed by the Memphis landscape. ''If you took away 60 percent of the buildings,'' he says, ''Yokohama would look just like Memphis.''
When, at the end of the day, they are finally ensconced at the Arcade, Jun starts taking pictures of their room. Why? He'll remember the sights outside, he says, but he'll need the snaps to recall everything else, including the airports they've passed through.
Jun and Mitzuko are tourists, serenely voyaging on the cheap as they make the grand tour of America's holy places. The second segment of ''Mystery Train'' is about Luisa, a pretty Italian widow forced to spend a night in Memphis while accompanying her husband's body back to Rome. In the lobby of the Arcade, she befriends DeeDee, a chattering young woman who, nearly broke, is running away from her boyfriend. Luisa offers to share her room with the younger woman.
DeeDee is fleeing Memphis, while Luisa is just passing through. For her, Memphis is an anonymous stopover until, sitting in a coffee shop, she is gently accosted by a tall, skinny man with a strange story. The gist of his tale is that the ghost of Elvis has entrusted him with a crummy pocket comb to be given to Luisa. She listens, amused and rather pleased, until the man suggests they continue their dialogue elsewhere.
The third vignette, which more or less brings all the elements of the narrative together, involves the fellow DeeDee is leaving, an unemployed, working-class Englishman who is named Johnny and nicknamed Elvis, and his two pals. They are Will Robinson, a laid-back truck driver, and Charlie, DeeDee's brother, a fastidious barber who can't hold his liquor.
In the course of a feckless spree, Elvis holds up a liquor store for two bottles of whisky, and a gun goes off, forcing the three to seek a hideout at the Arcade. It's not easy to describe the dizzy gaiety of Mr. Jarmusch's films, each set in a universe that seems to be even more torpid than that of the film before. ''Mystery Train'' is buoyantly funny from start to finish. One doesn't laugh out loud all that often. One grins and, as the odd events and eccentric information accumulate, begins to recognize an enchanted vision within the seediness.
Mr. Jarmusch is an American original who, for all of his hipness, is remarkably benign. Like ''Stranger Than Paradise'' and ''Down by Law,'' the first two Jarmusch films to be commercially released, ''Mystery Train'' has something of the pragmatic craziness of the great Krazy Kat cartoons.
Nobody tosses bricks in ''Mystery Train,'' which, unlike Krazy Kat and the two earlier comedies, has been photographed (by Robby Muller) in brilliant colors. Yet there is a bluntness to the Jarmusch method that gives substance to the seemingly fragile narratives.
It's now obvious that calling his comedies shaggy-dog stories isn't good enough. They aren't really stories at all. Each is an amalgam of attitudes, images and music, especially music (blues, jazz, rock), which evoke something most cheering and comic about the human condition, even in extremis.
The dialogue sounds as if it had been gathered by means of microphones hidden in diners, buses, waiting rooms, restrooms, motels and park benches. Sometimes it is hilariously banal, with never a word wasted.
The ''Mystery Train'' performers fly. There isn't enough space to give them all their due, but those who must be mentioned include Masatoshi Nagase and Youki Kudoh, as Jun and Mitzuko, Nicoletta Braschi as Luisa, and Joe Strummer as ''Elvis.''
Presiding over these hapless folk are Screamin' Jay Hawkins, who plays the Arcade's unflappable night clerk, and Cinque Lee (Spike's younger brother), who plays the bellboy. John Lurie, the actor and musician who starred in ''Stranger Than Paradise,'' wrote the film's fine score, which is punctuated by Elvis hits.

HEADLINE: A Final Fling on Nutcracker's Eve

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
THIS is the weekend before ''The Nutcracker'' arrives, like a fond but overwhelming aunt whose visit means that all else must be dropped or put aside. As if to celebrate those last free moments before the holiday classic gathers audiences up into its cheerful bosom, dance companies and soloists are presenting a wide-ranging variety of work in theaters around New York City tonight through Sunday.
The chilly, pure art of jiuta-mai, the most refined of Japanese classical dance forms, will be represented, as will the giddy vulgarisms of American vaudeville. There will be flamenco and home-grown American modern dance, including the newest of new choreographers and a veteran performance artist.
The Joffrey Ballet, which ushers in the first of the area productions of ''The Nutcracker'' next week, goes out in a blaze of repertorial glory this weekend at City Center. Tonight and tomorrow night, there is the company's spectacular newest addition, ''Two-a-Day,'' a souffle of a ballet by Gerald Arpino, the Joffrey's director and resident choreographer, filled with stock vaudeville characters and numbers presented with stylish and infectious exuberance. 
Other Joffrey highlights are performances tomorrow and Sunday afternoons of Eugene Loring's ''Billy the Kid,'' an American classic featuring two good lead casts; ''La Vivandiere Pas de Six,'' a piece of late 19th-century effervescence by Arthur Saint-Leon that is on the matinee program tomorrow, and William Forsythe's ''Love Songs,'' a dark, sardonic look at romance that is performed to some of the greatest songs sung by Aretha Franklin and Dionne Warwick, tomorrow night. Performances to watch for are those of Peter Narbutas, an unusually nuanced Alias in ''Billy the Kid''; Tina LeBlanc in a virtuoso role in ''Vivandiere,'' and the daredevil Jodie Gates in ''Love Songs.'' (The Joffrey Ballet performs at City Center, 131 West 55th Street, tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 and Sunday at 2 P.M. Ticket prices range from $8 to $42. Information: 581-7907.) Garth Fagan and his Bucket Dance Company have grown a great deal in the 20 years since Mr. Fagan started choreographing for a group of untrained, working-class students in Rochester.
The dancers are now sleek, expert performers. Mr. Fagan, once a member of the National Dance Company of Jamaica, has become a more sophisticated choreographer. But the rough-hewn, highly personal quality of the dances and dancers has remained a hallmark of the company.
''I like a kind of freshness and rawness about these dancers,'' Mr. Fagan told the dance writer Eric Taub in 1984. ''But freshness is not to be confused with a lack of discipline, form or structure. It's like the beauty of a wildflower versus a calla lily. I adore both, but I want my dancers to keep that wildflower feeling without having their dancing turn into an expressionistic, undefined free-for-all.''
This weekend, the company will present nine dances, ranging from Mr. Fagan's new ''Telling a Story'' to a revival of his ''Of Light and Melanin.'' The earlier piece, created in 1981 and set to music by Keith Jarrett, has become a kind of signature work, with a central, high arabesque in a solo for a lead female dancer that is emblematic of the magic Mr. Fagan and his dancers can create. It will be performed tomorrow afternoon in Program III. The acclaimed ''Telling a Story'' is a plotless, two-part homage to Miles Davis, to whose music the new work is danced, and to Mr. Fagan's parents and grandchildren. It will be performed in Program I, tonight, tomorrow and Sunday nights.
There are pieces set to music by other jazz composers and to scores by Dvorak, Brahms and Vivaldi. Mr. Fagan's use of African dance idiom comes to the fore in ''From Before,'' performed on Sunday night in Program II. ''Oatka Trail,'' a signature work performed in Program I, displays his individual mixing of idioms that include ballet, gymnastics and modern dance influenced by Mary Wigman and Martha Graham. (The Bucket Dance Company performs at the Joyce Theater, Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 8 and Sunday at 2 and 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $22.50. Information: 242-0800.)
 
Economy of Jiuta-Mai
Suzushi Hanayagi is an experimentalist modern-dance choreographer who has made use of video in some of her dance. She has also worked with Robert Wilson, creating the Bessie Award-winning choreography for his ''Knee Plays'' and co-choreographing the Paris Opera Ballet's ''Martyre de St. Sebastien.'' But Miss Hanayagi is also one of Japan's foremost classical dancers, trained by the famous Takehara Han and specializing in the stark, utterly refined dance form of jiuta-mai, which was developed by the Kyoto aristocracy in the 17th century. And in works like ''Yuki (Snow),'' a study of a woman withdrawing from the world, which Miss Hanayagi will dance tonight and tomorrow night at Asia Society, she offers an unforgettable example of how economical great performing can be.
Miss Hanayagi will be joined by her older sister, Suzusetsi, also a noted performer of Japanese classical dance, and Suzusetsumi Hanayagi, who is unrelated but has taken on the professional name. The program will also feature kabuki numbers, including ''Echigo-Jishi (Lion Dance).'' (The Hanayagis will perform at Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, tonight and tomorrow at 8. Tickets are $20. Information: 288-6400. Charge: 517-2742.) If Suzushi Hanayagi could be called a performer of magnificent economy, Victoria Marks will probably always be known as the choreographer who gave us a look at the process of socialization through the minimalist gestures of four young women in drab schoolgirls' winter coats. That signature work, ''Dancing to Music,'' will be performed again, tonight through Sunday at Performance Space 122, in a program that also features Miss Marks's new ''Force of Nature,'' a fast-paced and wild ensemble piece danced to music by Chris Cochrane, and her ''Natural Selection,'' which has been described as an ode to the Reagan years in the White House.
Later each night, Charles Dennis takes over at P.S. 122 with an evening of performance and dance pieces that includes ''Just Say Yo,'' set to music by Bob Telson, with slides, film and video. Mr. Dennis, a founder of P.S. 122, will also perform in his recent ''Living RRRoom,'' a solo that examines the domestic life of a freelance artist. His ''2 x 2 x 4'' is a dance for Mr. Dennis and 14 two-by-four planks. (The Victoria Marks Performance Company dances at 8 and Charles Dennis performs at 9:30 P.M. at Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street. Admission to each show is $8; Theater Development Vouchers accepted. Information or reservations: 477-5288.)
 
Flamenco
Paco Pena, the flamenco guitarist, has appeared before in New York only as a solo artist. On Sunday night, he brings his company to Town Hall for a single performance sponsored by the World Music Institute. For those who like to know exactly what they are about to see, the program for the company's first American tour ranges over styles from all periods of flamenco. And Mr. Pena's reputation as a musician of great spontaneity and warmth with austere virtuosity bodes well, too, for a provocative evening of dance. (The Paco Pena Flamenco Dance Company performs at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, on Sunday at 8 P.M. Tickets are $15, $20 and $25. Information: 206-1050. Charge: 947-5850.) And for those who like to be surprised, there is ''Fielday,'' a five-hour program of dance tomorrow night by 21 choreographers. All are new or ''emerging,'' as the organizers put it, and all have been invited to take risks with their dances. Some of the names are familiar, among them Sara Pearson, Bill Coleman, Alice Varga Forner and Lorn MacDougal. Most are not. But the Field, which is sponsoring the marathon, is serious and imaginative about encouraging choreographers, so there ought to be at least a gem or two in the bag. (''Fielday'' will take place tomorrow night, beginning at 7, at Eden's Expressway, 537 Broadway, near Spring Street. Tickets are $5, for all or part of the program, and will be available at the door. Information: 691-6969.)

HEADLINE: House Votes to Raise Members' Pay and Ban Fees for Speaking

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
After a year of scandal and internal turmoil, the House of Representatives voted today to raise its members' salaries, tighten its ethics rules and sharply reduce the members' dependence on outside income.
By a vote of 252 to 174, the House approved a measure that would raise the pay of House members, Federal judges and top Government officials by more than a third over the next two years. It would prohibit House members from accepting speaking fees from outside groups, a practice that critics have attacked as an effort to curry favor and influence. It would tighten rules on gifts, travel and outside earnings. 
''I think it's a breakthrough day for the institution,'' said Fred Wertheimer, head of Common Cause, the governmental watchdog group. ''It really is, I would hope, the beginning of the end for the anything-goes ethics era that has functioned in Washington in the 1980's.''
 
On to the Senate
''The House has suffered a great deal of damage, both from within and without,'' said Representative Lynn Martin, Republican of Illinois, a co-chairwoman of the House group that produced this measure. ''The House has a rare opportunity to redeem itself today.''
The proposal would raise the salaries of House members, judges and other officials by 7.9 percent Jan. 1, 1990, and 25 percent more, plus an adjustment to make up for inflation, one year later. House leaders estimated that this would raise members' salaries to about $125,000 in 1991, from the current $89,500, for an overall increase of about 40 percent.
The legislation now heads to the Senate, where leaders from both parties are still struggling to find a politically palatable plan for Senate salaries and outside income. By tradition, neither chamber tries to set the pay or otherwise dictate the internal workings of the other chamber. The Senate could adopt the pay package and the guidelines on speaking fees set by the House for its own members, or it could approve the proposal for House members and come up with a different plan for its own members. President Bush has endorsed the House proposal. George J. Mitchell, the Senate majority leader, said tonight that the House measure would come to the floor on Friday. Opponents of the measure, including Ralph Nader, who sharply criticized the size of the raise, said they hoped to block it there.
Today's vote in the House came after a campaign carefully orchestrated to build bipartisan support and political protection for lawmakers. Unlike the 51 percent raise that would have taken effect in February if Congress had not blocked it, this salary increase was made part of a sweeping revision of the House ethical rules so that leaders could promote it as an ethics package, not a raise.
 
Pledge From Party Leaders
One leader after another rose to argue that the new rules were critical to restore public confidence in the House and that the long-term gain to the institution would far exceed the outcry over the pay increase.
To buttress their courage, lawmakers were presented with an extraordinary non-aggression pledge from four party leaders: Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman; Ronald H. Brown, the Democratic chairman; and Representatives Guy Vander Jagt, Republican of Michigan, and Beryl Anthony Jr., Democrat of Arkansas, the heads of the Congressional campaign committees. ''The four of us have agreed to issue instructions to our staff that the vote on H.R. 3660 is not an appropriate point of criticism in the coming campaigns,'' the leaders said.
In the end, the measure shot through the House: More than 150 aye votes were cast in the first 30 seconds, to whoops and whistles.
 
No More Speaking Fees
In return for the pay increase of more than a third, the legislation would require members to give up their speaking fees, starting in 1991. Currently, lawmakers may accept fees and other outside earnings equaling 30 percent of their Congressional salary. They could still earn outside income from activities like teaching, but the amount would be limited to 15 percent of the Congressional salary. And the measure would prohibit members from earning professional, legal or directors' fees. ''It was a real effort to close off all the spigots,'' said Mr. Wertheimer.
Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, said of the legislation today: ''It says: 'Boys and girls, this is a full-time job. Pay attention to what's going on here. We'll compensate you straight from the public Treasury, right out in the open, but no more side employment deals.' ''

HEADLINE: With America Honoring Walesa, Little Poland Is Filled With Pride

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK

 BODY:
In the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, which is known as Little Poland, the ties to the old country remain strong.
Meat markets are heavy with the garlicky scent of kielbasa and the sweet fragrance of freshly baked babka. A liquor store on Manhattan Avenue boasts of stocking 118 brands of vodka. Signs in store windows announce ''Polska Mowa,'' or Polish Spoken Here. Travel agencies do a brisk business booking flights to Warsaw and arranging shipments of food, clothing and dollars to family members overseas.
This week the neighborhood is buzzing with talk, much of it in Polish, about Lech Walesa's first visit to the United States and his two-day trip to New York City that began yesterday. His triumphant welcome in Washington has renewed the pride of Polish-Americans in Solidarity, the trade union he founded that helped bring about a new political order in Poland. 
Greenpoint is still the main destination for many Polish immigrants seeking economic liberation. But it is also a reminder of the hardships facing the new Poland. Until the shelves of the markets in Warsaw are as full as those in Greenpoint, Poles are likely to continue to come to the West, abandoning the promise of freedom at home for the certainty of abundance abroad.
Such was the case with Peter Walczak, a 38-year-old carpenter who left his home in Poznan two weeks ago to come to the United States. On Wednesday, he was shopping for bread and kielbasa in Greenpoint with his older brother, Andy, who came to New York City 10 years ago.
''The situation in Poland is not going to change day after day,'' Mr. Walczak said in Polish, using his brother as a translator. ''It's going to take time, and right now it's very drastic - shortages of food, shortages of clothes, shortages of supplies. If you want to buy, say, a TV, you have to wait two years. You have to put your name on all of these lists.''
Asked to identify the biggest difference between the United States and Poland, Mr. Walczak said, ''being able to buy things.''
Except for that distinction, and the street signs in English, Mr. Walczak said he feels as if he is walking through a small Polish city when he wanders through Greenpoint.
 
A Common Culture
Although only a short trip across the East River from midtown Manhattan, it is a neighborhood that has maintained much of its ethnic insularity since Polish immigrants first settled there in the mid-19th century.
During that era it was shipyards, one of which built the Civil War ironclad Monitor, that attracted Polish, Irish and Italian immigrants. Succeeding waves of immigrants settled there to be near family members and to share a common culture.
Greenpoint's cultural isolation is at least partly due to its lack of a direct subway link to Manhattan. Commuters must change trains either in Queens or elsewhere in Brooklyn. That may also have something to do with the neighborhood's relatively low crime rates. There has not been a homicide there since February.
The city's Planning Department estimates that about five percent of New York City's 350,000 residents of Polish descent live in Greenpoint. But because many of the roughly 1,000 Poles who emigrate to New York City each year settle in Greenpoint, the area has retained its ethnic vitality.
 
Memories of 1939
The six Polish Masses celebrated each weekend at St. Stanislaus Kostka Church, the neighborhood's spiritual center, are packed with parishioners. In the early 1980's, when Solidarity was banned under martial law, dozens of residents crammed into the back room of the Pol-Am Bookstore to plot strategy for raising American money and consciousness for Solidarity.
The memory of Germany's invasion of Poland in 1939 is fresh enough in Greenpoint that there was some nervousness in the neighborhood last week when it was announced that travel restrictions were being relaxed in East Germany. ''Polish people do fear the reunification of Germany because of the history of aggression of the German nation,'' said Edward J. Celmer, a doctor who grew up in Greenpoint but received his medical training in Poland during the early days of martial law.
Virtually everyone in Greenpoint regards Mr. Walesa, a former shipyard electrician, as a national hero. And his trip to the United States has brought home Solidarity's accomplishments to the immigrants who have had to watch the ferment from afar. They found immense gratification in his being awarded the Medal of Freedom by President Bush and his being honored as only the third person who was not a sitting head of state to be asked to speak to both houses of Congress.
''It means they can pick up their heads, look people in the eyes and say, 'We are not so low, not so downtrodden. We have people we can be proud of,' '' said the Rev. Stanislaw Staniszewski, pastor of St. Stanislaus Kostka Church.
 
No Visit to Little Poland
Father Staniszewski said he wept yesterday while reading a transcript of Mr. Walesa's speech to Congress in Nowy Dziennik, the New York-based Polish daily.
Many people in Greenpoint said they were disappointed that Mr. Walesa was not planning to visit the neighborhood. Dr. Celmer said he could envision a huge rally in Walesa-Solidarity Square in front of St. Stanislaus Kostka Church.
Most, however, were willing to forgive Mr. Walesa for planning to spend his time with labor leaders, politicians and newspaper editors. They said they understand that the focus of his trip is not Polonia, as the Polish-American community is called, but the politicians and opinion leaders who can help Poland win greater economic aid from Congress.
 
Rendezvous at a Shrine
Mr. Walesa's visit to New York will be largely out of the public's view, and so some Greenpoint residents plan to go elsewhere to catch a glimpse of him. On Sunday, Father Staniszewski plans to take two busloads of parishioners to Doylestown, Pa., where Mr. Walesa is to attend a Mass at a Polish shrine.
Mr. Walesa chose not to run for Parliament last summer, but has maintained a strong influence on the government from his home in Gdansk. Many Polish-Americans in Greenpoint believe he made the right decision.
''He's a national figurehead,'' said Dr. Celmer. ''He represents - the Polish word is ruch oporu - the Underground, but you could also translate that to mean conscience.
''In those bleak times, he was the one who held fast. My personal opinion is he should not be in the government because he represents the Polish conscience, the movement. He should not become tainted by the everyday workings of government.''
Darek Sczepanczyk, who owns the Pol-Am Bookstore with his wife, said he wished the new non-Communist government well, but he added he was skeptical about its prospects for success, and about Mr. Walesa's role as the power behind the parliament. ''Basically people like him,'' he said, ''but there are a number of people who feel he's turned into a dictator, that we're talking about democracy but there is a strongman. I hope he knows what he's doing.''
Mr. Sczepanczyk conceded, however, that Mr. Walesa's status as an international figure holds advantages for Poland. ''He is a Nobel Prize winner and people know him,'' he said. ''Nobody can get things done for Poland as he can.''

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Jackson And the Democrats

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Is Jesse Jackson, as he claims, entitled to a share of the credit for the recent election victories of David Dinkins in New York and Douglas Wilder in Virginia?
Mr. Wilder, the apparent victor in a close election for governor, certainly doesn't think so; indeed he regards the Jackson claim as ''amazing.'' Reverend Jackson, he says, gave him no help ''directly - or indirectly -that I know of.''
Nor does the record show that Mr. Jackson appeared with or on behalf of Mr. Wilder, or with any frequency or substantial impact for Mr. Dinkins, the Mayor-elect. And it has been frequently pointed out - in this column, for example - that both those candidates, though black, campaigned essentially as middle-of-the-road moderates with little of Mr. Jackson's fire and originality. 
Nevertheless, Jesse Jackson's claim seems justified to me. Had he not been as active and vocal in Democratic politics as he has been at least since 1984, David Dinkins and Douglas Wilder might well not even have been at the head of their party's tickets - and that is said with no intent to detract from the courageous, well-conceived and tightly managed campaigns each of them waged.
One of Mr. Jackson's contributions is obvious - voter registration. He has been highly successful in getting black voters to register and turn out on Election Day; it's not as clear but highly likely that he also encouraged a good many whites, particularly among the disadvantaged, to sign up. Not just Mr. Wilder and Mr. Dinkins, but numerous black and white Democratic officeholders owe more to Mr. Jackson's registration efforts than perhaps they care to admit. That's especially so in Southern states where most blacks and a lot of whites once were unable to vote.
But Mr. Jackson's greater contribution is less tangible - his presence in national politics as a black candidate not only able to win Presidential primaries and command a large bloc of delegates at a party convention, but as an articulate advocate of bold, often original economic and political approaches that appeal to white and black alike.
Can it really be doubted that that presence, striking as it has been, has made black candidacies more plausible, black political participation more effective, black political performance and aspiration more demanding of respect from all races? Jesse Jackson himself may never be President but he has made it considerably more likely that a black President can and probably will be elected in his lifetime - not to mention black governors and mayors.
It can be argued that had Mr. Jackson, who turns off a lot of white voters, remained a Chicago community leader unknown to national politics, black candidates like Mr. Wilder and Mr. Dinkins would have won by larger margins. Maybe; and no doubt that possibility is why both resisted Mr. Jackson's active support. The likelihood seems to me, nevertheless, that each won on his own merits, but not least because black candidacies everywhere had been made more credible by the success and obvious ability of Jesse Jackson.
The moderate, centrist appeal of Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Wilder is the best way to build the broad coalitions needed for victory on Election Day, former Gov. Charles Robb of Virginia pointed out the other day at a meeting of moderate, centrist Democrats. That's true; but a sharp-edged, issue-laden, occasionally radical approach is vital, too. Whether by Jesse Jackson or Ronald Reagan, such a candidacy gives American politics what ideological content it has, provides the goals toward which coalitions glacially move, and prevents the center - sometimes - from settling into an inert mass.
There's a warning here for those Democrats who urge Jesse Jackson to run for mayor of Washington D.C., mostly in hopes of keeping what they consider his divisive presence out of the Presidential campaign of 1992. Mr. Jackson, in fact, is his party's most charismatic figure; he upholds its best tradition of enlightened concern for the downtrodden; he leads one of its most important and loyal factions; and Governor Robb described him as a politician with more ''raw talent than anyone else on the scene.''
If he's divisive, it's mostly because his is one of the few voices in either party that has anything new or interesting to say about the nation's political and economic straits. That's always divisive, and needed.

HEADLINE: How About a Real Minimum Wage Increase?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Help, at Last, for the Working Poor'' announced your lead editorial Nov. 2, referring to the increase in the minimum wage and the expanded tax credits for low-income families. You agree with President Bush, who prefers tax credits to minimum-wage increases: ''Because most low-wage workers, like students, are not from poor families, lifting the minimum wage helps poor and nonpoor alike.''
If most low-wage workers are not from poor families, who are the working poor that will get this ''powerful relief''? Although there are students from nonpoor families in the work force, they by no means constitute the majority of low-wage workers. And surely you realize that there are working students from poor families - that not all students are middle class. 
If President Bush and you are afraid of the nonpoor benefiting from an increase in the minimum wage, check out the people at soup kitchens and food pantries. In New York State alone, there are 1,550 food pantries and 325 soup kitchens. The soup kitchens serve one million people annually, while the food pantries provide free food to 440,000 hungry each month. Between 20 and 30 percent of them are employed - or to be more precise, underemployed.
The figure for Americans at or below the poverty line is 13.1 percent; in the inner cities and in rural areas, that jumps to 18 percent. These numbers are considerably higher than the unemployment rate and reflect not only the chronically unemployed, but also the underemployed working poor, those whose minimum wages are not enough to raise them above the poverty level.
Figures are impersonal. I suggest that President Bush and you venture out into the real world of the hungry in our society and talk to people who must eat in soup kitchens and get free food from pantries. You might not then be so concerned about a few nonpoor students benefiting from a meaningful increase in the minimum wage.
 
LILLA WILSON
 Kingston, N.Y., Nov. 3, 1989
The writer is director of nutrition outreach for Family of Woodstock Inc., a United Way agency.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: Administration Gives Momentum To a Vote on Puerto Rico's Status

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The Bush Administration gave momentum this week to a Senate bill that would give Puerto Rico the right to decide if it is to be the 51st state, an independent country or remain a commonwealth, but with greater control over its own affairs.
The measure, endorsed by the White House, has already been approved by the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee and is expected to reach the Senate floor early next year. On the House side, the Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs plans to hold hearings in early 1990 on similar legislation.
But the 3.3 million people on the Caribbean island are sharply split over the issue, and their Governor, Rafael Hernandez Colon, opposes the bill on two grounds. He is against statehood and feels that the bill unfairly tilts the referendum in favor of statehood. The bill would provide immediate benefits to Puerto Ricans but delay the costs, if the island becomes a state. The vote would be held in 1991. 
The Bush Administration readily admits it favors statehood. And that assertion was repeated this week by Kenneth W. Gideon, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for tax policy, in testimony to the Senate Finance Committee. ''As the President has noted a number of times,'' Mr. Gideon said, ''he favors the admission of Puerto Rico to the Union as a state, thereby assuring the people of Puerto Rico an equal standing with other U.S. citizens.''
 
'You Can't Have Both'
The chief sponsor of the Senate bill, Senator J. Bennett Johnston Jr., the Louisana Democrat who is chairman of the Energy and Natural Resources Committee, has told the Puerto Ricans, ''You can't have both independence and the wealth of services,'' and added, ''Puerto Rico has to understand that it can't have its cake and eat it too.''
The island was ceded by Spain to the United States after the Spanish-American War in 1898 and became a commonwealth in 1952. The status gives Puerto Ricans all the usual obligations and privileges of citizenship except the right to vote in Federal elections and the duty to pay income taxes.
Statehood would mean the current $82 million ceiling for Federal money for welfare, Medicaid, food stamps and other social programs on the island would be removed. And Federal expenditures for these programs are expected to increase at least tenfold if Puerto Rico became a state.
But statehood would also mean the end of an estimated $2 billion a year in tax benefits intended to lure United States companies that invest in the island. That tax break is responsible for most of the economic investment in Puerto Rico. The Senate bill would phase out the tax break over a seven-year period.
Puerto Ricans would also lose their exemption from Federal income taxes, although the Senate bill would delay this provision until 1994.
 
High Rate of Unemployment
Governor Hernandez Colon argued that the big expected increase in Federal benefits would prove popular on the island, which has a per capita income of $5,157, less than half that of the rest of the United States, and an unemployment rate of 15 percent, almost triple the United States average.
The Senate measure, Governor Hernandez Colon said this week, ''obscures the true costs of statehood from the electorate.
''It camouflages, for them, the disastrous long-term economic consequences of statehood while spotlighting the prospect of immediate and dramatically higher welfare benefits,'' he added.
And the Governor emphasized the importance of the tax benefits for United States investors. ''This is not just another provision of the tax code, but rather the very foundation of the Puerto Rican economy,'' he said. ''Statehood would inevitably destroy that foundation.''
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, agreed that under the bill, ''statehood offers Puerto Ricans the prospect of immediate social welfare benefits but long-term economic losses.'' On the other hand, he said, ''Commonwealth promises long-term economic gains, but with no immediate social welfare enhancements.''
 
Champions of Statehood
The bill was strongly supported by two former Governors, Carlos Romero Barcelo and Luis A. Ferre, who are both champions of statehood.
''Congress is insuring the right of self-determination,'' Mr. Ferre told the Senate Finance Committee.
Mr. Barcelo said, ''We are living in one of democracy's finest hours.'' He noted that ''Europe's eastern bloc is moving en masse toward democracy,'' and said that in Asia, Africa and Central and South America, ''the people will not long be denied.''
''And, with this legislation, the longstanding promise of self-determination for the world's oldest colony finally will be realized for the 3.3 million American citizens living in Puerto Rico,'' he added.

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
In Quest of a Post-Cold War Plan

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Dennis Ross, the director of policy planning for the State Department, was musing the other day about the difficulties of doing any kind of advanced strategic planning for the Secretary of State at time when so many things are changing so fast.
''I had a friend of mine from the C.I.A. come down yesterday to give me a briefing on East Germany,'' remarked Mr. Ross. ''He told me that he revised his paper three times on the drive from the C.I.A. to the State Department just because of things he was hearing on the radio.''
''It gives you a flavor of what we're up against,'' he continued. ''The world is changing in very big ways, hour by hour. That keeps you humble when someone says, 'Please draw me up three scenarios for the future of Europe.' '' 
Indeed, as the cold war draws to a close, the members of today's policy planning staff find themselves in the same quandary as did their founding predecessors 42 years ago, when a devastated Europe was struggling to find a new postwar order.
 
Origin of Marshall Plan
In 1947, George Marshall, then Secretary of State, summoned a bright young Sovietologist to his office, told him to form a policy planning staff and in 10 days turn in a program for reconstructing the European continent. His only advice was two words: ''Avoid trivia.''
''I was supposed to review the whole great problem of European recovery,'' George F. Kennan, that young Sovietologist, recalled in his memoirs, ''to tap those various sources of outside advice, to present to the Secretary the recommendations he wanted, and be prepared to defend these recommendations against all governmental critics.''
Mr. Kennan somehow managed to pull it off, crystallizing ideas already proferred by Dean Acheson, John McCloy and Averell Harriman into what eventually became the Marshall Plan.
As the European order that Mr. Kennan and the other ''wise men'' helped to forge is rapidly dissolving, the State Department policy planners once again find themselves playing a central role at Foggy Bottom - but with one big difference.
 
Contrast in Missions
The policy planning bureau was created by Secretary Marshall at a time when American power was at its zenith, when Europe was begging for American leadership and there was a clear-cut enemy: the Communist world led by the Soviet Union. Now, the group must rethink the world for Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, providing visions of how Western and Eastern Europe can be peacefully reintegrated into a new European order, at a time when American power is more limited and when the enemies have not quite disappeared, but also aren't what they used to be.
''Be careful in drawing parallels with the past,'' said Mr. Ross in an interview in his office. ''The United States emerged from World War II with unparalleled power - politically, economically and miltarily. Today, we do not have unparalleled power. Policy planning is more complicated now. As we shape our responses, we have to recognize our real assets and our real strengths. That doesn't mean that we don't have a potential to lead, but that we have to lead in partnership.''
Even before the dramatic events of the last few weeks, Mr. Baker, who came into his job not entirely trusting the judgment or the capacity for ''new thinking'' of the State Department bureaucracy, had been using the 25-member policy planning staff as both his personal think tank and mini-State Department. This did not, to say the least, endear the policy planning staff to some Foreign Service veterans, who viewed Mr. Ross and his associates not only as outsiders but also as a group of still-wet-behind-the-ears whippersnappers with too much authority for their tender years.
Nevertheless, after several months of tension, a fairly amicable working relationship appears to have been established between policy planning and the rest of the building. Department veterans have learned that they must build alliances with the policy planning bureau to be effective, and policy planning has built alliances with the operating bureaus to get ideas carried out.
 
Crucial Role in Department
''Policy planning has become like a National Security Council staff for Baker - they don't just write speeches they actually micromanage certain policies,'' observed one State Department veteran. ''If you want to be influential these days, you better have a contact on policy planning -otherwise you will end up with the crumbs. We feed things into them but we don't always get fed back.''
''Let's keep our influence in perspective,'' counters Mr. Ross, who greets publicity with the enthusiasm normally reserved for a $100 parking fine. ''The best way to pursue policy is to insure that there is a marriage between the conceptual and the operational. Too often in the past there has been a total gap.''
Save for a brief two-year stint as director of the Berkeley-Stanford program on Soviet International Behavior, the 41-year-old Mr. Ross has been working in Washington since the early 1980's, first as a Middle East specialist on the policy planning staff of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., then in the Pentagon and finally as the Middle East adviser to the N.S.C., where he came to know George Bush, and later, as Mr. Bush's senior campaign foreign policy adviser.
Mr. Ross's carefully balanced sense of the limits and opportunities, his penchant for policies with high potential gains and low domestic political risks, infuses Mr. Baker's approach to foreign affairs. It is, in many ways, the intellectual bond cementing their relationship.
The rest of the 25-member policy planning staff reflects Mr. Ross's eclectic background. There is a C.I.A. Sovietologist, Foreign Service veterans of Central America, an Air Force colonel, economists and environmentalists, as well as the only man in the State Department who has had almost as much written about himself in the last year as Mr. Baker: Francis Fukuyama. Mr. Fukuyama's essay, ''The End of History,'' about how Western liberal ideas have triumphed over their ideological competitors, has touched off a heated debate among intellectuals.
''We have a range of philosophies on the staff - from those who think we are at the end of history to those who think we are at the beginning of it,'' said Mr. Ross. ''I wanted people who did not reflect conventional thinking in their areas of the world, since the conventional thinking did not predict any of the changes we are now seeing.''
 
Preparing Strategies on Europe
Mr. Ross runs the policy planning staff in coordination with Mr. Baker's counselor, Robert Zoellick, a self-described ''36-year-old public policy junkie, with a background in law, finance and government,'' who oversees both the policy planning papers and all those from the rest of the State Department that go into Mr. Baker's office, thereby insuring that the ideas being generated by the policy planning staff are meshed with the department's day-to-day operations.
At the moment, the policy planning staff, in coordination with the European Affairs Bureau, is preparing strategies on Europe for Mr. Baker on three interrelated themes.
The first area that the staff is concentrating on involves ''trying to look at how you transform established institutions, such as NATO, to serve new missions that will fit the new era,'' explained Mr. Zoellick.
The Bush Administration is approaching the next phase in Europe's transformation with the assumption that no matter what happens with the Soviet military threat, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has to be maintained as a vehicle for managing change in a post-cold war Europe. With German reunification now a live, though still very remote possibility, Administration officials feel that NATO will be needed more than ever as the basis for a stabilizing American military presence, as a forum for alleviating friction among the allies and helping to constrain German influence and keep Germany securely under a Western umbrella.
The second area, consists of a series of papers examining how Eastern and Western Europe might be more closely reunited, as well as the different ways in which West and East Germany might choose to be reassociated.
 
How to Exercise Leadership
The third area being examined is how the United States, lacking the power it had 40 years ago, can continue to exert leadership in Europe.
''That means finding ways to impart leadership through the force of ideas,'' said Mr. Zoellick.
''People on the outside have a lot of illusions about how policy planning actually gets translated into policy,'' he continued. ''The truth is most of the people at the senior level of government don't always have a lot of time to sit down and reflect. Therefore a lot of new thinking, while it draws on prior reflection, tends to get fed into the policy makers in short conversations, or in a brief paper, or quick preparations for meetings.''
''I bet if you looked back at how NATO and the Marshall Plan were produced, though,'' he added, ''you'd find out that a lot of their concepts came together in conversations which took place in the hall.''

HEADLINE: Vermont Journal;
The Fire For Wood As Fuel Is Cooling

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Nov. 16

 BODY:
There is a closet in John Illick's house where a wood stove used to be. For seven years, he and his wife, Beth, burned wood for primary heat in the long winters here, for economic and esthetic reasons. But the appeal began to wear thin. ''Wood is dirty and it's a lot of work,'' said Mr. Illick, who is a vice president at the Bread Loaf Construction Company. ''I got sick of vacuuming up the dirt and dust and bugs all the time! You end up jamming your fingers in the stove while you're loading it and swearing a lot. My daughter, Adrienne, tripped and burned her face on it.''
When the Illicks renovated their house two years ago, the stove went. 
There was a time after the Arab oil embargo when wood seemed the answer, when many Vermonters had more time than money, when ''renewable resources'' was the battle cry.
But that was before doctors warned of the respiratory hazards of wood smoke and states began to regulate wood-stove emissions. It was also a time when oil prices were high.
''When the price of oil and other fuels started to go back down, wood was no longer a tremendous cost saving,'' said Mr. Illick. ''If the price of oil went back up, would I go back to wood? Well, there's a closet there now, so it's a moot point.''
The Green Mountain Power Corporation surveyed its customers this year and found that only 16 percent used wood as the primary source of heat, as against 33 percent five years ago.
Figures compiled by the state's Conservation and Renewable Energy Unit indicate that Vermonters, over all, burned 323,000 cords of wood in the 1987-88 heating season, 36 percent less than the 503,000 cords of the 1981-82 season.
''While the state is still actively promoting the use of wood, it's true that fewer and fewer people are using it,'' said Stuart Slote, the wood specialist for the state agency.
Stephen Morris, vice president for sales and marketing of Vermont Castings Inc., a wood-stove manufacturer, has seen many competitors go out of business. He said Vermont Castings has stayed afloat, has in fact grown by expanding its market overseas and emphasizing the smaller, fancier stoves that appeal to owners of second homes. ''The market has moved upscale to enameled, highly efficient models,'' he said. ''A lot of people who used to burn wood for primary heat are becoming recreational wood burners.''
Roger Mann Jr. has been in the wood business in Waterville for 15 years. As the price of diesel fuel, chain saws and log skidders has gone up, so has his price for a cord of wood - ''$85 in the country and a city fee when I deliver around Burlington.'' He travels as much as 300 miles a day, making three round trips to Burlington.
''In the early 80's,'' he said, ''I'd take my customers a load of logs, and they'd have a chain saw and a splitter to cut it up. Now they want their wood already split. I see a lot of splitters and chain saws just sitting in the corner. They're expensive pieces of equipment.''
To be sure, wood still has its fans. Robert Sherman, a lobbyist who lives in Washington, Vt., owns 400 acres and burns about eight cords of wood a year to heat his house. ''I love to cut wood,'' he said. ''It's great exercise. I love being in the woods and cutting it and splitting it - the whole process. I also love the fact that you never have to worry what the thermostat is set at.''
More typical is Rodney Morris, a teacher. Once, when he wanted heat, he would wad newspapers, pile kindling on top of them and chunks of wood on top of that. Sometimes the wood was dry. More often it wasn't. It would splutter and steam before it caught. He couldn't travel in the winter: his pipes might freeze and burst.
''I was tired of water all over the floor from the melting ice because I never had my wood under cover,'' he said. ''I was tired of competing with the stove for the available oxygen in the house. The last straw was realizing how many burn holes there were in the linoleum in front of the stove.'' Now he has a propane heater. Just turn the dial.

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST: PRAGUE'S SHAKY BARGAIN;
The Government Seeks to Stop the Decline In Industry Before It Leads to a Rebellion

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Czechoslovakia is like a young man who inherits a fortune from his grandfather and fritters it away, dissipating the capital instead of investing it wisely. Two generations ago, at the time of World War I, this was a rich country, with two-thirds of the industrial capacity of the entire Austro-Hungarian Empire concentrated in Bohemia and Moravia, which make up the western two-thirds of Czechoslovakia. The Skoda armaments works and the Bata shoe factories were world famous.
The region was comparable to Pittsburgh or Manchester or the Ruhr. 
Now Czechoslovak industry is inefficient, old-fashioned and undercapitalized. Soft coal still turns many wheels; its soot and its smell are everywhere. The famous glass industry, which once taught the world, is trapped in the styles and technology of the 1930's. The machine-tool industry cannot supply the computer-driven elements that can be ordered from Japan or West Germany. And things are getting worse. If the Communist Government cannot halt the rot, and many of its own economists doubt that it can, it will eventually be unable to deliver on its side of the bargain that has kept the Czechoslovak public quiet for the last two decades: We'll keep your standard of living up, and you leave the political decisions in our hands.
 
Threat to the Social Contract
So far, Czechoslovak consumers have been served. There were lines outside a greengrocer's shop on Narodni Street on Monday, but they were not terribly long, and there were plenty of oranges, grapefruit and lemons available. Most manufactured goods are dowdy or shabby or both - skimpy towels, tinny pans, rough gray writing paper, oafish shoes. A grandmother, looking for children's books for Christmas presents in a shop near Wenceslaus Square on Tuesday, shook her head at the pitifully small selection that was available.
Still, most shelves are full, and Government subsidies keep prices low. A bottle of decent Moravian wine can be bought for $3 retail, for example.
Now, the underpinnings are threatened, and with them the unwritten, unspoken contract between the rulers and ruled. The economies of the Soviet Union and Poland, both prime trading partners, are in tatters. The spread of peace in various parts of the world has hit hard at Czechoslovak munitions plants, like those in Brno that produce automatic rifles.
Many Arab countries have turned out to be customers who don't pay on time. So feelers have gone out from an increasingly desperate Government to what a Western diplomat calls ''the kind of ideologically unsound countries that they'd never have done business with in better times'' - Taiwan, South Korea and Chile.
 
Revisions and Inflation
Even Israel. Edgar Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress, was in town this week talking to the leadership about a number of matters and Israel, he said, ''would be the ideal kind of trade partner for them.''
Extensive revisions have also been proposed in the domestic economy, including limited authority for managers of state enterprises to hire and fire employees. So far, most American experts who have examined the plants have been unimpressed, largely because of the absence of entrepreneurial elements.
What Mikos Jakes and the rest of the Czechoslovak leadership are trying to do is what the Yugoslavs and the Hungarians have already failed to do: restructure the economy without setting off an inflationary spiral and without lowering the standard of living. Both of those countries have considerably more political and economic flexibility in their systems than Czechoslovakia.
It will not be easy, even in a nation with a 150-year legacy of industrial skills and enterprise.
 
'Words Aren't Enough Anymore'
''If the new ideas don't work,'' a prominent Czechoslovak journalist said, ''then you'll see people in the streets. People here are bourgeois. We tend to think about a roof over our heads and a meal on our plates before we think about abstract ideals. So we look around, we like our situation better than Poland's, where there's nothing to eat, or Hungary's, where it costs too much.
''Those are essentially aristocratic countries, where people are willing, even happy, to live on debt and glory in a way that we're not.''
A middle-level hotel employee said: ''Words aren't enough anymore. I admire Vaclav Havel and the other dissidents, sure, but I won't raise my head above the wall until they show me that they can run things.''
All of that would probably change, of course, if Poland or Hungary or East Germany showed marked economic progress over the next year. The Czechoslovaks are accustomed to comparing themselves to the Austrians and the Germans, not the Russians and the Bulgarians, and the stirring that is palpable today could become an earthquake if Mr. Jakes or his successor lets Czechoslovakia, an island of resistance to change in a changing Europe, fall behind the others.
Mr. Dienstbier, a wry man, sat in his center-city apartment the other night and told of a visit from an elderly Communist, a former Politburo member, still a member of Parliament.
''For 40 years,'' the dissident said, laughing, ''this man has known when the wind was shifting. He's never been wrong. So if he wants to know me now, he must see something that isn't obvious to us yet. It must mean that the sleepy Czechs are awakening.''

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
Walesa Warns on Reunification Of Germany, Citing Hitler's Rule

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity movement in Poland, gave a sharp warning today against any early consideration of the reunification of Germany.
In a talk to the National Press Club here, Mr. Walesa, who is on a weeklong visit to the United States, applauded the changes occurring throughout Eastern Europe. But when asked about reuniting East Germany and West Germany, he offered the long-held Polish wariness of a united nation. 
''This is a bomb,'' he said of the issue. ''We paid a heavy price for the existence of Hitler. I do not need to say how heavy.''
In addition to the heavy casualties the Polish people suffered during World War II at the hands of Hitler, he said, ''there was a second nation on Polish soil, the Jewish nation, and it disappeared.''
''We have to do everything to avoid repeating mistakes,'' he said.
 
A Step Before Reunification
Mr. Walesa said that with the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, he favored moves toward an economically united Europe. Only then could German reunification be considered.
Earlier, he told a small audience at the Board of International Broadcasting that ''we cannot make a mistake here'' when asked about reunifying Germany. ''We have had enough of bad solutions. We should leave the political situation as it is now.''
Mr. Walesa told the National Press Club audience that if Europe could be integrated economically, the issue of German borders would naturally arise because the current situation is ''artificial.''
''Economic integration will necessarily be followed by political integration,'' he said. ''If we try to do it in reverse, it will inevitably lead to disaster.''
 
An Electrician With Influence
Mr. Walesa sought to soften his harsh words by concluding with a smile, ''Of course, this is only the opinion of an electrician.'' But while he is indeed a former electrician and while he holds no official Government position, he remains the most influential public figure in Poland.
Mr. Walesa has been a relentless salesman during his visit, urging American entrepreneurs to invest in Poland.
''The Iron Curtain is no more,'' he said at the press club. ''We have fought and we have won, but the victory is mostly a theoretical victory.'' He said it amounted to ''a beautiful house of cards'' that would collapse without a lot of American aid and investment.
On Wednesday, in a speech to a joint session of Congress, Mr. Walesa called for an investment and loan program along the lines of the Marshall Plan, which was used to help rebuild Western Europe after World War II.
At today's luncheon, when the moderator announced that the program was over, Mr. Walesa interrupted and complained cheerfully that no one had asked him a question that allowed him to make a sales pitch, which he then offered.
 
The Question of Anti-Semitism
Mr. Walesa's remarks about the fate of Polish Jews prompted him to complain about what he said was the chronic accusation that Poles have been anti-Semitic. He said, ''This is something we cannot catch up with, cannot eliminate.''
''In Poland all or nearly all the Jews were murdered,'' he said. ''Of course, there were some pigs, as there are pigs everywhere, but not the whole country.''
''Cohabitation with Jews was profitable'' for Poles, he said. ''For Jews cohabitation with Poles was profitable. Please stop those who, even today, try to play the political card of anti-Semitism.''
