HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
NATO Officials See Role in Transition of Europe

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Playing down its traditional role as a military alliance, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has begun arguing that it is the instrument through which the United States and Western Europe can best manage the political transition of Eastern Europe.
Senior NATO officials here said a strong Western alliance remained essential, not only as a shield against possible outbreaks of violent unrest in Eastern Europe or the Soviet Union but also as a framework for negotiating the terms of any future reunification of Germany.
''At a time of generalized euphoria, it is our job to be cautious and prudent,'' one official said. ''We have to adjust to events, but we can't lower our guard.'' 
The officials further noted that it was vital for the United States to participate in the reshaping of Europe and that this was only possible through NATO. ''Take away the United States and a decisive factor of stability in Europe has gone,'' said NATO's secretary general, Manfred Worner.
 
Defining Its Role
NATO's sudden need to redefine its role in more political terms reflects the tremendous impact that recent events in Eastern Europe have had on an organization that had come to view the Berlin wall as the ultimate symbol of its reason for existence. With the Soviet military threat seen to be shrinking as democracy spreads through Eastern Europe, the alliance has had to come up with reasons to justify why it continues to be necessary.
The 16-nation alliance, which for most of the last four decades has represented the West in its dealing with the East, is also now being quietly challenged for leadership by the European Community. Several European governments believe the Community should even assume some security responsibilities so that Europeans - and not Americans or Soviets - can design the new Europe.
In reality, 11 of the 12 members of the Community are also in NATO. But that coincidence has not sufficed to eliminate tensions because, while the United States belongs only to the alliance, France, which is currently president of the European Community and is strongly committed to promoting a European solution, has only limited participation in NATO.
Worried that the Soviet and American Presidents will make crucial decisions about Europe without consulting Europeans when they meet off Malta on Dec. 2 and 3, President Francois Mitterrand of France has invited other Community leaders for dinner in Paris Saturday to prepare their own strategy for Eastern Europe.
 
A Briefing in Brussels
The United States, in contrast, still prefers to work through NATO, where its influence remains enormous. And, to reinforce this position, either President Bush or his Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, is expected to travel to Brussels to brief NATO ministers on the outcome of the Malta summit on Dec. 4.
''There is a temptation, particularly among some European members, to use other, smaller focus for collective approaches to common problems,'' said William H. Taft IV, the chief United States delegate to NATO. ''Whichever course is chosen, our concern is that European unity not be purchased at the expense of Atlantic cooperation.''
Many NATO officials in fact believe the alliance's importance will grow as developments in Eastern Europe bring new tensions to a European Community already strained by disagreements over the speed and extent of its own economic and political integration.
''I even have my doubts that the process of the political-economic reunification of Europe would continue without the umbrella of NATO, without the commitment of the United States,'' Mr. Worner said in an interview.
 
Question of Reunification
Specifically, some officials believe the military-political nature of NATO will enable it to handle the delicate question of German reunification more easily than the European Community, where some countries are already worried whether they can avoid being totally dominated by a single Germany.
''A strong NATO can act as a counter-balance to German might,'' one official said. ''In fact, there are some European governments that want the United States to stay in Europe to protect them as much from the Germans as from the Soviets.''
Another Western defense analyst said that although the Bonn Government had repeated its commitments to both NATO and the European Community, the alliance would nonetheless have to reduce the political and even psychological burden to West Germany of membership of NATO.
Already this year, Bonn successfully demanded that NATO postpone a decision on modernizing short-range nuclear weapons currently stationed on its territory. Now, with German reunification the talk of Europe, the expert said Bonn's acceptance of a new generation of missiles ''that only kill Germans'' was virtually impossible.

LENGTH: 706 words

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
Europeans Press Case For Shaping the Future

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
As the European Community prepares to meet over the dramatic developments in East Germany, politicians and commentators say that its 12 member countries hope to make clear the importance of their role in fashioning Europe's future before the meeting next month between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
Some analysts said they thought the hastily called summit meeting in Paris on Saturday would give the Europeans a chance to organize their positions and remind the superpowers that the first major response to the developments in Eastern Europe should come from the countries most affected.
Analysts said the community wanted to avoid a situation that developed during the superpower summit in October 1986 in which President Reagan agreed to remove cruise missiles stationed in Europe without first consulting his European allies.
On a visit to West Berlin today, the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said the European Community must quickly decide the framework within which to deal with Eastern European countries emerging into democracy. 
 
Membership for the East Bloc
In Bonn earlier in the day, Mr. Hurd did not rule out eventual European Community membership for countries like Hungary and Poland when they became fully democratic. But echoing Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, he said the first step ''will probably be some form of associate membership,'' similar to that enjoyed by Turkey.
The Paris summit meeting is seen by some commentators as an attempt by President Francois Mitterrand of France to deal with the German question quickly and keep the agenda of the European Community's meeting in Strasbourg in December clear for two projects he favors, European monetary union and a European social charter.
Those analysts said President Mitterrand hoped that accelerated steps toward monetary and economic union in Europe would lock West Germany into the union and prevent the Community's plans from being derailed by East European revisions.
Developments in Eastern Europe, and the West's reaction to them, continue to dominate headlines, editorials, news bulletins and political commentary in Western Europe. An editorial in El Pais, Madrid's leading newspaper, said there were ''two contradictory attitudes among European political circles: joy at the progress of democracy'' and ''concern, even anguish over the expiration of political and mental structures.''
 
No Talk of Dissolving NATO
In Belgium, political comment has turned cautious after the initial euphoria produced by television images of the breaching of the Berlin wall. The Christian Democrat-Socialist coalition Government of Prime Minister Wilfried Martens, while welcoming the change, has emphasized that prudence in the face of an uncertain future is the best policy.
Defense Minister Guy Coeme of Belgium, who is a Socialist, has said that prospects for a settlement at negotiations on reduction of conventional forces had dramatically improved because of events in Germany but that there were currently no plans for decreases in defense spending, and there is almost no talk of dissolving NATO or reducing the 24,000 Belgian troops stationed in West Germany.
In Italy, Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti told Parliament on Wednesday that events in Eastern Europe had made it ''our obligation to accelerate the pace of European construction,'' despite the resistance of those countries that ''are not so much against economic and monetary union as against the very concept of European union.''
Sergio Romano, an editorial writer for the Turin daily La Stampa and a former Ambassador to Moscow, said in a telephone interview that in light of the summit meeting, he was writing an editorial that warned that ''Europeans must not frustrate German aspirations to unity.''
''Surely, a certain preoccupation is justified,'' Mr. Romano said. ''But not to the extent of creating a frustrated Germany again. We've seen frustrated Germans before.''
''This is a unique historical opportunity for political unity, not only monetary unity, which Europe must not miss,'' he said. ''The two superpowers will step back and a new space will be there to fill in. It is the time for Europeans to fill that space.''

HEADLINE: KILLING OF PRIESTS DENOUNCED BY U.S.

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The Bush Administration today condemned the killing of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador and said it had asked President Alfredo Cristiani to order a full inquiry.
The State Department spokesman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said the United States did not yet know who was responsible for the killings, apart from circumstantial evidence from El Salvador of Army involvement. The Rev. Jose Maria Tojeira, the Jesuit Provincial for Central America, said that the victims were tortured before they were killed, but this could be not independently confirmed.
''We do not know who committed this barbarous act, which we condemn in the strongest possible terms,'' Miss Tutwiler said. Other State Department officials said that William J. Walker, the American Ambassador, had raised the matter today with President Cristiani. 
''We made the point that there has to be the fullest inquiry and certainly a rapid one,'' one American official said. ''Cristiani said he was undertaking a complete investigation.''
In El Salvador, Eduardo Valdez, the director of Jesuit studies there, said that the Jesuits had received many anonymous threats in recent days and that a rightist death squad was probably responsible for the killings. But a Jesuit priest who asked not to be identified said that a witness at the site of the killings saw about 30 uniformed soldiers enter the university grounds and the priests' residence shortly before shots were heard.
In a letter today to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, the human rights organization America's Watch said circumstantial evidence indicated that the Salvadoran military carried out the killings. It called on the Bush Administration to take ''firm and immediate measures'' to prevent further slayings.
Citing reports from church officials in El Salvador, the letter said that a large contingent of soldiers had surrounded the Jesuit university grounds for the last several days. It said that the soldiers had searched the Jesuit rectory where the priests were killed while the Rev. Ignacio Ellacuria, one of the priests killed, was present.
''We call upon the United States to denounce these killings and to insist on punishment of the soldiers responsible,'' the letter to Mr. Baker said.
If the Salvadoran military played a role in the killings, the Bush Administration will come under pressure from Congress and human rights organizations to suspend American military aid to El Salvador.
Miss Tutwiler confirmed that the Salvadoran military had asked for arms and ammunition to help beat back a rebel offensive, and she said that the Administration was ''moving to address their needs.''
In 1980, under President Carter, the United States briefly suspended new military and economic aid to El Salvador pending a clarification of the role of Salvadoran security forces in the killing of three American nuns and a lay missionary.
When the Reagan Administration took over, it initially blamed ''right wing'' elements for the murders. It was later determined that those religious workers were killed by National Guard troops, who were eventually prosecuted and convicted.
At a hearing on Friday, the Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on Western Hemisphere Affairs will question the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, Bernard W. Aronson, on the slaying of the priests and the escalating violence in El Salvador.
''I am devastated by these cold-blooded murders, which appear intended to silence human rights activity in El Salvador,'' said Senator Claiborne Pell, the Rhode Island Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations committee.
''I appeal most urgently for an end to the fighting and for a cease-fire so that civilian wounded can be evacuated, he said, ''and ask that those responsible for these murders be brought to justice as swiftly as possible.''

PUB-DATE: November 17, 1989

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1061 words

HEADLINE: 6 PRIESTS KILLED IN A CAMPUS RAID IN SAN SALVADOR

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Six Jesuit priests, including the rector of a leading university, were killed here before dawn today by what one witness described as a group of 30 men dressed in military uniforms.
Most of the priests were dragged from their beds in cubicles in a dormitory at the Jose Simeon Canas University of Central America on the outskirts of the capital and shot in the head with high-powered rifles, apparently of the same type issued by the army. The Jesuits' cook and her 15-year-old daughter were also shot to death.
''They were assassinated with lavish barbarity'' said the Rev. Jose Maria Tojeira, the Jesuit Provincial for Central America. ''For example, they took out their brains.'' 
 
Torture Is Reported
He said the victims were tortured before they were killed, though this could not be independently confirmed.
In Washington, the Bush Administration condemned the killings ''in the strongest possible terms,'' and said it had asked the Salvadoran President, Alfredo Cristiani, to make a full inquiry. [Page A12.] Colleagues of the dead priests and some human rights monitors blamed the army or right-wing death squads for the killings, which provoked outrage here. They noted that only Government forces were able to move freely during the dawn-to-dusk curfew now in effect.
 
Government Vows Inquiry
The Government denied it was responsible and denounced the killings. It promised an investigation and said the rebels had the most compelling motive for the slayings, strongly hinting that the rebels were responsible.
If the army is found to have been responsible for the killings, this would probably cause severe strains in its relations with the United States, which has been the Salvadoran Government's chief supporter for more than a decade. It has supplied the Government with hundreds of millions of dollars in military and economic aid and an American military advisory team has been involved for most of that period in helping to train Salvadoran armed forces.
The killings came during a major military offensive by leftist guerrillas that began on Saturday night and has touched off the fiercest fighting in the decade-old civil war, which has claimed 70,000 lives.
 
Soldiers Ring University
A letter issued in Washington by Americas Watch, a human rights organization, said that for the last several days, a large contingent of soldiers had surrounded the Jesuit university grounds and that a group of soldiers had searched the rectory where the priests were killed.
Persuasive evidence has often linked the army and the governing party -the Nationalist Republican Alliance, known by its Spanish acronym, Arena - to the death squads. In the early 1980's, they marked for assassination those who tried to organize the left or criticize the right.
Until the shootings today, the most notorious attack occurred in March 1980 when Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero of San Salvador was shot to death as he was saying Mass in the chapel of a hospital. Political opponents of Roberto d'Aubuisson, the leader of Arena, accused him of responsibility for the killing.
The victims of today's killings included Ignacio Ellacuria Beas Coechea, the rector of the university, who was a critic of right-wing violence; Ignacio Martin-Baro, the Vice Rector and a leading expert on Salvadoran public opinion, and Segundo Montes, the dean of the school's department of social sciences. The three other slain priests were identified by colleagues as Joaquin Lopez y Lopez, Amando Lopez and Juan Ramon Moreno. The Jesuit's cook, Julia Elba Ramos, and her daughter, Celina, were found shot to death in the bed they shared.
''They did not want to leave witnesses,'' said Eduardo Valdez, director of Jesuit studies at the university, which is considered one of the best in the region.
An employee of the university who said he saw the killings of the six priests told their colleagues that about 30 men broke into the back of the rectory shortly after 3 A.M.
According this account, the intruders tossed a bomb into the one-story, stucco building, and shot two of the priests in their sleeping cubicles and then killed the cook and her daughter.
Colleagues of the victims said the witness had told them that the three other priests were dragged from their beds. The attackers then went next door to Father Ellacuria's small home, gathered the four men on the lawn and killed them.
A sign left with the bodies saying the killings were the work of rebels was being widely dismissed by the colleagues of the priests as amateurish dissimulation.
 
'Crime of Such Repugnance'
The United States Ambassador, William J. Walker, denounced the crime and said it played into the hands of the rebels. But he acknowledged that an investigation would be almost impossible during the current heavy fighting.
''This is a crime of such repugnance that to say that I condemn or deplore seems inadequate,'' he said in a briefing. ''It is a barbaric act that has brought shame to El Salvador.''
''I have difficulty in imagining what sort of animals would, in cold blood, execute priests, and other innocents,'' he said.
The killings came a day after Mr. d'Aubuisson issued a thinly veiled threat against rebel sympathizers. He warned Salvadorans who had known about the coming rebel offensive but had not informed the Government. In the past, death squads have often followed up similar warnings by killing those Mr. d'Aubuisson had publicly criticized.
In testimony before a Congressional committee, Robert White, the former United States Ambasador to Salvador, referred to Mr. d'Aubuisson as a ''pathological killer,'' saying the State Department had ''compelling if not 100 percent convincing evidence'' that he had ordered the killing of Archbishop Romero. Had Been Shunned by U.S. Mr. d'Aubuisson had been shunned by American officials since 1984 when the United States learned that he had reportedly ordered the killing of Thomas Pickering, then the American Ambassador. That policy of ostracism was ended when Vice President Quayle met with Mr. d'Aubuisson last June.
The university, which was started as an alternative to the radicalized National University, is one of the most highly respected in Central America. But for more than a decade the extreme right has accused its Jesuit teachers of favoring the rebels and fostering subversion.

SECTION: Section A; Page 39, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 735 words

HEADLINE: DIALOGUE ON CHANGING SOVIET FORCES - IS MOSCOW CUTTING ITS MILITARY?;
Yes, By Necessity

BYLINE: By Barry M. Blechman; Barry M. Blechman is chairman of the Henry L. Stimson Center, a research and educational organization.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
State Department analysts have concluded that Soviet military spending will decline in 1989, to between 14 and 16 percent of gross national product, down from 15 to 17 percent in 1988. While this conclusion is disputed by others in the Government, the evidence is overwhelming.
Less than a year after Mikhail Gorbachev's surprise announcement of dramatic cuts in his military forces, reductions in Soviet military deployments and operations are accelerating rapidly. The cutbacks, which will bite deeply into important Soviet military capabilities, are the result of necessity, not choice. 
By cutting military spending, Mr. Gorbachev hopes to free the capital, skilled manpower and technology needed for modernizing the sick Soviet economy. By moderating Western perceptions of the Soviet military threat, Mr. Gorbachev no doubt hopes that the cutbacks also will help his nation gain greater access to Western technology, capital and expertise.
Whatever the reason, the cutbacks - and further cuts sure to come -will diminish significantly the Soviet threat to vital Western interests in several categories, including:
Ground and air forces. Unilateral cutbacks amount to perhaps 15 percent of Soviet forces. Roughly one-half the total reductions of 500,000 personnel - including 100,000 officers - will come in Eastern Europe and the European portions of the Soviet Union. By the end of 1990, 10,000 tanks, 8,500 artillery pieces and 800 aircraft will have been removed.
When completed in 1990, the reductions - estimated by a House Armed Services Committee delegation to reduce Soviet capabilities in Eastern Europe by 20 to 25 percent - will make it impossible for Moscow to mount a surprise attack in Europe.
Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev has stated that annual tank production would drop to 1,700 in 1989, one-half the number that the U.S. says were produced annually, on average, between 1986 and 1988. Western intelligence sources confirm that Soviet tank production is declining.
Naval forces. According to a Defense Department publication, ''Soviet Military Power,'' Soviet naval activity outside home waters has dropped by 15 percent, and further cuts can be expected. Even at current production rates, Moscow is not producing warships and submarines fast enough to maintain the strength of its rapidly aging fleet. And Soviet civilian analysts say that the next five-year plan includes major cutbacks in shipbuilding. Western observers already have noted delays in completing Moscow's first large aircraft carrier and slowdowns in submarine production.
Nuclear Forces. Although the Kremlin continues to operate formidable modern missile forces, it is phasing out older nuclear forces. According to the Natural Resources Defense Council, the Soviet nuclear stockpile peaked in 1988; substantial reductions can be expected in coming years.
Programs to deploy modern weapons also are being cut back. For example, the Soviet Blackjack bomber, long expected as a counter to our B-1, is apparently being abandoned.
Obviously, not all weapon programs will be terminated. The Soviet Defense Minister, Dmitri Yazov, said in early October that Moscow would continue developing and producing new variants of strategic missiles. The appearance of a new model of the SS-18 - much remarked upon by conservatives - confirms this position.
On the other hand, many futuristic weapon programs appear to have been abandoned. ''Soviet Military Power,'' for example, makes little or no mention of a follow up to the SS-24, a new class of strategic submarines, new submarine-launched cruise and ballistic missiles or the SA-X-12, a surface-to-air missile. Each of these strategic systems previously was said to be under development.
Clearly, Mr. Gorbachev's initiatives have opened the door for negotiated reductions that would complement and reinforce the radical political changes underway in Eastern Europe. Yet, we should not respond to the unilateral Soviet cutbacks with unilateral cuts in our own forces. Instead, we should seek to pocket the concessions already made, before Mr. Gorbachev's enthusiasm for the talks fades in the face of growing opposition from the military.
Defense Minister Yazov has said that Moscow could cut its defense spending by 50 percent if the negotiations are successful. We should not disappoint the Minister; both countries could make productive use of the resources.

HEADLINE: MILITARY TO DRAFT PLAN FOR A 6% CUT IN 1992-94 SPENDING

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON with STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has ordered the nation's armed services to draw up plans for cutting $180 billion in projected spending, reflecting the Bush Administration's judgment that Federal deficits and political changes in Europe are leading toward a smaller Pentagon budget.
In addition, Mr. Cheney appears prepared to accept a decline in military spending in the fiscal year 1991 after inflation is taken into account, a senior Administration official said. The Administration will present its 1991 spending plan to Congress in January.
The $180 billion in cuts by the services would cover Pentagon spending from the fiscal years 1992 through 1994. It would represent an average annual drop of about 5 percent in spending after inflation over the three-year period, Administration officials said. President Bush had previously proposed increases of 1 or 2 percent in each of these years. 
 
No Decision at Hand
A senior Pentagon official said Mr. Cheney has made no decision on whether to go forward with all the $180 billion in reductions and added that the exercise is intended to force the services to identify their priorities and to set an outer limit for negotiating somewhat less extensive trims.
Administration officials said a $180 billion reduction could mean extensive base closings, deactivation of several Army divisions and the retirement of two or three aircraft carriers. That would mark a retrenchment equivalent to the decline that followed the Vietnam War. A Pentagon official said, however, that if the cuts were enacted, the Defense Department would do everything it could to avoid reductions in forces by paring spending on maintenance and on installations.
 
One of Potential Sources of Cuts
But this official and other Administration specialists said the orders were significant because they represent a recognition that the twin pressures of budget deficits and political changes in Europe have eroded Mr. Bush's earlier plans for slow, steady growth in the Pentagon budget.
With the White House committed not to increase taxes, cuts in military spending represent one of the few potential sources of money to pay for Administration programs that Mr. Bush has begun with great fanfare but limited financing, including his effort to combat drug abuse. The military budget represents about a quarter of total Federal spending but has well over half the money available for reductions because programs like Medicare and Social Social Security have been relatively politically difficult to cut.
''We have got to be prepared for the inevitable, instead of waiting for it to happen and doing the cuts in haste,'' a senior Pentagon official said.
''This is quite serious,'' another official said. ''It is not a game.''
 
'Worst-Case Scenario'
Another senior official in a military service termed the proposed $180 billion cuts a ''worst-case scenario'' intended to produce options for Mr. Cheney, but added: ''This is not a bookkeeping exercise. My sense is that if we do not take the bull by the horns we will be gored by it.''
Sean O'Keefe, the Pentagon's comptroller, sent a directive to the services Monday night ordering them to devise plans for cuts by today because the recent changes in Eastern Europe added new momentum to the growing movement on Capitol Hill for significant reductions in the military budget.
The Pentagon comptroller's directive was intended in part to change the Pentagon ''culture'' in which the military based plans on the assumption that military spending would steadily increase in the future, officials said.
 
'Not All Asleep at the Switch'
''What this indicates is that we are not all asleep at the switch,'' an official said. ''This building is going through culture shock. The services have always assumed you have got to produce some kind of growth out there.''
Members of Congress have warned in recent days that East Germany's decision to open its border to the West will lead to a further erosion of public support for military spending. By some estimates, about 60 percent of military spending is devoted to the defense of Western Europe.
Cuts in American military spending will come at a time when the Soviet Union is beginning to make its own cuts in military spending, apparently fulfilling the promises made by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. Mr. Gorbachev has said the Soviet Union will cut its military spending by 14.2 percent. Soviet officials said the cuts will occur over three years, beginning with a 1.5 percent cut in 1989, 7 percent in 1990 and 5.7 in 1991.
Conservative members of Congress, like Senator Jim Exon, a Nebraska Democrat on the Armed Services Committee, said the Pentagon must now be prepared to accept cuts after inflation of up to 5 percent over the next several years.
''I would say that if the Defense Department suffered only a 2 percent per year annual cut over the next five years, it would be a miracle,'' said Senator Exon, who heads the Armed Services' Subcommittee on Strategic Forces and Nuclear Deterrence. ''There is a general perception in the land that peace has broken out all over. The public will demand, and the Congress will respond in some fashion.''
Mr. Bush pledged strong support for military spending in last year's Presidential election campaign, portraying Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts as soft on the military.
 
Temper Spending Plans
But the growing Federal deficit is forcing the Bush Administration to temper its plans, Administration officials said.
Mr. Bush has proposed spending about $295 billion on the military in fiscal 1990, which keeps pace with inflation. Congress is the process of approving the fiscal 1990 spending plan.
The Administration is now preparing its military spending request for fiscal 1991, which will be reviewed by the Cabinet in early December and sent to Congress in January.
Mr. Bush had projected a $311 billion Pentagon budget for fiscal 1991, a 1 percent increase on top of inflation.
One Pentagon official said, however, that preliminary cuts of $13 billion to $14 billion have been identified in the projected spending for fiscal 1991, although the military services are expected to appeal some of the cuts.
Pentagon officials are considering a range of options, including a cut of 3 to 4 percent in the fiscal 1991 budget after the effects of inflation are taken into account. Already, the fiscal 1990 budget now before Congress marks the fifth consecutive year that military spending has decreased after the effects of inflation are discounted.
Cuts of the magnitude under discussion are likely to force members of Congress to make an unpleasant choice between closing bases and canceling weapons that provide work for large numbers of constituents.
''Cheney is right,'' said Senator Patrick J. Leahy, a Vermont Democrat who serves on the Appropriations Committee's Subcommittee on Defense. ''There are bases that will have to be closed, and we're going to have to accept that. We're not going to be able to just stretch out procurement costs to save money.
 
'Some Serious Choices'
''There will be some serious choices about cutting whole systems,'' Mr. Leahy continued, ''and that's going to hurt some companies that are major employers in member's districts.''
''We can't do this by nickel and diming,'' Senator Leahy said.
Representative Les Aspin, Democrat of Wisconsin, has said that next year's spending plan will be the first ''Gorbachev-driven budget,'' an allusion to the political changes encouraged in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe by Mr. Gorbachev. Other lawmakers agreed, but said that the deficit remains a significant factor pushing military spending downward.
Senator Malcolm Wallop, Republican of Wyoming, said the tide had shifted in Congress for lower spending. He expressed concern that Congress was being overwhelmed by a ''1935-style isolationism'' but said Pentagon budgets of zero real growth could be preserved if Mr. Bush exerts vigorous leadership.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 20, 1989, Monday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A headline in some editions on Saturday, with an article about the reduction in spending that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has ordered the armed services to plan for, misstated the percentage of the reduction. With inflation taken into account, it would average about 5 percent annually for the fiscal years 1992 through 1994.

HEADLINE: Doors Closing as Mood on the Homeless Sours

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER

 BODY:
As New Yorkers become increasingly disturbed and exasperated by the overwhelming presence of homeless people, more and more public institutions are adopting policies intended to keep out the homeless.
Dr. Kim Hopper, an assistant professor of anthropology at the New School who has extensively studied the homeless, said the new policies reflected the public's growing sense of helplessness.
''They're thinking,'' Dr. Hopper said, '' 'It's still going on after all these years and after all this money has been poured into it, maybe it's time to get tough.' The public is being misled into thinking that these folks have had their chance.''
The tougher attitude is particularly evident in the city's transportation centers. 
Last month the transit police began enforcing rules that prohibit behavior like begging, lying down or sleeping in subway stations or cars. At the same time, efforts are being made to coax homeless people from the stations and into shelters. Advocates for the homeless say, however, the rules have the effect of forcing homeless people out of certain stations in Manhattan, where enforcement efforts are concentrated, and into other stations or onto the streets.
Since last year, only passengers with tickets have been allowed into the Port Authority Bus Terminal after 1 A.M. A few months ago, the terminal began replacing its old wood seats with narrow plastic ''flip seats.'' The seats, which are six and a half inches deep and fold down like theater seats, require so much concentration to balance that sleeping or even sitting for long is impossible.
A train ticket is needed to sit in the new waiting area that opened in September at Grand Central Terminal, and the six benches there now represent the only public seating in the entire terminal.
At Pennsylvania Station, Amtrak also restricts its waiting area to passengers with tickets, and it has begun stationing police officers outside restrooms to prevent people from sleeping inside.
 
Private Institutions Take Action, Too
Private institutions are taking similar steps. An organization of homeless people had been meeting on Saturday mornings for a year in the sculpture garden at the Whitney Museum Annex inside the Philip Morris Building, across 42d Street from Grand Central. But in August, signs were posted banning meetings there.
''We've been coexisting with the homeless since we've been in the building,'' a spokesman for Philip Morris, George L. Knox, said. ''But one Saturday they had nearly 200 people in there. We said: 'It's enough. You have taken over the space.' ''
Officials at the institutions, as well as advocates for the homeless, said the restrictions had emerged as a result of the failure, after nearly a decade, to ease homelessness. The homeless who are living on the streets and in public spaces are having an economic effect on public agencies like the Transit Authority. And New Yorkers have grown tired of confronting homeless people every day on the subway, at the train station and at the entrances to supermarkets and apartment buildings.
''People are tired of stepping over bodies,'' the advocacy director for the Coalition for the Homeless, Keith Summa, said.
Lynette Thompson, a Transit Authority official who oversees the outreach program for the homeless in the subway, said there had been a marked change this year in letters from riders.
''At the beginning of last year, the tenor of those letters was, 'Please do something to help the homeless,' '' Ms. Thompson said. ''But since August and September, they've been saying: 'Just get them out. I don't care. Just get them out any way you can.' It got worse, and people got fed up.''
Transit officials said they worried that ridership levels, already flat, would decline because of deepening aversion to homeless people who not only panhandle, but also live in stations. According to Transit Authority figures, average weekday ridership so far this year is just 0.4 percent higher than in the same period last year.
''If we get a decreased ridership, we eventually get decreased funds from state, city and Federal sources,'' Ms. Thompson said. ''If we get decreased funds, then we go into a downward spiral, and then we go into decreasing service.''
 
Expensive Effort And Major Distraction
For the homeless, the new restrictions mean it is more difficult than ever to find a place to rest. Charles Lark, 29 years old, who said he had spent the last three years sleeping on subway trains and platforms, left New York on the day the subway-enforcement program began. ''This is a coldhearted city,'' he said. ''I'm going to Washington. I hope it'll be better there.''
''The mere fact that we have to devote so much time and effort to dealing with the homeless in our facilities is a sign of a lot of other people's failures,'' said Stephen Berger, executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which is spending more than $1 million this year on social services for the homeless.
In all, New York City will spend more than $320 million this year to shelter 25,000 single homeless people, as well as 11,000 homeless families. Although the city has reduced the number of homeless families in the system, from 5,200 in August 1988 to 3,800 now, the number of people on the streets has continued to increase.
No one knows precisely how many people live on the street. Some estimates put the number at 40,000 to 60,000. An estimated one-third are mentally ill or drug abusers, or both. Estimates of the number of homeless people in the subways - on platforms and trains as well as rat-infested tunnels near the electrified third rail - range from 2,000 to 4,000.
Advocates for the homeless, as well as the homeless themselves, say city-run shelters, where widespread drug abuse and violence have been documented, are too frightening and overwhelming to serve people on the street.
In his successful campaign for mayor, David N. Dinkins said in response to a questionnaire from the Coalition for the Homeless that he would close 80 percent of the municipal shelters for singles by July 1991 and replace them with transitional and permanent housing. He also said he would create community rescue centers, for fewer than 100 people each.
Nancy Wackstein, a member of Mr. Dinkins's transition staff who has been his policy adviser for social services, said yesterday that although Mr. Dinkins still intended to fulfill the pledges, that might be more difficult than anticipated.
''There is an intent to pursue that path,'' Ms. Wackstein said. ''But he's probably got a $1 billion budget problem. He's going to have to make the decision as to how he balances the needs of the homeless against the other needs of the city.''
 
The Public Reacts, With Ambivalence
Gauging the public attitude toward the homeless is difficult. In a New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll in June, 59 percent of the respondents said that they would pay more taxes to help the homeless.
Further, the advocacy groups for the homeless, as well as private shelters, say they have more volunteers and are receiving more contributions than ever. About 13,000 volunteers work at the 150 church and synagogue shelters of the Partnership for the Homeless. The Coalition for the Homeless reports that it receives 75 to 100 telephone calls a week from people who want to help.
Yet advocates for the homeless also see and understand the public's increasing frustration, as if a scale of tolerance is being tipped. When the Transit Authority polled its riders last spring, they found the two greatest sources of unease were homeless people and aggressive panhandlers -many of whom are not homeless.
''There's just too much of it,'' said Diane Sonde, director of Project Reachout, which serves the homeless mentally ill on the Upper West Side. ''You can't get away from it. People are tired of going to their neighborhood bank machine and having it opened by someone asking for money.''
Paula Dubrow, a freelance graphic designer, does more for the homeless than many New Yorkers. One night a week, she sleeps in a shelter at a synagogue on the Upper West Side. She gives money to people on the street. But she has come to dread riding the subway, because of the parade of panhandlers working their way through the cars.
''I'm never without a book now,'' Ms. Dubrow said. ''I hide behind that book, because I feel like I'm being assaulted. They're making me very uncomfortable - they should make me uncomfortable - and yet I don't know what I can do.''
When the Parks and Recreation Department adopted new rules in the spring, it deleted specific provisions against begging, sleeping and storing belongings in parks after civic and religious leaders had criticized the proposal.
''The public mood is both ways,'' Parks and Recreation Commissioner Henry J. Stern said. ''On the one hand, people don't want them around and demand that you remove them. On the other hand, people feel guilty and give them money.''
 
Daily Contact, Mounting Burden
Another purpose of the new policies is to try to lessen the enormous burdens felt by workers who never expected that dealing with homelessness would be part of their job.
As a Transit Authority superintendent, Urias Fritz is responsible for eight subway stations in lower Manhattan. Mr. Fritz started as a car cleaner 31 years ago and takes immense pride in his job. Over the years, he has come to know many of the homeless people who live underground, and he says he feels compassion for them. On winter days, he said, more than 60 people can be found on the mezzanine of the Broadway-Lafayette Street station, alone.
''I tell the people who work for me: 'This is another human being. You may not like the fact that he doesn't have a home, but that's a fact.''
As homelessness rises across the country, other cities are also adopting restrictive policies. Advocates for the homeless say the police arrested and otherwise harassed homeless people in downtown Miami last winter; the police said they arrested just those suspected of crimes. In Washington and San Francisco, gates are placed at the entrances of the subways at night to keep homeless people out, when the subways stop.
 
The Push to Expand Social Services
Along with the new restrictions, institutions have stepped up social services. Since January, teams of social workers have been offering services to homeless people in New York's subway stations. The efforts have had modest success.
From January through September, workers from the Volunteers of America said, they contacted 36,000 homeless people, with many of the contacts obviously repeats. Of those, 3,380, including 230 repeats, accepted services, and most of those were taken by van to city shelters. It is difficult to estimate how long people stay in the shelters.
The Human Resources Administration has also been sending outreach teams through the subways with the transit police. From January through Oct. 31, those teams contacted 5,056 people, with 1,445 being sent to city shelters.
Officials acknowledge that these efforts hardly address the complex social problems and housing policies that underlie homelessness.
''I don't pretend that the drop-in center is a solution to the problem,'' said Mr. Berger, referring to two centers the Port Authority has opened near the bus terminal and in lower Manhattan. ''It's a responsible Band-Aid.'' To an extent, courts have protected the rights of homeless people in public places. Last year, New York State's highest court, the Court of Appeals, struck down as unconstitutional a law that had banned loitering in major transportation centers. The law had sometimes been used to arrest homeless people. The new regulations are narrower, aiming to regulate patrons' behavior or to exclude those who are not traveling.
Advocates for the homeless warn that the restrictive policies indicate that if steps are not taken now to come to grips with homelessness, the problem may never be solved. The chairman of the Coalition for the Homeless, Robert M. Hayes, said small rescue centers and safe shelters should be established, to attract people off the streets. Then, he said, the people should be given appropriate housing and additional support like psychiatric care, drug treatment, remedial education and job training.
''It's a pivotal moment,'' Mr. Hayes said. ''The growing public frustration is forcing a response, and yet this particular response will have no effect on what is causing the frustration. There are not enough troops in the Western world to shove homeless people out of doors when there is no place else to go.
''The politicians are the best reflections of public opinion, and right now they're saying, 'Let's help those people.' The danger is that ultimately the public will just get fed up and say: 'Let's get rid of them. Put them on Rikers Island.' ''

Grand Central Terminal has a new waiting area only for ticketholders. HEADLINE: Clamor in the East;
Walesa's View of Glemp Irks Jewish Leaders

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS

 BODY:
When Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, entered a midtown law office yesterday to meet with about 70 leaders of Jewish organizations, he was enthusiastically applauded. In a scene that has become familiar during the Polish leader's weeklong visit to the United States, many in the audience stood and cheered.
But many of those present at the private hourlong meeting that followed said that significant disagreement surfaced on the issue of Polish anti-Semitism and the dispute over a Roman Catholic convent at the site of the Auschwitz death camp.
Mr. Walesa has complained that repeated accusations of Polish anti-Semitism are unfair and exaggerated, and create divisions that are hampering Poland's efforts to move toward democracy and a free-market economy. But many of the Jewish leaders told him it was important to acknowledge what they said was a sad but undeniable history. 
''There was a great disposition to greet him in the warmest possible way, to treat him as a hero,'' said Philip Baum, the associate executive director of the American Jewish Congress. ''People were very much captivated by him, although many found some of his answers very unsatisfying.''
Seymour D. Reich, president of B'nai B'rith and the chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations, presented Mr. Walesa with an ancient vase from Israel as a gift. Mr. Walesa kissed the vase and declared his ''love of Israel and the Jewish people,'' Mr. Reich said.
Mr. Reich said he was one of several who told Mr. Walesa that ''Polish anti-Semitism existed and it had to be acknowledged and it could not be hidden.'' He said that Mr. Walesa seemed to feel that such an emphasis ''could tarnish the mood for investment.''
Much of the discussion focused on the dispute over an agreement to move a convent from the Nazi death camp at Auschwitz and the position taken on the issue by Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland.
Although the Vatican agreed in 1987 to move the Carmelite convent in deference to complaints from Jews, Cardinal Glemp resisted and eventually repudiated the agreement, complaining of what he said were shrill Jewish protests.
Angered by Jews' insistence that the convent be moved in accordance with the agreement, Cardinal Glemp complained in August that national sovereignty and the ''feelings of all Poles'' were under attack from the Jewish community. In September, he relented and said the convent would be moved to an interfaith center to be built nearby.
Mr. Baum said that Mr. Walesa described the August statement as unfortunate and badly formulated.
Justin J. Finger, the associate national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, said that Mr. Walesa said he regretted that Cardinal Glemp had made the remarks, but that he considered the reaction to the Cardinal's statement to be excessive. Mr. Finger quoted Mr. Walesa as saying that the Cardinal ''is my Primate and I listen to him in matters of religion, but not politics.''
 
Leaves Some 'Quite Cold'
Robert K. Lifton, president of the American Jewish Congress, said that Mr. Walesa's ''defense of Cardinal Glemp left the community quite cold.'' He said that many pointed out to Mr. Walesa that the Solidarity newspaper had been quick to criticize the Cardinal.
''In view of that,'' Mr. Lifton said, ''I found it surprising he felt obliged not to say he disagreed with Glemp.''
Rabbi Henry D. Michelman, executive vice president of the Synagogue Council of America, said that Mr. Walesa ''spoke very directly about his abhorrence and rejection of anti-Semitism.'' Rabbi Michelman said that while he was slightly dismayed by some of Mr. Walesa's responses, he applauded his overall approach to Polish-Jewish relations.
In a meeting yesterday with editors of The New York Times, Mr. Walesa said he was greatly troubled by the dispute over the Auschwitz site and that he was ''ashamed that they can fight over a thing like that.''
Mr. Walesa said he told the Jewish organization leaders that ''the Jewish community is the nation that has paid the highest price in the history of the world. And we, the Polish nation, have paid the second highest price. Are we supposed to fight among ourselves?''
Mr. Walesa said that ''Auschwitz belongs to the world. It does not belong to any cardinals, it does not belong to Walesa, it does not belong to the Jews.''

HEADLINE: Senate Panel Proposing Increase In Tribal Control of Federal Aid

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Finishing a two-year investigation into corruption and mismanagement of American Indian land and money, a Senate panel today proposed that tribes be given the opportunity for greater control over Federal aid that officials in Washington now administer.
The aim, according to members of the panel and their staff, is to give tribes the option of particiating in a program that offers them direct control over and accountability for their individual shares of more than $3.3 billion in annual Federal grants for education, health, economic development and natural resource development.
The program would be administered by a new executive branch office and would operate through a block grant system similar to the relationship between the Federal Government and state and local governments. More than 500 Indian tribes and Alaskan native groups would be eligible. 
Federal aid to these groups now comes through a wide range of Federal programs with varying obligations for monitoring and control over how the funds are used. The result, the Senate panel said, is a system where there is little accountability and considerable opportunity for abuse.
 
'Best Defense' Against Abuses
''The most basic of all rights, the right of self-determination, is the Indian's best defense'' against such abuses, said Senator John McCain, an Arizona Republican. The panel gathered evidence of abuses, including corruption in the tribal government of the Navajos; administrative lack of interest, which permitted child sex abusers to teach for years in Indian schools, and theft of oil from Indian lands in Oklahoma.
''The system is desperately in need of improvement,'' agreed Representative Ben Nighthorse Campbell, a Colorado Democrat and a Cheyenne who spoke at a news conference called by the panel's chairman, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona.
The reaction from Indian tribal leaders was cautious and uncertain, reflecting widespread doubts about whether many tribes had the technical and managerial knowledge to deal with the requirements of a Federal block grant.
The panel's recommendation ''is the long-term goal of all Indian tribes, but it cannot be done overnight,'' said Duane Beyal, a spokesman for the Navajo Nation. ''There has to be a lot of work and preparation so that tribal governments can develop the capability to administer Federal programs and services.''
Mr. Beyal is serving as press spokesman for the interim tribal leader of the Navajos, Leonard Haskie. Peter MacDonald, elected leader of the 210,000-member tribe, is currently suspended from his post and is accused, under tribal law, of more than 100 instances of fraud or mismanagement. The allegations against Mr. MacDonald figured heavily in the testimony before the panel earlier this year.
The panel's recommendations, the first major attempt in more than a decade to alter the tangled and troubled 200-year relationship between the Federal Government and the Indian tribal governments, also evoked a cautious reaction from the Bureau of Indian Affairs.
Eddie F. Brown, the Assistant Secretary for Indian Affairs in the Interior Department, acknowledged in a statement today that ''the report reveals many instances where the Bureau of Indian Affairs has failed to serve Indian tribes and individuals.''
In an interview this afternoon, Mr. Brown said the report ''reflects a trend which is growing stronger within tribal communities - the asumption of greater self-determination by tribal governments.'' The bureau, he added, ''is already in transition from being a direct service provider to being a contractor, monitor and assitant'' to various tribes.
He noted that under a 1988 Interior Department pilot program, 17 tribes are currently conducting limited experiments with self-governance.

HEADLINE: Touring the New York of 60 Years Ago in Pictures

BYLINE: By RICHARD F. SHEPARD

 BODY:
Like a musician playing variations on a theme, Irving Browning ''played'' New York on his camera. The New York of 60 years ago that caught his eye lent itself to every mood, to every interpretation. He was a professional who did work for hire, and in his off hours he snapped photographs of New York for the sheer joy and art of it.
''Irving Browning: City of Contrasts,'' an exhibition on view at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street, includes 65 of the 1,889 vintage photographs Mr. Browning gave to the society in 1959. They conjure up a vision of New York during the late 1920's and the Depression days of the early 1930's. He understood, like all the good and remembered photographers of New York, that every place in the city is a photo opportunity and that the comments, often contradictory with each new roll of film, actually represent the city speaking for itself. 
The Browning brothers, Irving and Sam, opened a photography studio on West 40th Street during the 1920's and were soon commissioned by architects, advertising agencies and magazines. As photographers, they worked in point-blank reality and in montage, depending on the client. Irving's own taste was New York eclectic; he could give a bright, clear image of a Waldorf-Astoria towering loftily into the sky, and he could catch the weariness of a jobless man.
 
Without Captions
The photographs bear no captions, although they are arranged in sections, each of which is introduced by a quotation about New York by an eminent writer.
''We don't have much documentation to go on,'' said Dale Neighbors, the assistant curator of photography at the society and the curator of this show. ''Browning was a good businessman and I am sure that he kept records, but they didn't come with the images he gave to us. His widow, who is still alive, believes that any documentation might have been discarded after he died in 1961.''
Browning's still photographs appeared in shows alongside those of such contemporaries as Berenice Abbott, Ralph Steiner and Margaret Bourke-White. He was also interested in movies; in 1931 he produced a short documentary, ''City of Contrasts,'' which gives this exhibition its name.
Mr. Neighbors told how a full-length photograph of the Chrysler Building, looming tall from top to bottom, came about.
 
'They Managed It'
''Walter Chrysler was told such a photograph of the building in full could not be made,'' he said. ''Somebody told him about the Brownings. He commissioned them and they managed it.''
The work Browning was hired for is on the society's walls: photographs of the Waldorf-Astoria, the Roxy Theater, the Earl Carroll Theater and the Empire State Building.
But there is also the photography that clearly represented no client. There are the Hoovervilles, built of packing boxes; the newsboy sitting atop a pile of papers and actually reading one; the jobless clustered around an employment-office bulletin board. Strange, how formally clad the jobless men appear, all wearing ties, jackets and fedoras, particularly in the photograph of what might well be a banker except that he is selling fruit neatly heaped on packing boxes, with a sign: ''Help the Unemployed. Buy Tangerines, 2 for 5 cents. Apples, 5 cents.''
 
Double-Decker on Fifth
There is a photograph of Fifth Avenue and 49th Street, the St. Patrick's Cathedral corner, with a double-decker Fifth Avenue bus passing the long-gone special avenue traffic lights: delicate gold-colored lamps, each topped by a figure of Mercury. Now only the church remains on the corner. There is another view of a vanished New York: the waterfront, with men loading the ships and cargo slings hauling the commerce that made the port great.
Broadway was as flashy then as it is now, as evidenced by a neon-streaked photograph of the street with signs proclaiming ''Al Jolson in Mammy'' and ''Carl Laemmle Presents 'All Quiet on the Western Front.' '' On a different, but no less popular, cultural scale are the burlesques and the dance halls in the Browning lens. The photographer captured the cityscape in different moods: a breathtaking glimpse of Manhattan rising in concrete from the Battery, the city as seen from the deck of the Queen of Bermuda in the Upper Bay, the mating of park and edifice that distinguishes the Sherman Square corner where Central Park meets the Plaza Hotel.
This exhibition of New York, from little apples to Big Apple, is being shown through Dec. 3 in tandem with ''Cased Images: The 150th Anniversary of Photography,'' a show of 40 daguerreotypes from the society's collection.

GRAPHIC: ''Sandwich Boards,'' a 1929 photograph, is in the exhibition ''Irving Browning: City of Contrasts'' at the New-York Historical Society.

HEADLINE: Opium War Was Nothing Like U.S. Drug Crisis;
The Long Battle Won

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Flora Lewis in ''The Opium War'' (column, Oct. 29) does not mention the outcome of the opium wars waged by the Chinese people, which ended in their winning the battle after a long struggle.
At the end of the 19th century, of a population of 300 million Chinese, 90 million were addicted to opium; the old Chinese empire was threatened by fragmentation, and the foreign powers were poised to divide it into economic zones of influence. The dismantling did not occur. 
In the first part of the 20th century, a national revival stressing basic Chinese values prevailed. It was a period of revolution and civil strife, but all the Chinese were determined to stamp out opium addiction from their country. The United States and the European powers supported them in this.
In 1906, a few years before the demise of the Manchu imperial dynasty, the Chinese Government concluded a 10-year agreement with India that specified that China should cease domestic cultivation of poppies and forbid the consumption of opium on the understanding that the export of Indian opium to China should be reduced in equal proporton and cease altogether within a decade.
This agreement reversed a longstanding British policy in India. But at the Shanghai international opium conference in 1911, held at the suggestion of Theodore Roosevelt, Britain and France were among the 13 world powers who began an international policy to restrict opium use to medical and scientific purposes.
Total eradication of opium use from China occurred only at the end of the civil war in 1949, when Mao Zedong assumed power over a unified country. All of it, including the former international concessions and the southern provinces, was made drug-free in a few years.
The Chinese nationalists, following their defeat, retreated to Taiwan, where the cultivation of the poppy has been banned since 1945. The Chinese in Taiwan share the mainland's contempt for opium and other addictive drugs. The Chinese were able to solve the problem of massive opium addiction by decreasing the demand for the drug and cutting off the supply. Opium addiction has been eliminated in mainland China and Taiwan, as well as Singapore. It still prevails only in Hong Kong, a British crown colony.
 
GABRIEL G. NAHAS
 New York, Oct. 30, 1989
 
The writer is author of ''Cocaine: The Great White Plague.''

HEADLINE: A Pipeline to Petroleum Security

BYLINE: By J. Bennett Johnston; J. Bennett Johnston, Democrat of Louisiana, is chairman of the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Warnings about our growing dependence on imported oil are coming thick and fast these days, and not without reason -imports will soon reach 50 percent of total demand. But in responding to the danger, we risk overlooking an important difference between today and the early 1970's: Key OPEC nations now seem anxious to strengthen America's perceptions of its own energy security.
In fact, a novel possibility arises that OPEC nations could help us expand our main protection against a supply disruption - the Strategic Petroleum Reserve - and do so faster than we could otherwise afford.
The Strategic Petroleum Reserve now contains 575 million barrels of crude oil. While this equaled the target of 90 days of imports in 1988, only one year later the reserve now represents barely 79 days. The reason? Oil imports are growing faster than our stockpile. 
To maintain the 90-day target in the 1990's, the reserve will need to grow to at least a billion barrels or more -far beyond the 750 million barrels it will contain by the turn of the century at current fill rates. The problem is finding the money to pay for the added reserves.
That's where a new approach, under study by the Department of Energy, shows great promise. It starts from the premise that we don't have to buy oil to accomplish our major objective of obtaining an option to buy oil during an energy emergency. To accomplish this, we can just as easily ''lease'' the oil from OPEC countries and store it in the strategic reserve.
Here's how it would work. We would secure physical custody over the oil and control over its sale on behalf of the owner. In return, we would pay annual lease payments that would be a tiny fraction of the oil's purchase price.
We would neither own the oil nor profit from its sale. But we wouldn't pay for the oil either. Yet the public would have the assured option of buying that additional oil at the market price during an emergency. When the term expired, we would have the option to extend the lease, buy the oil or terminate.
Several oil producing nations with excess production capacity appear willing to discuss the proposal, including Saudi Arabia, Venezuela, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. They are interested in the arrangement as a way to circumvent OPEC's quota ceilings.
Oil leased for storage in the U.S. apparently would not count against the quota until it is actually sold. A producer who leased his oil would receive annual lease payments under a contract with the U.S. Government, plus the hope of its eventual sale. Now, oil in excess of the quota has little value for the producer because its sale is barred by the quota.
In addition, Saudi Arabia and other OPEC nations with large oil reserves are anxious to reassure the oil-consuming countries that they can rely on a long-term supply of OPEC oil at an acceptable price. The OPEC nations long since recognized that the rapid run-up of oil prices in the late 1970's and early 1980's was counterproductive. It led to widespread energy conservation, fuel-switching, increased non-OPEC oil production and economic recession. As a result, demand for OPEC oil plummeted.
We can theorize forever about the merits of the lease arrangement. No one will really know until the Administration takes the initiative and negotiates specific terms with a potential lessor. The most important considerations may be political, not economic, however.
Given the deficit, an alternative financing approach such as oil leasing may be our best hope to expand the strategic reserve to an adequate size. If OPEC is extending an olive branch, we should accept it warily. Let's continue our energy security programs, but let serious talks on oil leasing begin.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-ed

HEADLINE: OBSERVER;
Pitiful, Helpless Giants All

BYLINE: By Russell Baker

 BODY:
Suddenly the world seems littered with pitiful, helpless giants. There was Lech Walesa in Washington knocking on the castle door, talking of another Marshall Plan to help make freedom ring in Poland.
President Bush gave him a medal and sent him up to Capitol Hill for a round of applause. That's nice, like getting a big locomotive and a chorus of ''Boola Boola,'' but Marshall Plan it ain't. 
What ''Marshall Plan'' means is not just ''big, big money,'' but also a heavy commitment of American political vigor and brain power. It means dollars by the billion and determination to make the investment pay off, as it paid off in turning 1945's ruined Western Europe into today's economic powerhouse.
The American giant that did all that has not grown old and feeble so much as muscle-bound to the point of helplessness. Congress will provide some money for Poland and Hungary, but it will be a lot less than $1 billion for the two, and ever since Washington discovered the trillion you're not even talking money down there if you're talking less than $1 billion.
The old muscle-bound giant has billions galore. He measures his bills by trillions nowadays, but his money is all tied up in enterprises he can't seem to get out of even when they don't pay off.
There's $70 billion committed for the Stealth bomber. Its usefulness was always debatable, but since the cold war started to vanish, it now seems a grotesque boondoggle. For obvious political reasons, though, the giant finds it nearly impossible to switch any of those Stealth billions to something as useful as a ''Marshall Plan'' for Poland: the cold war has built us an economy that lives by Stealth bomber construction.
Switch a few billion from Stealth to Poland and California screams, just as Long Island screams whenever somebody suggests switching Grumman's share of the cold-war budget to something sensible.
With American politics tied inescapably to cold-war spending, it's hard to come up with money for anything new, no matter how necessary - short of raising taxes, of course.
And what are the chances people will sit still for new taxes so long as the daily news is all about gigantic swindles conducted at taxpayers' expense?
President Bush is criticized for not showing zealous enthusiasm about Communism's collapse in Europe, yet one can see why it is a blessing he might have preferred not to happen on his watch. The cold war was a familiar way of life, the American economy was based on assumptions of its permanence, and American mentality was conditioned to preserve and promote it.
An end to the cold war meant rethinking absolutely everything. This would have been an extraordinary challenge for the most inventive and imaginative minds, and invention and imagination are not the strengths of Mr. Bush and the men around him, nor for that matter of any group anywhere on the American political horizon at present.
So we have the old muscle-bound giant hunkered down in the castle at Washington, dazzled by the excitements going on around him, but probably wishing, if the truth be known, that people didn't expect him to get up and participate in the havoc.
It was President Nixon who coined the phrase ''pitiful, helpless giant'' in a different context. The United States, he warned during the Vietnam War, would become ''a pitiful, helpless giant'' unless Americans showed the resolution needed to claim some kind of victory there.
He was alarmed partly by the popular movement against the war which had divided the country and made it difficult for him to apply American power casually in Asia.
Now we see popular movements everywhere turning governments into pitiful, helpless giants. Gorbachev, by responding to popular hunger for release from a moldering past, reveals that the Soviet Union may be the most pitiful, most helpless giant of all.
The discovery that Stalin really is dead, and Lenin had it all wrong, and the castle at Moscow is all cobwebs and decrepitude, quickly exposed the pitiful helplessness of eastern Europe's antique tyrants. While they had been strutting like giants, history had left them as pitiful, though not alas as comical, as the Wizard of Oz.
Armies of course can always give half-pints the illusion they are giants (see China), but the air just now is filled with a sense that the age of the giants is ending. In Washington nobody seems to have any idea what to do about it.

HEADLINE: Grocery Official Is Found Slain By Rural Road

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORRISTOWN, N.J., Nov. 17

 BODY:
An executive of the Pathmark supermarket chain was shot to death early Thursday, several hours after he left his office in Woodbridge, the authorities said today.
The victim, Robert E. Wunderle, 45 years old, of Westfield, was shot once through the heart and once above the left ear, and his body was left in a brush-shrouded drainage ditch beside a secluded unpaved road in Rockaway, about 100 yards from the closest highway, the authorities said today. The site, about a half-mile from Exit 37 on Interstate 80, is about 25 miles northwest of Mr. Wunderle's office. 
The Morris County Prosecutor, Lee S. Trumbull, said investigators had found no motive for the murder and had not ruled out the possibility that it was committed by a hired killer.
''That's an area we're exploring, but we're not focusing on that,'' Mr. Trumbull said.
Powder burns were found next to both wounds, suggesting that Mr. Wunderle was shot at a range of less than two feet, Mr. Trumbull said.
 
'Esteemed and Valued Colleague'
His wallet and his company car, a gray four-door Mercury Grand Marquis with New Jersey license plate EXC-26V, are both missing, Mr. Trumbull said. But because Mr. Wunderle's expensive wristwatch was undisturbed, the authorities are uncertain about robbery as a motive, Mr. Trumbull said.
Mr. Wunderle was chief economist and vice president of public affairs of the Supermarkets General Corporation, the Woodbridge-based parent company of the Pathmark chain.
''He was an esteemed and valued colleague whose tireless efforts on behalf of S.G.C., as well as the food industry as a whole, were remarkable,'' the company chairman, Jack Futterman, said yesterday.
Mr. Wunderle, who was married and had two sons, was a prominent lobbyist for the food industry in the Northeast, having served on the government relations committees of the New Jersey Food Council, the New York State Food Merchants, the Pennsylvania Food Merchants and the Food Marketing Institute, a national supermarket organization. He was former chairman of the Community Food Bank of New Jersey, an organization that distributes surplus government food to the needy.
 
Missed Business Dinner
As a spokesman for the industry, he was often quoted in news articles about trends in food merchandising and supermarket development.
Mr. Wunderle's body, dressed in business suit and raincoat, was found about 9 A.M. Thursday by a municipal heavy-equipment operator who was enlarging the ditch. He was identified by a business card found in a pocket.
He left his office at 8:45 P.M. Wednesday, and his whereabouts afterward are unknown, Mr. Trumbull said. He planned to attend a business dinner in Mountainside but did not arrive or call to cancel.

HEADLINE: Board Refuses Approval For Shelter's Expansion

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
The New York City Board of Estimate has refused to approve retroactively the addition of nearly 300 beds to a homeless men's shelter in the former Greenpoint Hospital in Brooklyn.
Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins joined the majority of board members who voted Thursday night to require the city to scale back the shelter by about 300 beds. The board was reviewing the expansion under a court order. 
Only Mayor Edward I. Koch voted to keep the shelter at its current capacity of nearly 1,000 beds. First Deputy Mayor Stanley Brezenoff said yesterday that it was unclear what the administration's next step would be. He said the city would continue to use the shelter for ''as long as we can,'' adding, ''We have no other place to put these individuals.''
The board also approved a housing project for the aged at Avenue C and Ninth Street on the Lower East Side. This site is now La Plaza Cultural, whose admirers call it a community garden, play area and open-air performance space. Its detractors call it a dangerous vacant lot.
 
Speakers Urge Rejection
Although the expansion of the Greenpoint shelter, at Kingsland and Skillman Avenues, has already occurred, the city is under a court order, obtained by a community group called the Greenpoint Renaissance Enterprise Corporation, to take the matter through the uniform land-use review procedure, which involves the Board of Estimate.
More than three dozen speakers urged the board to reject the authorization. They were protesting what they said was a reversal of a commitment by the Koch administration to reduce the shelter population to 250 over five years, beginning next May. Mr. Koch made that commitment last August, less than a month before the Democratic mayoral primary.
The president of Greenpoint Renaissance, Gary Sam Hattem, said yesterday, ''We're pleased with the vote in that it sends a signal that when government makes a promise to a community, that promise should be kept.''
Koch administration officials insisted that they had not broken their word but conceded on Thursday that the shelter would be phased out more slowly than they first indicated.
Councilman Abraham G. Gerges, whose district includes Greenpoint, said: ''The Mayor appeared in Greenpoint and personally assured people that the shelter would be closed. To now reverse that would be the greatest insult by the government to any community. And we will not stand for it.''
 
Apartments for the Aged
Several hours later, the board held its hearing on Casa Victoria, a proposed six-story building with 79 apartments for the aged, built by the Lower East Side Coalition Housing Development Inc.
The federally subsidized project attracted attention recently when it was cited by David Burns, the regional economist for the Department of Housing and Urban Development. In 1987, Mr. Burns said, Joseph Monticciolo, the department's regional administrator in New York, ordered him to approve the Lower East Side site, which he was going to reject.
''This project has not been and is not under any investigation,'' said Antonio Pagan, executive director of the development company. ''We intend to transform a drug-ridden hell hole into quality, affordable housing for the elderly.''
Opponents of Casa Victoria said the location was inappropriate for housing for the aged, given the number of abandoned buildings in the vicinity and the amount of drug dealing on the streets.
And yet, opponents stressed, the site was functioning well as La Plaza. ''Green space is as important to this city as housing,'' said Patsy L. Margolin, a neighbor.
