HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1989

 BODY:

 
 
Companies
 General Electric plans to buy back $10 billion worth of its stock during the next five years. It also announced a 15 percent increase in its dividend. The stock-repurchase program apparently is the largest ever announced at one time. G.E.'s shares rose $2, to $59.50. G.E.'s chairman said there were no suitable acquisition candidates now and buying back shares appeared to be the best use for the company's sizable cash reserves. [Page 35.] B. Altman is closing almost all its stores, including the 124-year-old chain's flagship store on Fifth Avenue. That store was once a favorite of Manhattan's carriage trade but its business has been in decline for more than a decade. Altman's current owner, the L. J. Hooker Corporation, is under bankruptcy protection and had been seeking a buyer for the seven-store chain. The five other stores to be closed are in New Jersey and Pennsylvania and on Long Island. A store in Cincinnati will remain open because it is an essential part of a new shopping mall. [35.] Lockheed will take a charge of about $300 million against fourth-quarter earnings because of a miscalculation in bidding for a contract to develop an antisubmarine aircraft for the Navy. The charge might result in a loss for the full year. The charge amounts to half of the $600 million contract. [35.] Northeast Utilities sweetened its bid for the assets of the bankrupt Public Service Company of New Hampshire and said that it had won the endorsement of some secured creditors. [36.] Dunkin' Donuts agreed to be acquired for $325 million by a British food and beverage group, Allied-Lyons P.L.C. The chain, which has more than 1,800 outlets, fought off a hostile bidder earlier. [37.]
 
 
 
The Economy
 The Fed's policy makers decided not to lower rates immediately when they met last month. A report of the meeting said that part of the reason for the decision was a reluctance to be seen as succumbing to pressure from the Treasury. The report was an unusually explicit acknowledgement of a division over interest rates between the central bank and the Treasury. [35.] Housing starts bounced back by 12 percent in October from September's seven-year low. Analysts said they expected the construction to remain stable through early 1990. [36.]
 
 
 
Markets
 Stock prices posted broad gains aided by a rally in high-technology stocks and G.E.'s stock buyback announcement. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 17 points, to 2,652.66. For the week, the Dow had a gain of 27.05 points, or about 1 percent. [38.] Treasury note and bond prices declined further as the debt market continued to digest the large volume of quarterly refunding and other offerings auctioned this week. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 7.93 percent, up from 7.89 percent a week ago. [38.] One argument for dual trading of futures was dismissed by the staff of a Federal regulatory agency. Their report said they had found no evidence that the market worked better when traders are allowed to deal for both themselves and their clients. [46.] Precious metals futures prices rose broadly, supported by continued buying of gold, silver and platinum, and by supply fears about palladium linked to reports of problems at a Soviet metals refinery. [43.] The dollar finished mixed in a quiet session with traders lacking any incentive to buy or sell heavily. [43.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
 The office chair has been redesigned by an engineer who says his version is more comfortable. The new chair has no springs in its recliner mechanism and uses balance and gravity to do most of its work. Patents. [36.] The holiday season poses a threat to the year-round financial health of many people, especially those who make only minimum monthly payments on their credit cards. One expert warns that browsing in stores can lead to impulse purchases and recommends instead that shopping be organized, using a list. Your Money. [36.]

HEADLINE: Split With Treasury Cited By Fed in Report on Rates

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Policy makers of the Federal Reserve decided at a meeting last month not to lower interest rates at once in large part because they did not want to be seen as succumbing to pressure from the Treasury, according to a report of the meeting released today.
This was an unusually explicit acknowledgement of a division over interest rates between the Fed and the Treasury and of the central bank's determination not to be swayed by the Treasury on monetary policy.
The Oct. 3 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee came 10 days after Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and the other finance ministers of the Group of Seven, the seven largest industrial democracies, announced that they had agreed to take steps to bring down the value of the dollar. The move was designed to improve American trade imbalances. 
Their effort to drive down the dollar would have been aided by lower interest rates in the United States, which would have made the dollar less attractive in the markets.
But, according to the Open Market Committee report, Fed officials felt not only that domestic economic conditions did not warrant a reduction in interest rates but also that ''an easing of policy so soon after'' the Group of Seven meeting ''would be misinterpreted as an attempt to use monetary policy to force the dollar lower.''
The Open Market Committee is made up of the seven governors of the Federal Reserve Board and the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve banks. It meets behind closed doors eight times a year to set monetary policy. A sketchy report of each meeting is published about six weeks afterward, a few days after the following meeting. However, if a decision is made to raise or lower interest rates, the markets recognize it within days.
The report published today said: ''Monetary policy should not be used, in the judgment of the committee, to attain particular levels for the foreign exchange value of the dollar that could conflict with domestic policy objectives. In current circumstances, an easing might well provoke an undesirable sharp decline in the external value of the dollar.''
Robert H. Chandross, chief economist in the New York office of Lloyds Bank and a student of the Fed, said he regarded that as ''an unusually clear statement by the Fed to the Treasury that they were not going to give in to pressure.''
After time had passed, however, the Fed did approve a lowering of rates. The rates were permitted to slide a bit following the stock market drop on Oct. 13, and the Open Market Committee members agreed in a telephone conference call last week to a further small reduction.
The report released today did not address those actions.
 
Rate Below Oct. 3 Level
 The Federal funds rate, which is controlled by the Fed and which is the rate banks charge one another for overnight loans, is now at 8.5 percent, about half a percentage point below the level on Oct. 3.
The Fed officials also took issue in the report with the decision by the United States and its allies - Britain, West Germany, France, Italy, Japan and Canada - to intervene in currency markets to drive the dollar down. ''Some members expressed concern,'' the report stated, ''that if this intervention resulted in a sizable depreciation of the dollar, the inflationary consequences could be viewed as inconsistent with the committee's long-run policy of achieving price stability.''
Following the September meeting of the finance ministers, the industrialized countries sold dollars aggressively. As a result, the dollar fell modestly against the West German mark and slightly against the Japanese yen. The higher values of the foreign currencies make their products more expensive in the United States, which can drive up inflation if the consumers' appetite for imports remains strong.
Differences between the Fed and the Treasury over interest rates are well established but, in the Bush Administration, have only occasionally appeared in public. The Fed's principal goal is to contain inflation, and that implies high interest rates. The Administration is more concerned about economic growth and believes that that requires somewhat lower rates.
 
Differences Minimized
 In an interview last week, Secretary Brady acknowledged but minimized the differences as ''between the 40-yard lines.''
''The Fed,'' he said, ''has a special view about the containment of inflation, and at the same time it is not unmindful of the necessity for growth. We have a special feeling about growth because it is the tide that lifts all of the boats, but we have an eye on inflation.''
Moreover, Fed officials have repeatedly told the Treasury that intervention in the currency markets cannot help the dollar for very long if market forces are pushing it the other way. Most economists accept that view. The Treasury, on the other hand, needs for political reasons to be seen as acting to help improve the trade balance, and a high dollar makes exports more costly and imports less expensive.

HEADLINE: $10 Billion G.E. Stock Buyback

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The General Electric Company, in an apparent effort to increase the price of its stock, announced yesterday that it would purchase up to $10 billion worth of its shares during the next five years. It is evidently the largest such repurchase program ever announced at one time.
The company also increased its dividend 15 percent, from an annual $1.64 a share, to $1.88 a share. G.E.'s shares rose $2 yesterday, to $59.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
''The reaction in the investment community is very positive,'' said Linda M. Shuman, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities. She said some institutional investors had feared the company would make an unsuitable acquisition as its cash reserves grew. 
 
Bright Forecast
 In a meeting with securities analysts in New York, G.E. officials projected a rosy future for the company. They predicted that annual revenue would exceed $60 billion by 1992 and that earnings would exceed $5 billion. Last year, the company earned $3.4 billion on revenues of $50 billion.
John F. Welch Jr., the chairman of the company, said G.E. officials had decided the company should buy its stock because they ''do not see the values'' in any potential acquisition candidate.
The G.E. repurchase plan appears to be the largest such undertaking covered in a single announcement, but other companies have also been buying back large numbers of shares. The International Business Machines Corporation has bought $1 billion to $2 billion of its shares each year for the last several years, and it announced earlier this year that it would buy as much as $1 billion in 1989. In 1987, the General Motors Corporation announced a $4.72 billion repurchase plan.
 
Generated Internally
 G.E. officials said about 60 percent of the money for the repurchase would be generated internally, with the rest coming from borrowings. Today, the Standard & Poor's Corporation and Moody's Investors Service Inc. both reaffirmed their top ratings for G.E.'s debt.
Mr. Welch said almost 10 years of divestitures and acquisitions had made the company a leader in 13 business categories. ''In the decade ahead, we believe these businesses will provide high earnings growth and significant cash flow,'' he said.
''These prospects give us flexibility to increase dividends in line with earnings, maintain a high level of internal investment, make complementary acquisitions and also repurchase a significant amount of stock,'' Mr. Welch said.
Russell L. Leavitt, an analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc., said, ''I think the message is that they are satisfied with their current postion and are poised to generate solid earnings and cash flow.'' He said yesterday's action, by reducing the number of shares publicly held, would bolster G.E.'s stock price because any increases in earnings or dividends would be spread over fewer shares.
Mr. Welch said the only event likely to derail the stock repurchase would be a large, very suitable acquisition opportunity. ''It would take a blockbuster acquisition,'' he said.
He said a stock repurchase, rather than a large one-time dividend payment or a sharp dividend rate increase, gave the company flexibility if a big acquisition became possible or if economic conditions changed. ''We are not after a higher stock price today,'' he said. ''We think it's is a sounder plan than a quick-hit dividend.''
Dennis Dammerman, G.E.'s senior vice president for finance, said the company expects 1989 revenues to total about $54 billion and net income would be $3.91 to $3.96 billion, or $4.32 to $4.38 a share.
The only dark spot in an otherwise bright picture, Mr. Welch acknowledged, was in the major appliances division, which he said was not meeting a productivity growth target of 4 to 6 percent a year.

HEADLINE: Starts in Housing Show 12% Rebound for October

 BODY:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -Housing starts bounced back by 12 percent in October from September's seven-year low, the Commerce Department reported today.
Analysts said they expected the construction rate to remain stable through the first quarter of 1990.
''The housing market seems to have bottomed out,'' said David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. But he and other analysts said they did not expect any surge in building.
The Commerce Department reported that new homes and apartments were built at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.42 million units last month.
 
Drops in Previous Two Months
 The 12 percent rebound from September was the sharpest gain since a 13 percent advance in December 1986. Starts had fallen 4.6 percent in September and 6.4 percent in August.
Although September's pace was revised upward from the 1.26 million reported earlier, it was still the most sluggish since new homes and apartments were built at an annual rate of 1.17 million units in October 1982 during the depths of a recession.
Many analysts attributed the September construction drop to a rise in mortgage rates and said the October gain followed a subsequent decline.
The housing industry has been among the hardest hit as the Federal Reserve drove up interest rates to slow economic growth and lower inflation. But the Fed has slowly eased rates over the summer and, except for the blip in September, rates on 30-year fixed-rate mortgages have fallen from March's 11.22 percent peak to 9.82 percent by the end of October, according to surveys by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
 
Decline in Inventories
 The higher rates stifled sales and bolstered inventories of single-family homes to an 8.1-month supply by last March, said Richard Peach, an economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association. As rates have fallen, he added, inventories have dropped to a six-month supply, which, he said, ''by historical standards'' puts the industry ''in good shape.''
But even though many analysts expect mortgage rates to drop another half of a percentage point in coming months, Mr. Peach said he did not expect a sharp rise in building.
Construction of single-family homes in October rose 6.9 percent, to an annual rate of 1.03 million units. Single-family starts had fallen 3 percent in September and 3.5 percent in August.
Apartment construction rose 28 percent in October, to an annual rate of 393,000 units. It had fallen 9.4 percent in September after dropping 14 percent in August.
Total housing starts during the first 10 months of the year were down 6 percent from the corresponding period of 1988.
The South, which posted a 14.7 drop for the steepest regional decline in September, turned in the sharpest increase in October, up by 17.1 percent, to 562,000 units. It was followed by the Midwest with a 16.5 percent gain, to 289,000 units.
Construction rose 6 percent in the Northeast, to 176,000 units, and 5.1 percent in the West, to 393,000 units.

HEADLINE: Treasury Issues Continue to Decline

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Treasury note and bond prices declined further yesterday as the debt market continued to digest the large volume of quarterly refunding and other offerings auctioned this week. Dealers said prices began falling from the opening, after the Government reported that housing starts rose 12 percent in October.
Dealers also said that the corporate bond market was depressed by the decision of the Tennessee Valley Authority to price $4 billion of seven- and 40-year bonds yesterday. Originally, $3 billion of bonds were due to be priced next week. Also, the T.V.A.'s 40-year bonds were priced to yield more than a percentage point above the Treasury's long-term bonds. 
Meanwhile, further evidence of an improving economy came in the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's index of general business conditions, which projected a sharp improvement for the current month. Economists watch the index as a precursor of the much more publicized index issued each month by the National Association of Purchasing Managers.
 
Manufacturing Component Gains
 ''The Philadelphia Fed's zero-based index for November is down 5.8 percent, a sharp improvement from the minus 10.2 percent in October and minus 7.6 percent in September,'' said Steven R. Ricchiuto, chief economist at Barclays de Zoete Wedd. ''What may have upset some people in the fixed-income market is that the manufacturing component of the Philadelphia Fed's index also showed improvement.''
But the index also showed that manufacturers were having to pay more for their purchases, while the prices they are receiving have slimmed along with their profit margins, Mr. Ricchiuto added.
Francis A. Scotland, managing editor of the International Bank Credit Analyst in Montreal, said: ''Other factors are also weighing on the fixed-income market. Few market participants care to take any significant position before a holiday-shortened week, when trading will be light and prices subject to the volatility that usually attends a relatively illiquid market.''
Mr. Scotland also noted that ''with the Fed still in a do-nothing mode and few important economic statistics due out in the next two weeks, the market doesn't expect any move until the November employment data are released next month.'' He added, ''We believe the jobs data will provoke the Fed into pushing the funds rate down to 8 percent by year-end.''
 
Federal Funds Down to 8 3/8%
 Late trading found the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for temporary loans, down to 8 3/8 percent, from 8 1/2 percent Thursday. This apparently had little impact on short-term rates. The discount rate on Treasury 90-day bills was unchanged at 7.68 percent; six-month bills rose four basis points, to 7.46 percent, and the new one-year bill was unchanged at 7.17 percent.
In the intermediate maturity sector, the new 7 3/4 percent notes of 1992 fell 5/32, at 100 1/32, for a yield of 7.74 percent; the 8's of 1996 dropped 12/32, to 100 24/32, and a yield of 7.85 percent, and the new long-term notes, the 7 7/8's of 1999, fell 13/32, to 100 3/32, for a yield of 7.86 percent.
The Treasury's benchmark long-term bonds, the 8 1/8's of 2019, tumbled 24/32, to 102 7/32, with the yield rising to 7.93 percent, from 7.86 percent Thursday and 7.89 percent a week ago.
Meanwhile, the T.V.A. priced $1.5 billion of 8.25 percent noncallable bonds due in 1996 at 99.45 to yield 8.355 percent, or about 52 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The $2.5 billion in bonds due in 2029 were given a 8 5/8 percent coupon and priced at 95.90 to yield 9.005 percent, or 110 basis points more than the Treasury's 30-year bond. Underwriters, led by Morgan Stanley & Company, said the bonds were noncallable for 10 years.
This offering follows last month's $4 billion issue, which marked the agency's first trip to the public debt market in about 15 years.
The T.V.A. said debt sales would raise funds to pay off $6.7 billion of high-interest debt the utility owes the Federal Financing Bank, an arm of the United States Treasury.

HEADLINE: Dow Up 17 Points, Led by G.E.'s Strength

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices posted broad gains yesterday, aided by a rally in high-technology stocks and General Electric's announcement that it intends to buy back as much as $10 billion worth of its stock.
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 17 points, to 2,652.66, as advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declines by about 7 to 6, with 766 rising and 682 falling. For the week, the Dow gained 27.05 points, or about 1 percent. 
G.E. rose 2 points, to 59 1/2, and was the Big Board's busiest issue on a volume of more than 3.1 million shares.
 
Technology Issues Rise
 Better-than-expected earnings by Hewlett-Packard provided a catalyst for the recently lagging high-technology sector, traders said. Hewlett jumped 3 1/4, to 44 1/2. Other technology issues quickly followed, with I.B.M. up 2, to 99 1/8; Digital Equipment up 2 1/2, to 88 1/4, and Motorola up 1/2, to 57 5/8. In over-the-counter trading, Intel gained 1/2, to 34.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 1.03 points, to 341.61, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index edged up 0.53, to 189.28.
Volume on the Big Board rose to 151 million shares, from 148.4 million on Thursday.
Joseph Battipaglia, associate director of research at Gruntal & Company, said yesterday's gains could be called the G.E. rally. ''The announcement of the $10 billion buyback and 15 percent dividend increase gave investors in blue chips cause to cheer,'' he said. But the analyst also pointed out that the many stocks were lackluster and the bond market weakened on a confused economic outlook. There have been signs of economic weakness in a number of recently released statistics, but the Commerce Department reported yesterday that housing starts rose a better-than-expected 12 percent in October.
A ''double witching hour'' occurred yesterday as November stock options and stock indexes expired, but analysts said it had little effect on stock prices.
Among individual issues, Lockheed dropped 2 1/8, to 39 1/2. The company said that it would take a charge of about $300 million against fourth-quarter earnings related to the development of a Navy patrol plane and that the charge could result in a loss for the year.
Active blue chips included Union Carbide, up 5/8, to 23 7/8; Unisys off 3/8, to 14 1/2; Philip Morris up 1/4, to 41 3/8; American Express, unchanged at 34 5/8, and A.T.&T. off 1/8, to 43 1/4.
Dun & Bradstreet added 3/8, to 42 7/8. The stock had fallen 7 3/4 the preceding two days after the company said it expected to show lower earnings in 1990 as it reorganizes its credit-services business.
Actively traded over-the-counter stocks included MCI Communications, which rose 3/8, to 44 1/8, and Sun Microsystems, which was up 5/8, to 16, and Lin Broadcasting, which dipped 1/8, to 115 3/4.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed on Quiet Day; Focus Now Is German Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed yesterday in a quiet session with traders lacking any incentive to buy or sell heavily.
Gold prices rose. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $394.60 an ounce, $3.20 higher than Thursday. The Republic National Bank of New York quoted an ounce of gold at $394.25 late in the day, up $2.95 from Thursday's late bid. 
''There was not much activity today'' in the dollar, said one currency dealer, John McCarthy.
Mr. McCarthy, who is with the New York office of the Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank, said currency dealers focused on buying West German marks.
Demand for marks has increased as currency investors speculate that West German economic growth will accelerate as a result of closer ties with East Germany.
Traders said news that United States housing starts had rebounded by 12 percent in October from September's seven-year low failed to evoke much of a response in the currency markets.
The dollar ended lower against most major currencies in United States trading after a mixed performance overseas.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 143.98 yen, up from 143.85 yen at Thursday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 144.15 yen. By the close of trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 144.25 yen, unchanged from Thursday's late level.
In London, the pound fell to $1.5705, from $1.5805 late Thursday. The pound weakened further in later New York trading, falling to $1.5670 from $1.5755 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.8410 West German marks, down from 1.8427; 1.6307 Swiss francs, down from 1.6326; 6.2630 French francs, down from 6.2725; 1,355.00 Italian lire, down from 1,357.25, and 1.16945 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16875.
Selected late rates for the dollar in Europe, compared with late Thursday's quotes, included: 1.8410 West German marks, up from 1.8375; 1.6315 Swiss francs, up from 1.6290; 6.2590 French francs, up from 6.2550; 2.0770 Dutch guilders, up from 2.0750; 1,353.50 Italian lire, down from 1,354.00, and 1.1697 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1700.
Precious metals prices moved higher. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $392.25 an ounce, down from $393 late Thursday.
In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $391.50, down from late Thursday's bid of $392.50.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose by $2.59 to close at $392.21.
Silver rose in London to a late bid price of $5.61 an ounce, up from $5.60 late Thursday. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.672 an ounce, up from $5.582 on Thursday.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;
Falling Mortgage Rates

 BODY:

The slowing economy has created opportunities in real estate, as a generally depressed housing market has reduced the average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage by more than 1.25 percentage points since March. It is now 9.66 percent, a five-year low. Continued soft spots in the economy, including housing, could push that rate down another half-point by spring, many analysts say. If so, delaying a $100,000 mortgage commitment could reduce monthly payments by more than $30, producing savings of more than $12,000 over the life of the loan. HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Antilock Brakes, Once Rare, Emerge as Prime Auto Option

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Antilock brakes, once considered an esoteric device to prevent uncontrolled skidding on slippery roads, are showing up as standard equipment or being offered as optional equipment in many new car, truck and van models. So more new-car buyers than ever before are getting a chance to buy this safety feature.
Automotive experts say the proliferation of these specialized braking systems - sometimes called A.B.S. - is likely to continue through the late 1990's, when antilock brakes are expected to become fairly common even on economy models.
Some insurance companies are granting discounts to clients whose cars have the brakes. Consumer advocates advise drivers who are shopping for cars now to make antilock brakes an important consideration.
 
A Helpless Feeling
The benefits of antilock brakes will be immediately evident to anyone who ever has had the experience of inadvertently braking too hard on a slippery road, only to encounter a frightening loss of control as the car careers or spins toward a possible collision. In this kind of situation, the wheels of the car, having been stopped by the brakes, remain locked while the car continues to skid. The steering wheel is useless: no matter which way it is turned, the vehicle continues to move in the direction it was moving at the moment the wheels were locked. Sometimes the car will turn sideways or begin to spin.
Driver-education courses warn against slamming on the brake pedal precisely because it is so easy to lock the wheels on a slippery surface because of the lack of friction between the rubber and the road. Students are taught that on wet or icy roads, they should repeatedly pump the brakes gently then quickly release the pressure until the vehicle slows or stops. The series of short braking actions reduces the chance of lockup.
 
Electronics Take Over
 In essence, antilock brakes mimic those instructions, automatically applying and releasing pressure even faster than a driver could. As the brakes are applied, an electronic sensor detects when a wheel is about to lock and then releases it, overriding any pressure on the pedal. The driver retains the ability to steer the car and can depress the brakes as hard as possible without releasing pressure: the system will slow the wheels gradually without locking them. In some systems the driver can actually feel the pedal pulsing as the computer is applying and releasing the brakes.
The General Motors Corporation is installing antilock brakes as standard equipment in 20 of its 1990 models and will offer the system as optional equipment in 13 models. The most expensive Cadillac models will include antilock brakes, and so will sportier versions of the Pontiac Grand Prix and Buick Electra, as well as the Chevrolet Astro van. Buyers of the Buick Regal, Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme and other medium-sized models can pay $925 to receive them as an option.
For 1990, the Ford Motor Company has made antilock brakes standard on the Lincoln Continental, the Lincoln Mark VII, the Mercury Cougar and the Aerostar van, and some versions of the Taurus, the Thunderbird and other models. If ordered as an option, the brakes cost $924 to $1,085.
The Chrysler Corporation offers the system as standard on the Maserati TC, and as an option on the Jeep Cherokee and Wagoneer, the Dodge Dynasty, Chrysler Imperial and Chrysler New Yorker for $926 to $998.
The brakes are standard on Acuras, and some Mazdas. Toyota, Nissan, , Mitsubishi and Subaru all offer them as an option on a varitety of models; the prices range from $995 to $1,495. They are standard on all BMW's, Jaguars and many models of Mercedes-Benz.
G.M., Ford and Chrysler also offer antilock brakes on many pickup trucks.
Like many advances in automotive technology, this one has been around for decades. It was first used on airplanes in the 1950's and in large trucks in the 1960's.
Only in recent years, however, have auto makers deemed the systems practical and economical enough for industrywide distribution. This follows the pattern of disk brakes, which were introduced in more expensive vehicles and, over time, became commonplace.
Josef Mack, a manager for the Robert Bosch Corporation, a leading making of antilock brake systems, estimates that 15 to 20 percent of the cars and trucks on the road will have them in the near future. ''Since 1978 we have produced four million systems worldwide, and many consumers who have them say they'll never own another car without them,'' he said.
At present, it is so complicated and costly to retrofit a car or truck with an A.B.S. that it is not practical.
 
Some Practice Needed
 The brakes take a little getting used to. Deepak Dighe, a G.M. engineer, said pumping them, as many drivers been trained to do with stanbard brakes, will not take full advantage of the antilock technology.
Perhaps the greatest potential danger with respect to these systems is that they may imbue drivers with an undue sense of invulnerability when driving on wet or icy pavement.
''Antilock brakes improve controllability, but they don't necessarily reduce the stopping distance on slippery pavement,'' Mr. Dighe said. ''You cannot defy the laws of physics. It still takes longer to stop a vehicle on wet pavement than on dry.''

SECTION: Section 1; Page 52, Column 1; Style Desk

LENGTH: 996 words

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
This Year, Service Plus Bargains

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
When the holiday shopping season begins at Thanksgiving, people can expect to see still more of the heavy markdowns they have seen the last few holiday seasons.
But in department and specialty stores they are also likely to find more - and perhaps better - service from sales people because of snowballing trends like commission selling, manufacturers' representatives on sales floors and personal shopping services.
''Quality service is more important than ever this year,'' said Terry Lundgren, executive vice president of Neiman-Marcus in Dallas. ''We're adding 10 percent more selling associates on the floor, and the customer will definitely notice a difference for Christmas.'' 
Herbert Wittkin, a New York management consultant, said: ''The lack of customer convenience hit bottom last year and is mostly bouncing back now. I think there's something real happening.''
This year the practice of paying retail sales people a combination of salary and commissions, or commissions alone, became an industry-wide phenomenon. With Nordstrom's of Seattle in the lead, commission selling has spread to pace-setting stores like Jordan Marsh in Boston, Marshall Field's in Chicago and the Broadway in Los Angeles.
''With commission selling, the service level goes up,'' said Peter Schaeffer, vice president of Bloomingdale's in New York, which began converting its sales force to a commission structure this summer. ''As a result, this Christmas there will be fewer part-time employees.''
 
Avoiding 'the Claw'
 The danger of commission selling, however, is summed up by something that retailers call ''the claw,'' a sales person who will not let go until the customer buys. Susan O'Dell, president of Mandev Consulting in Toronto, said consumers will not fully benefit until retailers make it clear to their sales staffs that ''they are more heavily rewarded for creating a client for life than for making an immediate sale today.'' She added, ''This insures customers don't feel pushed and oversold.''
While store employees are likely to earn more in commissions than in salaries, more and more merchants are also augmenting their staffs with sales people who are on the payrolls of their suppliers.
This practice, long prevalent in departments like cosmetics, jewelry and shoes, has spread to other areas like ready-to-wear clothes and accessories.
''This trend has been growing because manufacturers feel that retailers can't do some of the things that should be done,'' said Walter K. Levy of Walter K. Levy & Robert E. Kerson Associates, a New York consulting firm. ''There are also people called rotators who are paid for by manufacturers and go to different stores to make sure that their merchandise is properly displayed.''
 
An Effective Sales Force
 Missy Lo Monaco, the vice president for fashion merchandising at Bonwit Teller, said sales people who are paid wholly or partly by manufacturers are very effective in working with customers. She acknowledged that their primary loyalty may be to the producer paying their salary, but she added, ''If someone wants to see something from another collection, they will pass them on and won't leave them standing there.''
Another service that will be more obvious in the weeks ahead is the increasing number of personal shoppers in the big stores. These men and women, who know what goods are stocked in all departments, either accompany customers to speed their shopping expeditions through the store or select merchandise in advance to show them individually in a room far from the madding crowds. Typically this service is open to anyone, with no additional fee or minimum purchase requirement.
''Everyone wants to do business with the working woman who has more money than time,'' said James Posner, a New York retailing consultant.
''But if stores use personal shoppers, there is an obligation that they be up to the level of the women who need them. They have to be really good.''
 
One Hour, Eight Gifts
 One store with such a service is Saks Fifth Avenue, which calls ait the Fifth Avenue Clubs. The clubs' offices are laid out like private clubs, where clothing can be shown or where customers can meet an experienced employee who will take them around the store.
''You don't have to stop at each department and pay at each department,'' said Susan Olden, director of the clubs. ''In one hour you can do eight gifts and you're on your way.''
Macy's, which has long had a personal shopping service called Macy's by Appointment, developed a new wrinkle this year: a display in the personal shopping office at which impulse items culled from all over the store are displayed for sale.
''Time is so precious at Christmas that we decided we would set this up,'' said Linda Lee, a Macy's vice president. ''While someone is sitting and waiting for something to be wrapped, they can view 70 different items.''
Other experts agreed that a major thrust by retailers in the pre-Christmas period will be systems and procedures to get customers in and out of the stores quickly - with as many purchases as possible, of course.
''In many families they no longer have the designated shopper, namely the unemployed mother,'' said John R. Kelly, a sociologist at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign. ''We did one study last year which showed that a main concern people have about shopping is the amount of time it takes.''
 
ESCORTS FOR SHOPPING
 Personal shoppers are sales people who know the merchandise in all departments and are paid to help you shop. A store may have 25 or more on duty in the holiday season. They work for salaries, not commissions, and will spend as much time as you need. Here are some things to remember:
* No minimum purchase is either required or implied, nor are there any extra charges for this service.
* It is best to call for an appointment, but personal shoppers who are available will take a customer through the store at any time.

PUB-DATE: November 19, 1989

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 1, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1997 words

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Curing the Greenhouse Effect Could Run Into the Trillions

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
World political leaders may be rushing to broad accord on the urgent need to halt global warming, but since the mid-1980's economists have been worrying about the bill. Their misgivings have been deepened by recent estimates of the cost of limiting emissions of carbon dioxide, which is the primary cause of the problem.
Economic analysts do not speak with one voice on the issue. But all recent studies, including those carried out by environmentalists, implicitly share one conclusion: unless it proves remarkably easy to adapt technologies that drastically cut the need for oil, natural gas and coal, the price of correcting the carbon dioxide problem will run to trillions of dollars through the next century.
By one pessimistic but not implausible estimate, the United States' annual cost of holding the line on carbon dioxide production could rival the current level of military spending. 
 
Obstacles to Consensus
Economists also agree that the benefits of reducing carbon dioxide are sure to vary greatly from place to place. That will make it difficult for countries to develop a consensus for a collective response to the problem.
Carbon dioxide and other pollutants trap infrared radiation from the sun in the earth's atmosphere, in much the same way a greenhouse works.
Some effort to curb carbon dioxide may eventually prove to be a cost-effective means of coping with the greenhouse effect. But in the near term, most economists conclude, a major effort to limit carbon effluent makes little economic sense unless it can be justified on grounds of energy security or tax revenue.
 
Overwhelmed Natural Processes
Scientists have long understood that certain trace-gases in the atmosphere efficiently trap solar energy and heat the planet. Some are naturally produced. But many, notably carbon dioxide, methane and chlorofluorocarbons, are also byproducts of modern civilization, and are being spewed out faster than the biosphere can neutralize their effects. It is now generally if not universally believed that a resulting warming effect is overwhelming natural processes that tend to cool the atmosphere.
How fast the greenhouse gases are heating the air is not known. Neither the heating effect nor the accumulation of carbon dioxide in the air is thought to have direct effects on human health. But there is at least a chance that another century or perhaps less of unchecked accumulation would melt polar ice and alter weather patterns, leading to coastal flooding and radical changes in land fertility patterns.
For many environmental advocates, those who believe in the ethical obligation to pass on the biosphere intact to future generations, the policy message is clear and simple: move quickly to reduce the production of carbon dioxide, which accounts for about half the greenhouse effect.
 
Using Fear to Get Action
The cause has drawn support from diverse interests who share what David Harrison of the National Economic Research Associates consulting firm, calls ''the Christmas tree view.'' These groups hope to use greenhouse worries as a lever for everything from promoting nuclear power to tightening automobile mileage regulations.
This month, all 68 nations taking part in a high-level conference in the Netherlands agreed that carbon dioxide emissions would have to be stabilized.
Only objections from the United States, the Soviet Union and Japan prevented the conference from endorsing a goal of cutting emissions to 1988 levels by the year 2000. But William Nitze, a State Department official coordinating Bush Administration policy, acknowledges there is now heavy diplomatic pressure for an accord next year.
 
Simulations by Computer
Greenhouse politics have yet to be influenced by sober economic analysis, however. And while environmental groups would generally be inclined to draw different lessons from a new utility-financed simulation by Alan Manne of Stanford University and Richard Richels of the Electric Power Research Institute, almost everyone agrees that the computer model does illustrate the potential cost dimensions of carbon-dioxide containment.
The Manne-Richels model compares a hypothetical future of unconstrained carbon dioxide output with one in which carbon emissions are limited to the 1990 rate through 2000 and then gradually cut by 20 percent.
Even if no technological adaptation to break the link between energy production and fossil fuels proved possible, consumers could muddle through for a while by switching to natural gas, which delivers 70 percent more energy per pound of carbon effluent. But the carbon limit begins to bite deeply around the year 2010.
With cheap supplies of gas exhausted, the model estimates that a twentyfold increase in the price of coal would be needed to force sufficient changes toward energy conservation. Annual losses in output would reach about 5 percent of national income, or about $500 billion, in the year 2030.
Optimists, including the economist Irving Mintzer of the World Resources Institute, argue that technological innovations might sharply cut these costs. And the computer model bears him out. Some reasonably priced way of trapping smokestack carbon would reduce the economic impact by one-tenth.
A low-cost source of electricity from non-carbon fuels, providing solar, nuclear or geothermal energy, would trim it further. Technical change that increased the efficiency of energy use for the entire economy by 1 percent each year at low cost would do yet more.
 
Drop in American Incomes
But even the happy circumstance of technological victories on every front would still permanently reduce American incomes by about 1 percent, according to the Manne-Richels model. And 1 percent in a $5 trillion economy is a whopping $50 billion a year.
Other studies suggest that this most optimistic Manne-Richels scenario is too optimistic. William Nordhaus, an economist at Yale University, pegs the cost of containing carbon emissions to 1990 levels at 1 percent to 2 percent of national income by the middle of the next century. A study in progress by the Congressional Budget Office is reportedly yielding numbers in the same range.
High cost alone need not rule out action, of course, if the alternative is catastrophe. The mere possibility that the greenhouse effect could lead to greater climatic changes in the next 100 years than those experienced in the previous 10,000 might be expected to give even the most detached bean-counters cause to lose sleep.
But according to Thomas Schelling, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, such projections can be misleading. While climate has not changed rapidly in the last century, both the will and technological ability to adapt to radically different weather obviously has. In 1860, he says, 2 percent of Americans lived outside temperate or subtropical zones. By 1980, the percentage had increased to 22 percent.
 
Adjusting to Climate Changes
While changes in rainfall, temperature and sea level could be dramatic, there is yet no reason to believe that the process would be completed too quickly to allow evolutionary responses - expanding irrigation, for example, or building dikes. The cost of growing food might conceivably rise by 20 percent, Mr. Schelling speculates. But this loss, he argues, is almost certain to be overwhelmed by a century's worth of improvements in seed strains and growing techniques.
By the same logic, Mr. Schelling says, the appealing idea of bequeathing the biosphere intact seems arbitrary. The quality of life in 100 years, he suspects, will depend as much or more on the endowment of technology and capital as on the percentage of carbon dioxide in the air. And if money to contain carbon emissions comes out of other investment, future civilizations could be the losers.
This hardly means that the greenhouse effect can be safely ignored. But it does imply that it should be viewed as a problem in balancing costs against benefits. And here, crude initial estimates suggest that for the next half-century or more it may be cheapest to deal with the effects of global warming rather than the causes.
For example, according to the Environmental Protection Agency, the cost of protecting America's coastal cities against a three-foot rise in sea level would be $73 billion to $111 billion, a lot of money but not so much compared with the likely cost of prevention.
A doubling of atmospheric carbon dioxide, likely to occur by the middle of the next century if output is not constrained, would dramatically reduce yields for some crops in some regions. But according to a 1989 study by three Agriculture Department economists, the net losses would be less than one-tenth of 1 percent of income in industrial countries. Argentina and Australia would actually be economic winners, since the likely fall in yields would be smaller than the increases in world prices.
 
Nations Most at Risk
This illustrates a looming problem in prevention strategies. The benefits from controlling greenhouse gases would be far greater in some countries than in others. Bangladesh, India and the Netherlands are at great risk from coastal flooding. But many countries would be able to expand farming into regions that are now too cold or too dry to support it. And a few, like Saudi Arabia, would lose much of their national income in a successful attempt to curb the use of fossil fuels.
The costs of carbon conservation would vary enormously. China, for example, is counting on its rich supplies of coal to develop with limited dependence on imported energy and capital.
Yet without a broad, enforceable agreement on containing carbon, expenditures by individual countries would not pay off. Lester Lave, an economist at Carnegie-Mellon University, argues that an early commitment by the United States to tough carbon standards could lead to the worst of both worlds. ''We pay attention to treaties,'' he says. But big carbon emitters like China and the Soviet Union might ignore their obligations, undermining the whole logic of collective action.''
Such considerations lead many economists, including Mr. Lave, to counsel waiting until more is known before trying to devise preventative measures. Dan Dudek, an economist for the Environmental Defense Fund, draws a different conclusion. He wants to buy a modest amount of insurance against the small possibility of a true greenhouse effect disaster, some as yet undiscovered ecological effect that is impossible to reverse.
This is the time, he argues, to experiment with flexible ''emissions-trading'' systems that ''improve the menu of options'' for slowing global warming at minimum cost. Electric utilities might, for example, buy the right to emit carbon from existing emitters, or plant a sufficient number of trees to absorb an equivalent amount of carbon effluent.
Mr. Nordhaus offers a different rationale for action soon. The potential damage from the greenhouse effect has not been pinned down yet, he concludes; but some damage is almost certainly being done. And any sensible approach to balancing costs and benefits in the future will almost certainly involve a limited attempt to control greenhouse gas emissions, along with parallel efforts to sequestor carbon and mitigate the effects of global warming.
 
A Financial Incentive
A modest tax on greenhouse gases, one targeted at heavily damaging chlorofluorocarbons as well as carbon dioxide, would thus be very likely to increase economic efficiency; it would also give emitters a financial incentive to search for alternative carbon-free technologies. And it could provide billions in taxes to offset the Federal deficit.
Virtually all economists seem to agree on the need to get beyond what Mr. Lave calls the ''Earth Day come back'' syndrome. The symbol of greenhouse effect, they argue, cannot be allowed to obscure the dimensions of the perplexing, high-stakes problem that lies beneath.

HEADLINE: AIR FORCE OFFERS TO CLOSE 15 BASES AND SCRAP MISSILES

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Responding to the Administration's call for major cuts in military spending, the Air Force has proposed closing 15 bases, stretching out purchase of the Stealth bomber and eliminating five fighter wings, Administration officials said today.
The Air Force plan also proposes cuts in purchases of the F-16 fighter, retiring some B-52 bombers that carry conventional weapons and retiring Minuteman II nuclear missiles. The proposal came in response to an order from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney for the services to offer reductions totaling $180 billion from projected spending levels in the three years that begin with the 1992 budget year.
The officials said the Air Force cuts equal about $34 billion, about $10 billion short of the amount the service was asked to find for the three years. #2 Factors Propel Policy It could not be learned today what the other services had suggested to meet the goals set by Sean O'Keefe, the Pentagon's comptroller. Some Pentagon officials have said cuts of two to three Navy carriers and several Army divisions would be necessary to meet the targets. 
Mr. Cheney's request for the $180 billion in cuts from projected spending from 1992 through 1994, disclosed this week, has been driven by the need to reduce the Federal deficit and respond to reforms in Eastern Europe, Pentagon officials said.
The decision to consider cuts of this magnitude is one of the major policy developments in the first year of President Bush's Administration.
The proposed Air Force reductions reflect the difficulties the Bush Administration faces in trying to rein in Pentagon spending without becoming caught up in the whirlpools of self-interest in military services and on Capitol Hill.
The Air Force plan proposes reducing the number of American bases worldwide to 125 from 140, 10 more than it had been previously expected to do. Officials did not say which bases would be cut. Proposals for base closings have historically touched off fevered protests from the House members and senators whose constituents are effected.
 
Counter to Cheney's Wishes
And the preference for stretching out procurement, as opposed to killing weapon systems outright, runs counter to Mr. Cheney's stated preference for making hard choices.
In general, Pentagon officials oppose delaying procurement because it forces inefficiencies in production, thus raising the cost per weapon.
The Air Force proposal does call for canceling some small programs for bombs or missiles, but prefers to extend procurement when it comes to the Amraam missile to shoot down fighter planes, one of the service's more favored new programs.
The plan calls for cutting the number of fighter wings to 31, from 36.
Military officials said the Air Force intends to submit further reductions in the coming days. Administration officials defended the Air Force recommendation against eliminating major weapons programs, citing the importance of maintaining weapons that are the subject of ongoing arms control talks.
Mr. O'Keefe asked the services to come up with cuts totaling $43 billion in fiscal 1992, $59 billion in fiscal 1993 and $78 billion in fiscal 1994, representing a reduction of approximately 5 percent annually after recent assumptions about the rate of inflation are incorporated, Administration officials said.
The Pentagon is looking to the long-term reductions even as it prepares a budget for the fiscal year 1991 that will cut military spending after inflation. An option under consideration includes cuts of about 3 percent.
Administration officials and lawmakers say Mr. Cheney stands at the center of maelstrom as the Administration tries to work out what may become the sharpest cuts in military spending since the end of the Vietnam War.
In an interview with The Washington Post today, Mr. Cheney said he was carrying out President Bush's instructions in ordering Pentagon budget analysts to find ways to cut spending. In assigning the task to Mr. Cheney, the President has underscored a striking feature of the political alignments in his Cabinet. Mr. Cheney, whether by accident or design, has positioned himself as one of the Administration's foremost skeptics about change in the Soviet Union and has thus armed himself with the hard-line credentials needed to roll Pentagon spending back from the high levels reached in the years of President Ronald Reagan's military buildup.
The American military cuts are coming at a time when the Soviet Union is beginning to make its own. Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President, has said the Soviet Union will cut its military spending by 14.2 percent beginning in 1989.
In an interview today on the CNN program ''Evans & Novak,'' Mr. Cheney confirmed that the Soviet Union has cut military spending this year.
The outlines of the Pentagon spending problem have been clear from the moment Mr. Bush anchored his Presidential campaign on a pledge of no new taxes. But they have come into sharper relief in recent weeks, as the fast-moving events in Eastern Europe have increased the pressure for a dramatic change in the military budget.
 
Money for Other Purposes
Mr. Bush's political advisers believe that to hold his support among younger voters, he must make some dramatic proposal on issues of concern to them, which polls show are drugs, the environment and education. One of the largest amounts of money available to deal with these problems is the Pentagon budget.
Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has confided to associates that he fears that the combined impact of the deficit and the euphoria over changes in Eastern Europe could stampede the Administration into cuts of as much as 25 percent in the military's forces over the next five years.
Administration officials say they are determined to learn the lessons of the 1970's, when the Pentagon achieved the post-Vietnam reductions by cutting across the board. Instead of eliminating whole divisions, for example, the Army shaved money for men and supplies from each outfit. The effect of this, Administration officials said, was to create a ''hollow Army'' that looked good on paper but was ill-prepared for combat.

HEADLINE: New York City Opera Union Ratifies a 5-Year Contract

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
Members of the New York City Opera orchestra have ratified a new five-year contract with the company, officials of their union announced yesterday.
The ratification, by a 47 to 16 vote, concluded a bitter 66-day strike that led to the cancellation of the City Opera's fall season at the New York State Theater and jeopardized its spring musicals season and the company's very future.
The vote took place Wednesday night at the State Theater, but the results were sealed until the executive board of the union, Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians, could meet yesterday morning.
''I think this contract is a major victory for both sides,'' said Martin J. Oppenheimer, vice chairman of the City Opera board and its chief negotiator. ''The orchestra has gotten increases that are fair and reasonable, and the company got what is perhaps most important, long-term stability.'' 
 
'A Huge Negative'
John Glasel, president of Local 802, sounded less sanguine. ''We're glad it's over and we hope the contract will lead to better relations,'' he said. ''In my personal opinion, though, the five years is a huge negative.''
Frank Morelli, the orchestra's principal bassoonist and chairman of its negotiating committee, said he thought the contract was the best one possible under the circumstances.
''I'm not really satisfied,'' he said. ''We were faced with the choice of coming to terms with this board or taking them at their word that they would go out of business rather than meet industry standards. I personally couldn't assume the responsibility of trying to force this thing to a cataclysm and hoping something better would emerge from the ashes.''
Christopher Keene, the opera's general director, was more optimistic. ''Five years will give us the chance to improve our relations with the orchestra without being disrupted every three years,'' he said.
 
The Major Provisions
The new contract runs retroactively from June 1 but will not compensate musicians for wages lost in the strike.
Its important terms include:
* A five-year duration, rather than the normal three years.
* Annual raises of roughly 6 percent, with a weekly base minimum of $800 this year - up from $755 in the final year of the last contract - to $1,000 in 1993-4.
* A comparable rise in the hourly rate for rehearsals, with an annual rehearsal guarantee starting in the second year.
* A cost of living provision in which wages can rise up to an additional 2 percent if the New York Consumer Price Index exceeds 6 percent in 1992.
* A rise in the second year in the number of guaranteed workweeks, from 23 to 26, with the elimination of the current six weeks in which either work is provided or half-pay supplementary unemployment benefits are paid. In the fifth year, the guaranteed weeks drop to 25 but the vacation weeks rise from three to four.
* An increase in the pension payments from the current 8 percent of performance pay to 9 percent in the third year and 10 percent in the fifth.
* A reduction in each player's workload in the fourth year from five and one-half performances per week to five and an increase, slightly greater than that received by the regular players, for some 100 substitute musicians who periodically perform with the orchestra.
 
Parity With Other Orchestras
As a whole, the package would seem closer to the company's original goals than those of the orchestra. The orchestra had been seeking parity with the orchestras of the Lyric Opera of Chicago and the San Francisco Opera, which already earn about 20 percent more than the City Opera musicians. An average City Opera player received approximately $27,000 from the company during the last year of the old contract.
Yesterday each side blamed the other for the strike. ''We had to go out just to get the negotiation started,'' Mr. Glasel complained.
The company hopes to settle soon on new contracts with its other unions, chief among them the American Guild of Musical Artists, which represents about 250 singers, choristers, dancers and stage directors.
This strike was but the latest stage in a troubled history of labor relations between the City Opera and its orchestra. Since 1962, every contract negotiation except 1986 resulted in a work stoppage.
Asked if this contract would lead to the same bitterness that followed the 54-day strike of 1983, John Palanchian, vice president of Local 802 and a City Opera violinist for 22 years, said the new pact was better than that of six years ago.
''At least this time,'' he said, ''we didn't have to go through all this agony for nothing.''

HEADLINE: Town Digs Out From Tumbleweed Invasion

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOBRIDGE, S.D., Nov. 15

 BODY:
Some people may see romance in the vision of tumbleweeds rolling along the prairie, but Mayor Darrell Bender of Mobridge sees only horror stories.
His town spent the past week and $8,500 digging out from under 30 tons of the dry prairie weeds.
''We had houses completely buried, streets plugged and alleys blocked,'' Mayor Bender said. ''If I hadn't seen it, I wouldn't have believed it could happen. The worst part is, nothing is to stop it from happening again. All it will take is another strong west wind.'' 
Mobridge is a town of 4,180 people on the east bank of the Missouri River near the North Dakota border. Its economy is built on nearby wheat and corn farms and cattle feed lots, and in more recent years, on a growing number of fishermen and pleasure boaters who use the river.
 
'As Big as Cars'
Residents on the south and west edges of town awoke on the morning of Nov. 8 to find houses buried and streets blocked by thousands of tumbleweeds.
''Some of these things were as big as cars, and they'd piled so thick in one tree belt it looked like a sand dune,'' said John Rothstein, who owns an insurance agency here. ''People had to take front-end loaders and tractors just to uncover their cars.''
Tumbleweed is the common name for a variety of plants that include the Russian thistles prevalent in South Dakota. They grow into fat puffballs in untended fields and ditches and along fences. In late summer and early fall, it is common to see them rolling across a highway or clinging to barbed-wire fences.
The tumbleweeds that bombarded Mobridge grew to an unusual size in the fertile river valley soil that is normally covered by the water of Lake Oahe, a 200-mile-long lake that extends almost from Pierre, S.D., to Bismarck, N.D. Two years of drought dropped the level of the lake this summer to 38 feet below the high-water mark. That uncovered an area of lake bottom two miles long and nearly one mile wide just outside of Mobridge.
A powerful west wind gusting to 60 miles an hour snapped the stalks of huge tumbleweeds and pushed them into town.
 
A Fire Hazard
''When I got up that morning, I couldn't see anything from most of my windows the weeds were so high and thick against my house,'' said Darlene Zahn. ''I couldn't even budge my door to let my little dog out, they were that tight.''
Ms. Zahn, the city finance officer, called the street department for help. Workers cleared a path but not before they gave her cause to worry.
''When I called, they said, Whatever you do, don't start your car,'' Ms. Zahn said. ''I got scared. The thought of a fire with all those things packed around, was really disturbing. There is no way I'd ever have gotten out of that house myself.''
Fire was Mayor Bender's biggest fear, too.
''When tumbleweeds are packed that tightly, they almost explode if they're ignited,'' he said. ''We had a dangerous situation, and we were fortunate to get out of it without injuries.''
City workers pulled weeds away from buildings and houses, and Mr. Bender hired a farmer to bring a four-wheel-drive tractor to crush the plants. The debris was fashioned into windrows, and another farmer brought a baler and picked up the windrows. #30 Tons of Tumbleweed ''We made 60 bales,'' Mr. Bender said. ''I figure 1,000 pounds to 1,200 pounds a bale, or at least 60,000 pounds of tumbleweed. That's 30 tons of weed. We used snow removal money to handle it.''
Unless weeds still growing along the river are somehow removed, the town could be buried again, Mr. Bender said.
''The long-range answer, of course, is a higher water level in the river to cover the problem,'' Mayor Bender said. ''That's not likely unless we get more rain and snow. In the meantime, we're a target for the next west wind that blows in.''

HEADLINE: Atlanta's Boom Area or City's Spoiler?

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 18

 BODY:
From a new skyscraper, Sam Massell presides over the boom town snaking along Peachtree Road that is billed in its own magazine as ''the Cultural Crossroads of the South.''
Mr. Massell is a former Atlanta Mayor, but the locale being extolled is Buckhead, the affluent, overwhelmingly white north Atlanta neighborhood where Mr. Massell is known these days as the unofficial mayor.
Buckhead has been a loosely defined part of Atlanta for 150 years. But when the Georgia Department of Transportation recently put up highway signs officially denoting the area, it posed some intriguing questions about the cultural and economic role played by the whitest part of a city that is now almost 70 percent black. 
''People say, 'Y'all must be up to something,' '' said Mr. Massell, Atlanta's last white Mayor, who served from 1970 to 1974. He is now president of a year-old group of powerful business leaders and developers, the Buckhead Coalition.
''We're just trying to preserve and protect what's here,'' he said. ''We have no desire or thoughts of seceding from Atlanta.''
 
Role in Development
Others say that it is not quite so simple. The growth has played a major role in the city's economic vitality by capturing some of the development that might otherwise have gone to the suburbs. But some feel that the growth has also helped pull development farther from the city's black core south of downtown, creating a new white hub. At the least, what is going on is in keeping with Atlanta's historic preference for something new.
Buckhead's name dates from 1838, when someone killed a deer at what is now the heart of Buckhead's downtown, and then hung it on a post at Henry Irby's store. As Atlanta grew, Buckhead became its most prestigious section, an area of lush, dense foliage and gently rolling hills, with middle-class neighborhoods and the grandiose mansions of Atlanta's business elite.
Over the past decade, Buckhead has been transformed by a surge in construction that has left 20-story office towers, like the one Mr. Massell operates from, across the street from two-story mom-and-pop businesses. Buckhead now has almost 9 million square feet of office space, as against 12 million downtown. A boom in hotel construction will result in 4,000 hotel rooms, and Buckhead now has more than a billion dollars in annual retail sales, dwarfing that of downtown Atlanta.
Downtown Buckhead is also becoming more and more a haven for the Mercedes-and-white-wine crowd. It now offers a plethora of trendy bars and eateries; there are plans for people movers, increased density and more of the feel of a new downtown. Boosters, who like to describe Buckhead as Atlanta's answer to Beverly Hills or Palm Beach, say Buckhead's office market will eventually exceed downtown's.
''I would hate to think what Atlanta would be without a Buckhead,'' Mr. Massell crowed in a recent issue of Inside Buckhead, a slick magazine about the area. ''We are the tail wagging the dog.''
He went on to acknowledge that Buckhead needs the rest of Atlanta, and indeed there is no separating the two. In fact, Buckhead often functions as a reconstituted, upscale version of what Atlanta once was. Its own business elite, the Buckhead Coalition, is modeled after the downtown business establishment that has guided Atlanta's development, and it has the same evangelical zeal for growth.
Atlanta has for decades fought battles over highways planned for inner-city neighborhoods. But this year, the Buckhead Coalition was one of the most ardent backers of a plan approved by the Atlanta City Council in May to build a $274 million six-lane toll road through one of the most densely wooded residential neighborhoods in north Buckhead.
 
Other Side of Growth
Not everyone is happy with the growth and its choking traffic and neighborhood change. Many longtime residents feel that Buckhead, like Atlanta, is losing whatever sense of place and distinctiveness it once had.
''I don't think it will even be habitable in 20 years,'' said Anne Rivers Siddons, a novelist who has chronicled Buckhead life in books like ''Peachtree Road.'' ''Buckhead used to have this wonderful village feel to it, which we've totally lost. It's gone to hell in a BMW.''
To some, Buckhead's growth and the proposed new highway linking it with the white northern suburbs continue and perhaps accelerate the region's lopsided growth away from Atlanta's black majority.
''The harsh fact - in a sense, the sad fact - is that one of the key development forces is the desire of developers and investors to distance themselves from the black population,'' said Clarence Stone, a professor of government and politics at the University of Maryland who wrote ''Regime Politics,'' a recent book on the way Atlanta is run.
 
Integration at the Malls
But other observers, like Leon Eplan, Atlanta's former Planning Commissioner, and Tom Weyandt, Atlanta's Commissioner of Community Development, cite the spurt in construction in downtown Atlanta and say Buckhead is more the northern end of Atlanta's core than the southern end of the white suburbs. And they note that Buckhead's shopping malls serve a truly interracial clientele and that Buckhead bears a disproportionate share of Atlanta's tax burden.
In the late 1960's, James Dickey wrote a poem, ''Looking for the Buckhead Boys,'' in which he searches for the lost Buckhead of his youth. Twenty years later, what remained from his youth is gone as well.
''Most people who grew up in Buckhead can show you any skyscraper or any mall and tell you who used to live there,'' said John Huey, who grew up in Buckhead and is editor of Southpoint magazine here. ''That's Atlanta. When you see something go up, you know it won't be long until they tear it down for something else.''

HEADLINE: Congress Grinds Toward Adjournment

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Lurching toward adjournment, Congress slapped together agreements on politically difficult issues this weekend, from Congressional pay and ethics to the program to protect the elderly from the costs of extended illnesses.
Early this morning, the House gave final Congressional approval to a plan that would raise the salaries of House members, Federal judges and top Government employees by at least a third by 1991 and tighten the lawmakers' ethical rules. Senators chose to give themselves a smaller pay increase but to retain, at least for now, their outside speaking fees, which would be banned in the House.
Senate leaders, who implored their members to accept the House plan for themselves, issued an extraordinary series of rebukes when their pleas were rejected. ''We have failed the country, we have failed the institution and we have failed its future,'' said Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia. 
 
Bush Backs House Plan
The pay and ethics measure is on its way to President Bush, who has endorsed the House plan. A Presidential spokesman said today that the White House still had to review the final bill as amended by the Senate.
The measure won initial passage in the House on Thursday, approval by the Senate on Friday night with the addition of its plan for its own members, then final passage early Saturday morning by the House. The House agreed to the Senate changes and eliminated the need for a conference committee.
In keeping with legislative custom, Congress is suddenly moving on a variety of other fractious issues as next week's planned adjournment for the year approaches. After five weeks of intense bargaining, House and Senate negotiators agreed to accept a House bill that would repeal the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act, which was intended to protect 33 million older Americans from the high costs of extended illnesses. The decision needs the approval of the House and the Senate.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, who was an architect of the program, told reporters about midnight Friday that negotiators were unable to reach a consensus to salvage the program. There was, he said, ''a lot of deep disappointment, starting with me.''
The program had proved enormously controversial because of the surtax it levied on about 40 percent of the elderly beneficiaries to help cover its costs. Some senators vowed they would wage a floor fight on Sunday to save part of the program.
The pay and ethics bill rolled through Congress over the past two days, with leaders in both parties intent on resolving an issue that has haunted this session from the start.
 
'I Regret This Decision'
Under the measure approved early this morning, beginning in 1991 House members would no longer be permitted to accept outside speaking fees, a practice that critics assert is a veiled attempt to influence lawmakers. Under current rules, House members can make up to 30 percent of their Congressional salary in speaking fees and other forms of outside earnings; senators can make up to 40 percent of their salary in speaking fees.
After an emotional and bitter debate Friday night, the Senate refused to accept the House plan for itself. Many senators appear to have made a political calculation that the speaking fees would be less controversial than a sizable pay increase.
''I regret this decision,'' George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate majority leader, said after announcing that he could not muster a majority for adopting the House plan for the Senate and would not force a vote.
Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Republican whip, hailed the House's courage for accepting the larger pay increase, ''while the majority of this body choose to sneak and pad around in the alley and get the bucks.''
Under this legislation House members, Federal judges and top Government employees would get a raise of 7.9 percent in 1990, and 25 percent more, plus an adjustment to make up for inflation, a year later. House leaders estimated that this would raise members' salaries by as much as 40 percent, from the current $89,500 to about $125,000 in 1991.
The Senate, meanwhile, would get a raise in 1990 of close to 10 percent, rising from $89,500 to $98,400. The legislation says that the Senate would eventually ban the acceptance of outside speaking fees, and would reduce the amount that senators could accept, dollar for dollar, as their Congressional salary goes up. But it sets no time frame for their elimination.
 
Close In on Deficit Plan
The late-night session also brought lawmakers an important step closer to final agreement on a plan to reduce the deficit. House and Senate tax negotiators cleared a final hurdle when they tentatively agreed on a plan to raise additional revenue to meet the deficit reduction targets.
Most of the revenue increases would affect businesses rather than individuals. That could clear the way for both Houses to act Sunday on the plan to reduce the deficit.
The plan is aimed at lifting most, but not all, of the $16 billion in across-the-board spending cuts imposed by the President on Oct. 16. The cuts were required under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law because Congress and the President had failed to agree on their own package to reduce the deficit by that date.
Under the tentative agreement between the two Congressional tax committees, a variety of popular tax breaks due to expire at the end of this year, and several that have previously expired, would be extended through Dec. 31, 1991.
Both Houses are pushing to complete their business and adjourn for the year on Monday. But there are many pitfalls along the way, including the possibility of a floor fight in the Senate over the repeal of the health care plan. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, said he would use whatever tactic is available to stop the repeal.
