HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
As U.S. Assesses East-Bloc Policy, Experts Differ on How Bold It Should Be

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE

 BODY:
American foreign policy experts interviewed last week differed widely on what steps the United States Government might take to respond to the radical changes under way in Eastern Europe.
The experts, including scholars and former Government officials, differed on whether Washington should move boldly or cautiously in setting policy on substantive matters. Those included troop reductions, relations with West Germany and the security arrangements of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Their views, offered mainly by telephone in response to questions from The New York Times, generally fell within the parameters defined by Professor Charles Gati of Union College in Schenectady, a specialist in Soviet and Eastern European relations. 
''U.S. policy must steer between two conflicting assumptions,'' he said. ''One is that a historic change is indeed under way in the Soviet Union and in Europe. The other is that the changes that have happened are reversible.
''We simply cannot forget the lesson of Tiananmen Square,'' he said, referring to the Chinese Government's crackdown on the democracy movement in June.
 
The 'Best Place' for Troops
Caspar W. Weinberger, who served as Defense Secretary in the Reagan Administration, said, ''I do not believe that the U.S. security role should be reduced'' in Europe.
''We must recognize that we are not in NATO or in Europe for purely altruistic reasons,'' he said. ''We are there because that is the very best place to defend the United States.
''Our presence there undoubtedly helps materially in the defense of freedom in Europe. But that defense of freedom is enormously in our interest, too. So the main thrust of U.S. policy in Europe should be to stay there.''
Mr. Weinberger, a lawyer who is now publisher of Forbes magazine, said he did not feel that ''anything has yet happened in the world situation that warrants deep reductions in U.S. or NATO military strength - certainly not at this time.''
''The Soviet military threat remains just as great despite a great deal of soothing rhetoric,'' he said.
 
Gorbachev's Prospects Uncertain
Referring to the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, he said, ''Even if Mr. Gorbachev should be completely honest and sincere in all that he has said, we have no indications whatever of how long he may remain in office, and we do not know who or what his successor would be.''
''Under those circumstances,'' Mr. Weinberger continued, ''it would be criminal folly for us to reduce the strength of our military, which after all was a key factor in producing much of the changed behavior we seem to be seeing now.''
Mr. Weinberger was commenting before published reports that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has ordered the armed services to draw up plans for cutting $180 billion in projected spending. The decision reflects the Bush Administration's judgment that the Federal budget deficit and political changes in Europe are eroding support for growth in military spending.
''If there are any troop reductions, they ought to be asymmetrical ones,'' Mr. Weinberger said, ''in which the Soviets would make very much greater reductions than NATO. That is because the Soviets still have a very large imbalance in their favor.''
 
Cuts 'in the Interest of Both'
Prof. Stanley Hoffmann, a political scientist who is chairman of Harvard University's Center for European Studies, said he was certain that troop cuts would take place in Europe within the next three years. ''It's in the interest of both superpowers,'' he said, ''and of course the West Germans are rather eager to be able to reduce their defense establishment also.
''Since there isn't any likelihood of war in Europe, there is no need to maintain the number of troops and weapons which were deemed necessary in the past,'' he added.
Professor Hoffmann, who analyzes American foreign policy, particularly relations with Europe, said that West Germany's continued role as a NATO stalwart would ''very much depend on whether, at some moment in the future, the Soviets offer to West Germany reunification in exchange for neutralization, and whether the West Germans then decide that this is in their interest, which they very well might.
''But ultimately, I think, that particular card is in the hands of the Soviets,'' he said. Neutralization of Germany ''would really mean the end of the two alliances,'' he noted, referring to NATO and the Warsaw Pact.''
 
Reductions 'All to the Good'
Richard Pipes, a director of Eastern European and Soviet affairs in the National Security Council under President Reagan, said, ''I believe it not only possible but likely for major troop reductions to occur in Europe in the next three years.
''If they are equitable, making allowance for the Soviet Union's closer proximity to Western Europe, and verifiable, they should be all to the good,'' he said in written remarks. ''The U.S. devotes some 60 percent of its military budget to the defense of Europe.''
Mr. Pipes, who is the Baird Professor of History at Harvard, said, ''I think it important that the United States, Great Britain and France make it unmistakably clear to Bonn that they will take strong exception to any German arrangements with Moscow at their expense.''
''Even if major troop reductions occur in Europe, and East-West relations improve considerably, Europe is likely to remain the principal focus of our security concerns for strategic, economic and political reasons,'' he said. ''Even a genuine detente is not going to mark an end of great-power competition.''
 
A 'Logical and Sensible' Step
Helmut Sonnenfeldt, counselor of the State Department in the Nixon and Ford Administrations, said that troop reductions were ''a logical and sensible accompaniment to the political transformations that are occurring in the East, and consequently with regard to the division of Europe.''
Mr. Sonnenfeldt, a guest scholar at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said he believed that West Germany would ''remain a major member of the Atlantic alliance in presently forseeable circumstances.
''Of course, there already are serious differences between the Germans and other alliance members on questions of nuclear weapons, or the deployment of nuclear weapons, and of chemical weapons also.
''But I don't believe this affects the basic German decision that it remains in their interest to be tied to the United States and to other European powers through the Atlantic alliance,'' he said.

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
Western Europe Pledges to Aid East

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 18

 BODY:
At an impromptu summit meeting called by France, leaders of the European Community nations tonight pledged to provide all possible economic assistance to East bloc countries that move toward democracy.
The informal session, held over dinner at Elysee Palace, was aimed principally at emphasizing the 12-nation community's determination to play an active role in the process of change sweeping Eastern Europe.
The 12 leaders also gave provisional approval to a French proposal that a new European Development Bank be created to provide low-interest loans to help finance the modernization of Eastern European countries.
 
Aid Linked to Democracy
The community leaders, who in the past have clashed over the pace and extent of their countries' own process of economic integration, appeared to have agreed on the need to link their aid program to democratic advances in Eastern Europe. 
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, who has often been at odds with her European colleagues, said tonight that ''we wish to do everything we can to encourage reform and the process of democracy through the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.''
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany also used the occasion to assuage fears expressed in Paris and other Western European capitals that the dramatic developments in East Germany over the last 10 days might result in a weakening of Bonn's commitments to the community.
''He who thinks we should now withdraw from Europe and take care of German things betrays the reform movement in East Germany, Poland, Hungary and surely tomorrow in Czechoslovakia as well as betraying perestroika in the Soviet Union,'' Mr. Kohl told reporters after the three-hour meeting.
 
Bush-Gorbachev Summit
President Francois Mitterrand of France, who is serving as President of the European Community until the end of this year, also played down speculation that the meeting was called to anticipate the meeting between President Bush and the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, off Malta on Dec. 2 and 3.
Mr. Mitterrand said he had spoken with Mr. Bush by telephone this week and would do so again in the coming days. He added that he expected to meet with Mr. Bush next month. Mrs. Thatcher said the American President would personally brief the leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Brussels after the Malta summit.
 
'Politics of Europe'
Mr. Mitterrand, who addressed a crowded press conference this evening, did nonetheless concede that one motive for tonight's session was to prevent developments in Eastern Europe from dominating the regular biannual community summit meeting to be held in Strasbourg on Dec. 8 and 9.
France hopes that at that meeting the European Community will approve a timetable for accelerating its move toward economic and monetary union as part of an existing program to create a single regional market by the end of 1992.
''If tonight's meeting was called urgently,'' the French President said, ''it was because everyone felt the need to talk about the politics of Europe.''
The focus of the debate, he said, was on how the community can help create healthier economies in Eastern Europe ''in exchange for a verified return to democracy, respect for human rights and the calling everywhere of free and secret elections.''
 
Poland and Hungary Discussed
He noted there was extensive discussion of the needs of Poland and Hungary, which already have economic agreements with the community. He added that it was essential that both countries reach agreements on new economic programs with the International Monetary Fund before the end of this year.
Referring to East Germany, he said its ''expected evolution toward democratic reform'' would open the way for conclusion of similar economic accords with the community. Noting that Bulgaria ''will probably go the way of the others,'' Mr. Mitterrand emphasized that the community wanted to encourage all reform movements in Eastern Europe.
The French leader said tonight's meeting had also asked for a study on his proposal for creation of a European Development Bank. A report, to be prepared by Mr. Mitterrand, Spain's Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, and Ireland's Prime Minister, Charles Haughey, will be presented to next month's summit meeting in Strasbourg.
But Mr. Mitterrand also warned that the community's commitment to completing its own integration program meant that it would not be possible for new members to join the 12 before 1993. He said this would affect not only Turkey and Austria, which have already applied for membership, but also countries of Eastern Europe.
Jacques Delors, the former French minister who participated in today's meeting in his capacity of President of the European Commission, arrived here today after holding talks in Hungary and Poland on the specific needs of the two governments.
In Budapest on Friday, Mr. Delors, who was accompanied by the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, held open the possibility of a loan to tide the Government over until Hungary's first free elections since 1947 are held early next year. He noted that Poland and Hungary were countries ''as European as us,'' and might eventually become ''cousins'' of the Community.
In Warsaw, Mr. Delors Mr. Delors said Poland and Hungary could receive as much as $1 billion from the Luxembourg-based European Investment Bank, while the community could take separate measures to strengthen the Polish currency.

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
Congress Approves Aid Plan Of $852 Million for Poland

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Congress approved legislation early today to support democracy and private enterprise in Poland with a major new program of economic aid over the next three years.
President Bush is expected to sign the bill, even though it provides twice as much money as he requested. The bill provides $852 million for Poland and $86 million for Hungary.
Final approval of the legislation came at 1:10 A.M. when the Senate, by voice vote, adopted a compromise version worked out in negotiations with the House of Representatives. 
Lech Walesa, the founder of Solidarity, appealed for such assistance when he addressed Congress on Wednesday. More than four decades of Communist rule have ''led the Polish economy to ruin, to the verge of utter catastrophe,'' he said.
 
Giving Solidarity a Chance
The legislation was immensely popular on Capitol Hill, but was delayed by two months of partisan wrangling. Republicans did not want Democrats to get too much credit for the legislation, feared a huge aid package could embarrass Mr. Bush and insisted that the bill promote the development of a Western-style free-market economy in Poland.
Senator Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, hailed the bill as ''a wager on Poland's experiment with democracy and an investment in our security,'' and he said it would give ''Solidarity a fighting chance to succeed.''
Mr. Simon, who has many Polish-American constituents, steered the bill through the Senate. He is up for election in 1990, has been listed as a prime target by Republican strategists and faces a challenge from Representative Lynn Martin, who suggested that a recent trip to Poland by Mr. Simon was politically motivated.
The bill, the Support for East European Democracy Act of 1989, seeks ''to facilitate the transition from state-directed controls to a free-market economy'' in Poland and Hungary.
It would provide Poland with $125 million in food aid and $240 million in grants to private businesses, including at least $25 million to help modernize Poland's telephone system. The bill provides up to $200 million to support the Polish currency, the zloty, whose exchange rate against the dollar sometimes fluctuates wildly. Poles have so little confidence in their currency that important business transactions are often conducted in dollars.
 
Loans to Import U.S. Goods
The legislation also provides Federal guarantees for up to $200 million in loans to Polish companies wishing to import American products.
The bill directs the Bush Administration to seek ''a generous and early rescheduling program for debts owed by the Government of Poland'' to the United States and other countries.
It also directs the Labor Department to help Poland develop job retraining programs and a system of unemployment insurance for people who may lose their jobs if state-run industries lay off workers or private businesses go bankrupt.
The bill also provides money to finance academic and cultural exchanges with Poland; to train Polish managers in Western business techniques, and to help Poland reduce air pollution and other environmental problems. $10 Million to Teach Capitalism The United States would spend $10 million to teach Poles the ''commercial, entrepreneurial, financial, scientific and technical skills'' needed in a market economy.
Ted L. Kontek, a founder of the Friends of Solidarity, in Washington, welcomed the aid package, saying, ''It will do a lot to help Poland get out of its economic disaster.''
Rafal H. Krawczyk, a profesor of economics at the Catholic University of Lublin, in Poland, said the United States must follow up to make sure the money is wisely spent.
''The Polish Government has a lot of good will, but it is easy to waste money in Eastern Europe,'' said Mr. Krawczyk, who is spending the year in Washington at the Heritage Foundation. ''Polish officials define the market from handbooks of socialist economics. The difference between the Eastern European understanding of markets and the reality is bigger than you could imagine.''
 
Big Demand for Dollars
The Solidarity-led Government of Poland has adopted an economic plan that calls for making zlotys more freely convertible into dollars. If that happens, Mr. Krawczyk said, there might be a big demand for dollars, and Polish banks ''might run out of dollars in half a year.'' Nobody knows if the $200 million offered by the United States will be ''enough to keep the exchange rate stable,'' he said.
Representative William S. Broomfield, Republican of Michigan, said the Administration supported the final bill because it ''contains the basic legislative package'' requested by the President, as well as many features added by Congress.
The House approved an earlier version of the bill by a vote of 345 to 47 last month. The Senate passed a similar measure on Tuesday by a vote of 99 to 0.
 
'Enterprise Fund' for Hungary
Most of the money for Hungary, $60 million of the $86 million, is for an ''enterprise fund'' that will make loans and grants to private businesses and credit unions in Hungary. The remainder is for scholarships, cultural exchange programs, medical aid and various forms of ''technical training.''
Conservatives who often vote against foreign aid supported the bill, in part because it states that Poland and Hungary should dismantle wage and price controls and give citizens ''full rights to acquire and hold private property.''
Liberals said their support was motivated in part by a belief that the United States could safely reduce military spending if Poland and Hungary became more firmly committed to democracy and free-market economic principles.

PUB-DATE: November 19, 1989

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 26, Column 3; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 964 words

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
Capitalism Arrives in Hungary With a Vengeance

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The gold rush is on in the new Republic of Hungary, even before the shape of its future government is clear.
Every weekend, the Audis and BMW's and Opels and Mercedes-Benzes roar in from West Germany and Austria, laden with shoppers and sightseers, and the hotels are so packed with businessmen that message centers and room-service waiters often cannot cope.
There were three or four antique shops on Buda's Castle Hill last summer, when President Bush was in town; now there are almost a dozen. Workmen are building new boutiques all over the city. Prices for vacation houses on Lake Balaton are soaring. 
General Electric has bought a controlling interest in the Tungsram Company, a long-established light-bulb manufacturer, and hopes to challenge Siemens and Philips in Europe from a Hungarian base. That deal was worth $150 million. General Motors is believed to be close to signing a $200 million deal to build auto engines near Gyor in northwestern Hungary.
 
Koreans Buy the Hilton
A South Korean group, local business executives reported, has closed a deal in the last 48 hours to buy the Budapest Hilton Hotel. The Japanese Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, is planning to visit Hungary in January, and the word is that he will have something to announce, perhaps an agreement on a car factory.
Working feverishly to keep up, the interim Government of Prime Minister Miklos Nemeth put out major policy statements this week on the establishment of a stock exchange, on telecommunications and on energy policy. It decided to set up a Labor Ministry to look after the interests of workers in the new capitalist environment. Officials held talks about aid with representatives of the International Monetary Fund and with Jacques Delors, president of the European Community, and Roland Dumas, the French Foreign Minister.
Foreign Minister Gyula Horn flew to Strasbourg to present his nation's application for full membership in the Council of Europe, a grouping of 23 Western European democracies. The joint, in other words, is jumping. Ronald S. Lauder, erstwhile candidate for Mayor of New York and before that Ambassador to Austria, flew into Budapest this weekend from Moscow, where the family cosmetics business has just opened a shop. It already has a thriving outlet here on Vacy Utsa, the local equivalent of Fifth Avenue.
 
'Not for Short Hits'
Now Mr. Lauder, who plans three more visits before Christmas, is looking for hotels, tourist businesses and manufacturing companies to buy -''not for short hits,'' he said, ''but good companies that, with an injection of capital from us, can grow and export, which is the way to generate earnings in hard currency.''
Sitting in the lobby of the Forum Hotel, where at least half a dozen groups of businessmen were huddling, Mr. Lauder said Eastern Europe and especially Hungary ''have got Americans so worked up that they're doing deals they would walk away from in the United States or Western Europe.''
With office space short, communications shaky and the political situation unsettled, Mr. Lauder said, ''a few people will make a lot of money, and a lot of plungers who don't know the territory will lose their shirts.''
Ultimately, the country's leaders promise, all of this activity will benefit the average Hungarian, who so far has seen little profit from the coming of capitalism. For the moment, inflation is cutting into the small fixed income of pensioners, and the forint, the Hungarian currency, is losing ground. Officially, the rate is 55 to the dollar, but in the streets it is rapidly approaching 100.
''I have to charge more, because the money isn't worth anything now,'' said a gray-haired dealer in the flea market, where foreigners flock in search of Jugendstil treasures.
 
Race of Decline vs. Reform
Several months ago, Janos Szentagothai, a former president of the Academy of Science, described the future of Hungary as ''a race between economic decline and political reform.'' His meaning was that it was unclear whether political change would come fast enough to halt the slippage in living standards in a country with an average annual income of only $2,200, about half of that in South Korea.
In formal terms, the change has come faster here than anywhere else in Europe. Hungary's old Communist Party has broken in two - a Socialist Party, which is the official successor to the old party, and a hard-line Hungarian Socialist Workers' Party, which pictures itself as the only real bearer of the Marxist torch.
But there is no sign that either remnant has been able to shake the stigma of the past and establish itself as a popular force. Only 30,000 of the Communist Party's 720,000 members have joined the Socialists. And none of the new parties has had enough time yet to build a widespread following.
The really hard economic decisions have not been made, because no one, in advance of the elections, wants to be blamed for causing hardship.
So the gargantuan agricultural co-ops have not been broken up into the efficient units that top economists here believe necessary. The industrial dinosaurs such as the steel mill at Miskolc have not been closed. The planning bureauracies have not been dismantled. The top-heavy Government-owned companies, many of them near-monopolies, have not been privatized. Payrolls have not been pared. And Professor Szentagothai's race is not over yet.
 
Only the Direction Is Clear
''Nothing is clear here except the direction,'' said Mark Palmer, the United States Ambassador to Hungary. ''The direction is toward democracy and toward a market economy. When the election will be held, what the system will be, who will win, whether the winners will get the economy under control - all of that is still impossible to predict.''

HEADLINE: Ban on Journal Erodes Thais' Tolerant Image

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Although Thailand's ban on the import and sale of The Asian Wall Street Journal is likely to be temporary, it is certain to diminish the country's reputation for tolerance. The damage has increased as the Government considers a similar ban on the weekly Far Eastern Economic Review.
In both cases, the Police Department and Interior Ministry are acting on complaints about particular articles that seem to have offended some Thais' notions of national dignity. Some Government officials, particularly around the Prime Minister, Chatichai Choonhavan, are seeking to have the ban on The Journal lifted rapidly, perhaps as early as next week. The ban was imposed on Nov. 2, but was not enforced until Friday. 
It is not unimportant, some Thai officials acknowledge, that Mr. Chatichai had previously welcomed a suggestion by The Journal that it would like to start publishing in Bangkok next year, in addition to Singapore, Tokyo and Hong Kong, where the paper is edited.
Mr. Chatichai's goal is to make Bangkok a regional financial and publishing center with special ties to Indochina. He is said to understand that The Journal cannot consider printing in Bangkok so long as it is subject to political pressure or a ban on circulation.
The police say they banned The Journal because of an article published in August about a rift in Thai Buddhism, the official religion. The article, by John Berthelsen, focused on the arrest of a fundamentalist monk named Phra Bodhirak on charges of heresy. The story suggested that Buddhist practices can sometimes be less than pure, and clearly stirred the ire of the kingdom's Supreme Patriarch, Somdej Phra Nyanasamvara, who is appointed by the king.
While The Journal's editor, Barry Wain, says the paper received only one letter objecting to the article, a complaint was filed at the Police Department's Special Branch. A recommendation to ban The Journal was apparently forwarded to the Interior Ministry in September, which issued such an order in mid-October. On Nov. 2, the ban legally came into force when it was published in the Royal Gazette.
But no one informed The Journal or its distributor in Bangkok, The Nation, an English-language newspaper. And nothing happened until The Nation's older rival, The Bangkok Post, published a story on Thursday about the ban, along with an editorial criticizing its impact.
Apparently stung into action, the Police Department issued its ban effective with Friday's issue, which was not delivered to subscribers. Mr. Wain flew here and appealed to officials to lift the ban, saying that The Journal ''regretted any misunderstanding the article may have caused.''
The Asian Wall Street Journal, which is owned by Dow Jones, the American publisher of The Wall Street Journal, has a circulation in Thailand of about 2,000 copies.
 
Applying U.S. Standards
The Journal is Asia's only regional English-language newspaper. The paper's efforts to apply American standards of journalism to countries whose domestic media are often censored or controlled has caused it many difficulties, most of all in Singapore.
Dow Jones also owns the Far Eastern Economic Review, a respected weekly magazine. A recent article about AIDS and the sex industry in Thailand, entitled ''The Lust Frontier,'' apparently offended the Tourism Authority of Thailand, which has asked the police to ban the magazine and to refuse to renew the visa of the author, Paul Handley. Mr. Berthelsen of The Journal said that his own Thai visa had just been renewed without difficulty.
The Thais have been moving from autocratic governments to a broader form of participatory democracy. Mr. Chatichai, in office since August 1988, is the first directly elected prime minister in 12 years. Still, it is a transition plagued by intermittent tensions.
While the Thai-language media have been subject to various constraints, foreign-language media have largely been left alone. Similar articles on sensitive topics have brought only oral complaints, provided that they are not published in the region.

HEADLINE: Greek Parties Make Final Effort for Coalition

BYLINE: By PAUL ANASTASI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATHENS, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Greece's feuding political parties have embarked on a last-ditch effort to form an all-party government to end the political and economic crises resulting from this month's inconclusive general elections.
The negotiations, called by President Christos Sartzetakis, are taking place amid clashes between anarchists and the police and stringent credit restrictions to save the economy from collapse.
If the parties fail in their effort, then new elections will have to take place on Dec. 17, the third elections in six months. They have until Tuesday. 
The attempt to set up an all-party administration, a last resort specified under the Constitution, followed the successive failures of each of the three major parties to form a coalition government after the Nov. 5 election.
Though the conservative New Democracy Party outpolled the Socialist Party of former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, it fell 3 seats short of a majority in the 300-member Parliament. The conservatives, who got 46.2 percent of the vote, attributed the deadlock to the electoral law passed by the Socialist Government shortly before it lost power this year. The electoral system is also the main reason for the three major parties' failure so far to agree to an all-party administration. The Socialists and Communists are insisting on further changes to the law to make representation in Parliament more proportional to the popular vote, a move from which they and smaller parties would benefit. The conservatives, led by Constantine Mitsotakis, prefer reinforced proportional representation, by which the larger parties would get a boost in their number of seats to ease the formation of a stable one-party government. They say that adoption of the Socialist-Communist demands would increase political instability and that the economy would deteriorate further.
Mr. Papandreou, who remains a strong political figure despite being indicted on charges related to a wave of scandals, almost succeeded last weekend in forming a coalition with the Communists and several independents. But his efforts failed when his offer was rejected by the sole deputy of the environmentalist Green Party.
 
Economic Crisis Deepens
The political situation is aggravated by the economic crisis. The Bank of Greece last week imposed severe restrictions on credit and mortgage loans for the private sector, saying it needed the money to cover the enormous public deficit. It said there was only enough money to pay civil servants and pensioners up to the end of December. In addition, over the last two days students and anarchist groups have clashed with the police and have caused extensive damage during rallies marking the anniversary of a 1973 student uprising against the rightist military dictatorship. They also made an unsuccessful attempt to storm the United States air base in Athens, demanding that the American bases in Greece be abolished.
The uncertain political climate here since the first inconclusive elections in June has caused a sharp drop in investment and productivity, as well as losses on the stock exchange. Discussions of key foreign policy issues have also been suspended, including talks on the future of the American bases and the American extradition request for a Palestinian wanted in connection with the bombing of a Pan Am jet in 1982.

HEADLINE: Is It Time Now to Cry for 'Evita'?

BYLINE: By JAMES GREEBERG; James Greenberg is senior editor at American Film magazine.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Political unrest, financial collapse and bruised egos - enough to rival the life of the dramatic Eva Peron herself - have marked the tortured path of ''Evita'' from stage toward the screen. Like so many film projects in Hollywood that go on for years without being made, ''Evita'' is an example of the hazards of the high-stakes marriage between art and commerce.
 
Almost since its London opening in 1978, the Andrew Lloyd Webber-Tim
Rice opera has been talked about as a potential motion picture, and with good reason. To date, more than 100 productions have been staged in 12 languages. The show has grossed in excess of $300 million, and the sound track has sold more than 10 million units. Four film companies have had their hands on the property; seven directors have been considered, and at least 15 actresses have been touted. And still no movie. 
If the history of the production resembles an elephant described by blind men, as one participant put it, it is because everyone involved has a different version of what happened based on their own experience and self-interest. And, as is often the case in Hollywood, many of the those interviewed for this story would not speak for attribution, if at all, about sensitive issues.
It did seem, however, that when Oliver Stone was signed in April 1988 to direct the film version of ''Evita,'' the long-delayed production might finally get under way. Meryl Streep was in the wings to star as the Argentine actress who became mistress and wife to the dictator Juan Peron and a national hero. The Weintraub Entertainment Group was financing the film, Robert Stigwood was producing and a Christmas 1989 release was tentatively planned. Now Mr. Stone is gone, Ms. Streep is likely gone and W.E.G. is gone. What remains is Mr. Stigwood and a project in search of a production.
But the failure to get ''Evita'' made is not just simply a set of unfortunate circumstances. There are some persuasive reasons why the project has remained stagebound. To make any motion picture is difficult (''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Next'' took 13 years), but Broadway musicals bring with them special problems. With the exception of the ''street'' musicals of the 70's (''Grease,'' ''Hair''), the tradition of film musicals has all but disappeared. The less than smash business of films such as ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' ''Godspell'' and ''Chorus Line'' delivered a sure message to producers that musicals were a genre in trouble artistically and commercially. Furthermore, for a young audience accustomed to the quick rhythms of MTV, a story in operatic form was regarded as problematic.
The producer Allan Carr (''Grease'' on film, with Mr. Stigwood, ''La Cage aux Folles'' on stage) agrees that ''musicals are like any other movies but trickier because you have not only the Hollywood people to satisfy but the Broadway people to satisfy, so what you've got are eight different camps vying for their own interests. Hollywood is terrified of Broadway.''
Over the years, ''Evita'' may have given the impression of being more active than it actually was. Because of Mr. Stigwood's relative silence on the matter, the press often took the slightest rumbling as fact. Among the more tantalizing combinations advanced by the media were: Franco Zeffirelli directing Diane Keaton; John Travolta, Olivia Newton-John and Elton John as Che Guevara, Eva Peron and Juan Peron, respectively; Bette Midler as Eva; Pia Zadora as Eva; Barbra Streisand as Eva and Elliott Gould as Juan; Sylvester Stallone as Che; Barry Gibb as Che and Meatloaf as Che.
 
Ken Russell Wanted Liza Minnelli
 In reality, Mr. Stigwood says that the project has had only two intense periods of activity: when Ken Russell was on board in the early 80's and most recently with Mr. Stone. There have been a number of directors who had ''great interest and will,'' says Mr. Stigwood, ''but not much clarity'' about how they would translate the play to the screen. ''When we sat down and talked they couldn't tell me how they'd do it.''
Paramount Pictures bought the rights to develop the material in 1981, and shortly thereafter Mr. Russell was named director with plans to shoot in Spain. At the time, the frontrunner for Eva was Elaine Paige, who had originated the role on the London stage. But as the librettist Tim Rice recalls, ''The Hollywood boys wanted an international film star, which I thought was generally narrow thinking, since so many films are hits without names.''
Mr. Russell, not surprisingly, had a mind of his own and screen-tested Liza Minnelli - in a blond wig. When he insisted that he could not make the film without her, Mr. Stigwood finally fired him. ''Russell was an insane choice and would have wrecked the film if he had gotten his hands on it,'' says Mr. Rice. ''I was relieved when he got the boot.'' Mr. Russell could not be reached for comment. Following Mr. Russell's departure, Mr. Stigwood attempted to pick up the pieces, and in not so rapid succession, the directors Herbert Ross, Richard Attenborough, Alan Pakula and Hector Babenco came and went.
 
Madonna Wanted A Rewritten Score
 The project was largely dormant in the mid-80's, with only occasional flurries of activity, as Mr. Stigwood went off to produce ''Staying Alive'' and other projects. By this time Paramount lost its enthusiasm but was briefly roused from its indifference when Madonna showed an interest. Obviously serious about playing the part, she arrived for a meeting with Mr. Stigwood with her hair styled in a 40's twist and decked out in an evening gown Eva Peron herself might have worn.
Mr. Stigwood was impressed with Madonna and actually thought she would be good in the role. His enthusiasm cooled considerably, however, when the actress requested that Andrew Lloyd Webber's score be rewritten to suit her. The producer did think enough of Madonna to suggest that Mr. Stone meet with her when he took over the reins, but a 15-minute meeting ended that possibility.
By 1987 the project seemed indefinitely stalled when Jerry Weintraub entered the picture. Mr. Weintraub was an old crony of Mr. Stigwood's from the music business who had made a fortune managing the careers of performers like Bob Dylan and John Denver and was now ready to move into the film business in a big way. He had raised some $460 million in bank loans and private investment to finance the Weintraub Entertainment Group, and one of his first moves was to pick up the rights to ''Evita.''
 
Oliver Stone Tried For Argentina
 At about the same time, Oliver Stone, hot off the success of ''Platoon,'' asked his agent to check with the Robert Stigwood Organization about ''Evita.'' Mr. Stone was a fan of the musical and wanted to know why it had never been made as a film. The response from the Stigwood group was positive - Mr. Rice was ''red hot keen'' on him - and before long the two sides were in negotiation.
What Mr. Stone brought to the project that earlier candidates didn't was a vision of how it should be done. He imagined a production that returned to the glamorous style of the Vincente Minnelli and Arthur Freed musicals of the 50's with beautiful sets and a cast of thousands. He believed ''a whole country'' was needed as backdrop for the action when Eva addressed the masses from the palace balcony. It was a fundamental precept for Mr. Stone, who began immediately to work on the screenplay.
What the new production also had going for it was a dramatically changed political climate in Argentina, which could make it possible to film in Eva Peron's homeland. As recently as the late 70's, anyone seen scrawling Eva Peron's name on a wall could be sentenced to death, but after the Falkland Islands debacle, the ruling military junta was ousted as the Peronist Party enjoyed a resurgence.
Mr. Stone set off on an exploratory trip to Argentina, where he visted Eva Peron's birthplace and encountered a Government eager for American film business. In subsequent visits, the newly elected President and head of the restored Peronist Party, Carlos Saul Menem, assured Mr. Stone that Argentina was not a banana republic and guaranteed the production freedom of speech as well as 50,000 extras.
The one remaining problem was who would play the lead. The press fueled speculation that Olivia Newton-John or Madonna was about to be offered the role. Barbra Streisand was so irked by published reports that she was under consideration that she denied for the record any interest. Barely mentioned was Ms. Streep, perhaps because on previous occasions when Mr. Stigwood had inquired about her availability, her agent, the powerful Sam Cohn, had reportedly demanded that his client be packaged with a director and writer from the same agency, International Creative Management. Mr. Cohn was unavailable for comment on this or any other matter related to ''Evita.''
Mr. Stone and Ms. Streep met, and a musical audition was scheduled. Mr. Stigwood recalls her arriving ''very quietly and very secretively'' at his New York office to rehearse with his musical director. After two weeks of work, she recorded a tape with just a piano backing, and the results, according to Mr. Stigwood, were ''just mind-boggling what she had achieved'' in such a short time. ''She has a marvelous voice.'' A copy of the tape was sent to Mr. Stone, Mr. Lloyd Webber and Mr. Rice, who all agreed that they had finally found their Evita. Mr. Lloyd Webber, Mr. Rice and Mr. Stigwood jointly control the rights to make the film.
 
Then Eyes Turned Toward Spain
 With Mr. Stone and Ms. Streep in place, there was now every reason to believe that ''Evita'' would finally be made. A $29 million budget was submitted to W.E.G., and an early 1989 start was targeted. But no sooner was the production rolling again than the wheels started to come off. Food riots erupted in Argentina in the summer, with 13 people killed. Fearful of a work stoppage and concerned about the safety of the cast and crew, Mr. Stigwood and Mr. Weintraub balked at the prospects of shooting there.
To this day, sitting in his Venice Beach, Calif., office, Mr. Stone heats up when he talks about the decision. ''I argued to shoot there, but Weintraub said he had it from his sources in the White House - he was a major financier of the Bush campaign - that there was no way he would shoot in Argentina. I told him he was defaming a country.'' For his part, Mr. Stigwood is willing to take the blame and says that the decision to pull the plug on the Argentina shoot was the result of State Department intelligence he had obtained, not Mr. Weintraub.
In any case, the Argentine shoot was canceled and after unsuccessful reconnaissance missions in Brazil and Chile, focus was shifted to Spain, where the estimated budget ballooned to $35 million. But by this time there was trouble at home as well. Without a box-office hit, W.E.G. was experiencing a severe financial drain and was virtually without production money. This led to what is euphemistically known in Hollywood as ''creative differences,'' and W.E.G. decided to abandon the project.
According to the W.E.G. president Kenneth Kleinberg, when the company took over the project in 1987, it imagined a budget in the $16 million range. W.E.G. saw the production as a concept picture not necessarily done on such a large scale. ''It's an opera; we're not talking about 'Batman,' '' argues Mr. Kleinberg.
 
When Money Became a Factor
 While W.E.G. apparently remained very high on Mr. Stone's script, ''The magnitude of the project was too large and consequently too expensive'' to continue, explains Mr. Kleinberg. ''If you decide all you want to spend is the money to buy a Pontiac and you look at a Mercedes, you might like it, but feel that you can't afford it.''
Mr. Kleinberg insists that the company's declining financial position had nothing to do with its decision to abandon the project and categorized it as purely a business decision. ''We didn't feel that, in the package presented to us, the rewards outweighed the risks.''
Other parties involved, however, see W.E.G.'s collapsing bank account as precisely the reason the filmJU wasn't made at that time. ''It didn't really matter if it was $26 million or $32 million because they [W.E.G.] had run out of production funds,'' says Mr. Stigwood. Mr. Stone was even more blunt. ''If Weintraub had the money, Meryl and I would be in Spain shooting right now.''
But they didn't, and with time running out at the end of August, W.E.G. informed Mr. Stigwood that the company was electing not to proceed with the production. That could have been the end of the road for ''Evita'' had not Carolco Pictures, the home of ''Rambo'' and the company where Mr. Stone had a production deal of his own, come to the rescue. Carolco picked up where W.E.G. left off and over the next three weeks tried to hammer out deals with the principal people. Ms. Streep, through Mr. Cohn, was asking for a pay-or-play deal, a common clause for a star of her stature whereby she would be paid for her commitment of time whether the film was shot or not.
According to parties privy to the negotiations, things came to a boil in mid-September when Ms. Streep kept escalating her salary demands. A 48-hour deadline was set by Mr. Cohn and was apparently met when all hands agreed to take a cut in their share, which would then go to Ms. Streep. Everything appeared to be back on track again when, in Mr. Stigwood's words, ''out of the blue,'' Mr. Cohn sent a terse, two-line fax to Carolco and to R.S.O. advising them that Ms. Streep was pulling out of the project for ''personal reasons'' because of exhaustion. Mr. Stigwood was reportedly furious and in retaliation sent out a press release to announce her departure.
 
Meryl Streep Did The Tango and Left
 Ms. Streep was in the midst of completing back-to-back productions, ''She-Devil'' and ''Postcards From the Edge.'' She had begun to work with the ''Evita'' choreographer Paula Abdul on the tango and was taking singing lessons to strengthen her voice and was scheduled to start rehearsals shortly.
At least one person with knowledge of the production wondered if her exhaustion may have stemmed as much from a weariness with negotiations and the prolonged preproduction period and concern over financing as any physical ailments. Another party suggested that Ms. Streep had wanted to get out earlier but when her demands were met, she was left no choice but to withdraw.
Whatever her reasons for leaving, 10 days later, according to Mr. Stigwood, Ms. Streep reconsidered and decided she wanted to make the movie after all. But when Mr. Stigwood called Mr. Stone to inform him that ''Meryl was back on track,'' the director told him that he was not. In the week that the film was down, Mr. Stone had already let the key production people go and had refocused his energies on a film about the rock group, the Doors, which he had been writing for the last several months.
For Mr. Stone, the roller-coaster ride of trying to make ''Evita'' had just gone on too long. Crucial relationships in making a movie may have been strained beyond repair. He also feared a production budget that could easily run up to $50 million. ''If it had all been there, it would have been fun and fantastic,'' says Mr. Stone, with equal traces of disappointment and relief. ''What started as a whim turned into a reality'' for Mr. Stone, and he says he was exhausted by the process.
But true to its history, ''Evita'' is still not dead. Mr. Stigwood is hoping to resurrect the project with Ms. Streep and a new director, using Mr. Stone's script, and is awaiting an answer from the actress. Despite the countless disappointments, Mr. Stigwood refuses to be discouraged and says that the production could be under way by early summer in Seville and in theaters by Christmas of 1990.
''Of course, to be in the wonderful world of entertainment you have to be optimistic. Some wonderful things have taken 10 years to make,'' Mr. Stigwood says. And, for better or worse, each of them has been the work of a producer who just wouldn't let it go.

LENGTH: 1035 words

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
Cabaret Polishes Its Image As a Solo Act With Attitude

BYLINE: By Stephen Holden

 BODY:
For most Americans, the term ''cabaret,'' if it suggests anything at all, probably conjures up movie images of a hyperkinetic Liza Minnelli and an epicene Joel Grey in a squalid Berlin dive on the eve of the Nazi era. In the film ''Cabaret,'' the Minnelli character's invocation of ''divine decadence'' helped stamp the very word ''cabaret'' with intimations of depravity that it unfortunately still carries.
A contemporary and equally negative image of cabaret is presented in the recent movie ''The Fabulous Baker Boys.'' During an audition sequence, aspiring nightclub singers are presented as a bunch of self-dramatizing, no-talent caricatures. The song chosen to illustrate the common denominator of musical taste among nightclub patrons is ''Feelings.'' And although the supposedly wonderful singer portrayed by Michelle Pfeiffer isn't embarrassing, her blandly sultry voice communicates no special feeling or point of view about what she's singing. 
Cabaret's negative image was one of many issues addressed last month by a shifting panel of nightclub owners, journalists and performers who convened at Town Hall for three days as part of the First Cabaret Convention. Organized by the Mabel Mercer Foundation, the weeklong series of events also presented several gala performances at which more than two dozen performers, ranging in age from their late 20's to well into their 70's, each sang two or three songs. Not all were first-rate, yet the level of talent and taste was on the whole impressive.
Besides image, some of the other problems addressed during the panel discussions were the reluctance of television talent coordinators to book performers perceived as cabaret-oriented, the tightrope economics of operating nightclubs and the difficulty of attracting the theater audience into clubs. Although no miraculous solutions were offered, the convergence of so many interested parties - the panel discussions drew audiences of around 200, and the galas, bargain-priced at $5 a ticket, were nearly sold out - helped bolster a sense of solidarity within the cabaret community.
If the convention's concept of cabaret had encompassed rock and comedy clubs, there would have been no crisis to discuss. In its narrow definition, however, the term refers not just to a physical setting but to a particular kind of entertainment and sensibility. The quintessential cabaret act is a solo performance of about an hour in which a singer, with an accompanist or backup group, turns a carefully selected program of popular songs into an intimate, often idiosyncratic expression of personal taste and attitude.
The golden age of cabaret in America is remembered as the 1940's and 50's, when singers like Mabel Mercer and Billie Holiday performed regularly in jazz clubs on West 52d Street, the Copacabana played host to Frank Sinatra and New York's grander hotels had plush, sophisticated show rooms. Though those days may be long gone, casualties of television, rock and the rise of glitzy entertainment capitals like Las Vegas and Atlantic City, the cabaret tradition continues in its quiet way in places like the Ballroom, Jan Wallman's, the Cafe Carlyle and the Oak Room in the Algonquin Hotel.
Cabaret matters for the same reasons the classical art song does. It is the only forum in which popular singers who possess vision but don't write their own material can express themselves on such an intimate and personal level. More than that, it is the most significant way in which the prerock tradition of American popular song is kept alive.
The last 10 years have seen a growing realization by music historiansand cultural institutions of just how singular and valuable that tradition is. ''The great craftsmen,'' as the late Alec Wilder called songwriters like Jerome Kern, Cole Porter, Rodgers & Hart, Johnny Mercer, Irving Berlin and Harold Arlen, bequeathed a literature that begins to look like a peculiarly American form of classical music.
Refined in its craft yet remarkably adaptable in performance, this literature occupies a special historical place. Conforming neither to the European classical tradition of written music intended for strict interpretation nor to the oral tradition of American jazz and rock, it stands as a bridge between opposite musical worlds. The often silly, dated shows in which the pop standards were introduced may never be mounted again, but the best songs have a life of their own.
Like any other music, this literature can continue to live only through performance. Though its preservation has already been guaranteed by a large body of recordings whose cornerstones are the Ella Fitzgerald songbook albums and most of Frank Sinatra's work, its future vitality depends on live performance. This large pool of literature represents about three-quarters of today's cabaret repertory. One has only to go see a performer like Andrea Marcovicci, now at the Algonquin, sing Irving Berlin's ''Always'' to discover how a cabaret artist can take a piece we think we all know and re-examine it from a fresh, very contemporary perspective.
Nowadays it is fashionable to disparage the predominance of romantic love and its complications in the lyrics of American pop standards. Yet as several generations of singers have shown, the love lyric is an endlessly adaptable platform for expressing states of feeling and philosophical points of view that go far beyond the question of two people ending up in each other's arms. As the generation of gospel-trained pop-soul singers demonstrated in the 60's, the lines between the secular and sacred in popular song are really very thin. Gospel inflections turn love songs into hymns. In the hands of a thoughtful, expressive cabaret performer, a ballad of unrequited love can become a pained, moment-by-moment reflection on spiritual faith and the meaning of life.
It would be foolish to anticipate a mass audience for a form as rarefied in its way as classical art song. But that's the level of artistry that cabaret, at its best, aspires to. More than just keepers of the flame of a classic literature, today's serious cabaret performers are vernacular art singers without an academy to certify their significance.

PUB-DATE: November 19, 1989

SECTION: Section 2; Page 17, Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1841 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
Japan's New Screen Image: Economic Toughie

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA; Susan Chira was a New York Times correspondent in Japan for nearly five years.

 BODY:
There is one moment in ''Black Rain'' when it is clear that the old film images of Japan are giving way to new ones.
Two detectives, American and Japanese, are trading insults at a bar. ''Music and movies are all America is good for,'' says the Japanese detective, played by Ken Takakura. ''We won the peace.''
The Japan of ''Black Rain'' has muscle. It is rich, powerful and arrogant, as befits a country that now challenges its former conqueror. 
This Japan is not the defeated land of ''Sayonara,'' the 1957 film starring Marlon Brando as an American soldier in occupied Japan who has an ill-fated affair with a geisha. Nor is it the rebuilt Japan that clings to noble traditions pictured in ''The Yakuza,'' the 1975 film that also teamed an American policeman with Mr. Takakura, this time playing a former gangster.
There is a new edge running through the portrayal of Japan in ''Black Rain,'' an edge born of economic rivalry. The film, which opened in the early autumn, has garnered mixed reviews, but is a hit in both Japan and the United States. The success of ''Black Rain'' insures that this new image of Japan is reaching mainstream audiences who have had little other exposure to Japan. And more films focusing on the American-Japanese relationship may be on the way. Alan Poul, the associate producer of ''Black Rain,'' who is fluent in Japanese and has worked extensively in Japanese film productions, said he knows of three separate film projects circulating about the life of American baseball players on Japanese teams.
''Black Rain'' pits Michael Douglas as an iconoclastic, dedicated but morally tarnished cop against the rule-bound but upright Mr. Takakura in a rivalry that mimics the one between their two countries. This undercurrent of economic tension, film critics and historians say, is replacing older film images of Japan, just as trade tensions between Japan and the United States dominate most discussions of relations between the two nations.
''I do think we are seeing a changing image,'' said Keiko McDonald, an associate professor of Japanese literature and cinema at the University of Pittsburgh. ''Japan as an economic power is very much to the fore.'' Professor McDonald had a cameo role in one of the earliest films to focus on Japan's economic role, the 1986 ''Gung Ho,'' the saga of an ailing American automobile plant whose workers ask the Japanese to manage the factory.
''Gung Ho'' recounted the tensions between the Japanese managers, shown as joyless, overworked perfectionists, and the more easy-going American workers. In ''Gung Ho,'' the Japanese are setting the standard of excellence, and it is the Americans who must work at near-superhuman levels just to keep up. Along the way, some of the Japanese managers learn to relax a little and have more fun, while the Americans gain a new pride in their work.
Yet this new image of Japan, in the eyes of many scholars and film critics, is little better than the old stereotypes. ''There was the geisha and the samuarai, the houseboy and the gardener, the bucktoothed, slanty-eyed kamikaze pilot,'' said Peter Grilli, an authority on Japanese films who has also examined the way American movies portray Japan. ''Now it's the Japanese as slick businessmen. There is no subtle depth to the image. A lot of stereotypes go from the economic pages to the screen.''
Todd Gitlin, professor of sociology at the University of California at Berkeley and a chronicler of American popular culture, pointed to the popular video creation ''Max Headroom.'' Several years ago, in the original episode, a reporter is trying to unearth the evil forces behind a television commercial that causes some viewers to explode. The bad guys turn out to be a Japanese company, Zik-Zak. By contrast, he said, the malevolent force in the 1976 film ''Network'' turned out to be Saudi Arabia.
''It's not uncommon to see the Japanese as a single cartel,'' he said. ''It's like the recent Newsweek headline 'Sony Invades Hollywood.' It's sort of a horror movie that's playing in America.''
On the surface, of course, ''Black Rain'' is not about economic rivalry at all. Michael Douglas plays an American cop who captures a Japanese gangster in New York, escorts him back to Japan and then hands him over at the airport to Japanese gangsters posing as police.) Under investigation for skimming profits off a drug deal back home, suspected by his superiors of taking a payoff for letting the Japanese gangster go, Mr. Douglas knows he cannot go back without recapturing his gangster. But his quest is frustrated by the Japanese police, who do not want him interfering with their by-the-book investigation. Mr. Takakura is assigned to be his liaison, and the film charts how Mr. Douglas enlists him in the search for his man through the shadowy world of Japan's yakuza, or gangsters.
In ''Black Rain,'' with flashes of realism, come more ominous images. The film is shot in Osaka, long a center of business and the underworld. Ridley Scott, the director who also emphasized stark urban settings in ''Blade Runner,'' shows Osaka mostly in darkness or shadow, suffusing the film with a sense of menace and mystery. And while the action focuses on staking out, chasing and shooting gangsters, the film's not-so-subliminal message is the superiority of the American way.
Michael Douglas is the embodiment of the American cowboy - loner, rule breaker - while Ken Takakura expounds the value of belonging to a group and obeying its codes. The investigation proceeds only after Mr. Douglas has convinced his Japanese counterpart to break the rules and go after the gangsters on their own. Although Mr. Takakura suffers for his rebellion and is briefly exiled from his group, he finally joins Mr. Douglas on his mission, and together they rope in their man.
''The movie says that Americans have to teach Japanese who cannot act effectively because they are bound by rigid rules,'' said Kyoko Hirano, director of the Japan Society's Japan Film Center. ''Takakura's character becomes sympathetic when he moves closer to the American model.''
That is a very different lesson than the one imparted in ''The Yakuza,'' written and filmed before economic conflict between Japan and the United States grew so heated.
''Black Rain'' is set in Osaka, famous even in Japan for its pursuit of money, but most of the action in ''The Yakuza'' takes place in Kyoto, a seat of Japanese tradition. This setting informs the film, which is a reverent, admiring portrait of Japanese values. In ''The Yakuza,'' directed by Sydney Pollack, Robert Mitchum plays an American detective who returns to Japan for the first time since his posting there as an American soldier during the United States Army's occupation.
Trying to help an old friend whose daughter is kidnapped by the yakuza, he is forced to enlist the help of Ken Takakura, as a former gangster and the brother of Mr. Mitchum's former mistress. Mr. Takakura hates his sister for having consorted with his former enemy and grudgingly agrees to help Mr. Mitchum because he had saved his sister's life. But rather than Mr. Mitchum teaching Mr. Takakura about the American way, it is Mr. Takakura who introduces him to the Japanese ideals of duty, honor and obligation. In the end, realizing that he has ruined Mr. Takakura's life, Mr. Mitchum chops off his finger, a yakuza tradition to amend for misdeeds. In doing so, he wins the friendship and respect of his former foe.
''The American in 'Black Rain' remains an outsider,'' said Professor McDonald. ''He comes out with only a little bit of knowledge about Japan. But in Sydney Pollack's film, the protagonist played by Mr. Mitchum returns to the United States with a much broader understanding of Japan. In 'The Yakuza,' the pattern moves from disparity to understanding to harmony.''
The clash of values is hardly a theme new to ''Black Rain,'' but now that contest is painted in explicitly economic terms. The gangster that Michael Douglas is chasing belongs to a counterfeiting ring, plotting to distribute counterfeit American money - and thus, by implication, to ruin the American economy. Several economists, policy makers and historians, notably the late Theodore White, have argued that Japanese are out for revenge, winning economically the war they lost politically. That, the head of the yakuza organization tells Michael Douglas, is what he is after.
''I was 10 when the B-29's came,'' he tells him. ''You made the rain black. You shoved your values down our throat. We forgot who we were. I am paying you back.''
Exchanges like these have fueled accusations by some scholars and film critics that the film is racist, or at the least grossly insensitive. Black rain is the way Japanese refer to the radioactive fallout that darkened the sky at Hiroshima and Nagasaki.
''I was extremely offended by the title,'' said John Dower, a professor of history and Japanese studies at the University of California at San Diego, who has written a widely acclaimed book on American anti-Japanese wartime propaganda. ''It's like taking Auschwitz and making it a code name for some gangster movie. Then using it gratuitiously in a speech about we're going to ruin your economy by taking revenge for your black rain - it somehow turns a tragedy into one more Hollywood gimmick.''
The film's producers and actors say ''Black Rain'' is not racist, and point to its huge popularity in Japan. On a recent trip to Japan to promote the film, Mr. Douglas found that the Japanese thought that Mr. Takakura, not he, was the hero. They see Mr. Takakura redeeming Mr. Douglas, teaching him a lesson in honesty by telling him that a cop who slips even a little betrays his profession. Japanese audiences burst into applause when the gangster talks about paying back Americans for forcing their values onto Japan. He and Mr. Poul said ''Black Rain'' reflects real conflicts between the two countries that are better aired than hidden.
Mr. Poul, the associate producer of ''Black Rain,'' said he does not believe the film chooses sides. ''I feel that Michael Douglas as a loner hero is a venerable movie icon and doesn't necessarily represent any proselytizing by the film makers,'' he said.
Ms. Hirano of the Japan Society also sees the film as essentially benign. It is true that ''Black Rain'' focuses on evil gangsters who chop off their fingers and gun each other down, she said, but movies about the American Mafia also show a closed and menacing crime underworld.
While the movie does champion American individualism over Japanese groupism, the film ends with its two detectives fast friends and the bad guys who set out to wreck the American economy defeated.
Whatever the verdict on ''Black Rain,'' it clearly marks another turn in the portrayal of a land that has long captured the American imagination. As the American hostess in an Osaka bar who helps Michael Douglas tells him when he thanks her for coming over to his side, ''A love-hate relationship can last a long time.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
