458 of 749 DOCUMENTS

Copyright 1989 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 19, 1989

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 3001 words

HEADLINE: The Treasury's 'Mr. Diffident'

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Some Treasury Secretaries over the years have dominated their Administration's economic policies with their political skills and their strong personalities. James A. Baker 3d, the Secretary in Ronald Reagan's second term, and John B. Connally, who served two years under Richard M. Nixon, are cases in point. They were glib and outspoken, politically ambitious, familiar faces on television and crafty manipulators of the press - men who caused heads to turn when they entered crowded rooms.
Other Secretaries have tended to fade into the woodwork. Like David M. Kennedy, Mr. Nixon's first Secretary, they seemed ill at ease on their feet and uncomfortable in the limelight. Often at home in boardrooms, they never grasped the peculiar ways of Washington. And whatever influence they had on policy has long been forgotten. 
By temperament, Nicholas F. Brady fits into the second category of Treasury Secretary. He is bland on television and awkward as a public speaker. In a city of bombast and pomposity, Mr. Brady is unusually gentle and modest, a man who can and often does enter a restaurant or a large party unrecognized. At international meetings, he has taken pains not to stand out from the ministers of other countries. At home, he has been overshadowed day after day in his first year in office by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director. With large egos, sharp minds and aggressive personalities, these politically sophisticated men have taken strong roles in the execution of economic policies.
''In all my years in Washington,'' said an admirer who has served here in several different capacities in the Government over the last 35 years, ''I don't recall a Treasury Secretary as diffident as Brady.''
But when the history of the Bush Administration is written, Mr. Brady will probably be recorded as a central figure. Although he had a rocky start, Mr. Brady seems to have learned from his mistakes, and has seen his reputation here grow the longer he has been in office.
Despite, or maybe because of, his preference for staying in the background, he has an asset none of his modern predecessors had.
Nicholas Brady is a close friend of the President, perhaps George Bush's closest friend. That alone gives him enormous authority.
''When he wants to, Brady picks up the phone and gets to talk to the President like that,'' said John E. Robson, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, snapping his fingers. ''Or he walks right over to see him. When you think of the DEW line created around the President, any President, that's unique.''
Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat who is chairman of the Budget Committee and who met with Mr. Brady for countless hours this year in budget negotiations, said that when the Secretary is in a room, the tone of the discussion changes. ''Just by being someplace, Brady brings Bush's lever into play,'' Mr. Sasser said. ''You get the sense that you are hearing directly from the President and that what is being said will be repeated to the President over cocktails or on the tennis court.''
Mr. Brady refuses to discuss his friendship with Mr. Bush and what influence it gives him within the Administration. ''I don't really care to talk about that,'' he said in an interview in his office. ''I don't think of it in those terms. I think of it in trying to get to the President substantive and correct positions on issues that he ought to have advice on. Whether that is easier or harder to do because we've been friends, I never think about.'' Period. Next question, please.
Mr. Brady's senior assistants say he never discusses the relationship with them either. They recount small incidents they have witnessed: a telephone call early one morning from the Secretary on his car phone to the residential quarters at the White House; his getting the President to host a reception at the White House for leading American and foreign bankers during the meetings this fall of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank; his spur-of-the-moment decision one night to walk over to the White House to brief Mr. Bush at an important point in the negotiations with Congress over cutting the capital gains tax.
But when they are asked how the friendship has manifested itself in Government policy, the aides draw a blank. They say they suspect it may have been a factor in the President's decision in May to name Japan, India and Brazil as unfair traders, subjecting them to possible sanctions, and the decision in July to extend import quotas on steel for only an additional 30 months, both matters in which Mr. Brady's position prevailed over others in the Administration. But the aides acknowledge that they do not know for sure and that those decisions might have gone the way they did regardless.
 
A Confidant
 ''One of the features of the unique relationship Brady has with the President is that Brady keeps things very quiet, very confidential, and the President knows that,'' said Hollis S. McLoughlin, the Assistant Secretary for Policy Management, who acts more or less as Mr. Brady's chief of staff and spends more time with him than any other assistant.
A White House official said Mr. Brady is important to the President as a confidential adviser as much as a Cabinet officer. ''The President knows,'' the official said, ''that if he tells Brady something or asks his advice on something, it won't go beyond the room.''
Mr. Bush and Mr. Brady met on a tennis court in 1975, introduced by Mr. Bush's brother Jonathan, and they became fast friends almost at once. Mr. Brady, who is now 59, is six years younger than Mr. Bush, but their backgrounds are remarkably similar - wealthy Eastern families, education at prep school and Yale - and they shared an interest in competitive sports. Mr. Bush had just completed a tour as the United States representative in China. Mr. Brady was chairman of Dillon, Read & Company, the New York investment firm where he had worked all his adult life.
Mr. Brady had never been active politically, but it soon became apparent that his political views were almost identical to those of Mr. Bush. By 1979, he was heading Mr. Bush's campaign in New Jersey for the Republican Presidential nomination. Mr. Brady's connection with Mr. Bush was also instrumental in his temporary appointment to the United States Senate in 1982 to fill the last eight months of the term of Harrison A. Williams Jr., a New Jersey Democrat who resigned during the Abscam scandal. And shortly after Mr. Bush was re-elected Vice President in 1984, he announced that Mr. Brady was the only person authorized to speak about his plans to run for the Presidency in 1988.
In September 1988, when Mr. Baker resigned as Treasury Secretary to run Mr. Bush's general election campaign, Ronald Reagan named Mr. Brady to the Cabinet post. It was understood that if Mr. Bush was elected President, Mr. Brady would remain at the Treasury.
He was in office only days when gossip began circulating here among bureaucrats, lobbyists and economists who follow the Treasury that Mr. Brady was in over his head, the latest of the Wall Street lightweights who could not cut it in Washington.
There was evidence to substantiate that view. His early testimony before Congress was disastrous. Lawmakers who had been on the banking and finance committees for years fired questions at him about elements of Government policy that he could not begin to answer.
 
An Embarrassing Gaffe
 His maiden speech about international debt managed to offend the Japanese. What seemed to Mr. Brady to be a casual comment in a television interview about the value of the dollar - ''Markets go up and down. I really don't worry about it very much'' - was misinterpreted by traders as a lack of concern. It caused the dollar to fall further.
A few days after the inauguration, he created a political firestorm by saying that the Administration was considering a fee on bank deposits to raise money to rescue the savings and loan industry. And news that he has a reading disability, perhaps dyslexia, and prefers that material be presented orally, caused snickers in some circles.
Mr. Brady was pushed further into the background as Mr. Darman dominated the budget negotiations with Congress, and Mr. Sununu took more interest in economic matters than any other recent chief of staff. ''You're just not very conscious of his presence,'' said Robert Solomon, an economist at the Brookings Institution. ''It's hard to characterize the absence of a presence.''
Abroad, Mr. Brady has been compared unfavorably with the dynamic Mr. Baker. ''I've seen Baker and I've seen Brady, and the difference in presentational skills is enormous,'' said a leading central banker from an allied country. ''Baker has the capacity to dazzle you. Brady doesn't. It's unfair, but you can't help but compare them.''
For many months, in fact, Mr. Brady could not emerge from the shadow of Mr. Baker, who is now Secretary of State. M. Peter McPherson, executive vice president of the Bank of America, who became Deputy Secretary of the Treasury under Mr. Baker in August 1987 and stayed on under Mr. Brady until last April, had an insight into the situation.
 
Beloved Baker
 ''Washington,'' he observed, ''likes people who are articulate and look at the big picture and have all the answers. Washington likes the Jim Bakers of the world. Brady doesn't fit in that way as a superb Washington operative. Washington doesn't have a very long focus. Brady talks about the long-term perspective, but he's often talking to an audience without appreciation of long-term views.''
Gradually, however, opinions here of Mr. Brady have changed. His success in moving the savings and loan legislation through Congress and his advocacy of a new plan for dealing with third world debt are widely praised, even by those who disagree with elements of one or the other. And he has used the skills he honed over years of serving clients on Wall Street to gain many friends and admirers in Congress.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat from Brooklyn who sits on the banking and budget committees, expressed the prevailing view: ''Is he the smartest guy in the world? No. Did he make some major screwups? Yes. But Brady is one of the few people in the Government trying to do real substance. On savings and loan, he stepped up to the plate and swung at balls. The same with the third world debt. I'm not sure I agree with his plan, but at least he tried to do something. So, in an Administration where so much seems aimed at image and hype, Brady does deserve a lot of credit.''
Perhaps most important to the Administration, key Democratic lawmakers, who are increasingly antipathetic toward Mr. Darman, have learned to like and trust Mr. Brady. ''Nick's candid,'' said Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee. ''What he says, that's it. He's not like some of these fellows, where they say, 'Good morning,' and you say, 'What do you mean by that?' ''
Asked if he was referring to Mr. Darman, Mr. Bentsen replied, ''You said that. I didn't.'' Mr. Darman declined to be interviewed for this article.
Mr. Bentsen was furious at the announcement late last month that Mr. Brady was advancing Government borrowing, at a cost of about $20 million, to give the Administration one more week to fight the battle over capital gains. The Senator said he chose to believe that Mr. Darman and Mr. Sununu had made the decision and forced it on Mr. Brady. Treasury officials say the decision was Mr. Brady's alone, but they are happy to let Mr. Bentsen think what he does.
 
Wall Street's View
 On Wall Street, Mr. Brady is criticized for not having lowered the budget deficit. And commercial bankers believe his plan encouraging banks to write off part of the debt of developing countries and make new loans to them at the same time is unrealistic.
But the overall view of him on the Street now seems to be positive. ''He's not going to be the most exciting guy in the world,'' said John H. Gutfreund, chairman of Salomon Brothers Inc. ''But he has good judgment. And he knows he doesn't know all the answers, and that's important.''
Mr. Brady said he learned from his early mistakes to be careful about what he said in public and to pay more attention to details. ''It takes a certain amount of time unless you've been in Government to learn all the details,'' he said, ''and it surprised me that you would be judged so much on your ability to spit out details.''
As an investment banker, he said, ''the essence of trying to make progress is to separate the details from the important things and act on the important things.'' He said he has learned in Washington, however, that ''each detail means something to somebody, and in trying to drive toward a conclusion in Government work, you have to be more responsive to what somebody else thinks is one of the three or four main factors even though in your own mind, it isn't.''
As for his difficulty in absorbing material by reading, Mr. Brady said, ''God gave us a number of senses. Maybe it has made me listen more carefully.''
Mr. Brady said he began the year determined ''to clear away the underbrush,'' problems that were inherited from the Reagan Administration. But, he continued, ''some of the underbrush turned out to be sequoias.'' He has had little time, he continued, to concentrate on anything other than three of those big problems: the collapsing savings and loan industry, the third world debt and, ''overarching everything,'' the budget deficit.
 
Raising Taxes
 A good start was made on the first two, he said, and despite setbacks this year, he is ''optimistic'' that the Administration and Congress will come to grips with the deficit next year. Without saying so directly, Mr. Brady seems to be more flexible than the President and others in the Administration on the question of new taxes. He suggested that if Administration officials and Congress could agree first on exactly how to spend the additional money that would be raised, they could then agree on a package of tax increases and spending cuts that would be acceptable to all parties.
If he can, Mr. Brady said, he would like to turn his attention next year to the herculean task of encouraging American industry to avoid the quick buck and take a longer-range view. He believes that ultimately the standard of living of all Americans is at stake. His aides have suggested that proposals in this area might be incorporated into President Bush's State of the Union message in January. But Mr. Brady said he realized that the proposals would have to be modest as long as the Government was running a large budget deficit.
For example, he said, tax changes that would make equity financing more attractive or expand individual retirement accounts to encourage people to save would create too great a loss in revenues to be practical next year. But he said he would continue to press Congress to lower the capital gains rate and might suggest some modest measures that would give managers incentives to focus on long-range performance.
In any event, he said, he does not intend to change his style and plans to continue as a confidant to the President as long as Mr. Bush wants him. If he is eclipsed in the public eye by Mr. Darman and Mr. Sununu, he said, so be it.
''I don't think for a minute about being out front,'' Mr. Brady said. ''If you have two people as bright as Dick Darman and John Sununu, why wouldn't you solicit their views? I don't care who gets credit. Those are two extraordinarily bright people, and where they've got insights in the economic scene, they ought to be sought out, and if those insights are correct, they ought to be pursued.''
Edwin L. Dale Jr., an assistant to Mr. Darman who has been following every Treasury Secretary since the Eisenhower Administration as a newspaper reporter or a Government official, said he has never known one so unconcerned about his public image. ''What's so impressive about Brady,'' Mr. Dale said, ''is that he's a man clearly at peace with himself and not likely to get upset by the to and fro of Washington.''
 
ALL THE RIGHT CREDENTIALS
Nicholas Frederick Brady's background is typical of an Eastern-establishment Republican. He has a family pedigree, an Ivy League education, a career on Wall Street and smooth strokes on the tennis court and golf course. He grew up on a large estate in Far Hills, N.J., and still has a home there as well as places in Washington, in the Bahamas, in New York and on the Eastern Shore of Maryland. He owns horses and has been chairman of the Jockey Club, the registry for Thoroughbred horses. He has been a director of the NCR Corporation, the Mitre Corporation and the H.J. Heinz Company, among others.
Mr. Brady's great-grandfather, Anthony, was an Irish immigrant who made a fortune as a business partner of Thomas Edison. His grandfather founded the Maxwell Motor Company, which was bought by the Chrysler Corporation. His father counted Rockefellers, du Ponts and Mellons among his investment partners, and also ran the Purolator Courier Corporation. Mr. Brady, who was born April 11, 1930, graduated from Yale in 1952 and from the Harvard Business School in 1954. At Yale, he was captain of the squash team and admits to spending more time on sports than schoolwork.
He joined Dillon, Read & Company, the investment banking firm, right out of graduate school and rose to become chairman in 1973. He got the Wall Street job initially through family connection, but colleagues say his skill in bringing in new business pushed him to the top. Under his leadership, Dillon, Read fell from the ranks of the most influential underwriters but remained one of the most profitable. He resigned from the firm to become Treasury Secretary.
Mr. Brady and his wife, Katherine, have four grown children.

HEADLINE: Exxon Valdez's Sea of Litigation

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
Can a bartender in Anchorage claim damages for tips he might have received from fishermen thrown out of work as a result of the Exxon Valdez spill?
What about California drivers who had to pay sharply higher gasoline prices after the Valdez grounding temporarily closed the port of Valdez and interrupted the flow of North Slope oil to California refineries?
And how about citizens of other states who have no plans to ever visit Alaska, but who, because of the spill, no longer have the knowledge that they could visit an unsullied region. What of the ''bequest value'' such knowledge would bring to future generations?
These are just a few of the legal questions stemming from the grounding of the Valdez in Prince William Sound on March 24 and the disgorgement of 11 million gallons of Alaskan crude oil into its pristine waters. The lawsuits began proliferating within days of the spill as lawyers from across the nation rushed to the scene. 
''One of the mayors up there told me that the only thing worse than the oil hitting the shore was the wave of gray-flanneled lawyers that came next,'' said T. Barry Kingham, a lawyer with the New York firm of Curtis, Mallet-Prevost, Colt and Mosie. Mr. Kingham is not involved with the Exxon litigation but is one of many lawyers who expects it to drag on into the next century. And he is in a better position than most to know why. He represents the French fishermen and villagers suing Amoco in the still unsettled litigation in the United States District Court in Chicago that began 11 years ago when the Amoco Cadiz ran aground off the Brittany coast.
The Amoco Cadiz case involved a spill seven times larger than the one in Alaska, but the latter may well involve more extensive environmental damage and more complicated interactions between state and Federal law. Already, it involves far more types of plaintiffs and byzantine negotiations among high-powered law firms from all over the country over how to share both the work and control over litigation strategy. ''You have to ask whether the legal system is set up to cope with something like this,'' Mr. Kingham said.
 
Exxon's Court Press
 So far, nearly 150 lawsuits have been filed in Anchorage against the Exxon Corporation, its subsidiaries and its partners in the Alaska pipeline. The state court cases have been consolidated for pre-trial motions and discovery (the process of gathering evidence and pre-trial testimony) before Judge Brian C. Shortell under the name Exxon Valdez Oil Spill Litigation. The Federal cases have been consolidated for the same purposes before United States District Court Judge H. Russell Holland under the name Seahawk Seafoods Inc. v. the Exxon Corporation.
Related actions have been filed on behalf of oil consumers in California and by Exxon shareholders against the company's directors. Lawyers have also been busy with administrative hearings before groups like the National Transportation Safety Board, grand jury investigations of possible criminal conduct by Exxon and the Valdez officers, and executing thousands of contracts to hire people to help with the cleanup.
Some lawyers involved say that the Exxon Valdez matter is, in many respects, not a particularly difficult challenge. Richard Gerry, a San Diego lawyer who is a co-chairman of the committee of plaintiffs' lawyers trying to coordinate most of the litigation, said: ''We have got one thing - oil. Whose is it? Exxon's. How did it get there? We all know.''
Mr. Gerry and other environmental lawyers compare that situation to the numbingly complex cases stemming from liability for pollution from waste disposal sites, in which a wide variety of pollutants have been deposited over a long period of time from many sources, some unknown.
But even he concedes that it may be years before the extent of damages from the Valdez spill can be determined. And while the oil was Exxon's, much of the damage may be traceable to the dismal failure of early efforts to contain and clean up the spill. That has drawn Exxon's partners in the Alaska pipeline into the case as defendants because Alyeska, the pipeline company, was responsible for preparations to respond to a spill. To complicate matters further, Exxon has filed a counterclaim arguing that the State of Alaska is liable for the damages because it blocked an Exxon plan to break up the slick with chemical dispersants.
In addition, it is not clear where the courts will look to figure out who is responsible and what kind of damages they might be forced to pay. Exxon's liability may be limited to the extent that maritime law governs the case. Legislation like the Alaska Pipeline Act, the Clean Water Act and the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act may also affect which plaintiffs will be allowed to pursue their complaints and what kinds of compensation or relief they can seek. Most plaintiffs are seeking punitive damages under Alaska state law.
''Our environmental law has become so complex that the tax code is child's play by comparison,'' said Thomas J. Schoenbaum, a University of Georgia law professor who is advising the State of Alaska in the Exxon Valdez litigation.
The dramatic nature of the accident, which has become a rallying point for environmentalists, and the wealth of Exxon and its pipeline partners have naturally acted as a lure for many lawyers. The result has been a Machiavellian jockeying for influence and hours devoted to reviewing - and sometimes nitpicking - documents drafted by others.
''So far, it hasn't created a situation of ineffectiveness but it is time-consuming,'' said Elizabeth Cabraser, a partner in the San Francisco firm of Lieff, Cabraser and Heiman, which has filed a class action on behalf of commercial salmon and herring fishermen. ''At some point, the whole thing could bog down.''
 
Feuding Lawyers
 One of the most basic disagreements pits class-action lawyers, many from big East Coast firms with experience in antitrust and securities cases, against tort lawyers who traditionally represent individual clients. The class-action firms have agreed to group the plaintiffs in the 150 damage cases into seven classes: fishermen; fish processors and distributors; union workers laid off by processors after the spill; Alaska natives; area businesses that supply equipment or services to the fishing industry; tour operators; recreational users of the region, and municipalities.
The traditional tort, or direct-action, lawyers say there is no reason to set up classes when all of the individuals affected can be identified.
''There's an element of scramble for clients, but I would hate to put it so crudely,'' said Richard Oesting, an Anchorage lawyer working on the class actions. ''It's a philosophical disagreement over the best way to handle this from the point of view of efficiency and fairness.''
The crunch comes on the issue of punitive damages. If the class-action lawyers have their way, the litigation will produce one giant punitive damages pot from which all plaintiffs would share according to a formula to be negotiated. Direct-action lawyers believe each plaintiff should have a separate shot at convincing a jury that a certain amount in punitive damages should be awarded.
So far, the two groups are cooperating because they can share the initial tasks of setting up schedules for pre-trial discovery and the basic job of establishing the liability of Exxon and its partners. But both are squabbling with environmental groups, led by the National Wildlife Federation and the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund. The environmentalists have filed suits of their own and want a major say in how the litigation proceeds.
The National Wildlife Federation asked in state court that damages be put into a fund to restore the affected area or, where that is not possible, to buy and protect comparable resources. The Federation's lawyers contend that those injured include even citizens who have no plans to ever visit Alaska because simply knowing that an unsullied region is there for future generations has a value, known as the bequest value, that a jury can estimate when presented with economic studies.
The Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund, in behalf of nine groups, seeks to have the Federal court order Exxon to present plans for continuing its cleanup next spring and to rule on whether they meet Federal standards.
 
Getting Organized
 The first job facing the plaintiffs attorneys was to propose to the judges how they could be organized into a committee, a common method of managing complex cases with many plaintiffs. Their initial proposal was carefully balanced between the class-action groups and direct-action lawyers with lesser roles for the environmental lawyers, who had filed suits only a short time before the plan was presented at an unusual joint sitting of the state and Federal courts. After weighing comments, including complaints from environmentalists, Judge Holland recently criticized the plan in a blunt memo saying it did not give the environmental lawyers enough influence and was ''top-heavy.''
Some lawyers agreed. ''It's overloaded with positions that have no purpose,'' said Leonard Ring, a well-known Chicago torts lawyer who dropped out after the plan was proposed in August. ''It's going to be a difficult case to prepare because there's too much politics.''
Exxon is keeping its views on such matters and its own litigation strategy close to the vest. The company has a reputation for following a scorched earth policy to discourage claimants from trying to dig into what is one of America's deepest corporate pockets. But unlike Amoco, which refused to pay damages to anyone for the French oil spill, Exxon has been quick to make payments to the groups most directly affected by the spill, like the fishermen.
''We have paid almost 10,000 claimants over $130 million so far but have settled very few cases,'' said C. Kenneth Roberts, general counsel for Exxon USA, the Houston-based Exxon unit whose subsidiary, the Exxon Shipping Company, owned the tanker. Exxon does expect the payments to be offset against damage awards.
 
Bad Press
 Plaintiffs' lawyers say Exxon has been cooperative so far. Thousands of documents have been exchanged in discovery though the court has not yet ordered it to begin. Some believe the litigation will move rapidly if the judges push it because it provides bad publicity for Exxon each day that it lasts.
However, pleadings filed to date indicate that Exxon can be expected to fight fiercely to avoid punitive damages and to avoid liability to plaintiffs who claim indirect injuries, like bartenders in Valdez or Anchorage. Exxon USA has about 15 of its staff of 170 working on the litigation. The oil company and its subsidiaries also have outside counsel from a battery of prestigious firms, led by Bogle and Gates in Seattle and Anchorage and O'Melveny and Meyers in Los Angeles and Covington and Burling in Washington D.C.
One predictable form of legal fallout from the accident has been the suits filed in behalf of Exxon by its shareholders against the company's directors and senior management. They allege that negligence at the top led to the accident and the huge bills Exxon faces, including the $1.3 billion it has already spent on cleanup and millions of dollars in legal expenses. Such suits are common in any kind of corporate mishap and, in this case, have been filed in both Alaska and the United States District Court in New York where Exxon is based.
 
Limited Liability
 ''As a practical matter, the limits of what we can recover will be the insurance policy, which we understand to be about $100 million,'' said Daniel Krasner, a partner in the New York firm of Wolf Haldenstein Adler Freeman & Herz who has represented shareholders in the Alaska cases. Exxon has appointed a committee of its independent directors to investigate management's performance and that committee has retained former Attorney General Griffin Bell, now an Atlanta lawyer.
A more unusual legal twist developed when J. Garrett Kendrick, a sole practitioner in Los Angeles who supports marine conservation groups, began pondering how he could express his anger with Exxon. That led to the filing in a Los Angeles county court of a class-action suit in behalf of California drivers. According to the suit, consumers were forced to pay up to 20 cents a gallon more for gasoline in the weeks following the Valdez grounding because of supply interruptions. ''It amounts to tens of millions of dollars,'' Mr. Kendrick said.
Not surprisingly, the lawyers involved are reluctant to talk about how much the spill will eventually mean to them financially. The plaintiffs lawyers will spend millions of dollars before recovering fees out of any damage awards. Class-action fees typically run between 10 percent to 15 percent of recoveries. Direct-action fees can run as high as 30 percent but, according to Mr. Gerry, are likely to be between 15 and 20 percent in most cases where one lawyer represents many individuals with similar complaints. The negotiations on how to divide the spoils may become heated if, as some lawyers suspect, the pot turns out to be smaller than expected.
''It will be a fun case, a chance to do some good for the public, but I don't think it's going to be very remunerative for plaintiffs' lawyers,'' said Stephen D. Susman, a Houston lawyer who was an early leader among the class-action plaintiffs' lawyers but was forced to drop out because of a conflict.
''Alaska is a funny place - they love the environment but they also love the oil industry and they won't want to punish it too badly,'' Mr. Susman said. ''Spill cases tend to have their maximum value in the early days when there are dead birds on television. There's going to be real questions in this case on how you measure damages.''
That issue alone may drag out the case, and delay the day when lawyers are paid. One solution, according to Mr. Gerry, may be to treat the spill as a running nuisance case in which damages are re-examined and new payments made every few years. ''It would be unfair to both Exxon and plaintiffs to try to settle some things quickly because it would be sheer guesswork,'' said Mr. Gerry.
Whatever the complications, many lawyers believe the Valdez case is unlikely to set any lasting standard for how much it costs the legal system to sort out liabilities after environmental disasters. ''Look at Chernobyl,'' said Professor Schoenbaum, referring to the devastation caused by the 1987 failure of a Soviet nuclear reactor. ''It is hard to imagine the legal impact of something like that if it occurred in the United States. We haven't scratched the surface.''

HEADLINE: Louisiana's New Philosophy

BYLINE: By MARY C. BOUNDS; Mary C. Bounds is a freelance writer in Atlanta.

DATELINE: BATON ROUGE, La.

 BODY:
Last month, Gov. Buddy Roemer stepped up to the microphone in the towering Art Deco State Capitol to announce that ICI Americas Inc., based in Wilmington, Del., had selected St. Gabriel in southern Louisiana as the site of a new $100 million plant to produce substitutes for chlorofluorocarbons, bypassing locations in Texas, Kentucky, New Jersey and Canada.
Typically, such announcements are made in a jovial, backslapping atmosphere. But St. Gabriel, where a cluster of chemical plants rises from the banks of the Mississippi, is no longer the trusting, idyllic farming community it once was. Although a recent study by Tulane University found otherwise, many residents believe their miscarriage rates are unusually high because of chemical pollution. 
So, at the news conference, Mr. Roemer praised ICI for making a product that could ease the world's ozone problems. But under forceful questioning from reporters, he made it clear that state leaders believe business and concern for the environment go hand in hand.
''They will have to meet our standards,'' Mr. Roemer said. ''If they can't, they can go to Kentucky, Tennessee or God cares where.''
For a state where the environment had been viewed for years as something that could be traded off for economic development, it was a stunning statement.
Louisiana's new-found interest in the environment did not offend ICI, however. ''We know the rules of the game,'' said Tony Mash, an ICI manager. ''If Governor Roemer has to tighten the law in some ways we respect that and will follow those guidelines.'' At a time of rising environmental awareness nationwide, environmental and economic issues intersect with particular force in Louisiana, for years viewed as one of the most environmentally degraded states. For instance, the Environmental Protection Agency said 776 million pounds of toxic chemicals were dumped into the state's waters in 1987, the second-highest total in the nation.
Cleaning up Louisiana would be difficult in the best of economic times, but with unemployment rates that have led the nation for much of the last three years - ranging from 7.6 to 13.7 percent - it requires a lot of nerve and even more diplomacy.
Louisiana is realizing how much its economic health is tied to cleaning up its environment. The result is a regulatory tightrope aimed at cleaning up existing messes and avoiding new ones without driving away old businesses or scaring away new ones.
It is too early to assess the long-term effects on the industrial base, nearly half of which is petrochemicals. But it has created some tension and, according to the Governor, has caused ''one or two'' companies to choose sites elsewhere ''because we would not arbitrarily and capriciously change the rules for them.'' But no major companies have left and some are even joining the cleanup effort.
The link between environment and economy was clear in the case of the Huntsman Chemical Corporation. A year ago it seemed certain that the company would buy and modernize a plant here. But after being impressed by the water and rail routes, raw-material supply and infrastructure, Huntsman found something less impressive: the soil under the site was contaminated by hydrocarbons.
When Huntsman changed its plans, the state lost 50 to 100 jobs. But it got a vote of confidence from Henry Sullivan, Huntsman's vice chairman. ''The state's attitude toward the whole thing was exemplary,'' he said. ''We didn't want them to have the feeling that if they cut corners we would stay. Cutting corners environmentally is stupid. Your employees aren't proud of you and it costs money in the long run.''
Louisiana's billion-dollar fishing industry has been badly wounded in the months since state officials issued warnings to consumers on the cancer-causing chemicals in the Calcasieu River basin's speckled and white trout. And white-collar jobs most often have gone the way of cleaner environments, where executives prefer to live and raise children.
''We now know that for jobs we must maintain our environment,'' said Paul Templet, head of the Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality.
For years, the former professor of environmental management at Louisiana State University was a lonely gadfly, haranguing state politicians with his message that pollution was stagnating the economy. That he now runs an agency whose budget has more than doubled in less than two years, to $62 million, is a sign of the degree to which the state has come to see its environmental crisis as an economic one as well.
One complication in that relationship is the economy's reliance on the chemical industry. With 27,000 employees, it is the largest employer in the state's manufacturing sector.
No one understands this better than Governor Roemer, whose campaign two years ago was built around the ''Four E's,'' environment, economic development, ethics and education.
''We're not trying to slam-dunk them,'' he said of industry in general. ''I consider them good neighbors. I'm still pushing like everything for jobs, and if a petrochemical company wants to come in, I encourage them to come. But we're not making the highest bid for polluters.''
State legislators and voters have followed his lead in making the environment a priority. In the spring, legislators ordered the state to halve toxic air emissions by 1994, phase out oil and gas production pits in the wetlands and start a solid-waste reduction and recycling program. In September they adopted new regulations on the disposal of 25 toxic chemicals into state waters. The law, now the subject of a lawsuit by the chemical industry, is said to be one of the nation's strictest. Last month, voters passed a constitutional amendment establishing a multimillion-dollar trust fund to preserve wetlands.
Chemical industry officials acknowledge that they, too, have had to change. ''In the past, we simply assumed that if we made a product, employed people and paid our taxes everything would be O.K.,'' said Richard Kleiner, a spokesman for the Louisiana Chemical Association.
''But as environmental problems and concerns about public questions came to the forefront, we got behind the curve in communicating to people,'' Mr. Kleiner said. ''Some had the attitude that even if we explained what we were doing, people wouldn't understand. But common sense is pretty darn common. We have no problems with the regulations as long as they are scientifically justified, achievable and applicable to everyone so that no one gets favored.''
Since the early 1970's, he said, the industry has reduced by 90 percent the amount of pollutants released into state waters.
There are other promising signs. The state unemployment rate fell to 7.6 percent in September. And $4 billion in industrial expansion is under way statewide, much of it in the chemical industry, which is experiencing a boom nationwide.
But everyone involved knows that massive problems remain. Even Mr. Roemer is cautious in his optimism. ''I don't want to be guilty of being a Pollyanna,'' he said. ''Right now we're living better than we were a year ago. I feel good about our position, but I don't want to tell you that we've scored a touchdown yet.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: THE VOLATILE DOLLAR;
Conduct a Test of a Gold Standard

BYLINE: By DAVID BOSTIAN JR. David Bostian Jr. is chief economist and managing director of Jesup & Lamont Inc.and president of Bostian Research Associates Inc.

 BODY:
In 1971, following President Nixon's repudiation of the agreement at Bretton Woods to redeem dollars in gold bullion, I was one of the first economists on Wall Street to warn that Nixon's ''New Economics'' policy would lead to serious economic and financial problems in the 1970's.
Ten years later, my testimony in Washington before the Gold Commission hearings stated: ''I do advocate a gradual and experimental shift toward a possible full gold standard through the issuance of new gold-backed bonds or notes.'' These bonds would offer important market information by which to gauge the plausibility of an eventual return to a complete gold standard.
An experimental issue of $100 billion in Government bonds, to be redeemed in gold coin, as proposed in a gold bond bill, sponsored by Representative William Dannemeyer, Republican of California, and now in committee, would demonstrate the value of a partial return to gold. This experiment would be conducted without exposing the debt heavy United States economy to the unforseeable and possibly negative consequences of a sudden return to a total gold standard. 
Bonds with gold convertibility would provide a savings in interest expenses to the Government (and taxpayers) that would be considerable. It is estimated that the Eagle bonds proposed in the gold bond bill would carry an interest rate of only 1.75 percent. The bonds would be attractive to investors even though they would pay such low rates because the gold backing to the bond would serve as a hedge against inflation and preserve the investor's buying power. If the bonds were well received by the market, a phased-in conversion of all Government bonds to gold-backed bonds - which might take five years - could result in interest expense savings averaging as much as $150 billion a year. This savings would substantially eliminate the Federal budget deficit.
The availability of gold-backed bonds would also foster increased savings by Americans. Gold-backed bonds would promote savings because investors would feel secure knowing that the gold backing their bonds will hold its value with less risk than higher yielding bonds not linked to gold. The resulting lower cost of capital, coming from increased savings, would greatly enhance our competitive position relative to major trading partners like Japan.
It is possible that the availability of gold-backed bonds would lead to more stable currency relationships and to a lower trade deficit. With regard to the former, there is a growing recognition that the volatile swings in the dollar over the past decade have had a destabilizing effect on corporate management and international trade as well as government policy.
The discipline of backing bonds with gold would put a measure of restraint on the seemingly endless growth of debt in the United States because gold, unlike paper dollars, cannot be created at will.
If one believes that gold-backed bonds offer such benefits, why not move to a full gold standard immediately?
Too sudden a return to the discipline of a gold standard could have a disruptive effect on economic growth. In a weakening economy it would make matters worse by bringing inflation to an immediate halt or even promoting deflation. This in turn would make it difficult for struggling businesses and individuals to pay back their outstanding loans in cheaper dollars.
There is also the question of what price of gold is appropriate in affixing the convertibility of currencies. While some advocates of a return to a full gold standard do not worry about this point, or assume the market will correct errors in economic judgment, the wrong gold price could result in either inflationary or deflationary tendencies, depending upon economic conditions.
World gold production is volatile, with major discoveries and disruptions of mining hard to predict. The Soviet Union and South Africa account for a majority of world gold production. Long-term economic growth could be retarded by supply and demand problems in the gold market from time to time.
Since America functions in a global economy, any broad-based move to a gold standard in the United States would require international coordination between the major industrialized countries and the international financial organizations. While an international gold standard might be a worthwhile long-term goal, it would require detailed international cooperation to put it into place.
But despite potential benefits attendant to a controlled experiment with gold, it is vital that we remain aware that neither gold nor monetary economics provide the complete answer to the economic challenges confronting the United States and the world economy.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS FORUM: THE VOLATILE DOLLAR;
The Floating Dollar Needs an Anchor

BYLINE: By DAVID RANSON; David Ranson is president of H. C. Wainwright & Company, Economics Inc. in Boston.

 BODY:
The United States has paid a high price for the instability of the dollar. A dollar that floats in value against other world currencies confuses markets, distorts supply and demand, and makes it harder for the economy to operate. Long-range investment decisions are clouded by unnecessary short-range uncertainties. Trade is distorted and taxation cannot be fair and efficient if incomes and wealth are miscomputed by fluctuations in prices, inflation and interest rates.
For these reasons the dollar needs an anchor that would firmly fix its value in relation to a set basket of commodities. The basket might, but does not have to, include gold. Fixing the value of the dollar to these selected commodities would stabilize the dollar's value against other currencies as well. 
In Washington, advocating a dollar anchored to a commodity base has, to date, been preaching to the inconvertible. Policy makers will always pay lip service to the idea of monetary stability, but are unlikely to abandon their fine-tuning activities. Indeed, they justify these efforts on the false premise that without their meddling, the private economy would otherwise be incapable of stability.
Prices today fluctuate unnecessarily because the dollar units in which they are expressed are just that: units of measurement and not stores of value. Prices cannot be stable when they must be expressed in terms of an unstable unit. Nor can interest rates be stable when the future value of the currency is unpredictable.
These truths appeal to common sense rather than to economic doctrine and tend to be more easily grasped by laymen than economists. Of course, like all such truths they are an oversimplication.
Monetary instability creates a chain reaction that reaches further than anyone can calculate. Inflation cannot be defeated if there is no limit to the rate at which the dollar is allowed to depreciate. Nor can interest rates remain low if inflation is expected to be high. Over time, an anchored dollar would reduce inflation and preserve buying power.
Globally, unstable money distorts the prices of inflation hedges, including real estate and precious metals. Foreign countries that derive their incomes from natural resources are condemned to an endless roller coaster. Some years when there is a flight from dollars, commodity prices escalate. Other years, when the dollar is in demand, commodity prices slump. An achored currency would reduce these fluctuations.
Why is the dollar an unstable unit? A close look at today's dollar bill doesn't inspire confidence. The dollar describes itself laconically as a note - a hint that it once represented a claim on something or other. In the past, the implied obligation written on the dollar bill was explicit and compelling. Paper money was redeemable in silver or gold: ''This certifies that there has been deposited in the Treasury of the United States one silver dollar, payable to bearer on demand.'' The last redeemable paper disappeared in the past few decades. Silver certificates were abolished by a 1963 act of Congress. Gold certificates were recalled back in 1933. Today a dollar bill is a promise by the Federal Reserve to pay the bearer one dollar: a circular promise which is no promise at all. Like the original greenbacks issued during the Civil War, it is no longer an obligation to pay anything to anybody, and fluctuates in its purchasing power like the debt of a bankrupt foreign nation. The miracle - in my opinion - is that prices are predictable at all and that people accept paper money so readily for goods and services.
Unfortunately, the debate over anchoring the currency has too often been sidetracked by disputes over returning to the gold standard. It's perfectly reasonable to advocate an anchored currency while remaining agnostic about, or even opposing, a gold standard. To use as an anchor a commodity like gold, whose supply is far from fixed and whose geographical distribution is far from uniform, presents problems. For modern times a better, more representative commodity anchor can surely be devised. But there is little point in working to design such a basket while the Federal Government is unwilling to consider an anchor of any kind.
With or without gold, anchoring the dollar would go further to stabilize the world economy than anything else Washington could do. The anchor needs to be firm, and people need to be sure that it is permanent and that it is designed to preserve their purchasing power.
If those conditions are met, foreign governments will not be slow to tie their currencies back to the dollar and, if they do, exchange rates will cease their meaningless gyrations. At a stroke, many of the instabilities that plague the world economy can be eradicated and volatility in the world's financial and money markets will cease.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Once Again, Vietnamese Are Turned Out to Sea

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

 BODY:
THE irascible Prime Minister of Malaysia, Mahathir Mohamad, recently caused a stir when he used the word ''scum'' to describe Vietnamese boat people who remain here after Western resettlement countries select those among them who qualify as refugees. ''Why should we be responsible?'' Mr. Mahathir asked. ''We did not cause the Vietnam War.''
Mr. Mahathir's remark was consistent with what Western diplomats and relief workers describe as the real inhumanity: Malaysia's policy, since the end of May, of refusing first asylum to boat people who land here and sending them, though with fresh provisions, back out to sea. 
According to Eric E. Morris, the representative of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for Malaysia and Brunei, some 2,600 Vietnamese arriving in at least 48 boats have been sent on from Malaysia since the end of May.
Mr. Morris's figures represent boat people who have landed elsewhere, most on the Indonesian island of Salang, south of Singapore. There is no way of knowing if others did not survive, he said. Mr. Mahathir says that ''all we are doing is preventing foreign vessels from entering our waters.'' But Mr. Morris says that virtually all the Vietnamese boats came ashore here before being refurbished or re-provisioned.
While mistreatment, rape and murder have been an intermittent hazard for the boat people for 14 years, Malaysia's pushoffs, Mr. Morris said, violated an agreement reached in June between so-called first-asylum countries like Malaysia and resettlement nations like the United States, Australia, France and Canada. Mr. Morris added pointedly that the agreement was reached at a Geneva conference instigated by Malaysia, and at which Malaysia held the chairmanship.
But Mr. Mahathir's comments and Malaysia's actions also reflect an impatience in Asia as the numbers of Vietnamese boat people continue to rise in camps throughout Southeast and East Asia. The old system of dealing with Vietnamese fleeing their homeland has been discarded; the operation of the new one, which was adopted in June, has been stymied by a disagreement over the forcible repatriation of Vietnamese judged not to be true political refugees, but simply economic migrants.
The dispute has pitted the United States, which insists on no forcible repatriation of Vietnamese, against most of the rest of the world, including Britain. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher often points out that Washington sends back Haitians, Mexicans and others who enter the United States illegally if they are economic migrants.
 
A British Lead
Britain, whose temporary colony, Hong Kong, is now coping with some 56,500 Vietnamese, has been most outspoken about wanting to send those who do not qualify as refugees back to Vietnam involuntarily. The only reason it has not yet done so, Western diplomats say, is because of strong opposition from Washington.
Under the old international agreement, all Vietnamese boat people were considered refugees fleeing political or religious persecution. The old agreement was reached a decade ago to end an initial period of extreme hardship for Vietnamese refugees, in which many died at sea. But in 1987, 12 years after the Vietnam War ended, a new surge of people fleeing one of the poorest of countries coincided with a drop in Western interest in their resettlement.
With the number of migrants in the camps rising again, Thailand started pushing the Vietnamese boats back to sea in early 1988, setting a precedent for other nations. The first-asylum countries, led by Malaysia and Thailand, insisted on a new agreement. Boat people arriving after March 14, 1989 (and in Hong Kong, after June 16, 1988), would be screened under United Nations supervision to see if they were legitimate refugees. Resettlement countries agreed to take everyone in the camps before the cutoff dates and those arriving afterward who were judged to be refugees. The first-asylum countries agreed to provide shelter for everyone arriving in the meantime. But the disagreement over what happens to those who do not qualify for refugee status has gummed up the process.
 
Inhospitality
What most exercises Mr. Mahathir is the prospect of being stuck indefinitely with what he calls the ''residue.'' Some Asians have suggested putting those who do not qualify in conditions so inhospitable they will agree to go home; diplomats and relief officials say the British in Hong Kong, though they deny it, have been trying just that, prompting protests by the High Commissioner and human-rights groups.
Malaysia, for its part, has been treating the 20,750 people now in its camps very well, with adequate food, shelter, clothing and health care. But more than half of them arrived after the cutoff date, and some officials argue that politically, no Southeast Asian country can afford to be seen lagging too far behind the British.
The United States finds itself in an awkward position, allied with Vietnam in opposition to forcible repatriation. But what bothers many other Western diplomats and relief officials is what they see as a deeper American inconsistency, rooted in what they regard as Washington's lingering trauma about Vietnam.
These critics say there is a contradiction between the American desire to resolve the problem of the boat people, many of whom are still seen as ideological heroes for fleeing Vietnam, and the way Washington continues to isolate Hanoi.
The continuing American-led Western embargo on aid, trade and investment in Vietnam helps keep Vietnam backward and impoverished, they argue. Though some countries like Australia are slowing cracking the embargo, there is a widespread feeling among Washington's allies that the United States is punishing Vietnam and adding new conditions for normal relations.
''Vietnam has to come to peace with itself and the United States is not helping,'' said an Asian diplomat. ''And one of the prime consequences of that is the boat people.''
In the meantime, the Vietnamese linger, the boats keep coming, and some continue to be pushed away, back into the insentient and unforgiving sea.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
U.S. Aid for Poland: Long on Incentives, Short on Dollars

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
LECH WALESA, the hero of Poland's democratic revolution, asked Congress last week for a Marshall Plan to revive the Polish economy. But Congress and President Bush have already decided how to help Poland, and their vision is much more modest.
The ambitious program devised by President Truman and George C. Marshall, his Secretary of State, rebuilt cities, factories, roads and railways devastated in World War II. With Europe close to economic collapse, Marshall declared that the United States ''should provide a cure rather than a mere palliative.'' In 1989, aid to Poland is enormously popular, but Mr. Bush and members of Congress continually emphasize the fiscal and political limits to what the United States can do. 
Poland's task, as described by its new rulers, is to establish a Western-style market economy in place of a Communist system. American officials, wrestling with their own budget deficit, say the best way to help Poland help itself is to stimulate private enterprise. Thus, the legislation approved by Congress last week would create an ''enterprise fund'' to provide loans, grants, insurance, technical assistance and training to private businesses in Poland.
The bill authorizes aid of $938 million over three years, or twice what President Bush requested. Most of the money would come from the Federal Treasury, but it is meant to generate much larger amounts of private investment in Poland.
 
Aid From Europe
On this measure, the Senate showed none of the urgency that characterized the Marshall Plan. In the meantime, West Germany, France and other countries - many of them beneficiaries of the Marshall Plan - beat the United States in offering aid to Poland. In Warsaw last week, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany signed an agreement to provide $2.2 billion, the most offered by any Western nation.
Western experts say the aid would be wasted if Warsaw does not make basic economic changes. Poland has a foreign debt of $39 billion and has been unable to make payments on schedule. Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate Republican leader, said Washington had to be ''fiscally responsible,'' and that ''just providing new subsidies for inefficient, outmoded state enterprises will not do the trick.'' Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, said ''a simple infusion of capital'' could not solve Poland's problems. ''The Poles have nothing to show for their orgy of borrowing in the 1970's but a heavy millstone of debt around their necks,'' he said.
Democrats say Poland does not want to repeat that experience. ''The Poles simply do not want direct Government aid,'' said Representative John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan. Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, Democrat of Maryland, said the aid bill was ''phase two of the Marshall Plan,'' but another Maryland Democrat, Representative Steny H. Hoyer, said it was ''far less of an action than we took in the Marshall Plan.''
Aid for Poland, like the Marshall Plan, is based on the premise that political stability is closely linked to economic prosperity. A major goal is to make sure that Poland's fledgling democracy survives and flourishes. Many countries assisted by the Marshall Plan had strong democratic institutions. By contrast, as Senator Paul Simon of Illinois observed, Poland has ''no experience, no background, no traditions to go by.''
Washington will provide Poland with $12 million to support ''democratic institutions'' like civic groups, trade unions and political parties. The United States also intends to share managerial expertise that Poland's state-run industries have conspicuously lacked. Said Mr. Walesa, the labor leader, ''We want to make business deals.''

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Making Industrial Policy at the Pentagon

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
IN the 1960's and 1970's, a small Pentagon office called the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency helped create an explosion of innovation in computer research that has had an immense impact on the American economy. Acting independently and without the bureaucratic strings that often shackle Government organizations, the agency served as a de facto venture capitalist for the American computer industry. By paying for innovative research in university and corporate laboratories, it almost single-handedly created the field of computer science in the United States.
Now it appears that the Bush Administration is on the verge of reining in the agency, which some economists consider the closest thing the Government has to a national industrial policy. The office, which is called Darpa, has long operated on the assumption that national defense means not only developing new weapons but supporting basic research and commercial technology. 
Supporters of Government technological initiatives say that for economic and ideological reasons President Bush's economic advisers want deep cuts in the Pentagon's research budget, including support for high-technology consortiums and Darpa programs to develop advanced robotic manufacturing technology and high-definition television. In 1989 the budget for the Pentagon research agency increased to almost $1.3 billion from $880 million in 1988.
The questions about Darpa come as many Democratic and Republic legislators are calling for a redefinition of national defense, with the military competition of the cold war giving way to economic competition with allies like Japan and West Germany. Almost a dozen bills before Congress would create a civilian equivalent of Darpa. Senator Albert Gore Jr., the Tennessee Democrat, has called for a $1.9 billion effort toward a fiber optic network linking the nation's supercomputers.
''I think the Administration truly doesn't understand the erosion and weakness of the American technology and industrial base,'' said Clyde Prestowitz, a former Reagan Administration official who is now at the Carnegie Endowment for Peace in Washington.
A study to be released tomorrow by the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington research center, warns that the United States stands to lose more than two million jobs and suffer a $225 billion trade deficit by 2010 if the Government fails to help industry compete in high-definition television and related technologies.
 
A Modern Renaissance
Since the United States is so far behind Japan on high-definition television, not all supporters of national high-tech efforts think it should be developed. But in general, leaders of the computer industry say Pentagon support has been indispensable. Alan Kay, one of Apple Computer's principal researchers, has referred to the early years of Darpa as a renaissance for computer science. The agency supported research into the first personal computers, computer graphics, computer networks and artificial intelligence. Sun Microsystems Inc., the world's fastest-growing maker of computer work stations, was started by researchers at Stanford and the University of California at Berkeley who worked with the agency's money. A Darpa-financed software project at Carnegie-Mellon University known as Mach has become the basis for several companies including Steve Jobs's Next Inc.
The agency's Strategic Computing Program, begun in the mid-1980's, is often described as the only response to the Japanese Fifth Generation project. Both efforts are aimed at developing machines that have the blinding speed and huge storage capacity of computers and some of the flexibility of human minds.
Still, some supporters of a national industrial policy believe that it should be entrusted to a civilian agency. For most of its 30-year lifetime, the Pentagon agency has been known for supporting research whose military connections were often remote. But in the 1980's it began directing money to more immediate applications. The Strategic Computing Project has spent more than $100 million a year since 1983 financing projects like a robot tank, which many critics consider a waste of money.
Some economists think that the money would be better spent on projects like a data ''superhighway'' to carry computer information, telephone conversations and television signals. The hope is that such a network would lead to the creation of dozens of new information-age industries.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4, Column 4; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 747 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Why the Hard Sell Didn't Work For Detroit

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
THE report on car and truck sales released last week was, by most accounts, a grim harbinger for the American auto industry. While foreign manufacturers are suffering, too, the brunt of the decline hit the Big Three automakers, raising new questions about whether Detroit is entering its first recession in almost a decade.
The report for Nov. 1-10 described a 23.1 percent decline in sales of domestically produced cars and a 15.3 percent decline in light-truck sales, compared with the same period last year. The bad news followed October's gloomy reports, which were somewhat less unnerving because they were expected. 
A couple of declines in a row happen now and then and cause no panic. But many analysts say the latest report demonstrated an underlying and persistent softening of demand for cars that is impervious to the enticements of rebates, cut-rate financing or airplane tickets to Hawaii. What these accomplished, apparently, was simply to stave off the inevitable crunch.
The droop in demand has many possible causes. It could be that consumers' income was being pinched or that consumer confidence was down. It could be that buyers already have what they want; car sales picked up along with the economy beginning in the early 1980's, and people are keeping cars longer. At the same time, imports, particularly from Japan, continue to gain market share.
Americans' disdain for new cars showed up in almost every category in the latest report. Chrysler's minivan continues to sell well, but almost nothing else does. One big disappointment is General Motors' new mid-size four-doors, the Pontiac Grand Prix and the Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme. Japanese manufacturers that make cars in the United States also suffered declines, but they did better than the Big Three. Sales of imports have generally been off, but figures for this month are not available yet.
For most of the summer, the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation - sensing that consumers indeed were tiring of buying new cars - had been offering rebates of up to several thousand dollars on certain models to cut back their huge inventories. G.M.'s rebate program was lavish. It sold cars, but it also cut profits by more than $500 million in the third quarter.
 
A Desperate Move
The automakers also dangled additional cash bonuses in front of dealers as incentives to cut their profit margins and close more deals. It was a desperate measure, but the result of the heavy promotions was strong sales through the end of September.
On Oct. 1, however, the new model year began, with the normal higher prices across the board and a stiff reduction in rebates. After all, automakers do not like to discount new models. The result was thousands of dollars of difference in prices, even though many models, as usual, remained largely unchanged from the previous year. The industry notes that this year's cars are equipped with expensive, Federally mandated passive restraints. But that seems to make little difference to consumers.
''You really had to want to be the first one on your block to have a 1990 to buy at those prices,'' said Ronald Glantz, an automotive analyst for Montgomery Securities Inc.
As expected, October sales plummeted because so many buyers had already been lured to the 1989's. Moreover, dealers still had many too many cars and trucks and began curtailing orders from the factories. October was what the industry calls a ''payback'' period, when it loses sales it gained previously.
In any event, the Big Three and Wall Street expected the period to be over in November. When the big declines were announced, Scott Merlis of Morgan Stanley & Company said, ''These are the kind of numbers that are so bad you want to blame it on the computer. What concerns me is that we still have pretty substantial rebates.''
A Big Three executive, who asked not to be identified, said he believed that because the winter is such a soft selling season it won't be possible until the spring to see what the long-term trend is.
In the meantime, the automakers are not taking chances. If unsold cars and trucks pile up much further they might have to rent space at local fairgrounds, as they did a few years ago, for storage. Plants all over the country have begun closing down for a week or two at a time. And last week the workers at G.M.'s plant in Fairfax, Kan., came back to work to learn that they would be idle for two more weeks.

GRAPHIC: Partly assembled Pontiacs at a plant in Fairfax, Kan., late last month after General Motors closed the factory for two weeks (The New York Times/David Hutson)

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
Wall Street's Cutbacks And the Ripple Effect On the City's Economy

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
TWO years after the market collapse, Wall Street has begun another wave of job cuts. The continued weakness of the financial services sector comes as another piece of bad news for Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins and his new administration. The growing loss of Wall Street jobs comes on top of an even greater loss of manufacturing employment in New York City and the increasing exodus of back-office workers from the city.
In the past month, Shearson Lehman Hutton, one of the largest investment banks, said it would eliminate up to 800 positions; Salomon Brothers said it would continue its cost-cutting by slashing at least 100 employees by year end; and Drexel Burnham Lambert has begun cuts that could approach 800 by early 1990. Most cuts are in New York offices, and analysts expect more firms to add their names to the list. 
The financial services sector, particularly the securities business, played a central role in the city's economic revival in the 1980's, so any slowdown greatly concerns officials and economists. In addition, a significant decline in Wall Street employment means fewer well-heeled young people purchasing new apartments and spending heavily on retail and other goods and services. The average Wall Street salary is two-and-a-half times that of the citywide average, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and the loss of thousands of jobs in the securities business means a large amount of disposable income lost to the city's economy.
But high-paid investment bankers are not the only ones being laid off. Most cuts involve clerical and other lower-level jobs that are crucial to many middle-class minority workers, a group the city can ill afford to lose.
''The loss of jobs on Wall Street is significant for apartment sales, retail sales and other parts of the service economy in the city,'' said Daniel Sandy Bayer, vice president for economic and commercial development at the New York City Partnership, a nonprofit group of business and education leaders. ''It has a major impact on business and consumption in the city as well as the negative impact on the tax base.''
The entire financial services sector, which includes banks, insurance companies, pension funds and other businesses beyond Wall Street, is one of the largest employers in the city, and in 1988 financial services companies contributed about $1.5 billion directly to the city's coffers, according to the New York City Partnership. Over the last decade, Wall Street alone accounted for 20 percent of the increases in total private-sector income in the city.
Still, Gary Kesner, commissioner of the city's Office of Business Development, said the city's economy is diverse enough to withstand the loss of Wall Street jobs.
''Clearly significant cuts in the industry have already been experienced,'' he said, ''but we have had increases in other areas that have balanced off the losses.''
The latest wave of cuts continues a retrenchment that began shortly after the market crash of Oct. 19, 1987, when most large investment houses saw flat earnings ahead and moved to reduce their fixed expenses. 24,000 Jobs Lost Bureau of Labor Statistics figures show that the entire financial services industry in New York City has lost about 24,000 jobs from its peak level of 364,000 jobs in mid-1987.
''There has been a decline in the number of Wall Street jobs but the movement has not been precipitous,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, who noted that the cuts have come in several waves since the beginning of 1988.
Many analysts who track the fortunes of Wall Street firms add that the current contractions will almost certainly continue into 1990 because the sources of profits in the big investment houses have shifted rapidly over the past few years and the firms are overstaffed in many areas.
''The initial round of cuts reflected excess capacity in the industry,'' said Alison Deans, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company. ''Firms were trying to get a handle on expenses across the board.''
Ms. Deans said the downturn in the retail brokerage business, flat earnings from trading and other shifts in profitable lines of business happened so quickly that Wall Street has not fully adjusted.
''Firms grew so quickly during the bull market that they couldn't get a sense of which aspects of the business were actually profitable,'' she said. ''The market changed faster than most of these firms.''
But beyond Wall Street's latest troubles, the city has lost 21,000 manufacturing jobs in the last two years alone. In addition, the city is losing a large number of support staff and back-office operations to New Jersey and the suburbs at the same time that an increasing number of companies are moving their front offices out. The Exxon Corporation, for example, announced recently that it will move its headquarters to Dallas.
''Clearly the last two years have shown us that we can weather the storm,'' said Mr. Kesner of the city's business development office, ''but we need to be more vigilant in our efforts to keep companies here.''
According to a study prepared by the New York City Partnership, New York must make a greater effort to cut the bureaucracy that Wall Street firms and others corporations face if it hopes to prevent more operations from leaving.
''In the long term, we need to improve the quality of the labor force and to take steps to make sure we continue to upgrade our telecommunications, which is the lifeline on which these business depend,'' said Mr. Bayer, the partnership's vice president. ''Short term, the city can address some of the bureaucracy that now exists to negotiate and get approval for financial packages, and to construct facilities in the city.''

HEADLINE: One Germany: Not Likely Now

 BODY:
No one was prepared for the rush of change in East Germany and the abrupt opening of the Berlin wall. So it's not surprising that the good news is being followed by much disquieting conjecture about a feared old topic: German reunification. Even careful Henry Kissinger calls that prospect inevitable. 
Surprises can't be discounted - witness not only the holes in the wall but the other changes in the East. But the fears seem highly premature. For many different and sound reasons, hardly anybody wants reunification to happen.
Look first at East Germany. Its Communist leaders are firmly opposed to political unification, though they certainly would welcome closer economic ties with West Germany. Closer political ties would jeopardize their grip on power as well as East Germany's identity as a socialist state.
Even opposition leaders don't want unification. They retain a belief in socialism; they want to reform rather than abolish their state, and want to combine free-market elements with a capacious social safety net.
Consider next West Germany, whose people already fear being swamped by a massive exodus from the East. Chancellor Kohl expressed the consensus accurately: ''Our compatriots in the German Democratic Republic must be able to decide for themselves which way they want to go in the future.'' To Mr. Kohl, reunification is not now on the agenda.
Though President Mitterrand says he does not fear German reunification, France doesn't want it. Reunification complicates Paris's priority of moving ahead quickly with Western European economic integration. A new fatherland of 80 million Germans would tip the balance in the European Community even further in West Germany's direction.
Britain shares French concerns about an enlarged Germany becoming the economic superpower in Europe. Prime Minister Thatcher's warning against talking prematurely about reunification springs from the traditional British desire to maintain a balance of power on the continent by resisting the emergence of any outsized rival.
Like Western Europeans, Poles and other Eastern Europeans have bitter historical memories of previous greater Germanys whose drives to the East have been at their expense. And Poland has a very particular concern about a new united fatherland claiming ''lost territories'' in now-Polish Silesia and East Prussia.
Washington doesn't want reunification because that would end U.S. military presence in West Germany and dissolve NATO without an adequate substitute. Secretary of State Baker, taking his cue from Bonn, pointedly talks about Germany's legitimate wish for unity Finally, the Soviet Union, the country that suffered worst from Hitler's war, fears the nationalism that might emerge from German reunification. Mikhail Gorbachev also worries that a united Germany might be more inclined to throw its weight around Eastern Europe than in a united Western Europe.
Perhaps the only spur to serious demands for a reunited Germany would be foolish, provocative statements that Germans have no right to such an aspiration. They do have that right, and one day it may become a reality. For now, however, neither Europeans, Russians, Americans, nor indeed German leaders themselves are ready or eager to see a Fourth Reich.
More likely, the two Germanys will gradually blend their economies. In time, this will open the way for new forms of political association. Meantime, the overriding goal, for Germans and non-Germans alike, remains to integrate West Germany into Western Europe and move toward a Europe with truly open frontiers. What better end to a tormented German history, and what greater hope for Europe?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial
