HEADLINE: Colonialism Isn't All of Philippine Story

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Stanley Karnow (''From St. Joan to Lame Duck,'' Op-Ed, Nov. 6) is unique among Americans who comment on the Philippines in that he does not evade discussion of the responsiblity of the two colonial powers - Spain and the United States - for that country's problems.
Mr. Karnow is correct about Spain's promotion of a ''plantation economy that pauperized the mass of the peasantry and enriched a handful of landowners.'' And the United States, when its turn at colonialism came, ''perpetuated the authority of the upper classes'' in the Philippines.
But the irony of colonialism is that the citizens of the former colonizing powers often believe in the righteousness of their country's expansionist adventure. They could never believe that that adventure had been a cause of a former colony's ruin.
Of course, what ails the Philippines today is not all attributable to its colonizers. Sadly, the country's history is littered with national leaders who sold out to vested interests - domestic and foreign - out of greed or fear. A backward glance shows Filipino leaders who were either collaborators with the colonizers, creations or puppets of spy agencies, or political charlatans who pretended to espouse the best interests of their countrymen even as they worked in private to preserve the status quo. The hope for the Filipino people is that President Corazon C. Aquino will turn out to be different.
 
L. CORONEL-VICTORIA
 Falls Church, Va., Nov. 7, 1989
 
The writer is a commentator for Filipino newspapers in the United States and in the Philippines.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN: Atlanta

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME; PETER APPLEBOME is chief of The New York Times's Atlanta bureau.

 BODY:
Atlanta, more than any other city in the South, has always looked forward rather than back - interested in the bustle of commerce rather than the history and lore that's so much a part of many Southern cities. Its charms rest partly on the gorgeous wooded setting it began with and partly on the modern city created by the economic juggernaut of the recent past and almost not at all on what came between.
For a change, however, what's new in Atlanta is what's old. The most eagerly awaited arrival in town over the past year has been the $142 million resurrection of Underground Atlanta, the entertainment complex built on what was once the deserted skeleton of the original 19th-century downtown. Underground Atlanta flourished in the 1970's, but attendance tapered off and it closed in 1982. The expanded project, which now covers 12 acres, was reborn this summer amid much hoopla as well as concern about whether Atlanta would support a project in its downtown, which shrivels up after business hours. So far, though, the project has drawn conventioneers, tourists and locals at a pace that has exceeded all expectations and given downtown a focus it badly needed. 
In December, Atlanta will celebrate another success that will be forever associated with the city - the 50th anniversary of the Dec. 15, 1939, premiere of the film ''Gone With the Wind.'' Festivities will include historical tours, appearances by cast members, an antebellum ball, and a Scarlett and Rhett look-alike contest.
 
Underground
The new version of Underground Atlanta (404-523-2311) has been reborn between Peachtree Street and Central Avenue at Alabama Street.
Unlike other projects of the Rouse Company, like Faneuil Hall in Boston and Harborplace in Baltimore, Underground Atlanta has no natural amenity such as a harbor or river to play off of. But its location at the heart of where Atlanta began and its evocative blending of old and new architectural touches gives it a distinctive sense of place.
Underground has about 140 shops, restaurants and clubs and is oriented toward night life. For fast food, there is the attractive food court, which offers a little of everything, for example the grilled chicken sandwich ($2.95) at Louie's Chicken Grill or the roast turkey plate ($4.85) at Turkey Express Diner.
For more serious dining, Lombardi's (94 Upper Pryor Street; 404-522-6568) is a good bet. A meal with a glass of wine is about $20. Try the veal Milanese ($12.95) or the pizzas made in wood-burning ovens ($8.25).
For night life, clubs offer jazz, blues, folk and country music. Perhaps the most popular is Dante's Down the Hatch (Lower Alabama Street and Lower Pryor Street; 404-577-1800). There's jazz nightly with a $5 entertainment charge. Banks and Shane's (94 Pryor Street SW;404-577-4300), offers, at various times, jazz, bluegrass and folk; $5 cover charge Tuesday to Saturday, $3 Monday. At Blues Harbor (155 Kenny's Alley; 404-524-3001) the music is Chicago-style blues and jump swing. The cover varies with the act.
 
'G.W.T.W.'
Visitors to Atlanta looking for traces of Rhett, Scarlett and Tara usually come away disappointed. There's no Tara, but December may be the best time ever for ''Gone With the Wind'' fans to fantasize about Atlanta's past. The biggest anniversary event will be the ''re-premiere'' of the film Dec. 15 at the Fox Theater, 660 Peachtree Street, N.E. The festivities start with the Parade of Stars motorcade at 5:30 P.M., followed by a 6 P.M. cocktail reception. The screening starts at 8 P.M. and is followed by a champagne breakfast at midnight.
Prices range from $15 and $25 for the screening only to $100 for the whole shebang plus a souvenir program. Some of the events, such as the ball and the re-premiere, will be attended by 11 members of the cast of the movie. They include Butterfly McQueen, who played Prissy, Cammie King-Conlon, who played Bonnie Blue Butler, and Evelyn Keyes, who played Suellen O'Hara.
Those convinced of their own star quality can enter the Rhett and Scarlett look-alike contest Dec. 12 at the Continental Ballroom of the Hyatt Regency Atlanta hotel, 265 Peachtree Street, N.E. Judging of 10 finalists will be Dec. 12 at 8 P.M. For information on applying call 404-262-7660.
Winners and losers alike can strut their stuff Dec. 14 at the Gone With the Wind Antebellum Ball - period costumes or black tie optional - an attempt to re-create the Premiere Ball in 1939. Admission, at the Georgia International Convention and Trade Center, (1902 Sullivan Road) is $100, which includes a Southern buffet.
Special tours as part of the celebration will be a good opportunity to explore what's left of Atlanta's past. Among them is the Frankly My Dear . . . Historic Jonesboro tour Dec. 12, which will take in one of the area's most historic communities and some of its Tara-like architecture. The tour runs Dec. 11, 12, 14 and 16 and the cost is $28. A tour called Mansions and Magnolias: The Houses of Newnan visits a part of Georgia that was spared by Gen. William T. Sherman and thus has the highest concentration of antebellum homes near Atlanta. The cost is $38.
A tour Dec. 12 and 14 tracing Sherman's march through Atlanta, concludes at the Cyclorama, a Civil War exhibit featuring a massive panoramic painting, next to Zoo Atlanta at 800 Cherokee Avenue, S.E. The cost is $19.
Atlanta's Black Heritage Tour Dec. 13 will include stops at such places as the Martin Luther King Jr. Center for Nonviolent Social Change and the Atlanta University complex. The cost is $14.
For information on the ''Gone With the Wind'' festivities and all tours, call 404-262-7660.
If you just want to see the film, ''Gone With the Wind'' shows daily year round at 2:15 and 7:15 P.M. at CNN Center, 100 Techwood Avenue, S.W.; 404-577-6974). Admission is $3.50; on Tuesdays, $2.
 
Other Events
One of the most popular Atlanta theatrical offerings in years has been the Alliance Theater's production of ''Driving Miss Daisy'' by Alfred Uhry, an Atlanta native. It runs to Dec. 31 at the Alliance Studio Theater, part of the Woodruff Arts Center (1280 Peachtree Street, N.E.; 404-892-2414). Tickets are $14.25 to $20.25.
The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Yoel Levi, offers a full schedule at the Woodruff Arts Center. Tickets are $12.50 to $40.
In the same complex is the High Museum of Art (404-892-4444), designed by Richard Meier, which opened in 1983. From its gleaming porcelain-enameled steel exterior to its swirl of ramps and wash of natural light inside, it is probably the most architecturally ambitious building in Atlanta. Currently on view is ''Land of Deepest Shade: Photographs of the South by John McWilliams.'' Museum admission is $4. The museum is open Tuesday through Saturday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. (open Wednesday until 9 P.M.) and Sunday, noon to 5 P.M.
The Atlanta Ballet, at the Civic Center (395 Piedmont Avenue; 404-892-3303), presents ''The Nutcracker'' Dec. 15 to 30. Tickets for evening performances are $8.50 to $31.25 and for matinees, $8 to $24.75.
The Carter Presidential Center and Jimmy Carter Library and Museum, 1 Copenhill Avenue, N.E.; 404-331-3942) has exhibits on the Carter Presidency and other subjects. Until Jan. 25, works of the 19th-century political cartoonist Thomas Nast are on display. Admission is $2.50. Open 9 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. Monday to Saturday and Sunday noon to 4:45 P.M.
 
Where to Eat
An interesting joint venture is Indigo Coastal Grill (1397 North Highland Avenue, N.E.; 404-876-0676) and Partner's, A Morningside Cafe (1399 North Highland Avenue, N.E.; (404-875-0202). The restaurants, owned by the same management, are next door to one another in the up and coming Virginia Highlands area northeast of downtown. Indigo specializes in coastal cuisine from Cape Cod to the Keys. The Northeast steamer (half a lobster, clams, scallops and mussels), at market price, has been $16.95 lately. Partner's specializes in what it calls ''cross-cultural'' cuisine, emphasis on Mediterranean. Try the fish in parchment, lately $14.95 or $15.95.
A popular hangout for the conspicuous consumption crowd in the affluent Buckhead area is the Buckhead Diner (3073 Piedmont Road, N.E.; 404-262-3336) where the food and the Art Deco decor are lively and irreverent and dinners run about $20. A speciality is the grilled salmon B.L.T. on homemade brioche with tarragon mayonnaise ($8.75). For dessert try the white chocolate banana cream pie at $3.95 a slice. For lunch downtown try Delectables (1 Margaret Mitchell Square, N.W.; 404-68l-2909), which is perhaps the best restaurant you'll ever find at a library - Atlanta Fulton County library in this case. A specialty is lemon tarragon chicken salad at $6.50 as an entree and $3.95 as a sandwich.
For dinner at one of the more formal restaurants in town, try the Hedgerose Heights Inn (490 East Paces Ferry Road, N.E.; 404-233-7673). Entrees run from about 6 to $23. A specialty is sauteed veal medallions served with chive sauce, asparagus and ratatouille ravioli for $18.50.
Perhaps the best formal dining downtown can be found at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel (l8l Peachtree Street, N.E., 404-659-0400). The Restaurant, as the dining room is modestly called, offers Continental cuisine. Entrees begin at $19.50.
 
Where to Stay
The 454-room Ritz-Carlton (l8l Peachtree Street, N.E.; 404-659-0400) is Atlanta's premier downtown hotel. Doubles start at 55. It and other popular downtown hotels such as the Hyatt Regency (265 Peachtree Street, N.E.; 404-577-1234) and the Omni International (100 CNN Center; 404-659-0000), the official headquarters of the ''Gone With the Wind'' extravaganza, will offer special package rates for the festivities. Standard rates for doubles are $170 at the Hyatt Regency and $160 at the Omni.
In Buckhead in north Atlanta are two exceptional new hotels, the Ritz Carlton Buckhead (3434 Peachtree Road, N.E.; 404-237-2700), where doubles start at 55 and the Westin Lenox (3300 Lenox Road, N.E.; 404-262-3344), where doubles start at $2l5.
Budget choices: Less expensive in Buckhead is the Holiday Inn Buckhead (3340 Peachtree Road, N.E.; 404-23l-l234). Double rooms start at $79. A comfortable hotel downtown is the Days Inn Downtown (300 Spring Street, N.W.; 404-523-1144), where doubles start at $79.
For information on about 100 bed and breakfast establishments at prices from $32 to $100 a night, contact Bed and Breakfast Atlanta, 1801 Piedmont Avenue, N.E., Suite 208, Atlanta, Ga. 30324; 404-875-0525).

HEADLINE: The Way It Should Be Remembered

BYLINE: By Blanche McCrary Boyd; Blanche McCrary Boyd teaches writing at Connecticut College. She has just finished her third novel, ''The Revolution of Little Girls.''

 BODY:
CHARLIE HALL HAS BEEN A WEATHERMAN at WCSC-TV in Charleston, S.C., since 1953, when the city's first television station went on the air. A silver-haired man with a rich voice, Charlie is a local celebrity, a highly respected figure, and one of the reasons WCSC-TV's local news programming has dominated the ratings. He is also my friend. At 3 o'clock on the afternoon of Sept. 21, 1989, Charlie Hall's voice broke while he was delivering the forecast.
''People had been calling the station all day asking, 'Where is Hugo going to hit?' '' he told me several weeks after the hurricane. ''But when I saw the 3 o'clock computer picture, I didn't need the National Weather Service anymore to tell me what was going to happen. What the people calling meant was, 'Where is the eye going to go across?' It didn't matter. This was a monster storm, a killer. It was bigger than the entire state, and it was headed straight toward us.''
I grew up in Charleston, and, like many coastal Southerners, considered myself hurricane savvy. At my home in Connecticut, I was watching the radar picture of the storm moving toward the South Carolina coast. ''It's not going to hit us,'' I said to my friends, forgetting, briefly, where I was. ''It'll swing up, you'll see. It'll hit Myrtle Beach or North Carolina. This has happened to us before.'' 
Like my family and friends living in the Charleston area, I could not take in the enormity of what was happening. Like them, I still can't. In fact, as I'd soon learn, this had not happened to us before.
HURRICANE HUGO, THE MOST DESTRUC-tive storm ever to hit the continental United States, struck the coast of South Carolina near midnight, near high tide. The eye went up the mouth of Charleston harbor. The winds were officially clocked at 139 miles per hour, although, as Charlie told me, no one knows for sure, because the local equipment broke at 119. The storm surge, a mound of water that moves much faster than a tide, was 10 feet in Charleston, closer to 20 feet a few miles up the coast, at the village of McClellanville. In McClellanville, 600 people had huddled in a brick school in darkness with water up to their chests. They had torn the paneling off the ceiling and stuffed their children into the air vents.
We tend to measure disasters by body counts and property damage, and to rate one disaster against another. Eighteen people in South Carolina were killed by Hurricane Hugo, 65,000 left homeless, and property damage will probably reach $8 billion. Nevertheless, Hugo, as news, was soon eclipsed by the San Francisco earthquake, where, although the body count was higher, property losses and homelessness were not as severe.
At first I didn't want (Continued on Page 90) to go. My family and friends were physically unhurt. There were trees on the houses and cars smashed, but everything was fixable, and I have worked hard to put South Carolina behind me.
But like many Charlestonians, I am obsessed with the place. Although I left home at the age of 18 and have lived in California, Boston, Vermont and New York City, the world, in many ways, has merely continued to divide, for me, into South Carolina and not-South Carolina.
Two weeks after Hugo hit Charleston, I was on a plane. Every day I'd found myself scanning newscasts for familiar buildings, familiar landscapes, and calling my family with questions. When my sister found out I was coming, she spoke slowly: ''Nothing you've seen on TV, Blanche, will prepare you for this. Pictures can't do it.''
The plane landed in the afternoon because the night lights along the runways had been destroyed. I missed the entry ramp to the interstate because the sign was gone and the landscape looked different.
''Everything is so oddly bright,'' my friend Ross had told me, ''because of all the trees that are down,'' As I drove across the Ashley River, everything was oddly bright. The Lowcountry has always been a shady place full of graceful, dense pines and huge, live oaks draped with moss, but now trees were snapped off or overturned everywhere, and those left standing were nearly denuded of leaves. All along the interstate I saw roofs that were torn or smashed, windows broken and boarded over.
This is not so bad, I kept telling myself, more amazed, in a way, at what was intact than at what was damaged. The river was wide, steady and serene, looping through the wavering marsh grasses, and if many of the houses scattered along the water had bright blue tarps instead of roofs, the sight seemed picturesque from a distance.
MY MOTHER'S apartment downtown was still uninhabitable, and she was staying with my aunt and uncle and cousins, who were crowded together in a house with a tree through the roof. I stayed with Ross.
Her house was intact, but her street was a tunnel of debris, with one lane cleared. There were extension cords running across the pavement because power had been restored on one side of the street, and neighbors were sharing.
Ross is a native Charlestonian and she grew up downtown in the ''historic'' area, where many houses are hundreds of years old and there is a distinctive style of architecture. A small, olive-skinned woman in her mid-30's, Ross has a placidity and a graciousness that represent the best of Charleston. Put off by the self-importance and pretentiousness that represent the worst of Charleston, she has chosen to live her adult life in a small housing development west of the Ashley River.
After I found her house, we rode together out toward Folly Beach.
On each pilgrimage I make to South Carolina, I go to Folly Beach. The hurricane of 1938 tore the front row of houses off of Folly, creating a kind of class effect, since the most expensive houses were gone and much of the beach itself was washed away. The houses that remained as beachfront property were generally small, and at high tide some had waves breaking against their pilings. Breakwaters were built out into the surf, to try to save the sand, but they haven't helped much. ''The day will come,'' my grandmother used to say, ''when the Folly River and the Atlantic Ocean will meet, and Folly Beach will exist no more.''
Folly's atmosphere of precariousness and ruin has always attracted me. Charleston is a city in love with its own history, its own myth of gracefulness and restoration in the eye of destruction. The Lowcountry has survived the Revolutionary War, the Civil War, hurricanes and earthquakes. As a child I was told that Charleston was not burned by Sherman during the Civil War because the canny residents put up warning signs about measles, and the Union army burned Columbia instead.
The highest point in the historic district of Charleston is only 17 feet above the average low tides, and some streets downtown flood at particularly high tides. There are visible ''earthquake rods'' in houses that survived the quake of 1886. Charlestonians are as proud of their bumpy streets, their cobblestones, the crazy angles of their settled houses as they are of their walled-in gardens, their tiny alleys, their brilliant flowers, and the descendants of slaves selling handwoven baskets made of marsh grass to the tourists. In Charleston, the horses that pull the touring carriages wear diapers. When Charlestonians talk about ''the Holy City'' they are not being particularly ironic.
But nowhere is the area's fragility more apparent than on its barrier islands - Sullivan's Island, the Isle of Palms and Folly Beach. Though Folly was not, when I was growing up, a place where many affluent people lived, a decade or so ago developers moved gingerly into the area. On the Charleston side of the Folly River, condominiums replaced a funky restaurant where you could sit at old carved varnished tables and eat buckets of boiled crabs. At the end of the road onto the island, a large hotel was built right on the beach, near where the pier had been repeatedly destroyed. With these projects, the values of the flimsy properties on Folly went up.
Ross and I both hold the opinion that Charleston has been overdeveloped and overrestored. We resent not only the outside developers but the careful grooming of the downtown area. We miss the sweatier, messier Charleston of our childhoods.
The main building in the condo complex looked ruined, and we could see daylight right through the body of the hotel. ''I have to admit I feel like cheering,'' I said.
Ross was hanging out the car window, taking pictures. ''I guess,'' she said.
THERE IS A THRILL to any destruction, the natural electricity we all feel in the face of an enormous force, but my first glimpses of the destruction in the Charleston area were weirdly satisfying. Charleston was like a lady wearing too much makeup, I told myself, and Hugo had blasted that makeup right off. Once again I was getting to see Charleston's scarred, lovely face.
We parked the car where a piece of the road had been washed out and went sightseeing through the debris of people's lives. In an exposed kitchen with the refrigerator door hanging open I saw Lean Cuisines and melted chocolate ice cream, and in a bedroom torn open and sitting in the road I saw water-stained pictures of a family, an oil painting of an ocean sunset still hanging on the wall, a broken record of Lawrence Welk's Greatest Hits on the varnished wood floor.
Ross was beginning to catch my mood. ''You know the place they call the washout? It washed out.'' We both began to giggle.
On the eastern end of Folly Beach there is a sharp curve in the highway where, at high tide, waves break against the rocks guarding the road. You can see clearly what happened in the hurricane of 1938, that the front beach washed away. The island is thin, mostly marsh and road.
We got back in the car and made our way down to the wouldn't let us take a vehicle in, so we parked and walked. Bulldozers were trying to repair the road, and power-company crews were stringing wires along the new poles they'd put up. Past the washout, some of the houses on the marsh side of the road appeared unharmed. A sunburned man in a bathing suit was talking to a power-company man wearing a hardhat. ''If I can get power to one house on the island today, I'll be satisfied,'' I heard the man in the hardhat say. The man in the bathing suit nodded to us. ''At least it's a beautiful day,'' he said.
HOME IS THE SA-cred refuge of our life,'' Dryden wrote. Home is also where you can get stuck, by birth, or economic dependejce, or love. Home can fael safe or horrible, lost or portable, and home can dredge up anguish, as any attachment can.
By the time I got to my cousins' house that night, my exhilaration was fading, and home had begun to dredce up m 3/4nguish. I was beginning to comtvelend tle {ersonel} loss that Hurricane Hugo meant for each person in its path.
I satith m 3/4$ mothernd aunt and uncle and iy cousins Samm and Glenn around the kitchen table, and they did what many Southerners do: they told their painful tales humorously. ''I swear I'll never be that scared again in my life,'' Samm said. ''You should have seen us huddled there in the hall. When that tree came through the roof, Glenn and I crawled up the stairs and put a trash can under the hole, to catch the water. Then we crawled back down.'' He made crawling motions with his arms.
They talked about how the rivers were turning black from spilled sewage, and they talked about the loss of all the trees in the yard, the destruction of the woods across the way, all the inexperienced people who were having to use chain saws. Many people were getting injured; one man had died. ''But the man that lives behind us he's found his calling,'' my mother said. ''He loves his chain saw more than Jason does.''
''Daddy's car got harpooned first,'' Samm said. ''Then it got flattened.'' ''I'll tell you this,'' my mother said, ''I never want to see another damn pine branch Christmas decoration in my life.''
They discussed the storm as if it had an anatomy. ''When we passed through the wall of the eye,'' Glenn said, ''and those thunder cells around it began to explode that's when all the trees were popping. Inside the eye it was pitch black, and we went outside, and everyone was calling down the street, You all right? I've got a tree through my roof. Everybody on this street had trees on the roof.''
''Did we tell you about the sheet lightning?'' Samm said. ''The whole sky would light up this powder blue color for maybe 10 seconds, and you could see everything, and then you couldn't see anything again. The glass in the windows was bulging out. You could feel the wind sucking by the door. I was afraid the house might explode.''
Some houses did, in fact, explode. An apartment in my mother's building had blown outward, moving the bathroom into the hallway.
The coffee we were drinking tasted terrible. Two weeks after the storm the water in Charleston was safe but nearly undrinkable: pine in the water supply from the downed trees had made it bitter, medicinal.
Glenn, who is a State Senator, mourned the loss of the roof of The Confederate Museum, down at The City Market. ''The Secession flag was lying in the water,'' he said. Then he remembered his humor. ''They had a lock of Robert E. Lee's hair, too. I guess it got washed.''
''I'll tell you this,'' Samm said. ''We're 13 miles from the water, and somebody had to stay and take care of the house. It seemed like the right decision. But when Charlie Hall broke down delivering the weather report, I thought, 'Maybe we've made a mistake.' ''
SOUTHERNERS LIKE to tell a story not quite the way it happened, but the way it should be remembered, and over the next few days I would hear that Charlie Hall had sobbed on the air, that he had thrown his papers on the floor, that he had turned to the news director and said, ''Goodbye, Bill.'' At the time I visited, the station could not find the videotape, and Charlie has been unable to find the paper containing his ''last words.'' ''He knew the winds were over 200 miles an hour,'' several people told me quite seriously, ''but he didn't want to say so.''
Hurricane Hugo was not a 15-second encounter with death, as in the San Francisco earthquake, nor was it a surprise, other than in degree. Hugo was prepared for, faced and endured, and it lasted for many hours. Every person I talked to admitted wondering, at some moment, whether he or she was going to die.
After any near-death experence there is the euphoria of being alive. For Charleston, this phase lasted several days. Then, slowly, the reality of all the destruction settled in. It was, my friend Ross said, like being in a terrible automobile accident. First you think, 'Hey, I'm alive,' and then you notice your arms and legs are broken.
A similar process took place in me. I spent a day walking around Charleston, another out at Sullivan's Island and the Isle of Palms, and I began to cry. I smiled a lot and talked with people and took lots of notes, but in the privacy of my rented car, I often seemed to be crying.
On The Battery, downtown, a postcard scene of Charleston's pride, the bricks were torn off the fronts of some houses, the roofs off others. The houses had been flooded, not just with salt water, but with slimy ''pluff'' mud. A woman showed me the ceiling light fixtures in her living room, corroded from salt. Her car had just died from salt damage. ''We are so lucky,'' she said sadly.
On Sullivan's Island I talked with a man whose 1882 Victorian beach house was off its stilts, lying crushed nearby. His eyes burned with a kind of shame. ''Don't use my name, Miss,'' he said, ''and please don't take any pictures.'' I asked if this was a summer house or his regular place of residence. ''Summer house,'' he said, staring at the ground. ''But my other house is wrecked, too.''
I found a house I had lived in once, a brick house on the front beach. It was torn nearly in half. An octagonal house I'd also lived in remained intact, but now the house that had been across the street was resting right against it.
On the Isle of Palms I tried to find my friend Charleen's place, but the roads were too torn up for me to recognize anything. Arbitrarily I chose a lane to the front beach, and there I met Helen Ray.
Helen Ray was walking around the lot where her house had been, trying to salvage something. An attractive older lady with blunt-cut white hair, she was wearing rubber boots and gloves, and placing carefully, on a piece of concrete, her finds: a nickel, a bottle of artichoke hearts, an unbroken plate from a set of eight. In the trunk of her station wagon was an antique chest she'd found several blocks away. Her Mercedes sedan was lying crushed, upside down against a tree. ''It was garaged,'' she said, pointing to a shingled roof nestled among two houses off their stilts farther back from the water. ''That's the roof of my garage over there.''
Helen Ray did not even have the satisfaction of having survived Hugo; she was in Maine when the storm hit. Her husband, a Navy chaplain, had died the year before, and Helen had lost a lifetime of their carefully collected treasures. She had also lost all her papers, having taken them out of the safe-deposit box shortly before the storm. ''I'm not dealing with this well at all,'' she said lightly.
Her house, designed by an architect, had been built in 1971. She showed me the metal hulk that had been her spiral staircase, the black hole where her goldfish pond had been, the bright patch of grass that had been her walled-in garden. ''It was nice here,'' she said. ''We had the sunrise over there, and the sunset over there.''
Another woman drove up to the empty lot to visit her. This woman was maybe 10 years younger and had short, frosted hair. ''We lost our house too,'' she said, ''but I wanted to see how you're doing.''
''I'm not dealing with this well at all,'' Helen Ray said.
''I'm doing O.K.,'' the woman said, ''except when I find a picture of the children, or something.''
THE LAST DAY I WAS in Charleston, I was supposed to visit one of the razed forests and then ride up to McClellanville. But it was raining, and, anyway, I didn't have the heart. Instead I went to my brother's business, near the airport, and waited for a plane.
It was raining through the corner of the roof of my brother's office building. Water was gushing down the stairs. His secretary kept saying, ''Charlie, we've got to do something about this.'' ''Wilma,'' he said, ''what do you expect me to do?''
My brother has chosen to live with his inheritance in a way that I have not. The business he owns belonged to our dead father. He plays golf, like our father.
Charlie is a tall, heavyset man with sweet, guarded eyes. He told me how, during the eye of the hurricane, he'd gone out of his house barefooted and nearly stepped on a raw wire. So he went back inside and got his shoes.
''Charlie, what good did you think your shoes would do?''
''I don't know.'' He said he'd tried to get through the branches of the tree across his car to see how bad the damage was. ''It was a good thing I couldn't get to it, because there was a huge wasp nest right where I was trying to crawl, and if I'd gotten there I've had been killed. It would have been the most ignominous death of the hurricane.''
Charlie had bought a generator, to keep his house powered during the storm. He'd thought the electricity would be off for maybe a day. It was off at his house for two weeks. He rested his chin in his hands and smiled. ''It's kind of depressing, you know? You wake up every day and it just hasn't gone away.''
Charlie's son, Hayes, who is 12, was there with us, in the raining office. ''You should see what I've collected,'' Hayes said. ''I've got a transformer, a street light, two street signs. I tried to get a stop sign, but I haven't been able to find one.''
I was lighting one cigarette off of another. ''What are you going to do with all that stuff, Hayes?''
He shrugged happily. ''I guess I'll show it to my children.''
I SURVIVED HUGO, MANY T-shirts in Charleston say, and, on the plane back to Connecticut, I was thinking how someday the wearers can tell their grandchildren of the time the biggest hurricane came, and the forests blew down like weeds. They can recount how the water was bitter and the rivers ran black and the sky turned powdery blue at midnight. They can say how the weatherman cried.
Where there is destruction there is also the story of destructon. The story of destruction requires narrators, requires survival. For now, Charlestonians are just hurting and smiling and going on. Someday, they insist, the Lowcountry will look almost like it used to.

HEADLINE: MEET ME AT THE WALT WHITMAN REST AREA

BYLINE: By EDWARD ALLEN; Edward Allen, whose novel ''Straight Through the Night'' is in part a celebration of the New Jersey Turnpike, teaches literature and creative writing at Rhodes College in Memphis.

 BODY:

LOOKING FOR AMERICA ON THE NEW JERSEY TURNPIKE
By Angus Kress Gillespie and Michael Aaron Rockland.
Illustrated by Ruth Strohl-Palmer.
219 pp. New Brunswick, N.J.:
Rutgers University Press.
$18.95.
There is something at once menacing and magnetic about the New Jersey Turnpike. Running through the heart of our most industrialized, most motorized, most suburbanized state, it is the ultimate American highway, the embodiment of the utilitarian ideal, a symbol of all our economic triumphs and human failures. Its power, efficiency and weird toxic beauty have inspired novelists, poets, painters and rock-and-rollers - not to mention the smirking aficionados of the New Jersey Joke. Although others might wince at the thought, the turnpike is, for many, an icon like the Brooklyn Bridge. 
One approaches a scholarly study of the New Jersey Turnpike with a mixture of curiosity and caution, on guard against everything from cultural snobbery to sentimental slumming. Happily, ''Looking for America on the New Jersey Turnpike'' by Angus Kress Gillespie and Michael Aaron Rockland steers clear of any number of academic vices and turns out to be a lively, informative, thoroughly entertaining examination of this most American of highways.
Mr. Gillespie and Mr. Rockland, both members of the American studies department at Rutgers University, have researched the turnpike from a number of angles, describing the insistently bottom-line spirit in which, in 1947, it was conceived, recounting the history of its construction and official opening in 1951, investigating its economic, environmental and psychological impact and, finally, speculating about its future. They explain in comic detail the paramilitary mentality of the Turnpike Authority, examine the sometimes corrupt workings of the turnpike's enormously profitable financial machine and explore its status as a semiautonomous political entity. Drawing on interviews with turnpike administrators, state troopers, toll collectors, tow truck drivers, rest area employees and commuters, Mr. Gillespie and Mr. Rockland provide a vivid, authentic and often humorous picture of life withinJU this otherworldly corridor.
In a particularly entertaining chapter titled ''Rest Area Culture,'' the authors explore that most anonymous of American meeting places. They visit the Walt Whitman Rest Area near Philadelphia in search of an employee who knows who Whitman was - in vain. They examine the purposefully bland rest area environment in its seldom-discussed function as sexual trysting ground: a place that has been the site of everything from back-seat student romances to alleged prostitution rings operating out of the snack bars. Unfortunately, Mr. Gillespie and Mr. Rockland rely mostly on vague hearsay reports or rather tame interviews to flesh out their vision of the turnpike's secret eroticism.
Anyone who has been struck by the ferocious beauty of the turnpike's northern reaches will be interested in the authors' discussion of the highway's role in art and esthetics. (This discussion is somewhat undercut by a brief lapse into self-indulgent silliness, in which they attempt to dramatize the turnpike's visual and olfactory impact by creating a fictional family of Virginia tourists headed by a father with the generic hick name of Jim Bob.) Much as we might recoil from its frenzied harshness, the turnpike stands as the purest expression of a distinctly American industrial esthetic, which finds articulation through artists as diverse as Allen Ginsberg and Bruce Springsteen. At the same time, the authors add, the bleakness and monotony of the road suggest there might be limits to the idea that beauty always results when form follows function.
In its examination of both the glory and the squalor of its subject, ''Looking for America on the New Jersey Turnpike'' remains admirably fair-minded. Nowhere do Mr. Gillespie and Mr. Rockland play down the harm that the road has done to countless communities (like Elizabeth, forced to endure a wall dividing the city into two sections); nowhere do they gloss over the stories of official corruption, administrative arrogance and police brutality; nowhere do they become apologists for dreariness and tedium. Yet their admiration - even affection - for this megahighway, coexisting with their dismay over its destructiveness, is evident throughout, and Mr. Gillespie and Mr. Rockland deserve recognition for writing an original and substantial work.

HEADLINE: THE ARTS, FOR WHAT THEY'RE WORTH

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK; Grace Glueck is the arts news editor of The New York Times.

 BODY:

PRICING THE PRICELESS
Art, Artists, and Economics.
By William D. Grampp.
290 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $19.95.
Don't be fooled by the innocuous title of William D. Grampp's book. It attempts to make an economic analysis of the visual arts, and from there, a case for abolition of government support for them. His grounds - are you ready? - are that such support is not cost-effective and nobody really wants it, anyway. The case has been made before, by such conservative thinkers as the political scientist Edward C. Banfield, who holds that Federal support of the arts is not constitutionally justified and doesn't work in practice; that is, it does nothing to enhance the esthetic experience. 
But ''Pricing the Priceless'' is anchored in economics. To be sure, art has always been allied with money; but to measure even esthetic transactions in monetary terms is like sticking pins in butterflies. A professor emeritus of economics at the University of Illinois and an advocate of unregulated markets, Mr. Grampp takes what are not exactly large-minded views: that painters, despite the lofty ideals they profess, are basically businessmen with a product to sell; that the arts should support themselves on a laissez-faire basis; that the Government misguidedly subsidizes such activities as art to ''protect people from the market,'' that is, to ''provide them with a higher income than they could earn there.''
In his discussions of various sectors of the art economy, he is perhaps most convincing when he chides museums for not acknowledging their collections as capital, that is, not thinking in terms of the interest income that would be received if the capital were invested in another form. By not doing so, he suggests, museums encourage the unbridled growth of their holdings, much of which languishes in storage. The implication is that more staff, better scholarship, more intensive research activities and so forth might flourish with the divestiture of swollen inventories. ''The effect . . . of an overstated gain or an understated loss is to induce the organization to do more than it efficiently can do,'' he writes. One serious consequence of museums' phenomenal growth, he points out, is that as they expand, they devote more of their space to administrative rather than exhibition purposes.
But generally, Mr. Grampp's points are tediously argued and insufficiently supported. We eventually arrive at the clincher, that it is not really productive for government to support the visual arts. Tilting at those who say it is, he attempts to dismantle their arguments premise by premise. There is no evidence, for example, to show that subsidizing art because it is a public good ''would yield as much benefit as there would be in subsidizing something else or nothing at all.'' He also gives short shrift to the ''positive externalities'' of art - for example that it makes communities attractive to live in and improves the cultural climate. ''To say that art diminishes the coarse fibres of human nature may be true, or may not,'' he writes, ''but is no guide to how to spend the public's money.''
And he rejects the idea of art as a ''merit good,'' that is, as something that should be given by the Government or other patrons to people who do not know enough to want it even though they can afford it. As Mr. Grampp sees it, ''if art is actually to the benefit of people they will themselves acquire a taste for it.''
Had enough? That the art world, like many other worlds, is not economically tidy and efficient most of us are prepared to acknowledge. We will even agree that some people - mainly those who buy cheap and sell dear - make inordinate profits from it while many of those who create art cannot live by their income. But in this country the battle for public support of the visual arts - and what a pittance it is, compared with the level of funding in Europe! - has been won many times in Congress, beginning with the birth of the National Endowment for the Arts in 1965. While Mr. Grampp believes that Congress has more of a mandate from the arts lobby than from the people, he overlooks the fact that most of the Endowment's grants are given on a collaborative basis; that is, funds from Washington must be locally matched, which hardly supports the thesis that at the grass roots no one cares. NOR, although he would like to abolish public funding for the arts, does Mr. Grampp say how he would do it. Would he kill the Endowment outright, as Ronald Reagan wanted to do when he took office, and as some conservative Congressmen want to do today? Would he have the Federal or local governments do away with educational funding that helps broaden the exposure of school children to art? Would he discourage grants to promising artists? Cancel funding for conservation of major works? As difficult as it was to initiate government support for the arts, it would not be easy to do away with it, and Mr. Grampp offers no program.
But this book has made a timely appearance. Even though it does not touch on the current furor over the Endowment's support of certain artworks held to be ''obscene'' and irreligious by conservative Congressmen, it gives aid and comfort to their views.

SECTION: Section 8; Page 11, Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 798 words

HEADLINE: About Cars;
Luxury Car Adds Trimmings

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
There is much truth in the notion that it is folly to tamper with success, and the Ford Motor Company's Lincoln division has made capital of this idea with its Town Car sedan.
For nearly a decade, the Town Car has been the epitome of American luxury: big, square-cornered, pillow-soft. During that time, luxury-car sales have grown 62 percent, compared with a 14 percent increase for cars in general, and Lincoln has billowed along on the crest.
Now, though, it is time for a change, in the opinion of Ross Roberts, the Texan who heads Lincoln-Mercury. He was in New York recently, and he talked about the car, the philosophy behind it, and the people who buy it. 
The 1990 model is bigger, rounder, more aerodynamic. It is more fuel-efficient and more hushed than its formerly already silent self. But it will make big noise on the country-club scene.
''We had to change it,'' Roberts said. ''We needed the aerodynamics. And we needed to move. The old car hadn't been changed much since we introduced it in 1980. And I think people are ready.''
The new Town Car is indeed sleeker than its predecessor, with a coefficient of drag of only .36, down from .46 last year. That translates into smoother airflow, with less wind noise, and better economy. And Roberts said more consumer clinics had been held on this car than on any other Ford product but the Taurus.
''We were nervous,'' he said. ''But the people at the clinics gave us good marks. And the dealers loved it.''
That may be so, but a bit of time behind the wheel of a metallic-gray test car garnered opinion that was both pro and con, and one driver took the trouble to holler across a Manhattan street that he had been waiting a long time for a look, and would now buy something else.
Indeed, a lot of people have had to wait for a look at the Town Car. That is because the cars are sitting by the thousands in parking lots around Detroit, waiting to be retrofitted with the fluted plastic side moldings that dress up the lower body and provide protection from flying gravel and other road hazards.
''Our supplier wasn't happy with the quality of the moldings as they were produced,'' Roberts said, ''and we decided we didn't want any cars to go out before they were right. It's going to take awhile.''
Despite the aero look, the 1990 model does bear a resemblance to its older kin, and the ''round Town Car'' is a reasonably conservative exercise in modern styling. But doors now wrap into the roof, and the softer look of the all-new sheet metal is complemented by flush glass.
There are opera windows in the rear pillars, and the six-passenger sedan is trimmed with bright metal. The powertrain remains conventional, too, with a 5-liter V8 driving the rear wheels.
All of that is to the good, given the Lincoln's conservative clientele. Roberts says the traditional customer's median age is 62, and 38 percent of those buyers are retired. Median income is $60,000, and one in five customers earns $100,000 a year or more.
A paper put out by Ford notes that the customers are far different from those who buy Lincoln's two other products, the sportier Mark VII coupe and the Continental sedan. The paper observes that Town Car buyers ''are less willing than Mark VII or Continental buyers to acknowledge prestige as a purchase motivation and attach less importance to technical innovations.''
The latter is also the reason given by the company for making antilock brakes an option, no matter whether the car is the basic model, the Signature version or the top-of-the-line Cartier. And it is probably just coincidental fallout for the accountants that a buyer who wants the safety afforded by ABS has to pay $936 extra.
Other options are few, as they should be on a car with a price ranging from $27,986 to $32,809, but they include such things as an electrically heated windshield and a locking differential to make the going better on snow and ice.
Whatever the weather, the car is a pleasure, particularly on the interstates. It is a cocoon that isolates the occupants from the reality out there, and the seating is all that could be asked, with more front and rear shoulder room than last year's car, and more knee room in back. Both driver and front-seat passenger have air bags for protection, should the unthinkable occur.
There is an electronic instrument cluster, and the car is easy to drive, although the four-speed automatic transmission might be smoother in its shifts.
The engine puts out 150 horsepower (160 in the Cartier, which has standard dual exhausts). That would seem insufficient in a 4,025-pound automobile. Oddly, though, you don't notice any lack of power, and the car performs effortlessly.
In fact, it feels very much like an American car of old - exactly what the buyers want.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES: Brighton Beach;
A Revised Proposal for the Baths Site

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
A CONTROVERSY over land use has taken a new turn in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn. Its roots are in history but the stakes are a community's future.
Back in 1955, the late Brooklyn builder Alexander Muss took a long-term lease on 21 acres facing the boardwalk in Brighton Beach as a choice location for development of high-rise oceanfront housing over the next five or six years.
He proceeded to use six acres on the eastern edge of the property to build two tall rental buildings, Seacoast Towers A and B, with 591 apartments, in the grace period before the city's 1961 rezoning took effect. The buildings conformed to pre-1961 zoning. They rented slowly in the competitive housing market of the time, however, and Mr. Muss deferred his housing plans. 
With the land came a successful business. The Brighton Beach Baths, as it was then known, had been operating on the property since 1919. Alexander Muss & Sons put in steam rooms and hot showers, added an 18-hole miniature golf course and three tennis courts, resurfaced 22 paddleball courts and continued to operate what by then had become the city's largest remaining private beach club. Later the property was renamed the Brighton Beach Bath and Racquet Club.
On the housing side, the developer's final project in New York City was a Manhattan co-op, 733 Park Avenue, in the early 70's. Then operations shifted to Florida.
NOW Mr. Muss's son, Stephen, owner of the Fountainbleau Hilton and the 800-unit Seacoast Towers in Miami Beach, wants to build in Brooklyn again. Having acquired title to the Baths property in 1980, he advanced a plan developed by the architectural firm of Beyer Blinder Belle a year ago to replace the beach club with 2,000 units of housing in six buildings called Brighton by the Sea. It would have meant 2.9 million square feet of new construction in two towers of 44 stories, two of 34 stories and two of 24 stories, plus ancillary facilities, on 15 acres.
By the time it had reached the City Planning Commission in its journey through the land-use review process it had been endorsed by Community Board 13 but battered as an overly dense inappropriate ''Florida-style'' development by an ad-hoc Committee to Preserve Brighton Beach and Manhattan Beach. Mayor Edward I. Koch, as well, had unfavorable words for it during the recent primary campaign.
In the end, Muss decided to withdraw the proposal and hired another architect, Costas A. Kondylis, to redesign the project. The revisions required a new environmental impact study, which was certified as complete this month, triggering the public six-month land-use review.
It is among the last of the major land-use proposals that is likely to be acted upon by the Board of Estimate before it closes for business next summer under the revised City Charter approved on Election Day. Projects that are certified for public review before the end of February are expected to complete the six-month ''old'' uniform land-use review process before a new Planning Commission and the City Council take over.
Brighton by the Sea, in its revised form, has been scaled down 27 percent, to 2.1 million square feet of construction on 15 acres. The residential component has 1,730 apartments in five buildings - one of 29 stories, two of 25 stories and two of 23 stories. There is also an 1,800-car parking garage, 82,000 square feet of commercial space - principally a 46,000-square-foot health club - and 19,000 square feet of medical offices. Development would proceed in phases, probably over not less than five years.
Looked at purely in local terms, the impact of Brighton by the Sea would be powerful. Assuming it were financed, built and successfully sold as a pure market-rate development, it would bring a large new population of higher-income occupants to oceanfront high-rises in Brighton Beach.
That would represent a remarkable turnaround for an area heavy with high-density prewar rental buildings that nearly fell collectively into city ownership during the dark housing days of the 70's. They owe their revival principally to the influx of Russian immigrants.
AN argument can be made that a new market-rate development - attracting families with incomes of perhaps $50,000 to $80,000 - offers the best long-term hope of sustaining that revival. On the other hand, if sales are weak for the first building, most of the site might languish vacant for years. The sales market for large-scale multifamily new housing in the location is largely untested.
The only recent experience has been provided by Seabreeze Plaza at 3111 Ocean Parkway, on a 35,000-square-foot beachfront site formerly occupied by Club 21. It is a 116-unit, 15-story building that was built last year and is almost 90 percent sold at average prices of $250 a square foot, said one of the owners, David Eshaghian. It benefited from the fact that there has been so little new beachfront development, he said.
To critics, the Muss plan is unacceptable on other grounds. The buildings seem out of context with their environment, a threat to the quality of life in the neighborhood and an abuse of zoning standards. ''It was too tall and too dense before, and it's too tall and too dense still,'' said Judith Baron, president of the Committee to Preserve Brighton Beach and Manhattan Beach, which primarily represents homeowners in the area.
The opponents also say that 1,730 new households would strain capacity at Coney Island Hospital; overload the already congested subway service on the D and Q lines during rush hours, and cause excessive traffic congestion. And they cite the Interstate Sanitation Commission for backing their claim that the Coney Island sewer treatment plant is already at or near capacity.
NEVERTHELESS, it is questionable whether the Baths site is appropriately zoned. Large private beach clubs on waterfront land are fading out as they grow economically marginal. On the East River in the Bronx, both the Shorehaven and Castle Hill beach clubs closed in the 80's, and a low-rise housing development is in construction at the Shorehaven site, on Clason's Point.
The zoning planners of the late 50's gave the Brighton Beach Baths land little elbow room for adaptation over time when they placed it in a category called C-3, however. This is designed mainly for boating-related waterfront activities with adjacent low-density residential use. The Baths property, with three swimming pools, has no ocean frontage and no opportunity for boat docking. Patrons reach the public beach by crossing the boardwalk.
The long-time manager of the Baths, Hyman Cohen, a Muss vice president, says that membership has dropped steadily in the 80's. Lack of parking space is one reason, he says. Four years ago he approached the Metropolitan Transportation Authority about allowing parking for 300 cars below the Brighton Beach elevated line, near the front door of the Baths.
The community board voted it down, but in retrospect he is not disappointed, he said. Membership has dropped to 2,000 from from 5,000 in 1981, despite a membership campaign in the mid-80's, he said, and he doubts now that even with parking facilities it would stage a comeback. In the 60's there were 8,000 members. The civically active Mr. Cohen has himself become a target of foes of the Muss plan, who charge that cronyism is advancing it. He was a member of School Board 21 for 11 years until his resignation under fire in November 1988, and is also a member of Community Board 13, though he has ''recused'' himself from the consideration of the Muss rezoning application. Nevertheless, teachers have complained that school district officials pressured them to support Brighton by the Sea and to write letters to the Planning Commission on school time to urge approval of the project. Mr. Cohen denies that he ever sought their support.
His opponents note that under C-3 zoning about 300 units of low-rise two- and three-story houses could be built. ''But Muss is a high-rise builder and he doesn't want to do houses,'' said Irwin Fruchtman, a former city Buildings Commissioner who is a director of the Committee to Preserve Brighton Beach and Manhattan Beach.
''I couldn't emotionally use the land for 300 units of low-rise housing,'' Mr. Muss conceded.
Can any appropriate alternative ''water-related recreational uses'' be developed on the Baths site? To build a modern 50,000-square-foot facility with a pool would probably cost about $6 million, according to Marc Sferrazza, vice president of Eastern Athletic Clubs, which operates health clubs at the St. George co-op in Brooklyn Heights and elsewhere. It would need about 5,000 members a year to break even, and perhaps 80 percent of them would have to live within walking distance.
MR. SFERRAZZA, who visited the Baths site at the request of the opposition committee, said he had not done a close enough study of Brighton Beach to know whether a new facility was a reasonable proposition there.
In the end, the use category provided by the 1961 zoning looks about as arbitrary as the manufacturing use proscribed for so much Manhattan land, which is too costly ever to be reused for modern, competitive manufacturing, warehouse or distribution facilities.
For planners to adjust without seeming arbitrary themselves, a master-plan overview is desirable. Gradually, New York City is developing this for its waterfront. But consideration of new zoning for a site as critical as the Muss tract in Brighton Beach need not await completion of a master plan. By carefully weighing community resources and needs, the commission should be able to determine an appropriate use for the tract.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Investing Abroad;
American Developers Are Now Looking To Europe, East and West, for Opportunity

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH the recent attention focused on Japanese and European real estate investment in the United States has tended to obscure the parallel activities of Americans overseas, the internationalization of property ownership and development is becoming a two-way street.
So far, involvement by American development companies abroad is only a trickle compared to the flood of foreign activity here. But the numbers, while small, are growing, spurred, some developers say, by diminishing development opportunities in major commerical centers like New York, Los Angeles and Dallas and the growing economies of Spain, Italy and West Germany.
Department of Commerce statistics tell the story: In 1988, foreign direct investment in this country represented $328.9 billion. Of that, $31.9 billion was in real estate. Last year, direct American investment abroad was $326.9 billion, with $2.1 billion of the total in real estate. 
But that has begun changing. David S. Solomon, principal in Solomon Equities of New York, which hopes to open an office in London next year, put it this way: ''I feel the same excitement in some European cities now that I felt in New York 10 years ago. For the time being, there are fewer opportunities here, so I think you'll see more of us finding ways of overcoming the obstacles.''
Mr. Solomon, whose projects in New York have included Tower 49, a 600,000-square-foot office building at 12 East 49th Street that was sold to a Japanese concern three years ago, is planning three developments in Europe: a 25-story office tower in Brussels, a 35-story building, also in Brussels, and an 18-story office building in Milan. He said there is a good possibility that the company will be joined in those ventures by a European institutional investment partner, such as an insurance company or a pension fund.
Among the other office projects under way or being planned by real estate developers based in New York are the 70-story, 920,000-square-foot tower being built in Frankfurt by Tishman Speyer Properties in partnership with Citibank and Kajima Corporation, a Japanese construction company, and an office complex that Park Tower Realty is developing in London's financial district with the Greycoat Group, a British real estate company.
The involvement of American companies in foreign real estate projects is not limited to speculative office projects. The ITT Sheraton Corporation and Pan American World Airways recently closed on a deal with the Moscow City Council and Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, that will allow them to open the first American hotel in Moscow. And last year Tishman Realty and Construction Company, which is not connected to Tishman Speyer, formed a joint venture with Aoki Corporation of Japan to sponsor projects in Japan worth about $2 billion. Tishman is the first American construction company to be able to enter the Japanese development arena.
These and other projects are harbingers of the international future of real estate development and investment, industry observers say.
''Just as we saw during the 70's and 80's an internationalization of the financial markets,'' said Michael J. Bamber, chief executive officer of European operations for Richard Ellis International, an international property consulting and brokerage company based in London, ''real estate has been moving toward globalization. Now more Americans are joining in.''
Richard Ellis, a company formed in 1773 that now has 30 offices in 18 countries, earlier this year merged with the Lexington Company of New York and reopened an office in New York as part of its strategy for exploiting this trend. The new company will retain the Richard Ellis name and its offices in Chicago, Washington and Minneapolis.
WHILE some American developers say the plan of the European Economic Community to remove existing bureaucratic, legal and trade barriers among 12 member countries at the end of 1992 was not the catalyst for their interest in Europe, they believe the harmonization of the economy there will draw more American developers overseas.
From a practical standpoint, the plan is expected to make development easier and less costly when monetary exchange controls and foreign investment restrictions are removed and specifications for design and construction are standardized.
''But what is even more significant,'' said Mr. Bamber, who is based in Brussels, and who was in New York earlier this month to speak at a conference on worldwide property investment, ''is that the E.E.C. represents by far the world's largest trading partner. Together, the 12 participating countries represent a marketplace of 320 million consumers. That is nearly as much as the United States and Japan combined.''
Jerry Speyer, president of Tishman Speyer, said that while he expects the barrier-free market in Europe to accelerate growth and lower the cost of doing business there, his company is not in Europe because of it.
''We have been exploring opportunites in Europe for some time,'' he said, ' as part of a long-term strategy. We've also turned our attention toward the development of housing for America's aging population and we've started acquiring existing commercial properties like 1301 Avenue of the Americas, the former J.C. Penney Building.''
Although Mr. Speyer said the company will continue to seek other opportunities in Europe, it will concentrate for the time being on finishing its 850-foot tower in Frankfurt, which will be the tallest office building in Europe. Mr. Speyer expects to complete the tower, designed by Helmut Jahn of the Chicago architectural firm of Murphy/Jahn, by the end of 1990, and he and his partners will be looking to both German and multinational service companies as tenants.
''We've been looking around in several countries for the past few years,'' said Veronica Hackett, executive vice president of Park Tower Realty. ''The St. Paul's project in London had the ingredients we were looking for. It is a very visible site and it is important in the financial district from both a design as well as an economic point of view.''
Park Tower and Greycoat, which have a 242-year lease with the Church of England, the property's owners, will build on a 4.1-acre site next to St. Paul's Cathedral between Warwick Lane and Newgate Street. The project will be a complex of low-rise buildings to complement the cathedral.
While most American developers have limited their activity to Western Europe, ITT Sheraton is demonstrating that development opportunities exist farther east. It was the first to enter into a management agreement with an Eastern Bloc country with the Sheraton Sofia hotel, which opened in Bulgaria in 1986.
''THERE is a serious lack of good hotels in Eastern Europe,'' said Jerry Morin, a Sheraton senior vice president who is responsible for development in Europe, Africa and the Middle East. ''Now that travel restrictions are coming down, there is a pent-up demand. We have been having discussions with some of the Baltic states and now, with the political atmosphere changing by the day, it is impossible to see where the potential for expansion will end.''
Mr. Morin described Sheraton's 450-room Moscow project as an extensive renovation of an existing six-story building.
''We wanted to go with a new construction project,'' Mr. Morin said. ''But we were not able to get a site in a location that was acceptable to us. So rather than lose the chance to open in Moscow we went with a plan to redevelop an existing building.''
Mr. Morin hopes the $75 million Gorky Street project will be completed in 1992.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Mixed-Use Mortgage
Question: I am trying to purchase a three-story town house in Greenwich Village. The building has a small storefront with a duplex apartment above it. The apartment would be my primary residence and I would relocate my retail business to the store space. I have just begun inquiring about mortgages and I have been steered in the direction of commercial loans. As the apartment would be my only home, I'm hoping to qualify for a home loan at a lower interest rate. Are there any banks that can help me? . . . L. W., Manhattan 
Answer: Maybe. But according to Lavelle Jackson, a princpal in Mortgage One Company, a Manhattan mortgage brokerage and consulting company, very few banks are willing to offer residential mortgages for mixed-use buildings.
''This town house is a borderline case,'' said Mr. Jackson. ''But in general most lenders would feel justified in offering only a commercial mortgage. The potential income from the storefront space would make the building an income-producing property.''
Mr. Jackson said that currently interest rates on commercial loans are generally two or three points above those for residential mortgages. It might be worth your time to continue making calls to banks or to find a mortgage broker; a broker will probably charge a fee, usually 1 percent of the loan value. In some cases, banks pay the brokerage fees as part of the points.
 
An Earlier Lord & Taylor
Question: The other day driving down Broadway we saw a building I never noticed before. It is on the southwest corner of 20th Street. What can you tell us about it? . . . C. C., Manhattan
Answer: It is the former Lord & Taylor department store, which opened for business there in 1870 as one of the department stores in what is now the Ladies Mile Historic District. According to the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission, which recently granted landmark status to the district, the building is a cast-iron structure done in the Second Empire style. Its architect, James H. Giles, specialized in cast-iron buildings. In 1914, Lord & Taylor moved to its present site on Fifth Avenue between 38th and 39th Streets. The Broadway building now holds the St. Laurie clothing store and a restaurant on the ground floor and commercial and residential lofts above.
 
A Rent Overcharge Claim
Question: I filed a complaint with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal concerning rent overcharges on my stabilized apartment about a year ago. I know there is a long waiting list for this, but is there any way for me to expedite the process? Is preference given to people because of their age? I am 82. . . . C. R., Manhattan
Answer: The agency does not automatically give priority to the elderly, though it would do so in response to a court order or in an emergency.
Unfortunately, even though much of the process has been computerized, according to Thomas R. Viola, a spokesman for the agency, it takes an average of two and a half years for a complaint to reach the desk of a rent examiner. Once the examiner starts work, most cases are settled in two or three months. The agency blames a backlog it inherited from the Office of Rent Control and Conciliation and Appeals Board in 1984 and expects that once it is cleared up within the next few months, the entire process should be faster.

HEADLINE: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;
A Strategy for Fairfield's Office Vacancies

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
IN the 20-odd years since Fairfield County was initiated into the wonderful world of office buildings, it has taken its lumps for overdeveloping and overpricing. But despite a third-quarter vacancy rate of 21.7 percent, according to Cushman & Wakefield Realtors of Stamford, the market survives.
''I think the confidence is there because it's now a mature market, able to sustain itself from within,'' said Jeffrey Sussman, president of the Louis Dreyfus Property Group in Manhattan.
The survival strategy is to rehabilitate the county's older corporate campuses and office towers, where there is a supermarket of low-priced space. ''By upgrading them we can produce the kind of modern, amenity-rich buildings that you would expect to find downtown in New York,'' Mr. Sussman said. 
When Dreyfus bought the 18-year-old Richardson-Vicks headquarters in Wilton earlier this year, it kept 70,000 square feet of the 220,000-square-foot building for itself and rented the rest to Deloitte-Touche of Manhattan. Dreyfus will seek site plan approval to build another structure, with 300,000 square feet of space, on the 60-acre tract.
Pickwick Plaza, built for the Xerox Corporation in 1974 in Greenwich, was bought by JMB Realty of Chicago four years ago and now, after a major modernization, is fully rented.
This year, Robert Martin, the Westchester developer who has several properties in Connecticut, acquired 2777 Summer Street, a 110,000-square-foot, 21-year-old building in Stamford, for $4.5 million.
Three years ago, Sunbelt Investment of Delray, Fla., bought Union Carbide's 1.2 million-square-foot, seven-year-old complex in Danbury. Union Carbide occupies 80 percent of the space on a leaseback, rents 100,000 square feet to Boehringer-Engelheim, a German pharmaceutical company, and has an additional 150,000 square feet available at $29.50 a foot.
Greenwich Plaza, at the Greenwich railroad station, ''was the first real office building in Connecticut,'' said Paul King, senior vice president at Grubb & Ellis Realty's Stamford office. ''It presents a tremendous image as you get off the train - overlooking Long Island Sound, with access to shops.''
It is also one of a dwindling number of buildings remaining in the hands of the original developer, the Ashforth Real Estate Group of Manhattan, along with some in Stamford built by the Connecticut companies F. D. Rich Company, Collins Development Company and Warwick-Malkin.
Some $4 million will have been spent when upgrading is completed in March on the Plaza's two glass-walled buildings. New lobbies, common areas, heating, ventilating and air-conditioning systems, entryways and general repairs to the buildings and connecting outdoor plaza are included. Rents will remain at the current low $30's a square foot.
The project was a source of major controversy when it was proposed in 1969. Many townspeople were furious at the intrusion of a city office building that cut off their view of the Sound from the entire length of Greenwich Avenue, the main street.
THE town had asked for a donation from Ashforth to paint the old railroad station. Instead, it got a 300,000-square-foot office complex containing 30,000 square feet of shops, a movie theater and a brand new station built over the railroad tracks through an air-rights agreement with what is now the New Haven Division of Metro-North Commuter Railroad.
''Lately there has been a decrease in the size of new tenants,'' said Darrell Harvey, executive vice president at Ashforth's Stamford office. ''Businesses that have a lot of clerical and middle-management people go to eastern Fairfield County, where there is more access to cheaper housing. The small executive-intensive firms that can afford Greenwich homes are coming here - financial investment companies and consultants who communicate all over the world without regard to where they are located.''
Joseph Ercolano, vice president of the Southwestern Area Commerce & Industry Association in Stamford, believes that ''as Class B space is renovated up to Class A, it will add to the glut of Class A space.'' He noted that it could discourage ''a steady influx of smaller companies inquiring about 5,000 to 15,000 square feet'' and he predicted it will take up to four years for Stamford's 27 percent vacancy rate to drop to 15 percent.
Third-quarter figures compiled by Cushman & Wakefield Realtors indicate that 227,000 square feet of offices are still under construction in Stamford and 3 million square feet are available out of a total of 15.6 million square feet citywide.
''All the economic uncertainty in New York can only help Fairfield and Westchester,'' said John Goodkind, vice president at the Mendick Realty Company in Manhattan, owner of 12 million square feet of offices in New York and several Fairfield County buildings.
Among them is the 25-year-old structure at 1351 Washington Boulevard, where renovations estimated at $6.5 million are to be completed in February, including a new metallic exterior skin, new lobbies, climate-control systems, a cafeteria, windows on two sides of the building where none existed, and access to a nearby health club. Rents will be around $19.50 a square foot. ''With today's transportation and telecommunications systems, the guy who lives in Stamford, Greenwich or New Canaan doesn't need to waste an hour and a half commuting every day,'' said Mr. Goodkind. '' I think we'll see a tighter market in 16 months.''
Connecticut's first corporate campus, the 600,000-square-foot headquarters that American Can (now Primerica) built in 1970 on 155 acres in northwest Greenwich, was sold in 1986 to a consortium called Greenwich American Limited Partnership. Unable to market the property because the town prohibited leasing it to more than three tenants, the partnership sued the town. The State Supreme Court ruled in favor of the partnership in May.
''We are now negotiating with 100,000-square-foot tenants of Fortune 500 quality,'' said Paul Liles of Manhattan, a partner in the consortium. ''We can fill in with smaller tenants later. Within the Fairfield-Westchester market there is a lot of relocation going on, and we will renovate to suit.''
