HEADLINE: Those Stay-Forever Sidewalk Bridges

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
TEN years after falling masonry killed a Barbard College student and inspired a rigorous new law governing the maintenance of building facades in New York City, vast expanses of Manhattan sidewalk have been covered by scaffolding and protective bridges in a surge of facade repairs.
The repairs, applauded by city officials and some civic organizations, are in many cases exceeding those mandated by Local Law 10, adopted in 1980. The law is intended only to insure public safety, requiring the owners of buildings taller than six stories to have their facades professionally inspected every five years, and to repair or remove anything that might fall off.
Now, having had their first detailed inspections in decades -- the first in 1982, the second in 1987 -- many of the city's older buildings are undergoing facade repairs that have more to do with structural quality than pedestrian safety. Windows are being replaced, bricks cleaned, cornices painted and terra-cotta ornaments restored. 
''The law has raised the consciousness of the city,'' said Walter Melvin, the principal in Walter Melvin Architects, a Manhattan firm, which specializes in facade work. ''People are looking up and becoming aware of things on their facades that they never knew existed.''
But while it is welcomed in some quarters, Local Law 10 is also extracting a high cost in esthetics and sidewalk congestion. Some find a grim irony in a law that is beautifying the upper stories of tall buildings but covering so much sidewalk with protective structures that the buildings' facades are hidden from view.
''We can't allow these sidealk bridges to stay up ad infinitum,'' said Charles M. Smith, the city's Commissioner of Buildings, whose department is reponsible for enforcing Local Law 10. He added that the city had been besieged with ''very legitimate complaints'' and was preparing to ''remedy the situation'' with legislative proposals.
Local Law 10 was prompted by the death of Grace Gold, a Barnard freshman who was killed in 1979 by masonry that fell from a Columbia University building at Broadway and 115th Street. Its enforcement gained impetus in 1981, when Mayda Alsace, a 28-year-old Legal Aid Society atttorney was killed by bricks that fell from 66 Court Street, near Livingston Street in downtown Brooklyn. No deaths or serious injuries have occurred since in that fashion, the Buildings Department said.
The scaffolding that is used in repairing facades has in some cases proven more hazardous than falling pieces on the facade. In the most recent case, on Oct. 3, a weight used to keep the scaffolding in place fell to the street from the 17th floor of the same Brooklyn building --66 Court Street -- killing John Dauway, a 48-year-old court officer. Though the sidewalk in front of the building was covered by a protective bridge, the weight bounced off a parapet on the 14th floor and landed in front of 62 Court Street, a neighboring building where no sidewalk bridges had been installed.
THE city now imposes no limit on how long the sidewalk bridges may remain in place. The companies that rent them out provide little economic incentive to perform repairs quickly, and repair decisions have been postponed by many building owners even after the sidewalk structures have gone up.
A result in some neighborhoods is that sidewalks have been covered for years, with little evidence that facade work is nearing completion.
''People on the first floor of our building haven't seen daylight in three years,'' said Malcolm Frouman, the art director at Business Week magazine and a member of the board of a 12-story co-op at 895 West End Avenue at 104th Street that remains surrounded by sidewalk bridges.
The building's problem is not unusual. After the bridges were erected for a minor facade repair in early 1986 more serious problems were found and the larger repairs were repeatedly delayed. With the bridges in place, the co-op board consulted architects and engineers, debated how to proceed and settled on a construction program in which damaged terra-cotta details on the facade are being replaced with ornately cast concrete, and other restoration work is being done the goes beyond the requirements of the law.
Mr. Smith said he had prepared a recommendation to the City Council to enact technical changes in Buildings Department procedures. If approved, the changes would allow the department to force the removal of some sidewalk bridges, but would not set a time limit in all cases.
Under current policy, property owners performing work required by Local Law 10 are granted a building notice by the city that lets them erect sidewalk bridges. The notice expires in 12 months, but is easily renewed. Problems in the facade that are deemed to pose an immediate hazard must be corrected within 30 days, or a maximum of 90 days if an extension is granted by the city.
But many problems are not considered urgent and property owners can take years to have the work done. When the owners also elect to combine Local Law 10 repairs with other facade improvements, their work schedules are stretched out even further, and the sidewalk bridges usually remain standing.
Another factor is that fees for the sidewalk bridges, which are rented out by more than a dozen New York City companies, sometimes encourage owners to keep them up a long time. The fees are high when the bridges are put up and when they are removed, but relatively low in the interim when they are left standing for months or years.
''Once a bridge is up, you want to make sure it stays up until every bit of work is done,'' said Richard Layman, director of construction for Crest Management, which has had a sidewalk bridge in front of 295 Columbus Avenue on a congested corner of 74th Street for more than two years.
Work on Crest's building, which originally was to have been confined to fixing a loose parapet, has since been slowed down because the company wants to replace its windows. And since it is in one of the city's historic districts, the design of the windows must be reviewed by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, where an application is pending.
Mr. Layman said his company paid $20,000 to have the bridges installed and the first three months rent in 1987. Since then, monthly payments have been reduced to $700. To have the bridges removed, he said, will cost more than $10,000.
Mr. Smith said the fee structure encourages property owners to delay repairs. He added that the many sidewalk bridges put up under the law, combined with those required at dozens of new construction sites, had covered more of the city's sidewalk space than at any time in memory.
The problems are more than esthetic. Around Times Square and elsewhere in West Midtown, awash in new construction and facade repairs, homeless people seek shelter, and drug addicts and street criminals lurk in the dank half light of the sidewalk structures.
SMALL merchants have been particularly affected because the sidewalk structures hide their signs, cast their display windows into shadow and create a menacing environment on the sidewalk that discourages shoppers.
''You hear horror stories,'' said Fran Leepers, owner of Little Leepers, a children's clothing store at 104th Street and Broadway, where a sidewalk bridge was being removed early this month.
Although the bridge was up less than a month in front of her store, she said other merchants had been robbed, litter had been strewn in front of their doors and a business had declined severely as their sidewalks were covered for months or years.
Mr. Smith said his proposal to the City Council is to require property owners seeking to renew their building notices - allowing them to keep their sidewalk bridges up more than a year - to submit an engineer's report on what work had been completed and a timetable for the remaining repairs. If the repairs are not completed by the end of the second year a sidewalk bridge is in place, property owners can be fined $250 a month under the proposal.
Some critics say Local Law 10 is severely flawed because its emphasis is narrowly confined to public safety and it gives many property owners the option of tearing off balconies, cornices, decorative garlands and other architectural details instead of having them restored and secured.
The potential implications became clear soon after the first round of inspections required by the law in 1982, when the owners of the Mayflower Hotel on Central Park West at 61st Street had its ornate, 60-year-old facade stripped of every detail. The work sparked a storm of protest from architects and preservationist groups.
Less dramatic changes in old facades have been widespread. The New York Landmarks Conservancy, a preservation group, estimated that the cornices and balustrades were removed from 10 percent of the buildings covered by the law on the Upper West Side between 72d and 96th Streets.
Still, even critics of the law say facade stripping is less prevalent than some had feared it would be when the law was passed in 1980. In part, they say, the public outcry directed at the Mayflower and the work done on some other buildings earlier in the decade has had an influence. More importantly, experts say, nearly a decade of experience with the law has made architects, engineers and property owners more aware of the value of details on their facades, which sometimes may appear to be only ornamental but have an important role in keeping moisture away from windows or performing other structural functions.
''Even though we've lost a lot of cornices and ornamental work, I am glad the law is in place,'' said Laurie Beckelman, executive director of the Landmarks Conservancy. ''People are becoming much more informed about their facades.''
The most ambitious facade work required under the law is being performed by the city itself on the Municipal Building, a richly detailed 80-year-old structure across from City Hall in lower Manhattan. The mandatory 1987 inspection found severe rusting of the steel structural beams supporting the building's facade, chunks ready to fall from its cornices and other problems.
The building has been all but hidden behind a sheath of scaffolding since late 1988. Work on the facade, budgeted at $39 million, is not expected to be completed until 1992.
Experts say one of the problems of Local Law 10 is that it created a boom in demand for the services of architects, engineers, masons, bricklayers, terra cotta crafts people and others who specialize in facade work. One result is that it has attracted companies with little experience into the business.
The law also has forced property owners and cooperative boards to make difficult decisions about the work to be performed, often with conflicting advice from different specialists.
''It is like getting bad news from the doctor,'' said Stephen E. v. Gottlieb, an architect and professor of preservation at Columbia University. ''People want a second opinion.'' The second opinion sometimes does little good, he said, because architects and engineers often recommend more extensive repairs than are necessary and ''somebody who isn't sure what they are doing is going to write a report to cover themselves.''
One co-op that encountered many frustrations is 450 West End Avenue, at 82d Street, where a sidewalk bridge was removed late in 1988 after being up more than two years. ''This has been a horrendous experience,'' said Alice Belgray, president of the co-op's board.
She said most of the problems resulted from delays or mistakes by Summit Waterproofing & Restoration Corporation of Long Island City, Queens, which has done work on many Manhattan buildings. Mrs. Belgray said the company's workers applied mortar improperly between bricks and had to correct their mistake, clogged up drainage holes in the lintels above the building's windows and at one point forced a broomstick, which they were using to unclog a drain, through the ceiling of a lower-floor apartment.
''If this building had a personality, it would have been moaning and groaning and saying what are these people doing to me,'' Mrs. Belgray said.
BRUCE WEISINGER, vice president of Summit, who said the company had been waterproofing New York City buildings for 15 years, acknowledged that there had been heated disagreements at 450 West End Avenue. Nonetheless, he said the company had corrected all mistakes it had made at the building and in the process lost money.
''We lost our shirt on this building,'' he said, adding that ''the question shouldn't be whether a contractor is perfect - it should be whether he comes back and repairs his mistakes.''
Mr. Melvin, the architect, said disputes involving building owners, architects, engineers and contractors have been widespread, and might have been expected because so much work has been required by the law.
''We are talking about very technical work, cooperative boards that aren't sure what is really required, and a lot of contractors moving into the business without much background or depth,'' he said.
Nonetheless, city officials maintain that the disputes are part of a learning process that is creating safer and better preserved tall buildings across the city.
Although he said the problems created by proliferation of sidewalk bridges had not been anticipated, Mr. Smith said the principal intent of Local Law 10 - protecting pedestrians from hazardous facades - has been accomplished.
An analysis of inspections by his department found that in the second round of inspections, 557 buildings reported facade problems that posed an immediate hazard; of those, 446 have finished corrective work and are deemed safe and 111 are being worked on, with the Department of Buildings monitoring the work.
In all, the city has 8,000 buildings tall enough to be covered by the law, the Buildings Department said.
Mr. Smith said he expected the number of hazardous conditions to continue shrinking after the next round of inspections in 1992, and that the greater awareness of the city's facades would continue to inspire improvements that go beyond public safety.
''This law has brought attention to the fact that buildings, like infrastructure, deteriorate,'' he said, ''and we can't just pay attention to the inside.''

HEADLINE: THEATER;
'Stand-Up Tragedy'At Hartford Stage LBy ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
IN its pursuit of eclecticism, Hartford Stage has been a study in extremes of late. Having opened the season with ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' Oscar Wilde's perfectly escapist Victorian comedy of gentility and absurdity, the theater is now shaking up its subscribers with ''Stand-Up Tragedy,'' a tough and loud dose of contemporary urban reality, replete with street talk, rap music and break dancing.
Not only does the piece, which deals with inner-city education, represent a radical departure even for audiences accustomed to the theater's revisionist interpretations of classics and modern works with controversial themes, but it also marks the first time Hartford Stage is producing a play in association with another major regional playhouse: the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles. This year, ''Stand-Up Tragedy'' evolved from workshops in February to a small-scale production at the Taper's second theater, Taper Too, in March, to a main stage production that had its premiere in May. 
During rehearsals in Hartford, where ''Stand-Up Tragedy'' opened on Friday and is to run through Dec. 16, the playwright, Bill Cain, and the director, Ron Link, went on making revisions in script and production. Six of the 10 Hartford actors are holdovers from the California company. A different production of the play is slated for the Arena Stage in Washington this season.
''The Hartford creative staff is building on the work done in Los Angeles,'' said Howard Sherman, Hartford's publicity representative. The work had a fast progression: Mark Lamos, Hartford's artistic director, heard about it on a Public Radio feature one morning. ''After friends from L.A. told us it was the best thing they'd seen in years,'' Mr. Sherman said, ''Mark asked for a script. We were all enthusiastic over it and didn't want it to end there. We're giving it a new life.''
The setting for ''Stand-Up Tragegy'' is a nontraditional fictional school named Trinity. It is modeled on the Nativity Mission Center on Forsythe Street on Manhattan's Lower East Side, where 10 full-time teachers work with a total of 50 students - an extraordinary ratio - from grades 6 through 8. The school operates daily from 7:30 A.M. to 10 P.M. It is run, but not financed, by Jesuits.
''It depends on fund raising - and begging,'' explained the 40-year-old Mr. Cain, who taught there for four years, from 1984 to 1987. The play is drawn from the extensive notes he took during that period. ''I'm a diarist,'' he said.
''It is a school that works,'' said Mr. Cain, who was also the artistic director of the Boston Shakespeare Company for seven years. ''Everyone makes a massive commitment. The teachers also live on the top floor.''
Before a recent rehearsal, Mr. Cain and Mr. Link discussed the form, content and implications of ''Stand-Up Tragegy,'' which has been described as a rap drama. They explained that the plot concerns two Hispanic students, Lee Cortez, a withdrawn mystic, as the playwright calls him, and Henry Rodriguez, a down-to-earth go-getter. As a survival mechanism, Lee retreats from reality, creating a mythological universe that is headed by Saga, a super hero whose mission is to create family peace - only he loses all the battles. Other characters of the play include a Catholic priest and a dedicated teacher. Mr. Cain said: ''Henry's family sells 'controlled substances at inflated prices,' as the principal says, and he's a charmer and already an entrepreneur. He can make money, but how can you keep him engaged - and free him from economic pressures?
''He's a visionary, but he can't cut it academically. When he arrives at the school, he isn't just illiterate, he's averbal, which is not even measurable. The school system and the family have failed him; he needs a shot at life that's not dominated by drugs and money.
''But Lee has no interest in drugs or money or school, only in holding his violent family together, and trying to keep them from killing each other. That's killing him.''
Commenting on the play's structure, Mr. Cain said, ''It was originally subtitled 'It's Just Like Stand-Up Comedy, Only Inside Out.' I've used the techniques of modern comedians, but ultimately this is not a comic view of life.
''This may be a genre play about teachers and students but it's not 'The Corn Is Green,''' Mr. Cain said. ''The form is nonlinear. The rappers function as a sort of Greek chorus. Lee has a series of monologues during which he plays all the people at home and we hear the horrific sounds of a family in explosion. And sometimes we see a class lesson, a rap number, a fantasy sequence and a kid playing basketball -all overlapping.''
Mr. Cain went on: ''The tragedy is that we accept evil, in terms of our lives, and we must oppose that. The evil of an affluent society is parallel to the evil of the streets. It's as if we need people - throw-away people - to fail, and we choose to make them invisible.
''We live in a booby-trapped universe,'' he said, ''and I call that the ecology of evil. It's a balance we are choosing to live with by accepting a certain level of evil as normal, and one of the teachers in the play tries to upset that balance by taking a boy away from his family. But one teacher can't save one kid. It's more complicated than that.''
Mr. Link, whose career as a director began in the Off Off Broadway theater of the 1960's, said: ''I was drawn to the play's social concerns - and its epic structure. I know it's an overused word, but we're all interconnected in some strange way.
''We seem to be admitting, even celebrating, a problem,'' he said, like the disasters we see every day on television, cheerfully reported by newscasters, - and not thinking that it's our problem, too, because we're removed and we're home. The play questions and provokes and we want the audience to ask, 'What can I do? How can I intervene?' ''
Mr. Link went on: ''The people who come to the theater are already involved. They said, 'I don't want to veg out in the house,' but we have to get them there.''
The play's visual elements include a backdrop representing a medieval warrior in comic book style, a drawing of Jesus and a dragon and a splash of graffiti. ''Multiple images are constantly crossing over,'' Mr. Link said. ''It's cinematic. nd at Hartford's wraparound stage, it's very Cinemascope.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TITLE: IMPORTANCE OF BEING EARNEST, THE (PLAY)

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Parents Don't Really Care About Education

BYLINE: By Barry Edelson; Barry Edelson lives in Baldwin.

 BODY:
ON the eve of the President's recent education summit, my wife went to Back to School Night at the high school where she has taught English for more than 20 years. In this annual ritual, parents are invited to meet with their children's teachers.
If the President and our 50 governors really want to know what is wrong with education in America, they would have spent their time and our money far more wisely had they forgone the speechmaking and witnessed instead this very real exercise in frustration.
My wife is lucky. She teaches mostly honors classes of 10th and 12th graders, in which the students are generally motivated and have a responsible attitude about their schoolwork. She also has some average classes. By the second or third week of school, she can predict with uncanny precision how many parents will show up to learn about what their kids are learning. 
The 10th-grade honors classes draw the largest number of parents. By the time the top kids are seniors, however, parents no longer seem all that interested in the curriculum; fewer than one-third of them bothered to come this time.
The most telling, and most discouraging, turnout is among the parents of average and below-average students. In a junior satire class, for example, only two parents attended. This isn't likely to surprise anyone, but consider that when my wife went to her first Back to School Night a generation ago, there weren't enough chairs in some classrooms for all the parents. And in those days, she taught mostly average classes.
Sixty years ago, Alfred North Whitehead wrote these prophetic words about the English educational system: ''In the conditions of modern life the rule is absolute; the race which does not value trained intelligence is doomed.'' Unfortunately, the problem is that simple. The kids are merely bringing to the classroom the indifference, even hostility, to learning that is fostered at home, and in the society at large.
The Op-Ed pages and documentary television might lead us to believe that the leaders of government and industry are deeply concerned about public education. But all they really want is a labor force. If Asia and Europe weren't now commanding a sizable chunk of the world economy that the United States used to monopolize, few would care about the language and math skills of our workers, let alone what kind of citizens our schools are producing.
If you don't have daily contact with large numbers of high school students, you probably don't know that most of them on Long Island are already part of the labor force. Few of the students in my wife's school do notM have a job, even if they don't particularly need the money.
Mothers and fathers, virtually all of whom are working themselves, are more often than not pleased that they don't have to worry about where their children are and what they're doing. They also imagine that the kids are learning valuable lessons in responsibility and managing their money. They not only fail to voice their concern over these excessive work hours, they actually encourage it.
Ironically, the very business community that bemoans the diminishing skills of American workers is exploiting the labor of teen-agers who could be home studying. Typically, expediency wins out over long-term planning, and impressionable youth naturally follows the example set by its role models in the ''real'' world. For teachers, this growing trend in adolescent employment is a constant source of dismay and disgust.
What is a teacher supposed to do with an intelligent student who cuts class consistently, doesn't turn in assignments, works 40 hours per week, and whose parents, when called upon to straighten him out, actually fabricate excuses to cover for him? If disciplinary policies in a school district are weak, it is because the parents won't tolerate stricter rules to keep their kids on school grounds and force them either to attend class or fail. Many parents deem the school unreasonable if it detains a child and makes him late for his job.
Regrettably, I have become all too accustomed to hearing my wife on the telephone with parents, futilely attempting to alert them to their child's chronic absences or delinquent assignments. It is almost embarrassing to see how infrequently these calls make any difference.
If test scores are down, if the dropout rate soars, if America doesn't compete as well as it used to, it's easy to point a finger at rising taxes and complain about how little we're getting for our money. Statistics can prove anything. It's a lot harder to get your kids to study, especially when you and everybody else in the country are screaming the same hideous message from every television and radio and magazine: You don't really need school to get ahead.
The vast majority of teachers are prepared, informed and eager. But children cannot be molded like so much clay.
Like any other public institution, our system of education is a reflection of the society it serves. Whether we are able to make it better depends upon whether we have the courage to look long and hard at that ugly reflection without flinching.
The platitudes with which we were assaulted at the president's conference, if miraculously put into practice, would only exacerbate an already miserable situation. But if people already believe that teaching is mostly empty talk, they may be easily convinced that more empty talk will improve education.
That is why the President's conference is the best evidence yet that our nation as a whole truly doesn't care about education.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 1244 words

HEADLINE: Architecture View;
A Radical Idea: Baseball As It Used to Be

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
The Baltimore Orioles did not make it to the American League pennant last season, but they came close. If major league baseball offered awards for architecture, however, this team would win hands down. For the design for the Orioles' new 46,000-seat stadium in downtown Baltimore, which will begin contruction this spring and be finished in time for the 1992 season, is the best plan for a major-league baseball park inmore than a generation. If it is half as good as the models and renderings suggest, it will represent a return to baseball as it should be; a game played on grass, not turf; under the sky, not a dome; in the middle of a city, not out on an interstate highway. This is a building capable of wiping out in a single gesture 50 years of wretched stadium design, and of restoring the joyous possibility that a ball park might actually enhance the experience of watching the game of baseball. 
 The $75 million Baltimore stadium, to be built on the site of the old Camden rail yards at the edge of downtown, will have a structure of steel, not the concrete used in most stadiums of our age, and its facade will be a series of brick arches. It will thus look like a building from the outside, not like some vast feat of engineering. This radicaql idea - that a stadium should look like a building and not like a chunk of Boulder Dam - comes, of course, from the great ball parks that inspired this design, place like Fenway Park in Boston, the late Ebbets Field in Brooklyn, Tiger Stadium in Detroit and, most beloved of all,Wrigley Field in Chicago. There was always a special joy to approaching those building precisely because they did not reveal everything about what they were from the outside; the magical world within their gates always came as a tiny surprise.
 So, too, with the wonderful older stadiums and their neighborhoods interwove, the crowds swarming over the sidewalks, the buildings overlooking the field, the view from the upper decks accross a great swath of the city. There was always a certain eccentricity to them, determined in large part by the surrounding city; an odd street pattern could make for a short right field, simply because the land ran out on that side. Ball parks were not standardized like McDonald's or Holiday Inns; each one was a special place, with itw own special qualities.
 That is the goal at Baltimor: not a strained and self-conscious eccentricity, but just enough of a sens of the city to make it clear at every moment, from every seat, that you are under the sky of Baltimore and not inside some dome that is just like the one in Seattle or Minneapolis or Houston or New Orleans. There will be splendid views of the downtown skyline from the stadium, and the seats (modern armchairs, not old-fashioned stadium seats) will wrap around the playing field to assure greater intimacy and a tighter foul line.
 There is another special connection between the ball park and the architecture of the city here that is particularly enticing. The site is bordered on one side by a sumptious brick warehouse, eight stories high and as long as a train, that stands like a wall between this land and the rest of downtown. The warehouse is one of those noble and somber industrial buildins that once filled the downtowns of this country, and it would seem to have little to do with the goals of a modern ball park. But instead of tearing it down, the architects and planners, midful of both the importance of buildings like this to the urban fabric and the possibility that could enrich the design of the stadium, have decided to let it remain. The facade of the warehouse will preside over right field from a respectful distance, becoming as much a part of this ball park's identity as the stadium itself, and the interior will be converted into ancillary space for the stadium and new executive offices for the Orioles.
 Ther very phrase "urban fabric" would have been an anomaly in any discussion of stadiums until recently; urban fabric is for planners, historic preservationists and architects, and stadiums are for big business, politicians and sportsmen. The miracle here is how easily this contradiction has been proved false, and how naturally the goals of all sides have come together. This is a design that enriches baseball, the city and the region, all at once, and it makes every sprawling concrete dome sitting in a sea of parked cars look bloated, fat and tired.
 This new structure, which will replace Baltimore's Memorial Stadium, was designed by the sports facilities group of Hellmuth Obain & Kassabaum, with Joseph Spear in charge. Now, this is a huge national firm that has designed an ample share of the very concrete hulks this stadium has designed to get away from, and it is quite obvious that, skillful as the architects have been here, something else has must have been motivating them. That something else is the determination of the Orioles and the city of Baltimore to honor a set of values other than packing the most people into the bigges pile of concret in the middle of the biggest suburban parking lot. (That the Orioles are owned by Eli S. Jacobs, an investor with a longstanding amateur's interest in architecture, hasn't hurt: Mr. Jacobs has proved to be the rarest thing in professional sports, a client who knows something about urban design.)
 The stadium is being built by the Maryland Stadium Authority, which was created by the state legislature to improve Maryland's attractiveness to professional sports after the traumatic departure of the Baltimore Colts professional footbal team in 1984. The authority concluded that downtown Baltimore made sense as a site for this stadium, not only as a means of strenthening the city's economic base but also because urban stadiums are more accessible that suburban ones and, contrary to common wisdom, create fewer traffic tieups than their suburban counterparts. The Authority rejected the idea of a combined baseball and football stadium, realizing correctly that shared stadiums, like halls built to house symphonic concerts and opera, are compromises that fail to serve either tenant well.
 And thus came the idea of going back to baseball's essence, to its traditional urban ball parks, in search of design inspiration. In a sense, this project is the opposite of an exercise in sentimentality, for the real search here is not for the past but for a means of finding those fundamentals in the experiences of attending a sporting event that transcend time and place, and of connecting these thing to the realities of a particular site in the city of Baltimore.
 The ideas underlying this project are not, in the end. so revolutionary. Thinking about buildings as sensuous presences - in terms of how they feel - rather than as purely efficient, functional ones has been more and more the common wisdom in the last decade, as had the whole idea of thinking of the city as a complex set of interconnecting elements, and of realizing that no building, no matter how big or how important, can be thought of in isolation.
 What is revolutionary is letting these ideas set the tone for the design of a sports stadium. Even in Toronto, as enlightened a city as there is in urban planning, the new stadium is a concrete whale. Baltimore is not the first city to understand the virtues of urban design - but it is the first one to prove that they need not be incompatible with the pleasures of professional sports.

PUB-DATE: November 19, 1989

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 16, Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1425 words

HEADLINE: For Cost-Wary Businesses: Leased Help

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
THREE years ago, when Brian O'Loughlin started an asbestos-removal company, only two people were on the payroll. But business was so brisk that in two years' time the company - New England Asbestos Control of Brewster - had grown to 10 times its original size in sales volume, and last year, Mr. O'Loughlin said, the company doubled in size again.
''We have 15 employees,'' he said, ''and of course I was glad to see the company growing, but I found I had to spend much more time taking care of paperwork. It took my wife at least 10, 15 hours at night at home a week working on the payroll, and we were also falling behind in our Workmen's Compensation payments, which is a big bill in this industry. We pay $15 for every $100 of salary a person, compared to 35 cents for the same coverage for a secretary.'' The cost for employee health benefits was also steep, Mr. O'Loughlin noted.
 
Time Was Misdirected
''I was spending more time comparing insurance premiums than I was thinking about the business.'' 
Mr. O'Loughlin said he was about to hire an office manager, though the company could not really afford one, when a friend told him about employee leasing.
''It sounded interesting so I got in touch with the International Charter Group in Rye. They market an employee-leasing company called United Staffing Corporation. And they showed me how I could get rid of the hassle of the payroll and get improved health benefits as well, by leasing. They figured how to take out Workmen's Compensation every week so we never got hit with a big bill, and they also set up a wraparound medical plan that gave us better benefits and cost $80 less a month per employee..''
 
A Growing Industry
Employee leasing is an industry that has grown dramatically over the last few years. The industry trade group, the National Staff Leasing Association, based in Encino, Calif., estimates that there are 450,000 leased employees nationwide, 100,000 more than last year. A report by the United States Small Business Administration described leasing as a significant innovation. It said employee leasing enabled ''small businesses to compete more successfully with large companies in the labor market by improving the employee benefits of small companies and reducing small business payroll-related burdens.''
While employee leasing may sound like temporary employment, leased employees are actually permanent full-time workers.
''The way employee leasing works is that a firm discharges all its employees, including the executives, and they're immediately hired by a leasing company like ours and leased back to the employer,'' explained Cleve Lynn, vice president of the Eastern region of International Charter Group, the marketing arm of United Staffing Corporation of America, which has headquarters in Perryburg, Ohio.
Employees do the same jobs and receive the same salaries as before, yet they are almost always better off under the leasing arrangement, Mr. Lynn said.
''It's the economy of scale,'' he said. ''Leasing companies such as ours have a larger number of employees than any single company. When a small company is able to offer the same benefits to employees as a large company, it gains a powerful recruiting and retention tool. It levels the playing field.''
 
Health Benefits Can Improve
Leased employees get better health benefits because the leasing company has such a huge payroll that it earns maximum discounts from benefits providers, Mr. Lynn said. ''We can also offer employee credit unions, employee discounts, 401K and flex-benefit plans - all services that are out of the reach of small companies with a dozen or so employees.''
Technology also helps leasing companies reduce costs. Sophisticated payroll automation becomes cost-efficient when a leasing company employs thousands of people.
Employee leasing companies earn their money by charging a management fee.
''Our major market is the small business,'' Mr. Lynn said. ''They benefit the most. Our management fee is 3 to 9 percent, based on the total payroll, but even when that is added in, the company usually saves money.''
 
It's Not for Everyone
But the employee leasing arrangement does not work well in every state, Mr. Lynn said. In Connecticut, for example, he said, a state service tax of 8 percent eliminates much if not all of the saving that companies New York-based companies realize.
''A Connecticut company with a weekly payroll of $100,000 would have to pay a tax of $8,000 a week. The tax might actually be more than our fee, which makes it unfeasible, although we do have a few Connecticut clients.''
Mr. Lynn, who opened the Rye office of the International Charter Group in July 1988, said he considers employee leasing his second career. He spent 30 years with United Airlines, becoming controller of United's eastern division in charge of financial operations at 50 airports.
''When United closed its Eastern division I didn't want to accept a transfer,'' he said. ''The employee-leasing industry is a really exciting one. It's where the temporary industry was 40 years ago, and its growth rate is phenomenal. By the year 2000, predictions are there will be 10 million employees leased in the United States.''
 
'Figured Out Everything'
Mr. O'Loughlin of New England Asbestos Control said: ''Employee leasing has put us on an even financial keel. The leasing company has figured out everything. All we do is fax the number of each employee's hours to headquarters. We have no paperwork and no paperwork costs. They not only issue the paychecks, they pay all taxes, insurance and health premiums and handle all employee-benefit claims. I've been free to take care of the asbestos removal business.''
While the trend in small companies is to rent employees, the trend in larger ones is to rent executives on a temporary basis. According to national labor statistics, temporary professionals make up the fastest-growing segment of the temporary employment market.
''There have been so many mergers and acquisitions that a lot of high-quality talent is available,'' explained Roger J. Preis, executive vice president of the Accountemps division of the employment agency, Robert Half of Westchester, based in White Plains.
''There's so much movement among corporations that clients have become applicants and applicants have become clients,'' Mr. Preis said. 
 
Temporary by Choice
While some of the professional temps are executives between jobs, others work on short-term assignments out of choice.
''They prize their independence,'' Mr. Preis said.''Many travel part of the year, and others like to winter in Florida.''
Professional temporaries, who earn $25 to $100 an hour, are usually brought in by companies for a particular project or assignment. There are firms that supply engineers, lawyers, accountants and general managers.
''Occasionally we get a call for a chief operating officer,'' Mr. Preis said, ''as was the case recently when a company moving to New Mexico from Westchester needed a chief executive officer to run the company in the county for six to eight weeks while the move was taking place.''
 
Helping in an Emergency
Professional temporary workers also fill important positions in emergencies.
For example, the assistant treasurer of a Fortune 300 mining company, who chose not to leave his home in Westchester when the company moved its headquarters from Manhattan to Phoenix, is now serving as temporary controller of one of the largest building materials companies in the nation.
The controller, who asked not to be named, said he was called in in June when the company's full-time controller suddenly left on medical leave.
''I'm looking for a permanent job and I find temporary assignments are a very good way to test the waters,'' he said. ''I'm managing the company's cash and all its bank relations on this assignment, and I'm enjoying it very much. I'm even helping them do the interviewing for someone to take the job permanently.''
When asked why he did not take the job himself, he said: ''Well, for the long term, I feel I have more skills than I'm currently using. And I also have a financial-consulting business, which I started in September 1987, just before Black October, so I wasn't able to gain a foothold. But I have some clients I'd like to expand that business to.''
The chief drawback of being a full-time professional executive temporary worker, he said, is lack of benefits. ''Unless you have a mate with good benefits, it's difficult.''

SECTION: Section 12CN; Page 3, Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1501 words

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT Q&A: JULIE D. BELAGA;
'Pollution Knows No Political Boundaries'

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
JULIE D. BELAGA of Westport, a Republican who lost her bid for governor in 1986, has been appointed Region 1 administrator for the United States Environmental Protection Agency, the Government's top environmental post in New England with a staff of 575 people and offices in Boston.
The office has an annual budget of $365 million to enforce the Clean Air and Clean Water Acts and supervise sewer repair and Superfund cleanup programs in the six New England states.
Mrs. Belaga, who is 59 years old, grew up in Boston, graduated from Syracuse University, and settled in Connecticut in 1965. She represented Westport in the State House of Representatives from 1976 to 1986, and was involved in issues of coastal protection, transportation of hazardous waste and solid-waste mangement. After her unsuccessful gubernatorial campaign, she worked as a commentator for WTNH-TV in New Haven and as an instructor at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard. Her new job will pay $78,600 a year. 
In an interview at her home, Mrs. Belaga talked about environmental issues but stressed that she was basing her remarks on her experience in the Connecticut legislature, since until her appointment is confirmed, probably early next year,she said she could not speak for the Environmental Protection Agency. Here are some excerpts from the conversation:
Q. Acid rain and low-level ozone are two problems Connecticut has but blames on the coal-burning plants of the Midwest and the industrial emissions of the New York metropolitan area. Should the E.P.A. be taking more of a regional perspective, rather than requiring cleanup state by state?
A. Frankly, one of the things I look forward to is meeting the other regional administrators, particularly from our neighboring regions. Pollution knows no political boundaries. And it's the same for clean water.
Cleaning up Long Island Sound is a major initiative, and it's something I've cared about since 1975 when Gov. Ella Grasso appointed me to a coastal area management task force.
You look at what's happening in Long Island Sound, and a lot of it is stuff coming down from the Connecticut River, and not all of that is from Connecticut. It's a very large regional issue. There are some close ties to our neighbors and some tough questions to address.
I can remember going to a legislative conference for the Northeast and wondering how anybody could not be tuned into acid rain, and then I met people from Pennsylvania who were coal miners and who have a lot of jobs at stake, and you begin to see the dynamics of some of these very difficult issues.
Q. For companies that say they cannot afford the best pollution control, should economics play a role in environmental issues?
A. I think what we need to do, as we move forward now that the public is with us, is to work cooperatively with business, to explain to them how they can meet these standards. I don't think we are really well served by a confrontational mode, and that's never been my style. I really believe in conciliation, and the only way we're ever going to make inroads on environmental issues is to make the environmental community and businesses friends and not enemies.
That doesn't mean I don't support tough enforcement, because that sends a message that we're serious about this, that there is a law and if you don't comply with that law, we're going to hold you accountable. But a lot of businesses get a bad rap because of one or two that are really grossly violating, and many businesses want to be good environmentally; they want to be good neighbors. I think they need to know there is an open door, that we look forward to working with them.
Q. Are people too concerned about environmental issues?
A. No, I don't think anyone is. But I can't tell you how wonderful it is that the public cares, because for a long time they didn't. In 1986 when I ran for governor I did a poll, and only 4 percent of the people in Connecticut cared about the environment. I was told, ''Julie, don't talk about those issues if nobody cares.'' Recently, there was a poll done and it ranked crime, drugs and the environment as the top problems.
This is a prime time to be an environmentalist, because the public cares. They're aware. They're willing to support an environmental initiative. It's a whole new mood now. There's a whole sense out there that ''Hey, let's do it.''
Q. A lot of business owners say that more harm is done to the environment by homeowners' dumping of paints and thinners into sewer systems or automobile drain oil into storm drains than by industrial effluents. How serious is that dumping?
A. I don't think it's ever a valid argument that ''I should be able to get away with it because someone else is getting away with it, too.'' I do think we can beef up and expand our program of household hazardous waste disposal. Nobody knew that stuff was dangerous. Everybody's going to have to pitch in, to play a role, but the thing is, now people care.
One of the things I did on television a couple of months ago was a piece on disposable diapers. I can remember when they were invented, and they were a nice little convenience. Now, we have this enormous problem in our landfills. A lot of young people were not aware of the long-term implications of filling our landfills with them. And a lot of them are rethinking the situation.
Q. With landfills filling up all over the country, why didn't the Federal Government take more of an initiative on recycling and source reduction?
A. I think you're going to see that. A very vital component of all our environmental concerns is going to have to be prevention. It's a lot cheaper to prevent it in the first place than to clean it up after it happens.
Q. In the 1960's everyone was convinced that landfills were the way to go. Now, we find that that contaminates ground water. Can environmental protection be effective when we know so little about the environment?
A. That's the nature of science. We're always trying to find some better way to skin that cat. Yes, we are going to find a downside, but because you make a goof, you don't just stop. What's fun about public policy is that it's a living, breathing thing, and it changes and you have to change along with it and learn with it.
I met with a woman in Washington last week who said environmental issues are becoming so complex and so technical and so highly refined that it's becoming more and more difficult to get people to work in the field for what the Government is willing to pay. There are a lot of talented people working in Boston who don't get a lot of satisfaction salary-wise, but they are dedicated, talented environmentalists.
That's going to be part of my challenge, to make sure those people feel good about what they do.
Q. A lot of attention has been paid recently to radon. As many as 10 percent of houses in some Connecticut towns have a problem. Is this something the E.P.A. should be taking the lead on?
A. That's a problem people have not been tuned into heavily. It is an enormous problem, a very high health risk, but it has been an invisible issue. What you will certainly see coming out of the E.P.A. is education of the public of how they can deal with this question and how they should protect themselves.
The numbers of people exposed to it are far larger than we expected. We now have a whole new problem. When I was at the legislature no one even knew about it.
Q. At a regional level, is there anything we can be doing about global problems like the greenhouse effect and the thinning of the ozone layer?
A. I am assuming there will be some interesting give and take between the environmentalists and the administrator in Washington and his counterparts internationally. Candidly, my role is going to be more regional, and I only look to have some input, through my conversations with the administrator as these national decisions are made.
Q What in your experience prepared you for this job?
A. I think the reason I was tapped as a viable candidate was because I have a unique array of experiences. My legislative involvement in environmental issues is right at the top of the list, but also simply understanding the process, understanding how government functions at the state level and, going back a few years, at the local level, has helped. More and more Federal initiatives are being implemented at the state and local level.
Q. What does this job mean in terms of your future in Connecticut politics?
A. Connecticut sure hasn't lost me. There is no way I would leave Connecticut. I will be commuting. I have family who live in Boston, so I will live with my family during the week and come back to Connecticut on weekends. But I would venture to say that it's highly unlikely I would ever run for office again.
This job is so tailor-made for my particular interests, but it is a very controversial seat to sit in. It tends not to be a stepping stone for political office.

GRAPHIC: Photo of Julie D. Belaga (NYT/Susan Harris)

HEADLINE: FAITHFUL TO HIS CLASS

BYLINE: By HUGH BROGAN; Hugh Brogan is the author of ''The Life of Arthur Ransome'' and ''The Longman History of the United States of America.''

 BODY:

HENRY ADAMS
By Ernest Samuels.
504 pp. Illustrated. Cambridge, Mass.:
The Belknap Press/Harvard University Press. $25.
Ernest Samuels' newly finished task was doubly unenviable. It must have been difficult enough to write the life of America's most famous autobiographer - to set up in competition with his subject, so to speak. But Mr. Samuels was also competing with himself. He is already the author of a three-volume, authoritative life of Henry Adams; it was completed in 1964 and won a Pulitzer Prize. This new book is a one-volume revision and abridgement. It is a complete success. Nowhere does it seem compressed or unintelligible (except where the fault is Adams's) or skimpy. Rather it seems both economical - not a word wasted - and ample - all relevant topics are thoroughly explored. It seems to be just the right length for its subject. In all, ''Henry Adams'' is a remarkable feat of the biographer's art. 
All the same, it is impossible not to dwell on the fact that a fine biography has been reduced by something like two-thirds. The necessary inference is that Henry Adams's standing is not as secure today as it was a generation ago, and after reading Mr. Samuels' new treatment, it is impossible not to see why. In 1989 Adams seems an unsympathetic character, less because of his numerous personal failings than because of the society, and class of society, to which he belonged.
Adams (1838-1918) was intolerably conscious of his privilege and burden in having been born into the United States' most distinguished political family and into the elite of Boston, for whom no other groups elsewhere in the world - not Virginians, not Europeans and certainly not New Yorkers - were quite dutiful and earnest and civilized enough; but what leaps to the eye nowadays is that this rich and cultivated gentleman never seems to have felt that he owed his fellow men any service. He lived across Lafayette Square from the White House for 40 years or so, sneering at every President in turn, dabbling in a little political intrigue when he could and coddling his sensibilities. He felt no call to carry on the work of the abolitionists, who had inspired his father's generation to heroism; he found the titanic energies that were going into building modern America vulgar and the era's politics merely corrupt. He was the embodiment of mugwumpery in an era when, as Theodore Roosevelt saw, mugwumps were little more than frivolous, indolent rentiers. Henry Adams came to disapprove of Roosevelt deeply.
Mr. Samuels, the Franklyn Bliss Snyder Professor of English, emeritus, at Northwestern University, is a biographer who sets nothing down in malice, but he also extenuates nothing; so he calmly makes it plain that Adams was a snob, was eaten up by egoism, was self-righteous and uncharitable and intellectually perverse and (what I found hardest to bear - no doubt Mr. Samuels did, too) was insistently anti-Semitic. Inevitably (for he visited France every year) he became an anti-Dreyfusard, but of greater historical interest is the fact that his anti-Semitism was wound about with a hatred for Wall Street and a belief in bimetallism, a monetary system based on silver as well as gold.
This son of Beacon Hill was enslaved to the same nexus of notions that characterized much of Midwest Populism. He was entitled to loathe the new America that was rising all about him, but he made no serious attempt to understand it, and that, in a professional historian and would-be prophet, is unforgivable. Instead he immersed himself in all the worst fallacies of positivism (he was much influenced by Auguste Comte and Herbert Spencer in his youth) and tried to reduce history to the manipulation of statistics. He also tried to apply the second law of thermodynamics (that the entropy of an isolated system must increase) to human affairs, without apparently ever being sure whether he was using it as a suggestive metaphor or as a serious analytical tool. He soon submerged himself and his readers in a sea of confusion. Even his biographer is at last driven to plead for a little intelligibility and to comment that ''in spite of the prodigious effort of thought Adams still could not . . . either state his problem or wholly know what he himself meant.'' To the outsider it is all too clear what he meant: he wanted to prove that America was certain to go to hell because it would no longer consent to be ruled by the Adams family.
''What was the matter with Henry Adams?'' someone once asked Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. ''He wanted it handed to him on a silver platter,'' was the answer. Holmes had a right to such a view: he too was born into the Bostonian aristocracy, but he did not let himself be paralyzed by his silver spoon. He earned his fame by doing his country the distinguished service (in Holmes's case, on the United States Supreme Court) which Adams was too neurotic to attempt, and we can still turn to his reflections on American law and politics with profit. He was not a little man. That Adams was by comparison personally insignificant is no new discovery, but in the end it must be admitted that no one has ever cared, for he was also a writer of outstanding gifts. ''The Education of Henry Adams'' is not a wise book, and its last chapters are stunningly tedious; but the first 20 chapters, in spite of a certain affectation, still captivate readers by their wit and honesty. ''Mont-Saint-Michel and Chartres'' is a book that no lover of France will leave unread. Historians and those who seriously enjoy history cannot fail to be pleased by the great work on the Administrations of Jefferson and Madison, and the political novel ''Democracy'' remains wonderfully amusing. All in all, the oeuvre is impressive, and its continuing vitality demonstrates the needlessness of biography, at least when the subject has led so quiet a life as Henry Adams did (his wife's suicide was just about the only thing that ever happened to him). Nevertheless I am glad that this brilliant, crotchety man has got a biography, and gladder still that it was written by Ernest Samuels.
 
THE BRAHMIN AS CRITIC
 Adams indulged his passion for stylistic criticism even in his private reading, and a burning trickle of comment would often run down the margin of the book. In Edmund Burke's Abridgement of English History, for example, he jotted down such editorial memoranda as: ''Strange assertion for a contemporary of Gibbon''; . . . ''This is very droll''; ''Curious want of critical capacity''; ''This is bad grammar, bad style, and bad sense''; and much more of the same, as if in imagination he were revising the text before him. To incite himself to a better performance he once proposed to young [Henry Cabot] Lodge that each write a review of Hermann von Holst's History. . . . ''I think it will give us both a spurt of emulation, so that we will do the most perfect work we can.'' Rigorous towards himself, Adams was equally rigorous towards others. . . . Lodge tells us . . . ''I rewrote [my first article] eight times before it passed muster.''
 
From ''Henry Adams.''

SECTION: Section 7; Page 11, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 653 words

HEADLINE: HE GIVES ENTHUSIASM A GOOD NAME

BYLINE: By EDWARD HOWER; Edward Hower, the author of ''The New Life Hotel'' and ''Wolf Tickets,'' is completing another novel.

 BODY:

THE PLEASURES OF THE PAST
By David Cannadine.
Illustrated. 338 pp. New York:
W. W. Norton & Company. $19.95.
One of the delights of the long literary review is having someone else read a book for us, so if it's an important but, well, somewhat inaccessible work, we can be informed about it without actually having to slog through the thing ourselves. And when a reviewer like David Cannadine knows just how to get to the heart of the book and reveal it to us with wit and eloquence - then a good overview can be a real treat in its own right. 
Such is ''The Pleasures of the Past,'' a collection of reviews of works on British history, most of which originally appeared in The New York Review of Books and The London Review of Books between 1981 and 1987. Reading Mr. Cannadine's reports of what scholars have said about England's past is like taking an eclectic survey course given by a professor who enjoys dazzling us with his enthusiasms for ideas and personalities. One week it's urban planning and architecture, the next it's economic history, followed by socialist interpretations of the lives of workers and criminals. We learn more than we imagined could be said in a short period about the changing nature of time. We hear about a variety of approaches to understanding the Industrial Revolution, the welfare state and the sex lives of the Victorian bourgeoisie, who ''cultivated their passions, like their gardens, behind high walls.'' The professor (Mr. Cannadine, who is British, does in fact teach history at Columbia University) especially likes biographies: assorted royals, prime ministers and other political figures are exhumed, examined, sometimes dropped back into their resting places with a thud, sometimes released to the company of angels - and are always presented in fresh historical perspectives.
Throughout his survey, Mr. Cannadine's own ideas always seem as interesting as those of the authors he reviews, often more so. This is the reason we read reviews of books that are no longer new - to enjoy the reviewer's individual perspective on their contents.
We also can't help admiring the elegant language with which this writer expresses his ideas. Mr. Cannadine is the master of sweeping, opinionated summaries. The British intelligence service, he tells us, ''seems not so much invincible and impregnable as incompetent and incontinent: a secret service which leaks its own secrets.'' Queen Victoria, he says, was considered by historians ''regina intacta'' until a new biography revealed her to be ''callous, insensitive, obstinate, outspoken, capricious and bigoted.'' And Britain's Victorian landed gentry, the object of so much nostalgia nowadays, were, he reminds us, the sort of people who ''favoured the death penalty for poaching.''
Mr. Cannadine reviews academics as well as their books, revealing the ways in which they have changed their approaches to history as they compete for eminence: ''The solitary scholar-gladiator of old, replete with lance and trident, was replaced by a new model army of research assistants, computer experts and applied economists who, under the guidance of a lab-coated field marshal, launched massive bombardments with all the scholarly firepower (and some of the strategic futility) of a Somme offensive.''
''A reviewer's job is to raise plausible doubts,'' he quotes one of the authors he reviews, and Mr. Cannadine soundly thrashes authors whose scholarship is lazy or whose prose is ''orotund to the point of flatulence.'' But he is full of enthusiasm for writers whose work is insightful and original. ''The Population History of England'' (not exactly bedside reading, though fascinating when sampled) is praised as ''a work of remarkable virtuosity, combining the panoptic vision of the parachutist with the meticulous scholarship of the truffle hunter.'' The same might be said for ''The Pleasures of the Past.''

LENGTH: 1156 words

HEADLINE: Japan, Weary of Barbs on Trade, Tells Americans Why They Trail

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 19

 BODY:
In one of the most sweeping critiques of the United States ever offered by an ally, Japan is telling the Bush Administration that it ought to upgrade schools, invest in scientific research, close the Federal deficit and take other drastic steps to improve American industrial competitiveness.
Japan's critique was presented in negotiations this fall as a reply to Washington's insistence that Japan open up its economy to more foreign imports and investment. The goal of the talks is to reduce the persistent trade imbalance aggravating relations between the world's two largest economies.
Japanese officials say their criticisms of the United States reflect Tokyo's view that American economic problems are rooted in years of mismanagement of the nation's industrial and educational systems. 
Under the negotiating ground rules, the specific arguments submitted by Japan have not been made public. But in interviews, Japanese officials disclosed details because, they said, the publicity surrounding the discussions has until now focused mostly on American criticism of Japan.
 
'Japan Alone' Cannot Close Gap
''If the United States wants Japan to change its system, the United States must be more ready to correct its own shortcomings,'' said a Japanese official involved in recent talks with Washington. ''We can't solve our trade imbalances looking at Japan alone.''
The Japanese critique will come as no surprise to Americans, since its basic elements have been debated throughout American industry, academic institutions and government. Nor is this topic new in Japan: Deficiencies of the American system have been discussed for years by Japanese officials, businessmen and scholars.
What is new is that for the first time, the informal Japanese suggestions have become the foundation of official Japanese policy, representing a consensus among the three most powerful ministries in the Japanese Government - the Foreign Ministry, the Finance Ministry and the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. And the decision to make its views public is a further indication of Japan's increasing assertiveness on foreign policy after decades of postwar timidity.
 
More Saving, More Investment
Japanese officials said their critique, presented to American negotiators in written form in September in Washington and amplified orally early this month in Tokyo, makes these seven principal recommendations:
* The United States should reduce its Federal deficit and increase the overall American savings rate.
* American businesses should invest more in plant and equipment.
* American businesses should abandon the ''short-termist'' mentality of showing more interest in quarterly profits than longterm investment.
* Federal regulations inhibiting exports, such as the ban on exporting oil from Alaska, should be dropped.
* The United States should increase Government incentives for corporations, allowing them to collaborate or undertake independent research and development.
* Washington must subsidize and encourage exports, perhaps by setting up an export committee headed by the President.
* American business and government must vastly increase their support of education and training; the $30 billion spent each year by American businesses on worker training has failed.
 
On Math and Science
In the education sphere, Japan is calling for American high schools and colleges to upgrade the teaching of mathematics, science and foreign languages to make American industry more competitive.
It is also urging that American businesses improve their education and ''practical training'' programs for workers.
Japanese officials have requested an outline of the concrete actions being contemplated as a result of President Bush's recent ''education summit'' with the nation's governors. The request appears to indicate skepticism that the Administration will back up its verbal support of education with large amounts of money.
Several other issues place Japan even more explicitly at odds with the Bush Administration. For instance, Japanese officials are questioning the wisdom of President Bush's proposal to cut the capital gains tax. Instead, Japan suggests a gasoline tax to close the Federal deficit, which Mr. Bush opposes.
 
U.S. Makes No Promises
Bush Administration officials say the Japanese criticisms come as no surprise, since Japan was in effect asked during the recent negotiations to present a list of particulars on what the United States might do to improve its trade position.
But American officials refuse to comment on the Japanese specifics, saying only that they will be studied. Some American officials endorse a number of Japanese proposals, such as the need to improve private and corporate savings to provide the capital for future investment.
''I would like to have the U.S. savings rate increased, and I have been saying that for a long time,'' Carla A. Hills, the special United States Trade Representative, said in Tokyo last week.
Other officials say Washington will have to respond positively to at least some of the suggestions if it expects Tokyo to accede to American demands for more open markets in Japan.
But even if American officials agree with the Japanese suggestions, some of them might be extremely difficult to follow since they would involve changing practices that have become standard for American corporations. For example, Tokyo is criticizing the high salaries paid to executives and the focus on short-term profits, which are deemed necessary to fend off takeovers but have led busineses to curtail investment and modernization.
 
Antitrust Laws Criticized
Japan asserts that costly corporate takeovers financed by mountains of debt have wiped out the resources needed to develop new products.
The Japanese Government also wants the United States to ease anti-monopoly laws so that American businesses can pool their resources for research and development, with government assistance as a catalyst. This has been the development strategy followed by Japan since the 1960's.
American corporations have made tentative steps in this direction, notably in the development of high-definition television and in advanced semiconductors. But this argument comes at a time when many in the Bush Administration are resisting the notion of Federal guidance for corporate activities of any kind.
The United States trade deficit with Japan has remained at about $50 billion a year despite American trade retaliation on specific products, threats of retaliation on others, and the drastic decline in the dollar's value since 1985.
For its part, the United States is asking Japan to streamline its multi-layered wholesale and retail distribution systems, and to curtail the influence of its huge business cartels, industrial combines and monopolies, which Washington says have led to the highest domestic consumer prices in the world.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 1102 words

HEADLINE: U.S. IS CONSIDERING SHARP REDUCTIONS IN EUROPEAN FORCE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the Bush Administration is discussing proposals for troop reductions in Europe that would go well beyond the cuts now being negotiated in Vienna by NATO and the Warsaw Pact.
Administration officials who spoke on condition of anonymity said planning for more substantial troop cuts was preliminary. But one senior Administration official said the conceptual outlines for additional cuts in American and Soviet forces in Europe could be presented to the Soviet Union as soon as early December, when President Bush meets President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union.
The Administration has not yet agreed on a proposal for further troop cuts, but several officials interviewed today said their deliberations were being driven by the pressure to reduce the Pentagon's budget and by the pace of reforms in Eastern Europe. 
 
Soviets Are Slowing Spending
The Bush Administration's discussion of deeper troop cuts comes as American analysts have concluded that Mr. Gorbachev is beginning to carry out his pledge to slow overall Soviet military spending.
Mr. Cheney, appearing the ABC News program ''This Week,'' said the likelihood of a conflict between the United States and Soviet Union was ''at its lowest point since World War II.''
Mr. Cheney said he hoped the current talks, called Conventional Forces in Europe, or C.F.E., could be completed next year. ''There are now discussions about C.F.E. II, about what comes after this first round of negotiations.''
''Given the changes today that we see in Eastern Europe,'' he said, ''I think it's possible to contemplate the possibility over the next few years that we may indeed be able to reduce the level of our deployments in Western Europe.''
 
Possibly in Current Talks
And another senior Administration official said the White House has not excluded the possiblity of seeking greater troop cuts in the current Vienna talks, rather than in a subsequent round of negotiations.
Under the Western proposal now being discussed, the United States would make small reductions in its troops in Europe while Moscow would make massive cuts.
Mr. Bush proposed in May that the United States reduce Army and Air Force troop levels in Europe to 275,000 from 305,000, or about 10 percent. Under Mr. Bush's proposal, the Soviet Union would cut its force of about 600,000 troops to the same ceiling of 275,000, a cut of about 54 percent.
The Congressional Budget Office has estimated that the current Western proposal would provide savings of only about $2 billion, and some analysts believe the savings could be even less. Mr. Cheney has directed the military services to identify $180 billion in possible budget reductions in the years 1992 through 1994.
 
Greater Cuts Were Considered
Bush Administration officials had previously considered far greater troop cuts than those proposed by the President at the May NATO summit meeting. But the Joint Chiefs of Staff rejected the proposal, which called for a reduction of 75,000 troops in Europe, because they said it undercut NATO's strategy for defending Western Europe against the combined forces of the Soviet Union, East Germany, Poland, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Bulgaria.
As a result, the Administration scaled back its proposed cut to 30,000 Army and Air Force troops.
But since then, political reform in Eastern Europe and growing pressure on the Pentagon budget have reopened the issue of further troop cuts proposals.
''There are those who think it makes sense to do more; that is where the money is,'' said a senior official today, who noted that this was not a unanimously held view.
Another senior official said: ''There is a growing recognition that C.F.E. I is not the end of the ball game, that if you want to achieve major savings you have to think beyond.'' This official said any new proposal should be presented after the current treaty is completed.
While some officials have expressed the hope that money could be saved through conventional arms control agreements, Mr. Cheney said further, painful cuts would be inevitable.
''We are going to have to make some cuts, some reductions in force structure, close some bases, terminate some weapons systems,'' Mr. Cheney said.
He said the cuts would have a detrimental economic effect on some areas and would draw protests from some members of Congress. ''It will mean, without question, some unemployment, and it means there will be great consternation on Capitol Hill because some of the things that will be cut members of Congress are very fond of,'' he said.
Mr. Cheney also indicated that the Pentagon was rethinking the costly program to build the B-2 Stealth bomber, which costs more than $500 million a plane. While saying the plane was needed, he added, ''How many we buy and at what rate we buy them is an open question.'' The Pentagon had said previously that it wanted to buy 132 B-2 bombers.
Mr. Cheney also suggested for the first time that the Pentagon might try to save money by ordering fewer than the 132 B-2 Stealth bombers it had previously said were necessary. He said the planes were needed, but added: ''How many we buy and at what rate we buy them is an open question.''
Mr. Cheney met at the Pentagon with Gen. Colin L. Powell, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to review proposals by the military services for cutting $180 billion from the budget from 1992-94.
 
No Decisions on Trims Yet
Mr. Cheney said today that no decision on how much to cut or which systems to cancel or reduce has yet been made. He added that he had directed the services to propose cuts after determining that the Pentagon would receive significantly less money in the future than had been previously planned.
''If you look at a realistic set of assumptions about how much money we're going to have,'' Mr. Cheney said today, ''then it leads you to the conclusion that we're going to have to spend significantly less than is currently programmed.''
A Pentagon official said today that planning is also going ahead for spending proposals for the 1991 budget and that Richard G. Darman, the Budget Director, wants the Pentagon to come up with 4.5 percent reduction, a total of $20 billion. That is a deeper cut than the Defense Department would like to make for that year, though Mr. Cheney is resigned to a reduction in spending for that year, once inflation has been taken into account, Pentagon officials said.
Meanwhile, the House today approved and sent to the White House $286 billion military spending bill for the 1990 fiscal year that began Oct. 1.

HEADLINE: Corrections

 BODY:

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Correction
