HEADLINE: Bush Vetoes Bill Including Aid to East Europe

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
President Bush tonight vetoed a $14.6 billion foreign aid bill that includes money for the new programs just approved by Congress to assist development of free-market economies in Poland and Hungary.
''I do not take this action lightly,'' Mr. Bush told Congress in his veto message, citing ''serious problems'' on constitutional issues and objections to a provision that would allocate $15 million for the United Nations Population Fund as his reasons for sending the bill back to Congress.
The United Nations agency does work in China, and abortion foes have opposed its financing on the grounds that China's population control programs include coerced abortion and sterilization. 
Douglas Johnson, legislative director of the National Right to Life Committee, applauded the veto, saying, ''President Bush has sent a loud message to all population control organizations: If you trample on human rights by supporting compulsory abortion programs, you'll get no help from the U.S. Government.'' The House immediately laid plans for a vote on Monday to attempt to override the veto, but it is unclear whether members can muster the required two-thirds majority.
Mr. Bush is expected to sign the separate legislation that establishes three-year economic aid programs for Poland and Hungary. But none of the money envisioned by that legislation can actually get to Eastern Europe unless the foreign aid bill, which includes the actual spending allocations for the current fiscal year, is approved by Congress and signed into law by Mr. Bush.
The foreign aid bill allocates $492 million to help promote democracy and encourage private enterprise in Poland. About $80 million is allocated for similar purposes in Hungary.
Mr. Bush and Congress have been at odds for weeks over language in the bill that prohibits use of foreign aid money for ''futhering any military or foreign policy activity that is contrary to United States law.'' The language also prohibits the use of foreign aid money to solicit foreign governments or their agents for money to carry out activities contrary to United States law.
The prohibitions are outgrowths of the Iran-contra affair, in which the Administration attempted to evade Congressional restrictions on military aid for the Nicaraguan rebels. But Mr. Bush and his legal advisers have argued that the language sought by Congress would tie the President's hands in conducting foreign policy.
The provisions, Mr. Bush said in his veto message, ''interfere with my authority to conduct the foreign relations of the United States.'' Both Democratic and Republican lawmakers have challenged Mr. Bush's interpretation and have waged a bitter behind-the-scenes battle with White House lawyers.
Lawmakers have also argued that Mr. Bush's objections to the United Nations funding are groundless because the foreign aid bill requires the population agency to separate United States contributions from those of other countries and specifically forbids use of any American money for programs in China.
Delay in approval of the foreign aid bill also ties up money for Israel and Egypt as well as a host of other nations, including those where the United States is attempting to renegotiate military base rights.

HEADLINE: China Irate at Congress Sanctions

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 19

 BODY:
China expressed ''utmost indignation'' today at a Congressional package of sanctions approved last week to protest the crackdown on the democracy movement.
''History has testified to the fact that no economic sanctions can crush the Chinese people,'' the New China News Agency quoted a Foreign Ministry official as saying in a meeting with Ambassador James R. Lilley. ''On the contrary, such practice will only have the United States eat its own bitter fruit and see its own interests harmed.''
The American legislation imposes two years of sanctions, including a suspension of trade assistance and an end to insurance for American companies doing business in China. It also freezes exports of satellites, controlled munitions like helicopters and certain nuclear material and components.
The bill condemns what it calls the ''unprovoked, brutal and indiscriminate assault'' on the protesters and unarmed civilians, which it said left 700 dead. China has said 300 people died, but Western intelligence estimates put the number as high as 3,000.
The bill is part of a wide-ranging measure that authorizes funds for the State Department. President Bush has accepted the idea of sanctions, but his advisers say they will urge a veto of the package because of a provision unrelated to China.
The official Chinese protest was read on national television. No reason was given for the Congressional sanctions.
The agency also paraphrased Deputy Foreign Minister Liu Huaqiu as saying: ''Since the Chinese Government put down the counterrevolutionary rebellion in accordance with the Chinese Constitution and laws, the U.S. Congress has meddled in China's internal affairs and stirred up an anti-China wave by adopting one resolution after another on this matter, which is purely the internal affairs of China.''

HEADLINE: Clamor in the East;
A Hungarian Gambles And Reclaims a Legacy

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, Nov. 19

 BODY:
From Budapest to Trieste to New York and Chicago, to Milan, Florence and finally back to Budapest, Peter Zwack's life has reflected the twists and turns, the ups and downs, the dreams and nightmares, of his native land.
Mr. Zwack is a distiller, like his great-grandfather, grandfather and father before him. He gives his age as 55, but his wife, Anne, says that he lies about it. A slight man with sharp features, he has managed to reclaim his 200-year-old family business here in Hungary from the Communists who seized it without compensation four decades ago in the turbulent aftermath of war. 
Nobody else has done anything like that, as far as anyone knows.
Peter Zwack sometimes seems utterly at sea in the modern world. Last summer, for instance, picking up some friends from the Budapest airport, he loaded them into his Alfa-Romeo, pressed what he took for the air-conditioning control and then, with a Magyar curse, hit the brakes as the trunk lid popped up instead.
And yet he is steely enough to have survived, indeed thrived, for 40 years as an exile. He is bold and imaginative enough to have gambled, when the winds of change now blowing through Eastern Europe were the merest zephyr, on the ability of a capitalist emigre to come home at last and do business with the Communists he hated.
 
A Role Model for Hungarians
So far, it has worked, and he has become a role model and a teacher for many in this country. Stand with him on a downtown sidewalk, and people he has never met will greet him, having seen him on television talking about the ways in which Hungary must change in coming years.
''People like you make the world a better place to live,'' a seemingly serious man told him the other day, much to his embarrassment.
Mr. Zwack guesses he gets that sort of reaction ''because people think I showed faith in Hungary when not too many others did,'' and because ''they had been fed this picture of a fat capitalist who smoked cigars and beat up the workers, and they saw me, a skinny guy who doesn't smoke, wears beat-up clothes and behaves more like the workers than the Communist bosses did.''
At first, his outspokenness got him in trouble. In an interview with a West German magazine, Mr. Zwack called the people who ran Hungary's economy ''bandits,'' and the workers' militia in his plant, the same one his father rebuilt after it was bombed in World War II, said they could not cooperate with him.
 
Outsmarting the 'Bandits'
But the workers' militias are going out of business, not Peter Zwack, and more ''bandits'' are losing their jobs every day.
As the country moves, seemingly inexorably, toward a market economy, the Zwack plant in Budapest is once again producing the authentic version of Unicum, a biting digestive liqueur distilled from herbs. Before too long it will also be making the rich fruit brandies and cordials on which Zwack & Company's reputation was built in the United States after World War I. Mr. Zwack paid $500,000 a few months ago for his 25 percent share of the company, and his Western partners, the German distilling company Unterberg, did the same thing. The Hungarian Government owns 46 percent, and a bank and an export company in Budapest each have 2 percent.
For the first time since 1948, new equipment is going into the distillery, and new export deals are being negotiated - including one with a big Japanese trading company, whose interest was piqued when both its president and a leading Japanese actress, here on visits, tasted Unicum and fell in love with the inky liqueur.
 
A Penniless Emigre in '48
Peter Zwack crossed the Yugoslav border in 1948, alone and broke, shortly before his father, Janos, was smuggled out of Budapest into Vienna on a Soviet truck whose driver had been bribed. The younger Zwack had to borrow change to phone a friend of his father's, a banker from Trieste, Italy, but father and son soon met in New York.
After an abortive first job selling vacuum cleaners in Queens (he couldn't get the appliances to work when he tried to demonstrate them), the younger Zwack went to work in the liquor trade, first in New York and later in Chicago, winding up as the manager of a wine-importing firm, marrying an American, fathering ''thoroughly American kids'' and gaining his naturalization papers.
In 1970 Mr. Zwack headed back to Europe. His father and uncle were making Unicum - the real thing - in Milan while the Hungarian plant was making something similar, based on a phony formula his uncle Bela had given to the new Communist management. Peter Zwack joined them, restarted brandy production in Vienna and eventually took over. While in Milan, he met and married Anne Marshall, an Englishwoman who writes on food and travel, mainly for American publications.
After a time, the Zwacks found themselves in Florence, living in the stables of a Renaissance villa overlooking the city. Then one day a call came from an old Hungarian friend who was visiting Budapest, reporting that Sandor Demian, the country's top marketing expert, wanted to talk to Mr. Zwack about coming back.
 
A Well-Timed Return
Talk the two men did, and in June 1988 the Zwack family headed north, supposedly for a year - parents, two children (Sandor, then 14, and Pinky, then 12), two cars, two birds, a horse, dogs and a guinea pig.
Why did they go? ''I'm Hungarian, first, and second, my father always wanted to get the company back, so I did, too, and third, I saw that I could make a profit - maybe.''
The timing could not have been more propitious. Mr. Zwack quickly made friends with fledgling politicians and businessmen and journalists as the country relearned the skills of a pluralistic society.
He resumed playing tennis with his old doubles partner from the junior national team of long ago. And the family found an apartment, modest but handsome, only three doors from the grand old Zwack house on Uri Utca, a street of Baroque splendor on Budapest's lovely Castle Hill.
''It's unbelievable,'' says this man who has lived several lives in one. ''Preposterous. Wonderful.''

HEADLINE: Indictment Clouds Deal That Saved a Steel Plant

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala, Nov. 17

 BODY:
What was once the South's biggest steel city has been shaken by Federal indictments charging that the USX Corporation secretly awarded fat pensions to union negotiators in exchange for the ground-breaking labor concessions that saved its steel works here in 1983.
The settlement, under which the union agreed to a host of job cuts, set a pattern for retrenchment in the steel industry at a time when foreign imports were squeezing American steel makers, scores of plants were idled and the union was scrambling to save members' jobs. In court depositions, the company was later to say that the agreement had saved it $24 million a year.
Now there is a sense of betrayal in the rank and file, though the United Steelworkers of America and many members stand behind the indicted union officials. As workers finished their shift at the huge Fairfield Works here on Friday, many said, ''We have been sold out.'' 
 
Not Guilty, Defendants Say
Both the company, through a spokesman, and the two union officials, through their lawyers, say they will plead not guilty to the charges, which were handed up on Wednesday. The Government says that the company illegally tried to influence the union officials by offering them pension benefits for which they were ineligible and that the officials illegally sought and accepted the benefits for themselves and five other union officials. And it says top company officials ordered their pension fund employees not to disclose the pension arrangement to anyone, in violation of Federal laws governing private pension funds.
The indicted negotiators are Thermon Phillips, 61 years old, the union's district director for several Southern states and a member of its international executive board, and E. B. Rich, 59, a subdistrict director for the union. The indictment also named but did not charge three former USX officials who were said to have helped arrange the deal. They were James Bruce Johnston, then executive vice president for employee relations; William Miller, vice president for labor relations, and James D. Short, vice president for benefits.
Frank W. Donaldson, the United States Attorney for the Northern District of Alabama, said the two union officials could face up to 65 years in prison and fines of $3.2 million. The company faces fines of up to $6.6 million, he said. Mr. Donaldson said that the investigation was continuing and that there could be further indictments.
 
Union Defends Its Officials
The United Steelworkers of America, which has long been criticized by many members for agreeing to the concessions, says Mr. Phillips and Mr. Rich deserve praise, not indictment, for saving the jobs of union members. ''If there was a bribe, as the U.S. Attorney alleges,'' said the union in a statement from its headquarters in Pittsburgh, ''why do they indict the Birmingham union officials and allow the high-level corporate headquarters officials directly involved in the alleged payment to escape prosecution?''
William E. Keslar, a USX spokesman, said the company cooperated in the grand jury investigations and was ''extremely disappointed'' in the indictment. He added that the charges appeared to result from a ''strained interpretation'' of the events of 1983.
Those events marked a watershed in the steel industry, then under siege from economic recession and foreign competition. In Birmingham, the Fairfield Works had been closed since June 1982, its 3,500 workers laid off. The company had invested money in a mill to produce pipe for the oil industry, but declining oil production called that into question as well. In 1981 the company reported that Fairfield was losing more than $150 million a year and was a strong candidate for permanent closing.
But the day before Christmas 1983, as the company was preparing to announce layoffs and closings at plants around the country, the negotiating team headed by Mr. Phillips granted a host of concessions: job cuts, new manning arrangements, elimination of some incentives and the dropping of all pending grievances, among other things. In return, the company reopened a scaled-down Fairfield plant with about 2,000 employees and salvaged the pensions of 1,500 others.
In his recent book ''And the Wolf Finally Came: The Decline of the American Steel Industry'' (University of Pittsburgh Press), John P. Hoerr writes that the Fairfield agreement set a pattern for the industry in labor relations and new concessions by other local unions around the country. And a union official here, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said:
''It clearly saved the Fairfield plant, and it was a model in that other locals began to wake up to the need to negotiate such things as manning. It was the first time that the company had achieved a major breakthrough in negotiations with the union on manning levels.'' He emphasized, however, that such concessions varied widely from one local to another.
 
Dissension in the Rank and File
Many in the industry and the national union were unhappy with the agreement at the time, and there were allegations of collusion in the negotiations. A rank-and-file group in Birmingham sought to overturn the agreement, saying it was illegal and damaging to members' interests; its suit is still pending. And union officers who got wind of the pension arrangements went to court, seeking benefits similar to those granted Mr. Phillips and the others. Their lawsuits were dismissed.
Mr. Donaldson, the United States Attorney, said in an interview that the Government's case against what he called a conspiracy between the company and the two officials began with information from an informer. He would not give details of the investigation, but court papers in the pending civil suit and the decision to dismiss another give some insight into the 1983 negotiations.
In depositions, company officials admit that Mr. Phillips, Mr. Rich and five other union officials began getting pension benefits three months to a year after the Fairfield agreement. Those pension payments, negotiated separately from the labor agreement that kept the plant open, were a result of a policy change by the company to ''foster and promote the good will of former employees'' who became bargaining agents for the union.
The policy change altered the amount of time that national union officials could take leaves of absence from the company and maintain pension benefits. In 1984, USX specified in a policy memorandum and a letter to the president of the steelworkers' union, Lynn Williams, that the change would apply only to officials with bargaining responsibilities who had left the company for their union posts before 1978.
 
'Secret Negotiations'
But nearly three years later the company ended the policy, noting that some recent court decisions indicated it might be illegal. At that time it denied all pending requests for such pensions, but did not rescind those already granted. Court papers say Mr. Phillips, who received $55,319 between November 1984 and May 1988, Mr. Rich, who received $48,318, and the other five Birmingham officials were among those who kept their pension benefits. The pending suit says that the payments resulted from ''secret negotiations'' and that rank-and-file members did not learn of them until last year.
Plaintiffs in that suit say that for months their fellow workers criticized them for bringing the lawsuit, fearing that it could lead to the closing of the plant. But Lorenzo East, who has worked at the plant for 38 years, said that since the indictments, ''some of them are getting on the bandwagon because they see that the leadership is just taking our union dues and laughing at us.'' The union officials, he added, ''have sold us out and taken away what our daddies and granddaddies fought for.''
Other steelworkers do not believe the charges. Leaders of the city's locals say the indictments are political, the work of a conservative Republican Justice Department bent on undermining the labor movement.
But Barry Nichols, who has worked at Fairfield for 20 years, said most workers were cheered to see that USX was indicted as well.
''Most people have felt that the company was so rich they were above the law,'' he said. ''But this indictment gives them some hope and faith in the law.''
Not everyone is optimistic. Al La Pierre, executive director of the state Democratic Party, recalled a time when both the company and the union ''ruled this area.''
But he added that both have fallen on hard times since the 1970's, and he said of the indictment, ''This has hurt them more, I think.''

HEADLINE: Budget Crisis Dominates Race in Massachusetts

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
A wide-open race for Governor is getting under way this month under some of the most unusual circumstances in memory. For the first time in 30 years, the incumbent is not seeking another term.
Indeed Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, who lost the Presidential election last year, has fallen so far from public favor that other Democrats are scrambling to stay as far away as possible from him.
But while the state is struggling with one of the worst budget crises on record as the regional economy slows, Republicans, who might otherwise be gloating over the opportunity to recapture the office, are having trouble getting their candidates to toe the party line on issues like abortion.
''We are in a unique situation,'' said Kevin B. Harrington, a former president of the State Senate, as a Democrat, and who now runs a political consulting and lobbying firm here. ''There won't be that many people voting for X, Y or Z on the Republican side. They'll be voting against the Democratic Party.'' 
 
Focus on Abortion and Economy
The election is a year away, but the major issues seem to be abortion and the economy. The most pressing for the 2.9 million voters, leaders of both parties say, is how to heal the ailing economy that only last year was being admired as the Massachusetts miracle.
On Tuesday, Governor Dukakis said in a speech that the miracle was no more. On Wednesday, Moody's Investors Service lowered the state's bond rating again, leaving it tied with Louisiana for the lowest. At least two economists have said the state is suffering a recession. Largely a result of declining revenues, the budget deficit has reached $1.2 billion for the current fiscal year, which ends next June.
''A year ago, the Democrats' greatest suit was that the so-called Massachusetts Miracle appeared to have reached its height under Democratic tutelage,'' said Paul Watanabe, the chairman of the political science department at the University of Massachusetts in Boston. ''Now that is perceived as their greatest burden.''
United States Representative Chester G. Atkins, the state chairman of the Democratic Party, said: ''The continuing deterioration of the state's fiscal situation has hurt all incumbents. I think the Democrats in the Legislature have now arrested that slide, and are doing a very difficult chore, trying to assess what the core functions of government are and what levels they need to be supported at and how to finance that.''
There are protests daily on Beacon Hill, where the Governor and the Legislature are trying to overcome the deficit with spending cuts and new tax proposals. The protesters say essential services like housing and human services were severely harmed by the first round of cuts in July when the deficit was $500 million. At a protest earlier this week, one man waved a placard that labeled the state ''Axachusetts.''
Jim Braude, the executive director of a lobbying group called Tax Equity Alliance for Massachusetts, said no candidate had offered voters real solutions to the crisis. ''Each is moving at breakneck speed toward a poorly defined middle,'' he said. ''What the people believe is that no one tells them the truth.''
The abortion issue has become a difficult one for the Republican Party. The front-runner for the party's nomination, William Weld, the former United States Assistant Attorney General, has declared that he favors abortion rights. The party's other candidate, Steven Pierce, the minority leader in the State House of Representatives, is an opponent of abortion rights.
''I don't think it will be a governing factor in the election,'' said Ray Shamie, the party's state chairman. ''On most issues, the party is fairly well united. We're toe-to-toe on defense and economic issues, but there is some diversity on social issues.''
Others disagree. ''A pro-choice position is the one that is most politically successful here,'' Dr. Watanabe said. ''This is a state in which a strong anti-abortion stance is a political liability.'' The wrong position on abortion, political analysts say, could cost a candidate either the party's nomination or the general election.
Otherwise, many consider that the 1990 election will give Republicans their best opportunity in many years. The last Republican Governor, Francis Sargent, was unseated by Mr. Dukakis in 1974.
The Democrats' first choices for Governor are not even announced candidates. A poll of 600 Democrats, published last week by The Boston Globe, ranked former United States Senator Paul Tsongas, who quit the Senate in 1984 when he was diagnosed as having lymphatic cancer, and Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d at the top of the list.
Mr. Tsongas said in July that he would not run, but he told The Boston Globe last week that he was reconsidering and would make a decision by January. Now a lawyer in private practice and the chairman of the State Board of Regents of Higher Education, he did not return telephone calls seeking comment from him this week. But several Democratic Party insiders said privately that they believed he was serious about running. Mr. Tsongas's health situation was unclear but would be a factor in his decision, analysts said.
 
Beacon Hill Is a Target
Chuck McDermott, the chief of staff for Representative Kennedy, said: ''Joe sees the governor's office as a very important job and one that could greatly affect the lives of hundreds of thousands of people in Massachusetts, but at this time, he is committed to what he's doing in Congress and trying to resolve some family issues.'' Mr. Kennedy and his wife separated last year.
Any candidate who is perceived as outside the present Beacon Hill circle would not be as easy a target of blame for the state's fiscal difficulties, analysts said. One declared candidate, Lieut. Gov. Evelyn F. Murphy, already appears to have been politically damaged by her association with Mr. Dukakis, with The Boston Globe's poll finding her popularity had dropped by 9 percentage points since July.
''If the election were held next Tuesday, goodbye any Democratic nominee, in my opinion,'' Mr. Harrington said. Others consider the Republican Party hampered by the lack of a strong statewide field organization and the Democrats' firm majority. ''In a state with two viable parties, I would say the Democrats would be in terrible shape,'' Mr. Corgan said. By CONSTANCE L. On Tuesday, Governor Dukakis said in a speech that the miracle was no more. On Wednesday, Moody's Investors Service lowered the state's bond rating again, leaving it tied with Louisiana for the lowest. At least two economists have said the state is suffering a recession. Largely a result of declining revenues, the budget deficit has reached $1.2 billion for the current fiscal year, which ends next June.
''A year ago, the Democrats' greatest suit was that the so-called Massachusetts Miracle appeared to have reached its height under Democratic tutelage,'' said Paul Watanabe, the chairman of the political science department at the University of Massachusetts in Boston. ''Now that is perceived as their greatest burden.''
United States Representative Chester G. Atkins, the state chairman of the Democratic Party, said: ''The continuing deterioration of the state's fiscal situation has hurt all incumbents. I think the Democrats in the Legislature have now arrested that slide, and are doing a very difficult chore, trying to assess what the core functions of government are and what levels they need to be supported at and how to finance that.''
There are protests daily on Beacon Hill, where the Governor and the Legislature are trying to overcome the deficit with spending cuts and new tax proposals. The protesters say essential services like housing and human services were severely harmed by the first round of cuts in July when the deficit was $500 million. At a protest earlier this week, one man waved a placard that labeled the state ''Axachusetts.''
Jim Braude, the executive director of a lobbying group called Tax Equity Alliance for Massachusetts, said no candidate had offered voters real solutions to the crisis. ''Each is moving at breakneck speed toward a poorly defined middle,'' he said. ''What the people believe is that no one tells them the truth.''
The abortion issue has become a difficult one for the Republican Party. The front-runner for the party's nomination, William Weld, the former United States Assistant Attorney General, has declared that he favors abortion rights. The party's other candidate, Steven Pierce, the minority leader in the State House of Representatives, is an opponent of abortion rights.
''I don't think it will be a governing factor in the election,'' said Ray Shamie, the party's state chairman. ''On most issues, the party is fairly well united. We're toe-to-toe on defense and economic issues, but there is some diversity on social issues.''
Others disagree. ''A pro-choice position is the one that is most politically successful here,'' Dr. Watanabe said. ''This is a state in which a strong anti-abortion stance is a political liability.'' The wrong position on abortion, political analysts say, could cost a candidate either the party's nomination or the general election.
Otherwise, many consider that the 1990 election will give Republicans their best opportunity in many years. The last Republican Governor, Francis Sargent, was unseated by Mr. Dukakis in 1974.
The Democrats' first choices for Governor are not even announced candidates. A poll of 600 Democrats, published last week by The Boston Globe, ranked former United States Senator Paul Tsongas, who quit the Senate in 1984 when he was diagnosed as having lymphatic cancer, and Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d at the top of the list.
Mr. Tsongas said in July that he would not run, but he told The Boston Globe last week that he was reconsidering and would make a decision by January. Now a lawyer in private practice and the chairman of the State Board of Regents of Higher Education, he did not return telephone calls seeking comment from him this week. But several Democratic Party insiders said privately that they believed he was serious about running.
 
Beacon Hill Is a Target
Chuck McDermott, the chief of staff for Representative Kennedy, said: ''Joe sees the governor's office as a very important job and one that could greatly affect the lives of hundreds of thousands of people in Massachusetts, but at this time, he is committed to what he's doing in Congress and trying to resolve some family issues.'' Mr. Kennedy and his wife separated last year.
Any candidate who is perceived as outside the present Beacon Hill circle would not be as easy a target of blame for the state's fiscal difficulties, analysts said. One declared candidate, Lieut. Gov. Evelyn F. Murphy, already appears to have been politically damaged by her association with Mr. Dukakis, with The Boston Globe's poll finding her popularity had dropped by 9 percentage points since July.
''If the election were held next Tuesday, goodbye any Democratic nominee, in my opinion,'' Mr. Harrington said. Others consider the Republican Party hampered by the lack of a strong statewide field organization and the Democrats' firm majority. ''In a state with two viable parties, I would say the Democrats would be in terrible shape,'' Mr. Corgan said.

HEADLINE: Yes, Toughen Ethics. But Not Quite Yet.

 BODY:
A new, tough code of ethics is causing turmoil in the Koch administration's waning days. Some New York City workers worry that the new rules, scheduled to go into effect Jan. 1, will prevent them from getting decent jobs in the private sector if they wait around to find out if Mayor-elect Dinkins wants to retain them.
Mr. Koch and Mr. Dinkins, worried about a mass exodus, want the City Council to delay implementation of the new rules for six months. That's too long, but a three-month delay would make sense. 
A change in the City Charter, approved last year and effective Jan. 1, builds on current ethics rules by imposing new limits on the work city officials may do once they leave government. The idea is to prevent former officials from later working on projects they dealt with in government.
The new code would permanently bar former public servants who worked closely with an applicant on a ''particular matter'' from appearing before a city agency on that same matter on behalf of that same applicant. The current rule includes a similar ban, but it is for three years rather than permanent, and doesn't refer to a ''particular matter.''
Supporters of the new version claim it is clearer than the old one, not necessarily stricter, but few people in and around City Hall see it that way. They're concerned that the new provision will be interpreted so broadly that they'll be unemployable. Their fears have hardly been eased by Mayor Koch's failure to appoint the new Conflict of Interest Board until last month - eight months late. Board members have yet to issue any interpretive guidelines or rulings. Delay would give them a chance to do so, and give city agency employees a better idea of where they stand.
Opponents of delay argue that postponement confirms unfounded fears that the rules are unfair and overly restrictive. In fact, they are fair and reasonable. And Mr. Dinkins, dogged by questions about his personal finances, must let the city work force know that he embraces regulations intended to improve government.
Arguments against delay have merit but don't outweigh the practical problems. Employees and their agencies are entitled to a clear understanding of the ethics code, and Mr. Dinkins is entitled to an orderly transition.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
The Hypersonic Plane

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
With a minimum of controversy and a major commitment of money, America has once again tossed its cap over the wall of space.
This time, we are embarked on the development of a 4,000-mile-an-hour National Aerospace Plane (NASP) that will zip past the French-British Concorde the way a souped-up Corvette passes an antique tin lizzie.
If all goes well with our X-30, we will enter the new millennium with a made-in-America aircraft capable of taking off from any major airport, zooming out into space and re-entering the atmosphere to land at any other airport in less than three hours.
This will not solve the world's transportation problems: it will take longer to drive downtown from Tokyo's Narita airport than it will take to fly from New York to Tokyo. 
But the National Aerospace Plane (the infelicitous acronym suggests a NASP in our bosom, and this is hardly the snake that killed Cleopatra) will thrust the United States into the lead in aerospace technology and give our economic competitiveness a much-needed boost.
The commitment of R.&D. money to this project is a fait accompli: although the Senate originally voted no funds for the spaceplane, the House aggressively adopted it in the President's defense budget request, and senators Friday night ratified a conference agreement to spend a quarter of a billion dollars in the next fiscal year to get NASP research off the ground.
How come this went through without a lot of hollering? Where were the old opponents of the SST, the anti-defense denigrators of Star Wars, the free-market stalwarts who want private enterprise to finance its own future?
Knee-jerk objections were finessed because a sound idea was presented on grounds that raise the fewest red flags.
The old debate about the supersonic transport centered on national pride versus commercial feasibility; our SST was turned down because it was felt, rightly, that it just wasn't the taxpayer's job to keep America's passenger aircraft the world's fastest.
The nation's aerospace plane, which leapfrogs the SST, was not sold strictly on economic competitiveness, although there was an underlying warning that ''if we don't do this, we'll be buying tickets on the Japanese plane.''
The taxpayer investment could not be justified on the basis of helping American industry alone; this Administration resists massive aid to television technology, semiconductors and robots for fear of weakening the lure to private capital. The combination of budget restraint and capitalist philosophy usually overcomes the force of nationalism.
In this case, the defense dollars had to be justified on defense grounds: in an era of arms control, sudden surveillance is needed for verification; in an otherwise pushbutton missile age, a recallable retaliation craft and a swift interceptor is a safety catch; as the threat of subpower terrorism increases, we should be able to knock down missiles from space, though this does not pretend to be a substitute for a space shield.
But the national defense steak has little sizzle; as a new weapon alone, NASP would never fly. What puts this across is a bid to regain space leadership: as a taxi for humans visiting space stations and satellites, as a test vehicle for research on new materials.
An array of former astronauts, gathered by the Rockwell Foundation's Gilbert Robinson, pressed the need for such a craft as a stimulus for NASA research. It's going to be fueled, for example, by hydrogen slush. (You never heard of hydrogen slush? Best slush around.) The competitive commerce point is thus a kind of fillip, an added advantage: a U.S. spaceplane, built by American technicians and workers, will shrink the planet to less than three hours between any points. That affects balance of payments, careers, and an intangible we call the national spirit.
The skillful orchestration of good arguments - defense, space, commerce - defanged the opposition, disarmed the skinflints, walled this off from more vulnerable defense research investments, and built support for a dream that was written off only last summer as impossible to sell to Congress.
The man who made it all happen, who got down there in that hydrogen slush and rescued the spaceplane from oblivion, is the chairman of the National Space Council.
He is Dan Quayle, the Underestimated Man. When he made speeches about a Bush commitment to space research, the Vice President was derided for not accompanying rhetoric with a willingness to do budget battle.
Despite defense cutting, the new dollars are there; the designers are working; watch that space.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Subway Service: Is It Any Better? Or Worth More?

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
A year ago, the Transit Authority revamped schedules and opened new stations in what it touted as the greatest number of service improvements since New York City's subway system opened in 1904.
Now, with the likelihood that the $1 fare will - by being raised - be reduced to a historical footnote, too, subway and bus riders are entitled to ask whether they are better off today than they were a year ago.
Statistically, while last year's promise was vastly overstated, service for many riders, though not all, appears to have improved.
''What we find is very mixed results,'' said Gene Russianoff, whose Straphangers Campaign plans to release its periodic survey of subway service tomorrow. ''They trumpeted improvement over all for the system, and that's true. But because of the homeless, crime and lack of reliability, it is still the city's most underutilized capital asset.'' 
Since 1984, average weekday ridership has grown modestly by 7 percent, surpassing 3.7 million last year for the first time since 1974. But this year, ridership has been flat, which officials say is largely because of the cooling local economy. A fare increase is likely to drive away riders.
Bus ridership has declined steadily. But other numbers point toward some light at the end of the tunnel:
* The mean distance between subway car mechanical failures soared from 8,479 miles in 1984 to 18,654 last year and 24,083 this year.
* The percentage of cars purchased or overhauled since 1984 climbed to 93.5 percent this year, from 88.6 percent last year, on the IRT division and to 64.1 percent, from 37.5 percent, on the IND and BMT divisions.
* The percentage of trains completing their runs within five minutes of schedule inched up to 82.6 in 1989, from 81.4 in 1988, during the evening rush hours and to 85.2 percent, from 79.8 percent, in the morning rush.
Even the troubled R line may be rallying. Before last December's revision of routes and schedules, the R's 400,000 daily riders faced a 24-hour on-time performance rate of 59 percent. By last summer, it had plunged to 48 percent. But last month, officials said, the rate had increased to 80 percent. The Straphangers Campaign found that while the percentage of late trains last summer declined modestly compared to 1988, morning rush-hour delays on Brooklyn-bound trains then still averaged close to 20 minutes.
Transit officials attribute delays on R and N trains to repairs on two East River tunnels, which are to be completed late next year, and to work trains that clog the route. Millard Seay, the authority's senior director of schedules, said that timetables were revised to better reflect actual running time and that additional trains were placed in service. Nonetheless, he acknowledged, the regular six-minute gap between Queens-bound trains during rush hour can easily double.
No wonder the prospect of a fare increase puts many riders in a purple rage.
New York's $1 fare is generally not comparable with rates in most other major cities, where fares often vary by zone and fees are imposed for transfers. The basic subway fare ranges from 75 cents in Boston to $1.25 in Philadelphia.
In New York, the fare was 5 cents until 1948, when it was doubled to a dime. It rose to 15 cents in 1953, 20 cents in 1966, 30 cents in 1970, 35 cents in 1972, 50 cents in 1975, 60 cents in 1980, 75 cents in 1981, 90 cents in 1984 and $1 in 1986. At that rate, coupled with the Transit Authority's projected deficit, an increase is overdue.
On Friday, the authority's president, David L. Gunn, cautioned that paying a $1.15 fare, one increase proposed, could require an unwieldy six coins on a bus. To ease congestion, he proposed a 25-cent increase. To cushion the impact, packs of 18 tokens would be sold for $20, reducing the rate to $1.11 for those who could afford to buy in bulk. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will decide in December.
Do mass-transit improvements justify a fare increase, let alone last year's immodest comparison to the greatness of 1904? ''It wasn't my slogan,'' Mr. Gunn said. But he does consider the subway system cleaner and more reliable. ''I've never had anyone write and say, 'Sock it to me and raise the fare,' '' he said, ''but you're certainly getting more value now.''
Not that a fare increase will be based on the extent to which rider satisfaction is expressed at public hearings next week. Whatever the overall statistics show, individuals will have to decide for themselves whether a subway ride is safe, reliable and convenient enough to be worth $1.11 or $1.15 or $1.25. And then they must ask themselves, compared to what?

LENGTH: 1169 words

HEADLINE: States Turn to Business To Help Build Highways

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LEESBURG, Va.

 BODY:
Strapped and hoping to build a road from here to Dulles International Airport, Virginia decided to revive a Colonial-era solution: Let private business build the road and profit from the tolls.
Ralph L. Stanley took the offer. ''I love a traffic jam; they're all customers to me,'' said Mr. Stanley, president of the Toll Road Corporation of Virginia. He headed the Federal Urban Mass Transportation Administration in the Reagan Administration. 
His Leesburg-Dulles Airport toll road would be the first privately owned toll road built for the public in this country since the late 1800's, when most major roads were privately built.
Transportation experts say a 1987 Virginia law that encourages private ownership of toll projects may serve as a national model: Most states are hard up for money to build or repair their roads, bridges and tunnels.
 
Activity in Other States
California is trying the idea, A law passed last year encourages companies to propose four private toll roads, bridges or tunnels. Other states, including Pennsylvania and Illinois, are considering similar legislation or proposals. One private toll bridge has been built this year, linking Moorehead, Minn., and Fargo, N.D.
Private toll roads are a seductive concept. Private industry raises the money, takes the risk, and can complete the road sooner than most public agencies, which must follow time-consuming rules for competitive bidding.
After a company has earned a profit from the road, the state takes possession and can drop the tolls. The average motorist might never know the road was privately owned. It would be built to Federal standards and would be patrolled and maintained by state agencies under contract with the private owners.
There appears to be no alternative, some transportation officials say.
''With the unwillingness of the politicians to raise taxes and of the people to pay higher taxes, the alternatives are to build no highways or seek other sources of revenue,'' said Carl B. Williams, an assistant director of the California Department of Transportation.
 
Construction vs. Traffic
That department is soliciting proposals for private financing of toll projects, and 350 companies have shown interest. If this program is successful, Mr. Williams said, the state would probably encourage companies to build a ''substantial'' portion of all its new bridges, highways and tunnels.
The states need new and improved roads, but construction has not kept pace with automobile traffic, mostly because taxes linked to highway improvement have not kept up with the cost of improvements, Federal officials say. Most Federal and state highway money is from gas taxes, but tax revenue has risen only gradually as cars became more fuel-efficient.
The American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials estimates that states should be spending a total of $80 billion a year to maintain existing roads and another $21 billion a year to build new ones. But, the association said, the states are only spending $66 billion a year.
''This nation has been unintentionally disinvesting in its surface transportation infrastructure since the 1960's,'' the organization said in a report in October.
 
Roads Virginia Can't Afford
Virginia plans to spend $10 billion on highways in the next decade, but by its own estimates it needs to build an additional $5 billion in roads it cannot afford. Pennsylvania, which temporarily ruined its credit in building highways in the inflationary 1970's, likes the idea of private developers taking the risk. Illinois may not be able to build a 450-mile toll road from Chicago to Kansas City unless private businesses participate. There are also strong opponents. The consumer advocate Ralph Nader said private ownership of roads was a ''terrible idea'' because corporations would charge exorbitant tolls and build only the most profitable projects, the ones easiest for states to finance. John Kenneth Galbraith, a Harvard economist, said, ''Private highways are a fraudulent substitute for the proper course of action, which is to pay for the roads through taxes.''
The American Automobile Association, which has 30 million members, opposes almost all toll projects, public and private. The main reason, said John Archer, an A.A.A. spokesman, is that bond financing makes toll roads several times more expensive than public roads that are paid for with taxes.
 
The Costs of Collecting
Another strike against toll roads is that collection costs alone devour over 15 percent of the tolls, he said. But the association does not oppose toll projects like the proposed Leesburg-Dulles Airport road, which provides an additional route for commuter travel.
This road proposal, in fact, has progressed with a stunning lack of public opposition. Landowners along the route donated land worth an estimated $100 million to make sure the road would be economically feasible. Most of them real estate developers who would benefit.
Mr. Stanley's proposed 14-mile, four-lane thoroughfare, the Dulles Toll Road Extension, would be built in a rural section of Loudoun County. Although traffic is expected to be light initially, it is expected to grow as the residential and commercial development in adjacent Fairfax County spreads outward from Washington. The road would tie into the 11-mile Dulles Toll Road, which links the airport with Interstate 495 and other major highways to Washington. Mr. Stanley said the road would reduce travel time between Leesburg and Washington to 45 minutes from 90.
The proposal faces only one more hurdle: The State Corporation Commission, which is expected to review the company's projected tolls and profit margins this month.
 
Company's Expectations
The company is looking for a relatively high rate of return, 16 to 18 percent, on the investors' equity as well as on the debt incurred to build the $160 million road. The company says this return is justified because of the risk involved in building a road before a region's traffic can support it.
Traffic on the toll road is not expected to be sufficient for the company to turn a profit until 2001. Tolls would initially be $1.50, or the same as the state's Dulles Toll Road, on a per-mile basis, and would gradually be increased to $3.25 by 2010. But toll increases would have to be approved by the state.
If the state approves the company's financial plan, Mr. Stanley and his partners plan to raise money for construction and operation of the road by selling about $25 million in stock to institutional investors and by borrowing about $135 million in the bond market.
Construction would take 24 months and could begin as early as next spring, Mr. Stanley said.
Mr. Stanley, meanwhile, has new projects in sight. He says he has become as fond of failing bridges as he is of traffic jams and is now offering to repair bridges at no cost to a city or state. All it takes, he says, is a temporary toll booth to collect the repair costs and his profits.

LENGTH: 925 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Advances to World Cup

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Defying a sea of crimson shirts and a scoreless funk of two months, the United States scored the goal it needed today to reach the main round of the World Cup of soccer.
Paul Caligiuri, who had called this ''the biggest game of our lives,'' scored in the 31st minute to allow the United States to defeat Trinidad and Tobago, 1-0, and guarantee a trip to Italy next June.
The United States last reached the final round in 1950. In this eight-game qualifying round for next summer's final round, lack of scoring punch had put the Americans in jeopardy going into today's game. 
The team from the Caribbean republic that was founded in 1962 had stunned the giant nation with a goal in the 88th minute, to tie the United States, 1-1, last May. Because Trinidad and Tobago had a better scoring differential over the course of the qualifying round, it needed only a tie today to advance.
 
No Goals in 239 Minutes
The well-mannered young men representing the United States had not scored a goal since Sept. 17, or in 208 minutes of soccer going into today's game.
That streak was extended by 31 minutes with the home players showing their willingness to counterattack, to keep the Americans from swarming upfield.
Patience has not been an American virtue this year. Going into this game that would either take them to Italy or wreck many hopes and not a few careers, Bob Gansler, the coach, had told them: ''Simple things. Perfectly. As often as possible.'' The United States responded with a patient game. Caligiuri, a 25-year-old from U.C.L.A. who has played in West Germany for three years but has been injured for much of this year's World Cup chase, showed his professional skills in the middle of red uniforms.
 
'I Knew I Had the Space'
Inserted in the center of the midfield because he could handle the quickness of the home players, Caligiuri received a loose ball about 40 yards from the goal. He chipped it right-footed past one defender and then chased it down. His hard left-footed volley from 25 yards swirled hard to the right past Michael Maurice, the goalie, landing in the high right corner.
''We knew we needed a shot,'' Caligiuri said later. ''I knew I had the space. You have to take what they give you.''
By scoring, the Americans had taken the home team out of its first game plan. The home players seemed jittery until halftime and then mounted several good attacks down the left side. But the Americans showed more patience than they have all year, and Tony Meola smothered a few hard shots, particularly on screens in the 85th and 86th minutes.
''We just dropped back and I swept out all the garbage,'' said Mike Windischmann, the only survivor from the 1985 loss to Costa Rica in a game in which a tie would have taken the United States to the last qualifying round.
 
Red Clothes and Black Umbrellas
The goal also minimized the impact of the 30,000 fans, almost all wearing red outfits and many carrying black umbrellas, to create one of the most uniform and impressive sights possible in a soccer stadium, particularly only 100 yards from the glittering sea with green mountains jutting from the other side.
The republic of 1.2 million residents was hoping to become the smallest nation to qualify for the 1990 World Cup. It has never played in the final round, and although emotions were high, the fans were friendly.
''I told my players, 'Pretend they are cheering for you,' '' Gansler said. ''In a way, I think we took energy from the fans.''
There is no such colorful or noisy reception for soccer in the United States, which has been awarded the 1994 World Cup because of the vast corporate money that could be generated there.
 
Legacy of Betrayal
As host in 1994, the American team will automatically be included among the 24 finalists, but these players wanted to earn a berth on their own this year.
The road was made easier when Mexico was banned for falsifying the ages of several junior players and Canada was upset in an early round.
The American players never expected to have to come to this island needing to win to advance. The oil bust has hurt the local economy in the past few years and there has also been a legacy of soccer betrayal since 1973, when officials called back four goals to give Haiti a 2-1 victory. The sport's world governing body later banned the officials, but never ordered the game replayed.
Soccer stayed down here until two years ago when Everald (Gally) Cummings, a member of the 1973 squad and a former player in the North American Soccer League, was appointed coach.
 
Aggressive, Happy Style
Stressing national pride, Cummings installed an aggressive, happy style of soccer, based on the Brazilian ''calypso'' brand, always advancing the ball. He also asked a behavioral psychologist, Dr. Shirley Rudd-Ottley, to work with the team because ''I think Trinidadians function well in a family-oriented situation.''
The goal in the 88th minute in May had haunted the United States for the past six months, but today they slipped through 90 minutes untouched. The drums stopped in the stands, and the champagne began spraying in the Americans' locker room.
''I-ta-ly,'' the players chanted, along with other slogans, as the giant nation celebrated the victory over the tiny nation.
The United States will play three games in the first round next June, and will not be expected to do well, but today the players saved their program and maintained their careers by playing a rewarding and patient 90 minutes in the biggest game of their lives.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
How Too Much Success Undid Speaker Jim Wright

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

The Ambition and the Power
By John M. Barry
768 pages. Viking. $22.95.
In 1986, several months before James Claude Wright Jr. was formally elected Speaker of the House of Representatives, John M. Barry, a former Washington editor of Dun's Business Week, approached Mr. Wright and asked him for his cooperation on a book. Mr. Barry foresaw that Mr. Wright's speakership was going to be an extraordinary exercise of power, so he asked the Congressman for permission to follow him through his daily routine and even to sit in on his private meetings ''so that the book would truly reflect an insider's view of power.''
Against the advice of his senior staff, Mr. Wright agreed. Little did either of them know that the book would be the story of the future Speaker's fall from power. Yet Mr. Barry would make the most of his unique opportunity. Although flawed in several respects, ''The Ambition and the Power'' remains an overwhelmingly powerful story and one of the best political books to be written in several years. 
In it, Mr. Barry unfolds a nearly archetypal drama of hubris and nemesis. When Congressman Wright captured the speakership, he set out to exploit the power of the office as no one had done since Henry Clay in the early 19th century. And in Mr. Barry's view, he very nearly succeeded, surpassing even President Ronald Reagan's White House in controlling the legislative agenda as well as in influencing the course of Central American peace talks involving Nicaragua, the Sandinistas and the contras.
''No Congress in decades could even approach the record of the 100th Congress,'' Mr. Barry writes. ''It had addressed in major initiatives the environment, international trade, health care, the social fabric, economic infrastructure, civil rights. And it had brought peace. All of Wright's agenda had passed, all of it. Every law carried the policy stamp of House Democrats. It was a remarkable record.''
But in helping to compile it, Mr. Wright made bitter enemies. In reshaping the House of Representatives into an instrument of his will, he antagonized Republicans and left many of his own party feeling bruised and restive. And he had left himself highly vulnerable. In the process of his rise he had made errors of judgment that in the right hands could be exploited to his fatal detriment.
Representative Newt Gingrich, a Georgia Republican, concluded: ''If Wright consolidates his power, he will be a very, very formidable man. We have to take him on early to prevent that.'' So the archconservative Republican undertook a calculated campaign built around what he saw as Mr. Wright's ethical lapses. Eventually, in the spring of 1989, it forced the Speaker to resign.
Such a summary, of course, does not even begin to suggest the sweep and detail of Mr. Barry's narrative, which goes back to Jim Wright's Texas boyhood as the lonely son of an itinerant salesman of business ideas, and explores layer by layer and deal by deal the development of the complex personality that lay behind the smiling mask.
We learn of the subtle disillusionment he suffered at one stage of his career, and of his turn to what he much later judged to be greedy practices. But by doing so we also come to understand the truth behind what Mr. Barry persuasively insists were the distortions and exaggerations of the case against Mr. Wright that caused the House ethics committee to vote against him. (For instance, Mr. Barry points out how Richard Phelan, who was hired as outside counsel by the ethics committee, quoted language that had been rejected by the Rules Committee to condemn Mr. Wright falsely for collecting excessive royalties on his book when he was actually taking advantage of a loophole in the rules.) In fact, so detailed is Mr. Barry's narrative that he is afraid to let it speak for itself. Instead he insists on hyping it with italicized phrases in the style of Tom Wolfe and Stephen King, repeated so often that we grow tired of reading phrases from such things as the Speaker's testament (''If they think they do not like me it is because they do not know me.'') or Representative Gingrich's pronouncements (''He creates himself when he acts.'') or Elias Canetti's theory of crowd behavior as enunciated in his book, ''Crowds and Power.''
Nor do the florid metaphors help (''His speakership began to resemble a great python trying to wrap itself about a sleeping tiger, preparing to wrap it in a death grip, the tiger just beginning to stir, one eye alert, preparing to lash out''), nor the author's attraction to cliches like Mme. Defarge knitting or Antaeus renewing himself with the earth, or the world's indifference to tragedy as expressed by W. H. Auden's poem about Icarus's drowning, ''In the Musee des Beaux-Arts.''
Still, it is a measure of Mr. Barry's accomplishment that these shortcomings are made to seem minor by his elevation to the level of Greek tragedy what to many eyes might have seemed an episode of political chicanery. In his final judgment, the Speaker erred by putting ''his shoulder against the edge of the law and the rules'' and pushing ''until he bent back a place'' for his conduct.
But this was hubris, not venality as the ethics committee concluded. If the Speaker was small in his concern for financial security, he was large in his ambition, ''his vision of his role was large, and what he was willing to do to achieve those things was large.'' Shortly before he gave his speech of resignation in the House, Mr. Wright spent a weekend in the Shenandoah Valley. He went for a walk. As Mr. Barry recounts it: ''It was warm. In the 80's. In the foreground was a barn, some hay. Behind them he counted range after range of ancient mountains, so ancient that the world had worn them down to little more than hills. He counted within his view five distinct rings of mountains and imagined the five sets of valleys between them. There was not a sign of men in them, not that he could see, except for the barn immediately before him. He thought for a moment that for all one's ambitions, all one could do was change the foreground a little. He had done that already. He felt at peace, his decision made.''

HEADLINE: Tax Writers Reach Pact to Raise Revenue

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Tax negotiators from the House of Representatives and the Senate have reached a tentative agreement on about $5.3 billion in revenue-raising measures as part of their contribution to a plan Congress is trying to fashion to reduce the deficit.
The agreement, which also includes about $2.2 billion in tax changes that would lose money for the Treasury, is tentative because the tax writers are waiting for more detailed revenue estimates before formally accepting the accord.
The revenue provisions mostly affect business but include a $3-a-ticket increase in the tax on international flights and a new $6-a-ticket tax on international cruises that would be paid for by consumers.
The lawmakers are still at odds over unrelated provisions dealing with spending for Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security, which fall under the jurisdictions of the tax committees. 
 
Rare Session at the Capitol
Called to the Capitol for a rare Sunday session, the lawmakers scrambled to complete their work on the deficit plan and to resolve the fate of the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act so they can end their legislative year before Thanksgiving. But the Senate rejected a conference agreement to repeal the act, which is intended to protect 33 million older Americans from the high cost of extended illness. Their action means that the current law continues in effect.
The deficit-reduction plan, which has been under negotiation for weeks, is aimed at producing enough budget savings for this fiscal year so that Congress can lift the $16.1 billion in across-the-board spending cuts imposed by President Bush on Oct. 16. The cuts were required by Federal law because Congress and the President failed to agree on their own deficit-cutting plan by that date.
Mr. Bush has warned that he will veto the Congressional plan unless it achieves at least $14 billion in ''real'' deficit reduction without accounting gimmicks. Republicans in the House and Senate said the plan now taking shape falls at least $5 billion to $6 billion short of that goal.
 
Extensions on Tax Breaks
While lawmakers may need several more days to resolve that problem, the final tax measures are expected to remain essentially as the negotiators decided in a bargaining session that concluded in the early hours of Saturday morning. They include a one-year extension, through Dec. 31, 1990, of a dozen popular tax breaks that have either expired or are scheduled to expire at the end of this year.
The tax breaks include credits to companies for research and development spending, credits to employers for hiring economically disadvantaged workers and to investors in low-income housing. The breaks would cost the Treasury about $1.7 billion in the current 1990 fiscal year.
Despite his campaign pledge of no new taxes, President Bush agreed with Congress in the spring that at least $5.3 billion in revenue would be needed to help meet this year's deficit- reduction goals. While many of the revenue-producing tax changes contemplated under the negotiators' agreement can be classified as closing of loopholes, some, like the fees on international flights and cruises, are clearly tax increases. The airline and cruise taxes would apply to tickets bought after Dec. 31.
The corporate tax changes include a new tax on the production of ozone depleting chemicals, a speed-up in collection of payroll taxes withheld by employers, new restrictions on deductions available to banks that lend money to employee stock ownership plans and new restrictions on tax breaks for companies involved in leveraged buyouts. Tax writers also agreed to impose a 5-cent-a-barrel tax on oil producers to pay for cleaning up oil spills.
 
Biggest Help
The biggest revenue raiser is the payroll tax speed-up, which would bring the Treasury an estimated $2.4 billion in fiscal 1990. Effective Aug. 1, 1990, employers would be required to make payroll tax withholding payments to the Internal Revenue Service within a day of the time the amounts withheld from employee paychecks reach $100,000.
Under current law, most employers make withholding payments to the I.R.S. on a schedule that allows them at least three banking days before payments are due. Thus companies with smaller payrolls that do not reach the $100,000 withholding threshold would not be affected by the change.
Republicans protested today that the payroll tax change was an accounting gimmick, but Democrats asserted that it would produce real revenue.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: PUBLISHING;
Book Industry's Confidence Hurt by Shake-Ups and Cuts

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
For the first time within decades, the book industry is beset by a crisis of confidence. While heads of houses still exude optimism in their public statements, in private it is difficult to find a publisher of general-interest books who has not been shaken in the last year - and especially in the last few weeks.
This uncertainty was more noticeable than ever in conversations during and after the annual Literary Guild publishing party last week at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan. A number of publishing executives were still bewildered by the recent turmoil at Random House and Penguin USA and by the large write-off at Simon & Schuster. 
Many are concerned that the industry may be jeopardizing its long-term investments in books and authors for short-term financial gains.
The industry has its share of problems. Sales of general-interest books, known as trade books, have been in a slump for about a year. Sales of hardcover fiction were particularly poor last summer, falling an estimated 16 percent from a year earlier.
Adding to the pressures on profits are the huge advances that publishers continue to pay for big-name authors. Sometimes they know they will never earn the money back, but they pay it to keep authors from going to a competitor. And many smaller advances are being written off as well.
Book publishing has historically been punctuated by peaks and valleys, so publishers have tended to be optimistic even during prolonged downturns. Yet the current malaise and confusion are so striking, and so disturbing, because they appear to be caused by problems unrelated to the cyclical nature of publishing.
Even considered in isolation, the events of the last several weeks have been unsettling:
* Random House named Alberto Vitale to replace Robert L. Bernstein, who headed the company for 23 years. Mr. Vitale, the president of Bantam Doubleday Dell, is widely believed to have been called in to make Random House leaner and to increase the profits.
* E. P. Dutton's 137-year-old adult trade book division was eliminated, leaving it only an imprint within Penguin. And a few days later, the bearer of the bad news for Dutton, Robert G. Diforio, the chairman of the New American Library, was told by Penguin that his employment contract would not be renewed.
* Simon & Schuster, the largest American book publisher, said it was taking a $140 million pretax write-off against its earnings.
* And there was speculation that another large publishing house would report a significant write-off after its board meeting early next month.
What makes those events foreboding is that they appear to be related. The appointment of Mr. Vitale is widely thought to presage for Random House the kind of ''consolidation'' - that is, layoffs and retirements - that Peter Mayer, the chairman of Penguin USA, has implemented at E. P. Dutton and the New American Library. Mr. Vitale quietly took such steps at Doubleday and Dell in the two years since they were acquired by Bantam.
Simon & Schuster's surprisingly large write-off was the result of the general softness in consumer publishing and its mounting expenses, including the advances it paid authors for books that did not sell enough copies to earn back their investment.
What is sending chills throughout the industry is that Random House, Penguin and Simon & Schuster are among the industry elite - well-financed companies that often publish good books, often pay big money and presumably have the know-how to make a decent profit. Moreover, all three are international publishers.
So if their profit margins are not what they should be, or if sales of their general-interest books are less than robust, industry executives wonder what that portends for other houses? And if the leading houses feel compelled to close divisions, write off losses and trim staff, what does that say about the publishing assumption that bigger is necessarily better? Or that acquisitions and mergers would result in a stronger, more professional publishing industry?
Many publishing executives who once did not question the conventional wisdom are now having serious second thoughts. One question they are asking is not only whether it is bad for publishers to collect other publishing houses like some people collect baseball cards or stamps, but whether such takeovers are even all that good for the acquirers. Are the economies of scale that apply to manufacturing incompatible with book publishing, where editors acquire books individually and where most books are different from one another?
These executives are also asking whether big publishing enterprises are so burdened with debt that they have no choice but to slash the payrolls and often the number of titles published? Do big publishing enterprises stifle creativity by piling layers of management upon editorial staffs, sales forces and the other departments directly concerned with publishing books?
One chief executive argued that while general-interest book publishing was in a slump, other types of publishing were ''extremely healthy'' - especially in such areas as textbooks and children's books.
Still, the doubts and the worry are pervasive. One high publishing executive, who himself has figured in much recent speculation, suggested that the weaknesses underscored by the events in the last few weeks may be endemic to the industry.
Another top executive said business was fine at his recently merged company. ''But,'' he added, ''ask me again in six months.''
Perhaps the gloomiest recent assessment came from a publishing veteran who said that, for the first time, he was looking forward to his impending retirement. Why? Because he did not like the direction in which publishing has been headed, nor did he know how to change it.
And one executive - saying that he was being only slightly melodramatic - described the situation with a quote from Yeats: ''Things fall apart; the center cannot hold.''
