SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1371 words

HEADLINE: Data Are Signaling Bad Slump

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
With the release of each week's data, the message is growing clear: the United States economy is suffering from a severe downturn, perhaps the worst of the last seven years.
This month brings the seventh anniversary of the economic expansion that began after the 1982 recession, an unusually long period of prosperity that nevertheless was nearly interrupted by two earlier downturns, in 1984 and 1986. The current one began to show itself in late summer.
The economy bounced back quickly from the two earlier slumps, and most economists speak of a similar revival this time. But there is an undertone of uncertainty in their reassurances. 
''We lack the rebound potential of 1986 and 1984,'' said Nigel Gault, a senior economist at McGraw Hill-Data Resources Inc., which expects a rebound. Mr. Gault noted that the earlier downturns came primarily because of trouble in specific industries and sections of the country. ''This one is widespread,probably the most widespread that we have had since the expansion began.''
 
Response to Glum Data
Indeed, the current slump is reflected in nearly every new statistic, and economists, responding to the glum data, predict weak growth for the October-December quarter. Fifty forecasters, surveyed monthly by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, for example, say the gross national product, the total value of goods and services produced in the nation, will grow at an annual rate of only 1.2 percent.
''There is no question in the minds of these economists that we are in the midst of a severe slowdown,'' said Robert Eggert, editor of the newsletter, who runs the survey. ''The 1.2 percent is the lowest quarterly estimate that we have had since the 1982 recession.''
While a recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of G.N.P. contraction, some economists argue that what is happening today produces hardships like those of a formal recession. ''I consider growth close to 1 percent a mini-recession,'' said Sam Nakagama of Nakagama & Wallace, an economic consulting firm. ''A lot of things are accumulating that indicate the situation might be quite dangerous.''
Until recently, the expectation was that economic growth would remain at 2 percent or more. Indeed, the G.N.P. grew in the third quarter at a 2.5 percent annual rate. Not since 1986 has there been a quarter with an expansion below a 2.5 percent rate.
 
Auto Sales Hurting
The deterioration shows up above all in auto sales and new-home construction, both lately at levels close to those of the 1981-82 recession. Real estate prices, which had risen for more than a decade, are flat now or falling nearly everywhere except the Portland-Seattle area.
Appliances, computers and other ''big ticket'' items are selling poorly, and while there is demand for clothing, toys and other ''soft goods,'' retailers say they can sustain sales only by cutting prices sharply. The price cutting even includes furriers and fast-food outlets.
Corporate profits have fallen since last winter. This decline is blamed partly on price cutting and also on production cutbacks as many businesses hold down new orders to avoid accumulating inventory they may not be able to sell. Whatever the reasons, fewer jobs are being created than early this year, and businesses everywhere are cutting back on spending, a tactic that ripples through the economy.
 
First Time Since '82
One ripple has hurt car rentals, which rely heavily on corporate accounts. Frank A. Olson, chairman of the Hertz Corporation, said that for the first time since the 1982 recession car rental revenue is growing at less than 10 percent throughout the country.
Another ripple has hurt Caterpillar Inc. and the Cummins Engine Company, which make engines for tractor-trailers, which transport most of the nation's products from factories, warehouses and docks to their final destinations. ''Our engine sales are off sharply, and that is a leading indicator that fewer goods are being shipped,'' said Don V. Fites, Caterpillar's president.
Finally, three forces that drove the economy in recent years are disappearing now. One is the boom in exports. Overseas sales are leveling off, partly because the dollar's value has risen this year, making American products more expensive abroad. In addition, the 48-day strike at the Boeing Company is expected to reduce exports until early next year, even if the strike ends this week. Boeing alone accounts for $1 billion a month in overseas sales.
 
Less Military
A second waning force is military spending, which is being cut back as East-West tensions ease and the Administration tries to reduce the budget deficit. ''All of the defense contractors in the West have announced staff reductions,'' said Jerry L. Jordan, chief economist at First Interstate Bank in Los Angeles.
Perhaps most important, until recently, steel, chemicals, paper, aluminum and other key materials had seemed in short supply. Demand for them had backed up orders, and factories were operating at full capacity. The situation has reversed today. Nearly every raw material is in oversupply, and the prices of some - for example, steel sheets - have fallen by as much as 20 percent.
''The weakness in the economy comes from a broadly distributed sense that supply has achieved dominance over demand,'' wrote Albert T. Sommers, a senior economist at the Conference Board.
The upshot is that inflation, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, has fallen to an annual rate below 5 percent in recent months, from one well above that level earlier this year. With the decline in inflation, the Federal Reserve has allowed interest rates to decline, slowly at first but more rapidly since early October, to avoid a recession.
The central bank acknowledged as much on Friday, in the release of a summary of a policy meeting held in early October. Acknowledging a readiness to reduce rates, the summary stated that ''the risks to the expansion were more heavily toward a shortfall from current expectations than toward faster growth and greater inflationary pressures.''
 
Blaming the Fed
Many economists have said the current slowdown is primarily the result of the Fed's decision to push interest rates up sharply to fight inflation. With higher rates, the Fed tried to reduce the pressure on prices by discouraging spending based on credit.
The strategy apparently worked, and now that interest rates are declining, the hope of many economists is that consumers and business executives will spend again, and in so doing create a revival.
''Rare is the economy that declines in an environment of falling interest rates,'' said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. Mr. Roach and others put their faith in consumers. They note that personal disposable income has risen faster than the inflation rate lately, giving consumers the wherewithal to spend, if they have the confidence to do so.
That confidence exists, according to the University of Michigan's October survey of consumer sentiment, released last week, although the survey says consumers today ''are apprehensive about the future course of the economy.''
 
Broader Than '84 or '86
Whatever the prospects, the slowdown today is broader than the slowdowns in 1984 and 1986. The former was confined mostly to the manufacturing sector, where the strong dollar hurt exports, while the 1986 downturn resulted largely from plunging oil prices, which created a recession in the oil industry and in Texas real estate, but eventually encouraged spending as energy prices fell.
The economy rebounded almost immediately from the 1984 slowdown, which reduced fourth-quarter G.N.P. growth that year to 1.7 percent. (The first quarter of 1985 was a lusty 4.9 percent.) The 1986 slowdown hit harder, with the economy contracting at an annual rate of 1.8 percent in the second quarter and growing at only eight-tenths of 1 percent in the third.
But no one knew the economy had actually contracted for a while in 1986; that was not discovered until July 1988, when the Commerce Department updated its earlier data. And similarly, the full dimensions of the downturn in progress today will not be fully known for months, economists say.

HEADLINE: Bid Is Raised To $3.8 Billion For Nekoosa

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
The Georgia-Pacific Corporation yesterday raised its offer for the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation to $3.8 billion, or $63 a share, from $3.1 billion, or $58 a share.
In a terse statement, Great Northern acknowledged receipt of the revised offer and said its board would meet tomorrow to review it.
T. Marshall Hahn Jr., Georgia-Pacific's chairman, sent a letter to William R. Laidig, the chairman and chief executive of Great Northern, urging the rival paper company to accept the proposal and repeating his request for a meeting.
Georgia-Pacific, which holds 349,900 Great Northern shares, or less than 1 percent, said it was seeking a special meeting of Great Northern's shareholders to vote on a resolution approving the new offer. Under Great Northern's 1988 shareholder rights plan, Georgia-Pacific has the right to demand such a meeting. 
Georgia-Pacific made its initial offer on Oct. 31. Great Northern's board rejected the bid on Nov. 13.
 
Investors Expect Higher Bid
Great Northern's stock has been trading above the level of the original offer, indicating that investors believed a new, higher bid was in the offing. On the New York Stock Exchange on Friday, the shares closed at $61, down 12.5 cents.
''Our increased price makes an already fair offer even fairer,'' Mr. Hahn said in his letter yesterday. He denied Great Northern's contention that the combined company could not handle the debt it would carry if the merger was completed.
''The increased offer enhances the appeal to the shareholder to tender into our offer and to vote their proxies for our offer in the meeting we've demanded,'' Mr. Hahn said in an interview yesterday.
 
Antitrust Violation Seen
In rejecting the first Georgia-Pacific offer, Great Northern's board said it was inadequate and would violate antitrust laws. Great Northern, based in Norwalk, Conn., filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Bridgeport, Conn., seeking an injunction against the takeover on antitrust grounds.
Mr. Laidig has argued in a letter to shareholders that if the takeover was completed the combined company would be saddled with a debt load of $4.5 billion.
Mr. Hahn responded to Great Northern's assertions by attacking the company's defense tactics.
''Vexatious litigation and delaying tactics serve only to cause needless anxiety among your employees and to take value out of your shareholders' pockets,'' he said in his letter. Mr. Hahn also said he believed that the antitrust suit brought by Great Northern was an attempt to delay the offer but that the revised offer would win over the company's shareholders.
 
'Appeals to Shareholders'
''One of the reasons for leaving ourselves some room was to be able to negotiate a friendly transaction,'' Mr. Hahn said. ''Raising the price further encourages the Great Northern board to come to the table and it also appeals to shareholders.''
Georgia-Pacific, which is based in Atlanta, also announced that it would file an amended complaint in its lawsuit filed in Maine, which contends that Great Northern's board breached its fiduciary duty in rejecting the original offer, and in challenging the recent adoption of additional employee benefits and enriched executive compensation agreements, or golden parachutes.
The Georgia-Pacific bid for Nekoosa has shaken up the small almost gentlemanly world of the paper industry. Paper company executives said the takeover battle signals a more aggressive acquisition posture that some will have to adopt if they hope to grow.
 
Bleak Earnings Forecast
After two years of heady growth in the industry, many analysts are forecasting lower paper prices and bleak earnings during the next few years. In addition, some are predicting that as the paper market weakens some companies may begin to seek economies of scale by making acquisitions.
Shares of Georgia-Pacific closed up 62.5 cents, at $48.125, on Friday. Georgia-Pacific extended the expiration date of its buyout offer to Dec. 4.

HEADLINE: Greenspan's Lincoln Savings Regret

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
In late 1984, Alan Greenspan, then a private citizen, took on a consulting assignment for the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., and its owner, Charles H. Keating Jr. Five years later, Mr. Greenspan, as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is finding that four-month job a source of embarrassment and regret.
''When I first met the people from Lincoln, they struck me as reasonable, sensible people who knew what they were doing,'' Mr. Greenspan said in an interview last week. ''I don't want to say I am distressed, but the truth is I really am. I am thoroughly surprised by what has happened to Lincoln.''
Lincoln was taken over by Federal regulators in April in an action that is expected to cost taxpayers $2 billion. Mr. Keating was removed from control. 
 
No Conflict Seen
To be sure, no one in Washington is saying that Mr. Greenspan has compromised either his integrity or that of his office. And they add that consulting work done when he was a private economist should pose no conflict in his current role as one of the nation's top banking regulators.
Members of Congress and banking analysts say the issue for Mr. Greenspan, a highly respected economist, is one of appearance. And his critics ask why he did not spot the germ of future troubles at Lincoln.
The Justice Department is investigating Mr. Keating, the failure of Lincoln and also the five Senators who accepted contributions from Mr. Keating. The Senate Ethics Committee has hired a special counsel to investigate the Senators' actions.
Mr. Greenspan concedes that he misjudged the ultimate intention of Mr. Keating and Lincoln's management. ''Of course I'm embarrassed by my failure to foresee what eventually transpired,'' he said. ''I was wrong about Lincoln. I was wrong about what they would ultimately do and the problems they would utlimately create.''
Mr. Greenspan's views in the winter of 1984-85 are being used now by Lincoln's past and present supporters in the fall of 1989 in their own defense.
In late 1984, Mr. Greenspan, head of an economic forecasting firm, Townsend-Greenspan & Company, was retained by the New York law firm of Paul Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison for four months. Mr. Greenspan says he does not remember how much he was paid but that it was at his usual rate.
 
Heavily Involved in Development
He was asked to conduct a study on real estate investment, known in the savings industry as direct investments, by savings and loan associations. Mr. Keating, Lincoln and its parent company, the American Continental Corporation, were heavily involved in real estate development.
He was also to study Lincoln's financial condition, and if he considered the institution stable, to write officials of the Federal Home Loan Bank of San Francisco supporting an application by Mr. Keating for an exemption for Lincoln to a bank board rule forbidding substantial amounts of such investments. Mr. Greenspan sent such a letter in February 1985. Lincoln did not receive the exemption.
A spokesman for Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and one of the Senators whose intervention with Federal regulators on behalf of Lincoln two years later, in early 1987, is the subject of the Senate and Justice Department inquiries, said that ''Senator McCain has cited the Greenspan study many times as a powerful force in his approach to Lincoln.''
The other four Senators involved in the inquiry are Democrats: Alan Cranston of California, the majority whip; Dennis DeConcini of Arizona; Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan and John Glenn of Ohio.
 
Same Conclusions Today
Mr. Greenspan says that if he had the same assignment today, confronted with the same evidence he had in 1984, his conclusions about Lincoln and about development projects in the industry as a whole would be very much the same.
The issue at the time was whether ownership by savings and loan associations in real estate projects and other commercial ventures posed excessive risk. Mr. Greenspan, long a proponent of deregulation, argued then - and does still - that the laws Congress passed in setting up the savings industry would eventually drive it into a crisis, because institutions would be making their money from interest on 30-year fixed mortgages while having to pay depositors interest rates that at times fluctuated wildly.
Mr. Greenspan and others argued that if the industry could diversify its mix of business by adding more short-term lending, like loans on development projects, savings institutions would be cushioned from the potentially disastrous effects of rising interest rates.
 
Limitation Was Planned
The Federal Home Loan Bank Board believed that such direct investments posed an excessive risk to the industry. In late 1984, when it was planning to adopt a regulation that would have limited those activities to 10 percent of an institution's activities, Mr. Greenspan was hired by the law firm on behalf of Lincoln.
He submitted his study on direct investment to the bank board, but it adopted the regulation limiting such real estate investments anyway. Then Mr. Greenspan wrote the regulators, asking that Lincoln be given an exemption from the new rule.
Mr. Greenspan described Lincoln's management as ''seasoned and expert in selecting and making direct investments,'' as having a ''long and continuous track record of outstanding success in making sound and profitable direct investments,'' as succeeding ''in a relatively short period of time in reviving an association that had become badly burdened by a large portfolio of long-term fixed-rate mortgages'' and that it had ''restored the association to a vibrant and healthy state, with a strong net worth position.''
 
View on Direct Investments
Asked last week about his view of direct investments, Mr. Greenspan said: ''What I argued then, and argue now, is that direct investments are risky. If you give me two institutions, one that has a mix of short-term direct investments and long-term mortgages properly capitalized, or the same financing structure but invested only in long-term mortgages, I would say the first institution may well be safer.''
The problem was that as the economy in the Southwest collapsed in 1986, so did the value of the direct investments made by savings and loan institutions, many of which have since failed. This summer, Congress passed a $159 billion 10-year bailout of the industry.
Although Mr. Greenspan's connections with Lincoln and Mr. Keating were raised at his confirmation hearings in 1987, they were of passing concern. Mr. Greenspan says he has met Mr. Keating twice, and has had no contact with Mr. Keating or Lincoln associates since early 1985.
 
Troubled by Assertions
What appears to bother Mr. Greenspan most are the assertions of the Senators that his letter to the regulators led them to believe intervention on Lincoln's behalf was warranted.
''How could anyone use any evaluation I would have made in early 1985 as justification more than two years later?'' he asks. ''No one ever called saying, 'Do you still hold these views.' It's almost as bad as saying, 'I just read a report written two years ago that Amalgamated Widgets is a good stock to buy.' It just doesn't make sense.''
Could Mr. Greenspan have seen the handwriting on the wall on Lincoln, particularly signals that Mr. Keating's plans for Lincoln were far too ambitious and risky, as some critics maintain?
 
Doubling of Size Cited
Bert Ely, a financial consultant in Alexandria, Va., who recently reviewed the Lincoln case, noted that during 1984 - the first year that Mr. Keating owned Lincoln - the institution's financial statements raised red flags. Lincoln doubled in size, from an institution with $1.1 billion in assets at the end of 1983 to one with $2.24 billion a year later. Its depositors' money was going to investments in raw land and unrelated businesses, which soared from $6.6 million to $308 million.
''Any time you double in size, particularly of that magnitude, that should be a warning sign,'' Mr. Ely said. ''Rapid growth is a very risky strategy.''
Still, members of Congress and banking experts doubt that the damage to the Federal Reserve's chairman will be great.
 
Mistake 'Now Meaningless'
''The possible mistake in judgment that was made in 1984 and 1985 is now meaningless,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association. ''He has done a superb job as chairman of the Fed.''
But Clifford L. Brody, a financial consultant in Washington, warned that while the Keating involvement was not likely to hurt Mr. Greenspan in his conduct of monetary policy, it would make it harder for him to champion bold new deregulatory steps for the banking industry in general.
''I think you will find it will hinder him from being in the forefront of the debate,'' Mr. Brody said. ''Because every time banking deregulation is mentioned, he will be concerned that in the back of people's minds will be the ghost of Charles Keating.''

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Electronic Niches Provide Growth

BYLINE: By Phillip H. Wiggins

 BODY:
DESPITE problems facing the $42 billion electronics components industry, some smaller companies in high-growth niche markets are showing significant earnings momentum.
The industry's troubles were recently underscored by disappointing third-quarter earnings reports from two corporate giants, the Zenith Electronics Corporation and Motorola Inc.
Still, Wall Street analysts see promise in selected smaller electronics companies serving growth markets, including local area networks, cellular telephones, medical equipment, airport security systems and military display systems. Some are trading at price/earnings ratios below the current stock market P/E of about 13, several analysts said. 
While large electronics companies also have operations in these niche markets, the bulk of their revenues is derived from slower growing or no-growth business sectors, analysts say.
Of course, some of the smaller companies with strong niche markets at present are potentially vulnerable to adverse factors, like technological breakthroughs that would make their products obsolete, future recessions and a possible inability to raise capital fast enough to finance growth.
Benefiting from the boom in local area networks - a faster, more efficient system that allows peripheral computers to share information without going through a mainframe - is North Hills Electronics Inc., of Glen Cove, L.I., which trades over the counter. The company manufactures baluns, or adapters, which allow incompatible computer systems to communicate.
Jerome Ballen of Fahnestock & Company said North Hills' earnings could reach 17 to 20 cents a share in fiscal 1990, ending Jan. 31, up from 13 cents a share in 1989. The stock closed Friday at $1.75, down 12.5 cents.
The Del Electronics Corporation, an over-the-counter company based in Mount Vernon, N.Y., makes power supply systems and components used by medical, industrial and military companies. In the medical industry, for example, Del provides high-voltage components used in laser surgery and CT scans.
Recently the company announced plans to acquire RFI Inc. of Bay Shore, L.I., a $10 million subsidiary of KDI Holdings of New York. Assuming that the RFI acquisition is completed, analysts estimate that Del Electronics will earn 40 to 45 cents a share in 1990, ending July 31, up from 30 cents a share reported in fiscal 1989. The stock finished the week at $4.25.
The Kent Electronics Corporation of Houston distributes electronic connectors, cable assemblies and related products. The company also serves the local area network market with interconnect products used in voice and data communications.
In its fiscal year ended March 31, Kent reported earnings of 69 cents a share, up from 60 cents a year earlier. ''Internal growth has been exceeding our expectations,'' said Mark Jordan, an analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. He said he expected Kent to earn 80 cents a share in fiscal 1990 and 85 cents a share in fiscal 1991, not reflecting the potential effect of acquisitions. The stock closed Friday at $8.25, up 25 cents, on the American Stock Exchange.
Paul Johnson, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., likes the Dallas Semiconductor Corporation. Dallas Semiconductor makes proprietary electronics products for original equipment manufacturers. Analysts say this approach limits the company's vulnerability to pricing volatility.
Mr. Johnson expects Dallas Semiconductor's earnings to grow 50 percent in 1989 and at a rate of 30 to 35 percent over the next several years. He said 1989 earnings should rise to 45 cents a share from 30 cents a share in 1988. He foresees another gain, to 60 cents a share, in 1990. The stock closed Friday at $6.875, down 25 cents, in over-the-counter trading.
The Nu Horizons Electronics Corporation, based in Amityville, L.I., has attracted the attention of some analysts. The company distributes both active components like memory chips and passive components like capacitors and resistors.
Ted Allocca Sr., at G. K. Scott & Company, a brokerage firm based in Plainview, L.I., expects Nu Horizons to earn 25 cents a share in fiscal 1990, ending Feb. 28, up from 17 cents the preceding year, and about 40 cents a share in fiscal 1991. The stock closed unchanged Friday at $2.125 on the American Stock Exchange.
''Nu Horizons has put together an explosive high-tech line,'' Mr. Allocca said. ''They have about four or five companies that have developed products that have the potential to make any of them another Intel.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Canada's Dollar Defies the Trend

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
While the yen, the West German mark and other European currencies have fallen against a strong American dollar this year, the Canadian dollar has been the odd man out: it has risen in value.
In addition, Canada's dollar has outperformed the other ''high-yield currencies,'' which are attractive to investors because of their countries' high interest rates. These include the British pound and the Australian dollar, which have both declined this year.
But the strong currency is a mixed blessing for Canada. It is helping to slow inflation by making imports cheaper. At the same time, however, it is resulting in higher imports and lower exports, hurting businesses ranging from producers of wood products to oil companies and film production. 
 
Wider Deficit Expected
In the last year, Canadians have taken 30 percent more day trips to the United States, where their dollar now buys more and gasoline is cheaper. Because of this, economists estimate that Canada's current account deficit - trade in merchandise, services and investments - will widen by at least 50 percent this year.
The Canadian experience shows that a country's monetary policy, and the resulting interest rates, has a dominant effect on foreign exchange rates, economists say. In this case, negative factors like a rapidly deteriorating trade balance or a domestic budget deficit have not weakened the currency. And the impact of a nation's monetary policy is greater if the marketplace believes that the Government will hold to that policy.
At the end of 1988, the Canadian dollar was worth 83.9 cents in United States currency. On Friday, it reached 85.57 cents, up almost 2 percent for the year and just off its nine-year high of 85.76 cents on Nov. 9.
In the same period, the Japanese yen has fallen 15 percent in value against the American dollar and the West German mark has dropped 4 percent. Among the other high-yield currencies, the British pound reached its recent high against the dollar near the end of 1988, and is down by 13 percent so far this year. The Australian dollar, which reached its recent peak against the dollar early this year, has declined almost 9 percent.
The Canadian dollar has been strong this year because of the Bank of Canada's continued and determined effort, supported by the Government of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, to slow the economy and lower inflation.
 
Battle Began in '87
This battle, which began in earnest in 1987, has lifted the Canadian dollar off the floor. It had begun to drop in 1976, when it was at par with the American dollar, and the fall stopped at an all-time low of 69 cents in February 1986. Since then, the Canadian dollar has risen 24 percent.
But the recently strong Canadian economy has been stubbornly growing, and the Bank of Canada has had to push key interest rates so high that they now exceed the customary spread of 150 basis points above United States rates.
With these key rates now above 12 percent, the spread is now more than 400 basis points, up from an already high 250 basis points at the beginning of this year. A basis point is one hundredth of a percentage point.
This widening interest-rate differential is especially attractive for currency speculators, who want to take advantage of the higher interest-rate earnings.
The spread widened even more in the second week of November when the Federal Reserve in the United States took another step to ease interest rates as the American economy showed signs of slowing. But the Bank of Canada did not ease, sending the Canadian dollar to its nine-year high.
 
Dramatic Impact
The cumulative impact of this policy on Canada's trade balace has been dramatic. The current account deficit, which was $10.3 billion in Canadian currency in 1988, is projected to be $15 billion to $17 billion this year. But it may not be as alarming as a similar jump in the United States trade deficit, some economists said, because some negative factors could improve next year.
For example, Larry Greenberg, international economist at Ried Thunberg in Westport, Conn., said the Canadian trade figures have been skewed by a boom in capital spending, which has resulted in higher machinery imports. But these imports may be starting to moderate, economists say. In addition, a decline in wheat sales, because of last year's drought, is likely to be countered by sales from this year's harvest.
But a third negative factor is likely to continue next year: since nearly 80 percent of Canada's trade is with the United States, the slowing American economy has hurt Canadian exports.
For most economists and foreign exchange traders, the Canadian dollar's ability to sustain its strength has been the biggest surprise.
 
'Bank of Canada Was Tougher'
''People had expected the Canadian dollar to go lower,'' said Peter Frick, a foreign exchange economist at Union Bank of Switzerland in New York. ''But the Bank of Canada was tougher than expected.''
John Grant, chief economist at Wood Gundy Inc. in Toronto, said the Bank of Canada and its governor, John Crow, had outwitted the market for now. ''We're not in a situation where the market will take a run at the bank and force them to prove themselves,'' he said. ''Crow's outgunned the market.''
Many Canadian economists expect their dollar to fall next year, however, because they predict that years of high interest rates will finally slow the economy, which is still growing at about a 3 percent rate. Some even expect an economic downturn.
But this scenario assumes that the Bank of Canada will soon ease interest rates. But that may not happen, because inflation remains a concern.
Economists including Bryan Griffiths, senior vice president for foreign exchange at the Royal Bank of Canada in Toronto, note that wage settlements are rising, not falling, coming in at 5.1 percent in the second quarter and 5.9 percent in the third quarter. And inflation, which declined slightly in 1988, is rising. The Canadian consumer price index is projected to rise about 5 percent this year, up from 4 percent in 1988.

INDUSTRY: NAICS 213112 OIL & GAS INDUSTRY (71%);

LENGTH: 989 words

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;;
Ads to Join Details in Congressional Quarterly

BYLINE: By ALBERT SCARDINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The ghost of Nelson P. Poynter floats over the offices of Congressional Quarterly these days with one eyebrow raised.
The magazine that Mr. Poynter founded with his second wife, Henrietta, in 1946 as a chronicler of the proceedings on Capitol Hill will begin to accept advertising in January, ending a 53-year tradition of giving readers just the cold, hard facts of legislative business.
Mr. Poynter, who also owned The St. Petersburg Times in Florida, died in 1978. In their offices overlooking Rock Creek Park, a few miles west of Capitol Hill, the men who now run the company often ask the ghost what Mr. Poynter would have thought about their decision to let others buy access to the magazine's audience to deliver commercial messages. 
 
An Expensive Alternative
"Have we tampered with something sacred?" asks Robert W. Merry, the managing editor of the company's Congressional publications, including The Weekly Report. "Subscribers used to read us with a pen in hand, but they don't have time for that anymore," he pleads with the ghost. "They need something different than a civics-class view of Congress, and producing an alternative can be expensive."
CQ, as the magazine is universally known in Washington, won a loyal following among librarians, journalists and Government staff members during the Poynters' stewardship by providing details about the performance of the legislative branch. As a market, those groups stopped growing in the last decade, so circulation stagnated at about 10,000 weekly.
To hold onto its subscribers, the magazine changed its appearance earlier this year by adding limited color and graphics. But its publishers see little room to raise more revenue by increasing circulation or the subscription price, already as high as $1,075 a year.
 
'Symbol of Editorial Integrity'
Producing a livelier, more analytical magazine requires a professional staff that must be paid more than the law students Mr. Poynter used to hire in the 1950's, says Neil Skene, the executive editor. "I know that the lack of ads stood as a symbol of editorial integrity," he says to the ghost, "but our competitors all take ads now. We think of it as a financial opportunity for us and a service for our readers."
Wayne P. Kelley, the publisher, comes to the conversations with the specter after doing his homework. "We've talked to hundreds of our readers," Mr. Kelley says. "They said they wouldn't mind as long as it did not interfere with the quality of the product. Besides, growth has been flat in the 80's."
Mr. Kelley's boss, Andrew E. Barnes, does not believe in ghosts. Mr. Barnes is the chairman of the Times Publishing Company, which owns The St. Petersburg Times and several business magazines, as well as Congressional Quarterly.
"Nelson thought you could provide an authoritative stenographic service on a low budget and charge a high price to a few subscribers," Mr. Barnes said. "The economics of doing that don't work any longer."
 
An Awkward Name
No one knows why the company and the magazine continue to have the word "Quarterly" in the title. The magazine became a weekly almost at the outset, carrying the awkward name Congressional Quarterly Weekly Report. "We thought about changing it, but what would we call it?" Mr. Merry said.
The 233 staff members who work in the Washington headquarters also produce newsletters and special research reports and organize conferences for private clients.
Last year, the company introduced Washington Alert, an electronic publishing service, to provide immediate delivery of much of the data now in the magazine - including the text of legislation, roll-call votes and the status of bills in committee.
Congressional Quarterly Inc. accounts for about 9 percent of Times Publishing's annual revenues of $225 million, or about $20 million. The privately held company does not release its earnings, but Mr. Barnes said the subsidiary has not earned its share of the profits in recent years.
"If the magazine is going to be vital, it has to make some money," Mr. Barnes said.
 
Money-Loser for 10 Years
 The Poynters did not place a high value on profits at Congressional Quarterly, at least not in the beginning. The magazine lost money for at least 10 years after its founding, according to company executives.
"It was started as a service for newspaper editorial writers who could not afford their own Washington bureaus," Mr. Merry said. "It wasn't until librarians and trade associations in Washington began to use it in the 1960's that it became a profitable enterprise."
By 1969 it had become a research tool indispensable for anyone responsible for tracking legislation through Congress. But that year, most of the editorial staff resigned to start a similar publication covering the executive branch, The National Journal.
In the early 1980's, The National Journal decided to broaden its appeal. The writing became more analytical, competing in many ways with the national weekly news magazines. Still, only a few thousand readers could pay the subscription price of several hundred dollars a year.
 
'We Tiptoed In'
John Fox Sullivan, the publisher of The National Journal, said his magazine decided then to accept ads from companies and trade groups.
"We went through our share of angst about how advertising might change the way our readers viewed us," he said. "When we finally decided to go ahead, we tiptoed in."
Mr. Sullivan remembers telling Mr. Kelley that he expected the competition to follow suit. "I said it wouldn't kill him to take ads," he said. "Poynter might roll over in his grave, but it's free money."
However free it may be, Mr. Kelley said it would amount to no more than $2 million a year. He said most of the ads would probably come from Government contractors and lobbying groups. The magazine will increase its size to include as many as 20 advertising pages in a 100-page issue.

HEADLINE: CONFEREES BACK MAJOR OVERHAUL IN MEDICARE FEES

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, Nov. 21

 BODY:
House and Senate negotiators agreed on Monday to overhaul the way the Government pays doctors to treat the 33 million elderly and disabled Americans covered by the Medicare program.
The proposal is intended to address the wide disparities in fees that are said to discourage doctors from going into family practice. It would mean that specialists like surgeons and radiologists would be paid about 20 percent less by the Government than they are now, while general practitioners would be paid about 40 percent more. As a group, surgeons would still earn more than family doctors. 
Experts say the proposal could have a profound effect on the way medicine is practiced in the nation. They say the change in fees could reduce the incentive to perform surgery, radiology and other expensive procedures and could encourage preventive measures and office consultations practiced by internists and family doctors.
 
Changing the Rules
''Our current doctor payment system entices doctors to practice in high-paying specialty fields and to locate in high-cost areas like New York City and Miami,'' said Senator Dave Durenberger, Republican of Minnesota, who helped draft the plan. ''Our proposal seeks to change the way health-care services will be provided by changing the way we pay for services.''
The fee changes would apply only to the Medicare program. But private insurance companies follow the Government's lead in setting their own reimbursement rates, and many experts expect them to do so if the Government adopts these changes.
Agreement on the Medicare changes came as lawmakers spent a frantic day searching for consensus on the two major bills that stand between them and adjournment until Jan. 23.
At 1 this morning, House and Senate leaders announced that they and the Administration had reached agreement on one of them: the plan to reduce the Federal deficit by $14.7 billion. But the two Houses remain at odds over a separate Medicare program that covers the catastrophic costs of major illness.
Only days ago, the plan to overhaul Medicare payments, which had passed the House, seemed dead for this year. But with the support of the Bush Administration, it was revived in the final hours of the Congressional session.
Lawmakers say the plan would neither raise nor lower the deficit. In the long run, they hope that it will help control the soaring cost of health care. Support From A.M.A. The plan has been opposed by the American College of Surgeons, whose members would suffer the largest cuts in reimbursements. Lobbyists for the college have argued that the new system does not properly take into account the benefits of more extensive procedures.
But the American Medical Association, the major organization of physicians, supported the changes when it recognized that Congress was bent on overhauling the payment system. On Monday Dr. John S. Zapp, director of government affairs for the A.M.A., called the overhaul ''a very positive move, an appropriate reallocation for physician services.'' He added that it remains to be seen if the reforms actually redirect procedures and treatment.
Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, the West Virginia Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Subcommittee on Medicare, said the changes did not mean that doctors will leave specialties, ''but rather that the financial disincentives for getting into family practice will be substantially removed.''
Doctors who treat Medicare patients are now paid by the Government on the basis of ''customary, prevailing and reasonable'' fees. The new system would be based on standardized fees. Medicare reimbursements to doctors would be determined by the time, training and skills required to perform a particular service, plus a doctor's overhead costs, like those for malpractice insurance.
Lawmakers on three Congressional committees, who have worked on the plan for nearly nine months, say the current system encourages doctors to follow costly procedures when less expensive ones may work just as well. For example, ulcers are often diagnosed by endoscopy, in which a tube is inserted into the stomach. The procedure takes 30 minutes and costs $350. Dr. William Hsiao, an economist with the Harvard School of Public Health who helped develop the fee system, said the same diagnosis might also be made by giving the patient a complete physical examination, which takes 45 minutes but costs only $75.
Under the new payment system, Medicare would pay considerably less than it does now for the more expensive procedure.
Negotiators agreed that the payment changes would carried out over a five-year period beginning in 1992 and that a model fee schedule, describing some of the affected services and procedures, would be published in late 1990 or early 1991 to help doctors and insurers begin to make the adjustments.
The cost-setting overhaul is a vast undertaking, involving 7,000 different services and procedures reimbursed by the Medicare program, hundreds of thousands of doctors, and variations in patient volume, population and general medical costs in several hundred regions. While the new system would still take account of regional differences, proponents say that it would give Congress and the Administration a more rational way of evaluating Medicare costs and making the yearly decisions on how much to raise or lower reimbursements.
Mr. Rockefeller noted that the agreement includes other measures aimed at protecting Medicare patients from unwarranted fee increases and at keeping overall Medicare costs in check. Starting in 1992, doctors could charge patients only 25 percent in excess of the payment they receive from the Government; in 1993, that amount would drop to 20 percent and thereafter to 15 percent.
As part of the package, negotiators established a major study to determine the costs and benefits of various treatments and services paid for under the Medicare program.
Final Congressional approval of the payment proposal hinged on adoption of the deficit reduction plan, to which it is attached.
President Bush threatened to veto the deficit reduction measure unless lawmakers found at least $14 billion in budget savings without relying on accounting gimmicks. The package announced this morning would produce $14.7 billion in deficit savings, including $4.6 billion that would be achieved by allowing the automatic spending cuts imposed in October to remain in effect through the first week in February.
The cuts, which affect a wide array of domestic and military programs, shave about $1 billion a month from the deficit.
At the Administration's suggestion, the negotiators agreed to eliminate about a dozen tax breaks three months earlier than planned; this would save some money and would also provide the President with a legislative vehicle next year for his proposal to cut the tax on capital gains.
But lawmakers remain at odds over the catastrophic coverage program, with some of the House negotiators still pushing for outright repeal and the Senate still trying to salvage some of the benefits while eliminating the surtax that was to finance them.

HEADLINE: U.N. Official Assails Curbs on Aid to Afghans

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 20

 BODY:
The United Nations official in charge of coordinating supplies of aid for Afghanistan expressed concern today that the United States and other countries are withholding donations in order to weaken the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul.
The official, Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, said relief workers now enjoy their best access to Afghanistan in 10 years. But he said they lack money to start reconstruction projects in the war-ravaged countryside, although these would encourage the return of five million refugees from neighboring Pakistan and Iran. 
He said donors appeared reluctant to give more for fear this would help President Najibullah remain in power and because they wish to see a substantial return of refugees get under way first. He did not name countries other than the United States but suggested that a number of Western nations shared this approach.
 
A Way to Attract Refugees
Prince Sadruddin told a news conference that with most of the country's territory now in the hands of the rebels, the assistance he wants would go mainly to those living outside Government-controlled areas. Rebuilding villages, hospitals and schools would also encourage refugees to come back.
''With the possibility of a military solution to the conflict discounted and a suitable political formula not in sight,'' Prince Sadruddin wrote in his latest report on his agency's operations, ''it is becoming clear that massive economic and humanitarian assistance administered by the United Nations offers the best prospect of achieving the degree of socioeconomic stability from which a political settlement and a large-scale return of refugees may emerge.''
Although donors had pledged $991.5 million as of Aug. 31 toward last year's United Nations appeal for $1.3 billion in Afghan aid, most of what they are offering is in the form of food, medical assistance and supplies, and most of this has not yet been delivered. As a result, Prince Sadruddin said, he has only $17 million in cash to finance reconstruction inside the country, with 60 percent of this donated by Japan.
 
The Wider Disagreement
Officials and diplomats say Prince Sadruddin's complaints are part of a wider dispute developing over the last few months between the United Nations and the Bush Administration over policy toward Afghanistan.
Although the guerrillas have failed to capture a single Government-held city since the Soviet army completed its withdrawal in February, the Bush Administration apparently thinks they should strengthen their bargaining position by scoring new victories. As a result, the Administration is lukewarm toward any new peace initiative.
American officials did not deny that they were channeling aid through the guerrillas rather than the United Nations, but they stressed that a political compromise seems distant when the guerrillas refuse to deal with the Najibullah Government and enjoy substantial support among ordinary Afghans.
The United States channels roughly $100 million a year of humanitarian aid through the guerrilla groups in the hope of strengthening their position in the country, while providing only token assistance to Prince Sadruddin's agency.

HEADLINE: CLAMOR IN THE EAST;
In the 'New' Europe, Puzzling Out Roles

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Western diplomats and officials, considering how to encourage liberalization in Eastern Europe, say that the easy thing is deciding to give generous aid to Communist countries that move to hold free elections.
The hard part, it now seems, is deciding what the role of the United States and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization should be as change continues in the Soviet bloc and East-West arms reductions now being negotiated actually get under way.
In the wake of the European Community leaders' meeting in Paris last weekend, the difficulties are being felt most acutely in Britain, where they are complicated by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's disagreements with the 11 other members of the community on how tight their federation should be after a true common market is achieved by the end of 1992.
An official close to Mrs. Thatcher today criticized the American Secretary of Defense, Dick Cheney, for saying on television over the weekend that with the likelihood of conflict between the United States and the Soviet Union now being at its lowest level since the end of World War II, it was possible to contemplate even bigger reductions of American forces in Europe than those currently being negotiated by the two countries in Vienna. 
 
Mood Called Pro-NATO
''We know there is political and budget pressure to make bigger reductions, but to link them to what's happening in Eastern Europe is infelicitious,'' the British official said. ''The mood at the Paris meeting over the weekend was very pro-NATO. This kind of remark is all people like the Belgians and the Danes need to start demanding big reductions in NATO spending.''
A NATO diplomat in Brussels said Mr. Cheney's statement had also caused surprise at the alliance's headquarters there, although he said that the Secretary of Defense had apparently made clear that reductions in American military spending would be spread worldwide, not concentrated on forces in Western Europe.
A spokesman for the British Ministry of Defense added, ''Our general view is that these things are being discussed in the negotiations in Vienna and through NATO, and that if there are any reductions on our part, they'll follow that discussion.''
Mrs. Thatcher, who believes that it is unwise for Western countries to begin disarming until it is clear that economic change and democratization are going to succeed in the Soviet bloc, plans to travel to Washington to see President Bush on Friday at Camp David. Mr. Bush will meet the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, in Malta on Dec. 2 and 3.
''At the Paris meeting we all agreed that Eastern Europe had come this far because we had all been following the right policy, firmness,'' a British official said.
 
More Aid Likely
He reported that the consensus at the weekend talks in Paris made it likely that the next European Community summit meeting, scheduled for Strasbourg, France, on Dec. 8 and 9, will decide on a larger aid package for Poland and Hungary than the $330 million the community's executive commission recommended in September. The American Congress has approved $852 million for Poland and $86 million for Hungary over the next three years, and West Germany alone has agreed to provide about $1.5 billion in export guarantees and loans to Poland.
British officials, in particular, fear that the postwar Western consensus on the need for a strong defense against the Soviet threat could unravel in West Germany if East Germany evolves into a Western-style democracy.
The bulk of the 317,000 American troops in Europe are stationed in West Germany, and a large part of the 555,000-strong Soviet forces in Eastern Europe are based in East Germany. NATO has proposed a negotiated reduction to 275,000 each for the United States and the Soviet Union.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl emphasized West Germany's commitment to the European Community and to the Western alliance at last weekend's meeting, which President Francois Mitterrand of France called after East Germany opened its Western border for all of its 16.7 million citizens.
''I don't know why he made such a song and dance about it,'' one of the British officials present said. ''Nobody really thought the Germans were about to leave.'' But Mr. Kohl said late Saturday after he emerged from Elysee Palace: ''The world has changed. It's a great hour for Germans, and we felt that here.''
American arms control specialists have been saying for weeks that success in the Vienna negotiations is bound to lead to further, non-negotiated reductions by the United States and other Western countries, in response to budget as well as political pressures.
They fear that NATO could then become fragmented by recriminations like those that distracted the alliance last spring, when Mrs. Thatcher and President Bush wanted Mr. Kohl to agree to let the United States modernize its short-range nuclear rockets in West Germany after the intermediate-range missiles are withdrawn next year. President Bush finally agreed to a compromise in May and put off the decision until after the West German elections next fall.

HEADLINE: Jobs Are Lost in Plant Shutdown, but So Is Foul-Smelling Air

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRONT ROYAL, Va.

 BODY:
Some people said the odor that hung over Front Royal for almost half a century smelled like money. But that was just an old mill town joke.
Actually the smell was closer to rotten eggs. Worse, to hear safety experts and many residents of Front Royal tell it, too much of that smell could make you sick. 
But now the air is clean and clear here at the base of the Blue Ridge Mountains, 50 miles west of Washington, and the smell is gone. The rayon plant that caused the odor has been closed, shut down almost two weeks ago by state officials on the ground that the plant had become one of the worst and most recalcitrant polluters in the mid-Atlantic region.
The closing of the plant, operated by Avtex Fibers Inc. of Valley Forge, Pa., climaxed a five-year struggle that pitted Avtex against Federal and state agencies, with environmental advocates standing off to the side, alternately criticizing both sides for foot dragging. To many of the environmentalists, the struggle constitutes almost a textbook example of how political and economic concerns can slow progress in cleaning up the nation's air, water and soil. #450 Workers Lose Jobs More than 450 workers have been laid off as a result of the closing, with only a slim prospect that the plant will be reopened. State officals are concerned for the workers, but they argue that they had no choice but to close Avtex.
The plant's pollution, they say, went well beyond fumes coming out of the big brick Avtex smokestack that dominates the Front Royal skyline. They contend that Avtex also was a major polluter of underground water, that it repeatedly permitted toxic substances, including carcinogenic PCB's, to foul the nearby Shenandoah River and that it frequently ignored worker safety regulations.
According to state officials, Avtex has violated environmental and safety regulations more than 2,000 times over the past five years. Many of the violations, the officials say, came in direct contravention of court or government orders and resulted in the state's suing Avtex for almost $20 million, with about $8 million collected so far.
''Avtex showed a continuing contempt for the public as well as Virginia's environment,'' Richard N. Burton, the executive director of the state's Water Control Board, said after the board concluded Nov. 9 that the plant should be shut down because the company had repeatedly ignored regulations on discharging waste water.
 
'How Sweet It Is!'
David N. Crump Jr., the town lawyer for Front Royal's 12,000 residents, reached the same conclusion but expressed himself in more visceral terms.
''How sweet it is!'' he exulted after taking a deep whiff of the newly freshened air over Front Royal.
Still, Mr. Crump's view of Avtex, like that of many Front Royal residents, is a bit ambivalent.
''The company hasn't been a very good neighbor in recent years,'' he said. ''On the other hand, you don't like to see people put out of work. That hurts a lot, too.''
Avtex has said little about the closing. The company's chairman, John N. Gregg, charged in a statement released to the press that the Water Control Board's decision ''cannot be justified'' and was made so precipitously that it did not leave Avtex enough time to close the plant in an orderly, environmentally safe way.
''The action taken by the board has resulted in a complete and permanent shutdown and the attendant loss of hundreds of jobs,'' he added. ''It has accomplished absolutely nothing from an environmental perspective.''
State officials said Avtex was given every opportunity to make things right before the order went out.
Environmentalists contend that the company was given too many opportunities and that the plant should have been shut down years earlier.
 
'Negotiated and Negotiated'
''This is a classic case of state and Federal officials worrying more about jobs and the economy than about the environment,'' said Pat Lewis, whose home is on the banks of the Shenandoah, downstream from Front Royal, and who is active in an environmental group, the Commonwealth Coalition.
''I can't swim in the Shenandoah or eat its fish because of Avtex,'' she continued. ''They just negotiated and negotiated, and all the while the poisons were flowing out of the plant.''
At one point last year, Avtex moved to shut the plant on its own rather than carry out all the cleanup operations demanded by state and Federal officials. But then the Federal Government stepped in with a contract for a special type of rayon used in military and space rocket engines, a product made only by Avtex.
Environmentalists were infuriated. Since then, however, the Government has built up a stockpile of the special rayon and is now looking for a new contractor.
Once one of the country's largest rayon plants, Avtex is now something of a ghost site, its machinery silent, the liquid rayon left in pipes and tanks slowly hardening. And if the plant no longer spews pollution, its forced closing has struck a major economic blow to Front Royal. But over the long term many of the 450 workers who lost their jobs will probably be able to find work by commuting to the booming suburbs of Washington.
''We're hurting, hurting bad,'' said James V. Brinklow, an Avtex employee who also is business agent for the local unit of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union.
 
Chemicals Left on Site
State officials say that not only was the company not correcting faults but that it also left much dangerous material lying around when the plant was closed. In particular, the officials are worried about clearing a stockpile of volatile chemicals that went into the making of rayon, including carbon disulfide, which becomes a deadly gas when exposed to air. They say they have also found tons of toxic sludge and other byproducts scattered about the 400-acre plant site.
The plant, spread across bottomland next to the south fork of the Shenandoah, once employed nearly 3,500 workers. But in recent years, as the 50-year-old plant began to show its age, the work force steadily declined, dropping to fewer than 500 workers earlier this year.
''Avtex has milked that old plant for all they could,'' said William Poland, a former Avtex maintenance worker who lives across the river from the plant's sludge basins.
''They just took and took,'' he continued, ''and never put anything back in because the place had worn out its useful life after 50 years. They let the pollution get so bad that it poisoned the wells where I live and then the company had to buy out a lot of people or, in my case, had to agree to haul in water to a cistern every month.''
Mr. Poland does not know if his water deliveries will continue.
''But this much I do know,'' he said. ''I know that now I can get a fresh breath of air.''

HEADLINE: Two Sides of the Contemporary South: Racial Incidents and Black Progress

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 19

 BODY:
A rising tide of racial incidents across the South, including attacks and cross burnings, has provided a sour counterpoint to a decade of electoral progress by blacks.
Organizations that follow hate crimes and racial incidents say there has been a bewildering increase in racial incidents in the past year, and many experts say that what is happening here is part of a national trend that is as virulent elsewhere.
But others say the South, home of half the nation's blacks, remains the best baromoter of racial issues in the nation.
''We're finding a very great and vehement resurgence of racial incidents in the South,'' said Earl Shinhoster, the southeastern regional director for the N.A.A.C.P., whose office here was evacuated in August when a tear gas bomb delivered in a package went off. ''We're still putting out fires, still fighting the old battles over and over again, not because we want to, but because there's no choice.'' 
 
Bush Asked to Speak Out
Members of the Black Leadership Forum, composed of the heads of major black organizations, met with President Bush at the White House on Friday and expressed their concern about such incidents. The group, including Joseph Lowery, the head of the Southern Christian Leadership Council, and Coretta Scott King, asked the President to speak out on racial incidents, particularly those on college campuses.
Explanations of the incidents vary from one about increasing economic competition between whites and blacks in a slowing economy to others about the legacy of what critics see as the Reagan Administration's indifference to racial issues. Still, many of the incidents recall an earlier era in the South's racial history.
Clayton County, near Atlanta, has had eight incidents of vandalism or racial threats against blacks in the last few months. In Birmingham, Ala., several cross burnings last summer brought back memories of that city's bitter past.
Many of the incidents, like attempts to retain segregation at a swimming pool in Saluda, S.C., and a restaurant in North Augusta, S.C., received widespread publicity. Many others, including a fire in Florida where two wooden crosses were found at the house of a black family that was burned in Okaloosa County and the vandalism of black churches in Spartanburg, S.C., received only local attention.
Particularly alarming have been racial clashes at high schools in places like Little Rock, Ark.; Adamsville, Ala., and Valdosta, Ga.
 
Seen as National Problem
The increase in racial incidents is ''astonishing,'' said Morris Dees, who heads the Southern Poverty Law Center in Montgomery, Ala., which collects information on such incidents. There are no national statistics, in part because many jurisdictions do not keep records on such incidents.
But both Mr. Dees and Mr. Shinhoster see the problem as a national one, not a regional one, and no recent incident in the South has matched the killing of a 16-year-old black youth, Yusef Hawkins, in Brooklyn.
Blacks are often the most vehement in saying the racial climate of the North is every bit as troubled as that of the South. ''I'm not at all persuaded that race is closer to the bone in the South,'' said John Hope Franklin, a historian at Duke University. ''I've lived in New York, and it's awful in terms of race. I don't make any fine distinctions between North and South. When it comes to kicking blacks around, they can turn it into a fine art there as well as here.''
But others say that given the South's historic preoccupation with race and the fact that it is only two decades away from segregation, it flies in the face of history to think race relations would be the same throughout the country.
 
'Feelings Don't Vanish'
Charles Reagan Wilson, a professor of history and Southern studies at the University of Mississippi, said that because so much of the symbolism of the South has come to be associated with race - the Confederate flag, the white robes of the Ku Klux Klan and the antebellum world of the Old South - relations between whites and blacks are still extremely volatile. ''The South has gone through amazing changes in the last 20 years,'' he said, ''but the intensity of feelings doesn't vanish overnight.''
Similarly, Joel Williamson, a historian at the University of North Carolina whose book, ''The Crucible of Race,'' is regarded as one of the authoritative works on the subject in the United States, says the incidents occurring now are consistent with the racial history of the region.
He said social and economic change, like that buffeting the region, has often been accompanied by racial incidents. For example, he said, the election of David Duke, a former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, to the Louisiana Legislature in February from a district that is 99.6 percent white showed that racial themes still play a role in Southern politics.
''We're in a period of transition,'' said Dr. Williamson, ''and in the South when change breeds tension, the natural tendency is to point a finger at black folks. It's part of the psychology of the South that when things go wrong, we look to blacks as the cause.''
 
Unprecedented Electoral Gains
But the incidents also come at a time of unprecedented electoral gains by blacks in the South. In Virginia, L. Douglas Wilder's narrow victory made him the nation's first black elected Governor of a state, although it is still subject to a recount.
More than half the 7,226 black elected officials in the nation are in the South, with the largest numbers in Alabama and Mississippi, once the nation's bastions of segregation.
One need only see what is happening in Oxford, Miss., to see how much racial life in the South has changed. There the students, alumni and staff of the University of Mississippi, still remembered for the riots that attended the school's integration in 1962, have mobilized to raise money for a black football player, Lee Roy (Chucky) Mullins, who was left a quadriplegic by a football injury three weeks ago.
But the university is also a symbol of the region's crosscurrents. Only two months earlier, a white fraternity was suspended after a prank in which a member and a pledge were left naked, their bodies painted with racial slurs, at a nearby black college.
David Sansing, a history professor at the University of Mississippi, said the important thing about several racial incidents in the state this year that received widespread publicity was not so much that they occurred but that they generated so much criticism and official condemnation.
''The response is incredibly different from what happened before in Mississippi,'' he said. ''The battle against racism in Mississippi is never going to end, but, by God, at least Mississippi is battling it.''

HEADLINE: Rigid Ethics Code Is Urged In Los Angeles Government

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20

 BODY:
In a move that supporters hope will be a national model for cleaning up corruption, a special commission proposed a new ethics code today for Los Angeles's city government, calling it the toughest and clearest such measure in the country.
The code would require all elected officials, high-ranking civil servants and even candidates for office to disclose fully all investments, including their homes, and list the names of their stockbrokers. It would ban all outside earned income and honorariums, place tough controls on lobbying by former government employees and set up a strict three-level enforcement mechanism. City employees and officials who are lawyers would have to give up outside practices if they are full-time government employees or have decision-making responsibilities. Part-time employees and lower-level workers who are lawyers would not have to give up outside work. 
The proposed code would also partly finance election campaigns with public funds, as New York City does.
The proposal comes against the backdrop of growing public outrage over ethical lapses by public officials. In Washington, five prominent senators have been linked to efforts to prevent Federal officials from shutting down a failing savings and loan company owned by Charles H. Keating Jr., a wealthy Arizonan. And criminal investigations have begun into allegations of corruption at the Department of Housing and Urban Development under President Ronald Reagan. Toughest in Any City? The panel says that, taken together, its recommendations would be the most comprehensive ethics rules in any American city.
In New York, 12,000 of the 369,000-member work force must file disclosure forms, the Los Angeles panel said. The 12,000 are those who make $49,000 or more a year or have decision-making responsibilities.
A new ethics code in New York would permanently bar former officials from appearing before a city agency on behalf of an applicant if they had worked closely with the applicant on the same matter while in office. The current New York code bars former officials in that situation from appearing before agencies for three months. The new code is to take effect Jan. 1, but Mayor Koch and Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins favor a delay of six months to prevent a mass exodus of employees between administrations.
Chicago requires 7,000 of 41,000 employees to file disclosure forms. Those affected are those who earn $40,000 or more a year. Unlimited honorariums are permissible and must be reported within five busineess days.
In Los Angeles, Mayor Tom Bradley has been under investigation for his personal financial dealings and alleged influence peddling by former aides. Several investigations are under way, but no criminal charges have been brought.
 
'Banish the Gray'
''We have sought to banish the gray - to eliminate those areas of uncertainty that have become loopholes for those who wish to avoid compliance, and have become confusing traps for those who wish to comply,'' said the chairman of the Los Angeles panel, Geoffrey Cowan, former chairman of California Common Cause.
The measure will be offered first to the City Council in the form of an ordinance. It is given a good chance of being adopted, even if the Council should try to water it down, because California permits voters to make law directly through the ballot initiative. The seven-member panel indicated today it would start a signature drive to put the code on next November's ballot if the City Council did not adopt the bulk of it.
Initial reaction was mixed. Mayor Bradley, who appointed the panel last April a day after he won re-election, said he would do ''everything within my power'' to have the City Council pass the code, and would support the ballot initiative if necessary.
Mr. Bradley's difficulties include conflict-of-interest questions raised about his serving as a paid adviser to two banks that did business with the city. Mr. Cowan said the new rules would clearly have forbade such outside employment.
The chairman of a City Council committee that is also developing a new ethics code, Michael K. Woo, was lukewarm toward the panel recommendations. He said the Council would consider the recommendations and possibly work them into its own proposals.
 
Money From Outside
Soon after Mayor Bradley appointed the panel, it reconstituted itself as a private body to insure independence. Funds came from the Bank of America, Warner Brothers, 20th Century-Fox and other private sources.
In addition to Mr. Cowan, the members are Rabbi Allen I. Freehling, senior rabbi at University Synagogue here; Antonia Hernandez, president and general counsel of the Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund; Archbishop Roger Mahony of Los Angeles; Margaret M. Morrow, past president of the Los Angeles Bar Association; Gilbert T. Ray, a prominent lawyer, and Delbert E. Wong, a retired Superior Court judge.
Of the 30 recommendations, the one on financial disclosure is probably the most far reaching. Under the city's current vague and largely toothless ethics code, only 1,500 of the city's 45,000 employees are required to provide personal disclosure statements, and the statements require only limited information. No precise value of investments is required, and many items are excluded, such as companies or real estate that are more than three miles beyond the city limits.
One of the controversies swirling around Mayor Bradley concerns his partnership in a real estate venture in Riverside, Calif. One of his partners is Juanita St. John, appointed by him to head the city's Task Force for Africa/ Los Angeles Relations. That group received $400,000 in city funds, much of it unaccounted for. There have been no charges in the affair.
 
Drawing on Washington
The proposed code, drawing on a proposal by President Bush for Federal workers, would require city officials and full-time top decision-making employees to list the exact dollar amounts for all income and investments.
Any lobbyist who received more than $1,000 a year to influence lawmakers or city officials would have to file quarterly statements listing all money paid or received to influence official actions. City consultants receiving more than $10,000 or more a year would have to disclose ''relevant'' economic interests.
The code would ban top officials from taking any outside earned income or honorariums. Lower-ranking employees would be permitted to receive such income only when ''there is no reasonably foreseeable likelihood of a conflict of interest, loyalty or time.'' Moreover, top officials would have to divest all investments that might create a conflict of interest.
The panel urged that all former employees of the city be permanently barred from acting as lobbyists or advocates on the matters in which they were active while in government. Top officials would be prohibited from lobbying any department for one year after leaving city employment.
To enforce all this, a city ethics commission would be created and would be empowered to levy civil fines of up to $5,000.

HEADLINE: From Mere Defense to True Security

 BODY:
The Bush Administration seems to be verging on its most farsighted and momentous decision. Defense Secretary Cheney, with apparent White House support, has ordered the military services to produce projected spending cuts of $180 billion-plus in the early 1990's.
That won't amount to much if President Bush and Mr. Cheney are simply taking the services through a budget exercise. They may have no more in mind than pre-empting Congressional cuts that they may consider inevitable given the deficit and the changed military situation in Europe. Unbelievably, until the last few days Mr. Bush has been promising the services spending increases. 
But if Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney are really prepared for such large reductions, a creative policy transformation is at hand. At last, America's approach would change from preoccupation with defense defined strictly in military terms into a desire to meet the truest security concerns - like declining economic strength and the desirability of doing more to help nascent democracy in Eastern Europe. If the Administration has this broader concept of security in mind, then there's urgent need for three further elements.
Fast Planning. The Administration will have to move quickly, and make decisions now. Congress is about to approve Pentagon spending of $296 billion for fiscal 1990, which began Oct. 1. Mr. Cheney reportedly is willing to contemplate $10 billion less in fiscal 1991 and then cuts totaling $180 billion in the next three years. Congressional politics and service resistance will defeat this timetable unless he pushes hard this year.
Clear Strategy. The Administration needs to develop policy guidelines for each of the services. Otherwise, they will simply buy less of the same and Congress will have a field day chopping up the budget to fit its political needs. These reactions will produce the weakest possible forces at the highest possible cost. Containing these pressures will call for a persuasive strategy, focused on the primary threat to national security.
Is it still all-out conventional war with the Soviet Union? If so, the U.S. needs a thinned-out version of the existing services. Will future threats, more realistically, come from third world flareups? In that case, what's needed is compact forces ready to go in emergencies. In any event, the U.S. will have to eliminate redundant strategic nuclear forces like the B-2 bomber, at $500 million per copy.
Congressional Consultation. The Administration has to work with Congress immediately. Some legislators will want big cuts; others will resist them fiercely. Sam Nunn and Les Aspin, chairmen of the Senate and House armed services committees, can help create political support, if they're involved from the start in the planning of security strategy and legislative tactics.
World events present the Administration with an extraordinary opportunity to think big, and creatively. If Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney are serious about reducing Pentagon spending as reported, they can establish a new concept of national security.
