HEADLINE: How to Reduce Military Spending

BYLINE: By Lawrence J. Korb; Lawrence J. Korb directs the Brookings Institution's Center for Public Policy Education.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For some time now, there has been no mistaking the direction in U.S. military spending.
Since 1985, the budget for the Defense Department has fallen by about 15 percent, after inflation. Last week, the Defense Secretary, Dick Cheney, bowed to the inevitable and agreed to recommend cutting the fiscal 1991 budget by an additional 3 percent to 5 percent and to reduce military spending by about $180 billion over the next five years.
Also clear is the cause of the decline: Gramm-Rudman-Gorbachev. The huge Federal budget deficits, the perception of fraud, waste and mismanagement in the Pentagon and Mikhail Gorbachev's replacement of the Brezhnev Doctrine with the Sinatra Doctrine of national self-determination have combined to destroy the defense consensus. 
Not so clear is what type of strategy and force structure will or should emerge from this abridged military budget. Initially, the Pentagon tried to keep alive all the major programs by stretching out production schedules. But this approach, which greatly increases unit costs, has been harshly criticized.
To his credit, Mr. Cheney accepted the new fiscal situation and did attempt to kill some major weapons systems. But the failure of the Bush Administration to produce a national security policy has made it impossible for Mr. Cheney to present a coherent strategy to justify his reductions. Thus, his effort last spring to cancel the V-22 Osprey tilt rotor aircraft and the F-14D fighter was easily defeated by a Congress more worried about jobs than about a coherent and efficient military strategy.
Fortunately, the outlines of the post-containment era are already clear. We know enough about our military needs for the next decade to structure spending so that we gain greater security for less money. The outlines of this new era are contained in the proposals put forth at the strategic arms reduction talks and the negotiations on conventional forces in Europe.
At Start, both sides have agreed to reduce the number of strategic nuclear warheads to 6,000. Pending the completion of these talks, the U.S. should defer deployment of such systems as the rail-mobile MX missile, the single-warhead Midgetman ICBM, the B-2 bomber, additional Trident submarines and the Strategic Defense Initiative. It should continue research and development in these areas, however, as a hedge against a breakdown of the talks.
The research and development would consist of testing the 13 B-2 bombers already paid for, providing modest funding for the Midgetman, designing a new smaller ballistic missile submarine and continuing S.D.I. as a research program. Such a strategy could reduce projected defense spending by about $100 billion over the next five years.
Progress at the talks on conventional forces should allow the Administration to begin drastic reductions in forces defending Europe. Now, the U.S. is committed to having 10 divisions, 100 tactical air squadrons and a Marine brigade in Europe within 10 days of a Warsaw Pact mobilization. If the negotiations are concluded along lines already agreed to, the U.S. would have a minimum of three to four months to respond to a Soviet buildup. This extra warning time would allow the Pentagon to cut its active Army divisions and tactical air forces in half, while eliminating the amphibious lift for a Marine brigade.
Moreover, the more benign international environment should allow the Navy to reduce the tempo of its overseas deployments and return to a traditional force of 12 carrier battle groups, from 14 now.
Reductions of these land, air and sea forces would save relatively little in the short run. But by the middle of the 1990's, the savings would add up to about $50 billion a year in today's dollars. However, during this transition period, the Pentagon could save about $20 billion a year by slowing down modernization of land, sea and air forces.
Since the services just completed the most expensive and thorough modernization in history, there is no need to rush into expensive programs like the advanced tactical fighter at $100 million a plane, the Amraam missile at $500,000 each, the LHX helicopter at $35 million a copy, Burke class destroyers at $1 billion each and Sea Wolf submarines at $1.5 billion each. These programs could easily be kept in research and development, pending the outcome of the talks on conventional forces.
Together, these steps could save at least the $180 billion that Secretary Cheney hopes to save by 1994. But nothing will happen unless the Administration takes a tough stand.
Indeed, early indications point to a scramble by the military services to protect their own bureaucratic interests at the expense of the national interest. For example, the Air Force is reported to have proposed saving the B-2 Stealth bomber and the Amraam missile by stretching out production while cutting out purchases of the highly effective F-16 fighter.
Neither the nation nor the Pentagon can afford to stumble along trying to sustain a $400 billion military on a $300 billion and declining budget. Secretary Cheney has taken a bold and logical first step. He needs to follow this by imposing a coherent strategic vision and complementary force structure on the Pentagon.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: OP-ED

LENGTH: 761 words

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
A President Beholden

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
By vetoing the foreign aid appropriations bill, President Bush has made clear his blind fealty to the right-wing zealots who he fears will turn against him if he retreats an inch - even an imaginary inch -from his cruel stand against abortion.
His veto also makes it clear that he has closed his eyes and his mind to the political trend running against the anti-abortion position - a trend underlined once again by three changed votes in the Senate.
In vetoing, moreover, one item in a bill containing many, he has sabotaged many of his own political interests. Included in the appropriations bill, and going down with the veto, were aid for Israel and Egypt, the emergency assistance for Poland just promised to Lech Walesa, and support for the hard-pressed Government of El Salvador, to which the Bush Administration has committed itself. Only special legislation, if it can be had from an angered Congress, can restore these items. 
So it's fair to ask: Is there no limit to what George Bush will do to placate the zealots peering over his shoulder?
Ironically, the bill he vetoed with such disastrous consequences did not contain even one dollar for abortion, in any country or under any circumstances. What produced Mr. Bush's veto was only $15 million for the U.N. Population Fund, which devotes itself to badly needed family planning -not including abortion - to help stem the worldwide population explosion.
Once, the United States was properly a leader in pointing to the dangers of rising world population, which threatens to overwhelm economic growth and an already endangered environment. But under Ronald Reagan, as obsequious as Mr. Bush in the service of abortion extremists, U.S. aid to the U.N. fund was cut off, as well as any aid that might go to abortion services anywhere.
That left Washington in an untenable position. It could not maintain the strong position, much less the lead, against mushrooming population growth that it once had taken if it was unwilling to spend any money for that purpose. To put an end to that dilemma, and to restore the nation to its rightful role in the population effort, the Senate voted earlier this year to renew aid - the $15 million -to the U.N. fund.
The fund, however, supports population programs in China, which authorizes abortion and sterilization -though none of the U.N. money is spent for those purposes. To avoid the false charge that the $15 million would support Chinese abortion services, even indirectly, the Senate provided that none of the U.S. money could be used to aid China; and that it must be kept in a separate account that Washington could audit at any time.
That did not satisfy anti-abortion fanatics to whom Mr. Bush listens; they charged that the $15 million was abortion money. In the House, Representative Christopher Smith, Republican of New Jersey, proposed an amendment to leave it to the President to determine whether the $15 million actually would be contributed to the U.N. Though that in effect gave Mr. Bush a line-item veto, the House voted 219 to 203 to accept the Smith amendment.
Proponents of family planning, notably the Population Institute in Washington, fought back; and the Senate, given another vote, defeated the Smith amendment, 52 to 44. Crucial help came from three changed conservative votes, cast by Senators Alan Simpson of Wyoming and Pete Wilson of California, Republicans, and John Shelby of Alabama, Democrat.
All had previously voted against the $15 million. All must have been well aware of the November election returns in three states that gave evidence of the pro-choice trend in American politics. Senator Wilson, significantly, will be running for governor of California in 1990.
The House then reversed itself and killed the Smith amendment, 207 to 200. By voice vote, it also added the strong provision that if any U.S. money was spent for family planning in China, or for abortion-related services in any country, the entire contribution to the U.N. would have to be refunded.
Family planning advocates, with good reason, believed Mr. Bush had been left no grounds for a veto. But they reckoned without his puzzling and shortsighted belief that right-wing zealotry is the dominant political force in America. Ignoring the demonstrable need for worldwide family planning, he declared the accounting requirements unacceptable, asserted without evidence that the U.N. Population Fund previously had violated U.S. restrictions, and wielded his veto stamp.
Was that prudence? Kinder or gentler? No, it was just outrageous.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1, Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1284 words

HEADLINE: $3.9 Million, and Friends' Trust, Vanish in a Betrayal in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON

 BODY:
Every neighborhood has its givers and takers. In the Canarsie and Flatlands sections of Brooklyn, for years Elaine Stouber was a giver. She dispensed political favors and hinted that she had friends in high places who could get things done. She ran a neighborhood charity and always seemed to be there when people needed help.
So, to many of her neighbors, it was unfathomable last month when the 62-year old woman and her 61-year old husband, Frank Aprigliano, admitted in Federal Court in Manhattan that for years they had secretly been takers, too.
The couple pleaded guilty to defrauding at least 200 of their friends and neighbors of at least $3.9 million in what prosecutors said was a fake investment scheme. They could be sent to prison for as long as 25 years when they are sentenced by Federal Judge Robert W. Sweet next month. 
In the Brooklyn neighborhoods that Mrs. Stouber worked in the manner of an old-style politician, ''Everybody was shocked at first and everybody carried a sense of disbelief because of who she was,'' said Herbert E. Berman, the City Councilman from the area.
But among the middle-class people who handed over tens of thousands of dollars of their savings to the woman who promised them as much as 200 percent a year in interest, disbelief has given way to more powerful feelings. These days, some of them said in interviews, they are coping with the knowledge that all their money is gone, and with it, some of their trust in people.
 
'Such an Actor, a Performer'
''I don't understand how somebody could be such an actor, a performer, to be so sweet and take away your livelihood with a smile,'' said Miriam Torren, a Brooklyn schoolteacher who gave Mrs. Stouber $76,000 and then persuaded relatives to put in another $70,000 so they they could share in the bounty that she felt sure was coming.
Their experiences, investigators said, provide a snapshot of the way confidence schemes work. But theirs is also a story of how, in the city of gilded shops and epic Wall Street deals, some New Yorkers feel sidelined in life's game of opportunity.
Eileen Drucker, a Flatlands housewife who coaxed nine friends to invest $250,000, remembers that Mrs. Stouber told her she had a special arrangement with an unnamed ambassador who was permitting her a once-in-a-lifetime chance to invest in a ''no risk,'' high-profit venture. The money would be used to rebuild the city of Brussels, she said. Brussels, the Belgian city, is in no particular need of rebuilding, and none of the investors interviewed mentioned hearing any further explanation.
Early investors received receipts and huge monthly interest payments that seemed to promise more. Only later did they realize that the money had come from other people's deposits.
When Mrs. Drucker worried, she said, Mrs. Stouber belittled her fears and told her the rich got rich with such inside deals. She warned her, Mrs. Drucker said, that if she told too many people about their special deal, it would end. ''They didn't want 'little people' in on it,'' Mrs. Drucker said, ''because this was how the rich stayed rich.''
Many of the would-be investors said they now know there was no ambassador. Part of the fault is theirs, they said, for wishing Mrs. Stouber's stories were true.
''I thought: 'Maybe it is too good to be true,' '' said Naomi Slomovitz, who lost $35,000 that she and her husband had saved in 28 years of marriage. ''But I said, 'Maybe this is the opportunity of my life.' ''
Mrs. Stouber's stories seemed plausible because of who she seemed to be, said some who were drawn into the scheme. For years, she was an aide to Abe Stark, the Pitkin Avenue clothing store owner who became City Council President and Brooklyn Borough President.
 
Abe Stark's Political Surrogate
When Mr. Stark died in 1972, Councilman Berman said, Mrs. Stouber became Mr. Stark's surrogate in the community. She ran Abe Stark Philanthropies, a charitable organization he had organized, and helped with political tasks at the Thomas Jefferson Democratic Club.
Often, she was at the arm of one politician or another as they made their way through the old-age homes and kaffeeklatsches of Brooklyn. In her living room was a large photograph of herself with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, Mrs. Drucker said, and Mrs. Stouber would often say she had a direct line to the Governor's mansion in Albany. A spokesman for the Governor, Darren Dopp, said Mr. Cuomo would not say whether he knew Mrs. Stouber.
The tale of the ambassador with his special deal seemed plausible, too, some of those who lost money said. Mr. Aprigliano, Mrs. Stouber's second husband, worked for 34 years at the United Nations until he retired in 1983. He would often arrange tours for neighbors. The neighbors were vague about what his job had been. Last week, the United Nations public information office said Mr. Aprigliano had been a clerical worker in its publications office.
Mrs. Torren said Mrs. Stouber had seemed to focus on the concerns of others. She had worried about a Canarsie woman with a disabled child. She had offered help to another who did not have enough money to repair her dilapidated house. ''She would take my face in her hand,'' Mrs. Torren said, ''and say, 'Don't worry.' ''
 
'We Each Had Our Dreams'
''We were stupid, we were naive, and a little bit greedy too,'' Mrs. Drucker said. ''But we each had our dreams and she knew the dreams that we each had and she played us like a fine violin.''
Many of those who see themselves as victims of Mrs. Stouber and Mr. Aprigliano are hoping the two get stern sentences when they appear again in court on Dec. 14. The couple have said they do not have the money to make restitution. They refused to be interviewed, but their lawyer, Kenneth J. Kaplan, said they were hoping for leniency because they, too, were victims.
He said they had been abused by confidence-scheme operators and loansharks, and he said their involvement with their neighbors had amounted to nothing more than borrowing and ''redistributing'' money.
The United States postal inspector who investigated the case, Gregory Rhatigan, dismissed the idea that Mrs. Stouber and her husband were victims, and he said the Government had no evidence that they had been involved with loansharks.
 
Joined Financial Fax Network
But he agreed with one point that Mr. Kaplan made. The lawyer said his clients had heard about the fortunes being made in deals in the early 1980's and had decided to join in the action. After Mr. Aprigliano retired, they obtained a fax machine and joined a network of people who passed information back and forth about huge commodity and currency transactions.
The idea, Mr. Rhatigan said, was to broker deals and make multimillion-dollar commissions. ''Frank and Elaine thought this was going to give them the gold ring,'' Mr. Rhatigan said.
While they waited from 1983 to 1987, Mr. Rhatigan said, they took money. Perhaps, he said, they believed at first that they would soon pay it back. But no deal ever came through. Mr. Rhatigan said that while he was working on the Stouber case he interviewed 20 other people involved with the fax network. None of them had ever completed a deal either.
Eventually, Mr. Rhatigan said, Mrs. Stouber and her husband invented the ambassador with his Brussels project and crossed the line into fraud.
The people who handed over their money and their trust are not likely ever to fully understand what happened. Mrs. Torren said that as the scheme was coming undone, she went to the woman she had always respected and asked her to explain her betrayal.
The answer from Mrs. Stouber, she said, was ''I was more desperate than you.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Economy
Government help to the electronics industry is needed to avert dire economic consequences, two studies warned. The reports by the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors and the Economic Policy Institute said that the U.S. was falling behind foreign competitors in key areas of semiconductors and telecommunications and would suffer a loss of jobs as a result. [Page D1.] 
The International Trade Commission has ruled that American manufacturers of telecommunications equipment have experienced substantial damage because small-business telephone systems from Japan and Taiwan are being sold in this country at unfairly low prices. The ruling paves the way for countervailing duties to be imposed on the imports. [D1.]
Lawyers for the former head of Lincoln Savings and Loan tried to get the House Banking Committee to permit Charles Keating to invoke his Fifth Amendment rights against compelled self-incrimination without appearing before the committee, but the overture was rejected, House staff members said. [D1.]
 
 
 
Companies
Bankers and their regulators say rules being considered by a committee of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants could cause bank earnings to fluctuate more widely with changes in interest rates and thus disrupt the bond market. [D3.]
The Navy is reviewing allegations of procurement irregularities involving I.B.M. to determine whether the computer concern should be temporarily suspended from Navy contracts, a spokesman said. The company said such action would be ''unwarranted and inappropriate.'' [D2.]
Dun & Bradstreet agreed to buy Management Science America for $333 million in cash. [D4.]
Eastern Airlines has resumed talks with AMR about selling Eastern's Latin American routes and other assets. [D4.]
Texas Instruments will take a special charge of $55 million against fourth-quarter profits and eliminate 1,500 jobs. [D3.]
Attorneys handling the personal bankruptcy suits of William and Nelson Hunt and their creditors averted the scheduled liquidation of one former billioniare's estate and paved the way for both to be reorganized. [D3.]
McCaw Cellular Communications sweetened its bid for Lin Broadcasting by offering $150 a share in cash for 22.5 million shares, or 46 percent, of Lin's stock. [D22.]
 
 
 
Markets
Stocks fell broadly, battered by weakness in military issues. The Dow slumped 20.62 points, to 2,632.04. [D8.]
Treasury securities prices rose modestly, as market participants failed to follow through on a rally that began during overnight trading in the Far East. [D17.]
A debate has been reignited over whether the futures industry is too rife with cronyism to regulate itself because of the testimonies of past and current leaders of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in support of a trader who faces disciplinary action. [D1.]
Crude oil prices advanced, bolstered by the large number of actual deliveries against the spot December futures contract. [D18.]
The dollar fell against European currencies but rose against the yen. [D18.]

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Behind the Military Stock Selloff

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

 BODY:
The outlook for military contractors has grown steadily dimmer since the Reagan Administration's arms buildup peaked in 1985. Still, the news over the weekend that the Pentagon is contemplating deeper spending cuts yesterday sent investors bailing out of virtually all aerospace, shipbuilding and military-technology stocks as Wall Street bet that from a financial perspective at least, the cold war might be over.
Stocks of many companies, including some that until now had been relatively resistant to the decline in military-related issues, fell by as much as 10 percent of their value, and analysts said there were few buyers even at the depressed prices.
Bond prices rose yesterday as traders viewed the reports of military spending cutbacks as a way to reduce the Federal deficit, which in turn would reduce the Treasury's need to issue securities to raise money. [Page D17.] Hardest-Hit Military Stocks Among the hardest-hit stocks yesterday were General Dynamics, which fell $4.875, to $44.125; Litton Industries, $8.125, to $76.50; Martin Marietta $4.50, to $39.50; Lockheed $3.625, to $35.875, and Raytheon $6.75, to $68.625. Northrop fell 87.5 cents, to $17.625. Other losers were Grumman, down $1, to $17.125; McDonnell Douglas $1.125, to $68.25; Rockwell International $1.50, to $21.375, and Tenneco, the parent of Newport News Shipbuilding, $1.25, to $58.25. 
The Standard & Poor's aerospace index dropped 15.06, or 4.1 percent, yesterday, to 348.60.
The only major contractor to buck the trend was the Boeing Company, which relies on commercial aircraft orders for more than 70 percent of its sales and which on Sunday reached a tentative agreement to end a nearly seven-week-old strike. Boeing was up $1.50 a share, to $59.50. The rise reflected Boeing's huge backlog of orders for jetliners.
Some analysts said that the market might have overreacted, and that a few companies continued to show promise in an age of rapid change in the relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union. For example, E-Systems Inc., a Dallas company that makes surveillance equipment used to monitor compliance with arms-reduction treaties, is widely believed to have bright financial prospects. But even its stock was dragged down with those of other contractors yesterday, ending at $29.75, off $4.
For the most part, contractors now face the likelihood that almost every major weapons project will be reduced in size or stretched out, with some programs facing the possibility of being canceled.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney indicated on Sunday, for example, that the Pentagon might be willing to buy fewer than the 132 B2 Stealth bombers it wants from Northrop. The B2 accounts for about half of Northrop's revenues.
Jerry Cantwell, an analyst at Wertheim Schroder, said that across-the-board cuts affecting the size or scheduling of most major weapons programs are more likely than any outright cancellations. Cancellation usually means ending existing jobs or forgoing the creation of new ones, something that most members of Congress strenuously resist when it comes to arms makers operating in their districts.
''Congressional district politics will have as much to do with the choices as national security needs,'' Mr. Cantwell said.
But keeping programs alive on a smaller scale or at a reduced rate of production also carries a financial penalty for the companies involved as they fail to reach the levels of manufacturing efficiency they had planned when making their original bids. Less-efficient production invariably means that the per-unit cost of a program also rises, meaning the Pentagon not only gets less but gets less for every dollar it spends.
Many analysts believe the Air Force will now scale back or further delay its Advanced Tactical Fighter program to build the next generation of fighter planes. A group led by Northrop and McDonnell Douglas is competing against a team led by Lockheed, Boeing and General Dynamics in the design and development stage of the program, with the winner to produce a fleet of fighters originally estimated to be worth at least $35 billion.
Both teams have invested at least $500 million of their own funds in the project, above and beyond the $691 million development contract received by each team. The teams have always known that one of them would lose despite the heavy financial investment, but now even the winner faces the prospect of a production contract that could be far less lucrative than once planned.
That risk and others that sent investors fleeing from military-related stocks yesterday have been apparent for months or years. But, as Wolfgang H. Demisch of UBS Securities said, ''This is a case of a variety of factors crystallizing.''
News that the Pentagon is drafting plans to slash its previously proposed budgets by 5 percent annually for three years starting in fiscal 1992 came after several weeks in which the postwar political system in Eastern Europe continued to go through convulsions, suggesting a fundamental easing of East-West relationships.
Moreover, Mr. Demisch said, the perils of military contracting were made clear to investors on Friday, when Lockheed announced a huge $300 million charge on a contract that is worth only $600 million.
And earlier, both the Ford Motor Company and the General Electric Company, both of which had been mentioned as possible acquirers of one of the major military contractors, took actions that suggested they are not interested in becoming bigger players in the industry. Ford moved to acquire Jaguar P.L.C. of Britain, and General Electric said that it would buy back up to $10 billion of its stock in coming years.
Most of the companies whose stocks were hit the hardest rely heavily or exclusively on Pentagon contracts. General Dynamics, for example, gets more than 80 percent of its revenues from military programs. Its most profitable program is the F-16 fighter plane, and the Air Force has already drafted budget proposals for 1992-94 that provide for a lower rate of F-16 purchases. Cuts in conventional forces stationed in Europe could also bring cuts in the company's M-1 tank program.
But even diversified companies like Rockwell, whose military business has been overshadowed in recent years by its electronics and other commercial businesses, and Tenneco, whose Newport News, Va., shipyard is a major builder of submarines, were tarred by yesterday's selloff.
Phillip R. Brannon of Merrill Lynch said that while the perception that military contracting is a troubled business is perfectly valid, the widespread selloff might not have been totally justified.
''Have things changed so dramatically from a week ago that stocks should be down so sharply, that you should mark off the value of Raytheon by 10 percent?'' he asked. ''I'm not sure, but it's possible the market is overreacting.''

LENGTH: 1700 words

HEADLINE: Supporters of a Trader Anger Industry Critics

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Testimony by past and present leaders of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in support of a prominent trader who faces disciplinary action has reignited a debate over whether the industry is too rife with cronyism to regulate itself as it does now.
The trader, Brian P. Monieson, a former chairman of the exchange, is accused of inadequately supervising two employees who in turn are accused of cheating customers. He maintains his innocence. The accusations against him are being considered at a disciplinary hearing by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which oversees the Merc and is pressing the cases against the two employees. The hearing resumes Tuesday.
 
An Unusual Arrangement
Among those who have agreed to testify on Mr. Monieson's behalf are Clayton K. Yeutter, the Secretary of Agriculture and a president of the mercantile exchange when Mr. Monieson was chairman, and Leo Melamed, the chairman of the exchange's executive committee. Jerrold E. Salzman, the exchange's outside legal counsel, has agreed to defend Mr. Monieson in what even exchange officials acknowledge is an unusual arrangement. 
The case has already led Thomas F. Eagleton, the former Missouri Senator and one of the mercantile exchange's most prominent board members, to resign in protest. In a rare public airing of dissent that is frequently only muttered, Mr. Eagleton said he was fed up because the futures exchanges are insiders' clubs with far too much leeway to regulate themselves.
''The Brian Monieson case proves that self-regulation is a 14-carat myth,'' Mr. Eagleton, now a lawyer in St. Louis, said in a telephone interview last week. ''It proves that when an insider gets in trouble, the other insiders will come to his aid and rescue.''
The case is only the latest source of trouble for the commodity futures industry. Earlier this year, an F.B.I. ''sting'' operation led to indictments against 48 traders on the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade. And the Board of Trade suffered another blow to its image when it intervened in the pricing of soybean contracts after a large Italian grain merchant appeared to have cornered the market. Critics charged that the Board of Trade was seeking to bail out powerful members who had entered into contracts that required them to deliver soybeans.
These cases have served to intensify criticism of the commodities industry that has been brewing for years among investors and economists.
The Monieson case has increased concerns on Capitol Hill about the industry's ability to police itself. Even before this case came up, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, has been pushing legislation that would mandate stricter oversight of the exchanges by Federal regulators.
Critics of the exchanges find it a conflict of interest for important industry officials, who under the futures industry's system of self-regulation are responsible for enforcing commodities laws, to testify in Mr. Monieson's defense. Mr. Eagleton particularly objected to permitting Mr. Salzman, who frequently advises the board on complex disciplinary matters, to defend Mr. Monieson.
At least one industry official who was scheduled to testify on Mr. Monieson's behalf has already canceled his appearance ''to avoid even the appearance of impropriety.'' He is Robert K. Wilmouth, president of the National Futures Association, which helps police the industry.
 
Propriety Questioned
Specialists in government ethics, including people who have not been involved with the case, questioned the propriety of Mr. Yeutter's testimony. They note that while the Department of Agriculture is technically separate from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, both agencies are part of the executive branch of Government.
''Why do we have one member of the executive branch undermining what another member is doing?'' asked Alan Morrison, director of the Public Citizen Litigation Group, a Washington-based public-interest organization, who was asked to comment. ''Either Yeutter shuts up and lets his friend swing or goes to the support of his friend and resigns his job.''
But the former and current mercantile exchange officials involved say they can justify their positions. Mr. Yeutter, who spoke through an aide, has said he is acting as a private citizen, testifying only to Mr. Monieson's good character. Mr. Melamed, who declined to be interviewed, has said he considers his testimony to be that of a private citizen acting as a character witness for a long-time friend. Mr. Salzman did not return a telephone call, but mercantile exchange officials have said that contrary to Mr. Eagleton's view, Mr. Salzman is not technically an enforcement official and therefore is free to defend Mr. Monieson.
 
Witnesses Defended
And Mr. Yeutter has backing for his decision to get involved. His testimony ''will support the legal process rather than undermine it,'' said Leonard Garment, a White House counsel under President Nixon who is now a Washington lawyer. Such testimony, Mr. Garment said, ''permits people to have a full defense, which includes character testimony.'' Mr. Garment added that there was considerable precedent. He noted that when Alger Hiss was tried for perjury in the 1950's, two Supreme Court justices testified as character witnesses.
Exchange officials have also raised questions about Mr. Eagleton's motives. One board member, who asked that his name not be used, said Mr. Eagleton had become a critic only this year, after more than two years on the board, when the possibility arose that board members might be sued by disgruntled investors concerned about Justice Department accusations of fraud on the exchange floor. In fact, this board member noted, Mr. Eagleton began showing up at certain exchange meetings with his own private attorney.
''Through April there was not a peep of a problem,'' the board member said, adding: ''Eagleton is trying to make much more out of this than it is. There is a strong record of people in important public positions acting as character witnesses.''
 
'Circling the Wagons'
Mr. Eagleton was so disturbed by the Monieson case that he released a resignation letter in which he accused the Merc board of ''rallying around the flag'' and ''circling the wagons'' to defend Mr. Monieson and of regularly engaging in ''non-Lincolnian decisions of insiders, by insiders and for insiders.''
He followed that with a blistering attack on the board, published on the Op-Ed Page of The New York Times on Nov. 14.
Mr. Eagleton said the Monieson was but the final straw.
Last spring, when a special committee empaneled to consider trading-practice changes issued its report, Mr. Eagleton released a separate conclusion calling for tighter Federal regulation of the futures business. In board meetings, he had already been an outspoken critic of the exchange's ''open outcry'' system of trading, which he viewed as inviting abuse, and of what he considered the exchange's lax training requirements for brokers and feeble enforcement efforts.
 
None Share Concern
At the board's meeting this month, Mr. Eagleton immediately voiced his concern about having exchange officials testify on Mr. Monieson's behalf. According to the former senator, none of the board members shared his concern.
Mr. Eagleton said he then attempted to learn whether the exchange was pursuing its own disciplinary action against either Mr. Monieson or his firm, GNP Commodities Inc. Board officials refused to comment.
Finally, Mr. Eagleton pressed the board on what he considered to be the most glaring conflict: permitting Mr. Salzman to defend Mr. Monieson. In Mr. Eagleton's view, Mr. Salzman was attempting to wear two hats, as an exchange prosecutor and as a defense lawyer.
 
Dissent Is Rare
In a business known for rarely breaking ranks, at least one industry executive thinks the mercantile exchange leadership has mishandled the case. ''The people who are responsible for exchanges and self-regulation have to be awfully careful not to get too closely attached to an individual,'' said James H. Lindau, president of the Minneapolis Grain Exchange.
But such dissenting views within the industry are rare. And one industry defender goes so far as to suggest that the Monieson case demonstrates how well self-regulation can work.
''The system works so effectively that they even get the heavyweights,'' said Philip McBride Johnson, a former chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission who is now a New York attorney, referring to Mr. Monieson. ''If the people who are prominent in the business were never touched by the regulatory process, I would be more concerned.''
Mr. Monieson could be banned from the futures business if the C.F.T.C. wins its case.
 
Started as a Trader
For years, the 53-year-old trader has been a prominent member of the mercantile exchange. A native of Chicago's North Side, Mr. Monieson started in the business in the early 1970's as a pork-belly trader with $50,000 in capital, just above the minimum necessary to trade. In 1973, he and a childhood friend, Myron Rosenthal, formed GNP and were soon dealing in virtually all the mercantile exchange's trading areas. In 1983, Mr. Monieson was elected chairman of the exchange and he served for two years.
Along the way, however, both GNP and Mr. Monieson have had run-ins with enforcement officials. The current C.F.T.C. charges relate to Mr. Monieson's supervision of two former GNP salesmen, Norman R. Furlett and Ira P. Greenspon. In brief, the commission charges that the two salesmen diverted profitable trades to their personal accounts while steering losing trades to customers and that Mr. Monieson knew about the wrongdoing but failed to stop it. Mr. Monieson, who denies the accusations, declined to be interviewed.
Earlier, GNP was reprimanded or fined on six occasions by the Merc's enforcement department for violating various exchange rules. And in 1986, Mr. Monieson's personal trading positions became so large that at one point the exchange fined him $10,000 for exceeding speculative limits. It apparently was the only time someone who had served as exchange chairman had been disciplined.

HEADLINE: Studies Ask Electronics Aid by U.S.

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Just as the Bush Administration is reported to be planning cutbacks in support for high technology, two studies issued today warned that the nation faced dire economic consequences unless the Government more actively helped the electronics industry.
The studies - by the National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors and the Economic Policy Institute, a nonprofit Washington research organization started by economists who favor Government involvement in industry - said that the United States was falling behind foreign competitors in key areas of semiconductors and telecommunications.
Both urged programs to develop consumer electronics products and nationwide high-speed telecommunications networks.
 
Loss of Jobs Seen
''The jobs of millions of Americans are at stake'' if the semiconductor industry is not preserved, said Ian Ross, chairman of the semiconductor advisory committee. The Economic Policy Institute estimated that the failure of American industry to participate in high-definition television and the related industries of semiconductors, computers and video displays, would result in a trade deficit from those industries alone of $225 billion in the year 2010 and the loss of two million jobs. 
The reports have long been in the planning and were not a direct response to the recent reports that the Administration was thinking of cutting Defense Department programs that support the development of high-definition television and semiconductors. It is not certain yet that those cuts will be made.
 
Opposition of Officials Cited
Still, opponents of such cutbacks think the studies will help preserve financing for high-technology initiatives. On the other hand, they acknowledge that the opposition of some key officials in the Administration to helping specific industries could mean that many of the more ambitious recommendations would be disregarded.
The National Advisory Committee on Semiconductors, a group of industry leaders and Government officials set up by last year's trade law, said in its report that the nation's computer chip industry was rapidly losing ground to Japanese competitors.
''Every trend you look at, if you read our report, is in the wrong direction,'' said Dr. Ross, the chairman, who is the president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories.
Even more serious, he added, was the condition of the many small companies that made the equipment and materials used to produce computer chips. Dr. Ross, who spoke at a Washington news conference that could be heard by telephone, said that the industry would fall a generation of technology behind the Japanese unless corrective action was taken in the next two years.
The committee's report was delivered to the White House earlier this month and not officially made public, although a copy of it was obtained and reported on previously. The lack of official release prompted critics to charge that the report was being suppressed because of Administration opposition to a Federal role in industrial development. But Dr. Ross denied that the report's release was delayed. He said he expected the report to prompt ''debate and discussion'' within the Administration.
The study calls for an effort to establish a Consumer Electronics Capital Corporation, which would provide low-cost, long-term capital to fledgling consumer electronics companies and technologies.
 
Billions in Commercial Debt
The capital corporation would raise hundreds of millions of dollars in equity from industry, institutional investors and state and local governments, and would also raise billions of dollars in commercial debt. The Federal Government would not contribute money directly, but would provide ''pledges of support'' to help the corporation get lower interest rates when borrowing.
Dr. Ross said such pledges might be loan guarantees or something less. Robert Cohen, a consultant to the committee, said the investment corporation might work like the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Student Loan Marketing Association, which are private entities with some implicit Government support.
The report also calls for increasing the financing of Sematech, the semiconductor research consortium, by $100 million a year immediately and by $800 million over three years. The purpose would be to step up Sematech's role in helping the developers of equipment and materials used in chip-making. Sematech's financing now amounts to $200 million a year, half of which comes from the Federal Government and half from industry.
 
General Steps Urged
The report also calls for various general steps to help reduce the cost of capital, to improve education and to transfer to industry some work being done by the National Laboratories related to X-ray lithography, a technique for making advanced chips.
The Economic Policy Institute said in its report that American telecommunications policies had been dictated more by antitrust and rate regulation considerations than by the concerns of international competitiveness.
The industry is fragmented, with different telephone companies and different state regulatory commissions making it difficult to plan nationwide improvements, it added.
''The existing policy framework impedes constructive responses to the challenges posed by foreign competition, the emergence of digital technologies and the convergence of computers and communications,'' said the report, which was written by Mr. Cohen, a New York-based consultant, and Kenneth Donow, an adviser to the National Center for Telecommunication and Information Policy. It urges creation of a national Department of Communications to coordinate policies.

HEADLINE: U.S. Securities Advance in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose modestly in quiet trading yesterday, as market participants failed to follow-through on a rally that began during overnight trading in the Far East.
Activity in Japan and in the futures pits in Chicago was heavy Sunday night, as traders snapped up securities after news reports of huge potential cuts by the United States in military spending in the wake of developments in Eastern Europe.
As trading shifted around the globe, however, doubts about whether those cost reductions would have a beneficial impact on America's budget deficit began to surface. In the wake of those doubts, Treasury prices began to slide. 
''The Cheney bounce is over,'' one Treasury bill trader said, referring to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Mr. Cheney made public over the weekend plans to cut $180 million in military spending from the Federal budget from 1992-94.
''It is hard to believe that cuts in defense spending will translate into a dollar-for-dollar cut in the budget deficit,'' said Mike Tindall, an economist at the Discount Corporation of New York.
 
Traders Monitoring Funds Rate
Aside from speculation about military spending, traders were closely monitoring movements in the overnight Federal funds rate.
The Fed, which sent a clear signal to the market last week that it did not want the funds rate to dip below 8.50 percent, yesterday failed to enter the market to drain reserves when the funds rate was trading at 8 3/8 percent.
''The funds rate was at 8 3/8 percent and the Fed was not in the market,'' one government trader said. ''It makes you wonder if they didn't decide to do something at the Open Market Committee meeting last week.''
The funds rate subsequently inched higher, and in late trading was offered at 8 7/16 percent.
''They could be setting up for an easing move,'' the government bond trader said. ''Since the Fed is concerned about the manufacturing sector, Wednesday's durable goods report could influence their decision to move.''
While it may influence trading, market participants do not expect today's report on consumer prices to tip the Fed's hand.
 
Consumer Price Forecast
In advance of the report, most Wall Street economists were forecasting that consumer prices rose by about four-tenths of a percentage point in October, and a shade less excluding the volatile food and energy sectors.
In other developments, interest rates on short-term Treasury bills eased at the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills.
At the auction, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.61 percent, down from an average rate of 7.68 percent a week ago.
Six-month bills were auctioned at an average rate of 7.40 percent, compared with an average rate of 7.51 percent last week.
In the secondary market for notes and bonds, the Treasury's 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered at a price of 102 14/32 late yesterday, up 1/4 of a point, to yield 7.90 percent.
Meanwhile, the 7 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 1/8, up 1/32, to yield 7.85 percent. The 8 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 101 26/32, unchanged on the day, to yield 7.79 percent. And the 7 5/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 25/32, up 1/32, to yield 7.74 percent.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate and tax-exempt municipal bonds was extremely slow, traders said. Prices of corporate bonds rose by about 1/8 of a point, participants said. Prices of most municipal bond issues were unchanged on the day.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Crude Oil Prices Advance; Taking of Deliveries Cited

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Crude oil prices advanced, bolstered by the large number of actual deliveries against the spot December futures contract, which expired yesterday.
Those not interested in taking delivery or in delivering the underlying product by expiration day usually roll over their contracts into the next delivery month, often paying a premium to do so. But there were only a relatively small number of rollovers into the January contract. 
The expired December contract settled on the New York Mercantile Exchange at $20.07 a barrel, up 16 cents on the day, after trading between $20.25 and $19.75. The contract's high was $20.67, set this past Oct. 13, and the low, $12.70, was posted on Nov. 17, 1988.
As for the new spot January delivery, it rose 16 cents, closing at $19.99, after trading between $20.02 and $19.75.
''Although January crude traded above the spot month at times during the session on strong investment-house demand, it wasn't enough to keep it there,'' said Bradford H. Hughes, energy products trader at Cargill Investor Services. ''Not even the two big buyers of the January crude, Shearson and J. Aron, appeared interested in bidding the new spot delivery above $20.''
Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. is believed to be the largest futures trading house, while J. Aron is the commodity trading arm of Goldman, Sachs & Company.
 
Fire at Chevron Ignored
In the usual excitement that attends the expiration of a contract, the energy market ignored the fire last Friday that shut down a Chevron Corporation crude refinery in California, Mr. Hughes said. ''Besides,'' he added, ''there is plenty of crude in California, and the 135,000-barrel-a-day facility is expected to be back on line in a few weeks.''
Peter C. Beutel, energy specialist at Elders Futures Inc., said the market also ignored trade reports that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries plans to raise its collective output by a million barrels a day, to 21.5 million, on Jan. 1. ''Even if it were true, demand for crude tends to decline in the first quarter,'' Mr. Beutel noted. ''Barring any unexpected news from OPEC, the Northern Hemisphere crude market should now be focusing on heating oil.''
Heating oil prices tend to decline from mid-November to just before Christmas, Mr. Beutel said, mainly because November is a warmer month than March. After Christmas, heating oil prices reflect weather conditions but tend to soften by late February. ''But in early March, there is usually an upward spike,'' he explained. ''Why? Because heating oil stocks are down and refineries have begun to switch more facilities to gasoline production. So any cold spell in early March usually sends heating oil prices up temporarily.''
The spot heating oil contract for December delivery rose 0.81 cent a gallon, closing at 60.08 cents, while the same unleaded gasoline contract was up 0.27 cent a gallon, at 52.25 cents. Spot December heating oil and gasoline contracts expire on Nov. 30.
Copper futures prices fell sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York as worries about the United States economy fueled a selloff that began last week.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's remarks on Sunday that there could be big cuts in military spending was also seen as a bad sign for copper. Copper settled 0.60 cent to 3 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in November at $1.062 a pound.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off in Mark Trading But Is Higher Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against European currencies yesterday but rose against the yen.
The central banks of several nations, including the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan, sold dollars in an effort to halt the dollar's rise against the yen. While the dollar still rose against the Japanese currency, the intervention appeared to worry traders enough to push the dollar lower against the mark and other European currencies. 
Traders were also concerned about the possibility that United States interest rates might decline further.
 
Dollar at 144.67 Yen in Tokyo
The dollar rose to 144.35 yen in New York, from 144.25 late Friday. In trading earlier in Tokyo, the dollar had closed at 144.67 Japanese yen, up from 143.98 yen, and in London, it had closed lower at 144.50 yen.
Against the mark, the dollar fell to 1.8338 from 1.8410.
In its decline against European currencies, the dollar was hurt by signs of progress from Washington on budget cuts, said Jack Barbanel, a foreign exchange analyst with First Global Asset Management Inc.
Congressional leaders said yesterday that they were close to agreement on a bill reducing the Federal budget deficit, while Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was considering $180 billion in military spending cuts over the next six years.
 
More Possible Fed Leeway
Budget cuts might give the Federal Reserve Board some leeway to allow interest rates to fall, Mr. Barbanel said. If rates decline in the United States while remaining high overseas, the dollar would be less attractive to foreign investors.
In earlier trading abroad, the dollar was mixed. Dealers said the dollar initially rose on reports of planned military spending cuts, but the currency was unable to maintain its advance.
The British pound fell sharply against the dollar, prompting the Bank of England to buy pounds for dollars. Dealers said there was some nervousness about the October British trade figures due on Thursday in view of increasing deficits in recent months.
In London, the pound cost $1.5595, cheaper for buyers than late Friday's $1.5705, and in New York, the pound fell to $1.5582, from $1.5670 late Friday.
 
Late Dollar Rates
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.62975 Swiss francs, down from 1.6307; 6.2435 French francs, down from 6.2630; 1,350 Italian lire, down from 1,355, and 1.7105 Canadian dollars, up from 1.6945.
Gold bullion prices, meanwhile, continued the steady upward climb of the last three weeks, and dealers said they expected to see the $400 level tested soon.
In New York, the Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $398 for a troy ounce of gold, up $3.75. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, a troy ounce rose $3.60, to $398.20.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2269 words

HEADLINE: Steady, Painful Transition To a Humbler Wall Street

BYLINE: By SARAH BARTLETT

 BODY:
These are nervous days on Wall Street. As cutbacks mount, more and more investment bankers, brokers and office workers face the year-end prospect of sharply lower incomes or no jobs at all.
The recent round of cutbacks at leading investment houses like Shearson Lehman Hutton and Drexel Burnham Lambert is not just a belt-tightening exercise. It represents a fundamental realignment on Wall Street, one that is likely to result in investment houses being smaller, more specialized and more humble in their aims.
Some firms, Wall Street executives and analysts said, will pare back costly operations, like vast networks of local brokerage offices catering to individual investors across America and international outposts in many countries. Other firms could drop out of certain securities businesses altogether. 
 
Glory Days Are Over
Today's retrenchment is driven by an underlying recognition that the glory days of the 1980's, when 26-year-olds commanded $300,000 a year and takeover deals flourished, are truly over. ''People are having to make some very tough decisions,'' said Peter A. Cohen, chief executive of Shearson Lehman. ''We're just emerging from one of the longest up cycles the industry has ever had.''
The transition to a smaller, lower-paid, less glamorous business is bound to be painful, both for the bright young stars who were drawn to the industry and for the New York region, which became dependent on it. Many bonus checks could be cut by 30 percent or more, some executives said.
Traditionally, Wall Street's fortunes swing up and down with the stock market. But today, small investors are retreating, corporate takeovers are getting scarcer and the market for high-risk, high-yield ''junk bonds'' is in turmoil. What especially worries industry executives is that business is depressed at a time when the economy is still holding up reasonably well and share prices are up more than 20 percent for the year.
 
Little Debate on Direction
''The industry is having problems before the economy even slows down,'' observed Sanford I. Weill, chief executive of the Primerica Corporation, which owns Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''What happens if there is a serious economic downturn?''
There may be uncertainty about the securities industry's final shape, but there is little debate about its direction. ''Today, people don't know how far down 'down' is,'' said Lowell L. Bryan, who heads the financial institutions practice at McKinsey & Company, a consulting firm.
One sign of the chastened tone on Wall Street is that several big investment houses are actually seeking the guidance of outsiders. McKinsey, for example, is advising four Wall Street firms on ways to reshape management and improve profitability, far more than in previous periods, Mr. Bryan said.
The decline on Wall Street By SARAH BARTLETT These are nervous days on Wall Street. As cutbacks mount, more and more investment bankers, brokers and office workers face the year-end prospect of sharply lower incomes or no jobs at all.
The recent round of cutbacks at leading investment houses like Shearson Lehman Hutton and Drexel Burnham Lambert is not just a belt-tightening exercise. It represents a fundamental realignment on Wall Street, one that is likely to result in investment houses being smaller, more specialized and more humble in their aims.
Some firms, Wall Street executives and analysts said, will pare back costly operations, like vast networks of local brokerage offices catering to individual investors across America and international outposts in many countries. Other firms could drop out of certain securities businesses altogether.
 
Glory Days Are Over
Today's retrenchment is driven by an underlying recognition that the glory days of the 1980's, when 26-year-olds commanded $300,000 a year and takeover deals flourished, are truly over. ''People are having to make some very tough decisions,'' said Peter A. Cohen, chief executive of Shearson Lehman. ''We're just emerging from one of the longest up cycles the industry has ever had.''
The transition to a smaller, lower-paid, less glamorous business is bound to be painful, both for the bright young stars who were drawn to the industry and for the New York region, which became dependent on it. Many bonus checks could be cut by 30 percent or more, some executives said.
Traditionally, Wall Street's fortunes swing up and down with the stock market. But today, small investors are retreating, corporate takeovers are getting scarcer and the market for high-risk, high-yield ''junk bonds'' is in turmoil. What especially worries industry executives is that business is depressed at a time when the economy is still holding up reasonably well and share prices are up more than 20 percent for the year.
 
Little Debate on Direction
''The industry is having problems before the economy even slows down,'' observed Sanford I. Weill, chief executive of the Primerica Corporation, which owns Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''What happens if there is a serious economic downturn?''
There may be uncertainty about the securities industry's final shape, but there is little debate about its direction. ''Today, people don't know how far down 'down' is,'' said Lowell L. Bryan, who heads the financial institutions practice at McKinsey & Company, a consulting firm.
One sign of the chastened tone on Wall Street is that several big investment houses are actually seeking the guidance of outsiders. McKinsey, for example, is advising four Wall Street firms on ways to reshape management and improve profitability, far more than in previous periods, Mr. Bryan said.
The decline on Wall Street comes at an unfortunate time for the New York area, already suffering from a stagnant real estate market, an economic slump on Long Island and mounting fiscal problems. With pay scales two and a half times the city average, Wall Street has been responsible for 20 percent of the rise in private-sector income over the last decade.
In the early 1980's, the securities industry boomed, fueled by a surging stock market and a wave of huge takeovers. The industry responded by vastly expanding its foundation. Firms like Salomon Brothers and Morgan Stanley tripled or quadrupled their work forces, while the amount of capital the largest firms committed to the industry grew from $5.4 billion in 1980 to $27 billion at the end of last year.
 
Response to '87 Crash
The stock market crash in 1987 was the first blow to the industry, and in response Wall Street promptly shed about 24,000 jobs, or about 10 percent of the work force. But despite widespread predictions to the contrary, the economy remained strong and the takeover business, briefly quiescent, soon rebounded.
Starting this summer, however, Wall Street's two most lucrative fee-paying businesses - arranging mergers and underwriting junk bonds - turned sour. ''Clearly we and everyone else on the Street are under pressure,'' said Frederick H. Joseph, chief executive of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., whose business has been heavily dependent on mergers and junk bonds. Mr. Joseph confirmed that Drexel has not yet been profitable in the fourth quarter.
The havoc in the junk bond market has been caused by the fading fortunes of several of the big mergers financed with junk bonds and large amounts of bank debt. Heavily indebted companies like Campeau, Resorts International and Integrated Resources have had trouble keeping up with interest payments, scaring off potential junk bond investors. With investors and bankers skittish, the number of takeover deals in the works is falling off, and analysts say this newfound caution is not temporary, but reflects a deeper skepticism of the excesses of the past.
 
Dramatic Results
This turnaround in sentiment is already yielding dramatic results. Junk bond issuance in the second half is about 40 percent below what it was for the period last year. And the dollar amount of takeovers is almost 30 percent lower than it was last year.
Wall Street's profits have also been hurt by the market plunge of Oct. 13, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 190 points. Individual investors who had begun to tiptoe back into stocks scurried for cover, more convinced than ever that the market was not a place for them.
The turbulent stock market also dampened another key business on Wall Street: issuing equity for companies. When stocks began to climb earlier this year, many corporate treasurers took that as a sign that stability was finally returning and that it was time to line up to issue new shares or to go public.
''The Street was going to make a good piece of its money on equity offerings in the fourth quarter,'' said Michael W. Blumstein, an analyst at C.S. First Boston Inc. But he said, ''We're not seeing the same number of offerings since the 13th.'' And that business was already down 36 percent in the first 9 months of the year.
 
High-Stakes Bets
With profits disappearing in so many critical areas, many executives are now having to place high-stakes bets on which businesses will help them get through the next few difficult years.
At Shearson Lehman, for instance, Mr. Cohen is close to instigating a management shake-up he has reportedly agonized over for months. The changes, which will be announced in the next few weeks, are likely to include a reduced role for the firm's president, Jeffrey B. Lane, a longtime friend and colleague of Mr. Cohen. Mr. Lane is closely identified with the 1987 decision to purchase financially troubled E. F. Hutton & Company for nearly $1 billion, a move that vastly increased Shearson's army of retail brokers. And he has had supervisory responsibility for the firm's Boston Company subsidiary, which had surprising losses this year.
After the management changes are announced, a young group of investment bankers is expected to play a much larger role in the running of the firm, a shift that some executives said would result in a much closer scrutiny of the firm's retail business, and a re-examination of the goal to be a global enterprise. Already Shearson is taking a much tougher line, reducing commissions to its brokers for the first time in 15 years. And although the firm recently acknowledged that it was laying off 800 employees, executives close to the firm say the number is likely to be much higher.
 
All Things to All People
For its part, Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. is pruning back its investment banking effort, focusing it on areas where it has an advantage, rather than trying to be all things to all people. That marks a sharp reversal from 1986, when the firm, with great fanfare, announced ''Project '89'' - an initiative intended to boost the firm into the big leagues of investment banking.
George L. Ball, the chief executive, said this shift ''reflects a belief that investment banking revenue opportunities will be more difficult to come by than was the case in the early and mid-1980's.'' Indeed, one of the two authors of Project '89, Theodore V. Fowler, recently resigned from the firm, citing differences over direction. People close to the firm said Mr. Fowler had wanted to hire 50 or 60 more investment bankers.
Salomon Brothers also has plans to cut its investment banking force. Of the 100 executives the firm intends to lay off by year-end, at least 60 are going to come from the investment banking side, not sales and trading.
 
Reworking an Image
Some industry observers view that as a change in Salomon's strategy. For the last year and a half the firm has worked hard to convince the public that it is not simply a trading firm but a broad-based investment bank that can advise on mergers as well as the next one.
In recent months, though, Salomon's earnings have been won or lost by large trading bets it has made for its own account. Against that backdrop, industry analysts view the Salomon cutbacks in investment banking as a sign that trading is once again being recognized as the driving force at the firm.
Salomon's chief executive, John H. Gutfreund, denies that there is any shift in strategy. ''We are committed to investment banking and research, but we have to convert our commitment to profitability,'' he said. ''And we are not satisfied yet.'' Mr. Gutfreund said he would be willing to add more people in investment banking, but they would have to come at the expense of those at lower rungs.
 
Anxiety at Drexel
At Drexel, meanwhile, anxiety continues to mount. As the dominant firm in the field, Drexel is the most seriously affected by the decline in the issue of junk bonds and the trading losses that have afflicted that area this summer. Drexel tried to address its profitability problems earlier this year by selling its retail business and sharply reducing its commitment to municipal bonds and mortgage-backed securities. But the recent downturn in deal making and junk bonds has sent the firm reeling.
Executives there talk of managerial turmoil and an almost desperate effort to scrape up fees. Rumors have been rampant that Drexel is considering selling its institutional equities business to the Nomura Securities Company of Tokyo, although Mr. Joseph dismisses such stories as ''baloney.'' But that such a rumor would even make the rounds indicates how far-reaching Wall Street's restructuring is likely to be. Only a few years ago, the thought that a major firm would give up a business as central as institutional equities would have been considered laughable.

HEADLINE: Greeks Agree on a Broad Coalition Until April

BYLINE: By PAUL ANASTASI, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATHENS, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Ending a two-week political crisis, the three main political parties set aside their differences today and agreed to a coalition government that will rule Greece until new elections are held in April.
After four days of difficult negotiations, the conservatives, Socialists and Communists issued statements saying that compromise was needed to address pressing economic problems and to avoid a new election immediately. Elections have been held twice since June, and no party gained a parliamentary majority in either. The parties said the new government will be established within a day, and that Xenophon Zolotas, an 85-year-old former governor of the Bank of Greece, will be Prime Minister. 
The leaders of the three main parties will not hold posts in the Government. Other major posts will go to technical experts and politicians in proportion to the percentage of the popular vote each of the three parties party won in the most recent election, on Nov. 5.
But the partners in the new Government made it clear that it would have difficulty tackling such major foreign policy issues as the American bases in Greece and the extradition to the United States of a Palestinian wanted on terrorism charges.
If the parties had failed to agree, Parliament would have been dissolved today and elections held in four weeks.
On Nov. 5, the conservative New Democracy Party won 46.2 percent of the votes, the Socialists 40.7, and the Communists 11 percent. The remaining 2 percent went to the Greens and smaller parties.
The deadlock in negotiations was overcome after Andreas Papandreou, the Socialist leader and former Prime Minister, withdrew a demand for a change in the electoral system. If his demand had been met, smaller parties would have benefited and the conservatives would have had little chance of coming to power. Mr. Papandreou also failed in an attempt to negotiate a coalition with the Communists.
Mr. Papandreou had governed for eight years until a conservative-Communist coalition was formed after the June election with the purpose of pursuing corruption charges against him and officials in his Government.
The three parties agreed to a statement of principles that focuses primarily on social and economic issues and avoids problem areas like foreign policy. But they agreed that they would try to address the issue of the American bases in Greece, although they have widely divergent views on the issue. The Communists want the bases removed immediately, the Socialists want a referendum and the conservatives want a negotiated settlement for their continued presence.
The five-year agreement on the bases, signed in 1983, has already expired and the installations are due to be removed by next May. But officials from all parties said an extension may be granted pending a final solution.
The parties said they would not deal with the American extradition request for Mohammed Rashid, a Palestinian who is wanted for a bomb attack on a Pan American jetliner in 1982. A final decision on Mr. Rashid's case is not expected until next September.
''We want Rashid to be set free, or in the worst of cases to be put on trial in Greece, not in the U.S.,'' said Harilaos Florakis, the Communist leader. ''We will not spare any effort toward this end. In the meantime, nobody can touch Rashid.''

HEADLINE: Clamor in the East;
Old Master Spy in East Berlin Tells Why He Backs Changes

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Among the artists, intellectuals, clerics and other former dissidents at the forefront of those in East Germany calling for changes, Markus Wolf clearly stands out.
A big, dapper man given to well-cut tweed suits, Mr. Wolf was for 33 years East Germany's master spy. In fact, he is one of the few East Germans who cannot take advantage of the new travel freedoms because his espionage coups in West Germany have made him a wanted man there.
But three years after his retirement from the Ministry of State Security, Mr. Wolf, 66 years old, has become a leading proponent of change, appearing on television talk shows and opposition panel discussions, and he was a featured speaker at the huge rally in East Berlin on Nov. 4. 
Now there is talk that the man who bedeviled the West German Government with his spies - including the celebrated Gunter Guillaume, who became a personal aide to Willy Brandt and whose uncloaking brought about the fall of the Social Democratic Chancellor in 1974 - may himself become part of a new party leadership selected when the Communist Party holds its congress next month.
 
Savoring the Limelight
Mr. Wolf denies any such ambitions. But after decades of toiling in the shadows, he seems to savor the limelight, and he is not unaware that spymasters in both superpowers have risen to the top - his ''good friend'' the late Yuri V. Andropov in Moscow and President Bush in Washington.
His own emergence as a reformer, he insists, was not a metamorphosis. His position in the East German Ministry of State Security, where he headed foreign intelligence, gave him access to information and license to ponder the growing problems in his homeland.
And his wartime years spent in the Soviet Union left him friends among Russians who later emerged at the forefront of perestroika and glasnost, including Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, the man President Mikhail S. Gorbachev chose to head the K.G.B.
Through Mr. Kryuchkov, he knew what was happening inside Mr. Gorbachev's Moscow. And through him, Moscow evidently kept abreast of what was happening in East Germany.
''A year ago I was telling the Russians we could still turn things around here in respect to glasnost and perestroika,'' Mr. Wolf said in an interview, casually acknowledging a close working relationship with Moscow.
He was saying the same things at home. ''From the beginning of this year I told all our leaders that this will happen,'' he said, reflecting on the dramatic demonstrations that had forced the Communist Party into retreat.
''I didn't know it would be so powerful, or that there was such pressure. But even a half year ago there was still a chance for the party to take charge of these events. As it turned out, it was impossible with the old leadership.''
 
Critical of Stalinism
Mr. Wolf's public debut as a reformer was a book published this year. Called ''The Troika,'' it described the lives of three families who lived together in Moscow before World War II and followed separate paths during the war - the families of Mr. Wolf's father, Friedrich, the American historian Louis Fisher and Wilhelm Bloch, who fought in Hitler's army and ended up a businessman in West Germany. .
The biggest sensation, however, was that the celebrated spymaster took a highly critical view in the book of Stalinism, a view then still taboo in East Germany, and of East Germany's policies in the 1970's, when many artists were purged. Mr. Wolf became an overnight celebrity, now as a champion of change.
''The huge interest in my book was not linked to its content, but to the new demand for the truth, not to hide past errors,'' he said. ''These demands were very strong in the party. Whoever I met demanded change - I never met anyone, in fact, who did not demand fundamental reform. But we were unable to act in good time.''
Mr. Wolf professes to be proud of the peaceful and disciplined way East Germans handled their quiet revolution.
''Gorbachev's was a revolution from above,'' he said. ''Ours was from below. To those who know the history of Germany, this is a phenomenon, that the people have been so wise, so reserved.''
 
Still Favors Communism
His great regret, he insists, is that this initiative did not come from the party. He repeatedly refers to the Socialist Unity Party, as the East German Communist organization is formally known, as ''my party,'' and when he talks of reform, he leaves no doubt that he is talking of changes that would preserve a Communist system.
''If we want to preserve socialism -and for that we'll fight - we must have a precise concept of how we should move ahead,'' he said.
Mr. Wolf said academics at Humboldt University in East Berlin were already at work on concepts for reforming the party and the economy, while the opposition, including New Forum, had no expertise in these matters.
''If the leadership of the party is capable of again taking charge of the party, I'm convinced the party will not disappear,'' he said.
In an interview with West German television on Monday night, however, Mr. Wolf acknowledged that the Communist Party might eventually be forced into opposition. ''Considering that most opposition groups are aiming at some kind of socialism, whatever they understand by socialism, we might have to say goodbye to the thought that the future of socialism has to be bound to one single party,'' he said.
Mr. Wolf does not exclude his former organization from the need for change. He outlined several changes he would demand, including examination of every reported violation of law by the State Security organization and compensation for its victims; a ''new thinking, especially in regard to dissidents,'' and tight controls over the security apparatus.
Rehabilitating the State Security apparatus stands to be a major challenge. The hated Staasi have been a major target of virtually every demonstration, and Mr. Wolf himself faced prolonged jeers when he rose to address the demonstration on Nov. 4.
''Workers of my former ministry must appear in public and fight for public confidence,'' he said. ''If the public believes that this organization really takes care of state security, and that the rights of individuals are protected, it should accept it.''
