LENGTH: 870 words

HEADLINE: A Union Folds Its Hand

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The new union agreement at the Boeing Company, ratified after a 48-day strike, shows that even under the most favorable circumstances the labor movement cannot win the clear-cut victories that were commonplace a decade ago.
The struggle at Boeing was significant because, for the first time in years, a union entered a major contract negotiation holding the best cards.
With record profits and a huge backlog of orders for jets, Boeing could not plead poverty. And commercial aircraft manufacturing is not automated; Boeing could not operate without its production workers. 
Nevertheless, the International Association of Machinists fell well short of its main goals. It had insisted upon an 18 percent wage increase over three years, but instead settled for 10 percent. It tried to get rid of bonuses that for the six previous years had been substituted for wage increases, but the strike ended after Boeing sweetened its bonus offer while holding firm on its wage package.
 
The Trend Continues
''The Boeing settlement failed to reverse a national trend toward flexible pay,'' said Al Bauman, a Labor Department economist. ''I thought that if anyone was going to get rid of bonuses, it would have been the machinists.''
American companies have been moving slowly away from fixed wage increases, which must be paid in good times and bad. Instead, bonuses and profit sharing are being substituted, and these can rise or fall as a company's fortunes change. Today, about 44 percent of the six million people covered by major collective-bargaining agreements - and many thousands of non-unionized workers - receive bonuses or profit sharing, or some form of flexible pay. Among union members, this is up from 31 percent in 1984, according to the Labor Department.
The Boeing settlement is likely to further the trend, says Willam Wallace, Boeing's chief research economist. ''The machinists' willingness, in the end, to accept bonuses is a reasonable basis for exploring profit sharing and for tying labor costs more closely to profits,'' he said. Boeing has been exploring the possibilities of a profit-sharing plan, Mr. Wallace added.
 
Timed for Christmas
Some of the machinists' national leaders had criticized the leadership of the unit covering Boeing's 57,000 workers for allowing the company to substitute bonuses for wage increases. But even George Korpius, the machinists' national president, acknowledged that Boeing's workers, the majority of them young people with less than six years at the company, had become used to bonus payments, which are strategically paid just before Christmas.
For months before the strike the machinists had used videotapes and lectures to explain to the members that bonus payments are not as valuable as wages - or as costly for the company - because they do not count in the calculation of overtime, sick pay, vacation pay and pensions. In addition, a worker's pay compounds with annual wage increases, but bonuses do not. ''There is a money illusion here,'' said Brian Turner, an A.F.L.-C.I.O. official.
Boeing played to this money illusion, structuring the bonus so that two weeks after returning to work, the machinists will receive a bonus equal to 10 percent of their gross pay this past year, which means $3,000 to $7,000 for most workers. Each worker gets a $500 advance on this bonus upon returning to work today.
 
A Consolation Is Seen
Despite the bonuses, the settlement that resulted from the long strike did advance labor's cause in some ways. Mr. Korpius noted that for the first time in more than six years the union gained ground rather than granting any concessions - a claim many other unions cannot make.
While the Communications Workers of America, for example, recently sacrificed on wage increases to get telephone companies to agree to pay health insurance premiums, the machinists won not only their first wage increases in six years, but improvements in health insurance, overtime rules, pension benefits and cost-of-living pay.
Boeing's production workers earned an average of $13.50 an hour going into the strike, compared with the national average of $10.54 an hour for manufacturing workers. The wage increase, 4 percent the first year and 3 percent in each subsequent year, only matched the average achieved in other major contract settlements this year, the Labor Department reports. The machinists' great leverage in the Boeing negotiations gained them no advantage on this score.
But the leverage did help improve the cost-of-living increase, which does raise wages. While the trend in the 1980's has been to shed cost-of-living clauses, the machinists improved theirs, getting Boeing to agree to raise wages nearly a percentage point for each rise of a point in the Consumer Price Index. This inflation insurance compares with an average coverage of 62 percent won by other unions this year, and with the machinists' 80 percent coverage under the old contract.
''They took a long strike to get very little,'' said Gary Burtless, a senior fellow and labor expert at the Brookings Institution. ''But with the cost-of-living and wage increase and bonus, they are doing twice as well as the typical American worker.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Albany Must Take Steps to Keep and Attract Manufacturing Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Every New Yorker should be concerned about the loss of more than 230,000 manufacturing jobs in our state in this decade. But despite the loss of companies and jobs, manufacturing remains the heart of the state's economy. It's no exaggeration to say that all our livelihoods ultimately depend on manufacturing. Investment, employment and growth in other sectors are based on a healthy, goods-producing base that demands - and pays for - services, construction and wholesale and retail trade. 
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the State Senate and the Assembly have done much in recent years to create a better environment for manufacturing. The effort to cut personal income taxes, changes in corporate taxes to encourage long-term investment and improvements in economic development programs are a few examples. Yet more must be done. The cost of doing business in New York is still too high. Despite tax reductions, New York remains at or near the top on national lists of high-tax states. And state policies on health benefits, unemployment insurance and workers' compensation drive those costs higher than in most other states.
Problems with solid-waste disposal, which have homeowners paying more for household trash pickup, are imposing tremendous cost burdens on manufacturers as well. The state must take decisive action to insure adequate capacity for getting rid of both solid and hazardous wastes.
Schools must do a better job of preparing students for higher education or the workplace. New York's industrial development resources should be increased and made more accessible locally. And product liability laws that needlessly inhibit development of new consumer products and services should be repealed.
Governor Cuomo recognized the importance of manufacturing in his 1989 State of the State Message, in which he called for a statewide conference on manufacturing, to be co-sponsored by the Business Council. That conference, set for next Feb. 13, will give manufacturers an opportunity to tell state leaders what policies are needed to promote manufacturing in New York.
New York is a good place to make a home and do business. But we can and must do better. Manufacturing matters to New York - more than ever before.
 
DANIEL B. WALSH
President, Business Council
of New York State Inc.
 Albany, Nov. 6, 1989

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Watershed for Europe

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
The impromptu dinner summit meeting of European Community leaders here last weekend can turn out to be a watershed: Western Europe at last pulling together to help Eastern Europe into the future. An extraordinary moment has arrived and it is about assuring the triumph of democracy. In principle at least, The Twelve accepted joint responsibility instead of waiting for somebody (the U.S., West Germany) to do something.
The Belgian Prime Minister, Wilfried Martens, said afterward, ''For the first time, we were sitting around the table discussing a political issue like a cabinet at European level.'' It can set the course for the rest of the century and beyond. 
When Secretary of State George C. Marshall made his Harvard speech in 1947 proposing U.S. aid for the reconstruction of Europe, there was no clear plan either, only words. But they were seized upon, hammered into specific projects, turned into actions that changed world history. And it is the fruits of that success that now bring the East to set a new direction.
In that sense, the Community is on the brink of a new Marshall Plan. That is fitting, for Europe should take the lead. The U.S. must be involved, of course. Now President Bush has something practical to offer President Gorbachev when they talk of the need for stability during the tremendous task of transforming Eastern Europe. It is to support and encourage the European initiative.
Horst Teltschik, Bonn's national security adviser, was in Washington last month urging the appointment of a small group of distinguished Americans to work with Europeans on a program. It was such a group that developed the Marshall Plan. But Washington wasn't ready to think ahead. The idea should be taken up, now. Even for short-term survival help to work effectively, it is urgent to devise a medium-term, concrete plan so that people can see the purpose of the sacrifices, or rather investments, that have to be made. The West has won the cold war, but as Jean Monnet said after World War II, now the question is how to win the peace.
Unfortunately, there is no Jean Monnet on the scene, but his ideas stressing institutions and coordination provide guiding principles. He insisted on turning words into deeds.
The first step should be for the Community, at its formal summit meeting in Strasbourg on Dec. 8 and 9, to ask the Brussels Commission to work out specific proposals for the Development Bank for Eastern Europe, stabilization funds, investment incentives and cooperation among prospective Eastern partners. They will need to consult all concerned, including the U.S. and the Soviets.
Max Kohnstamm, a Dutchman who worked closely with Monnet, points out that this has nothing to do with the Communist notion of command planning. ''For Monnet, a plan meant getting the right people around a table to look at details and work out the moves. No great enterprise can live without a view of where it's going.''
The Community should also set a date for negotiating decisions on economic and monetary union, to strengthen its cohesion and its capacity to deal with the changing East. The choice, as Mr. Kohnstamm put it, is a ''reinforced Community or German hegemony, and that wouldn't be good for the Germans, for Europe, for the world.''
Prime Minister Thatcher of Britain can't see that. She calls it ''undemocratic'' to pool national authority in this way. Probably the only person who could enlighten her on the importance of choosing the right turn at this critical crossroads is President Bush. He would be doing a service to America's as well as Europe's future.
Her stubborn opposition to further integration is provoking increasing impatience among her partners. They are beginning to say the only way to get Britain in, which the Common Market wanted from the start, is to go ahead without Britain. Then it will try to catch up. In any case, it is possible to organize the new structures needed for Europe without Britain, if it insists on lagging behind. It is not possible without Germany.
Mr. Kohl seems to be wavering, torn between the insights of his strategists and the technical reservations of his Finance Minister and the head of West Germany's Central Bank. He repeated in Paris that West Germany is determined to remain anchored in the Community and not let itself be tugged eastward. The stronger the Community, the better the anchorage.
The last words of Jean Monnet's autobiography are brilliantly topical. He wrote: ''The sovereign nations of the past can no longer solve the problems of the present; they cannot insure their own progress or control their own future. And the Community itself is only a stage on the way to the organized world of tomorrow.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Landlords Win Battle in Court Over Rent Rises

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Tenants in rent-stabilized buildings may be charged permanent rent increases if their landlords make major improvements, like new windows or heating systems, New York's highest court ruled today.
The State Court of Appeals, in a 6-to-0 decision, struck down a challenge from tenants who had argued that landlords should be allowed to raise rents only long enough to recoup the money they spent making the improvements.
The decision was seen by both tenant lawyers and landlord groups as a landmark because it put to rest the question of whether the cost of major improvements could be passed on to tenants as permanent rent increases. 
Since rent stabilization began in 1969, lower courts and state housing agencies had usually allowed improvement costs to be met through permanent rent increases. But the issue had not been fully addressed in law.
 
Nearly 900,000 Apartments
Today's ruling affects the nearly 900,000 rent-stabilized apartments statewide. Most are in New York City, though some are in Buffalo and Westchester County.
''There isn't much we can do,'' said David Ng, a lawyer for the tenants association that lost the case. ''I can understand the courts. Why should they change 20 years of what's happening?''
The case involved Ansonia Associates and its 500-unit building at 2109 Broadway, near 74th Street on Manhattan's West Side. In 1981, Ansonia Associates asked the state for a permanent 3.1 percent rent increase to pay for new storm windows that it had installed in all but eight apartments. The landlord said it needed that increase to get a sufficient return on its $339,000 investment.
The state Division of Housing and Community Renewal, which enforces New York's rent laws, granted a permanent 2.1 percent rent increase.
Tenants then sued, arguing that the rent increase should only be imposed for five years, until the owners regained the cost of the windows.
But the Court of Appeals said that the housing division's decision was in line with the state law. The court also said that landlords have more of an incentive to improve their buildings if they are able to reap a profit from those improvements.
John Gilbert, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, a group run by landlords, said the decision would save thousands of New York City buildings from deterioriation.

HEADLINE: Pentagon Savings Unlikely to Be Spent Elsewhere

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
The reduction in military spending being contemplated by the Bush Administration will not provide much new money for domestic programs over the next several years, Government officials and economists say.
Many years from now, they say, the cuts could mean additional resources in areas like education, child care and environmental protection. But for the time being, in their view, nearly all the money saved at the Pentagon must be used to reduce the Federal deficit.
In the next fiscal year alone, they say, the problem in meeting the deficit level required by law is so daunting that the relatively modest cut planned for the military will be little help. The deficit is expected to be $110 billion this fiscal year, and the balanced-budget law mandates that it be no more than $64 billion in the next one. 
''Let's not sell it short,'' said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, speaking of the Administration's long-term military plan. ''It's very substantial. But we shouldn't look at this as providing us with the wherewithal to meet all our problems.''
President Bush's budget director, Richard G. Darman, declined today to discuss the military cuts. But addressing the deficit for the fiscal year 1991, which begins next Oct. 1, he said the problem was ''every bit as big as anyone has ever suggested it might be.''
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has directed the military services to identify ways that the Pentagon budget can be cut by $180 billion below the expanded levels the Administration had originally planned for fiscal years 1992-94. That would mean an actual reduction averaging about 5 percent in each of those years after inflation is taken into account.
 
Closing the Budget Gap
The military budget for the fiscal year 1991 is now being put in final form, and officials expect Pentagon spending to be cut by less than $10 billion after accounting for inflation.
That is less than one-fourth of the more than $40 billion in budget reductions across the Government that must be made to cut the deficit to the ceiling set by the balanced-budget law for the next fiscal year. The gap can be closed only through deeper military cuts, which are thought unlikely, tax increases, reductions in domestic spending or a combination of those.
The law requires the deficit to be cut further in succeeding fiscal years until the books are balanced in the fiscal year 1993. After that, the Administration and lawmakers in both parties believe further spending cuts or tax increases will be necessary to offset money raised in Social Security taxes that is used to meet expenses outside the Social Security system.
Some scholars looking far down the road see an eventual shift from military to domestic spending as dramatic as the change after Ronald Reagan took office, when taxes and domestic spending were cut and military expenditures mushroomed.
''There could be a tremendous change in society, a change in what the Government supports and doesn't support,'' said Richard A. Stubbing, a professor of public policy at Duke University and an expert in the military budget.
 
No Fundamental Realignment
But most experts believe that prospect is barely on the horizon. ''We're not talking about a fundamental realignment of Government,'' said Charles L. Schultze, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Carter Administration. ''Most of the money must go for deficit reduction.''
In Congress, a few conservatives like Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, believe that lower spending by the military should lead to tax reductions. ''I don't think the benefits from winning the cold war should go to the Government,'' Mr. Gramm said.
Some liberals, mostly Democrats, would use the money to immediately expand social programs. ''It isn't communism that's threatening us,'' said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan. ''It's our failure to deal with the problems of our cities.''
But the prevailing view is that the deficit overarches all other problems. ''We've got a fire-breathing monster staring at us,'' said Representative Les AuCoin, Democrat of Oregon. ''There's just not going to be much of a dividend here to be spent elsewhere.''
The economists and Government officials said the way the money was ultimately spent would depend in many respects on the political and economic climate. If international tensions continue to ease, they said, more military cuts might be in the offing. If there is a recession, more spending on unemployment insurance and other social programs might be needed.
In any event, the actual money that would become available in any particular fisal year from the Pentagon cuts is far from certain. In large part, it depends on what parts of the military budget are cut and when.
Military budgets are normally expressed in terms of the amount of money Congress allocates each year to the Pentagon. That ''budget authority'' is different from actual spending.
In some areas, like salaries and training, almost all the money is spent in the year that Congress makes it available. But in weapons procurement, for example, less than 15 percent of the money is typically spent in the year that Congress approves it, and the rest is spent over several years.
 
Parallel to After Vietnam War
By looking back about 20 years, when the Vietnam War was winding down, experts can track what happened the last time that military spending was sharply lowered. In constant dollars, the military budget was cut by 22 percent between 1968 and 1975.
Almost all that money was spent to expand social programs, especially Social Security payments and Medicare. The economy went into a recession, but almost no one blamed it on the military cuts.
Military contractors did not lose as much business then as might have been expected, because they were able to expand their sales abroad, particularly to Saudi Arabia and other oil-producing countries.

HEADLINE: President Seeks a Way to Adapt His Cool Persona to a Hot Medium

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
As George Bush's Presidential style comes to sharper focus on television screens, it is obvious that this chief executive is less interested in being another Great Communicator than in following the advice his mother used to give him: Don't brag; it's in bad taste.
After 10 months and one day in office, President Bush has shown an abiding aversion to grand public gestures, televised speeches, reflective ideological discourses and stage-managed media events intended to make him larger than life.
By this time in 1981, Ronald Reagan had given seven televised prime-time speeches. As President, he practiced his anecdotes for staff members in the Oval Office, coaxing tears from their eyes on one occasion as he read a story about a letter from a soldier's mother. 
Mr. Bush, who one associate said ''hates being compared to you-know-who,'' will deliver his second televised prime-time speech on Wednesday. He will rehearse with one or two people present to become accustomed to a Teleprompter, White House aides said.
 
'The Great Administrator'
''George Bush does not want to be the Great Communicator; he wants to be the Great Administrator,'' said S. Robert Lichter, an expert on the televised Presidency who is co-director of the Center for Media and Public Affairs in Washington.
''He is trying to deal with the public in the same way he deals with Congress: low-key without a lot of pretense,'' Mr. Lichter said. ''And he has that inbred sense that it is wrong to parade himself before the public.''
It is a reflection of Mr. Bush's position as Mr. Reagan's successor that this argument is being aired at all. Apart from Franklin D. Roosevelt, who was a master of the radio address, and the telegenic John F. Kennedy, modern American Presidents have not been masters of television, nor have they used it, as Mr. Reagan did, as a primary means of forcing policies into practice.
But some political strategists say Mr. Reagan changed the rules. They argue that Mr. Bush is still searching for his electronic Presidential voice and has suffered by appearing wooden or unfocused on camera.
Mr. Bush is not an adroit ad-libber. At times, he also seems to have trouble articulating his positions on tough issues like abortion, and he was widely criticized as not giving an enthusiastic enough response to the tumultuous events in Eastern Europe.
 
Blaming Speechwriters
Some critics of Mr. Bush's oratory blame his speechwriters, whose work can seem flat after the rousing convention and campaign speeches written last year by Peggy Noonan, who was a speechwriter for Mr. Reagan as well.
''With the proper guidance,'' said Myles Mertell, a former Republican political consultant who now specializes in corporate clients, ''George Bush may not be able to master TV as effectively as Ronald Reagan did, but he can certainly become far more effective than he currently is.''
But White House aides and other associates of the President say this is indeed the President's voice. They say it is as deep-rooted as that long-ago bit of maternal advice and is not likely to change.
Mr. Bush, they say, prefers small gatherings and is most effective in those settings. They note that he has high ratings in opinion polls despite a public image that gives him more of the exuberant gangliness of an Irish setter than the commanding, political terrier he is said to be in private.
Some critics say Mr. Bush's lack of television presence has left him open to charges of dull vision and has cost him a valuable forum for putting his programs into action. Again, he is often compared with Mr. Reagan, who seemed to have a knack for crystallizing national sentiment and expressing it on television.
But Robert Goodman, a leading Republican media consultant, argues that Mr. Bush is doing just that.
 
'People Want to Go Along'
''I don't think he has grand visions, but I don't think he's getting the message that the country is asking for a grand vision,'' Mr. Goodman said. ''This is a time when people want to go along, keep their kids safe, hope the school bus comes home on time, that inflation doesn't go up and we can make ends meet, and Bush does a nice thing with that mood.''
Clearly, Mr. Bush is not as commanding a television presence as Mr. Reagan was. Mr. Lichter, who calculates every minute devoted to Presidential coverage on the three broadcast networks, said there were 336 reports about Mr. Bush in his first 100 days in office, compared with 790 about Mr. Reagan and 906 about President Jimmy Carter.
But Mr. Lichter's analysis of Mr. Bush's television coverage in that period is revealing: 70 percent had a negative tone when it came to Mr. Bush's policies, while nearly as many, 61 percent, were positive when it came to the President as a person.
 
An Aversion to 'Handlers'
White House aides say Mr. Bush's approach to television speechmaking reflects an aversion to the ''handlers'' who exhort him to appear on television more often, to be more exuberant, to liven it up just a bit.
The speech, one official said, was conceived by the staff of the National Security Council ''as a way of showing U.S. and Presidential leadership on a historical happening - Eastern Europe - that has gripped the American people for weeks.''
Mr. Bush, the aide said, was no more widely enthusiastic about making this televised speech than he was about his previous prime-time address, a speech on his anti-drug policy in which he often appeared stiff and ill at ease.
''Bush hates to be cornered,'' said a longtime associate. ''Unless the stakes are high enough that he can suspend his aversion to television, one thing that has happened with him becoming President is that he now feels he can tell all the media handlers to shove off. He's the President, after all.''

HEADLINE: 5 Senators Struggle to Avoid Keating Inquiry Fallout

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Five Senators entangled in a fast-growing savings and loan investigation are struggling to devise a public relations and legal strategy to distance themselves from political fallout - and from each other.
The Senators - Alan Cranston of California, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, John Glenn of Ohio, Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, all Democrats, and John McCain, Republican of Arizona - are accused of intervening with banking regulators to protect a well-heeled campaign contributor, Charles H. Keating Jr. Political analysts and poll takers say that recent disclosures about the Keating Five, as they have been nicknamed on Capitol Hill, pose a political threat to the Senators, one that has grown particularly grave after last week's announcement of a formal investigation by the Senate Ethics Committee.
The Senators' efforts to deal with what even their closest supporters acknowledge is a political crisis are as different as the lawmakers themselves. 
 
All Seeking to Avoid Blame
Some are talking to the press; some refuse. A number have hired outside lawyers, while others see that as unnecessary, at least for now. All are trying to shift the blame to Federal regulators and to prominent figures in business.
Their strategies may have to be scrapped as more details emerge about their relationship with Mr. Keating, whose company, the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., collapsed earlier this year. The Lincoln bailout may cost taxpayers as much as $2 billion.
While the evidence of political damage from the Lincoln Savings debacle is still sketchy, statewide polls in Arizona have already shown a sharp drop in approval ratings for Senator DeConcini and Senator McCain.
In California, Michigan and Ohio, Republican organizers are not unhappy as Senators Cranston, Riegle and Glenn try to explain why they accepted such large campaign contributions from Mr. Keating and his associates.
 
Call From the Opposition
Last week, the Republican state chairman in Michigan, E. Spencer Abraham, called on Mr. Riegle to consider removing himself as chairman of the Senate Banking Committee. ''The ongoing revelations and conflicting testimony erode his influence in the Senate,'' Mr. Abraham said.
The Republican chairman in Ohio, Robert T. Bennett, said even though the Keating investigation may not yet have ''sunk in'' among the state's voters, it eventually will.
In California, the poll taker Mervin Field believes Mr. Cranston is ''in deep trouble'' since recent Congressional testimony by elderly Californians who blamed the Senator for the loss of their life savings in Keating-related investments.
''The fact that real, live people will testify that they're impoverished by the failure of a savings and loan which Cranston is linked to, is devastating,'' Mr. Field said. Perhaps the most important tactical decision faced by the five Senators is how much to say in public about the Keating investigation, and when to say it. At one end of the spectrum, Senator McCain has decided upon what his aides describe as a campaign of full disclosure.
 
McCain Speaking Out
On Oct. 16, the Senator, whose reputation as a rising star in the Republican Party has been tarnished by the investigation, held a 90-minute news conference in Phoenix to answer questions about his efforts on behalf of Lincoln Savings.
''He's talked with all of the major newspapers, and he's spoken at some point with each of the television networks,'' said Scott Celley, a spokesman. ''The Senator is quite confident that the more people know about his role in this, the more comfortable they will be.''
For the other Senators, however, full disclosure carries the risk that, by responding to each new wave of allegations, they may provide news organizations and political opponents with a daily vehicle to keep the issue alive.
Senator Riegle has said relatively little about his relationship with Mr. Keating, refusing interview requests and ordering aides not to talk to reporters about the subject.
A Riegle aide who spoke to talk on condition he not be identified said the Senator thought it improper to discuss subjects under investigation by the ethics committee. And the Senator, the aide said, does not have time to address a barrage of reporters' questions. ''The No. 1 consideration is making sure the Senator can get his job done,'' the aide explained.
 
Riegle Begins to Respond
But the strategy has threatened to backfire on Senator Riegle, who has been forced in recent days to ignore the no-comment rule and respond to news reports that have documented closer ties between the Senator and Mr. Keating than had previously been known.
The Senators have also faced a delicate issue of whether to bring in outside lawyers to represent them in investigation now being conducted by the ethics committee and the Justice Department, which has convened a grand jury in Los Angeles to review criminal allegations against Mr. Keating.
Senate aides who asked not to be identified said that some of the five lawmakers had been reluctant to bring in private counsel, fearing that a decision to hire a private legal team could create the appearance of crisis.
Yet in recent weeks Mr. McCain, Mr. Glenn and Mr. Cranston decided to take the gamble and retained high-powered lawyers to deal with the Keating affair.
 
Glenn Hires Ex-U.S. Attorney
Senator Glenn has hired Charles F. C. Ruff, a former United States Attorney in Washington and Watergate prosecutor, to oversee Mr. Glenn's reply to a recent letter from the Senate ethics committee about his relationship with Mr. Keating. ''That's what he's there for - just to put together that response,'' Rebecca Bell, a Glenn spokeswoman, said of Mr. Ruff.
Even as Mr. Ruff maps out a legal strategy for the Senator, Ms. Bell and her counterparts elsewhere on Capitol Hill are conducting their own campaign in the trenches of public relations.
For Ms. Bell, formerly of NBC News, that has meant steering reporters to documentary evidence that tends to mitigate Senator Glenn's role in the Keating affair. The evidence is contained in notes of an April 1987 meeting at which Senator Glenn and his four colleagues discussed Lincoln Savings with a group of Federal regulators.
The notes, prepared by one of the regulators, show that Senator Glenn may have been far more cautious than the other Senators in defending Lincoln Savings, and that at one point he told the regulators: ''I'm not trying to get anyone off. If there's wrongdoing, I'm on your side.''
In the press offices of the four other senators, aides have been busy photocopying and distributing copies of a 1985 letter written on Mr. Keating's behalf by Alan Greenspan, an economist who is now the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Mr. Greenspan's letter described the management of Lincoln Savings as ''seasoned and expert'' with a ''record of outstanding success.''
In an interview, Bob Maynes, a spokesman for Senator DeConcini, said that Mr. Greenspan's assurances were ''significant in convincing Dennis'' that Lincoln deserved assistance. Within hours of his conversation with a reporter last Thursday, Mr. Maynes made sure that a copy of the Greenspan letter was in the reporter's hands. ''We're trying to get this information out,'' he said.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Lessons

BYLINE: By Edward B. Fiske

 BODY:
The New York City economy, which once boasted a prosperous manufacturing sector, has become almost entirely oriented around service industries.
In 1988, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the proportion of jobs held by people providing services, everyone from hairdressers to investment advisers, reached 87 percent. Big gainers include lawyers, accountants, data processors, registered nurses and teachers.
The shift raises an important question for public schools: Should they be turning out students with different skills than in the past? 
One person who believes they should is Audrey Cohen, a former social studies teacher who has developed what she calls ''a whole new way'' of educating people. ''Today's world has almost nothing in common with the world of 50 years ago,'' she said. ''It requires a different system of education.''
Ms. Cohen began thinking this way in the mid 1960's when she established a federally backed center in Manhattan to train poor women for paraprofessional jobs in the public schools, hospitals and legal aid agencies. She observed that these jobs and others then developing required fundamentally different skills from those needed for manufacturing.
''Manufacturing jobs tend to involve knowledge that can be learned and applied in rote fashion,'' she said. ''Jobs are specialized. People work in isolation from each other. They don't have to be creative or able to make decisions.''
By contrast, she said, many service jobs require teamwork and the ability to improvise. ''Most service jobs pose problems that have no set answers,'' she said. ''If you're asked to improve the morale of a hospital staff, you don't just follow orders.''
To Ms. Cohen, American schools reflect the old values. ''They cut knowledge into subjects that are unrelated not only to each other but to real life,'' she said. ''They teach information, but not the ability to use it. They foster competition and individual achievement, not cooperation and teamwork.''
In 1964 Ms. Cohen set out to build a school around her ideas, founding what became the College for Human Services to train disadvantaged women - and, four years later, men - for service jobs. It is now an accredited institution offering bachelor and master's degrees.
In 1983 the New York City Board of Education became interested in her approach. A College for Human Services Junior High School was established in East Harlem, and last year the idea was extended to six elementary and intermediate schools in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx and to an evening high school in Manhattan. Ms. Cohen is also working with a middle school in Pensacola, Fla. Since jobs in the service sector require working with people, often in teams, the programs emphasize learning in which students carry out assignments as groups.
One day recently, students in Gloria Carlson's sixth grade class at Public School 38 in Brooklyn were studying world hunger, and she asked them what they might be able to do about it. They then split into six groups to consider the problem and fill out questionnaires. Asked what was most surprising about the team approach, Jennifer Fortunato, one of the students, replied, ''We didn't fight the way we usually do.''
Instead of organizing classes around mathematics, social studies or other traditional subjects, the schools use categories like ''recognizing values'' and ''understanding self and others.'' Doing so while conforming to Board of Education curriculum guidelines is no small feat.
Teachers insist everything is covered, though recognizable lessons show up in the strangest places. A fire became the occasion for the junior high school students to learn statistics by analyzing and ranking likely causes for the blaze. They also combined art and mathematics by visiting landmark buildings, taking measurements and then building models to scale. And an examination of Caribbean paintings became the springboard for studying prisms and color.
''Successful schools revolve around kids' interests, and these schools show a real-world connection,'' said Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers.
The College for Human Services and the United Federation of Teachers plan to propose that Joseph A. Fernandez, who will become the New York City Schools Chancellor in January, expand the experiment to more New York City schools.
To Ms. Cohen, the overriding goal for her students is to ''let them know that knowledge has consequences for action.'' It is a goal that was not lost on one student in Ms. Carlson's class. As a recent visitor was leaving, the student presented him with a handmade flier that read ''Help us put a stop to hunger.''

HEADLINE: Potato Museum Seeks a New Home

BYLINE: By RUTH M. RICHMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
They may be lumpy, dirty and taken for granted, but potatoes have managed to provoke excitement among six states vying for a museum dedicated to their history and social relevance.
Meredith and E. Thomas Hughes, who run what they call the world's only potato museum from the basement of their Washington house, must relocate when their lease runs out next August.
Since news of their predicament was published a few months ago, the Hugheses have been contacted by interested municipalities, states and economic-development committees in Colorado, Idaho, Maine, North Dakota, Washington and Wisconsin, as well as the United States Agriculture Department. Why does the museum hold so much appeal? The Hugheses say their museum is unique in concept, as well as subject. ''There are endless museums devoted to wars, battlefields and weapons, but nothing about food,'' Mrs. Hughes told a recent visitor.' 
As for those seeking the museum, officials see it as a potential boost to the industry and community in which the museum plants its roots.
The Hugheses' two-room exhibit, which accommodates only one-fourth of their collection, includes hundreds of historical drawings and tools documenting potato production. An array of stuffed ''couch potatoes'' and a 4,000-year-old potato discovered in Chile are among the items that crowd the shelves and floors.
Begun as a classroom project when Mr. Hughes taught fifth grade in Belgium, the museum moved with the Hugheses to Washington in 1983. Since then, it has become an internationally known center for information about potatoes.
Open on an appointment-only basis, the museum attracted several hundred visitors last year, Mrs. Hughes said. The National Museum of Natural History at the Smithsonian Institution has selected the potato, along with maize, sugar, the horse and disease, for an exhibit on five items that have changed the American continents. Mr. Hughes is a guest curator of the exhibit, scheduled to open in October 1991, which will feature several items loaned from the potato museum.
Although the nonprofit, tax-exempt museum receives some financing from the International Potato Center in Lima, Peru, the Hugheses earn their money teaching and writing. They see their impending move as a chance to expand the museum into a food exposition they will be paid to run.
But the states who have contacted the Hugheses seem more interested in a museum solely about potatoes. The question of which state most deserves those riches has sparked some debate.
''We were producing potatoes when Idaho was still full of Indians and buffalo,'' said Bernard W. Shaw, Agricultural Commissioner of Maine, during a recent visit to the museum. ''We were the first in the land, and at one time the largest.''
Maine produced the most potatoes in the nation until the 1940's, when irrigation techniques allowed Western states to take the lead. Maine now ranks third behind Idaho and Washington. ''Maine potatoes are O.K. for boiling, but for baking they are waxy and don't taste good.'' said W. Rex Call, head of the potato exposition committee of the Blackfoot Economic Development Council in Idaho. ''With or without the Hugheses,'' he said, Blackfoot plans to build a ''tiny Disney World of potatoes.''
Representatives from Colorado, North Dakota, Washington and Wisconsin sound equally certain that their potato-growing histories and locations make their states ideal for a tuber museum.
The Hugheses, who call themselves ''potato neutral,'' said the location most accessible to tourists would be the best one. Two million tourists pass Blackfoot on their way to and from Yellowstone National Park, for example.
But Mr. Hughes worries that Maine, on the other hand, would put a museum in northern potato country, where ''even a lot of people from Maine have never been.''
That is why a recent call from a United States Department of Agriculture Research Center in Beltsville, Md., was of particular interest to the Hugheses. Situated near the District of Columbia, Beltsville ''could be used for a major museum,'' Mrs. Hughes said.
The Hugheses hope to find a site by March and will travel the country to find it. They remain open to all offers. ''We're all potato eaters,'' Mrs. Hughes said.
Meanwhile, the museum is still open to visitors. For an appointment, call 202-544-1558. Admission is free.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Learning to Wear Poverty Like a Crown

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

He Included Me
The Autobiography of Sarah Rice
Transcribed and edited by Louise Westling
181 pages. Illustrated. The University of
Georgia Press. $19.95.
In the oral history tradition of Theodore Rosengarten's ''All God's Dangers: The Life of Nate Shaw,'' which related the hardships of a black sharecropper in Alabama, Louise Westling's ''He Included Me: The Autobiography of Sarah Rice'' reconstructs the difficult but dignified life of a black woman in Alabama and Florida during a large part of the 20th century. It's a moving story that reveals a hidden corner of American life. 
Most one-day-a-week cleaning women, North or South, live private lives that are largely unknown to the families they work for. They leave their own children at home in the care of grandmothers or older siblings and do the laundry or prepare the meals for someone else's family. In recession or prosperity, this imbalance has existed in the social fabric of the country for a long time. The theme of black families struggling to break out of poverty demands not benign neglect but continuing disclosure and attention.
Fortunately, Sarah Rice and Louise Westling are well matched to meet the challenge. Mrs. Rice, who was born in rural Alabama in 1909 and now lives in Florida, served as a one-day-a-week house worker for Miss Westling's mother 30 years ago. They have kept in touch ever since. Miss Westling, author of books about Eudora Welty, Carson McCullers and Flannery O'Connor, is an associate professor of English at the University of Oregon. Mrs. Rice spoke into Miss Westling's tape recorder for months; together they edited the material for narrative clarity.
The first-person voice of Sarah Rice develops anecdotally, assuming the natural form in which memories are stored. She is a gifted storyteller who doesn't hold back the unpleasant details of her life and marriages. ''He Included Me'' reads like an older generation's version of Maya Angelou's ''I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings'' and ''Mary'' and ''Mary, Wayfarer,'' Mary Mebane's autobiographical sketches, though without their literary underpinning.
Sarah Rice's poverty was inherited; finding the next meal was frequently the goal of daily life in rural Alabama, for unemployed whites as well as blacks. Young Sarah's mother obtained work doing washing and ironing for strangers, and Sarah remembers developing a feeling of shame about herself and her mother:
''One day she told my brother Jim and me to stop by at a white lady's house to pick up a bundle of clothes. Jim and I thought of ourselves as the preacher's children, and we weren't going to walk through the streets carrying any clothes on our heads. We told Mama we were ashamed. I never will forget that; I can almost feel the pain now.''
Her mother lectured them: ''I'm going to tell you something. Your father doesn't make much money. You all need clothes, and you need things like other children. I thought if I did some washing that I could help supplement your Daddy's income so that you all could look like other children. It's no disgrace to work. It's an honor to make an honest dollar.''
Sarah and her brother wept. It was almost sundown, but they immediately ran down the hill to the white woman's house and ''strutted like those clothes were crowns on our heads.'' The lesson of retaining one's dignity despite poverty stuck with her when she grew up.
At the age of 17, Sarah began teaching in grade school. Some of the students were older than she. She lied to the school board about her age so she could get her first teaching assignment. In one of the outspoken remarks that appear throughout the book, she says: ''You were supposed to be 21. White people just kind of look at black folks and think they all look the same, so I could pass for 21 with them.''
She endured two unhappy marriages. Both of her husbands had wandering eyes and wanderlust. While she worked to support the family, they squandered her earnings. She left each of them in turn and returned to live with her mother, who was always supportive. Instead of continuing to teach, she became a domestic. Her spirits were sustained by studies at black colleges and by church and community work. The narrative occasionally becomes disjointed, between her changing jobs, husbands and boyfriends. But eventually she moves to Florida and is happily married to Andrew Rice, a devout companion until his death in 1983.
The religious tone of the title derives from a song, ''He Included Me,'' that her mother taught her about being grateful for life. Sarah Rice ends her story on a hopeful note:
''Just to think that from my grandfather not being able to read or write, or his wife either, and coming up from slavery, all this family grew. When the slaves were freed, they didn't have any direction or anybody to tell them what to do, so they were almost as bad off as during slavery. But now, here we were all together, all these branches of the family, including teachers and nurses and preachers and businessmen and musicians. Wouldn't Mama and Papa have been proud?''

HEADLINE: Book Notes

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell

 BODY:

Report on South Africa
Last spring, Lisa Drew, a senior editor at William Morrow & Company, and Robert Wedgeworth, the dean of the School of Library Service at Columbia University, spent 10 days in South Africa, asking writers, librarians and educators on both sides of the issue of apartheid how they felt about including books and educational materials in the cultural boycott against South Africa. The two were there under the auspices of the International Freedom to Publish Committee of the Association of American Publishers and of the Fund for Free Expression, a group of authors, journalists, lawyers, publishers and others.
Dean Wedgeworth reported back to the two organizations that by embargoing the sale and shipment of books to South Africa, Americans are unwittingly abetting the South African Government in its ''systematic starvation of young black minds.'' Last week the sponsors released the report of that mission: ''The Starvation of Young Black Minds: The Effect of Book Boycotts in South Africa.'' 
In it Dean Wedgeworth and Ms. Drew wrote that each of the more than 75 people with whom they spoke - including those who support economic sanctions and the general cultural boycott as it affects athletic contests, rock concerts and so forth - opposed the book boycott. They said that the African National Congress also opposes a boycott of books and other cultural products that ''enhance the struggle for democracy and promote democratic human values.''
The two recommended that the Association of American Publishers request the American Library Association, the African Studies Association and other interested educational and cultural organizations to support their call for the removal of books from the cultural boycott.
 
2 No. 1's for Guild
Both December main selections of the Literary Guild will be No. 1's on the New York Times best-seller lists this Sunday: ''Daddy'' (Delacorte) by Danielle Steel will head the hard-cover fiction list, while ''My Turn'' (Random House) by Nancy Reagan with William Novak will head the nonfiction list.
Robert P. Riger, the president of the Doubleday Book and Music Clubs Inc., which owns the Literary Guild, said the two best sellers represented the guild's first attempt to pair a fiction and a nonfiction title. ''In the past, our main selections have been almost entirely fiction,'' he said. Now, he said, he wants that mix to include about one-third nonfiction, because nonfiction books have always done well when offered as alternate selections, and it is increasingly hard to pick 32 compelling fiction titles a year. (The guild offers dual main selections 16 times a year.) But the change in emphasis is no doubt also prompted by what publishing executives say is a shortage of ''big books,'' especially ''big'' novels. Thus in competing for popular novels to offer members, the guild and its principal rival, the Book-of-the-Month Club, often find themelves locked in costly combat over a relatively small number of titles. By offering more nonfiction, the guild can offer a broader choice while lessening the financial pressures of having to win battles for the most popular fiction or settle for what's available.
 
3 No. 1's for Janklow
Morton Janklow, the literary agent, is also happy about next Sunday's best-seller lists. He represents both Ms. Steel and Mrs. Reagan, and he also represents Sidney Sheldon, whose ''The Sands of Time'' (Warner Books) will be the No. 1 paperback fiction title. ''I think this is the first time any agent has ever had three No. 1's on the list at the same time,'' Mr. Janklow said.

THE ECONOMY

 
The executive who controlled Lincoln Savings declined to answer questions from Congress about the institution's collapse, but Charles H. Keating Jr. issued a statement blaming regulators for what may be the largest savings and loan failure. [Page A1.]
 
The Consumer Price Index rose 0.5 percent in October, the biggest increase since May, the Labor Department said. The rise was mostly from sizable gains in housing and transportation costs. [D1.] 
 
Congress neared final approval of a plan to pare $14.7 billion from the Federal deficit. [B6.] President Bush vetoed legislation to create a congressional panel to investigate and propose solutions to the Eastern Airlines strike. [B6.]
 
The Texas statehouse is in a bitter standoff over measures to overhaul the system of compensating workers for injuries. [D3.]
 
COMPANIES
 
Texas Instruments has received a patent for its original semiconductor from Japan's patent office. The action could bring the company more than $2 billion in royalty fees. [D1.]
 
Striking telephone workers reached a tentative settlement with New York Telephone. [B1.] The second-longest strike in Boeing's history ended as 57,800 machinists agreed to go back to work. [A1.]
 
The Federal Government accused New York Telephone of not informing employees about hazardous materials, and proposed $377,240 in fines. [B4.]
 
More investment bankers, brokers and office workers face the year-end prospect of sharply lower incomes or no jobs at all. [A1.]

Some large corporations squared off against the S.E.C. in a legal challenge to limits on an anti-takeover tactic. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Could Avert Recession

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
American consumers are laden with debt, but instead of staggering under the burden, they have plenty of borrowing power in reserve -enough, some economists suggest, to help ward off a recession.
This flies in the face of the common expectation that when consumers get deeply in debt they have to cut back on borrowing, weakening the economy in the process. No such cutback has happened yet, and now economists are revising their expectations. In fact, two new studies suggest that the consumer could, in theory, help prop up the economy. 
To be sure, Government data show the economy is weakening. Consumers have cut back on spending recently, not because they lacked the borrowing power to buy on credit, but because of ''apprehension'' about the economy's future, according to surveys of consumer sentiment.
''People see sluggish economic growth on the horizon and they are being more cautious about their spending,'' said Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's consumer surveys.
The new studies on borrowing power focus on the upheaval that in recent years has changed the structure of personal debt. The total debt held by individuals and households is $3.4 trillion today, higher than ever. But the repayment period has been so stretched out that a borrower's monthly installments barely rise with each new loan and use up a relatively small percentage of disposable income. What is more, Federal Reserve Board data show that most of the new consumer installment loans in the 1980's have gone to the nation's wealthiest households, and they have the income to handle repayment.
 
'The Consumer Is in Good Shape'
''The relentless story you keep hearing is that the consumer is tapped out; he can't borrow more and he is about to retrench,'' said James A. Wilcox, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, and the author of one of the new studies. ''But the debt service numbers tell a different story. They are remarkably stable, and they say the consumer is in good shape as a borrower.''
Many factors have led to the debt-stretching, which means, in effect, that a $240 loan over 10 years requires the same $2 a month to repay as a $120 loan over five years.
Car loans, for example, now average 4.5 years, up from three years in the early 1980's. Many fixed-rate mortgages are for 30 years today instead of the 25 years common a decade ago. And mortgages taken out at interest rates above 15 percent have been refinanced with rates at 13 percent or less. The lower rates reduce monthly payments.
Home equity loans, nonexistent until the mid-1980's, have become a major tool for stretching out debt. These loans, with payments stretched over 10 to 15 years, are often used to pay off loans with much shorter maturities, like credit card debt and revolving bank credit, which require repayment in monthly installments over only three years. Another reason for their growing use is that the interest paid on them is still fully deductible from taxable income.
Home equity loans are now held by about 5.5 percent of all homeowners, up from nearly zero in the early 1980's. The loans average $13,000, with most maturing in 10 to 15 years, according to the American Financial Association, a trade group.
 
Credit Cards Stretch Debt
Even credit cards have been used to stretch debt. Instead of presenting department store charge cards, which usually require repayment in one year, shoppers now often use a Visa or Mastercard, for which a three-year payoff is allowed.
''The result is that the ratio of payments to income has even declined since 1985,'' said Edward F. McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company. Debt repayment consumed 17.9 percent of Americans' disposable income in 1985 - the decade's high - and has declined since to about 16.7 percent now, he said.
But a major reason consumers can take on still more debt with equanimity is that 45 percent of the more than $750 billion in outstanding consumer credit is in the hands of the wealthiest 20 percent of the nation's households, said Thomas A. Durkin, a Federal Reserve Board economist, in a recent analysis. That is up from 21.7 percent in 1970 and 36.5 percent in 1977.
 
Poorest's Borrowing Unchanged
In contrast, the poorest households, at the bottom 40 percent of income, account for 19 percent of borrowing, unchanged since the early 1970's.
''My guess is that the same trend holds true not only for consumer credit, but for total household debt, although the Federal Reserve has not run the numbers on this,'' Mr. Durkin said. The total debt of $3.4 trillion held by Americans includes mortgages, home equity loans, brokerage house loans, mobile home loans and the various forms of consumer credit.
Why are the wealthy such big borrowers? During the high inflation of the late 1970's, wealthy households realized the advantages of repaying debt in dollars whose value was being eroded by inflation, Mr. Durkin said. And interest payments were fully deductible then. In addition, as the American economy expanded in the 1980's, the wealthy stepped up purchases of appliances, computers, cars and other expensive durable goods normally bought on credit, he said.
At the same time, the wealthiest households are also the nation's biggest savers, and with deregulation of bank interest rates, the earnings on their savings deposits have risen. ''Since you can get a good return on savings today, the wealthy borrow temporarily rather than draw down their savings,'' said William Dunkelberg, a Temple University economist.
Using Federal Reserve data, Mr. McKelvey calculates that total household debt is roughly equal to 90.4 percent of people's annual disposable income, down just a bit from the record of 91.1 percent in last year's fourth quarter. But while the total debt-to-income ratio has risen from 88.4 percent in 1986, installment payments as a percentage of income have fallen in the same period, to the 16.7 percent today, Mr. McKelvey said. That is only half the repayment level that lenders say households could handle without getting in over their heads.
 
'Not Being Pinched'
''People are certainly not being pinched,'' Mr. McKelvey said.
But even if Americans can afford more debt, they might retrench anyway - for psychological reasons, said Mr. Curtin, Michigan's director of consumer surveys. Among their concerns, he said, is fear that a weakening economy might push up unemployment and endanger their income.
Indeed, consumers have pulled back on spending, a trend that showed up last week in the Commerce Department's retail sales report for October. Consequently, consumer credit is growing more slowly now than in the spring and summer, although this slowdown in growth has been largely offset by a rise in home equity lending.
Michigan's monthly surveys also show that rising interest rates earlier this year discouraged consumers, since such increases frequently precede an economic slowdown, Mr. Curtin said, adding that interest rates are now falling again, but that consumers remain skeptical. ''They see the country just muddling along,'' he said, ''and that can slow their spending and their borrowing even if they have the wherewithal to take out new loans.''

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Up By 0.5%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Sizable increases in the cost of housing and transportation propelled the Consumer Price Index up five-tenths of 1 percent in October from September, the biggest rise since May, the Labor Department reported today.
Even though the seasonally adjusted acceleration was a bit faster than expected and affected a broad spectrum of goods and services, most economists seemed to believe that inflation would be kept from reaching worrisome levels by the current deceleration of the economy.
A minority, however, took today's report as further evidence that the inflation rate will soon exceed 5 percent over a sustained period and said that the Federal Reserve would need to perform a nearly impossible balancing act - curbing price pressures while heading off recession.
Before rounding, the October increase was 0.4811548 of a percent, a figure that if maintained and compounded for 12 months, would produce an annual inflation rate of 5.9 percent. The Consumer Price Index posted an inflation rate of 4.6 percent over the first 10 months of the year, slightly more than the 4.4 percent rates recorded for both 1988 and 1987. 
 
Higher Than Producer Index
Today's report of inflation at the consumer level was slightly higher than the four-tenths of 1 percent increase reported 12 days ago for prices received in October by producers of finished goods. In addition, the producer price indexes for goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production reported at that time showed no inflation at all. Generally, changes in prices at the producer level affect consumers after various lags ranging up to six months.
A seemingly typical reaction to today's figures was that of Gordon Richards, an economist for the National Association of Manufacturers. He said various temporary or erratic factors, such as the end of discount-financing programs used to encourage automobile sales, exaggerated the true degree of inflation in October.
Nevertheless, he added: ''Even if the increase is overstated, these figures are not likely to provide much assurance to financial markets. There is little likelihood that interest rates will decline until there is stronger evidence of a slowdown in inflation.''
Inflation accelerated in five of the seven main Consumer Price Index categories last month, while slowing somewhat from previously rapid increases in the remaining two categories.
When the volatile food and energy items are removed, the remaining categories, the so-called core rate of inflation, rose at a five-tenths of 1 percent rate in October - also the highest since May - up from two-tenths of 1 percent in September.
One Labor Department specialist said he expected the Consumer Price Index to post average monthly increases of four-tenths of 1 percent in the current quarter, a result better than when food and energy drove the annual rate to 6.7 percent in the first five months of the year, but worse than during the summer, when energy and apparel prices tumbled and the rate was 1.6 percent.
In all, the official said, ''nothing stands out on the horizon'' to cause alarm.
 
Moderating Forces Called Weak
But Joel Popkin, a Washington consultant and former Labor Department inflation expert, has been pessimistic about prices for some time and said today's figures did nothing to reassure him. He contended that the forces that had been holding down inflation - the drop in oil prices, moderation in food, a strong dollar and even poor car demand - are now played out and that the inflation rate was headed to 5 percent or higher.
When asked about continued poor auto sales, Mr. Popkin said Detroit was responding to this so far with production cuts rather than a new round of price incentives.
Grocery store prices advanced five-tenths of 1 percent in October, the biggest increase since May, as the price of fruits and vegetables rose 1.2 percent after falling nearly that much in September. Apples and bananas rose sharply, and dairy products jumped by 1.8 percent, the biggest increase in more than nine years.
The housing component, accounting for 42 percent of the Consumer Price Index, climbed four-tenths of 1 percent in October as rental costs, which include hotels, rose six-tenths of 1 percent. Telephone service, however, fell eight-tenths of 1 percent.
In transportation, which declined in each of the preceding months, the overall increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent in October largely reflected a statistical adjustment to include a nine-tenths of 1 percent jump in the price of gasoline. Actually, the price of gasoline - often said to be the nation's most visible single price - was unchanged at the pump from the month before. The rise reflected in the report was to take into account the amount of the usual seasonal price decline in gasoline for October.
 
Higher Prices for Cars
The price of new cars rose six-tenths of 1 percent after five straight monthly declines. The higher prices of 1990 models, which accounted for about one-quarter of the survey, were included for the first time this year. Automobile finance charges rose 1.3 percent after four straight declines, while the price of used cars continued to fall.
Apparel rose sharply for the second straight month, following the introduction of new autumn lines, but analysts predicted clothing prices would ease in coming months.
In medical care, the seven-tenths of 1 percent October advance was slightly less than in September, but the medical inflation rate is still 8.8 percent over the last three months, and 8.1 percent over the last year.
Today's report also showed that the cost of commodities climbed six-tenths of 1 percent last month after falling slightly on average in August and September. The price of services climbed five-tenths of 1 percent, or as much as in August and September combined.
The Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers, which are 80 percent of the population, now stands at 125.6. This means that a hypothetical basket of goods and services that cost $10 in 1982-84 now costs $12.56.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mark Shows Its Strength; Dollar Drops

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar dropped sharply against the West German mark yesterday, closing at its lowest level since early January. The dollar also fell against other leading currencies, including the Japanese yen.
Traders said the market action was a reflection of the strength of the mark and the West German economy more than a sign of weakness in the dollar. The mark also rose strongly against the yen, reaching its highest level since the end of 1987, and against the British pound, closing at its highest point in more than two and a half years. 
''This dollar weakness is better labeled Deutsche mark strength,'' said John Lipsky, director of international bond trading at Salomon Brothers in London.
In late trading, the dollar was at 1.8140 marks, down from 1.8337 on Monday. This is the lowest the dollar has been since Jan. 5, when it closed at 1.8003. The dollar's recent tumble against the mark, which began in earnest after the stock market fell 190 points on Oct. 13, has countered most of the gains the dollar had made against the mark this year.
At its 1989 high, when it was over 2 marks, the dollar was up more than 15 percent. But its gain is now just 2.5 percent for the year. In addition, the dollar is now well below the ceiling of 1.90 marks that the United States and its Group of Seven economic allies are believed to have set as an acceptable level.
 
Strong Against the Yen
The dollar still remains strong against the yen. At 143.55 yesterday, the dollar is still above the 140 level, which is believed to be the Group of Seven's ceiling against the Japanese currency. And the dollar's gain for the year still exceeds 14 percent.
One reason for the difference is that the Germans have aggressively raised interest rates and bluntly spoken of their desire for a strong mark, even if it meant a realignment of the European Monetary System.
The Japanese, with much less domestic pressure for higher interest rates, have not moved quickly to raise rates, and the yen has therefore remained weaker against the dollar. This has meant that the interest rate differential between the dollar and the yen is wider and more attractive to investors and speculators than the narrowing spread between the dollar and the mark.
With a wide differential, investors are more likely to buy securities denominated in the currency with the higher rates. As the differential narrows, investors tend to pull money back, which is what has pushed the dollar lower against the mark.
 
'Moving Into Other Assets'
''Interest rates are coming off on the short end,'' said Peter Frick, a foreign exchange economist at the Union Bank of Switzerland. ''People are moving into other assets. Until Christmas that will be the prevailing factor.''
Mr. Lipsky of Salomon Brothers said he could not point to a particular event that set off the dollar's decline yesterday. But most of it happened during European trading, before the markets opened in New York.
Factors that have hurt the dollar have been in play for weeks in the United States, he said, including the slowing of the United States economy and the expectation that the Federal Reserve will move again to ease interest rates to prevent the economy from sliding into a recession.
He added that some of the worries about West Germany's economy that had resulted from the opening of East German borders had subsided. With West Germany's economy growing strongly, demand for the mark has increased, reflecting expecations that the West German central bank, the Bundesbank, will have to raise interest rates again.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Insider Charge at Emerson Radio

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
The Emerson Radio Corporation is engaged in a seemingly minor legal squabble in a Brooklyn Federal court that has shed light on a little-known insider-trading suit against the New Jersey company's top management that could have a serious impact on the once high-flying consumer electronics marketer. What has emerged is a story with famous names, allegations of managerial deceit and disgruntled shareholders.
The documents in the two-year-old insider-trading case have become public as a result of a conflict-of-interest dispute. In a court order signed two days ago, United States District Judge Jack B. Weinstein instructed Emerson Radio's outside directors, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and a former Federal Reserve governor, Lyle Gramley, to determine whether it is a conflict of interest for Emerson to be defended in the insider-trading case by law partners of a Manhattan attorney, Jay M. Haft, who is also an Emerson director. 
Mr. Mondale, Mr. Gramley and Mr. Haft are not named in the insider-trading suit, but Mr. Mondale and Mr. Haft were on the Emerson board during the months when the plaintiffs say illicit stock trading occurred.
The case that has touched off this recent dispute was filed in December 1987 by four investors who had bought Emerson stock in March and April of that year. In the class action, the plaintiffs accuse Emerson Radio (which is not related to Emerson Electric) and seven top executives of conspiring in late 1986 and early 1987 to mislead the public about Emerson's prospects while they sold more than 775,000 shares of the company's stock. Emerson Radio and its senior managers have denied the allegations of insider trading.
The shareholders contend that Emerson's top managers knew at least by mid-December 1986 that incoming orders were shrinking and sales of video cassette recorders, a key product for Emerson, were softening. According to the complaint, the officers warned various friends and relatives of the impending problems but conspired to hide the news from the general public by continuing to make optimistic forecasts to shareholders and Wall Street analysts until late May 1987.
The delay, the plaintiffs contend, was aimed at keeping Emerson's stock price strong until the company could close on a pending loan, and until senior corporate executives were free to sell their own shares at a profit. The executives had exercised stock options in July 1986 and, under Federal securities law, could not reap a profit on stock sales for six months.
Trading records submitted along with the class-action complaint by the plaintiffs, represented by the law firm Coleman & Rhine in New York, show that seven of Emerson's top officers, 13 of their employees, and various neighbors, friends and relatives sold 1.3 million shares of the company's stock between December 1986 and April 1987, before the company announced the sales downturn.
According to the company's lawyers, the executives' sales were made chiefly for tax reasons, or were consistent with the executive's trading patterns in prior years. Further, the management defendants deny that they were aware that the company had undergone any ''material adverse change,'' as the securities code defines it, until after the disputed sales were made.
According to the company's lawyers, the slump in consumer electronics sales did not become apparent until six weeks or so before the company's fiscal year ended on March 30, 1987. The problems were reported to shareholders, along with the company's sizable gain in annual profits, on May 20, 1987.
Whatever the outcome of this most recent squabble, the pending shareholder lawsuit seems likely to be an increasingly expensive and embarrassing one for Emerson Radio.
For one thing, aside from the distraction the case may pose to management and any damages that might be owed if the company loses the case, Emerson is paying the legal fees for itself and 20 of the individual defendants - the officers, the employees and the company chairman's mother.
And the company's defense, that it did not become aware that sales were slumping until near the end of the 1987 fiscal year, is not particularly flattering to management, especially in light of internal sales documents recently made public because of the case.
As the company routinely tells shareholders in its filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, ''The ability of management to correctly anticipate and provide for inventory requirements is essential to the successful operation of the company's business.'' But the sales data filed with the court show that Emerson's net new orders began to fall behind the prior year's level as early as September 1986 and continued to shrink through mid-December, traditionally the company's strongest sales period.
When the company reported its results for the three months ended Dec. 31, 1986, its sales had climbed 32 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier. But an examination of those records, which were filed with the S.E.C. in early February 1987, shows that Emerson's inventory of unsold goods was 113 percent higher than a year earlier - typically a sign of trouble for any manufacturer since it indicates that retailers are not selling as much of the company's products as had been anticipated.
And tucked among the court papers filed in the Emerson case is a Sept. 16, 1986, memorandum by Marino Andriani, senior vice president for sales at Emerson, who warned the company's sales force of serious problems in the VCR market, an important line of business for the company.
The company's lawyers argue that order flow is not as crucial as the plaintiffs contend since orders are subject to change. But portions of a deposition filed with the court quotes Harold Falik, Emerson's chief financial officer, as citing a two-month decline in orders as the red flag that first alerted him to possible problems more than six months after the Andriani memo.
In any case, when the company released its fourth-quarter results in May 1987, with the warning of weaker sales ahead, its stock softened. When the first quarter of the company's 1988 fiscal year ended on June 30, 1987, the company reported a $5.8 million loss, and its stock tumbled even further.
''I'm not close enough to the subject to talk about it,'' said Mr. Gramley, the chief economist with the Mortgage Bankers Association in Washington, D.C. Mr. Mondale, now a lawyer in Minneapolis, did not respond to telephone requests to his secretary for comment.
The plaintiffs' charges are ''total nonsense,'' said Stephen L. Lane, president and chief executive of Emerson. ''It's unfounded and it will be proven so, hopefully,'' he added. ''It's not going to affect the company.''
Recently, Emerson Radio's stock price has gradually recovered, with a few analysts once again predicting a sharp climb in the company's future sales revenues as Emerson forges into the personal computer market. Those analysts' reports, however, do not mention the implications of the shareholders' lawsuit that is inching contentiously toward a trial.
