HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Sony Wishes Upon a Star

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
ARE the services of Peter Guber and Jon Peters, co-chairmen of Columbia Pictures, the Sony Corporation's latest venture into the entertainment business, really worth a half-billion dollars?
Americans have grown accustomed to cleanup hitters who bag $50,000 per home run. And they have learned to take in stride the occasional corporate chief executive who pockets $50 million as an incentive to early retirement. But some may have a hard time swallowing the idea that the new heads of Columbia Pictures are 50 times better at their jobs than a run-of-the-mill tinseltown deal maker who could be had for $10 million. It is just possible that Hollywood has gotten the better of the good folks who brought you the Betamax and the Walkman. 
First, a brief recap of the big news for those who have been unaccountably distracted by events in San Francisco or Eastern Europe. In September, with the ink barely dry on its $2 billion contract to buy CBS Records, Sony agreed to pay a shade less than $5 billion for the least successful of Hollywood's major studios.
Now as everyone who has ever seen a Bette Davis movie knows, a film studio is only as good as the mogul who tyrannizes it. That is apparently why Sony was so eager to bring on board Mr. Guber and Mr. Peters, the executive producers of ''Batman'' and ''Rainman'' and the hottest movie-making team around. Sony bought their production company for $200 million, or about $60 million more than its market value. The Guber and Peters share of the proceeds: $55 million.
But the $55 million was only an appetizer. The new co-chairmen, along with three other executives as yet unnamed, will each receive a $2.75 million annual salary for five years, plus annual cost-of-living adjustments, plus a share of studio profits, plus slices of a one-time $50 million bonus, plus 8.08 percent of any appreciation in Columbia's assessed value. If, for example, Columbia earned $300 million in 1994, and the studio appreciated by $1 billion - hardly an ambitious return on Sony's $5 billion investment - the five executives would be entitled to $156 million.
What Sony apparently never anticipated, however, is that in order to win Mr. Peters and Mr. Guber it would also be forced to come to terms with Steven J. Ross, the head of Warner Communications and the one mogul who can make the diamond-dust twins look like monks in penitent garb.
Mr. Ross, a former Manhattan funeral director, recently pulled off the slick trick of convincing Time Inc.'s directors to reject an acquisition offer from Paramount worth billions to Time stockholders in order to go through with a deal to buy Warner. And, fresh from the triumph in which he personally netted $125 million, Mr. Ross was apparently in no mood to allow the Guber-Peters team to walk away from their commitment to make movies for his studio.
Last week Warner settled its suit with Sony for a half-interest in CBS's mail-order record and tape business, plus cable distribution rights to Columbia's television productions, plus the better part of a Los Angeles real estate swap. The estimated value of the package is between $400 million and $600 million.
Mr. Guber's and Mr. Peters' big winners in recent years will gross $2.5 billion. And while only a small fraction of those grosses will ever hit the studio's bottom line, Wall Street analysts say, it would not take many hits on the scale of ''Batman'' to reward Sony's extraordinary faith in the home team.
But there is obviously an element of luck in making movies, no matter who is putting the deals together. Before ''Rainman'' and ''Batman,'' Mr. Guber and Mr. Peters were responsible for such costly flops as ''Caddyshack II,'' ''VisionQuest'' and ''Clue.'' And as with stock-picking, the real genius in the movie business is to get the people who put up the money to remember the winners and forget the losers.
It is possible that Mr. Guber and Mr. Peters have done little more than bet on the right horse the last few times out. It is also possible that they correctly intuited what people wanted to see on the silver screen - but that the muse of popular taste will desert them as mysteriously as it came.
Perhaps Sony believes that Mr. Peters and Mr. Guber really do know something worth hundreds of millions of dollars. Perhaps Sony is so flush with cash, and so proud of its new stake in the great American dream machine, that a billion more or less does not seem important. Or perhaps Sony is simply adopting the mores of American corporate culture - a culture in which the care, feeding and amusement of senior management matters as much as the return to the stockholders.

HEADLINE: Fight on Workers' Compensation in Texas

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Nov. 21

 BODY:
The Texas statehouse in Austin has seen many boisterous confrontations, but few can match the bitter standoff over measures to overhaul the state's system of compensating workers for their injuries.
Disputes over workers' compensation programs have become increasingly rancorous in recent years as insurers in a number of states have endured rising underwriting losses. But in no state has the issue become as charged as it is in Texas, where insurers over the last five years have paid out $1.41 in claims and expenses for every dollar of premiums paid by employers, compared with $1.22 for every premium dollar nationally.
Insurers in Texas expect to lose more than $1 billion this year, after $4.4 billion in underwriting losses in workers' compensation coverage since 1983. And employers in Texas will pay almost $4 billion in premiums for injured-worker insurance next year, compared with $1 billion in 1983. 
 
Limiting Medical Costs
But many Texas lawmakers, backed by insurers and employers, are trying to limit medical costs and the right to a jury trial. The proposals include restricting workers to two medical opinions on their ailments and a single set of medical tests to diagnose their condition. Current law permits unlimited opinions and tests. Also, costs for differing medical procedures would be limited to standards set by the American Medical Association. No cost limits now exist under Texas workers' compensation rules. The pro-business groups also want to raise benefits for severely disabled workers.
Opposing them are plaintiff lawyers and representatives of labor unions. They succeeded in blocking the proposed changes in two legislative sessions earlier this year. A third session, devoted solely to the workers' compensation fight, has been under way for a week, and top state officials have vowed to keep the session going until changes are made.
In the more than 75 years since all but a few states began requiring employers to carry workers' compensation insurance, most property and casualty insurers have usually found the business profitable.
But soaring medical costs, an expansion of the treatments covered under workers' compensation, legal haggling in claims disputes in some states and rising workers' compensation claims in areas where layoffs have been concentrated have been pushing costs sharply higher for employers and increasing losses among insurers.
The A. M. Best Company said insurers lost more than $3 billion on $29 billion in premium payments from employers last year, even after counting investment profits from cash reserves. Losses are expected to be even higher this year.
Primary insurers have reported deepening losses and requested large rate increases in Maine, Rhode Island, Florida and Louisiana as well as Texas. Requests for rate increases of 20 percent or more are being reviewed in Alabama, Tennessee, Mississippi, Kentucky, Arkansas and Massachusetts.
In Texas over all, the average claim cost nearly doubled last year, to $13,300 from $6,800 in 1984, according to the National Council on Compensation Insurance. Nationally, the average cost per claim is expected to reach $10,000 in 1990, compared with $6,000 in 1980, the council said.
The General Motors Corporation said its premiums in Texas, where it has a large car assembly plant in Arlington, averaged $1,829 for each employee last year, compared with an average of $577 at 18 of its other American plants.
Texas employers pay the fifth-highest premium rates in the nation for the insurance, but the benefits received by severely injured workers rank in the bottom third of all states, according to the Workers' Compensation Research Institute, an industry-financed research concern in Cambridge, Mass.
But less severely disabled workers, those who can go back to work fairly quickly, receive comparatively high settlements, or 100 percent of their lost pay. ''We overcompensate minor injuries at the expense of serious injuries,'' said Joseph C. Gagen, the chairman of the state's Industrial Accident Board, which governs the system.
Texas is also where injured workers have freest access to a jury trial. In most states, injured workers can seek an appellate-court review, and only on the facts of how a state-appointed mediator reached a settlement. In Texas, the jury is not allowed to hear facts from a mediator's prior ruling on a settlement dispute, including the result of the ruling.
Lawyers represent injured workers in half of all contested cases in Texas, compared with an average of 8 percent in other states. Also, the lawyers' payment is set at 25 percent of a plaintiff's final settlement, compared with 15 percent in many states.
 
Manipulation of Courts
Insurers say lawyers for plaintiffs manipulate the court system by scheduling cases before juries more likely to make high awards, increasing the cost of the claim.
''The average cost of what should be a $280 claim has become a $1,200 claim and it is eating us up,'' said Keith Lake, an executive vice president at Kemper Financial Group, a major insurer in Chicago. ''In Texas, everybody gets a lawyer and everything gets appealed.''
But plaintiff lawyers and labor leaders have protested the proposals for change, saying benefits to injured workers should rise, not fall. They assert that many employers, particularly in the oil and petrochemical industries, have been lax in safety efforts.
They also say insurers abuse jury trials by using their financial resources to outlast plaintiffs and force them into inadequate settlements.
The collapse of the oil, real estate and financial sectors of the Texas economy has magnified the state's problems with injured-worker claims. High unemployment in 1986 and 1987 pushed workers' compensation claims higher. Many workers filed injury claims after their unemployment insurance ran out, a practice that is often fraudulent, insurance and business consultants say.
Many insurers in Texas have retrenched.

HEADLINE: American Savings Delays Voting on a Shift in Charter

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Facing strong opposition from shareholders, the management of the American Savings Bank yesterday delayed until Dec. 20 a special meeting of stockholders to vote on converting the bank from a Federal to a state charter.
The proposal also included provisions that, according to the proxy of the White Plains-based bank, could make removing management more difficult and could discourage takeover bids.
''This was a vote of no confidence in management,'' said Gerald Chase, a private investor and shareholder of American Savings who favors a management change and possible sale of the bank. ''The management proposal would have been turned down overwhelmingly, by 80 to 20.'' 
The bank's stock fell by 75 cents a share yesterday, to $9.125, on the New York Stock Exchange, well below its high of $18.625 late last year.
 
Assets Total $4.5 Billion
American Savings, with $4.5 billion in assets, has 39 branch offices in New York City and nearby counties. The bank had a $10.3 million loss in the third quarter. Much of the loss was from leveraged buyouts, including a $14.7 million loan to the Seaman Furniture Company in Uniondale, L.I.
Henry Salzhauer, who controls 9.2 percent of American Savings and opposed the management proposal, said converting to a state charter ''probably makes economic sense.''
But he added that other parts of the proposal ''make it more difficult for stockholders to be recognized by the company'' and would ''promote a lock-in of current management.''
Earlier this year, Mr. Salzhauer led an unsuccessful attempt to place three directors on American Savings' board and to appoint a committee to study the possible sale of the bank.
 
Cumulative Voting
Under a state charter, the bank would have been able to prohibit cumulative voting by shareholders in director elections, a feature that many of the holders dislike. Cumulative voting, which is required under a Federal charter, unless special dispensation is granted by regulators, is favored by dissident shareholders because it is easier for them to concentrate their votes and elect directors not nominated by management.
American Savings said in a statement that it might revise its proposal before the December meeting.
Robert J. Hughes, the executive vice president, declined to comment on how the bank might revise its proposal.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 7.25, to 2,639.29; Volume Up a Bit

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
With many investors on the sidelines in advance of the Thanksgiving Day holiday, blue-chip stocks made modest gains yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 7.25 points, to 2,639.29.
However, the broader market drifted downward, with 860 declines on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering the 622 gains.
Although the Government reported that the Consumer Price Index rose five-tenths of 1 percent in October, which was higher than expected, the news had little impact on equities. 
While initially stifled by a weak bond market at the opening, stocks rose in the first half-hour of trading and moved to about a 10-point advance. The market then began to lose ground and continued a seesaw pattern until about 1:30 P.M., when it showed its biggest loss, about a dozen points. A half-hour before the close, the Dow bounced back to the plus side, where it hovered until the final bell.
''With corporate profits dwindling and the Federal Reserve Board unwilling to bring interest rates lower, stock prices, especially in this week of light volume, might come under light pressure,'' said Kenneth S. Hackel, president of Systematic Financial Management, an investment advisory firm in Fort Lee, N.J. ''Takeover activity has also slowed, shaving some of the premium off the equity market.''
Volume on the Big Board expanded to 147.9 million shares, from a skimpy 128.2 million on Monday.
Wider indicators than the Dow showed only fractional gains. The New York Stock Exchange composite index edged up a minuscule 0.02, to 188.05, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index tacked on 0.24, to 339.59.
Among individual issues, the Georgia Gulf Corporation plunged 6 1/8, to 46 1/4. The company, which has been a takeover target, said that it had preliminarily determined that a leveraged recapitalization would be the most beneficial course for its investors. Some analysts had expected the company to be sold for about $65 a share.
Witco fell 3 3/4, to 37 1/2. The petroleum and specialty chemicals company said it expected lower fourth-quarter earnings than a year ago.
On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index slipped 0.50, to 370.98, while in over-the-counter activity, the Nasdaq composite index dropped 1.57 points, to 454.14.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Spot Gold Ends Above $400 For First Time in 10 Months

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
With gold in strong demand, prices of precious metals continued to advance yesterday. The spot December gold delivery closed above $400 an ounce in New York for the first time in 10 months, following similar gains in Asia and Europe earlier in the day.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, the active gold contract, December, closed up $5.10 an ounce, at $404.40; the expiring November contract rose $5.50, to $403.70. The December silver delivery soared 14.2 cents an ounce, to $5.845. Meanwhile, the spot January 1990 platinum contract closed up $4.70 an ounce, at $535.30, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. 
''A number of factors caused gold to cross the pychological $400 barrier today,'' said Ian C. MacDonald, manager of precious metals at Credit Suisse. ''But if we had to pick the main factor, we would say that the events of this past Oct. 13 ended the decline in bullion prices.''
A month before the sharp drop in stock prices on Oct. 13, gold was trading at a three-year low of roughly $350 an ounce, after declining from about $440 at the start of 1989.
 
Hedging by Managers Seen
''Since Oct. 13, many investment managers on both sides of the Atlantic have been hedging against another plunge in equity prices by adding gold to their portfolios,'' Mr. MacDonald said. ''With many economists and newspaper articles forecasting a recession, they have been adding to their bullion holdings.''
Other factors supporting gold, he added, included the still wobbly stock market, a weakening dollar, falling yields on dollar investments and strong hints of an upturn in inflation.
But Frederick R. Demler, metals economist at Drexel Burnham Lambert, offered a somewhat different view. ''What we are seeing in gold is a classic technical pattern, as well as the economic fundamentals,'' he said. ''Moreover, demand for physical gold by the jewelry industry is usually strongest in the fourth quarter. And the demand by jewelry manufacturers has indeed been very strong this year because of the relatively low prices of all precious metals.''
Mr. Demler said he was bullish on gold over the near term, but added, ''We have doubts about the metal over the longer term, unless the dollar falls precipitously or stocks take another dive or some other major economic disaster occurs.''
As for the silver and platinum markets, both Mr. MacDonald and Mr. Demler said those metals were ''playing catch-up'' with gold. Mr. MacDonald added that ''what happens to silver depends on when copper output peaks, which we think will be in 1992.''
Much, if not most, of the world's silver output comes from copper and other base metals mines. With copper prices in particular tumbling in recent months, metals analysts expect that many producers will once again shut copper mines or sharply reduce output early next year.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Factory Being Converted in a Depressed Area of Newark

BYLINE: By Richard D. Lyons

 BODY:
A VACANT light-bulb factory that shut down four years ago in an economically depressed section of Newark is being converted by a group of Manhattan investors into rental space for light manufacturing and distribution companies.
The investor group, which bought the factory and renamed it the Metro Industrial Center, expects the project to cost $4 million for the acquisition and renovations and to take a year to complete.
The group, J.I.M. Associates, consists of three partners with interests in the garment industry: Jacob Mendelsohn, Isaac Dabah and Michael Gross. Triad Realty Services Ltd., a Manhattan advisory and investment brokerage firm, has been retained by J.I.M. Associates to oversee the renovations and the marketing of the 482,000-square-foot structure. 
The building, at 40 17th Avenue near Irving Turner Boulevard, is about two miles from both the Newark Amtrak station and the Newark International Airport. Built as a series of eight interconnecting structures between 1908 and 1958, the factory served as the East Coast manufacturing and distribution center for the light-bulb division of the General Electric Company. In the 1970's as many as 2,500 workers were employed in the building, working three shifts, and the closing of the plant in 1985 added to Newark's economic problems.
Officials in Newark said the project is the largest renovation in 15 years in the Central Ward, one of the city's poorest areas. They expect it to help revive the economy of that distressed neighborhood.
Triad will subdivide the brick and concrete building into 11 units of 30,000 to 42,000 square feet. Space would lease for $2 to $4 a square foot depending on its location on the four floors. None of the space has yet been leased.
Each tenant unit in the building, which takes up 100,000 square feet on a five-acre site, would have truck docks, staging areas and elevator banks. The building has five main elevators and 23 loading docks. The number of docks can be expanded to 38. One unusual feature is an interior courtyard of 18,500 square feet.
Mark C. Rosenberg, a partner at Triad, said that since New Jersey had designated Newark an ''urban enterprise zone,'' tenants might be eligible for benefits like exemptions from or reductions in sales taxes. He said tenants might also be eligible for loans and loan guarantees under the state's Economic Development Administration.
Mr. Rosenberg also noted that the Newark Economic Development Corporation had been helpful in calling the availability of the building to the attention of prospective tenants.
Alfred L. Faiella, executive director of the development agency, said the building ''is in a rough neighborhood, and to find investor confidence in a multistory building in the area is extremely significant for the Central Ward.''
The Central Ward was the site of a series of civil disturbances in the summer of 1967, and a large-scale abandonment of both commercial and residential properties followed. Many buildings that existed then have been torn down by the city, leaving several dozen open and desolate blocks.
Mr. Faiella said the purchase price of the building had risen several times since it was initially put on the market by General Electric. It has been through three changes in ownership since General Electric sold it. This, he insisted, demonstrates that Newark, even the city's distressed Central Ward, is making a comeback.
''Ten to 12 years ago there would have been no buyers for the property,'' he said.
He added that many buildings in the area had either been razed or abandoned, and that the Metro Industrial Center would help point the neighborhood in a more positive direction.
Mr. Faiella also said that while development in the Central Ward has stagnated over the last decade, during that period more than 10 million square feet of industrial development has taken place in Newark itself.

HEADLINE: Yankees Sign Perez To a 3-Year Contract

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO

 BODY:
The Yankees, who used 16 pitchers to staff a chaotic five-man rotation last season, plunged into the free-agent market with George Steinbrenner's bankroll yesterday and spent $5.7 million for three years to sign Pascual Perez, a pitcher with a losing record and a history of struggling against drugs.
It was the third major signing of this winter's free-agent market, which numbered 90 players when the deadline for filing passed last week, and the prices have soared. Kevin Bass signed with the San Francisco Giants last week for $5.25 million for three years, and Nick Esasky signed with the Atlanta Braves for $5.6 million for three years. And Mark Langston, Mark Davis and Robin Yount were being pursued with even bigger bucks as the superstars of the class. 
 
Joins the Sweepstakes
Perez joined the sweepstakes after winning 9 games and losing 13 this year for the Montreal Expos, bringing his record to 64 victories and 62 defeats in a career that began in 1980 with the Pittsburgh Pirates.
But he had a respectable earned-run average of 3.31 and he continued to pitch with the flair that has established him as one of the more colorful and provocative performers in baseball. He rushes onto the field, prowls round the mound, occasionally lobs a blooper pitch and frequently gets into confrontations or fights. Last season, he even threw a baseball into the Chicago Cubs' dugout.
Still, he doubled his salary of $850,000 and gave one more shot of inflation to a market that already has reached new levels. The Yankees would not give details of his contract, but a source familiar with the matter said the contract broke down this way: $1.2 million for next season and $1.9 million each in 1991 and 1992; plus a $500.000 signing bonus and a $200,000 relocation bonus.
The Yankees acknowledged that Perez came with questions.
''We are very aware of his past problems,'' said George Bradley, vice president for player personnel. ''However, he has been involved in a program with the Expos that has kept him clean and we will help him remain with that program.''
The problems, which included both alcohol and cocaine, have afflicted Perez for much of his career with the Pirates, the Atlanta Braves and the Expos. He seemed to hit bottom when he won 1 game and lost 13 for the Braves in 1985 and then missed the entire season of 1986. The Expos gave him a chance in 1987, and he responded by winning seven games without losing. But he missed all of spring training this year while undergoing treatment for drugs.
The Expos said they had hoped to sign him back, especially since they should become the worst victims of the free-agent ex odus. They have lost Langston and may lose Bryn Smith and Hubie Brooks. When the season ended, they offered $4 million for three years to keep Perez, but then Bass and Esasky triggered the explosion in the market and the Expos were told that Perez would now cost $5 million plus incentives.
''I hope the Yankees take good care of him,'' Dave Dombrowski, the general manager of the Expos, said yesterday from his parents' home in Chicago. ''He is a very fragile individual. He has a problem. ''I understand this is a big business. But for the good of the individual, I thought he'd stay with Montreal. I don't know how well he'd react to booing in New York.''
Dombrowski was asked the nature of the treatment program for Perez, and said: ''It's a very strong maintenance program. He'll be on it for the rest of his career.''
''They paid him a lot of money,'' Dombrowski said. ''Three weeks ago, I'd have said you're crazy to pay it. But the market's just gone wild.'' Perez was in the Domincan Republic yesterday and could not be reached for comment. Steinbrenner, who traveled last week to Los Angeles and Houston to pursue Langston and Davis, did not return telephone calls to his office in Tampa, Fla.
Langston's agent, Arn Tellem, said last night from Los Angeles that he didn't expect any decision for a few weeks and added: ''The Yankees are definitely in the picture. There is no location issue. He wants to be on a winner. We had a great meeting with Mr. Steinbrenner, and Perez is a sign that he is backing up his words.''

HEADLINE: Friendly Advice to a Shrinking Military

BYLINE: By John Kenneth Galbraith; John Kenneth Galbraith is emeritus professor of economics at Harvard University.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
In these last days, the newspapers and television screens have dealt fully and with wonderment with what is happening in Europe and its meaning for Europeans. Let no one doubt that there will also be great and enduring effects on us, especially on our military establishment. This is a word of sympathy, counsel and guidance for that establishment in what promises to be a difficult time.
The difficulty, needless to say, is the evident end of any plausible case for believing in Soviet expansionism - as regularly, and one thinks by some gratefully, it has been been called. And, additionally, there is the reduction in the Soviet armed forces in Eastern Europe and at home. 
From this comes a compelling thought: Is there any longer any serious likelihood of a Soviet armed thrust out of East Germany to the West? Would the Polish or Hungarian divisions, for example - perhaps even the Bulgarian divisions - be really stalwart on the march? They were cited as a threat a few days back by the Joint Chiefs.
To this are added earlier questions: Do the Soviets more than we yearn for the reciprocal destruction of a nuclear exchange? More distantly, in light of their own domestic economic trouble, could the Soviets really wish in any realistic way to take responsibility for running the highly sophisticated economy of Japan? If not, how necessary is the military umbrella we maintain at no slight cost over our distressingly effective competitor and rapidly emerging landlord?
From some public experience, I have, needless to say, no hope that the Pentagon or, for that matter, the larger foreign policy and intelligence bureaucracy will surrender easily to such conclusions. Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney has, indeed, asked for a list of possible reductions; one cannot think that results will come easily.
Forty and more years of vested intellectual interest and bureaucratic commitment are involved and so, also, are a deep political resistance and a massive and widely distributed economic reward. The temptation, in consequence, will be to say, in the face of great change, that nothing has changed or to invent and depict the requisite enemy.
This is not good. We pride ourselves on being a down-to-earth, plain-spoken, forthright people who rise well above cant and evasion. Implicit in the foregoing effort could be an embarrassing element of fraud made worse by being both tedious and transparent. No friend of the men and women in our armed forces can welcome their association with this. Let us rest the defense of our military establishment and its supporting weapons industry on honest grounds, on amply established reality.
For generations now, numerous military bases around the country have been sustained not for their military need or purpose but because of their contribution to local employment, industry and community pride. The revolving door consultants at the Pentagon, we have long known, are motivated not by concern for the defense of the Republic but by personal economic interest and, if in lesser measure, the economic interest of their clients.
In recent weeks, a New York Times article from Bethpage, L.I., told of an agreement in Congress to build 18 F-14 fighter jets, unwanted even by the Pentagon, to buy time ''to reduce the Island's dependence on defense spending.'' The cost was estimated at about $1 billion.
A few days later, the House of Representatives passed a $305 billion military appropriations bill that included $195 million for 36 helicopters and $585 million for V-22 Osprey airplanes, which the Pentagon said it did not want. There was widespread comment on the reluctance of the Representatives to cut, as they were called, ''politically popular weapons.''
So one comes to the future. As the great changes of our time proceed and the military effect becomes evident, let us not have a mendacious defense of our military budget and invented danger.
Let us have a forthright defense, in the best of our traditions, based openly on the contributions to employment, earnings, political appeal and bureaucratic stability. That is the honest course. In the tradition of Dwight D. Eisenhower, let us see the military power as having existence and justification in its own right, independent of military danger.
There is, however, one further thought that does obtrude. These last days in Europe have seen an extraordinary celebration of freedom, one in which we have joyously joined.
In keeping with our national commitment to down-to-earth truth, there is a domestic reality to which, in these celebrations, we should perhaps turn our thoughts.
That is to the number of our own citizens who, not less than the East Germans in the past, are denied freedom. Nothing more inhibits expression, action, movement, personal liberty than oppressive, grinding poverty. Nothing so enforces silence unless it be illiteracy or deficient education.
Nothing, we all know, so enhances freedom as some money. And in our cities, we have some millions devoid of shelter, food, medical care and money who are so repressed. No East German in pursuit of liberty would go wisely to the South Bronx.
Perhaps some day, as in East Berlin and Leipzig and our own cities in the past, our deprived and now voiceless may also express their discontent. It would be an exercise in sensible conservative foresight to redirect some of our present military budget, serving urgent urban needs and so enhancing freedom here at home. It would show that, in anticipating unfortunate eventualities, we are wiser than the Communist leaders who denied both freedom and the future.

HEADLINE: Lebanon's Slain Pact

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 22

 BODY:
The ultimate target of the bomb that killed the new Lebanese President, Rene Moawad, 17 days after his election was the accord reached between Lebanon's Muslim and Christian factions last month in Taif, Saudi Arabia.
''It is an assassination of the whole Taif agreement,'' said Adel Malek, a Lebanese and Arab affairs expert in London, in a comment widely echoed by many other Middle East experts. ''Whoever did it may have succeeded in eliminating the last attempt to put Lebanon together as a unified country even if the accord stays alive on paper.''
The accord, signed by Christian and Muslim members of the Lebanese Parliament last month, was reached under the auspices of an Arab League peace plan. The plan received the most vociferous backing from the major powers, including the United States, France and the Soviet Union, all of which have special interests in Lebanon and a history of involvement with various parties controlling the country's destiny. 
''It strikes me as another page in the ongoing tragedy which typifies the last 15 years in Lebanon,'' Uri Lubrani, coordinator of Lebanese affairs in the Israeli Foreign Ministry, said in a telephone interview from Tel Aviv. ''But in Lebanon one doesn't ask why. The question is futile.''
But the questions echoed everywhere tonight after the news of the assassination: who did it, who suffers most from it and who stands to gain?
What is clear is that the killing follows a well-established pattern of assassinating Lebanese leaders almost as soon as they seem to abandon their partisan positions and start to speak of national reconciliation.
Among those were the leftist Druse leader, Kamal Jumblat, who was shot in 1977; Lebanon's Sunni Muslim Prime Minister, Rashid Karami, killed by a bomb in 1987; President-elect Bashir Gemayel, also killed by a bomb in 1982, and now Mr. Moawad, a Maronite Christian killed on the 46th anniversary of Lebanon's independence.
Lebanese officials said they would meet quickly to elect a new president. But the assassination in Syrian-controlled Muslim West Beirut has put off for a long time any serious hope of ending the 14 years of civil war.
 
Factions Opposed to the Pact
The search for the assassin is on, and in Lebanon, revenge always follows. But more important, even before the assassination, the Taif accord looked good mostly on paper. Despite Arab and international support, the agreement was strongly opposed by a number of factions in Lebanon.
Those included the great majority of the one million Maronite Catholics, who felt it would only lead to a permanent Syrian occupation of their country and Muslim domination of the only Arab nation where Christians have not been reduced to second-class citizens.
Shiites, who number well over a million, also opposed it vehemently as it failed, in their view, to give them a greater share in power than the Sunni Muslims.
Other minorities in Lebanon, most notably the Druse, also openly said the Taif agreement fell far short of meeting their hopes for a greater share of power.
 
Maronite Support for Aoun
The countries that support those factions also expressed displeasure with the accord.
Iran, a strong backer of Shiites, assailed the agreement, even though its close Arab ally, Syria, gave it its backing. Iraq, an archenemy of Syria, continued to supply the Christian Maronite armed forces of Gen. Michel Aoun with weapons, as did Israel, which has had a longstanding alliance with the Christians of Lebanon and which occupies a slice of the country's south.
Because of his strong opposition to the accord, General Aoun has been immediately identified by Syria as the person behind the assassination.
But it is far from evident in the view of Lebanese experts that he had any real interest in killing Mr. Moawad. Among other things, it had become evident that a great majority of Christian Maronites supported General Aoun. He continued to occupy the presidential palace in Baabda and successfully blocked President Moawad's attempt to draft Christian support in the formation of a new government.
 
'There Is No Prime Suspect'
Killing President Moawad could only weaken the General's position by opening the way to the Syrians to attack him and resume their assault on his forces. It also weakens his position within the Christian camp. ''The Maronites can say to Aoun, please leave now otherwise there will be a massacre,'' said Farid Trabulsi, a Lebanese journalist and editor here.
''There is no prime suspect,'' said Ghassan Salameh, a Lebanese professor at the University of Paris who is an expert on Arab affairs. ''Too many parties have an interest in blocking the reunification of Lebanon today.''
A number of Arab parties, most notably Iraq, point to Syria, which appeared to be one of President Moawad's biggest backers. They asserted Mr. Moawad was failing in efforts to take control from General Aoun or lessen his power. ''Killing Moawad gives the Syrians an excuse to keep their army in Lebanon forever,'' said a senior Iraqi official who asked not to be identified.
Lebanon experts saw little motivation for Iraq's involvement in the killing, in part because it had no reason to derail General Aoun's quiet supremacy on the Lebanese political scene.
Others point to Iran, which they say could not have acted without Syrian approval. And, still others say, it may have been Israel, which has an interest in keeping attention away from the issue of talks with the Palestinians and the rising pressure on its Government to engage in those talks.
It is almost certain that a meeting called by the Palestine Liberation Organization in Tunis on Saturday for Arab foreign ministers to discuss the peace process with Israel has been completely sidetracked by the assassination.
As for the future of Lebanon, George Corm, a prominent Lebanese economist and expert on the country, said tonight, ''The only thing to do is pray.''

HEADLINE: Transcript of President's Speech on Relations Between the East and West

 BODY:
Following is the transcript of President Bush's address to the nation last night as recorded by The New York Times:
Good evening. Like many of you, I'm spending tomorrow with family. And we'll say grace and carve the turkey, and thank God for our many blessings and for our great country.
This holiday also marks the adjournment of Congress. And I've worked with Congress, extending my hand across the party aisle, advancing legislation to free our streets of the fear of crime and drugs. We proposed ways to clean the air, the water and the land around us. And we've joined with the nation's governors to enter an historic compact to better our schools.
And especially touching is that so many Americans have answered the call for community service, the thousand points of light, by rolling up their sleeves and pitching in for the hopeless, the helpless - each volunteer, a beacon of light for someone who has lost his way. 
And this will be a very special Thanksgiving. It marks an extraordinary year.
 
Pilgrims to Freedom
But before our families sit down tomorrow, we'll give thanks for yet another reason: Around the world tonight, new pilgrims are on a voyage to freedom and for many it's not a trip to some place faraway but to a world of their own making.
On other Thanksgivings, the world was haunted by the images of watchtowers, guard dogs and machine guns. In fact, many of you had not even been born when the Berlin Wall was erected in 1961. But now the world has a new image, reflecting a new reality, that of Germans, East and West, pulling each other to the top of the wall, a human bridge between nations. Entire peoples all across Eastern Europe, bravely taking to the streets demanding liberty, pursuing democracy.
This is not the end of the book of history, but it's a joyful end to one of history's saddest chapters.
Not long after the wall began to open, West German Chancellor Kohl telephoned, and he asked me to give you, the American people, a message of thanks. He said that the remarkable change in Eastern Europe would not be taking place without the steadfast support of the United States. Fitting praise from a good friend.
For 40 years, we have not wavered in our commitment to freedom. We are grateful to our American men and women in uniform. And we should also be grateful to our postwar leaders. You see, we helped rebuild a continent through the Marshall Plan, and we built a shield, NATO, behind which Americans, Europeans, could forge a future in freedom.
For so many of these 40 years, the test of Western resolve, the contest between the free and the unfree, has been symbolized by an island of hope behind the Iron Curtain: Berlin.
In the 1940's West Berlin remained free because Harry Truman said, 'Hands off.' In the 1950's Ike backed America's words with muscle. In the 1960's West Berliners took heart when John F. Kennedy said, 'I am a Berliner.' In the 1970's Presidents Nixon, Ford and Carter stood with Berlin by standing with NATO. And in the 1980's Ronald Reagan went to Berlin to say, 'Tear down this wall.'
 
Imagining a New World
And now we are at the threshold of the 1990's. And as we begin the new decade, I am reaching out to President Gorbachev, asking him to work with me to bring down the last barriers to a new world of freedom. Let us move beyond containment, and once and for all end the cold war.
We can make such a bold bid because America is strong, and 40 years of perseverance and patience are finally paying off. More recently, quiet diplomacy, working behind the scenes, has achieved results. We can now dare to imagine a new world, with a new Europe, rising on the foundations of democracy.
This new world was taking shape when my Presidency began with these words: 'The day of the dictator is over.' And during the spring and summer, we told the people of the world what America believes and what America wants for the future.
America believes that liberty is an idea whose time has come in Eastern Europe. America wants President Gorbachev's reforms, known as perestroika, to succeed. And America wants the Soviets to join us in moving beyond containment to a new partnership.
Some wondered if all this was realistic. And now, though we are still on the course set last spring, events are moving faster than anyone imagined or predicted.
Look around the world - in the developing nations, the people are demanding freedom. Poland and Hungary are now fledgling democracies - a non-communist Government in Poland, and free elections coming soon in Hungary. And in the Soviet Union itself, the forces of reform under Mikhail Gorbachev are bringing unprecedented openness and change.
 
Drama in Berlin
But nowhere in the world today -or even in the history of man - have the warm hearts of men and women triumphed so swiftly, so certainly, over cold stone as in Berlin. Indeed, in all of East Germany. If I may paraphrase the words of a great poet, Robert Frost, there is certainly something in us that doesn't love a wall.
And when I spoke to the German people in Mainz last May, I applauded the removal of the barriers between Hungary and Austria, saying, 'Let Berlin be next.' And the West German people joined us in a call for a Europe whole and free.
Just yesterday, the West German Foreign Minister gave me a piece of the Berlin Wall. And it's on my desk as a reminder of the power of freedom to bring down the walls between people.
It brought back memories of seven years ago, when I went to Modlareuth, a small town in Germany also known as Little Berlin. A divided village, really, its cobbled streets were blocked by barbed wire and concrete - on the one side freedom, and on the other despair. And I talked with the townspeople, not a hundred and fifty yards from the specter of armed guards in towers.
And some day I'd like to go back to Little Berlin, and see families reunited, see neighbors once apart, coming together. How wonderful that would be. Change is coming swiftly. And with this change, the dramatic vindication of free Europe's economic and political institutions. The new Europe that is coming is being built - must be built - on the foundation of democratic values. But the faster the pace, the smoother our path must be. After all, this is serious business.
The peace we are building must be different than the hard joyless peace between two armed camps we've known so long. The scars of the conflict that began a half a century ago still divide a continent. So the historic task before us now is to begin the healing of this old wound.
 
Good News in Warsaw
During our visit to Poland and Hungary last July, I found new encouragement that we were on track, there was, at long last, the chance for a fundamental change. I saw firsthand acts of healing and reconciliation.
And it was in Warsaw at my lunch for General Jaruzelski and the leaders of Solidarity that I met a woman who had worked, at great personal risk, for the release of jailed Solidarity members. And she was asked, 'How is it possible, after such a short time, to break bread with the men who ordered those imprisonments? Why the absence of bitterness?' And she replied, 'Our joy at what is happening now is more powerful than memory.'
I wish you could have been there, for what we witnessed was extraordinary. The old antagonisms melted away as former adversaries stood up, often with tears in their eyes, and toasted the future. Our guests knew that history would judge them by how well they would cooperate.
Well, there is a spirit of cooperation in Eastern Europe. The result: Poland and Hungary are being transformed.
And they deserve our support, and they are getting it. We have matched our words with action: new loans and grants, teams of American economic experts working to help them adjust to a free market society, clearing the way for U.S. investment and trade with Poland and Hungary. Now the peoples of these nations can finally expect their hard work to lead to a better life.
 
Exceptions Near U.S.
These same winds of change are sweeping our own hemisphere, democracy transforming the Americas with stunning speed. Regrettably, there are some exceptions: Panama, Nicaragua and Cuba. And these last two are holding out against their people only because of the massive support of weapons and supplies from their communist allies.
And so when I see President Gorbachev, I'll ask him to join with us to help bring freedom and democracy to all the people of Latin America.
And so as we celebrate the events of Eastern Europe, remember that some walls still remain between East and West. These are the invisible walls of suspicion. The walls of doubt, misunderstanding and miscalculation.
It was while in Eastern Europe last summer that I decided to make a personal effort to break through these last barriers.
 
Proposals for Gorbachev
And back in May, I set down five steps that the Soviets should take that would inevitably result in improved relations with the West. First, reduce Soviet forces. Second, support self-determination in Eastern Europe. Third, work with us to end regional disputes. Fourth, achieve a lasting pluralism and respect for human rights, and fifth, join with us in addressing global problems, including the international drug menace and dangers to the environment.
Serious problems still remain, especially those regional conflicts. But the Soviet Union has made progress in these five areas that is undeniable.
With that in mind and the momentous changes in Eastern Europe, I invited President Gorbachev to meet me 10 days from now. And this is a first meeting, a time for exploration. It is not a time for detailed arms control negotiations best left for next year's summit.
I want President Gorbachev to know exactly where the United States stands. And let me be clear: America stands with freedom and democracy. We are not meeting to determine the future of Europe. After all, the peoples of Europe are determining their own future. And though there will be no surprises sprung on our Allies, we will miss no opportunity to expand freedom and enhance the peace. But to those who question our prudent pace, they must understand that a time of historic change is no time for recklessness. The pace, and the confidence, and the security of our friends in Europe - it's just too important.
We will seek President Gorbachev's assurance that this process of reform in Eastern Europe will continue. And we will give him our assurance that America welcomes this reform not as an adversary seeking advantage, but as a people offering support. Our goal is to see this historic tide of freedom broadened, deepened and sustained.
We find enormous encouragement in its peaceful advance and its acceptance by the Soviet Union. We can now raise our hopes on other issues: our common environment, our common war against drugs, as well as human rights and the regional conflicts that remain.
 
Consulting With Allies
Immediately after my visit with President Gorbachev, I'll go to Brussels to consult with our partners in NATO, the very alliance that has kept the West free for 40 years. I will assure them that no matter how dramatic the change in Eastern Europe or in the Soviet Union itself, the United States will continue to stand with our allies and our friends.
For in a new Europe, the American role may change in form but not in fundamentals. After all, the Soviet Union maintains hundreds of thousands of troops throughout Eastern Europe. Study the map, review history and you'll see that this presence, with the Soviet Union's natural advantage of geography, cannot be ignored. So even if forces are significantly reduced on both sides - a noble goal indeed - we will remain in Europe as long as our friends want and need us.
Off the island nation of Malta, Mikhail Gorbachev and I will begin the work of years. We can help the peoples of Europe achieve a new destiny, in a peaceful Europe whole and free. And I will tell President Gorbachev, the dynamic architect of Soviet reform, that America wants the people of the Soviet Union to fulfill their destiny. And I will assure him that there is no greater advocate of perestroika than the President of the United States.
When we meet, we will be on ships at anchor in a Mediterranean bay that has served as a sea lane of commerce and conflict for more than two thousand years. This ancient port has been conquered by caesar and sultan, crusader and king. Its forts and watchtowers survey a sea that entombs the scuttled ships of empires lost - slave galleys, galleons, dreadnoughts, destroyers. And these ships, once meant to guard lasting empires, now litter the ocean floor and guard nothing more than reefs of coral.
So if the millennia offers us a lesson, perhaps it's this: True security does not come from empire and domination. True security can only be found in the growing trust of free peoples.
It's been said that peace is not the work of a single day, nor will it be the consequence of a single act. And yet every constructive act contributes to its growth; every omission impedes it.
Peace will come, in the end, as a child grows to maturity, slowly, until we realize one day in wonder - the child's almost grown.
It is our hope that Malta will be such a constructive act, guiding brave pilgrims on their journey to a new world of freedom.
And so, on this Thanksgiving Eve, as I prepare for my journey to Malta, I wish you a good night, and safe travel. God bless you and your family, and God bless the United States of America.

HEADLINE: Phantom of Mayor's Race Is Talk of New Orleans

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Here in the land of hot and spicy politics, the New Orleans mayor's race is sizzling with the usual rich language. But the dominant personality is only listening.
Former Mayor Ernest N. Dutch Morial has become the focus of attention, even though he is not a candidate - at least not yet.
So as the city faces its worst economic problems in years, the electorate is preoccupied not by issues and proposals for change but by the question of whether Mr. Morial will run. 
 
'Run, Dutch, Run'
As if to emphasize the point, a billboard above an elevated expressway on the way downtown urges: ''Run, Dutch, Run.''
Mr. Morial will not say what he will do. But his supporters have formed an ''exploratory committee'' to advance his candidacy. They say New Orleans badly needs strong leadership, a trademark of the combative man who became the first black mayor here.
The mayor's race comes at a critical time for New Orleans, when many people here are questioning the city's direction and prospects. Although there are economic bright spots, the depression that followed the collapse of oil prices is still all too evident. ''For sale'' signs on houses have become part of the landscape, along with ''for lease'' signs on offices. Hard times have spawned a rueful joke: ''At least the bankruptcy lawyers are prosperous.''
A newspaper advertisement placed by friends of Donald Mintz, one of the two official candidates in the nonpartison primary on Feb. 3, puts the issue bluntly: ''Is there hope for New Orleans?''
 
Incumbent Seeks 2d Term
Mr. Mintz says the economy here has suffered from a lack of leadership in the administration of Mayor Sidney Barthelemy, the incumbent, who is running for a second term. No other candidates have announced. The last day for qualifying is Dec. 15.
Mr. Mintz's ad called New Orleans ''the nation's most ailing city,'' a place that ''resounds with sad pessimism.'' It called Mayor Barthelemy ''a kind man overwhelmed by the demands of a city in the worst crisis of its life.''
Actually, times were probably tougher during Reconstruction. But there is no doubt the city has serious problems: widespread poverty, an exodus of residents to the suburbs or to jobs in other states, crime and drugs, packed jails and a city budget that is strained to the limit.
The good news includes a huge program to rebuild the port, a $114 million expansion of the Convention Center and a $40 million riverfront aquarium, both opening in 1991. But many more jobs are still needed to replace those lost in the oil crisis.
Pessimism is rife, dampening the joie de vivre that has defined New Orleans from its early days as a French outpost.
In recent years city budget gaps have been as certain as the potholes that pit the streets. Causes include cutbacks in Federal aid, low property taxes on homes and a state constitution that restricts local governments' taxation powers.
 
A Combative Personality
Soon after Mr. Morial took office in 1978, the city was flooded, literally, because of drainage problems. Budget problems came later, but he kept the city afloat, solved a police strike and won a second term. Many political analysts, including some now working for Mr. Mintz, say Mr. Morial's prickly personality overshadowed his record as one of the city's brightest, most competent mayors.
His combativeness played well among black voters, who are in the majority here, but voters still crushed his strong bid in 1985 to change the city charter to allow him to run for a third, consecutive term.
Voters in his own district later rejected his bid for a seat on the City Council. In the same election, Mr. Barthelemy became the city's second black mayor.
Mr. Morial has refrained from criticizing the incumbent, at least in public. The two men come from the same Creole culture that has produced many prominent politicians, but they are also old enemies. And sparks are expected to fly if Mr. Morial enters the race.
Mr. Mintz, an old friend of Mr. Morial's, is a civic and philanthropic leader who recently resigned as chairman of the New Orleans Port Commission. He and his law firm handled legal cases for the Morial administration. Mr. Mintz says he can bring jobs to the city and fill a vacuum of leadership.
Mr. Barthelemy is known as ''the gentle giant,'' in reference to his height, 6 feet 3 inches, and his mild manner. While Mr. Mintz has been lambasting the Mayor, Mr. Barthelemy has been garnering endorsements from former Mayor Moon Landrieu, ministers and social, civic and business leaders.
 
Difficult Times
His commercials say he is ''quietly getting the job done'' in the toughest of times. The incumbent ''has a very easy-going management style,'' said his political adviser, Jim Carvin. ''I hate to compare it to Reagan's, but the style probably is similar.''
Mr. Carvin says he is not worried that the polls show scant support for the incumbent. Such early polls, he says, ''could be influenced by the last TV commercial.''
''It's hard to run against a phantom like Dutch,'' Mr. Carvin said. But he added: ''we're prepared for him running and we're prepared for him not running. It hasn't kept people from contributing to us.''
Mr. Mintz's poll taker, Edward F. Renwick, said a recent opinion survey mainly showed that ''voters want change'' and ''are dissatisfied with the status quo.'' Mr. Mintz has found support among blacks and whites, including some of Mr. Morial's friends and former colleagues.
Mr. Morial's law partner, Fred Cassibry, said Mr. Morial's friends have been ''bombarded with inquiries'' from people who wanted the former Mayor to enter the race. Mr. Cassibry said a poll was under way to determine Mr. Morial's chances.
If Mr. Morial decides to run, ''he knows he can get into the runoff,'' said Joseph Logsdon, a friend who is a history professor at the University of New Orleans. ''The real war will be Sidney battling Mintz for the white vote. The more they bid for the white vote, the more black voters will go to Morial.''
Noting that Mr. Morial had become ''the story of the election'' without campaigning, Dr. Logsdon said, ''It just shows how clever he is.''

GRAPHIC: Ernest N. Dutch Morial (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Biotechnology Offers L.I. a Second Chance

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report on Long Island's reassessment of environmental and other commitments in a time of economic slowdown (news story, Oct. 17).
The economic downswing in New York's Nassau and Suffolk counties has been triggered by massive reduction in Federal defense spending. This large cutback has adversely affected the Grumman Corporation, Long Island's largest employer, which is threatened with having to lay off an estimated 5,000 employees. (Grumman's future agenda includes scaling back its presence on Long Island and building up facilities in other areas of the country.) The window of future economic opportunity for Long Island lies in the biotechnology industry. It has been developing over the last five years in this region. There are some 80 companies, half of them created in the last three years, which provide employment to about 5,000 people. Our industry projections indicate that this component of the Long Island economy can grow to some 25,000 jobs by 1992 (the same Long Island employment figure as Grumman).
Nassau and Suffolk County government leaders and the area's business community should recognize this second chance. They should seize the initiative by offering a broad range of business, financial and tax incentives so that this seedling industry will be properly fertilized in order to blossom.
 
DAVID G. BONAGURA
Jericho, L.I., Oct. 23, 1989
 The writer is a partner in Ernst & Young, certified public accountants.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Free at Last?

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
At no Thanksgiving since 1945 have Americans had such exhilarating reason to celebrate freedom. Overnight, as it seems, tyranny has lost its grip on Poland, Hungary, East Germany and Bulgaria. Czechoslovakia may follow. But there is something else in these events. There is the hope that our own country may be released from a great fear: the fear of Communism that has haunted American society for so long, distorting our law and marring our democracy.
To fear Communist totalitarianism is rational; Stalin's tyranny required vigilance of free people. But from the beginning the American response to Communism has gone beyond rational concern, to fear of ideas and the perception of danger in the feeblest radicalism. It has had the marks of paranoia. 
Within a year of the Bolshevik Revolution in 1917, fear had begun to mark our constitutional law. The case was Abrams v. United States.
In August 1918, anonymous pamphlets circulated in the Lower East Side of New York denounced President Wilson for sending troops to intervene in revolutionary Russia. Three anarchists and a Socialist connected with the pamphlets were convicted of ''sedition'' and sentenced to 20 years in prison.
In the Supreme Court, Justice Holmes said the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech protected what he called these ''puny anonymities.'' Certainly the pamphlets presented no conceivable threat to the Government. But Holmes's eloquent argument for ''free trade in ideas'' was made in a dissent joined only by Justice Brandeis.
Fear of Communism has marked the Court's approach to the First Amendment again and again in the years since then. In 1951 a majority found a ''clear and present danger'' that justified prosecutions of American Communist Party leaders, although the party by then was a pathetic raggle-taggle group.
The same fear led Congress to exclude foreign visitors who might have dangerous ideas: a foolishness that has repeatedly embarrassed us. The fear gave J. Edgar Hoover justification for his sick eavesdropping on Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Paranoia about Communist spies leads the current Director of the F.B.I., William Sessions, to defend its program to monitor libraries and investigate uncooperative librarians.
Richard Nixon, Joe McCarthy, Pat McCarran and a dozen members of the House Committee on un-American Activities used fear of Communism to advance their political careers. They destroyed lives, menaced American liberty, sickened our culture.
Is there really a chance now that the United States can free itself of the fear? The habit of mind is so deeply ingrained that it will surely not be easy to overcome. Even now, fear of being associated with ''Communists'' leads Congressmen to support arms aid to murderers in El Salvador. But I think there is reason to hope.
An essential element in our long paranoia has been the vision of Communism as a worldwide conspiracy, controlled from a powerful center in Moscow. Not even the China-Soviet split was enough to end that assumption in many Americans. Indeed, some leaders told us that the apparent split was really a trick: a master stroke by the conspiracy.
Today it is increasingly difficult to see Communism in those terms. In Europe and Asia, Communist parties are heading in many different directions. The Soviet Union faces monumental problems, economic and political.
Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney summed it up well the other day in talking about the realistic prospect of cutting U.S. defense expenditure. ''It doesn't make a lot of sense,'' he said, ''to spend a lot of time worrying about the Polish Army or the East German Army actively participating in an attack on Western Europe.''
In short, two things have happened. Communism has lost the ideological struggle with democracy. And the military threat of the Communist world is declining.
The hard question for the United States is no longer how to contain Communism. It is how to maintain a strong economy without the drug of military production. And how to build a better, more decent society.
The great changes in Eastern Europe happen to come at a time when our own political system is hardly working perfectly. Congress and the President seem equally stymied by the economic challenges of the 1980's. And the 1990's will require even sharper adjustments.
It is a Thanksgiving to celebrate. But not to be smug.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Silk and Steel: Softening Hard Edges

BYLINE: By ELAINE LOUIE

 BODY:
THREE years ago, when Connie Steensma and Richard Prins discovered they were going to have a baby after 15 years of marriage, they made the usual series of phone calls. First they called their parents. Then they called their architect.
''We wanted light and space, and we wanted to stay here 40 to 50 years,'' said Ms. Steensma, whose company, Accel Communications, trains executives in public speaking. Her husband is a partner at the Manhattan law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. Both are 39 years old. 
Their architect, Patricia Sapinsley, transformed their four-story Upper West Side brownstone into a bold juxtaposition of fragility and indestructibility. The renovation exemplifies a new direction many architects are taking, retaining the industrial-inspired design elements and imagery of the last decade, but softening them. It is a style that might be dubbed ''silk and steel.''
The architectural elements - the steel staircase, exposed steel beams and curved steel wall - are hard-edged, delineating space in no uncertain terms. The gray terrazzo floors throughout are stark, tough and childproof. Each of the four floors measures 60 by 19 1/2 feet, and a 50-foot-high stairwell topped by a skylight cuts through the center of the structure.
''The idea of exposing the steel, of exposing the building material, was partly economics,'' Ms. Sapinsley said. It was cheaper, she pointed out, to put in a steel support system and leave it exposed. Even so, gutting the 10 small rental apartments into which the building had been carved, installing a new electrical system and a central air-conditioning system and furnishing the house from scratch cost $500,000.
What softens the 5,000-square-foot space is a lavish and inspired use of fabric. Windows are covered by 20-foot lengths of peach muslin swagged over white muslin curtains. A piece of hand-embroidered Moroccan silk is casually draped over a marble shelf. Moroccan and Turkish rugs are scattered throughout the house, sometimes alone, but often overlapped in groups of twos or threes so they stand out against the vast expanses of terrazzo. The rugs, shawls and tapestries are all part of Ms. Steensma's collection, which she has gathered all her life.
Even the front door, which is made of wrought iron and glass, is curtained in draped white muslin. After one enters, what first attracts the eye is the glint of steel. A large curved steel wall, which screens off Ms. Steensma's study, leads into the formal living room on the first floor. Sunlight pours down through the skylight, making the steel sparkle.
The house is flooded with light, but the quality of light changes according to the weather and time of day. ''Most brownstones get no variation of light,'' Ms. Sapinsley said. At night, the skylight, which measures 6 by 12 feet, is spotlighted from underneath.
At right angles to the fireplace, whose curve echoes that of the steel wall, there are French doors, which Sayzie Carr, a Manhattan stylist and painter, draped voluptuously in peach and white muslin.
Peach walls add yet more warmth to what could have been a cavernous house. First, a coat of white plaster was applied over the Sheetrock walls. Mr. Prins, who created the color scheme, mixed red watercolor paint with lots of water, and did the same with yellow paint. Then he washed the wall with a soft badger brush, painting red in one direction, then painting yellow in another. The result is a slightly dappled effect of broad streaks of peach, with glimpses of white underneath.
The staircase, which is made of the same stainless-steel grating used for commercial buildings, looks tough, industrial and perhaps even dangerous for a house with two small children: Richard, who is 2 1/2 years old, and Mark, who is 10 months old. But it is childproof. Ms. Steensma's father, Arthur, a retired engineer who lives in Wyckoff, N.J., bought sheets of clear plastic and clamped them to the railings. The plastic provides an almost invisible barrier that prevents the children from tumbling off. But when the children get older, it can be unscrewed, Ms. Steensma said. Guard doors were added at the top of each flight of stairs.
The first-floor living room, with its gray-suede Eileen Gray sofa and grand piano, is consciously elegant. The second floor, the family floor, is more informal; it includes another living room, the dining room and the kitchen. The sofa and easy chairs, which were designed by Alan Buchsbaum, are overstuffed and oversized. The chairs, covered in a white, peach and celadon cotton geometric print, are so wide that an adult and a child can nestle side by side in one. The windows at either end of the floor have the same peach and white muslin curtains and window seats covered in beige raw silk.
There is also a granite-sheathed bathroom dividing the living and dining areas. To contrast with the granite, Ms. Steensma hung a gold and white hand-embroidered Moroccan robe. A marble counter jutting out from a wall of the bathroom is draped with a piece of gold silk, on which sit a collection of pewter vessels.
The wrought-iron Art Deco dining room table and chairs, which were designed by Jean Michelet, date from the 1930's. ''You can rock back on the chairs and think at first you might tip over, but you don't,'' Ms. Steensma said. This is where she cradles her children when they wake up in the middle of the night.
On the third floor, there are two bedrooms, both with window seats, and two bathrooms, whose design departs radically from the rest of the house. ''It's noisy and lively,'' said Ms. Sapinsley, who designed a red, blue and yellow geometric-tile pattern in the white-tiled bathrooms that suggests the designs of Russian Constructivist artists.
The top floor, with three more bedrooms, is unfinished. Rooms are unfurnished, walls unpainted. But even among the sparseness, there is a little magic. ''At night,'' Ms. Steensma said, ''if you're up here and look at the skylight, you can see the stars.''

HEADLINE: Planning a Modern City, With Legos

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Onkal (Duke) Guzey used to have to ask his small children if he could borrow their Lego toys to build his model homes. Now, five years and half a million Lego pieces later, he has built his own city.
Mr. Guzey, an architect in Washington, has assembled a Visionary City of miniature churches, city halls, shops, homes and apartments entirely out of the plastic building blocks in bright primary colors. The 30-foot-long city went on display today at the National Press Building here (1331 Pennsylvania Avenue, at 14th Street) and will remain through Jan. 3. 
Lego trains and monorails traverse the construction, and ships ferry tiny passengers along the waterways. But for Mr. Guzey, what sets this city apart is not that it was constructed entirely out of Legos, but how it was designed.
''This is not simply a mock-up of a modern urban environment,'' said Mr. Guzey, who works for D.M.J.M., an international planning firm in Washington. Rather, its design incorporates the natural topography and resources of areas including San Francisco, San Antonio, and La Jolla, Calif. The city is intended to solve the most serious problems of urban living like pollution, traffic congestion and shortages of natural resources.
''There is a great urgency for us to think in terms of different kinds of transportation and living environments,'' Mr. Guzey said. ''As architects and planners, we have a duty and an opportunity to make the public aware that there could be solutions to the problems of urban living.''
Asserting that people waste a great deal of time commuting, he said the city districts are designed so people ''live, work and entertain themselves within their community.''
There are no cars in Mr. Guzey's city and he has designed public transportation to be accessible and appealing. The canals that encircle the downtown carry boats filled with commuters. Monorail tracks pass through apartment buildings. Trains run under waterfalls that provide electricity to power the city. George Marston, a local engineer, designed a computer program to keep the trains running, elevators operating and street lamps lighted.
To emphasize his urban-planning point, at one end of the giant structure Mr. Guzey has built a replica of a crowded city of Legos, complete with raised freeways and bumper-to-bumper traffic. In the middle of the freeway is a jackknifed truck with ambulances and rescue crews blocking all four lanes.
The crowds that gather around the Visionary City are mostly awed; a few are skeptical. ''I don't like the idea of a perfectly controlled, 1984-type city,'' said Melissa Robinson, who works for a Washington-based news service. ''I think the Legos just take the edge off the idea of a planned city.''
Mr. Guzey has no answers for those who want to know how his principles could be made economically feasible or how the ideas could be implemented. He said the project is simply ''a message to force people to think that there are better living environment possibilities.''

Companies
Pilots at Eastern Airlines voted to end their nearly nine-month-long walkout, but the airline's machinists' union vowed to continue its strike. The pilots' decision came less than 24 hours after President Bush vetoed legislation that would have set up a commission to investigate the dispute between Eastern's unions and its management. Eastern said it would not immediately have planes for the returning pilots to fly. [Page D1.] Many striking machinists and flight attendants who have stayed off the job have become deeply concerned about their economic survival. [D5.] 
Nynex and telephone workers tentatively agreed on a contract that would end a bitter 16-week strike. Workers were scheduled to return to their jobs on Dec. 4. [B1.]

The Bush Administration said Japan continued to restrict American bidders unfairly from its $300 billion-a-year construction market, but it ruled out retaliation at this time. [D1.]
