HEADLINE: Retailers Are Wary Of Season

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
Perhaps more than in any year since 1974, when a severe recession started before Thanksgiving, the success of the Christmas shopping season that begins tomorrow is uncertain. But for bargain-hunting shoppers, opportunities may abound.
One negative portent for retailers is the profusion of stores put up for sale. These include Bloomingdale's, which was placed on the market by Canada's Campeau Corporation; the Bonwit stores, put up for sale by Australia's Hooker Corporation, and the Marshall Field, Saks Fifth Avenue, J. B. Ivey and John Breuner stores put up for sale by B.A.T. Industries of Britain.
Analysts and retailers say the planned sales of these stores could hurt consumer confidence. While some shoppers will buy elsewhere, some may simply buy less, they fear. 
 
Steep Discounts Possible
On top of this, other stores are suffering from a cash squeeze. Merchandise they cannot buy has been snapped up at steep discounts by healthier stores that can now sell it at prices 40 percent to 50 percent below normal. Such price cuts could well create a bargain-hunting shopper, which retailers consider an unreliable customer lacking store loyalty.
''It will be a very difficult Christmas selling period,'' asserted Walter F. Loeb, senior analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, New York. ''Consumers will hold back, and the situation will be complicated by considerable price competition in lots of cities. Because of the turmoil in the retail business created by mergers and selloffs,'' he continued, ''suppliers are hard-put and competitive, and they will be offering stores all kinds of brands and discounts, and that will make for a chaotic marketplace.''
For consumers, that all adds up to many opportunities for bargains. Retailers have reduced prices all year, and they are expected to continue. Indeed, the percentage reductions ahead could be higher, analysts said, which could leave shoppers with a reduced choice of goods by late in the season.
 
Traditional Optimism
Despite the uncertainties, retailers voiced traditional optimism over the period ahead, which, for many, is the most important of the year.
''The season has already started and we are optimistic because we have been running about a 9 percent gain in our stores that are at least a year old,'' said Robert E. Lawson, executive vice president and chief financial officer of Gottschalks Inc., Fresno, Calif., which operates 18 department stores and 26 specialty shops.
Despite their recent financial difficulties and delayed merchandise shipments, the Cincinnati-based Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores, also express confidence. The chain, which is owned by Campeau, exceeded third-quarter projected sales growth of 6 percent by an additional percentage point in its ''same stores,'' which is an industry term for stores owned for more than one year. James M. Zimmerman, president and chief operating officer, said he expected the same stores to gain at least 6 percent in the Christmas season, and that chain-wide sales in the period would be up 7.5 percent when the results of four new stores opened this year are included.
''The promotional climate will put pressure on profits, no doubt about it,'' Mr. Zimmerman said, referring to the atmosphere of price cutting, ''but we think our mix of merchandise and the franchise our stores have with the public will more than make up for that.''
 
New Toy Products
For Toys ''R'' Us Inc., the nation's largest toy retailer, based in Rochelle Park, N.J., ''it looks like a good season, partly because there are a lot of good new products on the market,'' said Michael Goldstein, vice chairman. He cited Game Boy, a new hand-held Nintendo video-game device; Tetrus, a Russian spy game, and Oopsy Daisy, a crawling and crying doll introduced last year that has had strong sales all year long. He said he remained optimistic, even though toy industry sales have been flat so far this year.
Nor are toys the only slack area. Three key merchandise categories, men's wear, electronics and household durables, have been slow, a trend, which if continued in the 31-day holiday season, could affect profits significantly.
 
Outlook in New York
In the New York metropolitan area, said the Touche Ross Trade Group, a research organization, retailers have a bleak outlook on the holiday season because of higher labor and overhead costs and sharp price competition.
''The retailers' mood is the most pessimistic we've observed over the last few years,'' said Harvey D. Braun, chairman of the trade group, ''The New York marketplace will be further impacted by retailers' concerns about the so-called troubled retailers in the region,'' he added. ''When you combine consumers' predictions about their holiday shopping plans with retailers creating a promotional environment, Christmas will be a flat season with minimal increases.''
For example, the announced closings of the B. Altman stores and the Alcott & Andrews chain in recent weeks has communicated a sense of unease not only among New York retailers, but also among consumers. As one shopper said this week: ''I put a deposit on a suite of furniture at B. Altman. But I can't get anyone there to tell me if I'll get it back. What can I do?''
Also, for the first time in years Christmas falls on a Monday, and retailers expect fewer last-minute shoppers with Christmas Eve on Sunday, than they would get on a Saturday or weekday.
''Consumers have few unmet material desires after the long United States economic expansion of the 1980's,'' said Sandra Shaber, economist with the Futures Group, a Washington-based economic research organization. ''It's a saturated market, and people are really determined to buy only when there are bargains.''
A good many retailers, apparently measuring these factors, decided to take early action. Many stores around the country began the start of the Christmas shopping season several weeks ago with vigorous price-cutting promotions.
 
Temptation to Slash Prices
''Warm weather slowed the apparel business in much of November, and the new cooler temperatures will show how retail sales perform in more seasonal weather,'' said Bernard Sosnick, senior analyst at the Deutsche Capital Bank, New York. However, many inventories of soft goods have backed up in stores in recent months, ''making retailers nervous,'' he said. ''If the season has a slow start, there will be a great temptation to slash prices and dump merchandise.''
Still, retail executives interviewed remain optimistic, some even ebullient, over seasonal prospects.
''It will be a good season with nothing to change the strong trend we have had so far this year,'' said Stephen Watson, executive vice president of the Dayton Hudson Corporation, Minneapolis, one of the nation's biggest retailers.
Robert J. Tarr, Jr., president of the Neiman Marcus Group, Chestnut Hill, Mass., said that the season ''will be O.K. but not a great one.''
''Consumers outside the major metropolitan areas are demonstrating caution and retailers have been somewhat hurt by the late arrival of imports,'' he said.
 
Double-Digit Gain
Mr. Tarr said that he expects the Neiman Marcus fashion stores to have a 6 percent to 7 percent gain in the season; the company's Bergdorf Goodman to ''enjoy a low-double digit gain,'' and the group's Contempo Casual apparel stores now in 30 states to ''continue to track at high double-digit increases.''
The Home Depot Inc., an Atlanta-based home-improvement chain of 107 stores, hopes for a continuation of the 15 percent gain in same stores it had in the third quarter, said Bernard Marcus, chairman and chief executive. Although the spring, summer and the fall seasons generally have higher sales than the Christmas season, he said, the company finds that it sells more power tools in the ChristConsequently, Home Depot, which is opening its first New York area store in East Meadow, L.I., next week, is attacking traditional gift-giving for men with such advertising lines as: ''Why give him a tie, when you can give him a saw or a drill?'' It works, Mr. Marcus claimed.

HEADLINE: A 'Prime Mover' in U.S. Banking

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The stakes are mounting each day, but I. A. Long has yet to show any sign of sweaty palms.
Once again, his Southwest Bank of St. Louis has placed an aggressive and highly visible bet on lower interest rates in the expectation that the industry's giants will soon join in. If they do not, the 90-year-old man sometimes called the ''prime mover'' will by the end of the month be suffering one of his rare embarrassments. 
''Ninety percent of the time we have reduced the prime rate, the rest of the banks came along, normally within two weeks,'' said Mr. Long, the courtly, pipe-smoking chairman emeritus of Southwest, who still heads its asset and liability committee. [Pressure on the big banks to join Southwest increased on Wednesday as the Federal Reserve, in a surprise move, sent a signal that traders interpreted as approval for further easing of interest rates. It was right after the Fed last signaled a drop in interest rates in early November that Southwest lowered the prime rate.] Small but Significant Nobody pretends that a $400 million bank with only two offices and 125 employees is putting much pressure on the Citibanks and Morgans of the world, but that does not mean Southwest's Nov. 8 decision to cut the prime rate a half-point, to 10 percent, lacks significance as a harbinger of national interest rates. Moreover, being wrong costs Southwest a few thousand dollars a day as well as inviting fresh charges in the banking fraternity of grandstanding.
But Mr. Long, a lanky 6-foot-3 Virginia native who still spends five days a week at the office, is seldom wrong. In fact, he cannot remember when it last happened, perhaps not since the spring of 1979, when Southwest cut its rate to 11 1/4 percent and was forced to retreat the next month.
Defeat has its compensations, however, mainly in the good will even a temporarily lower rate brings from Southwest's borrowers, mostly small manufacturers and wholesalers in the St. Louis area, which the bank considers a good microcosm of American business.
''It certainly helps our image,'' said Andrew N. Baur, the bank's 45-year-old chairman, who serves on Mr. Long's committee. Southwest's eagerness to be the first to cut the prime - and to be seen as such - is thus ''no gimmick,'' Mr. Baur said, but part of a hardheaded strategy that helps yield the bank a 1.3 percent return on assets and 19 percent return on stockholders' equity.
Indeed, Mr. Long and his colleagues have a number of admirers, including John E. Barnds, first vice president of the $15 billion National Bank of Detroit. ''It's absolutely wonderful advertising at negligible cost,'' he observed.
Mr. Long, who considers himself a banker rather than an economist, pays close attention to traditional indicators like production, employment and inflation in determining Southwest's prime rate, to which about two-thirds of the bank's $315 million loan portfolio is tied. But he is concerned more with trends than with actual figures, and he supplements his trend watching with a hefty dose of intuition.
''We rely on our brains, not the computer,'' said Mr. Long, who began his career in the New York office of the Royal Bank of Canada just after World War I. He also tries to think along with officials at the Federal Reserve - an autographed picture of the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, hangs on the wall of his ground-floor office. It was no coincidence that Southwest's latest cut came immediately after reports that the Fed had conducted a special telephone conference to nudge down the banking system's overnight loan rate.
Although Mr. Long said he would not be surprised if the prime fell below 10 percent by the end of the year, he is a member of the ''soft landing'' school that thinks any near-term recession will be avoided.
Banks use the prime rate as a benchmark for how much to charge on a wide range of loans to consumers and businesses.
If the current cut by Southwest Bank turns out to be one of Mr. Long's infrequent errors, do not count on it attracting much attention. When the bank increases the prime, which it is never the first to do, it does so quietly, Mr. Long said, without any general announcement.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Up on Sign of Fed Easing

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board signaled market participants that it might have sanctioned another modest drop in interest rates.
The Fed's action came as a surprise to traders, who were preparing to close their books early in advance of the Thanksgiving holiday.
That notion was temporarily abandoned when the Fed entered the market around 11:30 yesterday morning and aggressively pumped reserves into the banking system.
 
Easing Earlier in Month
At the time of the Fed's move, the closely watched rate for bank loans in the overnight Federal funds market was trading at 8 3/8 percent, or below the 8.50 percent level that analysts believe is the Fed's current equilibrium target. The central bank last eased policy in the first week of November. 
Most money market economists had been expecting that the Fed would either provide a modest amount of reserves or stay out of the market.
''The Fed's move has got a lot of tongues wagging right now,'' said Kristen Foster, a financial market economist at the Citicorp Investment Bank. ''The Fed knew that no one was expecting them to add reserves at this level. I think they are telling the market that it is O.K. for funds to trade at 8 1/4 percent.''
Following the Fed's operation, funds drifted downward until late in the day, when they were trading at 8 1/8 percent.
Analysts said the Fed's move yesterday probably reflected concerns about the current health of the economy. They added, however, that yesterday's report on durable goods orders during October, while weak, was most likely not the statistic that caused the Fed to act.
 
Concern on Layoffs Cited
''More than the durable goods report, it has been recent announcements of more layoffs that are upcoming that prompted this move,'' said Albert J. Gross, chief economist at Refco Inc.
Mr. Gross cited recent separate news reports that the General Motors Corporation and a number of financial services concerns, including Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest, intend to pare their payrolls.
''The significant slowing in the economy is the Fed's most important priority right now,'' Mr. Gross said. ''And the fact that they have now moved to ease policy twice in one month, a very unusual occurrence, is one of the reasons I don't think we are going to go into recession.''
The Fed's move prompted a burst of early-afternoon buying that quickly tapered off as dealers began their preparations for the holiday.
 
Long-Term Bond at 7.87%
In the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds, the 8 1/8 percent bonds of 2019 were offered late yesterday at a price of 102 27/32, up 1/4 of a point, to yield 7.87 percent.
Prices of shorter-term notes and bills, which are more sensitive to movements in the funds rate, posted gains as big or bigger.
By late in the day, the 8 1/4 percent five-year notes were offered at 102 6/ 32, up 10/32, to yield 7.69 percent, and the 7 5/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100, up 1/4, to yield 7.62 percent.
Treasury bill rates fell sharply in response to the Fed's move. In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.50 percent, down 12 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates dipped by 11 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.31 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 7.04 percent, down 10 basis points.
In other developments, the BT Securities Corporation, the investment banking subsidiary of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, yesterday became the first securities subsidiary of a banking company to act as lead manager on a negotiated underwriting since last summer, when the Federal Reserve granted these subsidiaries broader underwriting powers.
BT Securities acted as lead manager of a sale of $100 million worth of Federal funds rate notes for the Chrysler Financial Corporation.
The notes, which mature Dec. 2, 1991, have a floating rate coupon of 0.23 percent above the daily average of the Fed funds rate, paid monthly.
The issue is rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Activity in the secondary markets for investment-grade corporate bonds and tax-exempt municipal bonds was very light yesterday, dealers said.
Prices of most corporate issues rose by about 1/8 point. Buying activity was a bit more spirited in the municipal bond market, where market participants reported that prices of most issues rose by anywhere from 1/4 to 3/8 point.

HEADLINE: Survival Is Goal in Eastern Strike

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
Almost nine months since beginning a strike against Eastern Airlines, many machinists and flight attendants who have stayed off the job have become deeply concerned about their economic survival.
Even the pilots, whose leaders yesterday voted to end their walkout, will have difficulty resuming their pre-strike lives: the airline says it may not have jobs waiting for them.
Strikers who were receiving unemployment benefits are seeing them expire, and the small weekly allowances provided by the machinists' and flight attendants' unions are falling well short of meeting their members' needs. A little more than 10 percent of the strikers have returned to work; many others - the number is not known - have retired or taken jobs elsewhere, often at far lower pay.
One of the strikers' last hopes of ending the dispute was dashed late Tuesday when President Bush vetoed legislation that would have created a commission to investigate and make recommendations to Congress on how the strike could be settled. The President said Congress had no business interfering in the contract and court disputes over the strike. 
Eastern praised the veto. But George Kourpias, president of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, noted that President Bush had recently ''embraced the Solidarity union leader in Poland, Lech Walesa, and praised his contribution to democracy.
''His praise for union workers in Poland does not extend to workers in America,'' Mr. Kourpias said.
 
Ideals vs. Financial Need
While for many the issues that led them to the picket lines are still worth fighting for, the need to pay the bills is becoming more pressing.
''I have to try to get something right away,'' said Steve Clundt, an airplane cleaner from Queens who in some years earned $31,000 with overtime at Eastern. ''My auto insurance is due. I have to pay child support.'' Mr. Clundt has not been able to find a job that he thinks pays well enough for him to take. Until several weeks ago he survived on $245 a week from unemployment and $100 a week from the machinists' union. Now the unemployment benefits have run out.
George Ratcliffe, a mechanic with Eastern for 20 years in the Boston area, said his savings ran out a few weeks ago. He had been able to live on the $100 a week he received from the machinists' union and odd jobs he did for neighbors. Massachusetts does not pay striking workers unemployment benefits.
''One hundred dollars a week doesn't go very far,'' he said. He is married and has four children.
Several weeks ago he got a job as a mechanic at a company that does contract maintenance at Boston's Logan International Airport. His salary is about a third less than the $20 an hour he was making at Eastern.
But he said he did not think the strike had failed. ''There is more general awareness of what these corporate raiders do,'' he said.
 
Rebuilding Under Bankruptcy
As the strike drags on, Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, which owns Eastern, has been rebuilding the airline under the protection of the Federal Bankruptcy Court, using mostly nonunion workers, some of whom are paid far less than their unionized predecessors.
By using about $1.2 billion raised through the sale of Eastern assets, the airline expects by the end of the year to reach 80 percent of the size it was before the strike began on March 4. It hopes to emerge from bankruptcy proceedings early next year.
As strikers increasingly become forced to take jobs instead of manning picket lines, it will become more difficult for the strike to continue, workers say.
About 1,075 of the 6,000 flight attendants who struck are working again at the airline, which has about 4,000 flight attendants. About 300 of the 9,000 machinists' union members who struck - mechanics, baggage handlers and ramp workers - are now back on the job. The airline now has 2,400 mechanics.
The biggest loss of jobs has been among the ramp workers and baggage handlers, who had earned $15 an hour. Eastern has replaced virtually all of them with contract workers who earn about $6 an hour. The company plans to hire about 1,000 of these workers itself.
 
Weighing the Costs
Some striking Eastern workers have begun to wonder whether the strike was worth the cost. ''Both sides wounded themselves,'' said Mike Opitz, a striking co-pilot.
Mr. Lorenzo and his managers are struggling to rebuild the airline amid the uncertainties that come with bankruptcy. The unions are suffering because many older pilots and other less skilled workers in the machinists' and flight attendants' union are having a tough time getting new jobs.
Some workers did not wait as long as the current strikers before putting their own survival above fighting for the cause.
Many workers, particularly pilots, went back to work in August after some of the leaders of the Air Line Pilots Association declared to their rank and file that the union could no longer achieve its objective of forcing Mr. Lorenzo to sell the airline to an outside investor.
 
First Officer Returns
Among those choosing to return was Peter Clements, a first officer on a Boeing 727. He recalled that he joined the strike after having become convinced that the attitude of Eastern management was destructive and that there was no future at the carrier. Like many others, he hoped the strike would force Mr. Lorenzo to sell the carrier.
Although a sale to a group led by Peter J. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner, was arranged in April, it fell through, and no other buyer materialized.
When Jack Bavis, the leader of the pilots, told his members on Aug. 4 that there was no chance for another buyer and that the best option was for the pilots to go back to work, ''I realized it was a lost cause,'' Mr. Clements said. ''You have to be able to accept defeat.'' (Mr. Bavis was subsequently recalled by the union's master executive council and replaced by Skip Copeland, who advocated continuing the strike.) Mr. Clements added that to his surprise he had found a marked change in attitude among Eastern managers when he returned to work. ''There is a real commitment to listen to what employees are saying,'' he said.
Mr. Clements said he had been able to make more money than under the old contract because he can now fly 100 hours a month under new work rules instituted by the company instead of 84 under the old rules. He has also been cleared to fly a Lockheed 1011, a bigger jet. He said he now makes about $85 an hour, compared with about $65 an hour before the strike.
 
Handling the Baggage, Too
The trade-off is that he is no longer protected by many of the old work rules. In September he and about 25 other pilots volunteered to load and unload bags from airplanes in Atlanta because the carrier was having problems with manning.
''That could never have happened under the old contract,'' he said.
But workers like Mike Pedano, who was a fueler at La Guardia Airport for 10 years, have little chance of getting back their jobs even if the strike is resolved.
Until several weeks ago Mr. Pedano, who is single, was making ends meet with the $245 a week he got from unemployment benefits, which have now run out.
He has tried to start a business selling small replicas of baseball and football helmets in Long Island bars and flea markets. While he has had some success, his house is filled with boxes of unsold helmets. Meanwhile, the $1,000 he charged on a credit card to pay for them is due.
''I haven't even begun to break even,'' he said. ''My house looks like the locker room for a midget baseball team.''

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Fund Yields Mixed Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market mutual funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, with tax-exempt funds up and taxables down for the second straight week.
Analysts at Donoghue's said the release of October's Consumer Price Index and durable goods orders earlier this week did not dramatically change the picture of a slowing economy or the outlook for lower rates. Money market funds influenced by Federal Reserve policy on short-term interest rates are also expected to continue to fall. 
Because of the length of time money fund managers hold securities in their portfolios, yields offered by money market funds change less often with daily rate fluctuations compared with certificates of deposit. In a lower rate cycle, money market funds are usually about a month behind the changes of bank C.D.'s.
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market mutual fund declined by 2 basis points, to 8.31 percent, while the 30-day yield fell by 4 basis points, to 8.38 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The assets of the taxable funds increased by $4.4 billion, to $361.6 billion. The analysts at Donoghue's said the cash flow into the money market funds might have been spurred by a weak stock market on Monday and by some pension fund managers, who temporarily parked cash in the money funds to lock in profits made this year.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios increased by a day, to 44.
 
Dreyfus Top Return
Among the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million that are surveyed by Donoghue's, the Dreyfus World Wide Dollar Money Market Fund had the best return, with a yield of 9.26 percent.
Tax-exempt funds this week increased their assets by $300 million, to $70.7 billion, as the average seven-day compounded yield rose by 4 basis points, to 5.68 percent. The taxable equivalent for investors in a 28 percent tax bracket should be 7.88 percent, and for those in a 33 percent bracket, 8.44 percent.
The Evergreen Tax-Exempt Money Market Fund outperformed others in the category, according to Donoghue's. The fund posted a 6.41 percent return, or about 73 basis points better than the average.
By comparison, The Bank Rate Monitor's national index showed that the average yield for a bank money market account was down by a basis point, to 6.37 percent. The index also showed that the average yield for a six-month certificate of deposit was off by 2 basis points, to 8.09 percent.
Certificates with longer maturities were all down by 4 basis points. A one-year certificate fell to 8.12 percent, while two-and-a-half-year and five-year C.D.'s each dropped to 8.05 percent.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises 17.49 Points, To 2,656.78

BYLINE: By PHILLIP H. WIGGINS

 BODY:
Stock prices rose broadly yesterday in slow pre-Thanksgiving trading. The Dow Jones industrial average finished 17.49 points higher at 2,656.78.
Advances on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered declines by 888 to 565, while volume slipped to 145.7 million shares, from 147.9 million on Tuesday. 
''The market has absorbed a barrage of mixed economic news and 'doom and gloom' prophesies over the last six weeks,'' said Eugene E. Peroni Jr., chief technical analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia.
''The apparent ability of equities to withstand these pressures and show an overall advance over the last five trading days indicates a resilient market tone that should establish a foundation for a formidable year-end rally,'' he added.
 
Pivotal Indicator
The pivotal Dow indicator was ahead about 10 points an hour and a half into the session. It had moved to a 16-point gain by 3:30 P.M. where it leveled off before the final bell.
In the broader market, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 2.32 points, to 341.91, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index added 1.16 points, to 189.21.
In economic news, the Commerce Department reported that durable goods orders for October fell a seasonally adjusted six-tenths of 1 percent, a drop far smaller than a 2.1 percent drop expected by many analysts. Large swings in military orders strongly influenced total orders in October and September, the Government said. Traders said the latest results had little impact on stocks.
Among individual issues, Texas Instruments soared 4 3/4, to 36 1/2. Traders said the company's shares rose on optimism over a patent it was awarded for all integrated circuits made, used or sold in Japan. They said the patent could raise the company's revenues by up to $700 million a year in the 1990's.
 
National Semiconductor
National Semiconductor rose 7/8, to 7 3/8. Traders said that a patent in Japan for an invention by a scientist at the Fairchild Corporation, a unit of National Semiconductor, has expired. Speculation that National Semiconductor could benefit from a similar patent spurred the rise in that stock, analysts said.
Cigna dropped 1 1/4, to 64 5/8. The company said it was discussing the possible acquisition of Equicor, a group insurance and managed health-care joint venture owned by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and the Hospital Corporation of America.
Merrill Lynch slipped 1/2, to 26 1/8. The company joined an ever-widening list of brokerage firms that have recently reduced their staffs. Merrill said in a letter to its employees that it planned a restructuring and would probably lay off some staff because of intensified competition and increasing risks.
Syntex rose 1 5/8, to 49 5/8, as the stock continued to rise after its report of significantly higher-than-expected earnings for the third quarter.
Among actively traded blue chips, Honeywell dropped a point, to 79 3/4; Philip Morris added 5/8, to 41 3/8; Bristol-Myers gained 1 3/8, 56 1/8, and General Electric rose 1/2, to 60 1/8.
On the American Stock Exchange, the Amex market value index added 0.74, to 371.72, while in over-the-counter trading, the Nasdaq composite index rose 1 point, to 455.14.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Lower in New York As Traders Focus on Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar drifted mostly lower in sluggish, choppy trading yesterday, as traders remained preoccupied with the West German mark.
West German markets were closed for the day, and United States and Japanese markets were winding down for Thanksgiving holidays. 
Currency dealers are bullish toward the mark because West Germany may have to raise interest rates to keep its economy from overheating. It is widely believed that West German growth will accelerate as East Germans continue to come into the country.
Higher West German interest rates would raise returns on mark-denominated investments and spur demand for marks.
The dollar was quoted at 1.81275 marks late yesterday in New York, down from 1.81375 on Tuesday. It declined to 143.10 yen, down from 143.55.
In London, the pound rose to $1.5655, from $1.5645. One pound cost $1.56775 in New York, down from $1.56975.
Other late dollar rates in New York compared with Tuesday's late quotes included: 1.6110 Swiss francs, down from 1.6130; 6.1835 French francs, up from 6.1775; 1,337.00 Italian lire, up from 1,336.00, and 1.16875 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16995.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Hits $411.60 an Ounce; Highest Close Since Jan. 3

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Gold prices surged yesterday for the fourth straight day on New York's Commodity Exchange, where late buying put the market within range of a new high for this year.
Despite some profit taking earlier in the session and a downturn in silver prices, which normally move in tandem with gold, analysts said the gold market's five-week-old rally showed no sign of slackening.
''We're only now starting to reach a new leg of bullish enthusiasm,'' said Fred Demler, metals economist with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. 
 
Gains of $7.20 to $8.10
Gold settled $7.20 to $8.10 higher, with the contract for delivery in December at $411.60 an ounce and the lightly traded spot contract at $411. The close was the market's highest since Jan. 3, the first trading day of 1989, when the near-month gold contract finished at $413.40.
Silver finished 3.2 cents to 3.8 cents lower, with the December contract at $5.808 an ounce.
About a third of gold's gains occurred in the last half-hour of the session as traders who had earlier taken profits returned as buyers in anticipation of gains today on the European markets. The United States markets will be closed for Thanksgiving.
''I would want to be long, given the recent history of this market,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, a metals analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.
Investment demand for gold continues to increase as prices rise and economic uncertainty chases investors from the stock and bond markets, analysts said.
 
Action on Other Market
Livestock and meat futures rallied on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
After the close, the Agriculture Department released a monthly cold-storage report showing 40.2 million pounds of frozen pork bellies in warehouses as of Oct. 31. The number was slightly higher than expected.
Live cattle futures settled 0.10 cent to 0.42 cent higher, with December at 76 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.15 cent to 0.30 cent higher, with November at 83.45 cents a pound; hogs were unchanged to 0.28 cent higher, with December at 51.25 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 0.20 cent to 0.60 cent higher, with February at 63.25 cents a pound.
Cocoa futures prices sank to new 14-year lows on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, reflecting the large supplies of cocoa. Cocoa settled $19 to $23 lower, with December at $918 a ton.
Energy futures finished mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Heating oil was up sharply after the American Petroleum Institute reported that distillate stocks had unexpectedly dropped 3.14 million barrels last week. Forecasts for frigid weather in the Midwest and the Northeast also spurred buying.
West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 7 cents to 14 cents lower, with January at $19.82 a barrel; heating oil was 0.14 cent to 1.15 cents higher, with December at 61.09 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.29 cent lower to 0.10 cent higher, with December at 51.73 cents a gallon.
Soybean futures posted moderate gains on the Chicago Board of Trade. Wheat futures declined slightly while corn was little changed.

HEADLINE: Irving Friedman, 74, Economist

BYLINE: By JOAN COOK

 BODY:
Irving S. Friedman, an international economist who held high positions in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, died of a heart attack on Monday in Bethesda, Md. He was 74 years and lived in Bethesda.
Dr. Friedman began his career in 1941 in the office of the Secretary of the Treasury. In World War II he was a financial adviser to the United States Army headquarters in Chongqing, China. 
He joined the International Monetary Fund in Washington in 1946 as chief of the United States-Canada Division and later became a senior department director, heading missions to member countries.
In 1950, Dr. Friedman became director of the Exchange Restrictions Department of the monetary fund, where he developed and carried out policies involving exchange rates, restrictions on international payments and multiple currency practices. In 1964 he became economic adviser to the president of the World Bank and chairman of its economic committee.
 
Banking Posts
Dr. Friedman joined Citibank in Manhattan in 1974 as senior vice president and senior adviser for international operations. In 1980 he joined the First Boston Corporation as senior international adviser and a member of the international advisory board. In the 1980's he also held senior advisory positions with the African, Asian and Inter-American Development Banks and other public and commercial financial institutions.
In 1971 he became a Quondam Fellow of All Souls College at Oxford University and a visiting professor at Yale University. He was also a visiting professor at the University of Virginia and Fordham University and lectured abroad and in Canada.
He was a former president of the Society for International Development, chairman of Washington Capital Markets Group, the Center of Concern and the Population Resource Center, and a director of the Resource Development Fund. He received the medal of honor from the World Business Council in 1982.
He was the author of many articles and books on economics, including ''Toward World Prosperity: Reshaping the Global Monetary System'' (Lexington Books, 1987) and ''The World Debt Dilemma: Managing Country Risk'' (Robert Morris Associates, 1983).
Dr. Friedman. who was born in Manhattan, received bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees from Columbia University, where he was a University Fellow.
He is survived by his wife, Edna; two sons, Kenneth of Bethesda, and John of Frederick, Md.; a sister, Esther Wachs of Sunrise, Fla., and seven grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Arnold Bauman, 75, A Former U.S. Judge And Litigation Chief

BYLINE: By DAVID MARGOLICK

 BODY:
Arnold Bauman, a former United States District Court judge, a prosecutor and a prominent New York litigator for many years, died of cancer Tuesday night at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 75 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.
Mr. Bauman was named to the Federal District Court in Manhattan by President Richard M. Nixon in 1971 and took the bench in January 1972. The move capped a career in which he had served as assistant district attorney in Manhattan, chief of the criminal division of the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan and a member of the Knapp Commission investigating police corruption in New York City.
While on the bench, he presided over the tax-evasion trial of Aniello Dellacroce, a member of the Gambino crime family. He also was the judge at the bank robbery trial of Joanne D. Chesimard and Fred Hilton, reputed members of the Black Liberation Army, and presided at the prosecution of two members of the Jewish Defense League accused of bombing the Manhattan offices of Sol Hurok and Columbia Artists Inc. 
He served at the bribery trial of the New York lawyer Edmund Rosner - a case in which Robert Leuci, later the subject of the film ''Prince of the City,'' was the key witness.
 
Resignation Over Salary
Contending that it was ''economically impossible'' for him to remain on the bench, Mr. Bauman resigned in 1974. Later he remained active in the campaign to increase Federal judicial salaries.
Upon leaving the court, he became head of the litigation department at Shearman & Sterling, then New York's largest law firm. He stepped down from that position in 1985, though he remained a partner at the firm and continued handling cases.
Mr. Bauman was born in Manhattan on July 25, 1914. He attended James Madison High School, St. John's University and the New York University Law School. Upon completing his law studies in 1937, he found his first job as special assistant to Thomas E. Dewey, then New York City's special rackets prosecutor. He became part of the illustrious team of young lawyers known as ''Dewey's Boys.''
Others in the group included Frank Hogan, later District Attorney of Manhattan; Murray Gurfein and Whitman A. Knapp, both later Federal judges in Manhattan; William P. Rogers, President Nixon's Secretary of State, and Charles D. Breitel and Stanley Fuld, both Chief Judges of New York.
 
On District Attorney's Staff
When Mr. Dewey left the post the following year to become District Attorney of Manhattan, Mr. Bauman accompanied him as an assistant.
After four and a half years in the Navy during World War II, from which he was discharged as a lieutenant commander, Mr. Bauman returned to New York in 1945 and spent two years working under District Attorney Hogan. He spent the next four years in private practice and then, in 1951, was named chief counsel of a committee headed by Senator Matthew M. Neely of West Virginia, which investigated crime and police corruption in the District of Columbia.
In 1953 Mr. Bauman was named an assistant United States attorney in Manhattan in charge of the criminal division. Among those he prosecuted were Joseph P. Ryan, former president of the International Longshoremen's Association, who was convicted of taking payoffs in violation of the Taft-Hartley Act.
Mr. Bauman was a past president of the Federal Bar Council, a member of the American College of Trial Lawyers and was active in the City Bar Association in New York.
He is survived by his wife, the former Bernice Rechtman; a daughter, Jane B. Phillips of Berkeley, Calif.; a son, William K., of Van Nuys, Calif., and a grandson.

LENGTH: 1819 words

HEADLINE: Worries About Reaction in U.S., Japanese Assess Investment Policy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Fearful of an American reaction to the recent surge of Japanese acquisitions, business and Government leaders here are reassessing their strategy for investing overseas.
They worry that the door to the United States market may be closing, and in corporate board rooms, Government ministries and in the press, a debate has erupted over how to handle America: whether to ease up on the investment spree in hopes that the furor will pass, or to plunge ahead confident that the United States will decide it can no longer afford to live without Tokyo's money.
The Japanese seem taken aback by the severity of the American reaction which is played back nightly here, often in amplified and alarmist tones.
 
A Favorite Topic
Television talk shows these days frequently take up the topic of whether Japan's latest buying binge is turning the country into a financial pariah, or whether America is reacting to a gut fear that a foreign power, particularly an Asian one, is gaining influence over its economy. 
More than at any time in recent memory, the United States is being portrayed here as an emotional, often irrational ally that foolishly puts its choicest assets on the auction block for quick profit, then blames the buyer for snapping them up. Yotaro Iida, the president of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, seemed to reflect that view when he compared America to a bullying husband who ''tends to behave badly when he is drinking'' but who ''believes that his wife will never leave him.''
Yet the Japanese are concerned that the critical words they hear from American executives, trade officials and man-on-the-street interviews on television may be translated into restrictions on investment in the United States. Last week, a bill was introduced in Congress to limit investment in the United States by any country that has barriers to American investments, an outgrowth of T. Boone Pickens's futile attempt to get seats on the board of a Japanese automotive parts maker in which he is the largest shareholder.
In addition, some American officials have hinted that the United States may be moving toward a far broader interpretation of ''national security'' - the chief rationale for blocking foreign investment at present - to embrace economic matters as well as military defense.
The debate over Tokyo's investment policy represents a new chapter in the long-running economic conflict between the United States and Japan. For a decade, Japan has grown accustomed to seeing other nations take steps to curb Japanese exports. So in the last few years, Japanese industry has shifted to buying and building factories, high-technology companies and property, especially in the United States, rather than shipping goods abroad.
That strategy is deemed good politics, as well as good business, since every Japanese auto plant or building development abroad means more jobs for foreign workers.
Accordingly, many Japanese are now confused by what they hear of American fears about Japan's recent purchases in the United States, which include Columbia Pictures, control of Rockefeller Center, a Houston office complex and a handful of biotechnology and electronics companies.
''It would be one thing if these were hostile takeovers,'' said Makoto Utsumi, the Vice Minister of Finance. ''But I am not aware of a single investment that the United States did not invite, are you?''
Invited or not, Japanese direct investment in American assets has accelerated remarkably in the last couple of years. Direct investment refers to purchases of physical assets, like plants and real estate, as opposed to financial assets, like stocks and bonds. Japan's direct investment in the United States, analysts estimate, will reach a total of $75 billion by the end of this year, up 40 percent since 1988 and double the level just two years ago.
The Japanese investment position in America still trails that of Britain, but Japan is catching up quickly. Last year alone, Japan's investment in the American manufacturing sector, for example, increased by $7 billion, more than its total investment in American manufacturing in the previous four decades. Japanese investment in American real estate nearly doubled last year, while spending to acquire and set up banking and finance operations boomed as well.
 
Contradictions Are Seen
The Japanese reaction is heavily influenced by the fact that the voices it hears from America are almost all angry ones. Television here has shown Mr. Pickens, the Texas investor, declare that a six-month moratorium should be imposed on Japanese investment in the United States. Mr. Pickens has been frustrated in his attempts to get seats on the board of the Japanese company, the Koito Manufacturing Company.
Japanese television viewers have also seen Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, telling an American interviewer, ''I just can't believe that we are sitting here going into debt more and more every day, and let the Japanese buy Rockefeller Center.'' The Japanese attitude toward America, he said, is ''we're better than you guys are, and you better make up your minds and roll over and play dead.''
The American reaction strikes many Japanese as xenophobic, so much so that recently the United States Ambassador to Japan, Michael H. Armacost, began cautioning Japanese audiences against ''thinly veiled suggestions that criticism reflects racism.'' Such a view, ''deflects criticism from the real sources of concern,'' he said.
Those concerns, he said, are the slowness of Japanese companies that have American operations to put Americans in management positions, hire minorities or give local producers a chance to compete with Japanese suppliers.
 
Attempt to Ease Tensions
Such talk has come as a surprise to some people here because Japanese industry has long assumed, with encouragement from the Government, that investment in the United States would ease tensions by diminishing the trade deficit, thus reducing the pressure on Japan to import more.
Moreover, such investments deepen the web of interconnections between the two economies, sometimes creating jobs and often pumping Japanese capital back into American industry.
Some believe that strategy is still sound and that Congress will balk at placing restrictions on Japanese investment once it understands the economic consequences.
One possible consequence has been called Japan's ''second strike capability,'' a term that is gaining currency in the Japanese business world. The phrase has nothing to do with nuclear weapons; it refers to scenarios in which Japan responds to a closing of the American market by reducing its financing of the United States budget deficit and its private corporate borrowing. The result could be a sharp rise in interest rates and perhaps a recession.
A signficant concern among the Japanese is the possible broadening of the ''national security'' restriction on foreign acquisitions in the United States, beyond military contracting industries.
 
Warning From a Regulator
Several weeks ago the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Gerald E. Corrigan, hinted during a conference with Japanese executives here that the United States may begin reviewing foreign acquisition of banks in cases in which a country ''has an over-concentration of assets.'' That was seen as a clear reference to the fact that Japanese institutions now control about a quarter of all the bank assets in California.
Yoshitoki Chino, the chairman of Daiwa Securities, one of Japan's biggest securities houses, quickly agreed. ''We have to be careful about a financial overpresence,'' he said.
Mr. Armacost, while telling the Japanese that their money is still welcome under most circumstances, said recently that the Sony Corporation's $3.4 billion acquisition of Columbia Pictures last month ''has broadened the debate to include the potential loss of valuable cultural assets.''
Elliot L. Richardson, a former Cabinet official often hired by Japan, is telling Japanese clients that new rules promulgated by the Treasury Department ''cover far more transactions than necessary.''
The rules involve the Exon-Florio Amendment to the Defense Production Act, which gives the President the right to block foreign investments that threaten national security. The Treasury's rules are written so broadly, Mr. Richardson says, that they could cover joint ventures, minority stakes in companies and the acquisition of one overseas company by another if either had a United States subsidiary.
So far, the Bush Administration has interpreted the law narrowly. No foreign acquisitions have actually been denied, though some companies have dropped out of bidding contests and, in one recent case, an American company was forced to relinquish a contract to make triggers for nuclear weapons before the company could be acquired.
Some Japanese companies say the prospect of intense Government scrutiny has already deterred them from making acquisitions in areas that might raise new concerns.
 
Government Urges Caution
The Japanese Government itself seems divided on whether it should help suppress overseas investment, and the result has been a set of mixed signals. The Government has informally advised companies here to ''use caution,'' but that has been interpreted to mean that companies should avoid attention-getting acquisitions, like buying military contractors or well-known properties. When the Mitsubishi Estate Company bought control of the Rockefeller Center Group last month, that advice was apparently ignored.
In recent weeks, however, the debate has begun to take a new turn, focusing less on what Japan buys and more on how Japanese companies act once they are operating in the United States.
The criticism heard most often is that few Japanese subsidiaries in the United States are really run like American companies, with American decision-making and American senior executives. An official Japanese study done last year said that of Japanese-affiliated companies operating in the United States 85 percent of them were run by a Japanese chief executive. Only about 20 percent of American-affiliated companies in Japan were run by Americans.
 
A Promise From Sony
Sony seemed particularly sensitive to this point when it purchased CBS Records early last year and Columbia Pictures last month. ''You won't see a lot of Japanese faces going through the door,'' promised Akio Morita, Sony's chairman.
But such assurances seem difficult to keep once management problems set in. Last week, the Bridgestone Corporation, which purchased Firestone Tire and Rubber Company in March 1988, said its chairman, Teiji Eguchi, would move to Akron, Ohio, next year to ''expedite decision-making within North America.'' The move was widely interpreted by analysts here as reflecting dissatisfaction with the company's American managers.

HEADLINE: China's Frontier: The Search for Development

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LANZHOU, China

 BODY:
This is the ''other China,'' a land of poor peasants and occasional smokestacks, where for some households upward mobility means nothing more grand than moving out of their cave and into a house.
As China develops, the caves are giving way to brick or mud homes, and most people in northwestern China have basic clothing and enough food to eat. But there is still none of the sense of economic vibrancy and rapid change that permeates the coastal areas of southeast China.
The peasants here in Gansu Province earn an average of just $100 a year, the lowest of any province in China. Their basic needs have mostly been met, but economists and other analysts say that the people of Gansu have probably benefited less than other Chinese from the restructuring of the last decade. 
''In recent years, the country has had a policy of regional favoritism,'' said Chai Zhuqing, an official of the provincial planning commission. ''The coastal areas developed very quickly, with the help of the state and foreign investors. But we're in the hinterland, with long distances to transport goods.''
A recent survey suggested that the gap between China's rich and poor areas is continuing to grow. In the first half of this year, the survey found, per capita incomes of peasants were $49 higher than a year earlier in southern Guangdong Province, the wealthiest part of the country. In the poorest parts, like Gansu and Tibet, incomes grew by just $5, compared with those of a year earlier.
''The gaps have increased and I can't see that trend changing anytime soon,'' Nicholas Lardy, a China scholar at the University of Washington, said in a telephone interview. Professor Lardy said that the central government is no longer redistributing resources among regions the way it once did, and that this will limit Gansu's ability to bridge the gap.
Under Mao, China's economic planners milked rich areas such as Shanghai for the benefit of other parts of the country. The planners also tried to build up the industrial capacity of the interior, partly for national security reasons, so that the country could continue to produce if it were attacked.
Even so, China's industry is geographically lopsided. Of the nation's 500 largest industrial enterprises, 111 are either in Shanghai or in northeastern Liaoning Province, while only 25 are in the six provinces and autonomous regions of China's west.
The Government in recent months has expressed increased concern about the plight of the hinterland, and there is no longer as much conviction as there used to be that some areas should get rich first and then spread the wealth to the interior. But there is still not much of an economic strategy for China's interior.
''Opening the door on the northwest frontier'' read the headline of a front-page editorial in the semi-official China Economic News last month, but the article contained few specific ideas for how to develop the frontier. While rich in mineral resources, the northwest lacks the entrepreneurial tradition of coastal areas, as well as their wealth of overseas relatives and other links.
The People's Daily and other official publications have recently called for developing overland trade with other Asian countries and even rebuilding a ''land bridge'' to Europe. This revived form of the old Silk Route will take shape around the end of next year when China completes a rail link across its northwestern border with the Soviet rail system.
Officials here in Gansu Province are optimistic that the rail link will allow them to export their products to European ports, so that Gansu too can participate in the opening to the outside world that has left the coastal region so flush with wealth.
Much of China is now alarmed at the prospect of recession, because of an economic retrenchment, but Gansu seems less worried. In September, industrial production in the province was 8 percent higher than a year earlier, while in cities such as Shanghai production actually fell. Officials note that the local economy was never particularly overheated, so the slowdown will not be very painful.

HEADLINE: Diplomats at Japan's Embassy Worry About Anti-Tokyo Sentiment in U.S.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
The Japanese Embassy here is modest, quiet and plain. The unadorned three-story building on a tree-lined street does not look like the outpost of an economic superpower.
Its appearance gives no hint of the anxiety inside, where diplomats worry about anti-Japanese sentiment in the United States. Nor does it give any clue to the intense struggles among diplomats representing different agencies of the Tokyo Government.
What follows is a snapshot of life inside the embassy, a world seldom penetrated by American visitors. Other nations maintain large, active embassy staffs in Washington, but the Japanese have a style all their own, characterized by a passion for detailed information, a willingness to work around the clock and a combination of modesty and politeness that often disarms American officials. 
J. Michael Farren, the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, said Japanese diplomats ''often sidestep confrontation by conducting themselves with great politeness and formality, so it's very difficult to get mad at them.''
''As a U.S. Government official,'' he said, ''I grudgingly admire their effectiveness. They have done a phenomenally good job of serving Japanese interests by calming the waters at key times so there will be only a minimal U.S. response to trade problems with Japan.''
The embassy has become increasingly important as dozens of disputes strain the vast web of relations between the two nations. It serves as the hub of Japanese efforts to track American policy, to monitor the American economy and to influence decisions by the executive branch and Congress, which can have an immense effect on ties between Tokyo and Washington.
 
A Hard-Working, Well-Educated Staff
Japanese diplomats delve into the remotest corners of the Federal bureaucracy, assiduously cultivate mid-level officials, extract information, line up allies in the United States Government and deftly deflect pressure on Japan to change its trade practices or other policies. While Congressional criticism of Japan is common, it rarely results in concrete legislative or executive action against Tokyo.
Operating in orbit around the embassy are a bevy of lawyers, lobbyists and consultants whose activities are, from time to time, influenced or coordinated by the embassy. At the center of this network is a team of career diplomats led by Ambassador Nobuo Matsunaga, who has just wound up a four and a half-year assignment here.
Embassy employees normally start at 9:30 A.M. and often work past midnight. Shinichi Nishimiya, the first secretary for economic affairs for the last three years, said that as he returned to his home in suburban Bethesda, Md., he often passed commuters driving in the opposite direction just before dawn.
Nearly all the senior diplomats at the Japanese Embassy have graduate degrees from Harvard, Yale or Princeton, and a few studied in England, at Oxford or Cambridge. They include some of the best of Japan's professional bureaucrats and diplomats. They come not only from the Foreign Ministry but also from the Finance Ministry and the powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry.
After years in which they insisted that there were no serious problems between Japan and the United States, senior diplomats at the embassy now speak with a sense of foreboding, a premonition that relations between Tokyo and Washington may deteriorate before they improve.
''The perception of the American public that Japan is a potential threat to the well-being of the United States is alarming and problematic,'' said Koji Tsuruoka, a first secretary in the embassy's political section. ''That is something that worries us, regardless of whether it is right or wrong.''
The deputy chief of mission, Yoshio Karita, who polished his English while studying politics and economics at Oxford 30 years ago, said: ''The fact that we have been able to settle all problems in the past shows the degree of efficiency with which this embassy functions. But the problems are becoming chronic, more aggravated and serious.''
With about 200 employees, the embassy is Japan's largest. The State Department lists 103 people with diplomatic rank and privileges at the embassy. Saudi Arabia has 116, Israel has 42 and the Soviet Union 118.
Outsiders often see the embassy as a monolith, but employees say there are intense intramural rivalries, reflecting the different priorities of the Government ministries for which they work. If, for example, a commercial officer gets an advance copy of a Congressional report on a pending trade bill, he may send the text to Tokyo before the political section has a chance to see it.
The deep-seated rivalries among Japanese agencies give the diplomats a keen appreciation for disagreements among Federal agencies here. Michael B. Smith, who served as deputy trade representative in the Reagan Administration, said Japanese diplomats were eager ''to find inconsistencies in the positions of different U.S. agencies and to drive a wedge in there.''
 
Different Messages From Different Agencies
Nathaniel B. Thayer, a professor of Japanese studies at Johns Hopkins University, said, ''Each Japanese ministry and agency has its own representation in Washington.'' The rivalry among units of the embassy is so intense that Administration officials and Congressional aides say they are sometimes confused about the position of the Japanese Government.
''The Foreign Ministry tells me something different from what the Construction Ministry tells me,'' said Jamie Boucher, an aide to Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska. ''There is a myth of a homogenized Japanese negotiating position. But much as we have interagency spats in our foreign and trade policy, it's the same at the Japanese Embassy. This creates confusion about where the embassy stands on any given issue.''
The embassy is an elaborate information-gathering machine. A State Department official said: ''The Japanese diplomats build up mounds and mounds of facts and detail. Like a vacuum cleaner, they suck it up wherever they can. Sometimes they come to the State Department and ask: 'How do you decide what's real? How do you analyze it?' They are better at collecting information than at analyzing it.''
Mr. Smith, the trade negotiator, recalled that Japanese diplomats ''sometimes repeated a question four times just to make sure you gave the same answer.'' Such aggressive curiosity irritates some American officials, but Mr. Smith said: ''It made our job a lot easier. The worst thing is to go into negotiations and have big surprises.''
A half-dozen Americans work at the embassy as ''senior clerks,'' helping Japanese diplomats analyze political trends, economic policy-making and legislative developments in the United States. The clerks include Kate Taylor, who used to work for the National Republican Senatorial Committee; John Tobe, former Midwest political coordinator for the Democratic National Committee, and Luanne M. Chapman, a former aide to Representative Thomas J. Ridge, Republican of Pennsylvania.
''The Japanese are very detail-oriented,'' said Ms. Chapman, who prepares a weekly report on Congressional activity. ''They are eager to know the nitty-gritty details of the legislative process.''
 
Links With Congress And Private Sector
Members of Congress often denounce Japan as an unfair trader, express alarm about Japanese investment in the United States and prod the Bush Administration to pry open Japanese markets. But behind the scenes there is a cordial, steady exchange of views between members of Congress and Japanese diplomats.
Each month a half-dozen Congressional aides meet with a half-dozen people from the embassy to discuss trade and other issues. The luncheons are arranged by Steven R. Saunders, a trade consultant retained by the embassy. In 1981 and 1982, Mr. Saunders was the assistant United States trade representative for Congressional relations and public affairs.
More than 120 law firms, lobbying groups and public relations companies have registered with the Justice Department as agents of Japanese companies, but only 12 report working directly for the embassy. They include Mike Masaoka, who publishes a newsletter for the embassy every two weeks; H. William Tanaka, a trade lawyer, and Allan S. Mostoff, a former official of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who has advised the embassy for 12 years on the intricacies of S.E.C. regulations.
Mr. Farren, the Under Secretary of Commerce, said the embassy ''makes good use of the private sector'' to multiply its message on selected issues. For example, he said, in 1987, when Congress was considering legislation to punish the Toshiba Corporation for selling restricted technology to the Soviet Union, the embassy was like ''a coach on the sidelines,'' urging Japanese companies to lobby against the sanctions.
''You often get a cohesive story line out of the whole Japanese community here,'' Mr. Farren said. ''The Japanese Embassy does a good job of coordinating it.''
The embassy enhances its influence through several outposts loosely affiliated with the Tokyo Government. The embassy finances the Japan Economic Institute, a research center that compiles statistics and publishes weekly reports. Under a contract signed in April, the embassy is paying the institute $863,239 this year and is entitled to supervise its activities.
 
Trade Ministry Has Strong Role
The Ministry of International Trade and Industry, which often gets credit for engineering Japan's postwar economic achievements, has three diplomats at the embassy here. In theory, all report to Nobutoshi Akao, the embassy's economic minister, who holds a master's degree in international relations from Yale. But he said they often bypassed him and sent reports directly to ministry headquarters in Tokyo.
The ministry, known as MITI, also supervises the Japan External Trade Organization, or Jetro, a commercial intelligence service with offices in New York and six other American cities. Jetro says its main functions are to conduct market research and to promote imports into Japan. In fact, American officials say that several employees of the New York office are high-powered special emissaries from MITI who operate outside normal diplomatic channels.
The emissaries include Hajime Furuta and Nobuyuki Kodaira, who have registered with the Justice Department as Jetro researchers. But on their business cards, each is identified as a ''special representative'' of MITI. An American official said they had been ''very active in Washington, hobnobbing with the State Department, the Defense Department and the American trade representative during talks on semiconductors, steel and other sensitive issues.''
MITI's top man at the Japanese Embassy is Eiichi Ono, the commercial minister, who has a master's degree from the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.
When asked to describe his relationship to the MITI office in New York, Mr. Ono laughed and said: ''The division of labor is unclear. Theoretically and organizationally speaking, MITI does not have its direct representatives in the United States. My Government operates on the principle that foreign policy should be a unified policy and should be conducted through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.''
''Before World War II,'' Mr. Ono said, ''the military conducted its own independent diplomacy outside the Foreign Ministry, and that led to disaster.''

GRAPHIC: Despite the anxiety at the Japanese Embassy, where diplomats worry about anti-Japanese sentiment in the United States, it's still often business as usual. At a recent reception, Ambassador Nobuo Matsunaga and his wife greeted other envoys, including Rinaldo Petrignani of Italy. (The New York Times/Lisa Berg)

HEADLINE: Flint Journal;
G.M.'s Company Town Goes on Downhill Drive

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FLINT, Mich.

 BODY:
This is a city with a dependency problem, one that is destroying livelihoods, forcing people from their homes and contributing to pervasive crime.
The addiction has nothing to do with cocaine, although plenty of that can be found here too. The dependency, for better and for worse, is on the General Motors Corporation, which has been the biggest employer here for half a century.
Flint is the birthplace of General Motors and the biggest G.M. company town in the world. It is also ground zero for unemployed auto workers, a growing subclass of the nation's jobless. 
The unemployment stems from American makers' shrunken share of the automobile market. General Motors has produced about a million and a half fewer cars annually in the last decade than it did in the late 1970's. That has meant the shutdown and consolidation of dozens of plants all over the country. Flint has borne the brunt of this retrenchment: employment here has fallen from a peak of about 80,000 in numerous plants scattered around the city to just over 50,000.
''We have depended on G.M., all of us,'' said Shirley Prater, community service director for Local 599 of the United Automobile Workers. ''We never knew they would shut down so much.''
This year Ms. Prater has counseled 3,890 families of unemployed G.M. workers on matters like eviction, attempted suicide, lack of food, lack of money for heat and electricity. ''The people sit back,'' she said, ''and they wait and wait, thinking G.M. will come back. And then everything is gone.''
Some jobs are available here, but for nowhere near the wages that workers earned in the auto plants. And while General Motors provides job training benefits to those whose plants are shut permanently, the benefits go only so far in easing the transition to a new life.
Marcia McGee, a G.M. spokeswoman here, compared the once-perennial certainty of getting work at G.M. to ''an entitlement program, not unlike government entitlement programs.''
''But G.M. has been very direct,'' she said. ''We've told many people, 'Your jobs are never coming back.' ''
Flint has recently acquired a bit of national notoriety as the setting for ''Roger and Me,'' a documentary film by a native of the city, Michael Moore. In a humorous but unflattering way, the film explores the troubles of Flint and the auto maker and how they are being addressed by politicians, economic development officials and G.M. management, particularly Roger B. Smith, the company's chairman. ''Roger and Me'' - the title refers to Mr. Smith - received wide acclaim when it played at film festivals last month, and Warner Brothers has bought it for commercial distribution.
Understandably, officials of the city and the company are not pleased at the prospect that national movie audiences will be entertained at Flint's expense. From the reviews they've read, they say, the film sounds as if it offers a distorted picture of their hometown. The Mayor, Matthew S. Collier, believes a G.M.-bashing movie can only jeopardize efforts to persuade the auto maker to expand its activities. Still, the company did recently open a new engineering center here that will employ 1,500 on the site of an old Fisher body plant that hired 7,000 in its heyday and 3,300 when it closed in December 1987.
Mr. Collier's tack has been to rebut Mr. Moore's film by accentuating the positive aspects of the G.M. relationship. True, he concedes, the unemployment rate is high, 12 percent, virtually all of it accounted for by laid-off auto workers. But it is half the rate of a few years ago, when G.M. shut the Fisher and other plants. And while the crime rate is also bad, the Mayor said, it has been improving for almost two years.
''We've got six campuses, including a campus of the University of Michigan and over 23,000 students enrolled,'' the Mayor said. ''We've got some great assets. But we're looking for some niche. We're almost groping for it, quite candidly.''
For the moment, as short-term relief, Mr. Collier wants G.M. to attract automotive suppliers and allied automotive trades. For the longer term, ''I'm committed to diversification,'' he said. ''People shouldn't get the lackadaisical attitude that G.M. is always going to come back.''

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Changing World Implies Changes for the G.O.P.

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
It is beginning to dawn on many Republicans that the changing world order and a shifting public sentiment could spell major political problems for their party.
Republican electoral success over the last decade has been built on two basic promises: a strong defense against Soviet expansion abroad and reduced government to promote economic expansion at home. Both seem to be running out of steam as voting issues.
It is hard to fight the evil empire when the empire is quickly taking itself apart. Support for military spending is crumbling even faster than the Berlin Wall. That alone is causing Republicans a major readjustment - and internal divisions, as the Bush Administration tries to get ahead of public opinion and conservatives warn against making too many cuts too fast. 
But for all the political problems posed by the cold-war thaw, the economy threatens double trouble. If it stalls out, as many economists believe it is about to, President Bush and other Republican candidates will suffer. Meanwhile, even if the recovery goes on, political analysts and Republican poll takers see problems.
Voters have begun to take for granted basic stability, economic and geopolitical, and are looking now at problems that pound relentlessly at the quality of life in America: drugs, the compromising of the environment, the homeless, even the state of roads and bridges.
All this creates a new political playing field on which the Democrats should have better footing, if they can avoid tripping on their laces again.
Republicans say their Presidential administrations deserve credit for the disintegration of the Soviet empire and the longest economic recovery of the postwar period. Perhaps so. But they know, too, that voters don't reward past success so much as they weigh the chances of future fulfillment.
The point has not been missed at Republican headquarters or at the White House. Mr. Bush is moving with uncharacteristic swiftness to prepare cuts in the military budget. It is true that this will free billions of dollars for him to offer for domestic desires. But Democrats should have less trouble going toe to toe with Republicans on how to spend domestic dollars than they have had during the years when Pentagon spending was the top priority.
The trouncing of Republicans at the polls this month was at first attributed to bad candidates, bad campaigns and the power of a single issue, abortion, which came up suddenly in midseason. Now some Republicans are detecting deeper problems.
Kevin Phillips, a Republican analyst celebrating the 20th anniversary of his book ''The Emerging Republican Majority,'' says he thinks that the Republican coalition assembled two decades ago is coming unraveled, that the glue holding New York investment bankers in the same party as evangelical Christians in Texas is coming loose.
Mr. Phillips recognizes that it is dangerous to prognosticate from the scattered elections of an off-off year. Yet he sees an important trend. Republicans are misreading the 1988 election, he suggests: rather than gloating over their fifth victory in the last six Presidential contests, they should consider 1988 as an election ''they could have lost.''
And this month's defeats drove home the point. ''What the Nov. 7 returns do forecast,'' he said, ''is that some issues the Democrats harnessed in 1989 - from abortion to the environment - should be effective again next year, while the G.O.P.'s flag, crime and tax approach is showing signs of staleness.''
So a warning cry is beginning to go out. Vice President Dan Quayle told the Republican Governors Association last week that the party could no longer rely on its old issues for future success. A new message is needed, he said, one that says Republicans are ready to deal with the nation's social problems without resurrecting big government. His suggestion, prepared for delivery to the League of Cities next Monday: ''If we go to the 90's as an aggressive reform party, inspired by the principles of opportunity and responsibility, I think we'll become the majority Republican Party.''
That may or may not be the Republicans' new message. But they increasingly understand they need one.
