HEADLINE: NO RISE IS FOUND IN VOLUNTARISM

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Despite President Bush's emphasis on the ''thousand points of light'' and the community service they symbolize, the level of charitable giving and volunteering has not increased measureably, a new Gallup Poll shows.
''It may be too early to see a trend or the message may not be getting through to people,'' said Dr. Diane Colasanto, a sociologist who is senior vice president of the Gallup Organization.
But the Bush Administration says the public seems responsive to the President's appeal. ''Our sense in the Administration is there is an increase in the number of Americans willing and ready to respond to community needs by serving others,'' said Clark Ervin, associate director of policy for the White House Office of National Service. 
The President proposed the concept of community help in a campaign speech and developed it in his Inaugural Address, likening community organizations to ''a thousand points of light, spread like stars throughout the nation, doing good.'' Mr. Ervin said the White House plans to establish a ''Thousand Points of Light Foundation'' early in 1990 to encourage community service.
 
Slow Rise in Volunteers
The poll found that the level of voluntarism is about the same now as it was before the President took office. The 41 percent in the latest poll who said they were involved in ''charity or social service activities'' was statistically indistinguishable from the 39 percent measured by Gallup in December 1987.
The Gallup Organization began questioning Americans about their charitable habits 10 years ago. Polls since then showed the number of people working without pay in their communities has tended to increase gradually, Dr. Colasanto said. ''But we found no evidence of an increase since the poll two years ago.''
In the present poll, 1,230 people age 18 and older were questioned by telephone from Nov. 9 to Nov. 12 in a nationally representative sampling. The margin of sampling error for the poll was plus or minus three percentage points.
The report found 7 in 10 people said they contributed money to a charitable organization in the last 12 months and 6 in 10 gave money to their church that was earmarked for charitable activities. Seventy-four percent of those interviewed said they donated food, clothing or other property to organizations helping the needy.
Four in 10 reported they did unpaid volunteer work for charities in the last 12 months, with the average worker giving 6 hours in the past month. Eighty-four percent said they gave money, time or property directly to a person in need, not through an organization. About half said they helped a needy relative, neighbor or friend, and a third said they gave directly to a homeless person.
The Gallup survey found that people who attend churches or synagogues were more likely to be involved in charity. Non-whites were more likely to give personal assistance to needy people than whites.
 
Effort to Change Behavior
The responses on giving and volunteering are consistent with a poll also done by Gallup in March 1988 for the Independent Sector, the country's largest philanthropic coalition of foundations, corporations and nonprofit organizations. In 1987 the coalition began its ''Give Five Campaign'' to encourage Americans to contribute 5 percent of their income and five hours a week to volunteering.
In cities where early and intensive drives in the campaign have been conducted, there has been a substantial increase in giving and volunteering, said Virginia A. Hodgkinson, vice president for research for the Independent Sector. ''But giving and volunteering campaigns have to be seen as long-term undertakings,'' she said. ''You don't change behavior patterns quickly.''
According to recent polls in the Denver area, the first area to report on its progress, annual household donations to charitable causes increased from $715 in 1986, when the drive began, to $815 two years later. The level of volunteering did not change significantly, but 77 percent of Denver residents questioned in 1986 said they favored volunteering as against 91 percent this year.
Both the Independent Sector survey and the recent Gallup poll found a correlation between giving and volunteering: givers volunteer and volunteers are givers.
 
Women Give More Time
The new Gallup study concluded that women give more time and property to organized charities. Forty-five percent of the women interviewed said they were involved in some unpaid volunteer work in the last year, while only 38 percent of the men volunteered.
The implication for charities as more women join the labor force is that they will have to adjust their schedules to attract volunteers, Dr. Colasanto said. Many offices looking for volunteers have discovered they have to stay open evenings, she said.
More young people are also volunteering as some high schools and colleges require them to serve in the community.
''What we sense is a potential for people to increase giving,'' Dr. Colasanto said. ''Almost everyone is involved now and helping in many different ways, giving their time, money, food and clothing to people in need. A well-directed appeal should be able able to build on this commitment.''

HEADLINE: Hot Air and the White House Effect

 BODY:
Fearful that waste gases may alter the world's climate, European countries have proposed a deadline for limiting worldwide emissions of carbon dioxide. The Bush Administration was heavily criticized when it resisted that idea at a recent international conference. The criticism is partly deserved: despite President Bush's campaign pledges, Washington is still months away from developing a policy on global warming. 
But the White House has reason to hesitate. The computer models that predict global warming are still rudimentary. The President's science adviser, Allan Bromley, was chided when he said the models' predictions keep changing. But because of the vast economic consequences of setting a limit on carbon dioxide emissions, Dr. Bromley has a particular duty to keep the argument honest.
The forecasts of global warming will remain uncertain for several years. But there's every reason to take the greenhouse effect extremely seriously. Computer models aside, the earth's climate has been closely related to the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere over the last 60,000 years, as judged by ice cores from Antarctica.
Carbon dioxide is increasing steadily, and a warming effect seems inevitable at some stage. When proof of the warming finally arrives, the climate will already be locked into a significant temperature rise, one that could alter crop patterns and sea level. Washington should already be taking out insurance. Banning coal-fired electric plants would be a drastic remedy. But there are many actions to reduce carbon dioxide that are worth taking for other reasons. Chief among these reasons is the need to improve energy efficiency.
The United States still uses energy recklessly compared with Europe and Japan. In America, oil is very cheap; abroad, it is heavily taxed, inducing conservation. The fear of greenhouse warming alone might not yet justify a carbon-based tax or a tax on oil or gasoline, since such levies would curb economic growth. But there are other compelling arguments for such a tax.
A tax on gasoline, for example, would reduce dependence on foreign oil and the military costs associated with keeping the oil flowing. Each cent of a gas tax would produce about $1 billion in revenues, funds that could be used to reduce the Federal deficit.
The Administration's greenhouse insurance plan also ought to include incentives for forms of energy that don't produce carbon dioxide, like solar and a new generation of safe nuclear power plants. The Departments of Energy and Transportation are both working on energy policies, but separately and with no apparent sense of urgency.
''Those who think we're powerless to do anything about the 'greenhouse effect' are forgetting about the 'White House effect.' As President, I intend to do something about it.'' So said Mr. Bush during his campaign. Do what? ''In my first year in office, I will convene a global conference on the environment at the White House . . . We will talk about global warming . . . And we will act.''
Mr. Bush hasn't met, talked or acted. His environmental chief, William Reilly, gave a nod last week to the idea of a global conference. But nods and nonchalance will not redeem Mr. Bush's greenhouse pledge. A gas tax, if Mr. Bush could but reconsider his no-taxes pledge, would ease the deficit, enhance national security and buy serious insurance against the possibility of global warming.

HEADLINE: East German Change Owes No Thanks to Us

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In responding to the remarkable changes in East Germany, American politicians and news commentators have reveled in self-delusion and unwarranted self-congratulation. As a result, the American people have been shielded from a more genuine understanding of the events leading to the collapse of the Berlin Wall and beyond.
It is ironic and arrogant that the United States should claim credit for prompting East Germany's move toward democracy. But except for the positive United States participation in the 1971 four-power agreement on Berlin, the American impact on East Germany has been marginal. United States actions have more often served to retard than to advance the course of East German reform. 
Without exception, periods of United States bellicosity toward Central Europe have encouraged repressive measures against East Germans, interrupted the drive for economic progress and seriously undermined the fervent efforts of reform elements within the East German Communist Party. The reformers are winning -despite the many obstacles created by American intransigence.
For more than a decade, reformist ranks have been growing in East Germany. By the mid-1980's, a broad segment of responsible party members, leaders in many segments of public life, had created an agenda for reform. Mikhail S. Gorbachev's bold vision for the Soviet Union and his hopeful assessment of change in Hungary and Poland provided vital moral support. Yet it took the daring and spontaneous street demonstrations to sweep away the braking mechanism personified by Erich Honecker and his small clique of cold war veterans.
The changes under way may well be a victory for democracy. But since we can scarcely claim to own this notion, we cannot claim victory for America. Nor is it a victory for capitalism. East Germans know too well the dark side of capitalism, and they watch with dismay the careless Hungarian rush toward capitalism, with its surge of inequality, its bag ladies, its working-class husbands needing two jobs just to stay even with rising prices.
The new leaders and the people of East Germany have no intention of following Hungary, much less Poland or the Soviet Union. Nor do they intend to follow West Germany, much less the United States. There is a dogged self-assurance that leads East Germans to believe that they can chart a middle way. If there is a model to follow, it is Sweden - only a Sweden with a socialist, not a capitalist, foundation. An enlightened welfare state, with a peaceful and neutral role in world affairs.
We are witnessing the East German people's victory. Let us congratulate them, not further delude ourselves.
If there is one Western statesman who merits our acclaim and the gratitude of the East German people, it is not George Bush or Helmut Kohl -and certainly not Ronald Reagan. It is the courageous former Mayor of West Berlin, Willy Brandt. As the West German Foreign Minister in 1965 and as Chancellor in 1969, Brandt created the accommodating ''Eastern policy.''
Later known as ''transformation by drawing near,'' Brandt's policy relied less on threats and more on rewards and patience toward his East German counterparts. As a result, the Berlin Wall first cracked open in 1972, and contacts have grown ever since. The result was not to weaken East Germany, but to strengthen its most progressive internal forces.
It has been suggested that the Berlin Wall be preserved as a monument to the folly of Adolf Hitler and the folly of two generations of cold warriors. I see a Berlin Wall, with its gates flung open, as a fitting tribute to Willy Brandt.
 
BRADLEY SCHARF
 Seattle, Nov. 10, 1989
 
The writer is a professor of political science at Seattle University.

HEADLINE: It Was a Prosperous Summer on the Jersey Shore

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Business along the New Jersey shore rebounded sharply last summer after a slump in the previous two years caused by reports of medical waste on bathing beaches and garbage slicks floating offshore, a new study reports.
About 5.7 million people visited the shore between Memorial Day and Labor Day, slightly fewer than the six million who vacationed in 1987 but far more than the 4.8 million who showed up in 1988, when public confidence was at its lowest.
The study released by the state's Division of Travel and Tourism said vacationers spent $7.4 billion this year, a 37 percent increase over the $5.4 billion last year and higher than the $6.2 billion spent in 1987. The biggest increases were for rentals of rooms and for gifts and souvenirs. 
 
Back From the Dead
''We've come back further than we had any right to hope,'' Gov. Thomas H. Kean said. ''We can report the resuscitation of an area that many had given up for dead.''
The Governor said, however, that overdevelopment along the shore could bring a return of pollution problems, and he used a meeting with reporters in his office to call again for enactment of legislation to control growth along the beachfront.
''If we don't do something to control the construction of condominiums along the coast,'' Mr. Kean said, ''the future won't be as sunny as the present.''
The report of the shore's economic rebound was based on telephone interviews of 1,006 people conducted by the Opinion Research Corporation of Princeton between Sept. 6 and 19. The people interviewed live in New York, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, eastern Ohio and in New Jersey counties outside the shore area. The interviews were compared with similar surveys during the last two years.
Noreen Bodman, director of the Division of Travel and Tourism, said the study had revealed that Cape May, the state's southernmost resort, was the most popular destination for both season-long vacationers and overnight guests, while up the coast Atlantic City, with its casinos, was the greatest attraction for those who visited for just the day and returned home.
 
Decline in Overnight Guests
Of the 5.7 million visitors last summer, 1.1 million spent the full season, 2.5 million took trips that included at least one overnight trip, and 2.1 million took day trips. The number of season vacationers has remained fairly stable, while a decline in overnight guests that began two years ago continued. The number of day-trippers was up sharply over 1987, when there were 1.1 million, and exceeded the total in 1988, when there were 2.9 million.
Season rentals of rooms and houses accounted for $2 billion this year, compared with $1.2 billion last year; daily rentals totaled $2.7 billion, compared with $1.7 billion in 1988; boardwalk rides and attractions accounted for $658 million, compared with $453 million a year ago; gifts and souvenirs, $279 million, compared with $191 million; beach fees, which were rolled back in some areas because of pressure by the New Jersey Public Advocate, took in $33 million, compared with $43 million a year ago.
Visitors spent about the same over the last two summers on parking and transportation to the resorts, slightly more in restaurants and slightly less on nightlife. One big change was the amount of money spent on groceries -$495 million this summer, down from $657 million a year ago.
 
Increased Efforts Pay
Mr. Kean attributed the improvement in business to increased efforts this year to track medical waste, patrol offshore waters, clean trash from beaches with prison labor, test the water quality in bathing areas and publicity reflecting these efforts. Without the $3 million ad campaign that went on most of the summer, the results might not have been so good, the Governor said.
''It would be like winking at a girl in a darkened room,'' he said. ''You know what you're doing, but no one else does.''
Robert J. Hunter, the owner of the Clam Hut Restaurant in Highlands, was among a number of resort businessmen who came to the Capitol to learn the results of the study. ''The water along the shore is getting cleaner every year, and people aren't frightened anymore,'' he said. He added that the clean water had brought an unusual complaint from some fishermen who go offshore looking for tuna.
''They told me the water is so clear, the tuna can see their lures, and it's making it more difficult to catch them,'' he said.

HEADLINE: In New York, 4 Large Cities Are Growing a Little Smaller

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Upstate New York's four big cities - Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse and Albany - all showed population losses from 1980 to 1988, according to estimates released by state and Federal officials.
The big loser during the nine-year period was Buffalo, New York's second largest city. Estimated population declined 12.4 percent, from 357,870 to 313,570. 
The 1988 population estimate dropped Buffalo's rank in the list of the United States' most populous cities. In 1980, Buffalo was the 39th largest city; in 1970, it was the 28th largest city. Based on the 1988 estimate, it is now the 50th largest city, smaller than Newark, Omaha, Toledo, Ohio, and the resort city of Virginia Beach, Va.
The estimates also show that Albany dropped under the 100,000 population mark, that Rochester's population losses were recent and that Syracuse's population is down while surrounding Onondaga County's is not.
 
'Still Feeling Difficult Times'
The figures, which are based on births, deaths, tax returns and immigration statistics, were released this week by the United States Census Bureau.
According to Bob Scardamalia, chief demographer for the State Department of Economic Development, the figures show that Buffalo is still recovering from an economic downturn in the 1970's and early 1980's.
''Some areas of the economy have turned the corner from a total reliance on manufacturing, but clearly, it's still in a difficult state,'' he said.
Erie County, which includes Buffalo, also showed a population drop, from 1,015,472 in 1980 to an estimated 958,700 in 1988. ''There is a segment of Erie County - Amherst particularly - that is showing growth, but in general, the rest of the county is still feeling difficult times,'' Mr. Scardamalia said.
 
Onondaga County Stable
Rochester was the 49th largest city in the United States in 1970, with 295,011 people. Its rank dropped to 57th in 1980, with 241,741 people, and to 66th in 1988, with 229,780 people.
Mr. Scardamalia said the estimates show that in 1984, Rochester actually had slightly more people than in 1980, 242,560 compared with 241,741.
Syracuse was the 66th largest city in the country in 1970, with a population of 197,297. In 1980, its rank was 86th and its population 170,105. According to the 1988 estimates, the city's rank is down to 109th and its population is 153,610.
The population in surrounding Onondaga County, however, has been relatively stable throughout the 1980's, according to Mr. Scardamalia. The county's population in 1980 was 463,920; the 1988 estimate is 461,500.
Albany is not on the Census Bureau's most recent ranking of cities with populations of more than 100,000. Mr. Scardamalia said Albany met the criterion in the 1980 census, with 101,727 people. In 1988, however, the estimate is 94,450.

HEADLINE: LAW;
Computer Graphics Aiding Jurors' Recall

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Jurors hearing a lawsuit over the supposed merits of a new dog food were recently taken, via three-dimensional computer animation, on a journey inside a Labrador retriever's leg to see how its muscles, bones and joints function.
Once the preserve of advertising agencies and science-fiction movies, such visual aids are increasingly being used in the courtroom as exhibits in cases from airplane crashes to medical malpractice.
In the suit involving dog food, Alpo Pet Foods, part of Grand Metropolitan Inc., took issue with advertising by the Ralston Purina Company asserting that its puppy chow could lessen the severity of a potentially crippling hip ailment. Alpo, which contended that the advertising was false, presented colorful graphics to show the jury that the illness could occur anyway. Several veterinarians and radiologists also testified at the trial. The jury later awarded Alpo $10.4 million in damages, and Ralston Purina has appealed. 
Clear, simple graphics help jurors, who typically retain only 10 percent of what they hear, to increase recall by nearly 10 percentage points, said Gregory J. Mazares, the president of the graphics unit of Litigation Sciences Inc. in Los Angeles, which produced the puppy chow videotape.
 
Seeing Is Really Believing
''We're a switched-on, tuned-in, visually-oriented society, and jurors tend to believe what they see,'' Mr. Mazares said. ''This technology keeps the jury's attention by simplifying the material and by giving them little bursts of information.''
Industry officials, including Mr. Mazares, acknowledge that these ''little bursts of information'' are highly selective and possibly manipulative.
''We're looking to develop a complete graphics strategy that will focus the jury precisely on the facts and arguments on which we want them to base their verdict,'' Mr. Mazares said.
Critics warn that such slick packages raise issues precisely because of their effectiveness and the high cost of production, which makes them virtually inaccessible to poorer litigants. The price tag for three-dimensional productions runs from $10,000 for a simple 30-second exhibit to $250,000 for a complex 45-minute piece.
 
Advantage to the Rich
''High-tech computer exhibits may cause a jury to be persuaded for the wrong reasons - because the graphics are colorful or entertaining, and not because the facts are convincing,'' said William J. Genego, a professor at the University of Southern California Law School. ''Moreover, access to this technology may be dependent on someone's economic resources, so they allow only those with the bigger budgets to make use of them.''
The most expensive computer animations involve recreations of airplane crashes, which Forensic Technologies International, a San Francisco-based company, specializes in. ''It's a very powerful tool in the courtroom because it can clearly show a very complicated case in a very short period of time,'' said Marjorie E. Weingrow, an engineering manager with Forensic Technologies.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
Japan's business and Government leaders are reassessing their strategy for investing overseas. They are fearful of an American reaction to a recent surge of acquisitions and worry that the door to the U.S. market may be closing. [Page A1.]
The U.S. said 99 Japanese construction companies had agreed to pay $32.6 million to settle accusations that they rigged bids on projects at a Navy base. It was the first time the U.S. has successfully struck back against the ''dango'' system, in which construction companies consult in secret before submitting bids. [D1.] 
The award of a Japanese computer chip patent to Texas Instruments is probably not a sign that the patent system will be streamlined, experts say. U.S. companies have contended that the sluggish Japanese system is rigged against them. [D1.]
Debt-reduction talks with Venezuela could turn out to be the most difficult to date under the so-called Brady Plan. Many bankers contend that in contrast to the three countries that have completed debt agreements, Venezuela does not need significant debt reduction or much assistance. As evidence, they cite the state-owned oil company's recent agreement to buy half of Citgo Petroleum for $675 million. [D1.]
The president of Argentina's central bank resigned. Javier Gonzalez Fraga cited differences over policy with Economy Minister Nestor Rapanelli and said a two-time former central bank president, Egidio Ianella, would replace him. [D6.]
Britain's foreign trade deficit narrowed last month, easing pressure on Prime Minister Thatcher. The small drop was greeted with cautious optimism in London's financial markets. [D2.]
OPEC officials predicted that demand for the group's oil would average 21.5 million barrels a day next year, well under the members' current level of production. [D4.] Canada is inviting petroleum companies to explore for oil in the Arctic Ocean for the first time in nearly two decades. [D4.]
Chinese banks will lend $27 billion to state-operated enterprises that need cash, although the Government's tight credit policy will remain in effect, a central bank official said. [D4.]
 
 
 
Companies
Eastern's flight attendants were told to return to work by union leaders, a day after the pilots' union abandoned its nearly nine-month-old walkout. When the House and the Senate adjourned early Wednesday, they left behind a formidable agenda of unfinished business to take up after they reconvene on Jan. 23. The remaining issues range from child care to the Clean Air Act to the more fundamental deficit reduction that many lawmakers had hoped for this year. [A1.]
The deficit-reduction package approved by Congress is built around $8 billion in measures that will raise several taxes. [D2.]

HEADLINE: Thinking Long Term Is Costly to Caterpillar

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill.

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc., the nation's largest producer of earthmoving machinery, is learning that the costs of international competitiveness are high: $1.5 billion, ill will on Wall Street and a few dollars off its stock price.
Trying to fend off increasing competition from overseas rivals, led by Komatsu Ltd. of Japan, Caterpillar began a six-year modernization program in 1986. With the $1.5 billion plan, the company aims to reduce production costs by one fifth at 32 factories that make its bright-yellow bulldozers and other equipment.
But recently, estimates of the cost of the program have been revised upward and the time required for it to pay off has lengthened. In response, Wall Street analysts have scaled back their earnings estimates and Caterpillar's stock has dropped, closing at $58.25 a share on Wednesday, well below its 52-week high of $69. 
''At this point, no one is challenging Cat's strategic initiative to become a world-class manufacturer,'' said Eli Lustgarten, the heavy-equipment analyst at Paine Webber Inc. ''But we are finding out just how expensive that is to do.''
George A. Schaefer, Caterpillar's chairman and chief executive, brushes aside such concerns of Wall Street analysts. It ''doesn't bother us a bit, because we are absolutely convinced of the payoff in the long term,'' Mr. Schaefer said in an interview at the company's headquarters here. ''We have to play the long-term game because the competition is playing the long-term game.''
Indeed, some industry veterans say Caterpillar's experience is a classic confrontation between Wall Street's often-criticized fixation with short-term profits versus the need for American corporations to make long-term investments.
 
Response to 'Global Realities'
''Seeing an American company like this respond to global realities is pleasing,'' said Kirk Landers, editor of Construction Equipment, a trade journal. ''So I sure hope Cat is not pressured into producing short-term results.''
Yet the issue seems more complicated than a choice between profits today or competitiveness tomorrow. Analysts do not criticize Caterpillar's strategy, but there are doubts about how successful the company will be in executing its plan. And Caterpillar may face difficulties in the future, even if the cost-cutting modernization program works: Not only is the economy weakening, but a structural change in the demand for earth-moving equipment is underway.
Reduced demand from oil-rich Middle East countries, debt-burdened third world nations and a budget-minded American Government have trimmed the worldwide market for Caterpillar's bread-and-butter products - the mammoth earth-moving machines used in mining, road building and construction of dams, bridges and other large public works.
The action now is in smaller equipment, like the backhoe loaders used by independent home builders. Caterpillar has added the smaller machines to its product line, but they are less profitable. And even if demand for the big machines picks up, the stiffer foreign competition means continuing pressure on profit margins.
''Most people whom you talk to in this industry say you will never see the same type of demand in terms of product mix and, therefore, in terms of profit,'' said Frank Manfredi, an industry consultant based in Buffalo Grove, Ill., outside Chicago. ''You might see the same level of revenues, but never the same level of profits.''
The prospect of a permanently tougher market, company executives say, gives added urgency to Caterpillar's modernization program, known formally as the Plant With a Future project. It includes installing flexible machine tools that can produce a variety of parts; not just for bulldozers but for excavators, off-highway trucks and other earth-moving gear.
New inventory systems are also being introduced to trim the cost of materials. Machines that cut, bore and remove burrs from metal are being grouped so one worker can produce an entire part. And plant layouts are being revised to place related processes together.
 
Champion of Survival Strategy
The program is the survival strategy championed by Mr. Schaefer, a 61-year-old former accountant who has spent almost his entire career at Caterpillar. He became chief executive in 1985, one year before the modernization drive began.
Caterpillar learned about the need for global competitiveness the hard way. In the early 1980's, when the strong dollar made imports cheaper, Komatsu and other foreign manufacturers grabbed footholds in the United States market and took sales from Caterpillar overseas as well. In 1984, Caterpillar lost $428 million on sales of $6.6 billion.
Since then, the dollar has weakened and Caterpillar has been streamlined drastically, enabling it to recover. Last year, the company reported earnings of $616 million on revenues of $10.4 billion. But the recent improvement has not reduced Mr. Schaefer's belief that Caterpillar must become a lower-cost and more efficient producer if it is to weather the global competition and currency swings of the future.
If the modernization is successful, he said, ''we can stay ahead of the competition and be effective in either a weak-dollar or a strong-dollar environment.''
Wall Street analysts like that idea; they just do not like the price. Zacks Investment Research, a New York firm that tracks analyst sentiment, reported recently that most analysts expect Caterpillar to earn about $5.79 a share this year, down from the $5.81 a share estimated in a survey one month earlier. That was down from $6.28 a share that the analysts were predicting in a survey 12 weeks before that, and from $6.35 a share in a survey 13 weeks before that. As the estimates have fallen, so too has the company's stock price.
The company has also sent different signals to analysts about the costs and benefits of the modernization. A year and a half ago, for instance, Pierre C. Guerindon, a Caterpillar executive vice president who heads the Plant With a Future, or P.W.A.F., program, told analysts that the program would cost $1.1 billion. He has since raised that to almost $1.5 billion.
He has also increased his estimate of the annual start-up costs associated with the program from $100 million more than a year ago, to $150 million last summer, and to $200 million in a recent interview. In that interview, Mr. Guerindon also pushed back, to the end of 1990, the time when the program's benefits would begin to exceed its costs.
''We have lost a little ground but not much, and the promise of P.W.A.F. is still quite good,'' Mr. Guerindon said. ''On balance, it is still a very, very attractive proposal.''
The plan could add a huge amount to Caterpillar's financial results. On $10.4 billion in sales last year, Caterpillar reported manufacturing costs of just over $8 billion. Mr. Guerindon figures that modernization can cut that by nearly $1.6 billion, or 20 percent, which would flow directly to the company's bottom line. Such cost-cutting is crucial because Caterpillar's rival, Komatsu, has comparable manufacturing costs and is working hard to reduce them.
But to achieve that, Caterpillar is having to overhaul virtually every square foot of its 32 factories. And it is having to do so while maintaining production. The job, company officials say, is roughly equivalent to continuing to live in a house while it is being completely renovated.
Through careful planning, Caterpillar appears to be pulling it off. At a transmission factory in East Peoria, Ill., for instance, construction contractors are installing electrical lines and plumbing for new computer-controlled machine tools while, just a few feet away, Caterpillar employees are still using their old manually operated machine tools.
One result of such changes has been a sharp reduction in the number of unassembled parts that sit on the floor, in some cases, for weeks.
At one plant, production time on certain parts has been cut to five days from five months. That has enabled Caterpillar to have less finished inventory of these parts: two weeks' worth versus three months' worth.
''That's where the value is,'' said G. Kenneth Dawson, the plant's engineering manager.

HEADLINE: Attendants Halt Strike At Eastern

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The leaders of the flight attendants' union at Eastern Airlines told the members yesterday to return to work, a day after the pilots' union abandoned its nearly nine-month walkout.
That leaves only the machinists union on the picket lines in what has become the nation's longest strike at a major airline.
While the decisions by the pilots and flight attendants to end their strikes seem to be a victory for Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, which owns Eastern and Continental Airlines, there is no certainty that Eastern will recover and flourish.
 
Competitive Advantage
On the plus side, should Eastern survive it would have a younger and lower-paid work force than many airlines, giving it a competitive advantage. Only America West Airlines, Midway Airlines and Continental would have lower costs than the new Eastern, said John V. Pincavage, a partner of the Transportation Group, a small investment banking firm specializing in airlines. 
But the strike has sullied Eastern's image for customer service and imposed $400 million in extra costs on an airline that was already losing money heavily. The strike also resulted in Eastern seeking the protection of the Federal Bankruptcy Court. As part of its reorganization, Eastern has sold some valuable assets, including its Boston-New York-Washington shuttle and its operations in Philadelphia.
''I don't think there are any real victors,'' Mr. Pincavage said. ''Both sides had the ability to hurt each other a lot.''
The machinists struck on March 4 after they rejected demands by Texas Air that they agree to $150 million in concessions on wages and work rules. The pilots and flight attendants struck in sympathy. Five days later, Eastern filed for bankruptcy.
The airline has said it expects to emerge from bankruptcy early next year at 80 to 90 percent of its former size. But it says it has no immediate need for the returning strikers.
Eastern has hired nonunion replacements, who work longer hours and for lower pay. And because they are new, they have earned no vacation time.
The airline says it will place the returning workers on a preferential recall list and not pay them until jobs become available.
Eastern, whose schedule was crippled when the strike began, is now flying about three-quarters of the flights it did before the strike.
 
Bush's Veto
The pilots and flight attendants decided to return to work after President Bush, on Tuesday, vetoed a bill that would have created a bipartisan commission to investigate the dispute at Eastern. In his veto message, Mr. Bush said the Government should not interfere in a labor-management dispute.
The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents 8,500 machinists, baggage handlers and other ground workers at Eastern, vowed to remain on strike at least until early next year, when Congress returns from its recess. The union said it would lobby to have the veto overturned.
Eastern is also negotiating to sell its Latin American routes and a few other assets to American Airlines. After breaking off in August, the talks resumed nearly three weeks ago, as American agreed to drop its demand that Continental abandon a $1 billion lawsuit against American, a person involved in the negotiations said. The suit contends that the computerized reservation system that American offers to travel agents lists other carriers' flights unfairly.
 
Not the First Time
Th Eastern bankruptcy filing was not the first time that an airline controlled by Mr. Lorenzo has sought such protection.
In 1983, he placed Continental Airlines under bankruptcy protection, and was able to cancel the airline's union contracts and later hire back the striking employees at much lower pay.
Mr. Lorenzo was able to rebuild Continental by cutting fares because other carriers were slow to respond with fare cuts of their own.
But Continental has not posted profits, said George W. James, the president of Airline Economics, a consulting firm in Washington, in part because many flyers have viewed its service as inferior since the strike. Eastern now shares that image, Mr. James said.
And Eastern's rivals have aggressively countered the airlines efforts to win back customers as it has gradually resumed its flights.
Changes in the Federal Bankruptcy Code have prevented Mr. Lorenzo from canceling the contracts of Eastern's pilots and flight attendants. But Eastern's management was able to cancel the machinists' contract because the National Mediation Board declared an impasse in February in the negotiations and a 30-day cooling-off period ended without the two sides reaching an agreement.
 
Pilots' Advantages
Because they still have a contract, striking pilots who resume flying at Eastern will have full seniority and salaries that averages $72,000 a year. But Eastern has replaced half the pilots with new people who, although covered by the union contract, make $27,500 a year because they have no seniority.
Eastern is also paying its new flight attendants $1,110 a month compared with the $2,300 earned by the average attendant before the strike. And it has cut the pay of baggage handlers and other unskilled ground personnel by more than 60 percent, to $6 an hour from $15.60.
Eastern said the return of the flight attendants and pilots would make little difference because it already had enough employees.
''If this had happened three or four months ago it would have been cause for rejoicing, but the course is pretty much set now,'' said Jim Ashlock, an Eastern spokesman.
 
Strike Ended in Tears
For many striking employees, a labor action that began with euphoria and unity ended in tears. ''I got a real knot in my stomach and swelled with emotion and cried,'' upon learning of the Presidential veto, said Donna Feldman-Carboni, an Eastern flight attendant with 17 years of seniority.
The biggest questions, company and union officials agreed, concern how many jobs will be left for the striking employees and who will fill them. About 870 of the 3,600 striking Eastern pilots and 1,600 of the 6,000 striking flight attendants crossed picket lines before their union leaders voted the return to work, a person close to the company said. They have joined about 800 newly hired pilots and 1,600 new flight attendants.
Eastern also has 200 more pilots and 250 more flight attendants in training and has asked a Federal judge in Miami to rule whether the trainees can become permanent employees.
The Air Line Pilots Association has said that under the Railway Labor Act the trainees should be dismissed because they have not begun flying passengers - the standard for dismissal established in some other lawsuits.
 
Question of Seniority
Yet even if Eastern does dismiss the trainees there will be many more returning strikers than job openings. The pilots' union and the Transport Workers Union, which represents the flight attendants, have argued that the jobs available should be awarded on the basis of seniority, while a person close to Eastern said the company would seek to hire back only those employees, particularly pilots, already experienced in certain types of aircraft.
In addition to their dismay with President Bush's veto, the pilots' leadership had other reasons for asking their members to return to work, said pilots' union and Eastern officials who asked not to be identified.
Among them were doubts that the pilots' union members would vote to continue strike benefits at Eastern. In the last referendum, a continuation of benefits was approved by 54 percent of the members voting.
The other reason was that Wednesday was the deadline for pilots to bid for new flight assignments that begin on March 3, two Eastern pilots said. The leadership was concerned that if the return to work was not ordered, more pilots might cross the picket lines to insure that they would fly choice flights at convenient times instead of difficult schedules that would keep them away from their families. HEADLINE: Venezuela's Offer for Citgo Gives Bankers Indigestion

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
When Venezuela's state-owned oil company announced this month that it would spend $675 million to purchase the 50 percent of the Citgo Petroleum Corporation that it does not already own, the announcement got the attention of more than the oil industry.
Venezuela's bankers, to whom the country owes more than $21 billion, were stunned. Here, in the midst of already difficult negotiations with a Government pushing for significant debt reduction, it suddenly appears that that same Government can afford to spend more than half a billion dollars for an oil company. And no banker failed to note that the $675 million price tag was just a little more than the $600 miilion interim loan the bankers granted Venezuela at the end of September.
 
Good Deal, Bad Timing
''The timing was horrendous,'' said one banker involved in the negotiations, although he acknowledged that the deal itself was not a bad idea. 
Venezuela is the fourth country to go to the negotiating table under the Bush Administration's new third world debt strategy known as the Brady plan for its author, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. The strategy emphasizes debt reduction as a way to deal with the developing world's $1.3 trillion debt burden.
These negotiations could turn out to be the most difficult to date and will test the commitment of the Bush Administration, the flexibility of the commercial banks and the savvy of the Venezuelans.
 
Need for Debt Cut Questioned
A big difference in the Venezuelan negotiations from those completed with Mexico, the Philippines and Costa Rica, is that many of the bankers involved really do not think Venezuela needs significant debt reduction or much assistance. Venezuela disagrees.
''We still have to convince them of the need,'' Miguel Rodriguez, the minister in charge of the negotiating team, said in an interview in September, acknowledging the difficult job he faced.
While bankers felt pressure by the United States and other Governments in the Mexican negotiations, there was, nevertheless, a financial argument bankers could acknowledge. But in Venezuela's case, many bankers argue that the only claim for debt reduction is political: The new Government of Carlos Andres Perez needs to win an important victory to back its economic reform program, and the Bush Administration put Venezuela on the list of Brady plan candidates after riots rocked the country last February, killing 300 people.
 
Political Need Noted
''From a financial point of view Venezuela does not have a financial need,'' said a banker deeply involved in the negotiations. ''But politically it does.''
Any successful agreement, bankers said, will require a new approach, although it may borrow ideas from several of the pacts already negotiated. What needs to be worked out, one banker said, is a proposal that bridges both the dispute over Venezuela's needs and the differences among the banks over new loans versus debt reduction and the levels that are fair. The bankers admit they are still looking for the solution.
Most likely, this solution will mean a much broader range of options for debt reduction and new loans than in the Mexican agreement. These options may include regular buybacks of Venezulean debt offered voluntarily to the banks - a feature not in the Mexican plan. In addition, any set level or levels of debt reduction may be tied to a sliding level of guarantees to make larger debt reduction more attractive. These guarantees would give banks more choice but may make the outcome for Venezuela less certain.
 
Angry Bankers
''It is clear that a country like Venezuela wants, at the least, what Mexico got, and that is what is infuriating the banks,'' said another banker. The banks agreed to accept a 35 percent reduction in the value of Mexico's existing debt, through either a reduction in principal or a cut in interest rates. The third option was for new loans equal to 25 percent of a bank's current exposure.
In addition, a lot of bankers, having curbed their emotional dislike of the Brady plan in Mexico's case, are now likely to unleash their anger in the Venezuelan talks.
Several bankers said they feel that they were not consulted as the Brady plan was developed, and they are annoyed because they believe the Mexican debt reduction was mandatory for the banks, not voluntary.
 
Philippine Deal Cited
''Somehow the debt reduction element in the Mexican plan is not really voluntary, but the buyback in the Philippines is,'' said one American official supporting the Venezuelans, who asked not to be identified. He was referring to the Philippine negotiation in which no debt reduction level was set. Instead the Philippine Government offered to buy back the bank loans at 50 percent of value.
And the bankers argue that the banks and their stockholders are being asked to make the sacrifice needed for a policy that has insufficient Government support. Government loans to debtor nations have not been subject to debt reduction, and that really irks them. Also, some major banks have significantly increased their reserves for losses on third world loans, a move that can make them tougher at the negotiating table.
''There is anger,'' one banker said. ''It is very heavily emotional. The conclusion will clearly be impacted by all this. I am not sure what we will do for Venezuela.''
 
Shifts by Venezuelan
For its part, Venezuela has been working - the Citgo episode aside -to smooth the way to a settlement, despite the apparent tensions. In a striking move in September, the Government dropped its demand for 50 percent debt reduction alone and shifted to a menu of debt reduction and options for new money that should be more palatable to the banks.
This menu includes a range of options that offer more attractive guarantees of interest and principal in exchange for more debt reduction.
At the same time, the bankers finally agreed on the $600 million interim loan, which Venezuela used, along with some of its own reseves, to catch up on its interest rate payments to the banks, a move that pleased the bankers.
 
Reform Program Pursued
Mr. Perez has also continued to pursue his economic reform program, which is aimed at opening the economy and includes changes in trade practices and the privatizing of some state-owned businesses.
Some bankers see some progress. ''I say there is a change toward a better perception of reality on the part of the Venezuelans,'' one banker said.
But, at the same time, he added, there continue to be troublesome splits among the banks about Venezuela's needs and what should be offered in any package. Some of the banks, bankers said, are ready to do some debt reduction but some are not.
 
Differing Bank Goals
More importantly, some banks are willing to negotiate a package that sets some levels for debt reduction and new loans. But other banks want more flexibility. Some want an agreement that waives the existing clauses that prevent Venezuela from making separate individual deals with banks.
Another banker minimized the divisions among the banks, noting that they always seemed to be sharply divided at the beginning of a negotiation and then moved closer together.
One official said that since September the bankers had appeared to move closer to agreeing that Venezuela needs some long-term assistance but that they are still about $600 million short of Venezuela's estimates.
 
Venezuela's Projections
The Venezuelans, with the backing of economists at the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, maintain that they need about $1 billion a year in relief through the mid-1990's.
One banker characterized Venezuela's projections as politically, rather than economically, necessary. He argued that the country wanted the larger amount of assistance so that it could grow well economically in the 1990's. This year the economy is projected to decline by 5 percent to 10 percent, partially because of the Government's economic policy changes.
''The banks' view is that Venezuela should be happy with zero or negative economic growth for the next few years,'' countered an American official who supports Venezuela's position in the negotiations.

LENGTH: 716 words

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A Master Plan For Military Cuts

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE Bush Administration's decision to start planning for deeper cuts in military spending has come partly in response to dramatic changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe and partly as a result of domestic budgetary and economic pressures.
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's order to the military chiefs to submit plans to cut $180 billion from the budget for 1992 through 1994 came as an enormous surprise to all three services and was, as one military analyst put it, ''a culture shock of the first order.''
Mr. Cheney was under pressure from President Bush and the director of the Office of Management and Budget, Richard G. Darman, to come up with a plan to scale back military expenditures. The President had accepted Mr. Darman's argument that military spending provides the only big ''pot of money'' for reducing the budget deficit without steep increases in taxes. 
Mr. Darman, analysts close to the budget office said, is seeking bigger cuts than Mr. Cheney and the service chiefs would prefer. It is not clear how deep cuts will be, and in what areas of weapons, personnel, research, development testing and evaluation, and in operations and maintenance, they will be distributed.
But officials at the Office of Management and Budget say they have scrutinized the strategic plan for cutting military spending prepared by William W. Kaufmann for the Brookings Institution, and they say it falls within the O.M.B.'s range, but ''at the low end of our scale.'' The Kaufmann plan calls for cutting military spending, which is set to run at an annual rate of $300 billion in the fiscal year 1990, in three stages: to $265 billion in 1994; to $251 billion in 1997, and to a range of $195 billion to $160 billion in 1999, all measured in constant 1990 dollars.
The first stage of the Kaufmann plan would ''halt the rush to produce a next generation of weapons now in the acquisition process'' at a cumulative saving of more than $117 billion. It would also delete $48 billion in cumulative growth planned by the Bush Administration for 1990 to 1994.
The original Bush plan called for an annual growth rate in military spending of 1 to 2 percent above the inflation rate; the proposal announced by Mr. Cheney last week is described by other Government officials as calling for a real reduction of 5 percent a year between 1992 and 1994.
The second stage of the Kaufmann plan might overlap the first; former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara has urged acceleration of the second stage. It would stem from a successful completion of treaties to reduce strategic and conventional forces in Europe. The third stage of the Kaufmann plan can, he says, be visualized for the end of the century. It would include reduction of strategic offensive forces by both the Soviet Union and United States, cuts in conventional forces on both sides and a trading-off of American carrier battle groups for Soviet nuclear attack submarines.
While the stock prices of many military producers dropped sharply in reaction to news of Mr. Cheney's proposal to cut spending, most American economists consider the cuts likely to strengthen the economy by reducing interest rates, stimulating real investment in plants and equipment and in research and development, and by increasing the growth of American productivity. The shrinkage of the budget deficit would also be likely to strengthen the nation's foreign trade position.
In preparation for his coming summit conference with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the waters near Malta next month, President Bush is moving to take advantage of the opportunities presented by the Soviet reduction in military spending and the reduced tensions in Eastern Europe.
The threatened economic collapse of the Soviet Union, which lies behind the Gorbachev arms reductions, creates significant military and economic gains for the United States.
If arms control agreements can be reached with the Soviet Union, they will offer a way to reduce a good part of the cost and dangers of sustaining a military balance in Europe and easing the economic burdens on this country. But they will not, in the near future, eliminate either the need for such a balance or the need for the European countries to assume a greater responsibility for sustaining that balance.

HEADLINE: OPEC Expects Demand to Fall Short

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: VIENNA, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Officials of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries predicted today that demand for the organization's oil would average 21.5 million barrels a day next year, well under its current level of production.
Subroto, the Secretary General of OPEC, released the forecast after a special monitoring panel met.
Ministers of OPEC's 13 member nations agreed to meet privately on Friday before opening OPEC's winter conference on Saturday morning. 
The ministers will try to come up with a new arrangement that will halt cheating on production quotas and keep crude oil prices firm.
With higher output in Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia, OPEC produced nearly 23.5 million barrels of crude a day last month, analysts have estimated.
That is considerably higher than the fourth-quarter ceiling of 20.5 million barrels a day that it agreed to.
Despite the surge, prices have been fairly strong.
Dr. Subroto said the average price of crude oils monitored by OPEC was $17.16 a barrel from January through the third week of October, when it reached $17.76. OPEC's target price is $18 a barrel. A year ago, the same crude oil averaged $12.34.
Futures prices for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark American crude, have been running about $20 a barrel.
Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates have been cheating openly, pumping as much as double their individual quotas of about a million barrels a day, analysts said.
Saudi Arabia, OPEC's biggest producer and the world's largest exporter of crude, recently joined in the overproduction, a move seen by analysts as a negotiating ploy before the talks.
At a September meeting, Iran offered a proposal to cover the demands of Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates. The plan received considerable attention but failed to gain quick approval by all nations.
In his economic report, Dr. Subroto said OPEC expected an increase in world economic growth of 3 percent next year, a bit under the 3.3 percent pace of 1989.
Total demand for oil - excluding such centrally planned economies as the Soviet Union - was estimated at 51.8 million barrels a day in 1990, up from 50.9 million barrels this year.
Once the ministers set a production ceiling, they will have to divide the total among member nations.
Iran's September plan called for lifting the overall ceiling to 21.5 million barrels a day to meet the demands of Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates for larger shares of the total. Gabon and Ecuador would also get more.

HEADLINE: Argentine Bank Head Quits

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 23

 BODY:
The president of Argentina's central bank, Javier Gonzalez Fraga, resigned today, citing differences over policy with Nestor Rapanelli, the Economy Minister.
Mr. Fraga said President Carlos Saul Menem would replace him with Egidio Ianella, 68 years old, a two-time former president of the central bank now working in the private sector. 
''I am convinced that an economic team must be homogeneous,'' Mr. Fraga told reporters shortly after his resignation was accepted. ''If the central bank is not independent to set monetary and exchange policies, it makes no sense.''
Argentina's currency market had operated nervously in the last two weeks amid reports of a rift between Mr. Fraga and the economic team of Mr. Rapanelli, currency dealers said.
Argentina's currency, the austral, has lost more than a quarter of its value against the United States dollar this month in the unofficial exchange market. Today, it fell 5.2 percent, to close at 965 australs to the dollar. It had opened at 915.
Mr. Fraga was a critic of Mr. Rapanelli's policy of keeping an official exchange rate fixed at 652.5 australs to the dollar. He said that on Tuesday he had proposed to Mr. Menem an alternative program suggesting a free exchange market, but that it had been rejected.

HEADLINE: SCI Debt Extension

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: DENVER, Nov. 23

 BODY:
The investor George N. Gillett Jr. has been forced to extend the restructuring of $507 million in high-yield ''junk bonds'' for SCI Television Inc. because of a weak response from Wall Street, the company and investors said Wednesday.
SCI said that almost none of its bondholders had agreed to an exchange of their high-interest debt for a nonvoting stake in the company. If all bondholders agreed the size of their stake would total 39 percent.
The company said investors holding $37,000 of the $507 million in debt had agreed to Gillett's offer. SCI extended the deadline until Dec. 4 and said further extensions were possible. The company is continuing talks with a bondholders' committee and other debt holders.
If the restructuring fails, Gillett Holdings Inc., which owns 55 percent of SCI, could forfeit its $100 million investment in the company, which it owns with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the New York buyout firm.
SCI owns television stations WSBK in Boston, WJBK in Detroit, WJW in Cleveland, WITI in Milwaukee, KNSD in San Diego and WAGA in Atlanta.
Mr. Gillett, who also owns two ski resorts, had proposed extending some loans and cutting the interest rates on publicly traded SCI bonds in exchange for the nonvoting stake in the company, but bondholders have said they want more equity and faster repayments.
Last week, three SCI bondholders filed an involuntary bankruptcy petition against SCI at the end of a 30-day grace period after Mr. Gillett failed to meet an Oct. 15 interest payment.
A Chapter 7 bankruptcy petition would require the company to sell assets to satisfy creditors. The company has 20 days to respond to the petition.

LENGTH: 491 words

HEADLINE: A Capital Idea for Eastern Europe

 BODY:
Westerners are exhilarated by the drama of Eastern Europe but puzzled about how to help. The West cannot alter the fact that it's Eastern Europe's job to break the chains of centralized control and to wean consumers from subsidized prices and producers from guaranteed sales. But the West can ease this painful process and modestly improve the chances for success. 
An idea proposed last week by France's President, Francois Mitterrand, deserves support. He wants Western Europe to create a development bank that would extend loans and other financial assistance to Eastern Europe in exchange for democratic reforms. A detailed plan will be drawn up in time for the European Community summit meeting in Strasbourg next month.
Teh idea is for Western European governments to contribute capital that could be loaned directly for modernization projects. Even better, the bank could use the capital as the basis for borrowing vastly larger amounts from international markets, thereby making even greater funds available to Eastern Europe.
The bank would make little impact unless the U.S. and Japan participated. Felix Rohatyn, the New York investment banker, estimates that such cooperation could create an investment pool of $15 billion even if no single country contributed more than $1 billion. He offers a tantalizing prospect. Capital-starved Eastern Europe gets desperately needed funds; yet no Western country risks very much. The money could be for public or private projects, perhaps at below-market interestrates.
Skeptics will ask why Western governments need to be involved at all. Won't attractive investment projects in Eastern Europe lure private money? Mr. Rohatyn has a shrewd response. Hungary, Poland and East Germany have little experience with copyright, patent or other protections for private foreign investment. The proposed development bank would centralize the task of negotiating adequate safeguards, thereby eliminating cost and risk for everyone.
A development bank would solve one other important problem. Normally, East European countries would be forced to compete against one another for Western loans. That might maximize the West's profit. But it could deny funds that individual countries need to preserve their fragile experiments with political democracy and economic reform. A centralized development bank could help target assistance to the most needy.
Eastern Europe will need more than development loans. Debt relief and subsidies will also be required. Nor can the West be sure that its loans won't be squandered. Where markets are primitive or nonexistent, the task of discriminating productive from wasteful investment can be herculean. Witness the investment fiascoes in Latin America and Poland during the 1970's.
Yet the creation of a development bank is a wise start. Without subjecting any Western country to large financial risk, it would give East European reform a modest but vital boost.

HEADLINE: A Lok at the Session: What Congress Accomplished

 BODY:
ECONOMIC POLICY Budget: Enacted a $14.7 billion deficit reduction plan that relies heavily on automatic spending cuts and measures viewed as accounting gimmicks to achieve the reduction. Plan also includes a 9-month extension of expiring tax breaks.
Savings and Loan: Approved a $159 billion bailout over the next 10 years to shut down and sell off more than 700 savings and loan institutions and reconfigure Federal regulation of the industry centralizing power with the F.D.I.C. and the Treasury Department.
Minimum Wage: Raised the minimum wage to $3.80 an hour next year and to $4.25 an hour in 1991, the first increases since 1981. 
Section 89: Repealed a provision of the 1986 tax law the prohibits discrimination against low-wage workers in employer-sponsored health benefit plans because the provision was considered too complex and burdensome to administer.
 
DEFENSE AND FOREIGN POLICY
Nicaragua: Under a bipartisan agreement with the President, appropriated $49.7 million to provide food, clothing, shelter and medical supplies to the contras through February 1990. To get Democratic support for the package, the Administration agreed that no aid may be disbursed after Nov. 30, 1989, unless key Congressional leaders and committees give their consent. Congress also provided $9 million to help opposition parties in the election next February and to support international observers.
Poland and Hungary: Approved a $938 million package of aid over the next three years to Poland and Hungary, twice what President Bush requested. More than 90% of the aid is directed to Poland.
Military Spending: Passed a $286 billion military spending bill that contains the first budget reduction in the ''Star Wars'' missile defense plan and a cutback in the stealth bomber program.
 
SOCIAL POLICY
Abortion: In both the House and Senate, mustered enough votes to provide Federal financing for abortions for victims of rape and incest, money for a United Nations fund for family planning activities, and to allow the District of Columbia to spend its own money for abortions. But the two chambers were unable to override Presidential vetoes of their actions.
Catastrophic Cost of Illness: Yielded to the complaints of many older Americans and voted to repeal a far-reaching Medicare expansion designed to protect retirees against being bankrupted by a catastrophic illness. Originally signed into law just 16 months ago.
Disaster Assistance: Approved a $4.15 billion relief package to finance earthquake recovery efforts in Northern California and help the victims of Hurricane Hugo.
Medicare Payments: Overhauled the physician reimbursement system under the Medicare program. Specialists like surgeons and radiologists to be paid about 20 percent less by the government than they are now, while general practitioners to be paid about 40 percent more.
Child Care: Failed to pass landmark child care bill because of jurisdictional and philosophical disputes, but leadership committed to moving quickly next year.
Drugs: Approved $8.8 billion for anti-drug law enforcement and drug abuse prevention and treatment programs in fiscal year 1990. Totasl represents increases of $900 million over the amount requested by President Bush and $3.2 billion over the fiscal year 1989 level.
 
MISCELLANEOUS
Lobbying: Prohibited Federal contractors and Federal grant recipients from using any Federal money to lobby Congress or executive branch officials.
Airline Smoking: Banned smoking on all flights in the continental United States and all other domestic flights of six hours or less.
Oil Spill Liability: House passed legislation that consolidates Federal oil spill liability laws, raises the limit on liability for those responsible for oil spills, and provides for a $1 billion Federal trust fund to cover cleanup costs and damages not paid for by private parties. Senate passed similar legislation. Conference expected early in 1990.
Offshore Oil: Passed legislation continuing and expanding moratoriums on oil and gas leasing in specified areas off the coasts of California, Florida, Massachusetts, the mid-Atlantic states and Alaska.
Arts: Agreed to restrict Federal money for art defined as obscene by a 1973 Supreme Court decision. But to be restricted, such artworks must lack ''serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value.''
Pay and Ethics: House approved a plan to raise salaries of House members, Federal judges and top government employees by at least a third by 1991 and tighten the lawmaker's ethical rules. Senators chose smaller pay increase for themselves, but retained, at least for now, their outside speaking fees, which would be banned in the House.
Flag Protection: Passed a bill that makes it a crime punishable by a fine and imprisonment of up to one year for a person to knowingly mutilate, deface, burn or physically defile any United States flag.

HEADLINE: Organic Farms: Agriwisdom

BYLINE: By Richard Rhodes; Richard Rhodes is the author of ''Farm.''

DATELINE: Cambridge, Mass.

 BODY:
At a time when we celebrate the bounty of our farms, we might give thought to farmers.
 
My friend Tom
Bauer, who farms 1,000 acres of deep prairie loam out in central Missouri, east of Kansas City, applies nitrate fertilizer and chemical herbicides to his grain and soybean fields before he plants them. Although he hasn't used pesticides for 10 years, many of his neighbors do. ''The label said to burn my work clothes afterward,'' Tom told me recently, ''and I just decided I didn't want to be around anything that deadly.'' 
Such practices alarm city people, who worry about contamination of their water supply and toxic residues in their food.
In fairness, we ought to place the blame for chemically intensive agriculture where it belongs: in Washington, with the politics of farm subsidies. The National Research Council concluded in a recent report that changing Federal programs to encourage farmers to farm more organically would be better husbandry for all of us in the long term, improving the quality of the nation's soil and water and protecting the purity of its food supply.
Neither Congress nor the Bush Administration has rushed to implement the council's recommendations. Doing so would shift farming away from dependence on chemicals and artificial fertilizer, profitable inputs that large agribusiness corporations - chemical, grain and oil companies - supply.
The farmers I know are just as concerned with their health and their stewardship of the land as the rest of us. They'd like to work toward a more renewable agriculture. But agribusiness is collectively the largest industry in America, with corresponding political clout, while there are fewer than five million Americans left living on farms.
When I was a boy, living on a farm outside Independence, Mo., studying vocational agriculture in high school, I wondered why farm subsidies were based on limiting the number of acres a farmer could plant. Aggressive technological innovation was on the horizon in the early 1950's. My classmates and I were taught to admire the ingenious new chemical technologies whereby a farmer could boost his per-acre yields.
If old-fashioned Farmer Jones managed to grow 100 bushels of corn per acre by traditional methods, we learned, Farmer Smith down the road, alert to technology, could push his yield on similar land to 150 or even 200 bushels by pouring on the chemical fertilizer, by planting his corn rows closer together - so close that he couldn't cultivate by machine any more but had to apply herbicides to keep down weeds - and by using pesticides to eliminate bugs that thrived in his crowded fields.
It was obvious even to a 15-year-old that these acreage controls encouraged intensive farming practices that weren't necessarily good for the land in the long run, nor did they reduce surpluses. If we really wanted to limit surpluses, it seemed to me, we ought to limit not the number of acres a farmer could plant but the number of bushels he could sell at supported prices.
I understood that the farm subsidy program was illogical, but I was too innocent of politics to understand why. The reason why is encapsulated in an unkind saying that came into vogue a few years ago among organic-farming advocates: ''A farmer is someone who launders money for a chemical company.'' In fairness to the Tom Bauers of America, I would add that the farmer does so under economic compulsion. Sally Bauer's accounting books illustrate the point.
The Bauers grossed $152,090 in 1986, a typical recent year. Their largest single expense was feed for their cattle and hogs. But fertilizer and chemicals took second place at $22,345. Add $17,910 more for machinery repair and fuel, and the Bauers' purchases from agribusiness are the biggest overall expenditure.
In exchange for idling about 10 percent of their land, they earned some $11,000 in Government subsidies. Agribusiness pocketed all of those dollars and $29,000 of their unsubsidized gross income besides. The Bauers cleared only about $19,000 for their year's labor.
Government programs skew farming in another direction as well. The No. 1 rule for any farmer who wants to survive economically in farming today is to keep up his crop base -never to plant less acreage to a given commodity that he planted in previous years, a number on which his subsidies are based. If he planted 100 acres of corn each year for the past three years and plants only 95 this year, then his subsidies will be correspondingly reduced. He is effectively penalized for growing less surplus than he has grown in the past.
On the other hand, one of the best was to reduce pest infestations and to prevent depletion of soil nutrients is to rotate crops - to plant a field in different crops from year to year, renewing the land biologically rather than chemically.
Conservation-minded farmers like Tom Bauer recognize the benefits of crop rotation: Tom applies the practice to keep pests down without pesticides. But they understandably draw the line at encroaching on their crop base; rationally enough, they put economic survival ahead of conservation practices. Conservation correspondingly suffers. Many farmers with robust crop bases have given up crop rotation entirely.
If the independent farmer were on his way to extinction, then furthering the industrialization of farming with Federal subsidies to agribusiness might make sense. In fact, the 1980 census discovered only 7,140 corporate farms in the United States, only a small fraction of the nation's total. The rural depression of the Reagan years drove hundreds of thousands of farmers out of business, and about one-fourth of those left are in serious trouble today. But the more numerous three-fourths are finding themselves in better shape than they have been for a decade, with a better debt-to-asset ratio than most industries.
A Federal farm program directed toward sustainable agriculture would limit production of surpluses, encourage soil and water conservation and begin moving farming toward less dependence on chemicals and more reliance on crop rotation, mechanical cultivation and biological controls. Such a program would help farmers make a living, as current programs do. But because a larger share of transfer payments would end up in farmers' pockets, it would cost less.
Subsidizing agribusiness makes little sense, especially when farmers have had to take the rap for the damage to natural resources that such subsidy promotes. Competitively, agriculture is one of the last world-class industries left in America. Tom Bauer and his neighbors will keep it that way organically if we let them.
