HEADLINE: THE TALK OF FIFTH AVENUE;
Altman's Last Sale: Every Memory Must Go

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY

 BODY:
In the early morning yesterday, when most of Fifth Avenue was still largely deserted - the steel vault doors in front of Tiffany & Company still tightly shut, a lone man shoveling snow in front of Cartier's - a crowd had already gathered in front of B. Altman & Company.
Clapping their hands against the cold, stepping over patches of ice and pressed close together behind police barricades, shoppers said they had come in hope of a bargain. But many more said they had come to witness the end of one of their favorite stores.
Pamela Gordon, hugging her mink coat around her, said she had come from Savannah, Ga., to buy something, though nothing in particular, just because the 124-year-old department store was closing. 
''This is nostalgia,'' Mrs. Gordon said. ''I got an account here right after the war in 1946, and I thought it was the most exciting, incredible store. I just wanted to be here.''
By noon, Fifth Avenue was up to speed, the going-out-of-business sale at Altman's only part of the bustle on the day after Thanksgiving, the traditional opening of the Christmas-shopping season. Everywhere tourists peered at luxurious window displays and tired, hungry children demanded to be carried.
But this year, perhaps more than any other since the recession of 1974, the season's success is uncertain.
In recent months, several department stores have been put up for sale, including Bloomingdale's, Saks Fifth Avenue and Bonwit Teller. Analysts and retailers say the chaos in retailing could upset consumers' patterns, sending some searching for new places to shop and causing others to cut back on spending.
B. Altman & Company will close because after a month on the auction block it was unable to attract any acceptable bidders. Last week, a bankruptcy court decided that six of its seven stores, including its flagship at Fifth Avenue and 34th Street, would be shut down after the sale that began yesterday and is scheduled to last through Jan. 29.
When the building's richly paneled doors opened at 10 A.M., the hundreds of people who had stood waiting for more than an hour let out a mild cheer. Then they poured inside in such numbers that the escalators and elevators overloaded and stopped working.
Pools of people gathered in front of them, and the ground level became so congested that some customers waited as long as 20 minutes to move, pressed chest to chest with strangers.
Facing such a crush, many turned and left only minutes after entering, including Susan Pezzella and her daughter, Tara King, who said they would try Macy's instead.
''It's a zoo in there,'' said Mrs. Pezzella, who lives in Queens. ''And 20 percent off is no bargain.''
Others braved the onslaught and came out with a look of victory on their faces.
''I have my goodies,'' said Tamara Smith of Manhattan, who bought fruit cakes and nuts as presents for her relatives. ''I'm happy.''
Eventually the fire department deemed the store overcrowded, and security guards held the crowds back at the front door. They waited for 50 people to leave before allowing another 50 in.
Inside the store, some display cases were empty. But the essential lushness - the glitter of the crystal chandeliers, the wide carpeted aisles - remained intact.
Some who shopped yesterday talked of the end of era.
''This was one of the few stores left where they were polite to you,'' said Robbie Bullen, a retired teacher from Manhattan, who said that most everything she was wearing had been bought at Altman's.
 
Winds and Windows
While the windows of B. Altman bore red and white ''Everything Must Go'' signs, the ornate mechanical Christmas displays could be seen at the Lord & Taylor department store at Fifth and 37th.
As in past years, part of the sidewalk was roped off to allow for the orderly passage of people lined up to march by the windows.
But the weather, which offered frigid winds, seemed to be particularly vengeful toward the crowd.
The sun melted the snow on the store's evergreen awnings, so most viewers, forced to file under them, were treated to gusty winds and a shower of icy droplets.
For many, this meant rearranging hats, pulling up scarves and hunching shoulders.
But 5-year-old Tria Chang took a more original route. She walked through with a folded vest on top of her head and a pretzel in her mouth.
''She is mesmerized,'' her father, Eddie Chang, said. ''It doesn't bother her at all.''
 
March of the Minks
Passing by some of the world's finest fur coats on display both in and out of the stores, hundreds of animal-rights advocates marched down Fifth Avenue from 59th to 24th Street.
Led by Bob Barker, the host of the game show ''The Price is Right,'' they chanted slogans like ''Warm hearts don't wear fur.''
Occasionally a surprised pedestrian wearing a fur coat would be surrounded by the demonstrators shouting, ''Shame, shame, shame.''
Martha Brinkman, who was in a white mink, politely took the leaflet the demonstrators handed her and tried to go about her business.
''Where do you draw the line?'' she asked. ''We wear leather shoes, eat meat. I wear the coat because it's warm.''
But other fur coat wearers were angered by the confrontations. One woman, in a brown fur, chanted back: ''Give back your lamb chops. If I had any more money, I'd buy another coat.''
Animal-rights advocates also demonstrated in dozens of other cities including Harrisburg, Pa., Corpus Christi, Tex., and Syracuse. End of Carriage Trade? At Rockefeller Center, from 48th to 51st Streets, the horse-drawn carriages did a brisk business, charging about $20 for a half-hour ride around midtown.
A new law, passed recently by the City Council, could make this the last season for the rides through the streets. The law, which the carriage industry has said it intends to challenge in court, would restrict the carriages to Central Park while raising fares.
Many carriage customers were treated to an earful of complaints by the drivers and became converts.
''I think this thing is a bummer,'' Clair Simpson Schroeder from Westchester said of the law. ''These rides are a part of New York's tradition. It's not fair.'' ''We will fight them to the end,'' said Basil Northam, the driver of her carriage. ''These animal-lover types don't understand at all. Horses work much harder on a farm. Look at my horse. He's fat.''

HEADLINE: 2 Say Company Failed to Recall Crib-Death Monitors Suspected as Faulty

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Two former employees say a com pany that makes devices intended to prevent crib deaths failed to recall units it suspected were faulty.
The former employees, Neal F. Nordling and Theodore F. Nash, said in separate interviews that they were not aware of any deaths or injuries as a result, and the company, Aequitron Medical Inc., says the machines are safe.
Their comments come as Federal investigators seek to determine whether Aequitron told the Federal Food and Drug Administration of all reports of infant deaths that might be linked to the monitors.
Mr. Nordling and Mr. Nash said Aequitron, based in Plymouth, Minn., learned in 1983 that some infant monitors might fail in high humidity. The company makes monitors for babies susceptible to apnea, a sudden stoppage of breath. 
The former employees said the company issued no warnings, made no recalls and fixed only those machines that were sent in for repairs or service.
 
Official Denies Allegations
But David B. Morse, an Aequitron director, disputed their accounts and said the machines in question were safe. He described the two men as disgruntled former employees.
Mr. Nordling and Mr. Nash said they had not spoken out before because they had only recently become aware of allegations that faulty Aequitron monitors were linked to infant deaths.
Mr. Nordling and Mr. Nash left Aequitron separately, Mr. Nordling in 1986, and Mr. Nash last year. Both have been involved in disputes with Aequitron, Mr. Nash in a challenge over unemployment benefits and Mr. Nordling in a lawsuit over trade secrets.
Mr. Nordling and Mr. Nash were among a number of former Aequitron employees, interviewed by telephone in a recent days, who painted a picture of a company that worked hard to develop high-technology machines. But Mr. Nordling and Mr. Nash said Aequitron was at times slow to acknowledge equipment problems.
 
Use by 150,000 Infants
Last year, for example, Mr. Nash said, Aequitron employees removed from view certain problem monitors that were undergoing repairs so F.D.A. inspectors would not see them. Mr. Morse, the company official, said he could not comment because he had no knowledge of any such incident.
The Aequitron apnea monitor is intended to set off an alarm when an infant's heartbeat or respiratory rate becomes erratic. Although most infants with apnea revive when awakened or shaken, a few require mouth-to-mouth resuscitation. Aequitron officials say about 150,000 infants have been monitored successfully by company units.
Parents and others have asserted that 24 children died because Aequitron home monitor alarms failed to sound, company officials said. Aequitron officials dismiss those allegations and assert that the machines involved worked when tested. Also, several medical experts said that a child's being on a monitor that sounds an alarm is no guarantee that the child will survive an attack.
Mr. Nordling and Mr. Nash said Aequitron became aware of problems with its model 8200 monitor in early 1983, soon after the device was first marketed. Although the machines first appeared to operate normally, Mr. Nordling said, researchers discovered after several weeks that high room humidity caused some monitors to malfunction.
 
Lack of Plastic Coating
Mr. Nordling, a former Aequitron research and development manager, said the reason for the problem was that the circuit boards of early model 8200 machines did not have a protective plastic coating. As a result, he said, electrical problems could develop within the machine so it might give normal readings, even when a child was in distress. Mr. Nordling said Aequitron routinely corrected the problem in all machines sent in for repair or service. But he said the problem was not corrected in many machines because the company did not notify owners or users of the situation. He estimated that several hundred machines might have been affected.
Mr. Nordling and Mr. Nash, a former manufacturing engineer, said they knew of no death or serious injuries related to the monitor problem.
Mr. Morse, the Aequitron director, said that the machines were safe and that there was never any direct proof that high humidity affected the devices. He also said that none of deaths allegedly involving Aequitron devices occurred under conditions involving high humidity. But he acknowledged that in mid-1983, Aequitron, at Mr. Nordling's suggestion, began coating circuit boards. Mr. Morse said Aequitron officials believed that a recall of the affected units was unnecessary. ''We had no evidence that indicated it was a significant hazard to anyone,'' he said.
Mr. Morse said Mr. Nash was unhappy with Aequitron because the company had unsuccessfully challenged his request for unemployment benefits.
Mr. Nordling resigned from Aequitron in early 1986 to start his own company, Nonin Medical Inc., also based in Plymouth, Minn. In late 1987, Aequitron filed suit against Nonin accusing it, Mr. Nordling and three other former Aequitron engineers of misappropriating trade secrets. Mr. Nordling said he and his associates denied the allegations.

LENGTH: 1212 words

HEADLINE: Arts Complexes Are Thriving in Their Maturity in the East and West;
Los Angeles Music Center, at 25, Is the Cities Cultural Hub

BYLINE: By ALJEAN HARMETZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24

 BODY:
The birth of the Los Angeles Music Center 25 years ago is being celebrated with fanfares and flourishes this fall.Three months of celebration will culminate on Dec. 6, the exact anniversary date, with 25 high school bands and an audience of 5,000 singing ''Happy Birthday.''
When the center opened in 1964 -built at the considerable cost of $34 million - it was seen as a bold attempt to revitalize a decaying downtown and to breathe artistic life into a city that didn't seem to have any.
There is little doubt that the Music Center has fulfilled its role as the cultural hub of Los Angeles. Six companies now call the center home: the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the Joffrey Ballet L.A./N.Y., the Los Angeles Master Chorale, the Center Theater Group/Mark Taper Forum, the Center Theater Group/Ahmanson and the Los Angeles Music Center Opera. 
The center's three auditoriums -the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion, the Ahmanson and the Mark Taper Forum - have a combined annual operating budget of $80 million. Approximately two million people attend performances every year at the center, while another two million attend programs presented as far away as Palm Springs by the orchestra, the opera and the theaters.
 
The City Sprawled Away
Yet in 1964, it was considered a dangerous gamble to build three theaters downtown on seven acres of Bunker Hill. Physically, the city had long since sprawled away from downtown, with the richest suburbs a dozen miles to the west.
''The whole place was such a cultural wasteland when my husband and I came here in 1958 that we said we would stay a maximum of three years,'' said Claire Segal, director of public affairs for the Music Center from 1979 to 1987.
The mandate of the Music Center was to create a showcase for the serious arts that would give the city cultural credibility.
''It's certainly the center of establishment music in Los Angeles,'' said Robert Winter, professor of music at the University of California at Los Angeles. ''The Los Angeles Philharmonic is our one world-class orchestra, and it's one of the more adventurous major orchestras in the country.''
''But in a curious way, the music center doesn't have a lot of flavor or character,'' Mr. Winter continued. ''There's a lack of real identity. The Master Chorale hasn't dominated the choral scene. The Ambassador series in Pasadena does a better job of bringing major visiting groups here. In a city as sprawling as Los Angeles, however, it's probably not fair to expect any one site to dominate the musical scene.''
 
Opera Is in Fourth Season
The Philharmonic is indeed counted among the nation's major orchestras. The opera, the center's youngest venture, opened its fourth season in promising fashion in September with Placido Domingo conducting a well-received production of ''Tosca,'' which starred Maria Ewing.
For serious theatergoers, the Mark Taper Forum, under the direction of Gordon Davidson, was for years the only game in town. If the Taper has received mixed reviews in recent seasons, it nevertheless paved the way for other serious theaters, including the Los Angeles Theater Center, the South Coast Repertory, the revitalized Old Globe in San Diego and the La Jolla Playhouse.
In contrast, the Ahmanson has struggled for credibility. An awkward theater with bad acoustics, it has gone through many changes of management. The Ahmanson, which has been inhabited by ''Phantom of the Opera'' since May 31 and probably will be until the spring of 1991, is presenting its 1989-90 subscription season at the Dolittle Theater in Hollywood. It led with ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?,'' starring Glenda Jackson and John Lithgow.
 
Economic Stimulus
If the center has helped rid the city of its ''cultural wasteland'' label, its effect on the downtown area it overlooks is more complex.
Financially, it has helped stimulate economic development. According to Esther Wachtell, the center's chief operating officer, the value of the original seven acres of land was $2 million. A parcel of the same size donated to the center two years ago by Los Angeles County was valued at $50 million.
The center's stately hilltop plaza, adorned with a dancing fountain surrounding a Lipschitz sculpture, is isolated from the city below. But the center's presence has encouraged the establishment downtown of the Museum of Contemporary Art, the Temporary Contemporary, the Children's Museum, and the Los Angeles Theater Center.
''When the Music Center was put up, there was very little significant nighttime activity downtown,'' said Richard Sherwood, past president of the Center Theater Group and current chairman of its executive committee. ''It's still not necessarily a place you want to be wandering on foot outside of the cultural centers, but the restaurant business is now quite lively.''
 
A Business Attraction
Mr. Sherwood, a partner in O'Melveny & Myers, one of the oldest and largest law firms in the city, believes the center ''attracts businesses to Los Angeles, a place that is seen to have major theater, major music and major art.''
Speaking of the opera's decision to start with opulent, expensive productions, Mrs. Wachtell said: ''We can't sell anything to Los Angeles audiences unless it's world class. That's the only way to succeed here. And then you work out the financial picture.''
The Music Center was the creation of one woman, Dorothy (Buffy) Chandler, who used her social and political influence as the wife of the publisher of The Los Angeles Times and her considerable powers of persuasion to raise $20 million and to talk Los Angeles County into putting up $14 million.
Anybody's money was welcome, and her true value, says a promotional book published by the Music Center on its 10th anniversay, was her ability to size up donors for what they could afford to give, not what they wanted to give. In the book, Mrs. Chandler is quoted as saying that she went after ''new money, the Hollywood group, new leaders in aerospace and oil and savings and loans and a substantial Jewish community.'' Previously, culture had been considered the province of WASP families from Pasadena and Hancock Park.
 
New Hall for the Philharmonic
What will the next 25 years bring? Lillian Disney, the widow of Walt Disney, gave $50 million in 1987 for construction of a concert hall across the street. The Philharmonic will move to the new hall in 1994, leaving the Chandler Pavilion to opera and dance.
The center is trying to broaden its appeal to the city's changing population. For several years the Mark Taper has done one or two pieces of nontraditional programming annually. A recent example was ''Sansei,'' a play about third-generation Japanese Americans, created by the rock band Hiroshima and financed by an Asian volunteer group.
Mrs. Wachtell sees the opening of Walt Disney Hall as an opportunity for the center to bring such attractions as Grand Kabuki and Hispanic cultural offerings to the Chandler Pavilion.
''We are probably already the largest multi-cultural community in the United States,'' Mrs. Wachtell said. ''Approximately 86 languages are spoken in Los Angeles schools. We will have to bring diverse populations into the Music Center artistically and on our boards of directors.''

GRAPHIC: The Los Angeles Music Center is observing its 25th anniversay with a three-month celebration. (The New York Times/Bart Bartholomew); Map of downtown los Angeles showing location of the Los Angeles Music Center

PERSON: HARMETZ, ALJEAN
